title: Construction Value Up in May Despite Decline in Housing
description: The value of building contracts during May was the highest for the year despite a substantial decline in the construction of housing units, the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill Information Systems Company, reported yesterday.

title: Jazz Events
description: Today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival  New York:

title: U.S. Says Evidence On Cigarette. Link To Cancer Is Rising
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) The Government says that more evidence is being, compiled to show that cigarette smoking is the major cause of lung cancer, which killed 72,000 Americans last year.

title: TerrorStricken Throng Rushes for Narrow Stairway to Exit
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 30Suffocating smoke from a flash fire trapped and killed 24 panicstricken young patrons and employes of a singles bar astride the New YorkConnecticut border early today.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: Major League Box Scores and Standings

title: Peron's Condition Said to Show a Favorable Change
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 30The physicians atending Juan Domingo Perlin said tonight that the Argentine President's condition had undergone a favorable change but that he remained under constant medical treatment.

title: Prices And Politics
description: LONDONA harriedlooking woman pushed a ticket under the window of the change booth in the Notting Hill Gate underground station. May I return it, please? she asked politely: I have waited 45 minutes for a train and I cannot wait any longer. She was given her money back.

title: Film and TV Producers Reach Accord With Actors
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) A threatened strike by 29,000 members of the Screen Actors Guild was averted when the union and motion picture and television producers agreed on a new threeyear contract, an industry spokesmen said yesterday. Wage increases and higher compensations for reruns were included in the pact, which also covers members of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists involved in primetime dramatic programs. The contract was reached late Friday night.

title: Labor at Odds on Governorship Race, With Unions Supporting 3 Contenders
description: Organized labor's position in this year's gubernatorial contest is a little more scrambled than usual.

title: East Side Story: Romeo and. Juliet In the Third Rome
description: Most highlythroning Orthodox czar, lord of all: Moscow, the third Rome, shines like the sun in its Orthodox faith throughout the whole universe Two Romes have fallen [Rome and Constantinople], the third stands fast, a fourth there shall not be.

title: Easy Approval Expected For Newark Police Head
description: NEWARK, June 30Hubert Williams, the police lieutenant and lawyer nominated by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson last week, to become the city's second black police director, is expected to receive the Municipal Council's approval this week with relative ease.

title: LIVELY PUCK DANCED BY FROHLICH IN BOW
description: Casually setting off for a frenzied season in Saratoga Springs, N. Y., the New York City Ballet devised a goingaway bouquet of cast changes in its final full length Midsummer Night's Dream during the weekend at the New York State Theater.

title: Socialists Hear a Warning Against Selfish Oil Steps
description: CHEQUERS, England, June 30 (UPI)  Prime Minister Harold Wilson said today that countries taking selfish individual action to meet the world petroleum crisis and soaring oil prices could bring the world to disaster.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: New Corporate Bonds

title: Critics Say Pension Bill, Now Near Passage, Has Been Diluted by BusinessLabor Coalition
description: WASHINGTON, June 30As Congress neared agreement last tweek on a program to set naional pension standards for millions of American workers, critics contended that a businesslabor lobbying coalition had diluted many meaningful changes from what had been hailed as a major social reform.

title: Books of The Times
description: FIELDS OF FORCE. Fischer and Spassky Reykjavik. By George Steiner. 86 pages. Illustrated with diagrams. Viking. $8.95.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Cafe Society, the Greenwich Village nightclub that opened in 1938 and, two years later, added a midtown branch on East 58th Street, was such an active and vital part of the jazz scene in New York in the nineteenforties that the Newport Jazz Festival's decision to devote an evening to a Salute to Cafe Society seemed both logical and provocative.

title: Bel Canto Opera Presents Stylish Paisiello 'Barbiere
description: The Bel Canto Opera, a small company tucked away in a little meeting halltheater just off Madison Avenue on 31st Street, has proved to have more resourcefulness, strength and staying power than its size would suggest. Nurtured by the Madison Avenue Baptist Church and guided artistically by Theodore Sieh, it has presented in the last few years a number of lesserknown operas with singers of quality and, on occasion, productions of considerable ingenuity and attractiveness.

title: TERROR INSPIRES A RUSH FOR EXIT
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., June 30Suffocating smoke from a flash fire trapped and killed 24 panicstricken young patrons and employes of a singles bar astride the New YorkConnecticut border early today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The sportive bottlenosed dolphin that moved into Mattawan Creek in Keyport on May 27 was apparently killed by rifle fire ad stabbing this weeked. The carcass of the ninefoot female was found floating in the creek at 11 A.M. yesterday, according to the New Jersey Marine Police.

title: DELAYS CHARGED IN NAZI INQUIRY
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee on immigration has accused the State Department of seriously impeding investigations of suspected Nazi war criminals and ignoring the Justice Department's requests for cooperation.

title: Cost Climb Upsets CarPricing System
description: DETROIT, June 30A big jump in the price of raw materials from which most of the 15,000 parts of a car are made has been the major factor in pushing up prices of 1974 models by $300 to $400.

title: Sohio Gasoline Price: Cut 2 Cents a Gallon
description: CLEVELAND, June 30 (UPI) The Standard Oil Compa nies of Ohio announced today a reduction of 2 cents a gallon in gasoline prices, effective Monday.

title: t Cards Win, 52, and 53 in 10 After Disputed Call
description: It was a particularly sad afternoon for the Mets faithful in the crowd of 40,009 at Shea Stadium yesterday as New York dropped a doubleheader to the highflying St. Louis Cardinals and Tug McGraw, in relief, yielded home runs in each of the two games.

title: Harry B. Nason, Newsman, Was Post Managing Editor
description: SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., June 30 (AP)Harry B. Nason, former managing editor of The New York Post, died Friday of cancer in Will Rogers Memorial Hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Those Who Escaped Tell Of Panic. Death and Luck
description: For those who survived the fire in Port Chester early yesterday, there will always be the memories of those minutes of fear, of the wonder that they escaped and of the 24 others who died in the flames and smoke.

title: Laser Pioneer Gets Eye Post
description: Dr. Charles J. Campbell, pioneer in the application of lasers in the treatment of retinal disease, has been named chairman of the department of ophthalmology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, and chief of, ophthalmology service at the Presbyterian Hospital.

title: Secret Negotiations on Gas Stalled in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 Secret naturalgas negotiations between Senators and the Administration have stalled and both sides reluctantly acknowledge that there is little chance Congress will enact a naturalgas bill this year.

title: Nina Simone Sings
description: The response of large parts of the Newport Jazz Festival audience to Nina Simone Saturday night at Avery Fisher Hall might best be described as adorational. One hopes that, the love was meant for her whole person, her lifelong accomplishments and her priestesslike stature as a symbol of black womanhood For throughout the concert, she was treading rather erratically along the line that separates personal artistry from selfindulgence, and often as not she wobbled over that line.

title: Amid Detente, Soviet Military Expansion
description: Since 1972, in a period of detente to many in the United States and Western Europe, there has been a methodical improvement and expansion of nuclear and conventional military power in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. At the same time a barrage of official speeches and writings have warned the Soviet people that despite the agreements on limiting strategic arms and despite SovietAmerican exchanges such as President Nixon's visit to Moscow, the struggle against capitalism continues.

title: N.F.L. Players Strike
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI)  National Football League players went on strike at midnight tonight with the slogan. No freedom, no football.

title: CarParking Rates Are Raised At Three Metropolitan Airports
description: Along with the price of airline tickets, the cost of parking has risen at metropolitan jetports this summer.

title: FLORIDA WILL TRY TO RESCUE PALMS
description: MIAMI, June 30An effort to save Florida's coconut palms will be started in July with the use of an antibiotic that may arrest the spread of the tree disease called lethal yellowing.

title: A Parade Closes Gay Pride Week
description: Gay Pride Week ended yesterday amid predictions that more and more homosexuals would soon be coming out of the closet.

title: ROCKET LAUNCHINGS CALLED A SUCCESS
description: WALLOP ISLAND, Va., (AP) June 30Scientists said here today that their launching of 54 research missiles in 24 hours to test the upper atmosphere had been a success.

title: THE CHIEF AWARDS
description: THE CHIEF AWARDS

title: Bazaar Gives East Side An Exotic Appearance
description: A part of the East Side turned Eastern yesterday with a street bazaar featuring the exotic ways and wares of the Near East and Par East, such as couscous, rugs, storytellers, fireeaters and bellydancers.

title: Mother of Dr. King Is Killed in Church; Atlanta Deacon Slain
description: ATLANTA, June 30  Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., the 69yearold mother of the slain civil rights leader, was fatally wounded this morning when a young black man went on a shooting spree while she was playing the organ in Atlanta's famed Ebenezer Baptist Church.

title: AUSTRALIAN DOCTOR IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: A 37yearold doctor from Australia, was fatally shot last night during an apparent holdup in the Riveria Hotel in Jamaica, Queens, the police reported. Three other persons, including a bellhop, were robbed.

title: Deaths
description: In Memoriam

title: Playing in the City: Still the Old Games
description: Thad heard all this business of the games not being played anymore; I had heard that city kids today just sit and stare blankly, or get into massive trouble, said James Wagenvoord.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Ethiopian Military Seizes Aides of Previous Cabinet;
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 30 (AP)The Ethiopian armed forces said today that they had been arresting officials of the previous Government for conspiring to obstruct the fourmonthold administration of Premier. Endalkachew Makonnen.

title: Weather: The Month of July
description: Weather: The Month of July

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: Weekly List of Mutual Funds

title: COMMUTERS FACE TIEUPS ON BUSES
description: Strikes were threatening to halt two Bronx bus lines this morning, while Nassau County commuters were warned that they, too, could expect disruptions of bus services because of a labor dispute.

title: Polo Results
description: AIKEN (7)

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: John A. Moore of Lakeview, L. I., was arraigned on charges of murder, arson, burglary and robbery in connection with the beating and burning death of Mrs. Hanna Hansen, the 74yearold woman whose body was discovered June 15 by firemen responding to a fire in her Lakeview home.

title: PAST REPUTATION OF VILLAGE CITED
description: To generations growing up in the affluent gold coast of Connecticut's Fairfield County, Pori Chester, N.Y., an unasaliming, rather grim manufacbiting village, symbolized sin City just across the border. Until Connecticut lowered its legal drinking age from 21 to 18 in October, 1971, Port Chester's 50odd bars were Magnets for swarms of noisy, neerdrinking teenagers  old enough to drive but not to drink in their more Sedate native towns.

title: JULIUS H. BERMAN
description: Julius H. Berman, a retired restaurateur who had formerly helped operate the Claremont Inn on Riverside Drive, the Merry England restaurants at the New York World's Fair in 193940 and the TavernontheGreen in Central Park, died Thursday on a visit to Gettysburg, Pa, He was 83 years old and lived at 181 East 73rd Street.

title: Ghosts of Yalta
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 30Eager to haunt the latest example of dacha diplomacy, three ghosts of a previous summit gathered to discuss Yalta Two. The ghosts took the form of a pipe, a cigarette jauntily angled in a long holder, and a cigar.

title: Cup Soccer Scores
description: World Cup soccer scores will be reported daily in the sports section. Please do not telephone The New York Times for results. Lufthansa Airlines will provide all scores at 2123578400 in New York, 5164893930 on. Long Island, 8006453860 in New Jersey. In other areas, call the tollfree Lufthansa reservations number listed in the telephone directory.

title: U.S. AID FOR THE AGED IS CHANGING TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) More than 32 million Social Security and adult welfare recipients will be getting higher Federal checks in July, but many also will be billed more for their medical care.

title: Nightclub Fires Prove To Be Chronic Killer
description: Here is a history of earlier disastrous fires in nightclubs and theaters that have taken hundreds of lives in this country and abroad:

title: Rutherford Takes 500 for 3d in Row
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 30 Johnny Rutherford, who is becoming a sort of Secretariat of auto racing, won his third consecutive United States Auto Club race today, a 500mile cliffhanger that was not settled until the closing minutes with only 30 miles left to go.

title: SINGER AND DANCER TEAM AS FOLK DUO
description: Sally Bowden and Roy Berkeley are both lowkeyed, easy performers with a great deal of presence. On Saturday at the cavernous Blue Dome Reearsal Hall on the Bowery, she danced and he sang in a duet that showed how naturally they work together.

title: ICELAND LEFTISTS MAY LOSE 5 SEATS
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 30Iceland held a national election today, looking to formation of a new government, one of whose chief tasks will be to decide the future of the American base here.

title: Indians, Remodeled and Winning, Rout Red Sox, 92, as Arlin, Hendrick Star
description: The rebuilding job that has been going on in Cleveland for the last three American League seasons under Manager Ken Aspromonte is starting to get results. The Indians, who finished last in the Eastern Division by 26 games last season, are currently only 2 games behind the leaders, the Boston Red Sox.

title: REPORTS CONFLICT ON KILLER'S PAST
description: ATLANTA, June 30When the Rev. Martin Luther King Sr. confronted the young black man who had, only an hour or so before, shot the aging minister's wife to death, he reportedly asked the assailant why he had done it.

title: New Archbishop Prays for Peace as 7,000 Irish Hold Festival
description: HOLMDEL, June 30From the solemnity of a mass offered at noon for peace in northern Ireland to the presentation of Celtic rock music by the Casterbridge Union musical group, it was the day of the Irish today at the Garden State Arts Center.

title: CREDIT MARKETS CONTINUE SLUMP
description: Thickening gloom spread across the credit markets last week as interest rates continued to search for a ceiling, fueled by an uncommonly tight money supply situation. We are confused and demorCredit elized, one leadMarkets ing bond dealer declared last Friday. About the only bright spot is the fact that the calendar of new corporate issues is blank for next week because of the July 4th holiday.

title: Governor Leads Primary
description: AGANA, Guam, July 1, Monday (UPI)Gov. Carlos G. Camacho appeared to have won the Republican nomination for another term in the governorship primary over the weekend. He held a narrow lead over Senator Paul M. Calvo. Ricardo J. Bordello, who was defeated by Mr. Camacho in the 1970 race, held a decisive lead over three opponents in the Democratic governorship nomination.

title: Tax Rises Looming on Homes In Wake of State Court Ruling
description: A ruling by the State's highest court could bring higher tax bills for homeowners with relatively low assessments and a lesser burden on more severely taxed commercial and industrial property.

title: 300, Mostly Volunteers, Respond as Sirens Sound
description: Robert Mowbray, a 33yearold Port Chester volunteer fireman, struggled through smoke yesterday morning to rescue a man who lay face down on a stairway between the dance floor and the upperfloor bar of the fireravaged Gulliver's bar.

title: Midyear Finds Economy Stalled
description: A lowpaid black service worker in Chicago, mother of six, could not recall her union's name last week nor was she cheered by two 15cent hourly raises that the union had won her. It's worth nothing when they take out taxes, she scoffed. But there's nothing can do about it except keep on working and hope I don't get laid off like some of my friends.

title: Teachers March for Ousted Strikers
description: CHICAGO, June 30Marching six abreast, singing Solidarity Forever and bearing signs proclaiming Never Again, some 3,500 teachers from all 50 states paraded down Lake Shore Drive and into McCormick Place this afternoon to open the annual meeting of the National Education Association.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. (RadioWMCA, 8 P.M.)

title: Creativity and Copyright
description: The revolution in communications in the last decade requires Congress to bring the Copyright Act of 1909 into the 1970's. Technological advances in cable TV systems, Photocopying machines and Computers are ingenious; but this hardware cannot function without the socalled soft ware, a technicai term ironically standing for nothing less than the creative works of writers, editors, playwrights and composerS. Without the human spark, the machines would only draw blanks. ThiS ele mental idea is at the heart of the twelveyearold struggle for a fair copyright law.

title: WILLIAM P. REES
description: William Parker Rees, vice president in charge of radio for RKO General, Inc., died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 300 East 40th Street and Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Roseland Recalls Old Times Tonight
description: In 1916, when Louis J. Brecker was still a student at the University of Pennsylvania, he had a mind for business (he was at the Wharton School), he and his girlfriend Dorothy (later his wife) loved to dance, and he was convinced that Philadelphia wouldn't be such a sleepy place if it had a really nice ballroom.

title: Americans Mourn Mrs. King's Death
description: There was sadness and anger among Americans yesterday over the fatal shooting of Mrs. Alberta King, 69yearold mother of the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Major Bills In Congress
description: July 1, 1974

title: Judge's Home is Robbed; Police Hold 3 Suspects
description: Three men were arrested shortly after midnight today at the Brooklyn home of Lvdwig G. Glowa, chief administrative judge of the City Criminal Court, and charged with burglary, the police reported.

title: Cape May Protects Historic Mansions
description: CAPE MAY, June 27Cape May is taking strong steps to cement its claim as the country's premiere lateVictorian seashore town.

title: and New Budget
description: On taxes, the Administration is talking out of both sides of its mouth, and in the middle as well. The President's new economic czar, Kenneth Rush, says the Administration might want a tax increase to balance the fiscal 1975 budget. Chairman Stein of the C.E.A. says this is a possibility but not a probability. But Secretary of the Treasury Simon hints that the Adminisration might reduce its opposition to a personalincometax cut favored by some liberal Democratsprovided that the reduction were to be combined with tax incentives for business investment and provided that other, as yet unspecified, revenueraising measures were enacted.

title: Soviet Dancer in Canada Defects on Bolshoi Tour
description: OTTAWA, June 30Mikhail Barishnikov, a leading Soviet ballet dancer, fled from the touring. Bolshoi troupe in Toronto last night, apparently to continue dancing in the West.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Henri Pescarolo and Gerard Larousse of France, winners of the Le Mans 24hour auto race, won a 1,000kilometer event yesterday in Zeltweg, Austria. Their victory, at an average of 124.7 miles an hour, expanded the lead of MatraSimca in the world automobile manufacturers championship.

title: Midyear Finds Economy Stalled
description: A lowpaid black service worker in Chicago; mother of six, could not recall her union's name last week nor was she cheered by two 15cent hourly raises that the union had won her. It's worth nothing when they take out taxes, she scoffed. But there's nothing I can do about it except keep on working and hope I don't get laid off like some of my friends.

title: Consumer Notes Readable insurance Policies Sought
description: The fine print in insurance policies, theoretically designed to let consumers know what kind of protection they are entitled to, has traditionally been couched in a mumble of lawyer's Latinno legalistic letter I left undotted, no legalistic letter T uncrossed. The result is that intimidated policyholders are often unaware of their rights.

title: Conflict Over Protection of News Sources Enters New Phase Tomorrow in Farr Case in California
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30The conflict between the judicial process and the insistence of journalists who protect news sources enters a new phase Tuesday.

title: Deerhound Takes Best in Show And Makes History at Oneonta
description: ONEONTA, N. Y., June 30  In center field at Damaschke Baseball Park, where six years ago Amos Otis, the Kansas City Royal star, was snaring flies for the Oneonta Club in the New YorkPenn League, a Scottish deerhound snared the bestinshow honors today.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries

title: 2 JUDICIARY AIDES UNDER AN INQUIRY
description: Two Brooklyn law secretaries, one of them also the secretary of the Democratic County Committee, are under investigation for allegedly siphoning some $50,000 from the organization's funds for their own use, political sources said last night.

title: Peking Bids Party Heed Voice of People
description: PEKING, June 30 (Reuters)The Chinese Government has marked the 53d anniversary tomorrow of the founding of the Communist party with a call to the party to heed the voice of the people.

title: Kalmbach Said to Be Deeply Hurt by Nixon's Silence
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., June 30Herbert W. Kalmbach will go to prison tomorrow carrying what a friend described as a deep hurt over President Nixon's apparent displeasure because of Mr. Kalmach's decision to cooperate in the Government's prosecution of the Watergate conspiracy.

title: Women's Political Caucus Votes to Alter Membership Structure and Increase Dues Tenfold
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 30The National Women's Political Caucus, created three years ago with the goal of attaining more political power for women, voted today to change its basic membership structure and to increase its dues tenfold in an effort to build a more effective National organization.

title: Small Farms, Poor Distribution, Cause High Food Prices in Japan
description: TATEBAYASHI, Japan, June 27When Uhei Arai sold one of his black steers last week, he got $2.25 a pound, high by American standards though not enough to cover his costs.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Colonialism 11:30 A.M.

title: LITTLE GAIN SEEN ON WEAPONS PACT IN YALTA MEETING
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 30President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, talked for more than four hours today in the pleasant breezes of the Black Sea, but both sides suggested afterward that little progress had been made on the crucial issue under disct'ssionthe limitation of offensive nuclear weapons.

title: Town's Water. Forded After a Dockside Fire
description: STONINGTON, Conn., June 30 (AP)Some 16,000 residents were without drinking water after salt water contaminated the town's water system through fire equipMent used to battle a dockside fire early today.

title: A Heavy Sea Swamps Girl's Lifeguard Job
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 (AP)Gaye Kelly's chances of becoming this resort's first female lifeguard have been wiped out in a raging sea.

title: Dr. H. Harry Giles, 72, Dead; Led Human Relations at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. H. Harry Giles, a retired professor of education at New York University, who founded its Center for Human Relations Studies, died Saturday in a hospital in Fall River Mass. He was 72 years old and lived in nearby Westport, Mass.

title: Tevye and Family Take To Seashore for Summer
description: FIDDLER ON THE ROOF, a musical Book by Joseph Stein; music by Jerry Bock; lyrics by Sheldon Bernick; directa by John Fearnley; choreography by Robert Pagent; setting by John W. Keck; costumes by Winn Morton; lighting by Thomas Skelton; orchestrations be Don Walker; musical director, Jay Blackton; production supervised by Arreid Spector; production stage manager, Mortimer Halpern. Presented by Guy Lombardo. At the Jones Beach Theater, Wantagh, L. I.

title: Personal Finance: Summer Job Taxes
description: Many students and their parents face tax questions if the children take summer jobs. Depending on what he earns, the student probably will owe little or no tax, but there still is paperwork.

title: DR. HAROLD FOSTER
description: Dr. Harold Foster, director of otolaryngology at Parsons Hospital, Flushing, Queens, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 3415 Parsons Boulevard, Flushing. He was 76 years old.

title: Both King Sons Died in Their Thirties
description: It was just a little more than six years ago that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was assassinated in Memphis.

title: Radio
description: 67 A.M., WNYCFM. Polka and Fugue; Weinberger; Flute Concerto, Hoffmeister; Suite from The Red Poppy, Gliere.

title: HIGH ENERGY MUSIC AT SHAEFER FESTIVAL
description: High energy music was heard from both stage and audience Saturday at the Shaefer Music Festival. LaBelle started everything grooving, and Mandrill continued the momentum. It was also an evening that showed the directions in which black groups are moving.

title: Mother of Dr. King Is Killed in Church; Atlanta Deacon Slain
description: ATLANTA, June 30  Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., the 69yearold mother of the slain civil rights leader, was fatally wounded this morning when a young black man went on a shooting spree while she was playing the organ in Atlanta's famed Ebenezer Baptist Church.

title: Mrs. Meir Packs Up, Moves to Private Life
description: JERUSALEM, June 30 (UPI) Golda Meir, the former Premier, gave up the last trappings of office today when she moved out of the official residence. She left with a handful of clothes, giving a word of thanks to neighbor who always kept her phonograph turned down.

title: Postwar Israeli Aid Converted by Nixon Into Outright Grant
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) President Nixon today wrote $500million In debts owed by Israel for United States assistance replenishing her military establishment after the IsraeliArab war last October.

title: Angels Get Court Star
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 30 Mark Wulfmeyer, a high school basketball star, has signed a contract with the California Angels. Wulfmeyer, a righthanded pitcher who had previously announced he would attend the University of Southern California, will report to the Angels Idaho Falls farm club.

title: State Senate to Consider Plan For Ending School Disparities
description: TRENTON, June 30New Jersey's obligations for proviaing a thorough and efficient education for the state's children will be the primary subject of discussion by the state Senate when it convenes here in a working session tomorrow.

title: LOWENSTEIN ENDS RACE FOR SENATE
description: Citing the costs of a campaign, the need for party unity, and an unseemly wrangle over ethnic ticketbalancing, former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein withdrew yesterday from the Democratic primary for the United States Senate nomination.

title: Pamela J. Watt W. P. McBride Marry in Jersey
description: In the Presbyterian Church of Franklin Lakes, N. J., yesterday afternoon, Miss Pamela Jean Watt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Buell Watt of Franklin Lakes, became the bride of William Peter McBride. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Nevins McBride of Franklin Lakes, Quogue, L, I., and Sea Island, Ga.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: MRS. RAYMOND P. SLOAN
description: Mrs. Mabel MacArthur Sloan, wife of Raymond P. Sloan, an editor, publisher, author and lecturer on hospitals and public health and vice president of the Sloan Foundation, of which his late brother Alfred P. Sloan was the founder, died yesterday at their home, 19 East 72d Street. She was 87 years old.

title: Watson Rallies to Take Western Golf for His First Pro Victory
description: OAK BROOK, III., June 30 (AP)Tom Watson overcame a sixstroke deficit and scored his first professional victory today, sweeping past a struggling Tom Weiskopf to take the Western open golf tournament by two shots.

title: DEMOCRATS RAISE $7MILLIN ON TV
description: The Democratic party wrapped up a 21hour television fundraiser yesterday with songs, patriotic pleas and gibes at the Republicans. Nearly $7million in pledges were tallied.

title: DR. HAROLD B. ALDRICH
description: Dr. Harold B. Aldrich, a retired Manhattan oral surgeon, who established the dental clinic of the Boys Club of New York, died Friday in Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: Miss Hazen Breaks U.S. Swim Mark
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., June 30 (UPI)Karen Hazen, 16 years old, set an American record when she won the women's 1,500meter freestyle event at the Santa Clara international swimming meet today. Her time was 16 minutes 49.415 seconds.

title: Advertising: Watchful Waiting
description: It's a matter of watchful waiting the same as it was in Indonesia four or five years ago when it looked like that area could turn into another Japan or Brazil, but didn't.

title: SHOP TALK In an Old Livery Stable Contemporary Crafts
description: The work of close to 300 contemporary American craftsmen is readily available to residents of Greenwich, Conn., thanks to Kay Eddy, Betsy Beasley and Emily Toohey, owners of The Elements. Their crafts gallery and shop is in an old brick livery stable at 14R Lewis Street, just off Greenwich Avenue and adjacent to the municipal parking lot.

title: MOBUTU ADOPTING TITLE OF CITIZEN
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, June 30Zaire's governing political party announced last week that President Mobutu Sese Seko would no longer be referred to as His Excellency.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev conferred for more than four hours in Yalta, but both sides indicated afterward that little progress had been made on the critical issue of the limitation of offensive nuclear weapons. They will take a respite from their bargaining sessions today and will resume their meetings tomorrow and Wednesday in Moicow. American officials were hopeful that significant progress could still be made in the remaining two days. [1:5.]

title: E.I. Golf Captured By Murphy
description: PLANDOME, LI, June 30 Bob Murphy regained the Long Island amateur golf championship, which he won in 1970 and 1971, when he beat Gene Francis, the 1973 champion, in the 36hole final today at the Plandome Country Club. Murphy came from 2 down after 16 holes to win the match, 1 up.

title: Jews in Minsk and Odessa Reported in Hunger. Strike
description: MOSCOW, June 30 (Reuters) A group of Soviet Jews has begun a protest hunger strike in Minsk, the capital of Byelorussia, which President Nixon is to visit tomorrow, informed Jewish sources said today.

title: TV: Tilobolus and Joan, Solid Visual Achievement
description: Experimental video has found itself a superstar in Ed Emshwiller. Last year, the painter and film maker created ScapeMates, and gave WNET/13's Television Laboratory an abstract and unusually impressive combination of electronic landscape and choreography for two dancers. Now, in a program scheduled for 10 o'clock tonight on Channel 13, he i applying ideotapes's great flexibility for imagemaking to the superb telling of a narrative story, written by Carol Emshwiller.

title: Whaling Meeting Shows Signs Of a Priority for Conservation
description: LONDON, June 30Evidence emerged at the 26th annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission in London last week that the 15 member nations, succumbing to world opinion, were giving priority to the survival of the whale over the interests of the whaling industry.

title: New Owner for Old Ferry
description: OXFORD, Md., June 30 (AP) Gilbert C. Clark, a fifthgeneration ferryman from Shelter Island, Li., will take over tomorrow as skipper of the 200yearold ferry service from Oxford to Bellevue across the Tred Avon River. Mr. Clark bought the ferry from William L. Benson, who had owned her for 36 years.

title: Union Locks Horns With Coast Farmer
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 30The United Farm Workers of America (AFLCIO) and Hollis B. Roberts, one of the nation's leading growers of wine grapes, tree fruits and nuts are locked in a legal battle here over the union's attempt to dissolve a picketing injunction, which for over a year has restricted the number of individuals the Farm Workers have stationed near Mr. Roberts field.

title: FRANK J. M'CORMACK
description: Frank J. McCormack, a governor of the former New York Curb Exchange and later member of the American Stock Exchange, died Friday in Belmar, N. J., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: From the day they lurched into existence, the New York Mets have always done things a little differently. They had their annual OldTimers gala in Shea Stadium Saturday, and unlike the alumni of most other clubs, their oldtimers can run and throw and swing a bat. With this 13yearold institution, a man can be an oldimer before reaching his 30th birthday, like Ron Swoboda, also known as the Grand Old Man of Television. Still doing things differently, the oldtimers won their ball game. They beat a team named Opponents, 10, when Chuck Sports Hiller singled and ran home from first on a double by Ed Charles in the second and last of inning.

title: George W. Welsh, 91, Dies; Michigan Publisher, Official
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 30 (UPI)  George W. Welsh, who had a long career in politics and publishing, died yesterday at his home in suburban Ada. He was 91 years old.

title: Poland, W. Germany, Netherlands, Brazil in Semifinal
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 30After Poland defeated Yugoslavia, 21, at Wald Stadium today and took a giant step toward reaching the World Cup soccer final in Munich next Sunday, the question was how many more surprises the. Polish players had in their soccer boots.

title: Ford Calls the Americans He Hears Stout of Heart
description: WASHINGTON, June 30Is Gerald R. Ford's America peopled almost exclusively by checkbook Republicans and airport cops?

title: Mrs. Skala, On 69208, Wins by 3
description: CANDIAC, Quebec, June 30 (UPI)  Mrs. Carole Jo Skala dropped a 25foot putt for an eagle on the 460yard eighth hole today and totaled an 11underpar 208 to finish first in a 54hole Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: PRESSURES MOUNT FOR A.M.A. CHANGE
description: CHICAGO, June 28  The American Medical Association has ended a sixday meeting here with new leadership and new challenges for action in the next year.

title: Amsterdam's Food A Pleasant Surprise
description: AMSTERDAM  We have recently returned from a stroll with a friend along the banks of the canals in Amsterdam where we played a game called surprising Amsterdam. It went like this:

title: U.S. Newsmen Become Tourist Attraction at Yalta
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 30 The American press is considerably more blase about the current summit meeting between President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev than it was about their last two. But the White House press corps itself, one of the world's great movable curiosities, has been a tremendous tourist attraction during its brief stay in this resort city.

title: Locusts Back on Cape Cod
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass June 30 (AP)Carrying on a natural phenomenon that was first noticed by the Pilgrims 300 years ago, the 17year locusts have returned to Cape Cod.

title: Hearing Today to Delve Into Secret Police Work
description: In the shady world of illicit drug dealing, where narcotics crime and police corruption are often intertwined, undercover police agents and their informants are universally feared and loathed. A cover blown inadvertently can mean a quick death. And a cover purposely revealed is usually substituted by another, so that an agent can continue his secret work or go into hiding.

title: Television
Syria Names Envoy to U.S.
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, June 30 (AP)Syria announced today the appointment of a career diplomat, Sabah Kabbani, as Ambassador to the United States, a post that has been vacant since Syria broke relations during the 1967. Middle East War. Relations were restored June 16 during President Nixon's visit here.

title: Samuels Weighs Whether to Run Alone or With Others in Sept. 10 Primary
description: Howard J. Samuels is currently mulling whether he will do a solo in the Sept. 10 primary or run with one or more Democratic aspirants for other statewide offices. No matter what his decision, he will make enemies. His problem is to keep the enemies to a minimum.

title: Weicker Approval Rejected
description: VERNON, Conn., June 30 (AP) State Senator Thomas H. Carruthers, Republican of Vernon, says he will not accept an endorsement for reelection from Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut. Mr. Carruthers said in a letter he did not want any phonies such as you campaigning for me.

title: A 3YearOld Boy Is Bitten in Bronx By a St. Bernard
description: A 3yearold Bronx boy was bitten and seriously injured by a St. Bernard dog yesterday while chasing a ball.

title: 59 Call Morgue to File MissingPerson Reports
description: Although only 18 bodies from the Port Chester fire remained unidentified at the Westchester County morgue last night, Medical Examiner Henry Siegel said parents and friends of 59 people had called to report them missing.

title: Jam Parade Takes A Train for Duke
description: Jam sessions are supposed to be casual affairs, but George Wein, producer of the Newport Jazz Festival, evidently felt that the opening segment of the festival's jam session at midnight Saturday in Radio City Music Hall was so casual that it called for a word of comment.

title: L. I. Rabbi Is Elected Head Of the Zionist Organization
description: Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein was elected president of the Ziohist Organization of America at the close of the organization's 77th annual conventiori at the New York Hilton Hotel yesterday.

title: A WORLD SURPLUS OF OIL REPORTED
description: Today, less than four months after the end of the Arab oll embargo, there Is a decided surplus of oil in the world.

title: Upstate Public Library Lends Tools, Not Books, to Residents
description: COHOES, N. Y.  Nelson Hare came into the library here the other day and walked out with a jigsaw and a belt sander. At about the same time, Mrs. Mary McCormick came in and returned a big rug shampooer.

title: G.O.P. ROOKIES GET TACTICAL TRAINING
description: WASHINNGTON, June 30 The Republican campaign school for rookie candidates is a set of subtle lessons in ignoring President Nixon and a few tentative suggestions on turning the inflation issue against the Democrats.

title: U.S. Signs Pact to Supply AtomicPlant Fuel to Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 30 (Reuters)Iran and the United States signed a 10year agreement today, under which the United States will supply Iran with enriched uranium fuel for use in nuclear power plants.

title: ORIGIN OF BLAZE IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: Investigators were exploring theories yesterday that the Gulliver's bar fire in Port Chester, N.Y., had started in an adjoining part of the building, and that the airconditioning system had spread dense, killing smoke throughout the establishment.

title: Amid Hymns, Shooting and Death
description: ATLANTA, June 30It was 11 A.M. The morning worship service had just begun at Ebenezer Baptist Church.

description: To the. Editor: Any new highway in Manhattan is highway overkill, given the city's serious air quality problems, and the dwindling fuel supplies, conditions that encouragement of motor vehicle traffic would exacerbate.

description: Vancouver 2, New York 0.

title: Doctors Advise Nixon To Get Some Exercise
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 30 (UPI)President Nixon still has some phlebitis swelling in his left leg and his doctors are encouraging him to get, as much exercise as possible, White House aides said today.

title: New Fiscal Year
description: The Federal Government wound up fiscal 1974 with the budget approximately balanced. This is not a consequence of prudent planning but of inflation.

title: Miss Budweiser, Benns Driving, Captures Trophy
description: DETROIT, June 30 (AP)Howie Benns, driving Miss Budweiser, left George Henley, in Pay N Pak, in his wake in the second lap and hung on to win by threetenths of a second today and take the Gar Wood Trophy for unlimited hydroplanes.

title: Hearing Today to Delve Into Secret Police Work
description: In the shady world of illicit drug dealing, where narcotics crime and police corruption are often intertwined, undercover police agents and their informants are universally feared and loathed. A cover blown inadvertently can mean a quick death. And a cover purposely revealed is usually substituted by another, so that an agent can continue his secret work or go into hiding unusual.

title: City Is All Aglow for a Sparkling Fourth
description: FETES AND FIREWORKS The city's official birthday party, put together by the New York City Bicentennial Corporation, will be an eighthour affair on Thursday, beginning at 2 P.M. and continuing until 10.

title: Custodian of Power in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 30In his most recent speech, before he took ill, President Juan Domingo Perlin attributed much of the discord in Argentina to a fever over my succession among those who do not understand that the only successor of Perlin will be the Argentine people who, in the final analysis, must make the decision.

title: Brandt Confident of a Role in Politics
description: BONN, June 30Down but not out after his resignation as chancellor, Willy Brandt says that he is picking up the threads of a new phase in his career, confident that he will have more to do and say in West German politics.

title: Partial List of Casualties
description: A complete list of casualties in yesterday's Port Chester fire is being held up pending positive identification of the dead. However, the names of six of the dead and all of the injured have been released.

title: Farmers Holding Back Wheat From Market for Higher Price
description: CHICAGO, June 30A bountiful harvest of winter wheat is nearing it peak in Kansas, and the combines will soon be moving northward into Nebraska to cut the crop there. But this year a new element, is changing the usual patter, in which wheat has moved from field to grain dealer to flour miller.

title: OutofState Investment Fed Tulsa's Troubled HorneStake Empire
description: TULSA, Okla.,Of the 2,000 or more investors whom the Securities and Exchange Commission has said may have been cheated in a $100million scandal by the HomeStake Production Company of Tulsa, only two lived in Tulsa.

title: 4 Nixon Justices on High Court Vote in Bloc That Could Become Majority
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 The four Justices whom President Nixon named to the Supreme Court have solidified into a bloc that is increasing in both unity and capacity to produce a working majority for their views of the law and the Constitution.

title: A Shy Mrs. King Was Devoted To the 9 Children Her Sons Left
description: ATLANTA, June 30 (AP)Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., who was mortally wounded today in the same church where her son, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was mourned six years ago, was a quiet, devout woman who kept out of the limelight. collage There is one greatgrandchild.

title: Agitate, Favored, Wins Swaps Stakes
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 30 (AP)  Bill Shoemaker sent Agitate, the favorite, to the front early and kept him there to win the $111,300 Swaps Stakes for 3yearolds at Hollywood Park today.

title: N.F.L. Players Strike
description: The National Football League was hit by a players strike, which was expected to keep most players away from preseason training camps and possibly the exhibition games. Page 37.

title: Audubon Society Head Resigns to Join Staff
description: Gene W. Setzer, after 10 years as chairman of the board of directors of the National Audubon Society, has resigned the post to join the administrative staff as a vice president to take part in daytoday decisions.

description: Agreement in principal was reached over the weekend on the sale of the Alleghany Corporation's holdings of common stock in the USM Corporation to the Emhart Corporation, according to T. Mitchell Ford, of Bloomfield, Conn., president of Emhart.

description: An indictment against at least one of the country's major oil companies, accusing it of violations of New York State's antitrust laws, is expected to be handed up this morning in State Supreme Court.

title: MRS. MABEL S. EWER
description: SUMMIT, N.J., June 30 (AP) Mrs. Mabel S. Ewer, founder of the now defunct Women's Symphony. Orchestra of Philadelphia, died yesterday at her home, 19 New England Avenue. She was 93 years old.

title: Venezuela Initiates Hike On Prices of Oil Exports
description: CARACAS, June 30 (UPI)Venezuela implemented one of its announced oil price and tax actions yesterday, raising export prices moderately, for crude oils as well as refined products, including gasojine.

title: MRS., ELSE F. REIF
description: Mrs. Else Fritz Reif, a couturiere in Vienna, Stockholm and from 1940 to 1950, on Central Park South, died yesterday in Vancouver, British Columbia. She was 87 years old and the widow of Oskar Reif, who was killed serving in the Austrian army in World War I.

title: LITTLE GAIN SEEN ON WEAPONS PACT IN YALTA MEETING
description: YALTA, U.S.S.R., June 30President Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet Commitnist leader, talked for more than four hours today in the pleasant breezes of the Black Sea, but both sides suggested afterward that little progress had been made on the crucial issue under discussionthe limitation of offensive nuclear weapons.

description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 30The Nottingham regatta, the first of the 1974 international rowing events, ended today on the 2,000meter Holme Pierrepont course with the East German and Soviet national teams indicating that they will again be the teams to beat in the September world champoinship.

description: SANTA CLARA, Calif, June 30 (UPI)Meet records were set in both the women's and men's. 1,500meter freestyle during qualifying heats today in the Santa Clara international swimming meet.

title: Bridge: Pennsylvanians Take Title In Regional Open Pairs Play
description: Two young Pennsylvanian experts captured the open pair title here Saturday night in the New YorkNew Jersey regional championships. Heading a field of 48 pairs were Billy Gough of Oreland and Phil Brady of Philadelphia.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: For a Total Test Ban
description: For more than a decade, most efforts to curb nuclear arms have focused not on the weapons but on the missiles and the delivery systems that place atomic bombs on target. Recently, however, there has been a growing realization that, as the nuclear era began with an explosion in 1945, the arms race cannot be halted nor can the nuclear power balance be stabilized without ending nuclear explosions.

title: ORIGIN OF BLAZE IS UNDER INQUIRY
description: Investigators were exploring theories yesterday that the Gulliver's bar fire in Port Chester, N.Y., had started in an adjoining part of the building, and that the airconditioning system had spread dense, killing smoke throughout the establishment.

title: 11 KILLED IN CRASHES IN OKLAHOMA SMOKE
description: EL RENO, Okla., June 30 (AP) Eleven persons were killed and several others injured today when a series of vehicles drove into heavy smoke blanketing Interstate 40 near this central Oklahoma community.

title: Bissau's Meager Charms Quickly Pall for Visitors
description: BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea, June 29The prospect of having to leave Bissau when Portuguese Guinea becomes independent makes the hearts of Portuguese soldiers and officials here beat faster in happy anticipation.

title: Ballet: Bolshoi's Quixote and Swan Lake in London
description: LONDON, June 30The Bolshoi Ballet is behaving as if it were business as usual on the fourth visit to London of the first company. And certainly it is appearing before soldout houses with prices at a fat top of $21.50 for an orchestra seat. Yet every night there are Jewish demonstrators outside the London Coliseum, and on one night, despite the most stringent security measures, some brutal morons, completely unauthorized by any Jewish organization, disgustingly threw eggs and nails on the stage and let white mice loose in the audience.

title: 2d Straight Shutout Comes at Hands of Cuellar
description: BALTIMORE, June 30 With a little help from his friends and teammates in the field, Mike Cuellar prolonged the New York Yankees frustrations against lefthanded pitchers today by heating them, 30, before a crowd of 21,176.

title: About New York On the Trail of a Red Shopping Bag
description: A woman named Knox got on a No. 6 bus on a recent rainy Friday, taking with her a small pocketbook and a red shopping bag, and settled down for a long, dull ride to 12th Street. When she got there, she ran into a grocery to buy orange juice, realized that she had forgotten the red shopping bag, and ran back to the street to look for the bus. It was, of course, gone.

title: New Jersey Sports Star Without Team
description: JACKSON TOWNSHIP, June 30High pressure recruiting and athletic scholarships are usually reserved for the football and basketball standout. Occasionally, an outstanding athlete comes along to excite the lesspublicized, nonmoneymaking recruiting world. Such was the case Walter Wilson, who will attend the University of Kentucky on a $2,500ayear swimming scholarship in September.

description: Aqueduct Entries

title: WILLIAM HALE, 63, AN EDITOR, DEAD
description: William Harlan Hale, an editor and writer who served overseas with the Office of War Information during World War II, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived on Goodhill Road in Weston, Conn.

title: Soviet Dancer in Canada Defects on Bolshoi Tour,
description: OTTAWA, June 30Mikhail Barihnikov, a leading Soviet ballet dancer, fled from the touring Bolshoi troupe in Toronto last night, apparently to continue dancing in the West.

description: BUDAPEST  Buttressed by unprecedented prosperity and an atmosphere of contention on how national profits should be spent, Hungary's Communist trade union organization is seeking recognition by Western counterparts as an authentic labor movement.

title: Language Issue Haunts Canadian Race
description: MONTREAL, June 29 Canada's pervasive language problem arouses so much emotion that the political leaders have agreed informally to try to keep it from becoming an issue in the current election campaign.

title: Santee Heritage
description: At a stroke of the pen, some 25,000 acres of coastal marshland rich in wildlife, history and natural beauty have been spared potential exploitation and instead marked forever as a heritage for future generations South Carolinians and all Americans. For this remarkable transaction, the beneficiaries can thank the Santee Club, a group of sportsmen who donated the tract valued $20 million to the Nature Conservancy, which has assumed its ownership and management, and South Carolina's government, acting through its new Heritage Trust Program.

title: New Books
description: An Alcoholic in the Family by Mary Burton (Lippincott, $6.95). What was done to overcome a handicap.

title: THE CHIEF AWARDS
description: VARIETY GROUPS BEST IN SHOW

title: Iran in Concorde Options
description: Stith Reza Pahlevi of Iran has committed himself only to maintaining Iran's options to purchase three Concorde airliners; according to a spokesman for French Prime Minister, Jacques Chirac. It had earlier been reported that the Shah had decided to change Iran's longstanding option on the supersonic airliners into a firm order.

title: 3 C.O.P. VOTES FOUND FOR IMPEACHING NOW
description: If the vote were taken now, as many as 29 of the 38 members of the House Judiciary Committee would vote to recommend President Nixon's impeachment, Time magazine says in its current issue.

title: In Karachi, Nuclear India Is Topic Z
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 30The people of this steaming, grimy city 720 miles from New Delhi seem to regard India's new nuclear potential as just another Hindu trick.

title: East German and Soviet Crews Loom as Strongest
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 30The Nottingham regatta, the first of the 1974 international rowing events, ended today on the 2,000meter Holme Pierrepont course with the East German and Soviet national teams indicating that they will again be the teams to beat in the September world chainpoinship.

title: Retired Printer Stabbed to Death In His Williamsburg Apartment
description: A retired printer was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in his basement apartIment in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Head and. Staff of Museum In the Bronx Dismissed
description: The director and fivemember staff o the Bronx Museum of the Arts, a smal organization that stages exhibitions in the County Courthouse rotunda, were dismissed yesterday in dispute with the board of trustees.

title: COPPER FUTURES DECLINE SHARPLY
description: Copper prices fell sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, probably dire to slackening industrial demand, according to analysts.

title: Moscow Jews Science Seminar Thwarted by the Secret Police
description: MOSCOW, July 1The Soviet secret police has thwarted an unofficial scientific seminar planned by a group of Jewish scientists barred from working here since they applied to emigrate to Israel.

title: People in Sports
description: Dave DeBusschere has retired as a player to become general manager of New York Nets and the future of Willis Reed is uncertain. But one bright note for the Knicks is that Bill Bradley, a starting forward since 1969, will be back next season. He signed a oneyear contract, as he has done for the last four seasons.

title: Johnson & Johnson Buys Realty In Downtown New Brunswick
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 1 Johnson & Johnson, the New Brunswickbased manufacturer and worldwide marketer of pharmaceuticals and healthcare products, disclosed today that it had invested more than $1.5million toward the purchase of real estate in downtown New Brunswick.

title: Six on Impeachment Panel Face Reelection Difficulty
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  At least a halfdozen members of the House Judiciary Committee are facing difficult reelection campaigns even as they ponder whether to recommend that President Nixon be impeached.

title: Dance: Skymap Opens 27th American Festival
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 7The 27th annual season of the American Dance Festival, which just opened here at Connecticut College, is marked by so many new programs that anyone who really wants to keep up with the activities needs a scorecard.

title: Newport Jazz Return of Unaccompanied Pianists
description: When Art Tatum died almost 20 years ago, the art of playing unaccompanied jazz piano seemed to have died with him. Between a reluctance on the part of some pianists to seem to challenge Tatum's virtuosity as a solo pianist and a general feeling that a jazz pianist needed some kind of rhythmic supportbass alone or bass and drumsjazz pianists rarely performed unaccompanied until a year ago, when the Newport Jazz Festival, in what was considered an adventurous and daring bit of programing at the time, put on an entire evening of unaccompanied pianists.

title: CITY SAYS DOCTOR PADDED HIS BILLS,
description: A radiologist who specialized in processing Xray reports on patients eligible for Medicaid was arrested yesterday on charges that he bilked the city out of at least $32,000 by submitting hills for services he never performed.

title: Bakery Strike On
description: PHILADELPHIA. July 1 (AP)  Mrs. Smith's bakeries, producer of packaged pies, was hit by strikes today at three plants in Philadelphia, York and Pottstown. The union is reportedly seeking a costofliving escalator. Earlier, a management offer of 35cent hourly raises in each of two years was rejected by the union.

title: Maine Farmers See Aid in Beef
description: MEDDYBEMPS, Me.Git along little dogies will soon resound through the lonely hills of Washington County, the nation's easternmost county and one its most persistent poverty pockets, if Federal and state farm officials have their way.

title: Base Rent Plan Assailed In City as Unworkable
description: City officials acknowledged yesterday that they had issued 1974 rent authorizations for only about 40,000 of the 950,000 rentcontrolled apartments here, but they denied landlord charges that the massive delay was a deliberate attempt by the Beame administration to thwart the controversial maximumbaserent system of controls.

title: TV Scores Plan to Ban Premiums for Children
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The television board of the National Association of Broadcasters denounced today a proposal of the Federal Trade Commission to ban all mention of premium offers in television advertising directed toward children.

title: MASS TRANSIT AID APPEARS STALLED
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said today that he was pessimistic about the prospect of an accord with Congress on masstransit legislation.

title: BOY, 13, IS KILLED IN CAMDEN HOLDUP
description: CAMDEN, July 1A 13yearold boy was shot and killed and a 3yearold girl was critically wounded today when two men held up Litwin Brother's Superette here and escaped with about $10,000.

title: City Ballet
description: New York City ballet ended its spring/summer season at the New York State Theater Sunday night with a fine performance of George Balanchine's A Midsummer Night's Dream. Gratifyingly, the season has been markedly more successful at the box office than last season, with 131,808 seats sold this year as opposed to the 119,406 sold during the equivalent period last year.

title: Samuels and Carey Disagree Over the Need for Balanced Ticket
description: Civiltyi prevailed yesterday as the two contenders for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination disagreed in debate over the need for a balanced ticket.

title: The Cost of a Housing Act
description: The good news in housing legislation is that for the first time since 1968 there will probably be some comprehensive community development. The bad news that unless the House conferees and Administration officials approach the SenateHouse conference with a good deal of flexibility, the final product is apt to hurt many of the cities that have worked hardest at solving the great urban problems.

title: Tax News
description: The sales tax rose to 8 per cent in New York City yesterday. [Page 70.] A new 5 per cent surtax on offtrack betting payoffs took effect, and wagering at the city's 131 OTB shops declined about 20 per cent. [Page 41.]

title: Pericles in the Park Opens Papp Festival
description: The play Pericles, like the hero it celebrates, is seatost. Storms and shipwrecks alter the course of lives. Man is at the mercy of unfriendly elements. As in The Tempest, the greatest of Shakespeare's last plays, there is transformation in Pericles. The seemingly dead are reborn, and after many winds of change there is a final triumph of virtue not regained because never truly lost.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Financially troubled Bloomfield College has received a $1.5million Federal fouryear grant. The grant is divided into appropriations for academic and faculty development, programs for new students, personalgrowth counseling for students, new approaches to administration and advanced institutional development programs. The grants are given to private colleges by the United States Office of Education.

title: Pennsy Barred From U. S Plan
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad should not join a proposed new Federal rail system set up by Congress.

title: U.S. ACCEPTS PLAN ON DISTRICTS HERE
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 The Justice Department approved today new legislative districts for sections of Brooklyn and Manhattan that Hasidic Jews said gave blacks too much representation and that blacks said did not go far enough. The department brushed aside the objections of some black politicians in the BedordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn who argued that although the Legislature created two Congressional districts with 72 per cent and 63 per cent majorities of blacks and Puerto Ricans, respectively, neither district was safe because of the low turnout of these groups at the polls.

title: NIXON IN MINSK CALLS FOR AMITY
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R., July 1 President Nixon arrived here today to see a city bedecked in red, celebrating the 30th anniversary of its recapture from the Germans in World War II.

title: Borg and Ashe Bow at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1Bjorn Borg, the Swedish golden boy was thrashed in three sets, Arthur Ashe was upset in four and Jan Kodes, the defending champion, hobbled home in an overtime fifth set as the Wimbledon tennis tournament finally came alive under sunny skies and a blustery wind that made playing conditions precarious.

title: Families in Crisis: Help for Young Children
description: When a family is stricken by crisis, no one's emotional wellbeing is safe. But the little onesthe 4yearolds, the 6yearoldsare especially vulnerable.

title: Alexandra. Tolstoy, at 90, Is Honored for Lifetime of Helping Others
description: Tolstoy wrote masterpieces such as War and Peace, but he also collaborated on less famous works of art. One of themfrail and mortal, her mind brimming with memories expressed and joys inexpressiblewas 90 years old yesterday.

title: EmissionRule Charge Is Postponed 7 Months
description: TRENTON, July 1 (AP)Stricter autoemission standards that were to have gone into effect today have been postponed by the state.

title: Maheu Wins Suit Over a Statement By Howard Hughes
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 Robert A. Maheu won his clefamation suit today against his former employer, Howard R. Hughes.

title: Volunteer Army a Success Secretary Callaway Says;
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) Army Secretary Howard H. Callaway declared the vollancer Army a success today, saying the service ended the fiscal year more than 1,000 men over the strength author ized by Congress.
The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: PUBLICATIONS RULED FREE OF AD LIABILITY
description: TRENTON, July 1 (UP)A New Jersey State Appeals Court ruled today that magazines, newspapers and other publications could not be obligated to guarantee products that they advertised.

title: 40% IN U.S. FOUND ELIGIBLE FOR AID
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) A research study indicates that 85 million people, or 40 per cent of the nation's population, were eligible for some kind of Federal aid to the poor at some time during the last six years, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today.

title: ALABAMA PLANNING BIG NUCLEAR PROJECT
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July (AP)Gov. George C. Wallace announced today plans for construction of a privately financed nuclear fuel plant, a $2.75billion project.

title: VALUE OF BUILDING DROPPED 1% IN MAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)The total value of construttion in May fell 1.per cent or $1billion, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $135.2billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN

title: Guerrillas Said to Promise Lebanon to Stop Raids Over Border
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, July 1The leadership of the PalestinIan guerrilla movement is ported to have notified Lebanese Government that it will assume responsibility for keeping terrorists from attackthat ing Israel from Lebanon.

title: Avco Is Back in Black, but Operating Earnings Fall
description: The Avco Corporation reported yesterday a profit in the quarter ended May 31, buti operating earnings were down from last year. A year earlier, the company had deficits because of a $41million writeoff for investments and the costs of its 32 per cent interest in Cartridge Television, Inc., which went into bankruptcy in July.

title: Striking N.F.L. Players Face First Test at Chargers Camp
description: With no tangible facility to picket, members of the National Football League Players Association went peacefully through the first day of their strike against the N.F.L. yesterday. However, the situation promised to grow Moreinteresting as, the, week progressed.

title: Garrow Sentenced To 25 Years to Life In Upstate Slaying
description: LAKE PLEASANT, N. Y., July 1Robert Garrow of Syracuse was sentenced to 25 years to life in prison today for the murder of an Adirondack camper 12 months ago.

title: Net Gypsies Making Bid For Honors
description: While the big guns boomed at Wimbledon, the United States Lawn Tennis Association's summer tour, with 36 stops and more than $1.5mill ion in prize money, opened yesterday with a satellite tournament in Oregon. What is a satellite tournament? It is an event for the tennis gypsiesplayers below the top echelon who find it hard to get into major tournaments, such as the national clay or Open, and go wherever there is a chance to play and prize money to be picked up. If they do well in the satellites, they qualify for a major event and the opportunity to upset a highranking star. There are 13 satellite events.

title: Television
Boston Naval Shipyard, Nation's Oldest, Closes
description: BOSTON, July 1 (UPI)The 174yearold Boston Naval Shipyard, the oldest in the nation, shut down today.

title: Youth in Mrs. King Slaying Says He Came on Mission
description: ATLANTA, July 1Marcus Wayne Chenault, the former college student accused of murdering the mother of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. land a church deacon yesterday, stood before an arraigning judge today and said he had been sent here on a mission and it's partially accomplished.

title: American Family Reported Arrested in Philippines
description: MANILA, July 1 (AP)Government troops have arrested an American missionary, his wife and 10yearold son, Government sources reported today.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: DISPARITY FOUND IN AID TO SCHOOLS
description: CHICAGO, July 1A statis tical report released today in conjunction with the annua meeting of the National Edu cation Association emphasizes the disparities from state to state in financial support of public schools.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: Quotations supplied through NASDAQ as of 3:30 P.M. Quotes do not Include retail markup, markdown or commitions. Volume represents shares that changed ownership during the day. Figures include only transactions effected by NASDAQ marketmakers but may include some duplication where marketmakers traded with each other.
