title: PERON DEAD AT 78; WIFE TAKES OVER A DIVIDED NATION
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 1 President Juan Domingo Peron of Argentina, one of the most remarkable and controversial political figures in American history, died today at the age of 78. His death left his politically divided country in a state of deep uncertainty.The announcement of his death, reportedly of heart disease, was made this afternoon by his wife, Vice President Isabel Perdn, 43. She assumes her husband's office, becoming the first woman chief of state in the Americas.With great pain I must transmit to the people the death of a true apostle of peace and nonviolence, said Mrs. Peron on a nationwide broadcast from the presidential mansion.

title: Louis Fortgang, 67, Dead; State Tax Aide in Bronx
description: Louis Fortgang, Bronx district supervisor of the State Department of Taxation and Finance, died Sunday of a heart ailment in Albany. He was 67 years old and lived at 303 Beverly Road, Brooklyn.

title: Leuci Lists Bribes Among Hundreds Of His Prior Crimes
description: Detective Robert S. Leuci testified in Federal District Court yesterday that he had given an assistant district attorney $500 to fix a case and that he himself had received money from two lawyers seeking favors for their clients in other cases.

title: Wood, Field & Stream Flyrod Has Varied Assets
description: An exhilarating two hours of fishing for smallmouth bass with popping bugs on Maine's Damariscotta Lake recently reminded me once again that the fly rod is perhaps the most versatile tool the lighttackle angler can possess.

title: Site of 24 Deaths Lacked A Fire Detection System
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 1The lack of an emergency fire  detection system and a physical layout that caused scores of patrons to flee to a single exit were cited by investigators today as the major reasons why 24 people died and 32 were injured when a fire flashed through Gulliver's night club here early Sunday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: With a call for an end to cynicism about the future of Newark, Kenneth A. Gibson was sworn in to his second fouryear term as Mayor of the city.

title: Peron, After Years as Strongman, Arose From Defeat to Rule Argentina Again
description: Juan Domingo Pern was a phoenix among national strongmen. After running Argentina for nine years, from 1946 to 1955, and fleeing the country ignominiously, he waited out 18 years in opulent exile until he was called hack last year and assumed the presidency. In the interval, events showed, he had lost little of his guile and none of his capacity to excite popular enthusiasm.

title: Business Briefs
description: The International Business Machines Corporation asked a Federal Court here yesterday to hold the Federal Government in contempt for refusing to turn over certain Commerce Department documents to I.B.M.

title: Baseball Tryout Canceled
description: The Kansas City Royals Baseball Academy tryout; scheduled to be held at the Bayside High School athletic field in Queens today, has been canceled.

title: Chess:
description: NICE, June 30 The Soviet Union clinched first place in the International Team Tournament by defeating the Philippines 3 in the 14th round. With one round td go, the Russians have run up 43 points for an insurmountable 7point lead over the secondplace team, Yugoslavia.

title: Advertising: Giftamerica Shift
description: One of this year's more fascinating stories in a business filled with fascinating stories had to do with George S. Gordon leaving Foote, Cone & Belding to be chairman of Dillon, Gordon, Hawkey, Shortt, a new agency, which had among its first clients Giftamerica, a subsidiary of Western Union of which Mr. Gordon was also the new president and chief marketing officer.

title: RODINO ACCEPTS WITNESSES ASKED BY NIXON LAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee agreed today, in an apparent gesture of conciliation, to accept all of the witnesses proposed by President Nixon's defense lawyer for impeachment hearings scheduled to resume tomorrow.

title: NIXON IS CRITICIZED BY N.A.A.C.P. OFFICIAL
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 1 (UPI)  The chairman of the board of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today the Nixon administration had set back the black community by reducing Federal programs most helpful to blacks.

title: Tenement Fire Displaces 12
description: A smoky, twoalarm fire spread through three adjacent threestory wood tenements in the East New York section of Brooklyn last night, leaving 12 persons homeless. The blaze began around 7:30 in 188 Montauk Avenue, an unoccupied building, and quickly spread to 190 and 192. Ten firemen were treated for heat exhaustion and smoke inhalation, the polices said.

title: Nixon Pays Tribute to Peron; Pope Will Offer Mass for Him
description: MOSCOW, July 1 (AP)President Nixon paid tribute to Juan Domingo Pern today as a source of inspiration to his countrymen.

title: Summit Talks at Delicate Stage
description: MOSCOW, July 1The most delicate moment of the NixonBrezhnev summit meeting has arrived: the final effort to strike an agreement setting limits on the race to modernize the Soviet and American strategic arsenals @News with multiheaded missiles. The nego@Analysis tiations on this issue between President Nixon and Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, so far have been searching, intricate, and potentially promising than is generally realized.

title: NATO and Survival
description: LONDON  Two postwar international agreements have served and saved Europe: Marshall Plan aid, when American generosity helped rebuild Europe's exhausted economy to the advantage of both sides of the Atlantic, and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, which brought security to Western Europe and its Atlantic partners, the United States and Canada.

title: Italian Senate Gets Austerity Package; Approval Expected
description: ROME, July 1Premier Mariano Rumor today proposed to the Senate an austerity package designed to raise $5billion in revenue.

title: Chenault May Have Had Visitors at Dayton Hotel
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 1The, authorities here have learned that Marcus Wayne Chenault, the accused killer of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., may have had visitors to his room at the Downtown Holiday Inn. The authorities are also investigating reports that another Dayton man was seen in Atlanta yesterday.

title: Arms Cache at U.C.L.A.
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1 (UPI)  Thirty weapons, including five semiautomatic rifles, and several hundred rounds of ammunition have been discovered in student lockers at the University of California at Los Angeles, the campus police reported today. The authorities questioned a 29yearold former U.C.L.A. political science student in connection with the discovery, but his name was not disclosed and he was not arrested.

title: Unlikely Model
description: WASHINGTON  The odyssey of Richard Nixon has finally brought him to Yalta.

title: Notes on People House's Rules Man
description: The House of Representatives got a new chief adviser on rules and procedures yesterday. He is William H. Brown Jr., a 44year old lawyer from Huntington, W. Va., who had been an assistant to the former parliamentarian, Lewis Deschler, for 16 years. Mr. Deschler retired on Sunday. Albany, belted a homer. Councilman Theodore S. Weiss of Manhattan held the opposition to seven runs.

title: THWARTED PAPER SET TO SUE SPAIN
description: MADRID, July 1An unusual lawsuit is about to be brought by some 400 liberal Spaniards against the Spanish state for its failure to live up to its selfproclaimed desire to liberalize political life and assure freedom of expression and information.

title: Soviet Says London Pickets Threaten Bolshoi's Season
description: LONDON, Tuesday, July 2The Soviet Government has threatened to cancel the last three weeks of the Bolshoi Ballet's season here unless demonstrations at their performances cease.

title: Tax News
description: The sales tax rose to 8 per cent in New York City yesterday. [Page 70.] A new 5 per cent surtax on offtrack betting payoffs took effect and wagering at the city's 131 OTB shops declined about 20 per cent. [Page 41.]

title: Zaire Prepares With Pride to Become Battleground for Foreman Ali Fight
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 1 On Sept. 24, at 3 o'clock in the morning, this city's 20th of May Stadium is scheduled to hear the roar of more than 100,000 boxing fans gathered for the world heavyweight championship fight between the champion, George Foreman, and the challenger, Muhammad Ali.

title: TV: The Johnson lmpeachment in 1868
description: Last night's The Impeachment of Andrew Johnson, shown on public television from 8 to 9, was the first in a series of publicaffairs programs that will be produced under a new coproduction arrangement between Washington's National Public Affairs Center for Television (NPACT) and the British Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Stock Market Is Mixed As Turnover Decreases
description: The New York Stock Exchange showed few vital signs yesterday.

title: Dr. Christina Bogoslovsky, Directed School in Darien
description: Dr. Christina Stael Bogoslovsky, former director of the Cherry Lawn School in Darien, Conn., and widow of Dr. Boris B. Bogoslovsky, an educator who helped organize the translation section of the United Nations, died June 25 in Charleston, Ill., where she had been living. She was 86 years old.

title: N.L.R.B.Decides 1,520 Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July. 1 (UPI) The National Labor Relations Board said today that it had decided a record 1,520 unfair labor practice and compensation cases in the fiscal year 1974, which ended yesterday. The figure was 100 higher than last year's, the board said.

title: Williams Is Making Angels Moves
description: As Dick Williams prepared to make his managerial debut last night with the California Angels, the lastplace team in the American League West, two teams were playing in the East who looked more like candidates for Blue Cross than for a division title.

title: Shops Report 20% Drop in Wagering
description: Pickets marched outside OTB shops yesterday as New York's offtrack horseplayers reacted angrily to a new 5 per cent surtax by betting less and grumbling more.

title: JUNE AUTO OUTPUT DECLINED BY 28.4%
description: DETROIT, July 1 (UPI) United States automakers, hit hard by a winter gasoline shortage that curtailed bigcar sales, reported today that 28.4 per cent fewer cars were built in June than a year ago and that firsthalf output was at its lowest level since 1962.

title: RELIANCE, INC., SEES A SUIT SETTLEMENT
description: Reliance, Inc., formerly the Leasco Corporation, disclosed yesterday that it expected to collect $6.25million from Robert Maxwell, the British book publisher, and other defendants in settlement of a fiveyearold fraud suit arising out of its purchase of an interest in Pergamon Press, Ltd.

title: Machinery in Motion for Major Antitrust Trial in Pro Basketball
description: With the chances having vanished for a settlement involving the National Basketball Association, the American Basketball Association and the N.B.A. Players Association, machinery now has been set in motion for a major antitrust trial that will probably take place sometime next year.

title: Dealers Offer Unleaded Gasoline As Part of New Clean Air Drive
description: Beginning yesterday, America's biggest service stations had to offer leadfree gasoline to meet requirements of the Government's clean air campaign and a nationwide survey by The Associated Press found that most of the station operators were ready, willing and able, but not too eager.

title: Ferreira de Castro Is Dead; Portuguese Writer Was 77
description: LISBON, July 1 (AP)Ferreira de Castro, one of Portugal's leading writers, died Saturday. He was 77 years old.

title: 10 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: TROY, N. Y., July 1 (UPI)Ten persons were injured today when a small bus carrying retarded youngsters from a picnic skidded on a rainslickened highway about five miles east of here and overturned. The bus was carrying 15 persons. The injured included one child with a broken leg. The accident happened as the bus rounded a sharp curve on Route 1, which residents say is the most dangerous road in the state.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Jockeys Today's Entries at Aqueduct

title: Homecoming Fete Ended in Tragedy
description: VALHALLA, N. Y., July 1 On Saturday Jonetta Horsey started her twoweek vacation from her job as credit manager at W. T. Grant in New Rochelle. Her husband, James, was home on leave from Fort Jackson, S. C., and the family was planning celebration.

title: Blues Men Take Flight Over DeltaChicago Way
description: The two blues concerts offered by the Newport Jazz Festival Sunday night at Avery Fisher Hall were called The King's Road Highway 61, in honor of the link between Delta blues and Chicago, with its more modern, electrified style. It was functional metaphor, even if the order of programing darted back and forth on the NorthSouth axis and wandered occasionally off to the East. But the main problem was that anyone traveling on that road at the early show would have been arrested for speeding.

title: Publisher Is Named
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 1 (AP  George W. Wilson, genera manager of The Concord Monitor, was named publisher of till newspaper today.

title: Shipping/Mails
ExHudson Aides Acquitted
description: JERSEY CITY, July 1 (AP)Paul J. Lombardo and James E Lagomarsino, former Union City commissioners, were acquittec today on charges of keepinE Mr. Lombardo in a $6,000 nc show city job. Mr. Lombardc and Mr. Lagomarsino, whc served four terms each on the city commission until last May were charged with collusion.

description: Foreign Exchange

title: Boy, 13, Is Killed, 5 Others Are Shot In Camden Holdup
description: CAMDEN, July 1A 13yearold boy was shot and killed and a 3yearold girl was critically wounded today when two men held up Litwin Brother's Superette here and escaped with about $10,000.

title: Paris Assumes Top Post In the Common Market
description: PARIS, July 1France today took over the presidency of the European Common Market for the balance of the year, during which she reportedly plans to try to give the organization a new momentum.

description: Following is a list of those identifted so far by the Westchester County Medical Ex.: aminer as victims of the fire at Gulliver's night club in Port Chester early Sunday morning:

title: Angela Davis Is a Leader of New Leftist Alliance
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1Her name is not in the news as much as it once was but quietly, Angela Davis has moved to the forefront of the latest movement on the political Left.

description: ATLANTA, July 1Marcus Wayne Chenault, the former college student accused of murdering the mother of the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and a church deacon yesterday, stood before an arraigning judge today and said he had been sent here on a mission and it's partially accomplished.

title: Wearing TansBut With Autumn On Their Minds
description: Glady Solomon immediately ordered the slinky black knit with the halter neckline, lace capelet and no back. Joanne Winship thinks the knickers are absolutely divine, especially with capes. And Lisa Henry said the last dress mommy wore was the prettiest in the show.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: It was children's day at the carnival, an outdoor street fair that will run from noon to midnight each day through Thursday, but the hundreds of little brothers and sisters in the audience were at least as interested in the Snocones, herb popcorn, games of chance and recorded rock music as they wer ein learning Swahili.

title: PLAN BY HOMESTAKE ON DRILLING CLEARED
description: TULSA, Okla., July 1 (UPI)The HomeStake Production Company, a bankrupt concern that is the subject of an alleged $100million invesment swindle, was given permission through its trustee today to drill 45 oil and gas wells in Ohio.

title: Sadat Meets Bulgarian At End of East Bloc Trip
description: VIENNA, July 1 (Reuters)President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, nearing the end of his journey to Eastern Europe, held talks in Sofia today with Todor Zhivkov, the Bulgarian leader.

title: Bankers'Acceptances Surge
description: Bankers dollar acceptances outstanding in the United states climbed by a record $1.03billion in May to an unprecedented $11.727billion from the previous high of $10.692 billion in April, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Brooklyn Democrat Under Investigation Resigns Party Post
description: Frank D. Gilligan has resigned as secretary to the Democratic county committee in Brooklyn amid an inquiry into whether he and a former law secretary to a judge, siphoned off some $50,000 in organization funds for their own use, political sources said last night.

title: Families Silently Await Identifications
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., July 1A team of five dentists and eight physicians worked through the day at Grasslands Hospital here to identify the remaining bodies of the 24 victims of Sunday's discotheque fire in Port Chester.

title: U.S. DOLLAR DRIFTS ON MARKETS ABROAD
description: BRUSSELS, July 1 (UPI)The United States dollar today opened the week's trading higher in Tokyo and most European money markets, then drifted without pattern during the day. Gold prices fell in London and Zurich.

title: Kalmbach Begins Sentence, But Site Is Not Disclosed
description: BALTIMORE, July 1 (AP)Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's former personal lawyer, surrendered to United States marshals today, according to a spokesman for the United States Marshal Service.

description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phiilles, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8:05 P.M. (Television  Channel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.) Yankees vs. Tigers, at Detroit. (T elevision  Channe 8 P.M.) (RadloAVIVICA, 1811 P.M.)

title: Bar Where 24 Died Had No Fire Detection System
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 1The lack of an emergency fire  detection system and a physical layout that caused scores of patrons to flee to a single exit were cited by investigators today as the major reasons why 24 people died and 32 were injured when a fire flashed through Gulliver's night club here early Sunday. The investigators rummaged today through the ruins of the night spot, which straddles the New YorkConnecticut border, trying to pinpoint the cause of the fire. In nearby Valhalla, a team of five dentists and eight doctors worked through the day at Grasslands Hospital, trying to identify the bodies of the victims. By nightfall, the names of 15 persons killed in the fire had been released.

title: Books of The Times
description: As Nikita S. Khrushchev, the former Soviet leader, was taperecording his memoirs shortly before his death in 1971, a man asked him whether he thought a camel could walk the breadth of the Soviet Union, all the way from Moscow to Vladivostok. Khrushchev answered cautiously that a camel was a strong animal, with much stamina, and probably was capable of making such a trip. Wrong, the man said, it would be eaten by a meathungry populace before it ever got to Sverdlovsk, onefifth of the way across the country. In relating the episode, Khrushchev conceded that there was a certain amount of truth in that story and said he looked to the day when a camel would be able to walk across the Soviet Union without being eaten by hungry peasants along the way.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 1Elesnar, a 6yearold trotter owned by George M. Henderson of Montreal, is the seventh entrant named to the $200,000 Roosevelt International Trot which will be held on July 13. Elesnar joins Amyot and Axius of FWance, Lime Rodney of Sweden, Dosson of Italy and Delmonica Hanover, an American horse, in the annual event at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Bishop Arthur Moore, 85, Dies; Led Methodist Missions Board
description: Bishop Arthur J. Moore of the United Methodist Church, who was a noted evangelical leader and former president of the Council of Bishops and the Board of Missions, died Sunday in Atlanta at the age of 85.

title: President Signs Bill Easing Postal Rise for Magazines
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) President Nixon has signed legislation extending the time table for postage rate increases on newspapers, magazines, books, records and nonprofit tkailings, the White, House said yesterday.

title: Grocery Price Investigation By F.T.C. to Be Expanded
description: >WASHINGTON, July I (AP) The Federal Trade Commission announced today it was expanding to an industrywide scale its investigation of grocery prices.

title: Seret Scott Ages Brilliantly in. Sister
description: petulant child and brooding woman. Her slight 5foot 4inch, 105pound frame also makes her believable in the characters rapid age shifts.

title: MOBIL IS INDICTED BY A STATE JURY IN ANTITRUST CASE
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation was indicted here yesterday for alleged criminal violation of New York State's antitrust laws.

title: Bar Groups Urge Prosecutor For U.S. Crime Inquiry Leaks
description: A report by three committees of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York has called for the creation of special attorneys to investigate and prosecute those responsible for leaking information about Federal criminal investigations.

title: 2 IN GALLO'S GANG SHOT IN BROOKLYN
description: Shots from a passing automobile wounded two men standing on the sidewalk in front of the Henryville Social Club at 3905 Fort Hamilton Parkway in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn early yesterday afternoon.

title: NIXON, IN MINSK, CALLS FOR AMITY
description: MINSK, U.S.S.R., July 1 President Nixon arrived here today to see a city bedecked in red, celebrating the 30th anniversary of its recapture from the Germans in World War II.

title: STEEL OUTPUT SETS LOW FOR THE YEAR
description: Steel production for the week ended June 29 reached its low point for the present year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It placed weekly production at 2,802,000 tons, an index of 114.9. This compared with 2,842,000 tons a week ago, drop of J.4 per cent, and an index of 116.5. The prior low for the year was in the week ended June 15 when only 2,808,000 tons were poured and the index stood at 115.1.

title: Pro Transactions
description: ATLANTA (NL)Reacquired Mike McQueen, pitcher, from Cincinnati.

title: Cunard Cruise Ship Adrift 10 Hours Near Venezuela
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., July 1 (AP)  The cruise ship Ambassador with 625 persons aboard went adrift today because of a mechanical failure but resumed course later in the day, a Cunard line spokesman said.

title: African Carnival Holds Children's Day
description: Hibarigana means What's happening in Swahili, the master of ceremonies at the African Street Carnival in BedfordStuyvesant announced from the stage yesterday. We want all the little brothers and sisters in the audience to sav it with us.

title: ZARETZKI'S RIVAL SEES GAP, ABUSE
description: Assemblyman Franz S. Leichter, who is challenging the State Senate minority leader, Joseph Zaretski, for the latter's seat, charged yesterday that the Republican leadership in Albany had used public money to help the Senator retain his post.

title: NEW REAGAN BUDGET SETS MARK FOR U.S.
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 1 (AP)  Gov. Ronald Reagan has signed the biggest state budget in the nation's history, a $10.133billion spending plan for the fiscal year beginning today.

title: Jackson, in Peking, Asks More Speed Toward Full Ties
description: PEKING, July 1 (Reuters)Senator Henry M. Jackson, arriving here today for a sixday visit, said he favored a more rapid American approach toward full recognition of the Peking Government.

title: Winper of Hughes Suit
description: LOS ANGELES, July 1When Robert Aime Maheu finished his first interview as a fledgling agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, he left the subject's house and found that he had locked himself out of his automobile.

title: Mayors, Once Disaffected With Washington, Say They Are Impressed by Administration's New Receptivity
description: SAN DIEGO, June 27Two Years ago, Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia had an appointment at the White House with John D. Ehrlichman, then President Nixon's domestic affairs counselor.

title: People and Business
description: One professor on leave to the Nixon. Administration has picked up a new Washington hat at the same time that another longterm Washingtonian has disclosed plans to go the other wayinto academic robes.

title: Gulf Lifts Gasoline Price as BP Cuts
description: Price changes in both directions, mostly upward, were announced yesterday on a variety of items. Kaiser Plans Aug. 2 Rise for Aluminum Primary Ingot

title: DEMOCRATS HAIL TV FUNDRAISING
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The Democrats said today that they had netted nearly $4.5million double their previous record from their third annual fundraising telethon over the weekend.

title: Tests Find Changes In Atomic Behavior
description: Experiments with the world's most powerful atom smasher, at Batavia, Ill., have shown that five different atomic fragments get bigger when accelerated to high energy and that they begin to lose some, of their differing characteristics at these hugh energies.

title: Sindona Said to Vow to Save Franklin
description: ROME, Juy 1  Michele Sindona, the Italian financier Who is the largest shareholder in the parent company of the troubled Franklin National Bank, was quoted yesterday as having pledged to save that institution.

title: Excerpts From Supreme Court Briefs of White House and Watergate Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Following are excerpts from reply briefs filed in the Supreme Court today by the White House and the special Watergate prosecutor in the ??? involving President Nixon's refusal to surrender 64 tape recordings to Federal District Court and the Watergate grand jury's naming of the President as an unindicted coconspirator:

title: RODINO ACCEPTS WITNESSES ASKED BY NIXON LAWYER
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee agreed today, in an apparent gesture of condilation, to accept all of the witnesses proposed by President Nixon's defense lawyer for impeachment hearings scheduled to resume tomorrow.

title: Dr. Eugenie Chinnock Dies; Key Aide in City Schools
description: Dr. Eugenie Chinnock, who retired in 1956 as an assistant superintendent of schools, died Sunday in Long Island College Hospital. She was 83 years old, and lived at 200 Cadman Plaza West, Brooklyn.

title: Young Says Ehrlichman Took Sensitive Memos
description: WASHINGTON, July 1David R. Young Jr., in his first publiclsaid, testimony, told a Federal court today that John D. Ehrlichman removed two White House plumbers memorandums from a master file in March, 1973, because they were a little too sensitive and showed too much forethought,

title: 2 Boys Seized in Stolen Bus
description: BRISTOL, Conn., (AP)A 13yearold youth in a stolen school bus and his 9yearold boy passenger were turned over to juvenile authorities after the police stopped them at about I A.M. today, officials said. Police Lieut. Gerald Murphy said the teenager had intentions of visiting his father in Indiana but had changed his mind after a 50mile trip to Union, on the ConnecticutMassachusetts border. The bus was taken from the yard of the Dickau Bus Company in Bristol Sunday night, the police said.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Commercial banks have long enjoyed a special status in New York in checking accounts. They alone can offer them.

title: Japan Wholesale Prices Dip
description: TOKYO, July 1 (Reuters) Wholesale prices in Japan declined slightly during the first 10 days of June because of lower n onferrousmetals and textilegoods prices, the Bank of Japan said today. The index declined 0.1 per cent to 152.1 (1970 prices equal 100) from the previous 10day period but was 35.1 per cent higher than a year before.

title: No Scarlet Letter for Mr. Nixon
description: The carefully nurtured bipartisanship of the House Judiciary Committee is breaking down under the political strains of the Nixon impeachment inquiry. That will be no news to Ken Clawson, Pat Buchanan and other White House sources who have created and exploited discord with their charges that the committee Democrats and Chairman Rodino are prejudiced, unfair and out for Richard Nixon's scalp.

title: JUDGE BARS PRESS FROM TEXAS TRIAL
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 1 (AP)  Calling news reporters a bunch of locusts, Judge Preston Dial of District Court closed off his courtroom today while eight potential jurors were secretly chosen in the mass murder trial of 18yearold Elmer Wayne Henley Jr.

title: Indonesia Has Raised Her Export Price of Oil
description: JAKARTA, July 1 (Reuters) Indonesia raised the export price of her oil to $12.60 from $11.70 a barrel, the stateowned Pertamina Oil Company announced today.

title: Salomon Brothers Pays Bonus Following 9 Profitable Months
description: Salomon Brothers, the big investment banking house whose losses last year shocked Wall Street, said yesterday that this year's business has been good enough so far for it to grant all employes special bonuses.

title: Bridge:
description: A talented foursome of young experts captured the Swiss Team Championship, which concluded the New YorkNew Jersey Regionals at Grossinger, N.Y. Sunday night.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
description: AUTHORITY BONDS

title: The Weather Here in June
description: The Weather Here in June

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: POLAROID OFFICIALS SEE EARNINGS DROP
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July (AP)A sharp drop in the pro duction of film for the pocket sized SX70 Polaroid camerg was cited as the reason for decline in second quarter earn ings to less than 8 cents share by polaroid Company of ficials today.

title: CHESSIE SYSTEM NET UP 36% IN QUARTER
description: Chessie System, Inc., the first to issue results for the full Julie quarter and first half this year, reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for both periods. Parent to the Chesapeake & Ohio, Baltimore & Ohio, Baltimore & Ohio and Western Maryland Railroads, the company attributed the higher returns to increased coal revenues.

title: TREASURY PLANS CHANGE ON FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 1  A new Treasury study concluded today that private banks earn far more on the Treasury's large cash balances kept with banks than the value of services the banks provide.

title: Trading Extension Opposed by Panel Of Stock Exchange
description: The floor committee of the board of the New York Stock Exchange has told the board that it opposes an extension of the exchange's trading hours from 3:30 to 4 P.M.

title: ARMY IN ETHIOPIA TIGHTENS ITS GRIP
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 1Army forces tightened their grip on the Ethiopian capital today and established liaison with units elsewhere in this sprawling African country.

title: Expanded Campaign Spending Bill Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The House Administration Committee tentatively approved today a major campaign spending bill after reversing itself and authorizing the use of limited public funds to help finance Presidential primary elections.

title: New Band Proves Polished Ensemble In Jersey Rock Bill
description: John Scher had planned an afternoon and early evening of well  behaved, roots  oriented rock on Sunday afternoon at Roosevelt Stadium in Jersey City. And that was pretty much the way it worked out (with a healthy assist from the weather gods, who smiled beneficently all day), even if most of the interest in the affair lay elsewhere than with the two headliners, Seals and Crofts and America:

title: MEDICAL PROFESSION ASSAILED BY NADER
description: WASHINGTON,. July (UP)Ralph Nader denounced the American medical profession today iii testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: John V., $7.80, Wins Goshen Cup
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., July 1 (AP)John V., a 2yearold pacing colt, won the $16,015 Goshen Cup today as the first day of Grand Circuit racing began at Historic Track.

title: Macero Fans Rewarded With an AllStar Turnout
description: Either the publicity machine of the Newport Jazz Festival wasn't working at full tilt, or the information wasn't provided until too late. In any case, what was billed simply as Teo Macero's group at the sparsely attended free concert series in Fordham University's Pope Auditorium yesterday afternoon turned out to be an IIman band with seven superb saxophonists: Mr. Macero, Stan Getz, Phil Woods, Gerry Mulligan, George Young, Lee Konitz and Don Palmer, with Dick Katz on piano, Jimmy Madisbn on drums, Mike Moore on bass, Joe Beck on guitar, and Teddi King singing three songs.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: SCHOOL VOTE DUE IN SENATE MONDAY
description: TRENTON, July 1  State Senate Democrats, under fire by their Assembly colleagues for footdragging on tax reform legislation, agreed today to vote next Monday on a bill providing for a thorough and efficient public school system, but they refused to commit themselves to the kind of new taxation that would be needed to finance it.

title: Brazil, Without Pele, Is Gaining Support for Berth in World Cup Soccer Final
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 1West Germany and the Netherlands had been the talk of the soccer fans during World Cup play for two weeks. But, in the last two or three days and especially today, Brazil has gained as much attention.

title: Tigers Beat Yanks, 43, On 3 Clouts
description: DETROIT, July 1  The homerun ball was a nemesis for George Medich and the floundering Yankees tonight as they lost to the Detroit Tigers, 43. The Tigers scored their last three runs on homers.

title: 8% Sales Tax Makes Calm Debut
description: The weather was fine but everyone in the city seemed to be talking about the sales tax, which went up yesterday from 7 per cent to 8 per cent. They might just as well have been talking about the weather, however, because no one could do anything about it.

title: People in Sports
description: Dave DeBusschere has retired as a player to become general manager of the New York Nets and the future of Willis Reed is uncertain. But one bright note for the Knicks is that Bill Bradley, a starting forward since 1969, will be back next season. He signed a oneyear contract, as he has done for the last four seasons.

title: Nixon Sees Khatyn, A Soviet Memorial, Not Katyn Forest
description: The World War II guerrilla memorial at Khatyn, to which President Nixon was taken yesterday, is not to be confused with the Katyn Forest, scene of the massacre of about 10,000 Polish officers during the war.

title: LittleKnown Japanese Wield Vast Power
description: TOKYO, June 29He came into the bare conference room, a chunky man with a rolling gait like a sailor, his graying hair clipped so short that the harsh light glinted from his skull. His vacant eyes masked his thoughts but his manner was direct and simple as he extended his hand, bowed slightly, and said: I am Kodama.

title: Indian Party Nominates Moslem for Presidency
description: NEW DELHI, July 1 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's governing Congress party picked a Moslem politician today as its nominee for the presidency of this predominantly Hindu country.

title: Citicorp Issue Fought
description: The United States League of Savings Associations is urging the Federal Reserve Board to dissuade Citicorp from making its proposed $850million offering of 15year notes with a floating yield. Details on Page 54.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: Roosevelt Results

title: Power and Saintly Purity
description: LONDONAny public man who has ever succeeded in doing anything must be aware of how vulnerable his conduct is to moral judgment. Every biography of a great statesman bears this out. There are always skeletons in the cupboard; always incidents where even the most illustrious and heroic figure behaved with less than total honesty or truthfulness.

title: AirConditioning in Fires Studied
description: Because airconditioning systems have presented increasing problems in spreading of smoke during fires, the City Building Department is requiring builders of and agents for highrise structures to report by July 18 on plans for automatic detectors to shut down such systems at the first indication of fire.

title: LEUCI LISTS BRIBES AMONG HIS CRIMES
description: denied any coverup by his office. However, Mr. Dershowitz is expected to call witnesses today in an attempt to show that the Government knew about Mr. Leuci's broad involvement in crime before Mr. Rosner was sentenced in March, 1973, and concealed the information from the defendant.

title: Sacrilege of Slaying in Church Stuns Black Atlanta
description: ATLANTA, July 1 Churches have always been something extra special in the lives of black Americans, and nowhere more so than in the South.

title: CHARLEY LOFTUS, YALE SPORTS AIDE
description: NEW HAVEN, July 1 Charley Loftus, Yale University's director of sports information for 25 years, died here Saturday at the age of 55.

title: Atlanta Mayor Orders City Flags at Half Staff
description: ATLANTA, July 1Mayor Maynard Jackson has ordered flags flown at half staff in the city until after the funeral of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. at 11 A.M. Wednesday.

title: Upgraded School Is Urged As the Route to Integration
description: A courtappointed special master has recommended that Mark Twain Junior High School in Coney Island be reorganized next year as a special school offering a wide range of courses that would, it is hoped, attract an integrated student enrollment.

title: Springfield Loses Power
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 1 (AP)Transformer trouble in a substation left downtown Springfield and most of West Springfield without electricity for an hour today. The Western Massachusetts Electric Company said it had traced the blackout to a failure of two of the three transformers in a West Springfield substation.

title: Events Today
description: THE BURNT FLOWER BED, a play by Ugo Bettl. Directed by Paul Aaron. Starring Paul Sparer. At the Roundabout Theater, 307 West 26 Street, at 8.

title: Eloise McElhone, 53, Dies; TV Panelist of the 50's
description: Mrs. Eloise McElhone Warwick, who under her maiden name was a radio actress, then a television personality in its early days, died of a heart attack yesterday at her home, 115 East 86th Street. She was 53 years old.

title: Inmate Found Hanged
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., July 1 (UPI)John de Vries, the first man sentenced to death under Texas's new capital Punishment laws, was found hanged this morning in his cell at the Department of Corrections maximum security unit.

title: Theater:Defiant Hanna
description: Shabby, sleazy but defiant, Tom Eyen's anatomy of the New York freak show, Why Hanna's Skirt Won't Stay Down, arrived last night at the Top of the Village Gate. It is in fact twothirds of trilogy by Mr. Eyen called The Three Sisters (from Springfield, Illinois). The geographical note is doubtless introduced to distinguish it from another play of a similar name, but most people would soon sort out the difference by themselves.

title: Savings Associations Oppose Proposed Citicorp Note Issue
description: Attacks by savings bankers on a proposed offering by Citicorp of $850million of 15year notes continued yesterday. The United. States League of Sayings Associations urged the Federal Reserve Board to dissuade Citicorp from making the offering.

title: Officials Rule Out Beef Import Quotas
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Officials at the Department of Agriculture ruled out today any immediate effort to support cattle prices through restramts on beef imports.

title: MOBIL IS INDICTED BY A STATE JURY IN ANTITRUST CASE
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation was indicted here yesterday for alleged criminal violation of New York State's antitrust laws.

title: U.S. Coach Predicts Track Victory Over U.S.S.R.
description: DURHAM, N. C. July 1 (AP)  As American athletes started to arrive today, the coach of the United States track team, which is without some of the nation's top talent, said he thought the Americans would beat their Soviet Union counterparts in this weekend's dual meet.

title: The Tragedy of Peron
description: The supreme tragedy in the life of Juan Domingo Peron is simply stated: By the time he was willing to deploy his undoubted capacity for leadership and his formidable political skills to the task of bringing together a divided and drifting Argentina, it was too late. At 78 and suffering from respiratory illness complicated by a weakened heart, he could work only parttime at the job of President that he had triumphantly regained in a free election landslide last September after eighteen years of exile.

title: STOCKS IN DECLINE ON AMEX AND OTC
description: After being mixed for most of the session, stocks retreated on the American Stock Exchange in the last hour and closed off for the day. A similar situation prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Four New Supertankers Ordered at Yards in U.S.
description: Close to one and a half million tons of new American supertankers, worth slightly more than a halfbillion dollars, are to be built under construction contracts announced yesterday by the Maritime Administration.

title: Maheu Wins Suit Over a Statement By Howard Hughes
description: MAHEU WINS SUIT AGAINST HUGHES pany, the Summa Corporation, was rejected by the jury.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Space  10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: House Votes Interpol Dues,
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The House approved today a 1$40,000 increase to $120,000 for United States dues to Interpol, the international policelorganization with headquarters in Paris. The bill goes to the Senate.

title: Lisbon Concession Hinted on Portuguese Guinea Independence
description: BISSAU, Portuguese Guinea July 1The Governor of Portuguese Guinea says that this territory is already independent in practice, and indicates strongly that Lisbon has dropped its demand for a referendum before indepedence is formally granted.

title: American TV to Carry Nixon Soviet Speeches
description: President Nixon's addresses to the Soviet people today at noon, New York time, and to the American people tomorrow at 7:30 P.M., New York time, will be carried live by all three major television networks. The address over Soviet television today will also be carried live on radio by A.B.C., N.B.C. and C.B.S. Tomorrow's talk, from Loring Air Force Base in Caribou, Maine, will tie carried by the A.B.C., N.B.C., C.B.S. and Mutual radio networks.

title: Big Chicago Bank, Current Pacesetter, Holds 11.8% Prime
description: All moneymarket eyes were on the First National Bank of Chicago yesterday, but that recent pacesetter in interest rates held its prime lending rate at 11.8 per cent, the record level it set last June 24. HowCredit ever, the bank Markets noted in a statement that while the formula of credit market statistics it uses to determine its base lending rate now dictates a, level of 12.07 per cent, it had decided to hold at 11.8 per cent for the time being.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: While the total American military aid to Chile amounted to less than $10 million during the three years of the Allende Government, President Nixon has requested the United States Congress to vote for $20.5 million in military sales credit to Chile in fiscal 1975, above and beyond the money already allotted for military training.

title: School Gets $500,000 Gift
description: CHICAGO, July 1 (AP)Mr. and Mrs. Charles Maliotes of Belmont, Mass., have given $500,000 for a cultural center at the theological school of the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America. Archbishop Iakovos, primate of the archdiocese who announced the gift today, said the gift was the largest ever received by the Hellenic College and Holy Cross Greek Orthorox School of Tech.

title: PENNZOIL LEADERS IN CONSENT PACT
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The chairman and the president of the Pennzoil Company were enjoined in Federal District Court in New York today from further violation of Federal securities laws and, with the Choctaw Corporation, were ordered to surrender $108,125 to former Pennzoil stockholders.

title: MOTOR UNIT SOLD BY BANGOR PUNTA
description: The Bangor Punta Corporation, which has been experiencing cash flow difficulties, announced yesterday that it had sold Its Waukesha Motor Company division and selected assets of its Waukesha's Clinton, Iowa, plant to Dresser Industries, Inc. Although terms of the purchase were not disclosed, it was understood that the price exceeded $10million, David W. Wallace, chairman of Bangor Punta, said that regardless of the effect on Bangor Punta's 1974 net income as a result of the disposal and discontinuance of its Waukesha division, the transaction should be considpred as a step to strengthen the company's financial position.

title: Rich and Poor at Seabed Parley Debate Way to Exploit Minerals
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 1Proposals for an international seabed authority have become a muchcontested issue at the United Nations Conference on the Law of the Sea, now in its second week here.

title: Why So Few Women Hold Apprenticeships
description: A Government agency recently published a routine monograph that might have gone unnoticed among the glut of reports and handouts, except for one thing.

title: Maine Farmers See Aid in Beef
description: MEDDYBEMPS, Me.Git along little dogies will soon resound through the lonely hills of Washington County, the nation's easternmost county and one of its most persistent poverty pockets, if Federal and state farm officials have their way.

title: An ExpressBus Strike Affects 30,000 in Bronx
description: About 30,000 Bronx passengers had to shift to local buses and subway trains yesterday when 400 drivers and maintenance workers who provide express service went on strike against two bus companies.

title: U. S. Govt. and Agency Bonds
description: Business Records

title: Exxon Loses Bid to Halt Fuel Allocation Program
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr. of United States District Court here refused today to issue a preliminary injunction suspending the Federal allocation program under which 15 major oil companies are obliged to sell crude oil to independent and small refiners.

title: Mets Beat I.L. Nine
description: RICHMOND, July 1 (AP)Don Hahn's infield out scored Ted Martinez from third base in the fifth inning with what proved to be the winnig run as the New York Mets posted a 21 victory over the International League AllStars tonight.

title: F.B.I. Aides Silent on Criticism In Handling of Hearst Abduction
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July1 (UPI) The Federal Bureau of Investigation refused todaytocornment on published reports accusing the bureau of having mishandled the investigation, of the Patricia Hearst kidnaping.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System has awarded the Babcock & Wilcox Company $46.8million contract for a nuclear steamsupply system rated at 1,250megawatts capacity for its fourth unit on the Hanford Reservation in Eastern Washington. Combustion Engineering received $58.2million contract for a 1,240megawatt nuclear system for the fifth unit at the project.

title: Market Place: Margin Trading Posing Problems
description: The Damon Corporation debacle was played to its logical conclusion yesterday following a Friday trading halt to let investors absorb a disappointing earnings report.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In only three weeks, a legend already has evolved that Mike Schmidt hit a baseball so high and so far, scraped the roof of the Houston Astrodome, the colossus that Texans like to think is inches short of the sky. But the legend is not only not true, it's probably not humanly possible. The roof is 208 feet above the playing surface. But what the 24yearold third baseman of the Philadelphia Phillies did do on June 10 was hit Claude Osteen's fastball so high and so far, the Astros centerfielder, Cesar Cedeno, retreated to the wall to view Sports the apparent home run. The ball, after soaring about 340 feet in the air, crashed of into a publicaddress speaker box 110 feet The Times above straightaway center field. It dropped straight down, landing about 325 feet from the plate. Had the speaker box not been there, the Astrodome's amateur engineers estimate that Mike Schmidt would have had a home run of more than 500 feet, possibly 600 feet. Instead, he had a groundrule single. That ground rule has been mentioned by the umpires at each pregame conference since the Astrodome opened in 1965, but it never had to be invoked before. It probably won't have to be invoked again. Moments after Mike Schmidt's satellite landed against it, the speaker box was raised 173 feet.

title: Johnson & Johnson Acquiring Realty
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 1Johnson & Johnson, the New Brunswickbased manufacturer and worldwide marketer of pharmaceuticals and healthcare products, disclosed today that it had invested more than $1.5million toward the purchase of real estate in downtown New Brunswick.

title: Yankee Records
Britain Is Warned on OilPrice Impact
description: LONDON, July 1A prestigious economic advisory body warned today that the sharp increase in oil prices would mean major changes in British lifestyles for years to come.

title: JAWORSKI BACKS NAMING OF NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Leon Jaworski said today that the, Watergate grand jury had named President Nixon as an unindicted coconspirator so that any evidence he might have would be admissible in )any trial of members of the alleged conspiracy.

title: Construction Worker Dies
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 1 (AP)Fate Grimes, a construetion worker, plunged to his death today from the 10th story of a new apartment project, the police said.

title: Delay on Court Bill Voted
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) The House approved today a bill delaying for one year proposed amendments to Federal rules of criminal procedure. Many of the amendments proposed by the Supreme Court governing Federal pretrial and trial procedure are controversial and require more time for hearings and analysis, the House Judiciary Committee said in a report.

title: PERON DEAD AT 78; WIFE TAKES OVER A DIVIDED NATION
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 1President Juan Domingo Pern of Argentina, one of the most remarkable and controversial political figures in LatinAmerican history, died today at the age of 78. His death left his politically divided country in a state of deep uncertainty.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Juan Domingo Peron of Argentina, one of the most controversial political figures in Latin American history, died in Buenos Aires, reportedly of heart disease, at the age of 78. The announcement of his death was made by his wife, Vice President Isabel Peron. She assumes the presidency, becoming the first woman chief of state in the Americas. [1:78.]

title: Gibson Is Sworn; A Black Is Elected Council President
description: NEWARK, July 1  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson called for an end to cynicism about the future of this city as he was sworn in today to his second fouryear term.

title: Marty Snyder, Restaurateur, Eisenhower's Mess Sergeant
description: Marty Snyder, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower's mess sergeant in World War II, died of a stroke Sunday in Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in West Nyack.

title: Irked Faithful Among 23,192 at Aqueduct
description: The 5 per cent bite imposed yesterday on offtrack betting had beneficial repercussions for Aqueduct. The turnout of 23,192 was much better than the average for a Monday, and among those who showed up were many who had been in regular attendance at the OTB parlors around the city.

title: Chavez Gets Pledge of Support From Labor Leaders in State
description: WOODBRIDGE, July 1Caesar Chavez, the president of the United Farm Workers Union, asked for and received pledges of support today from New Jersey labor leaders on behalf of their unions for a boycott of West Coast Iceberg lettuce and California grapes, which, he says, are harvested under poor conditions by underpaid and overworked migrant workers not represented by the U.F.W.

title: House Votes Extension Of Eximbank for 30 Days
description: WASHINGTON, July 1The House voted (today to extend the life of the ExportImport Bank for 30 days pending passage of more permanent legislation.

title: Four Are Killed in Crash Of a Small Plane in Ohio
description: LORAIN, Ohio, July 1 (AP) Edward F. Johnson, a former automobile racing driver and his wife, Shirley, were among four persons killed in the crash of a light plane near Grafton during a rainstorm last night.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth.
description: FIRST$4,500, cl., mdns, 3 and 4YOs, ???.

title: Daths
description: ADLERB. George, of 1880 Palmer Ave., Larchmont, N. Y., on July I, 1974. Be. loved husband of Beatrice G. Adler, De. voted tallier of Jack T. & Paul M. Adler. Dear brother of Beulah F. and Jerome T. Adler. Loving grandfather of six. Services at the Geo T. Davis Memorial, 14 Lc. Count Pb., New Rochelle, N. Y., 10 A.M. Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, contribuflans to the Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Town of Mamaroneck, N. Y., would be appreciated.

title: Councilman Indicted
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) A Federal grand jury returned today a six count indictment against Isadore Bellis, a member of the City Council, The indictment charges that Mr. Bellis failed to report total of $86,513 in income earned during, 196868.

title: Great Adventure Park Opens Gates in Jersey
description: JACKSON, N.J., July 1Lions and tigers, herds of elephant and giraffe, the world's largest ferris wheeldecorated to glow in the night sky with 20,000 lights a steam carousel and bumper cars. Chariot races, skydivers, clowns and magicians.

title: JAWORSKI BACKS NAMING OF NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 1Leor Jaworski said today that the Watergate grand jury had named President Nixon as are unindicted coconspirator so that any evidence he might lave would be admissible in any trial of members of the alleged conspiracy.

title: 24 Needless Deaths
description: Officials of Westchester County and of the village Port Chester have the duty and responsibility not only to fix the causes of the fire that took 24 young lives early Sunday morning, but to determine how this terrible tragedy might have been avoided. If Gulliver's, the night club consumed in such sudden flame and smoke, was not in violation of any law or ordinance, then it is obvious that present laws and ordinances are totally inadequate.

title: Testimony Is Read At Trial of Brasco As a Witness Balks
description: Testimony that a reputed Mafia member gave last February at the first trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco was read to the jury yesterday at the second trial of the Brooklyn Congressman in Federal District Court here.

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Juan Domingo Peran of Argentina, one of the most controversial political figures in Latin American history, died in. Buenos Aires, reportedly of heart disease, at the age of 78. The announcement of his death was made by his wife, Vice President Isabel Perth. She assumes the presidency, becoming the first woman chief of state in the Americas. [1:78.]

title: Turks Lift Ban on Poppy Culture Imposed in 1971 at U.S. Request
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 1 (UPI)Turkey today lifted her ban on cultivation of the opium poppy, once the main source of illegal heroin on the United States market.

title: Great Adventure Is Open for Business
description: JACKSON, July 1Lions and tigers, herds of elephant and giraffe, the world's largest ferris wheeldecorated to glow in the night sky with 20,000 lightsa stream carousel and bumper cars.

title: Canadian Bank Lifts, Rate
description: MONTREAL, July 1(ReutersThe Royal Bank of Canada raised its base interest rate for lending United States dollars in Canada today to 13 per cent from 12.5 per cent, effective tomorrow. The bank said the action was prompted by ruing interest rates that it must pay on dollar deposits.

title: Rumania Cets $60Million
description: LONDON, July 1 (Reuters). The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development said today it was lending Rumania $60million for 15 years at an interest rate of 7 per cent annually, with a 4.5year grace period. The loan, the world bank's first to Rumania, will go toward the construction of a $200million fertilizer plant at Tecuci, in Galati province.

title: Treasury Bills Mixed At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 The rates of Treasury bills mixed today as the Government borrowed a total of $4.5billion at its weekly sale of shortterm securities. The average rate on threemonth bills was the lowest since early March.

title: Norman Singer Leaving As City Center Director
description: Norman Singer will step down as executive director of the City Center of Music and Drima on Sept. 1, after six years with the cultural center that is the parent organization of five constituents, including the New York City Ballet and the New York City Opera.

title: 2 IN GALLO'S GANG SHOT IN BROOKLYN
description: Shots from a passing automobile wounded two reputed hoodlums standing on the sidewalk in front of the Henryville Social Club at 3905 Fort Hamilton Parkway in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn early yesterday afternoon.

title: Times Picks Ad Executive.
description: The New York Times has announced that Carol Neuman has been appointed transportation advertising manager. She joined the newspaper last January from Doyle Dane Bernbach, where she had been an associate media director.

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: BIG WHEELS The Jazzmobile is hardly a novelty these days, but it may be difficult to believe that this summer marks the 10th year of the rolling jazz presentations that bring the country's top musicians into the streets of New York. With the Newport Jazz Festival restricting its own action this week mostly to central locations in Manhattan, the Jazzmobile is more welcome than ever in the city's neighborhoods.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RIDGEFIELD PARK, July 1Things just won't be the same at Ridgefield Park High School next fall because Frank Bell won't be around. After 32 years as athletic director and coach, Bell retired last Friday.

title: Highs and Lows
description: New York Stock Exchange

title: Atlantic Challenge
description: The French tenyear oilpayment deal with the Shah of Iran for the sale of $4 billion of industrial equipment and technology, including five large nuclear power reactors, dramatizes the dangers of division and rivalry that still threaten the Atlantic Alliancedespite the pious pledges of consultation, unity and joint action in the new Atlantic Declaration signed in Brussels.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: U.S. Record Set in Sales Of Stockpiled Materials
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 (Reuters)  The General Services Administration said today record had been established in sales of surplus strategic stockpile materials during the fiscal year ended June, 30.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TOKYO, July 2 (UPI)About 100 top golfers, including 40 Americans, will compete in the third annual $300,000 Pacific Masters golf tournament Oct. 10 through at the Sohbu Country Club course in nearby Chiba Prefecture.

title: Upgrading the Schools
description: The timing for the announcement of a major plan cooperation between City University and the public schools could not have been more auspicious. The conclusion of a generally encouraging academic year is the appropriate moment to launch an action program that assigns to the colleges permanent responsibilities for the upgrading of the high schools.

title: JACKSON HAS TALKS WITH CHINESE AIDE
description: PEKING, July 2 (Reuters)Senator Henry M. Jackson met for more than two hours today with Deputy Foreign Minister Chiao Kuanhua, one of the most influential figures in Chinese foreign affairs.

title: ARMY RESTUDYING BIG CARGO COPIER
description: WASHINGTON, July 2In 1970 the Army embarked upon an austere $80million program to develop the technology for a huge cargocarryidg helicopter. Four years later the technology has still not been proved, but the program has expanded to $250million, two flying models and an ultimate investment of more than $1billion.

title: HOUSE VOTES A BILL ON JUVENILE CRIME
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The House has passed and sent to the Senate a bill authorizing $480million to deal with problems of juvenile delinquency and runaway youths.

title: Jimmy Smith Displays Virtues of Jazz Organ
description: The Newport Jazz Festival's Jazz on the Hammond program at Carnegie Hall Monday night turned into something of a rout. Not that the five worthies who preceded Jimmy Smith  Wild Bill Davis, Jack McDuff, Don Lewis, Shirley Scott and Charles Earlanddidn't have their varying virtues. It was just that Mr. Smith's preeminence was so evident that it was hard after the event to remember anybody but him.

title: Marketplace Picture Awry. For Polaroid
description: When the Polaroid Corporation designed the SX70 electronic camera, the battery powering this remarkable picturemaking system was tucked into the individual film packages.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Agreement on a limitation of underground nuclear tests has been reached, but the summit talks with President Nixon have reached no breakthrough on controlling offensive weapons systems, Leonid I. Brezhnev indicated at their final Kremlin banquet. While Mr. Nixon's toast stressed their personal relationship, Mr. Brezhnev's emphasized hopes for the good relations of the Soviet and American peoples. [1:8.]

title: American Stock Exchange Transactions: Complete Price Summary of Yesterday's Trading
description: American Stock Exchange Transactions: Complete Price Summary of Yesterday's Trading

title: Nixon, on Soviet TV, Sees Positive Stake in Peace
description: In a speech over Soviet radio and television, Mr. Nixon said of his current visit that we have been able to meet this year, as we will meet again next year, not in an atmosphere of crisis, but rather in an atmosphere of confidenceconfidence that the work we have embarked on is going forward.

title: Mets Set Back Phillies, 42; Seaver and Jones Are Stars
description: Little Sheba never did come back, but Big Toni reappeared at Shea Stadium last night as the Mets heat the Phillies, 42, in the opener of a fourgame series.

title: Candidate Faces Tax Trial
description: DETROIT, July 2 (UPI)Mary E. Taylor, a Washtenaw County Commissioner and candidate for State Representative, will go to trial for, listing tax dependents representing the people of Indochina. The 30yearold woman, who is married but childless, claimed more than a dozen exemptions on withholding tax certificates filed with employers. She was arraigned yesterday in United States District Court and stood mute before a magistrate who entered a plea of not guilty for her and ordered a trial.

title: Open Interest
description: Open Interest

title: New Jersey Sports Yanks at Henley
description: The crew of Holy Spirit High School (Absecon, N. J.) had more trouble getting its boat out of London's Heathrow Airport than winning the qualifying race for the Henley Regatta.

title: Canada Film on Jewish Life Takes First at Berlin Fete
description: BERLIN, July 2  Canada's The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz, a comedy directed by Ted Kotcheff, was awarded the Golden Bear grand prize today at the close of the 24th international film festival in West Berlin. The film depicts Jewish family life in Canada.

title: U.S. CoverUp on Leuci Alleged By Lawyer Convicted of Bribery
description: Attorneys for Edmund A. Rosner, a lawyer who was convicted in 1972 of bribing Detective Robert S. Leuci to obtain secret court documents, yesterday criticized the Government for allegedly covering up accusations by a police informant that he was engaged in extensive drug dealings with the detective.

title: Text of Nixon's Address and Tosts by Him and Brezhnev
description: Following is a transcript of President Nixon's address to the Soviet people yesterday as recorded by The New York Times, followed by excerpts from his dinner toast last night, as distributed by The Associated Press, and excerpts from the toast by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, as distributed in English by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

title: Latin Nations of Left and Right, From Cuba to Brazil, Hail Peron
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 Latin Americans from Marxist Cuba to strongly antiMarxist Chile and Brazil paid homage today to the memory of Juan Domingo Peron as a leader of continental reconciliation.

title: Gaylord Perry Cited
description: Gaylord Perry of the Cleveland Indians was named yesterday as the American League's player of the month for June for winning six straight complete games. Perry, a 35yearold rightbander who has not lost since opening day, has a 14.1 wonlost record.

title: Milwaukee Golf Begins a Day Early
description: MILWAUKEE. July 2 (AP) Lee Trevino heads a surprisingly strong field for to morrow's early start in the $130,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: Nastase Toppled By Stockton Of U.S.
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2In the major upset, of the waterlogged Wimbledon tennis championships, secondseeded Ilie Nastase was beaten over four sets by Dick Stockton; who joined Stan Smith and Jimmy Connors to give America three berths in the quarterfinals tonight.

title: W. Germany and Netherlands Favored to Gain World Cup Final
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 2Four World Cup matches will be held tomorrow with the two semifinal games attracting nearly all the attention.

title: The Routine Summit
description: How much progress has been made at the Moscow summit toward a second strategic arms limitation treaty (SALT II) may be revealed in today's communiqu. Apart from that, as President Nixon stressed in his radiotelevision address yesterday, the salient point in this third annual NixonBrezhnev encounter is that it has taken place so routinely  as part of a continuing pattern that would have seemed inconceivable just a few short years ago.

title: Veterans Benefit Checks Held Up Until Nixon Acts
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Benefit checks for about 80,000 veterans are being held up pending President Nixon's decision on a benefits bill.

title: South Korean Sinks Vessel Thought to Be a Spy Ship
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, July 3 (Reuters)A South Korean patrol boat sank a threeton vessel, thought to be a North Korean intelligence ship after a chase off Pusan last night, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: CONSPIRACY LAID TO ARNHOLT SMITH
description: SAN DIEGO, July 2C. Arn holt Smith, the California financier who is a longtime friend and financial backer of President Nixon, today was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of criminal conspiracy and fraud amounting to $170million in the collapse of his $1.5billion banking and industrial empire.

title: Hart Schaffner Posts Earnings Drop
description: Hart Schaffner & Marx, a leading manufacturer of men's clothing and deriving the major portion of sales from companyowned apparel stores, reported yesterday slightly lower earnings for the quarter and six months ended May 31, despite record sales.

title: Assembly Panel Bars Plan To Tax Big Incomes More
description: TRENTON, July 2The Assembly Taxation Committee rejected today a revision of Governor Byrne's state income tax plan that would have levied extra taxes on high incomes. It decided to submit to the full Assembly next Monday the more moderate graduated scale originally proposed by the Governor.

title: Ethiopia's Armed Forces Isolating Haile Selassie
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 2The armed forces movement that has taken power here is gradually isolating Emperor Haile Selassie.

title: Reality in Rhodesia
description: It is hard to understand what Prime Minister Ian Smith hopes to accomplish in Rhodesia by calling new parliamentary elections for this month under the same old restrictive franchise. His announcement that he will also convene a new roundtable conference with all shades of African opinion about Rhodesia's political future is even more baffling.

title: Moscow Stops U.S. TV Transmissions on Dissidents
description: MOSCOW, July 2American television newsmen charged today that the Soviet television network had censored outgoing newscasts on Soviet dissidents.

title: CONSPIRACY LAID TO ARNHOLT SMITH
description: SAN DIEGO, July 2C. Arnholt Smith, the California financier who is'a longtime friend and financial backer of President Nixon, today was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of criminal conspiracy and fraud amounting to $170million in the collapse of his $1.5billion banking and industrial empire.

title: Pro Transactions
description: ATLANTA (NHL)Signed Dean Talafous, canter, to multiyear contract; Pat Ribble, defenseman, fourthround choice In amateur draft, and Jerry Badiuk, defenseman, fifthround choice in amateur draft.

title: P.S.C. Rejects Plea By Con Ed to Speed RateRise Decision
description: ALBANY, July 2The Public Service Commission today rejected a request by the Consolidated Edison Company for an early decision on its request for a permanent rate increase that would yield $422million a year.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: More than 300 people attended a mass for a Roman Catholic priest whose body was found bound and gagged last week following an apparent robbery in a North Carolina rectory. The services for the Rev. Francis T. Donaliue, 64 years old, were conducted by the superior general of the Trintarian Fathers, the Rev. Stephen Quinn, at the Shrine of St. Joseph in Stirling, where Father Donahue had been stationed on and off for more than 20 years. Twentyseven priests concelebrated the mass with Father Quinn.

title: Newport Jazz
description: In the two years that the Newport Jazz Festival has included an evening at the Roseland Ballroom in its programing, the event has been approached in two different ways that have produced decidedly different results.

title: EnergyPolicy Harmony
description: PARIS, July 2 The major industrial powers have achieved certain modest progress in concerting their energysupply policies to try to establish more stable arrangements with oilproducing countries. Under the Economic impetus of SecreAnalysis tary of State Kissinger, an Energy Coordinating Group of 12 nations was set up last February. But E.C.G. looked like just more alphabet soup for the international bureaucracy.

title: Ousted Camden Council Chief Sees Plot
description: CAMDEN, July 2John R. Marini, who yesterday became the first City Council President in Camden history to be voted out of the office by his fellow Councilmen after serving only a oneyear term, said in an interview today that Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti had blocked his reelection.

title: Nastase Is Toppled By Stockton Of U.S.
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2In the major upset, of the waterlogged Wimbledon tennis championships, secondseeded Ilie Nastase was beaten over four sets by Dick Stockton; who joined Stan. Smith and Jimmy Connors to give America three berths in the quarterfinals tonight.

title: U.S. Sets Safety Standards for Bicycles as Sales Boom
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Federal Government issued mandatory safety standards today for bicycles, which are outselling automobiles now and are said to be involved in more than a million injuries a year.

title: Guatemala, Honduras Join Coffee Export Halt
description: MEXICO CITY, July 2 (UPI) Guatemala and Honduras today suspended all coffee exports, joining other area producers in halting trading until the current decline is reversed.

title: $500,000 TO AID SUITS ON SCHOOLS
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 2Officials of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Pdople announced today that grants totaling $500,000 had been pledged to break the back of Northern segregation in urban school systems within two years.

title: Indians Keeping Up Hot Pursuit of First
description: The secondplace Cleveland Indians put more pressure on the firstplace Boston Red Sox in the American League Eastern Division race last night with their fourth straight victory, by 53 over the visiting Milwaukee Brewers.

title: Business Records
description: JAMES DENNIS ALLEN, also known as James D. Allen, 24 Sterley Ave., Saugerties, N.Y. Liabilities, $43,534; assets, $39,420

title: State Accuses Illinois Company Of Defrauding 386 of $400,000
description: TRENTON, July 2 (AP) The state charged today that an Illinois company and its New Jersey affiliates had defrauded 386 New Jersey residents of $400,000 through a fraudulent sales scheme.

title: CITY CENTER AGREES ON USHERS PAY PACT
description: The City Center of Music and Drama and Local B183 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes have reached an agreement on a new twoyear contract covering ushers and ticket takers employed at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center.

title: Bridge:
description: Nearly all experts are sensitive about their reputations and welcome favorable publicity. If they make a fine play, they like to receive credit for it, even if they know, in their heart of hearts, that no credit is deserved. The honesty prize for 1975 goes to Howard Schenken of New York, whose reputation stands so high that no publicity is needed.

title: NIXON, BEND AGREE TO REDUCE SOME ARMS AREAS
description: MOSCOW, July 2Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said today that he and President Nixon had agreed on a limitation of underground nuclear testing and on a lower ceiling for defensive missile systems. But he indicated that a breakthrough on controlling offensive missile systems had eluded them.

title: Aid to Philadelphia Planned
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that the Department of Transportation would make available nearly. $96million for three bicentennialrelated projects in Philadelphia. The projects include a pedestrian mall in the Chestnut Street area, a highspeed rail line between the city center and the Philadelphia International Airport, and improvements for the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority.

title: Family's Yacht Sinks in Gulf; Sharks Kill Child, a 2d Drowns
description: TYNDALL AIR FORCE BASE, Fla Tuly 2 (UPI)  A Coast Guard plane found family of seven clustered around a single life preserver in the Gulf of Mexico today, menaced by sharks. Two small boys died before they could be brought to shore.

title: Cinerama Gets Extension On Repayment of Debt
description: Cinerama, Inc., has received an extension on repayment of $18million, of its $39million debt that matured Juy 1, William R. Forman, chairman and president said yesterday. The company previously announced an agreement with creditors to defer until Dec. 30 the payment of $21million of debt, which, had been due July 1. An additional $4.8million is due by the end of 1974.

title: A SpareTire Policy  Without Change
description: WASHINGTONShould Vice President Gerald Ford ever be propelled to the White House by fate, an implacable Congress or the blind goddess of justice he would continue to apply United States foreign policy along present lines and would do everything in his power to retain Henry Kissinger as Secretary of State.

title: RODIN UNIT HEARS NIXON INTERVENED IN OFFICE DETAILS
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The House Judiciary Committee reportedly heard today testimony that President Nixon paid close attention not only to grave policy matters but also to the most minute details of White House business.

title: OFFICER INDICTED IN HIREDGUN CASE
description: A special state grand jury indicted a city police officer yesterday on charges that hel conspired to pay a hired killer to carry out a contract to murder a man described by lawenforcement authorities as an underworld figure in Harlem.

title: DRUG CENTER WINS EVICTION REPRIEVE,
description: Four Appellate Division justices unanimously allowed drugcontrol program yesterday to move back  at least temporarily  to the ornate town house at 35 East 68th Street from which it had been evicted by a lower court's order a month ago.

title: Mr. Nixon's Moscow Message
description: President Nixon is a great admirer of Woodrow Wilson, and when he goes abroad he tends to speak in the heroic idiom of the most eloquent American President of this century. This was evident in Mr, Nixon's television address from Moscow.

description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 2Four World Cup matches will be held to morrow with the two semifinal games attracting nearly all the attention.

title: Suspect's Friend Hunted In Slaying of Mrs. King
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 2The Dayton police and the F.B.I. were searching today for a close friend of a man charged with killing Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. The man, sought for questioning in connection with the killing, was identified as Walter E. Brooks Jr., an associate of Marcus Wayne Chenault.
