title: VICTIMS PARENTS PLAN A CRUSADE
description: VALHALLA, N.Y., July 2 As the Westchester Medical Examiner's office worked tonight to finish the identification of the 24 persons who died in Sunday morning's fire in a Port Chester singles bar, parents of two of the victims talked of a parents crusade for safeguards against similar tragedies in the future.

title: Canada Grants Dancer a Year's Stay
description: OTTAWA, July 2  Mikhail Baryshnikov, the Soviet ballet star who fled from the visiting Bolshoi company of Moscow in Toronto over the weekend, has been granted a special permit by the Ministry of Immigration that will allow him to stay in Canada for a year.

title: People and Business
description: Insurance companies were active on the management front yesterday with the Travelers Corporation announcing two new executive vice presidents, four new senior vice presidents as well as the establishment of a new corporate office for policy and operations and Metropolitan Life Insurance Company naming a new director.

title: Suffolk Vandalism of Black Family Under Inquiry
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., July 2The Suffolk County police searched for suspects today in the vandalism last weekend at the home of a black family that had just moved into a mostly white residential area here.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: 1974, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: DryDocked Fiddler Is Lombardo's New Flagship
description: Guy Lombardo, the unlikely Jones Beach impresario who succeeded where Billy Rose quailed and Mike Todd paled, has started his 20th year as producer of seaside summer spectaculars.

title: 'SMALL OILTAX RISE SEEN IN VENEZUELA
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 2 (UPI)  Venezuela's proposed tax rise for United States and foreign oil companies will be very small and aimed at adjusting prices to the level of Arab oil rather than cutting into alleged excess company profits, high Government sources said today.

title: Y.W.C.A. to Shut Last 3 City Residences
description: The Young Women's Christian Association, citing rising costs and changing mores, announced yesterday that it was closing its last three residence facilities in the city.

title: Price Waterhouse Retained As Commonwealth's Auditor
description: Courtappointed coreceivers of the Commonwealth Corporation, a Floridabased mortgage banking company, announced yesterday that Price Waterhouse & Co. had been retained to perform a complete audit of the firm.

title: About New York
description: The people were standing on the deck of the Cornelius G. Kolff in bright sunshine yesterday, staring as they always do at lower Manhattan. The Cornelius G. Kolff is a ferry, 290 feet long, and it is named after the man who, among other things, founded the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce. This ferry is not meant to be especially romantic, but like all Staten Island ferries, it is.

title: On Communism and the Camps
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  Communists are unable to free themselves from their greatest disgrace, the concentration camps. Even when they abolish them, they justify them by the necessity of the given stage of development. Stated another way, the revival of camps cannot be excluded from consideration, for it could happen again to the rulers that there is a similar necessity at some new stage of development.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: Money

title: Williams Returns and Sales of Angels Tickets Are Winging
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 2 The return to baseball of Dick Williams, so abruptly realized in the last few days, made vivid two longknown truths: that baseball is, indeed, a cult of the personality, and that major league baseball is a remarkably inbred society.

title: Books of The Times
description: Frederick Forsyth's latest documentary thriller, The Dogs of War, gets off to promising start. A mineralogical Survey lands on the desk of a British tycoon, Sir James Manson, revealing to his eyes only that a certain mountain in the small West Africa coastal kingdom of Zangaro contains a vast fortune in platinum deposits. Learning that Zan garo is ruled by a maddog dictator marginally under the influence of the Russians, Sir James conceives a grandiose scheme. He decides to hire a small army of mercenary soldiers to pull off a coup d'etat and install a puppet who will give Sir James's company mining rights for a token fee. Knocking off a bank or an armored truck is merely crude, Sir James observes to one of his loyal and unscrupulous henchmen. Knocking off an entire republic has, I feel, a certain style. And thus we are off and running in a story that looks to equal in excitement Mr. Forsyth's first novel, The Day of the Jackal, and to surpass his somewhat disappointing second one, The Odessa File.

title: Joseph McCabe Jr., 53, Dies; Brown Harris Stevens Aide
description: Joseph V. McCabe Jr., a mortgage specialist and former vice president of Brown Harris Stevens, the real estate firm, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 53 years old and lived at 126 Brook Street, Garden Ctiy.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: City Held Loser as Volume Falls
description: Howard J. Samuels, former head of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, charged yesterday that the new 5 per cent surcharge on the winnings of OTB bettors was a Government tax incentive for organized crime.

title: Taxes Raised and Pay Cut As Israel Battles Inflation
description: JERUSALEM, July 2The new Government of Premier Yitzhak Rabin announced Sweeping economic measures today to curtail spiraling inflation and offset the huge deficits accumulated as a result of the October war.

title: Problems Close Some Italian Museums
description: ROME, July 1  The bald notice Chiuso on the locked doors of threestar museums and art galleries will quickly become all too familiar to visitors seeking cultural uplift in Italy this summer. Just today, in fact, Turin's Egyptian Museum, Europe's largest, closed its doors indefinitely only 10 days after Milan's famed Brera Picture Gallery was forced to take the same action. The Turin museum, with 8,000 items on display and twice that number in storage, is second in the world only to Cairo's Egyptian Museum. And the state picture galleries in Bologna and Ferrara have also closed for the summer.

title: Johnny Livingston, the Pilot Who Inspired Seagull Book
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, July 2John H. Livingston, the man who inspired the bestselling novel Jonathan Livingston Seagull, died Sunday at the Pompano Beach (Fla.) Airport soon after completing his last plane ride.

title: Illinois Bank's Arab Venture
description: LONDON, July 2 (Reuters)The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago announced today plans to set up a joint banking venture in Manama, capital of Bahrain, an island in the Persian Gulf. The new subsidiary, to be called Continental Bank, Ltd., will be formed in partnership with Bahrain interests.

title: Reclamation Plan for StripMined Land Stirs Debate
description: DENVERA crucial debate is under way over whether Western coal lands can be reclaimed after they are stripmined. At stake are hundreds, perhaps thousands, of square miles of land in this generally arid and fragile region. The key element in the controversy is water.

title: INVENTORIES ROSE 1.8% DURING MAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 Manufacturers inventories continued to rise strongly in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: People in Sports
description: Tom Weiskopf played with a hairline fracture in his left wrist last week, when he lost the Western open with a collapse on the back nine. The golfer, who left yesterday for England, where he plans to defend his British Open title next week, said he had consulted his physician and Xrays confirmed a hairline fracture of a small bone in my left wrist. They don't know when it happened. It could have been any time in the last couple of weeks.

title: Draths
description: ARMSTRONGHelga Evensen, of 35 Lockwood Ave., Old Greenwich, at the Green with Hospital, on Tuesday, July 2, 1974. Beloved wife of John C. Armstrong. Adored mother of Mrs. Arthur (Karin) Newhouse III, Christine F. Armstrong and Elizabeth Anne Armstrong. Daughter of Captain tar Evensen of Bergen, Norway and sister of Mrs. Karin Boehm of GarmischParten kircken, W, Germany. Services will be held at the First Congregational Church, Old Greenwich, Ct., on Friday, July 5 at 3 P.M. interment private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Cancer Care, Inc., Rosemary Hall Foundation or StoneleighBurnham School.

title: Inquiry Indicates Fire Fatal to 24 Started in Nursery
description: PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 2 The boundary between this New York village and Greenwhich, Conn., assumed a special importance today as investigators appeared more certain that the fire that killed 24 young people here Sunday actually began in Connecticut.

title: Trudeau's Rival Is Running a LastChance Race
description: MONTREAL, July 2Robert L. Stanfield, who has spent six years trying to become the Prime Minister of Canada, faces what is generally regarded here as his last chance in the parliamentary election next Monday.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
description: AUTHORITY BONDS

title: C.I.A. IS CRITICIZED OVER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Central Intelligence Agency's knowledge of the activities of some of the Watergate burglars was more extensive than the agency has publicly acknowledged, according to a report by the Senate Watergate committee's minority staff.

title: NIXON, Male AGREE TO REDUCE SOME ARMS AREAS
description: MOSCOW, July 2Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, said today that he and President Nixon had agreed on a limitation of underground nuclear testing and on a lower ceiling for defensive missile systems. But he in Wcated that a breakthrough on controlling offensive missile systems had eluded them.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX HIT A LiYEAR LOW
description: Prices fell sharply yesterday on both the American Stock Exchange and the overthecounter market as many glamour stocks on the New York Stock Exchange declined.

title: Coker Player of Week
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP)Ade Coker, forward for the Boston Minutemen, was named today North American Soccer League player of the week. Coker was selected for scoring all the points, a goal and an assist, in the Minutemen's 30 victory over the New York Cosmos last Saturday.

title: Johannesen Named to Post
description: Grant Johannesen, the pianist, has been appointed music director of the Cleveland Institute of Music to fill the place left by the death of Victor Bahin in 1972. During the last year, Mr. Johannesen was music consultant and adviser to the institute. He taught there since 1972. Mr. Bahin was director of the Cleveland Institute from 1961 until he died.

title: Where Are the Bright Young Men of the Lindsay Years?
description: They came to City Hall as wunderkinds, mayoral aides fired by a sense of mission, confident and sometimes cocky, imbuing the Lindsay administration with their youthful vitality and antagonizing some with their brashness.

title: Mourners Pay Respects to Mrs. King
description: ATLANTA, July 2  Thousands of persons filed sorrowfully into historic Ebenezer Baptist Church today to pay final respects to Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr., who was killed Sunday when a young black man went on a shooting spree in the church's sanctuary.

title: Deputy Mayor's Assistant Drowns While on Vacation
description: Harold Wade Jr., an assistant to Deputy Mayor Paul Gibson Jr., drowned last weekend in a swimming accident while or vacation in Barbados, the West Indies, a spokesman for Mayor Beame's office reported yesterday.

title: FRAUD CHARGE LAID TO DALLAS INSURER
description: DALLAS, July 2 (AP)Top officials and auditors of the Republic National Life Insurance Company of Dallas have been named by the Securities and Exchange Commission in a case that the agency says involves massive and serious violations of the securities laws.

title: Red Smith
description: For the first time in many years, Charley Loftus was absent from New Haven last weekend. He left town Saturday by the only route still open to him. Charley died, apparently of a'heart attack. He was 55 years old.

description: Cash Prices

description: NEWS INDEX

title: Skitch Henderson Indicted on Taxes
description: Skitch Henderson, the pianist, composer and bandleader, was indicted here yesterday on charges of tax evasion involving a $350,000 deduction that he claimed for music scores that he donated to the University of Wisconsin.

title: Patriots Sign Aide
description: PDXBORO, Mass., July 2 (AP)  The New England Patriots announced today the signing of J.I. Albrecht, former general manager of the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League, as an executive assistant in the National Football League club's personnel department.

title: Typhoid. Case in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, July 2 (UPI)The State Department of Health said today it had received the first report of typhoid fever in Connecticut this year. The Health Commissioner, Dr. Douglas S. Lloyd, said the illness had been detected in a Bridgeport woman who had just returned from overseas. This has been the case in most of the other 36 typhoid cases reported in the state in the last 10 years.

title: LEFRAK CHARGES OILGOUGING PLOT
description: The Lefrak Organization, the city's largest private landlord, filed a $115million damage suit yesterday against six major oil companies, charging them with conspiring to control the supply and rig the price of heating oil.

title: TV: CBS Begins Variety and MiniHistory Shows
description: Tonight at 8 o'clock CBSTV turns over its rotating Wednesday slot to Tony Orlando and Dawn, which will run for the month of July, following last month's Bobbie Gentry's Happiness Hour. Tomorrow night, July 4, the network will begin its twoyear series of Bicentennial Minutes, oneminute American history spots that will run every night through July 4, 1976.

description: Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Jersey City's Council Rejects Oil Refinery on Garbage Dump
description: JERSEY CITY, July 2The City Council unanimously rejected today a zoning variance that would have permitted the construction of a large oil tank storage and refinery complex on a sprawling garbage dump on the western edge of the city.

title: Italian Designers Look Backward And They're Calling It Progress
description: Four designers who helped in the nineteensixties to shape Italian modern into a style characterized by spontaneity, exuberant color, wit and technological innovation have switched gears in the nineteenseventies and are unabashedly looking backward,

title: Ford Raises Prices $58, Citing Higher Steel Cost
description: DETROIT, July 2 (UPI) The Ford Motor Company today raised prices of its cars and trucks an average $58, the second of the United States auto makers to change price tags since steelmakers increased their charges last week.

title: LEGISLATOR HELD ON FRAUD CHARGE
description: ELIZABETH, July 2The Union County Prosecutor's office today charged Assemblyman Arnold J. D'Ambrosa, Democrat of Union, with fraud and embezzlement in connection with the sale of property owned by the city of Railway.

title: 3 Small Banks Sue On NOW Accounts
description: Three smalltown commercial banks, charging unfair competition, filed suit yesterday to halt the spread of checking account services by savings banks.

title: Stock Prices Tumble
description: The stock market plummeted 15.56 points on the DowJones industripl average yesterday to reach its lowest level of the year. Glamour and bluechip stocks were among the hardesthit issues. Details on Page 39.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Federal Judge Anthony J. Travia declared a mistrial yesterday in the case against Herbert K. Cronin, a former chief underwriter for the Federal Housing Administration, after the jury reported that it was hopelessly deadlocked. Mr. Cronin, 61 years old, had been charged with conspiring to approve fraudulent appraisals on houses for which applications were pending for insured F.H.A. mortgages. The 12member jury had been deliberating since June 17 the case of Mr. Cronin, who lives at 14 Dartmouth Street in Garden City, L. I. United States Attorney David G. Trager would not comment on the possibility of a retrial.

title: Emotional Throng Mourns Peron as Rites Are Held
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 2 Argentines in vast numbers crowded the streets here today for an emotional farewell to President Juan Domingo Pern, who had a dominant role in the nation's affairs for three decades.

title: Jets and Giants Expect Rookies to Pass Picket Lines Next Week
description: It's Saturday night Aug. 3 and the Jets are in Denver for their first exhibition game. At the same time, the Giants are in Houston for their preseason opener.

They don't know when it happened. It could have been any time in the last couple of weeks,

title: Carey Greeted Warmly By 34th St. Pedestrians
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, who is campaigning for the Democratic nomination for Governor, was greeted in friendly fashion as he made a meetthepeople walking tour of 34th Street during the lunch hour yesterday.

title: Prize to U.S. Violinist
description: Eugene Fodor, a 24yearold violinist from Colorado, shared second prizes in Moscow yesterday with two Soviet musicians in the Tchaikovsky Violin Competition. He is the first Americanborn violinist ever to win this prize. There was no first prize. Page 20.

title: Stock Prices Tumble
description: The stock market plummeted 15.56 points on the DowJones industrial average yesterday to reach its lowest level of the year. Glamour and bluechip stocks were among the hardesthit issues. Details on Page 39.

title: Bangor Punta Payments Set On 2 Preference Issues
description: Directors of the Bangor Punta Corporation declared yesterday the payment of all arrears on its two classes of preference stock on Aug. 5 to record holders July 18. Stockholders of the $1.25 convertible preference stock will receive a total of 62% cents a share to cover the March 15 and June 15 payments. The $2 convertible preference shareholders will receive $1 a share, representing the two 50cent dividends for the same periods.

title: Court Rejects Bid By Imperiale Group To Stop Kawaida
description: TRENTON, July 2 (AP) A state appeals court today rejected appeals by State Sena for Anthony J. Imperiale and two other Newark residents seeking to stop development of the Kawaida Towers apartment project in Newark.

title: Union Pays $300,000 Toward $723,500 Fine
description: A hospital union has paid $300,000 toward a $723,500 line imposed for contempt of court in a oneweek strike last November against voluntary hospitals and homes.

title: SOLOMON SHUFER
description: Solomon Shufer, a realestate broker with offices at 1400 Broadway, died Monday at New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and was a resident for many years of Long Beach, L. I. He is survived by four sans and three daughters.

title: DoubleDecker Buses Returning Here in Test
description: Doubledeck bus service will be revived on Fifth Avenue and Riverside Drive next summer after an absence of more than 20 years, sources in the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: Sawhill Seeks to End Quotas On Residual Oil Used by Utilities
description: WASHINGTON, July 2Federal Energy AdministratorJohn C. Sawhill said today that he wanted to stop allocating supplies of residual oil, a heavy fuel used by electric utilities and industry, because there is no longer a shortage.

title: FED ACTS TO EASE LIQUIDITY PINCH
description: The Federal Reserve bought Government, paper yesterday under the longest repurchase agreements on recordnine daysin an effort to inject liquidity into the extremely tight money market. Normally, the Credit Fed buys GovernMarkets ment obligations from banks, dealers in Treasury paper and other market factors under agreements that the seller buy them back the next day or in, say, three or four days.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium. Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow. Queens, 2:15 P.M. (RadioWHN. 2:15 P.M.)

title: ROLLS ROYCE IN DEAL WITH ALFA ROMEO
description: MILAN, July 2 (AP)Alfa Romeo, S.p.A., the Italian statecontrolled auto maker, announced today plans for a joint venture with Rolls Royce 1971, Ltd., to manufacture small jet engines for planes and hellcopters.

title: RAP BROWN TERM IS CALLED UNFAIll
description: The Federal Court at Nev Orleans has been asked to set aside a fiveyear sentence given H. Rap Brown, the blact activist, on the ground that the Federal Bureau of Investigation set out to destroy him and other black leaders in the summer of 1967.

title: F.C.C. Would Limit Reply Ruling on Ads
description: Richard E. Wiley, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, told an organization of New Jersey broadcasters that the fairness doctrinewhich requires broadcasters to present all sides of controversial issues of public importanceshould not apply to radio and television commercials for standard products.

title: Storytelling by the Theatre of the Deaf, and Some Other Fun for Children
description: Films Plays Dance and Music Exhibitions Miscellaneous

title: Prize to U.S. Violinist
description: Eugene Fodor, a 24yearold violinist from Colorado, shared second prizes in Moscow yesterday with two Soviet musicians in the Tchaikovsky Violin Competition. He is the first Americanborn violinist ever to win this prize. There were no first prizes. Page 20.

title: State Welfare Rolls Rise First Time in 19 Months
description: Discrepancy Explained 60,000 Added to Program

title: Circumventing Folly.
description: Shortly before Nelson Rockefeller's ultrasevere antidrug law took effect last September, State Supreme Court Justice James J. Leff wrote a letter to The Times pointing out that, confronted with the, witchcraft mania of the seventeenth century, some court officials had the courage to speak with sanity and compassion and circumvent the harsh penalties imposed by unjust laws.

title: Dickenson Wields a Witty Trombone
description: Vic Dickenson, a trombonist who is a master of the sly slur and a virtuoso with the rubber plunger mute, has enlivened so many groups led by other jazz musicians that it was  particularly pleasing to find him leading a group of his own yesterday afternoon at one of the free concerts in Pope Auditorium of Fordham University that are part of the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Priest Calls on Rodino To Disqualify Himself
description: BOSTON, July 2 (AP) The Rev. Dr. John J. McLaughlin, a Jesuit White House aide, today called the House Judiciary Committee's chairman, Peter W. Rodino Jr., a crude political tactician and said that he should disqualify himself from the impeachment deliberations.

title: PROF. JOHNSON, 97, WROTE OF SWEDES
description: Prof. Amandus Johnson, a pioneer in historical research about the Swedes in the United States, died Sunday at the Swedish Home for the Aged 20 Bristol Avenue, Staten Is land. He was 97 years old.

title: Events Today
description: Music Dance

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Soldertale, Sweden, I had the pleasure of visiting the SaabScania factory and witnessed the job enlargement program in the engine assembly division. Tom Wicker, in a recent column, wrote about the Volvo plant in Kalmar, Sweden. The Saab experiment preceded Volvo's endeavors by almost four years.

title: Gallo Reprisal Held Motive in Shootings
description: Reprisal against a breakaway movement within the Gallo underworld family was the motive behind the shooting Monday of two reputed hoodlums on a Brooklyn sidewalk, knowledgeable law enforcement authorities believe.

title: Optimist Takes School Board Helm
description: James F. Regan, a captain in the Naval Reserve who feels that the city's educational system has finished the shakedown cruise on decentralization, was elected president yesterday of the new and expanded city Board of Education for a oneyear term. A vice president of the interim school beard that went out of office Sunday, Mr. Regan won out over two former presidents of the board, Joseph Monserrat and Isaiah E. Robinson. Mr. Robinson was elected vice president of the new board.

title: REALESTATE GROUP FACES CONSENT MOVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) The Justice Department filed a proposed consent decree today that would prevene a realestate association and 50 members firms operating in a Virginia Tidewater area from fixing brokerage fees and other pratcices that allegedly violate Federal law.

title: London Level Ends at $138 an Ounce
description: BRUSSELS, July 2 (UPI) The price of gold hit a fivemonth low today. The United States dollar declined on most European markets but reached its highest rate since March in Tokyo.

title: Hill Samuel at Herstatt
description: A prestigious British investment banking group, Hill Samuel, has disclosed that it had entered into a foreignexchange transaction with Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt on June 26, the day the Cologne bank was ordered into liquidation, and has not been paid. Details on Page 46.

title: Catholics Oppose Abortions In Health Insurance Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) Three Roman Catholic organizations urged Congress today to prohibit the inclusion of abortions as a family planning measure in any national health insurance plan it adopts.

title: Philadelphia Politician Slain
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 2 (AP) A south Philadelphia political leader was shot to death last night during an argument with a man who had knocked on his door, the police said. The victim was Vito DiLorenzo, 41 years old, who was the Democratic chairman of the 26th Ward. After the shooting the gunman jumped into a car driven by another man and the vehicle sped off, the police said.

title: FRENCH SOCIALIST Visiting PORTUGAL
description: LISBON, July 2  Francois Mitterrand, the French Socialist leader, arrived here today to give a boost to the Portuguese Socialist movement, which is hard pressed to catch up with the Communists.

title: Dance: American Ballet Theater Sleeping Beauty
description: American Ballet Theater came into the New York State Theater last night, opening a sixweek Lincoln Center season. The program, began wit' Alvin Ailey's The River (which was here dedicated to the memory of its composer, the late Duke Ellington), and then offered The Don Quixote Pas de Deux, Dennis Nahat's Some Times and, the ncvelty of the evening, the first New York performance of the companys new production of Act Three of The Sleeping Beauty.

title: Major League Box Scores and Standings
description: The Way They Stand Today Mets' Records BATTING Yankee Records BATTING

title: Bipartisan Judgment
description: The strong ugly drift toward partisanship in the House impeachment proceeding has gathered steam over the past ftrw days. Last week, rancorous charges were hurled at Judiciary Chairman Peter W. Rodino Jr. On Monday, there was a large Republican vote on the House floor which, despite a bipartisan plea from the Judiciary Committee's leadership, prevented the committee from adopting streamlined rules for expediting the hearings. Finally, there was an almost straight partyline vote on the issue of whether the hearings would be continued behind closed doors. In each instance, the bulk of the Republicans opposed the course proposed by Mr. Rodino.

title: Hill Samuel Discloses Herstatt Deal
description: LONDON, July 21(Reuters) The Hill Samuel Group, Ltd., a prestigious British investment banking group, disclosed today that it, too, had entered into a foreignexchange transaction with Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt on June 26, the same day that the Cologne bank was ordered into liquidation by the West German central bank. Hill Samuel said it had not received payment.

title: Premier in Iceland Quits After Setback To Leftist coalitionevr
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 2 Premier Olafur Johannesson, who took office in 1971 as head of a majority coalition of leftists, resigned today in the wake of a leftist setback in general elections Sunday.

title: Guam Raises Wage Base
description: AGANA, Guam, July 2 (UPI) Gov. Carlos G., Camacho signed into law today a bill increasing the minimum wage on Guam from $2.05 to $2.25 an hour, the highest in the United States. The law on this island, a territory of the United States, will apply to all classes of employes.

title: Highs and Lows
description: New York Stock Exchange

title: HOUSE VOTES AID TO POOR NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The House voted today by a wide margin to approve a United States contribution of $1.5billion over the next four years to the World Bank to aid the world's poorest countries.

title: F.D.I.C. Lists 23 Banks Slated For Payment on Credit Letters
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (Reuters) The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation today listed 19 foreign and four domestic banks eligible to receive payment on standby letters of credit they issued to the United States National Bank, which failed last year.

title: SUBSIDY IS SOUGHT FOR CONGRESS RACES
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) A bipartisan coalition in the House proposed today a partial Federal subsidy to underwrite Congressional political campaigns.

title: Bolding's 48.1 Wins 400Meter Hurdles
description: MILAN, Italy, July 2 (Reuters)  Jim Bolding of the United States ran the second fastest 400meter hurdles in history tonight when he clocked 48.1 seconds at an international track meet here.

title: SETBACKS MOUNT FOR COAST BANKER
description: The indictment yesterday of C. Arnholt Smith on charges of conspiring to misappply $170million in bank funds was the latest in a series of setbacks that have marked the California banker's slide from power in recent months.

title: TEXAS OIL LEASES BRING BONUSES
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 2A new method of bargain sale on state of Texas oil and gas leases brought in dozens of new independent oil companies today, and the Texas School Land Board collected $24,686,. 448 in cash bonuses, even at the reduced prices. It was the largest sale in bonuses collected since 1965.

title: EXF.C.C. AIDE LOSES IOWA CONTEST AGAIN
description: TAMA, Iowa, July 2 (UPI)For the second time in a month, State Representative Stephen Rapp of Waterloo scored an apparent victory tonight in the Democratic race for Iowa's Third Congressional District nomination.

title: Charles Johnson, 79, Dies; Led Union of Carpenters
description: Charles Johnson Jr., president emeritus of the New York District Council of Carpenters, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Decline Here Is Laid to Weakness Abroad
description: Silver prices again slid on the Commodity Exchange yesterday although the drop was not the 20cent limit as on Monday. Sharply lower London gold prices was the reason given for declines both days.

title: U.S. Student Stranded 5 Days in Kenya Desert
description: NAIROBI, Ken ya, July 2 (AP)A young American student working with anthropological expedition in northern Kanya was in fair condition in a hospital here today after spending five days without food or water in the desert near Lake Rudolf, 200 miles north of here. Jeffrey Hammock, 25 years old, of Gales Ferry, Conn., wus working with an expedition under the archaeologist, Richard Leakey, when he became lost.

title: RESERVE OPPOSES CITICORP'S NOTES
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Federal Reserve Board has expressed to the Securities and Exchange Commission its doubts that the unusual new floating interest rate debenture proposed to be offered by the parent holding company of the First National City Bank is in the public interest at this time.

title: Skitch Henderson Indicted on Taxes
description: Skitch Henderson, the pianist, composer and bandleader, was indicted here yesterday on charges of tax evasion involving a $350,000 deduction that he claimed for music scores that he donated to the University of Wisconsin.

title: PROFESSOR FOUND DEAD IN VILLAGE
description: A 53yearold associate professor of English at Pace College was found dead yesterday in his Greenwich Village apartment, the apparent victim of strangler.

title: Taxes Raised and Pay Cut As Israel Battles Inflation
description: JERUSALEM, July 2The new Government of Premier Yitzhak Rabin announced sweeping economic measures today to curtail spiraling inflation and offset the huge deficits accumulated as a result of the October war.

title: ARMY RESTUDYING MG CARGO COPIER
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 In 1970 the Army embarked upon an austere $80million program to develop the technology for a huge cargocarrying helicopter. Four years later the technology has still not been proved, but the program has expanded to $250million, two flying models and an ultimate investment of more than $1billion.

title: G.O.P. Senators Hire a Lawyer for Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP)Senate Republicans have retained a lawyer to help them prepare for an impeachment trial in case the House votes to impeach President Nixon, Congressional sources disclosed today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Dr. King's Mother Honored
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 (UPI) The Board of Supervisors voted today to name the children's clinic at Martin Luther King Jr. Hospital for the slain civil rights leader's mother, who was shot to death on Sunday. the board named the facility the Alberta King Children's Clinic.

title: Prosperous SugarBeet Growers Fear Cloud
description: ELCENTRO, Calif.Hoxsie Smith should be happy. He isn't. So should Fred Jenkins and John Borchard and Jack Fleming. They aren't.

title: Bomb Kills British Soldier
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 2 (Reuters)  A British soldier was killed and two were injured in an explosion near the Irish Republic border tonight, an army spokesman said. They were searching a remote area when they entered an abancloned house, triggering a boobytrap.

title: Threat to Strip Mining Is Seen in House Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Legislation pending in the House could result in a virtual prohibition against strip mining or surface mining of coal, Representative Robert McClory, Republican of Elinois, said.

title: Loftus Funeral Today
description: A funeral service for Charles Randall Loftus, Yale University's former director of sports information who died at New Haven on Saturday, will be held at 2 P.M. today at the Beecher and Bennett Funeral Home, 100 Broadway, New Haven Original plans for a private funeral were changed yesterday.

title: ChinaWatching Hazard
description: HONG KONG, July 2 Imagine for a moment that an authoritarian regime has come to power in the United States and cut it off from normal contact with the rest of the world, erecting what comes to be known as the plastic curtain. Then imagine that small fraternity of America  watchers based in Bermuda suddenly finds itself confronted with reports of fistfights in factories in Detroit and allegations of sexual misconduct in Tennessee. What could they conclude?

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
DUTCH MAY SEEK INDIAN HEAD, INC.
description: The Thyssen  Bornemisza Group of the Netherlands, which now owns 34 per cent of Indian Head, Inc., is considering making a cash tender offer for outstanding shares of Indian Head common stock, Indian Head said yesterday.

title: Kennedy InLaw Accused Over 60c Taxi Fare
description: Stephen Smith, the brotherinlaw of the late President John F. Kennedy, was arrested, handcuffed and charged with theft of services early yesterday, the police said, after he allegedly refused to pay a 60cent taxicab fare.

title: A CONTEMPT PLEA WON BY REPORTER
description: LOS ANGELES, July 2 William Farr, the Los Angeles reporter who has fought threeyear legal battle to protect his news sources, again avoided jail today when a Superior Court judge vacated contempt order against him.

title: 15 Fans Injured At Reds Game
description: CINCINNATI, July 2 (AP) At least 15 persons were injured at Riverfront Stadium tonight when a large glasslike section exploded, showering a sheet of jagged splinters on leftfield fans.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Inquiry Is Asked in Death Of a Prisoner in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 2A group of residents has forced an investigation of the death of a 28yearold man who the police say hanged himself with his shirt in a cell in the jail here.

title: U.S. Govt. and Agency Bonds
description: U.S. Govt. and Agency Bonds

title: GOING OUTGuide
description: RENDER CONTENDER As an art form, architectural rendering has declined quite a lot since the glorious days when it sought to do justice to the heroics of classic revival buildings in the last century. Architects today are more inclined to employ models than drawings. And in architecture schools, students don't recieve as much training in sketching and rendering as they used to.

title: U.S. Violinist Shares Tchaikovsky Prize
description: MOSCOW, July 2Eugene Fodor, a 24yearold violinist from Colorado, shared top honors today with two Soviet musicians in the Tchaikovsky Violin Competition, the first Americanborn violinist ever to win a prize in the event.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: NEW YORK COTTON EXCHANGE Market Averages

title: Nurse Kept Faith During Captivity
description: The American missionary nurse who was kidnapped by Ethiopian guerrillas and then released unharmed 10 days ago said yesterday that faith had kept her calm during the ordeal and that she hoped to return to Ethiopia.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: Horses & Equipment

title: NL in Indonesia Oil Unit
description: N L Industries, Inc., announced yesterday formation of a joint company with an Indonesian company to produce oilwell drilling fluid compounds in that country for its oil drilling industry. The new company, to be known as P. T. Baroid Indonesia, would be 49 per cent owned by N L and 51 per cent by Indonesia International.

title: Claude Jacob, ExOfficer Of American Airlines, Dies
description: Claude W. Jacob, a retired senior vice president of American Airlines, died yesterday at Hilton Head, S, C., where he was vacationing. He was 67 years old and lived in Fort Worth, Tex.

title: Dow Off 15.56 to 790.68; Glamour Issues Plummet
description: A heavy pounding of both glamour and bluechip issues yesterday forced the stock market to its lowest level of the year.

title: Advertising: The Yellow Pages
description: Of course it pleases national advertisers who use the Yellow Pages to know that there are a lot of fingers walking through them, but in these days of ultrasophisticated marketing they also want to know who's at the end of those fingers, how much they make, how do they live, how many kids they have.

title: Contractors Given Racial Hiring Plans In 21 Areas of U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) The Labor Department imposed racial hiring plans today on building contractors in 21 areas of the country.

title: BrandyDuty Cut: Toast to E.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The United States, in a further gesture toward better trade relations with the European Common Market, has decided to reduce the duty on uppermedium grades of imported brandy, mainly from France, it was officially disclosed today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN

title: In the Soviet Union, It's Not the White House Staff That Gives the Orders
description: MOSCOW, July 2  In the United States, White House advance men are noted for going into a city where the President is visiting and ordering virtually everyone around, even the local police. But in the Soviet Union they are at the mercy of the bureaucracy, is is everyone else.

title: Dip in Electric Rates Expected This Month
description: TRENTON, July 2 (AP) Anthony J. Grossi, president of the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, said today that electricity custom: ers of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company would pay slightly less for energy consumed in July.

title: RIVALRY EMERGES IN BORDER PATROLS
description: SAN YSIDRO, Calif., July 2 Rivalry and tensions between United States customs and immigration patrols along the Mexican border have erupted into open acrimony over an Administration proposal to curtail sharply the Customs Bu reau's antismuggling operations.

title: Y.W.C.A. to Shut Last 3 City Residences
description: The Young Women's Christian Association, citing rising costs and changing mores, announced yesterday that it was closing its last three residence facilities in the city.

title: TEACHERS STUDY VIA A SATELLITE
description: In 15 classrooms throughout Appalachia yesterday, a total of 300 teachers watched a color television presentation on how to teach children about adult careers. It was the first instructional television program to be broadcast directly via a space satellite.

title: Young Says Ehrlichman Knew Ellsberg Psychiatrist's Files Would Be Searched
description: WASHINGTON, July 2David R. Young Jr., codirector of the White House plumbers, testified today that he believed that John D. Ehrlichman had specifically authorized the examination of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatric records in 1971 without the knowledge or consent of Dr. Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Business Briefs
description: The delinquency rate on savingsbank home mortgages climbed during the first quarter of 1974, while the foreclosure rate remained steady, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

title: Yankees Drop 6th Straight
description: DETROIT, July 2A fourrun rally in the fifth inning, interrupted only by a flareup involving Manager Bill Virdon and Umpire Larry Barnett, was all the Tigers needed tonight to hand the faltering Yankees their sixth straight defeat.

title: Vietnam Veterans Protest in Capital And Criticize Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) About 200 Vietnam veterans marched through Washington today, chanting demands for improved Federal benefits and demonstrating at the Veterans Administration building and across the street from the White House.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 3, 1974

title: Sports Today
description: Sports Today

title: Mrs. Jessica Wilcox, 83, Former Fashion Consultant
description: Mrs. Jessica Rosengrant Wilcox, mother of Candy Jones, the model and modelagency owner, died Sunday at St. Barnabas Hospital for Chronic Diseases in the Bronx. She was 83 years old and lived at 1199 Park Avenue.

title: Alfred N. Goldsmith Dies at 85; Pioneer in Radio and Color TV
description: Dr, Alfred N. Goldsmith, a worldrenowned electronics scientist, engineer and inventor whose career spanned the early days of radio to the present day of color television and satellite communication, died yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: Pentagon Sees Saigon Aid Cut To Ammunition, Fuel and Parts
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 United States military aid to South Vietnam in the current fiscal year will probably be limited by Congressional budget cuts largely to ammunition, petroleum and spare parts, Pentagon officials said today.

title: W.E. Hutton and Thomson & McKinnon in Talks
description: Having lost $2million last year and more than $1million this year, the old carriagetrade brokerage house of W.E. Hutton & Co. confirmed yesterday that it was negotiating a merger into Thomson & McKinnon Auchincloss Kohlmeyer.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: Most Active Stocks INSURANCE BANKS AND S & L's MUTUAL FUNDS OTHER BONDS Supplementary OTC

title: MURREL J. ADES
description: Murrel J. Ades, a retired distilling industry executive who had been president of the International Distributing Corporation of Washington, from 1955 to 1967, died Monday in Miami Beach of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: Brokers Group Backs Longer Trading Hours
description: The Securities Industry Association, which represents most of the nation's major brokerage firms, yesterday threw its weight behind a proposed halfhour extension of New York Stock Exchange trading hours.

title: Daylight Time Opposed
description: LANSING, Mich., July 2 (UPI) Gov. William Milliken urged Congress today to abandon the yearround daylight saving time experiment before its scheduled cutoff next April.

title: Screvane Vows to Seek Repeal
description: Business at 131 Offtrack Betting parlors dropped for the second straight day yesterday, leading again to an upswing in attendance and betting at Aqueduct.

title: Holiday Auto Travelers Assured on Finding Gas
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Fourth of July holiday travelers should have little trouble finding gasoline, the American Automobile Association said today.

title: PPG in Furnace Lighting
description: WICHITA FALLS, Tex., July 2 (UPI)PPG Industries today lit the first of two furnaces at its new flat glass plant near here, the company said. The lighting was the first step in a procedure to bring the first float line into production. When the plant is completed by the end of the year, it will have a production potential of about 400 million square feet of glass a year.

title: Contract Awards
description: Texaco, Inc., said yesterday it had purchased three supertankers from the A. P. Moller Group, a Danish shipping company. The ships are of the 285,000ton class and industry sources estimated their total cost at more than $200million. Texaco expects to take over tontrol of the ships in 1975 and 1976.

title: Suspect's Friend Hunted In Slaying of Mrs. King
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 2The Dayton police and the F.B.I. were searching today for a close friend of a man charged with killing Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. The man, sought for questioning in connection, with the killing, was identified as Walter E. Brooks Jr., an associate of Marcus Wayne Chenault.

title: Castro Says Close Voting In Test Necessitates Runoff
description: MIAMI, July 2 (AP)A Cuban experiment, in the secret ballot has resulted in such closely contested races that runoff elections will be necessary, Premier Fidel Castro says.

title: New Forest Hills Coop For Poor Draws 10,000
description: More than 10,000 families have flooded the city's Hous ing Authority with requests to live in the lowincome coopers live nearing completion in the Forest Hills section of Queens.

title: Staff Will Review Watergate Report On Two Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) Senators George McGovern and Hubert H. Humphrey, both Democrats, have complained and won reconsideration of Watergate committee staff reports criticizing their 1972 Presidential campaign finances.

title: Television
Ethiopia's Armed Forces Isolating Haile Selassie
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 2The armed forces movement that has taken power here is gradually isolating Emperor Haile Selassie.

title: C.I.A. IS CRITICIZED OVER WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 2The Central Intelligence Agency's knowledge of the activities of some of the Watergate burglars was more extensive than the agency has publicly acknowledged, according to a report by the Senate Watergate committee's minority staff.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Doubledeck bus service will be revived on Fifth Avenue, Riverside Drive and possibly other routes on an experimental basis next summer, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday.

title: Jets and Giants Expect Rookies to Pass Picket Lines Next Week
description: It's Saturday night Aug. 3 and the Jets are in Denver for their first exhibition game. At the same time, the Giants are in Houston for their preseason opener.

title: CITY MOVES AHEAD ON INDUSTRY PLAN
description: Alfred Eisenpreis, the city's Economic Development Administrator, said yesterday that he expected to have in operation this summer the city's new Industrial Development Corporation, which was authorized by a bill signed into law two weeks ago by Governor Wilson.

title: Warren, 83, Is Hospitalized; Heart Condition Called Fair
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI)  Former Chief Justice Earl Warren was hospitalized today for the second time in six weeks and was reported to be in fair condition with a heart ailment.

title: REBOZO LOSES PLEA TO BLOCK CITATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) A Federal court denied today Charles G. Rebozo's plea for an order barring the Senate Watergate committee from either inquiring further into his affairs or citing him for contempt.

title: Radio
description: 610 A.M., WNCN. Trio Sonata No. 4 in E minor, Bach; Concerto No. 21 in E, Vivaldi; Intermezzo and Dance from La Vida Breve, Fella; Song of the Flea from Trepak, Mussorgsky; Overture to L'Italiana in Alger, Rossini; Sinfonia in E flat, C.P.E. Bach; Overture to Medea in Corinto, Mayr; 11 Lamento d'Arianna, Monteverdi; Concerto Grosso No. 1 in B flat, Handel. 9:06.10, WQXR: Piano Personalities. Murray Perahia and Robert. Silverman. Piano Sonata No. 2, Chopin; Dance Suite. Bartok. 1011, WNCN. Flute Sonata, Hovhaness; Klavierstuecke, Schanerg; Fantasiestuecke, Schumann.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth
description: Today's Entries at Monmouth

title: Capitalism, BrazilStyle
description: RIO DE JANEIROAn accurate profile of Brazil's highly advertised model for economic development would surprise a lot of people.

title: Holiday Regulations In Effect Tomorrow
description: Tomorrow is the Fourth of July and virtually all businesses will be closed, including banks, government offices, stock exchanges, department stores and most retail stores. Sunday parking regulations will be in effect in New York.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN SHORE BUS STRIKE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 2 (UPI) A tentative agreement was reached today to end a labor dispute that has halted Atlantic City Transportation Company bus service to about 10,000 commuters in 18 municipalities in the county.

title: British Scientists Acclaim 100 Years of the Cavendish
description: A century ago the seventh Duke of Devonshire decided to finance construction at Cambridge University of of a small laboratory for research in physics. He named it for his ancestor Henry Cavendigh, who in the 18th century had been able to weigh the earth by determining its mean density.

title: Kretchmer Seeks Murphy's House Seat
description: Jerome Kretchmer, former City Environmental Protection Administrator and former Assemblyman, yesterday announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Congressional seat now held by Representative John M. Murphy of Staten Island.

title: Lebanon Asks Arab Aid to Guard Camps
description: CAIRO, July 3Lebanon and the Palestine Liberation Organization jointly appealed to the Arab countries today for help in protecting Palestinian refugee camps on Lebanese soil against Israeli attacks.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company was awarded $22.1million Navy contract for radio sets, The company also signed a contract with the Indonesian Government for the initial phase of a $350million satellite communications system for that nation. The contract, valued at $800,000, is for feasibility survey for installation of twin synchronous orbiting satellites worth $25million each.

title: Wheatley Heights, Expensive Area of Wyandanch, Wins Battle for Post Office
description: WHEATLEY HEIGHTS, L. I., July 3Herman Griem leaned against the balustrade of his porch and proudly displayed a telegram he had received this week from the United States Post Office in Washington.

description: Shipping/Mails

title: Gaylord Perry Registers 15th Victory in Row, 42
description: Gaylord Perry survived a rain delay of 90 minutes last night in Milwaukee's County Stadium to defeat the Milwaukee Brewers, 42, for his 15th consecutive victory.

title: COURT EDICT LEADS BUFFALO TO DROP 110,000 AS JURORS
description: A State Supreme Court Justice  in Buffalo has discharged virtually the entire prospectivejuror list for that city, effectively eliminating all jury trials in Erie County until at least September.

description: CROSSWORD PUZZLE

title: Miss America: She Always on the Road
description: WINONA, Minn.  There she was, Miss America, there, she was, signing autographs yesterday for farmers kids who blew pink bubblegum bubbles in her face at Choate's Department Store. There she was, posing for pictures with the Rev. Armin Deye, a smiling Lutheran minister who sat on the arm of her throneforaday.

title: Personal Finance: Bank Credit Lines
description: The bank line of credit, traditionally restricted to businesses borrowing funds for their operations, is now being pushed on the personal loan market as a wave of the future for consumer bank borrowing.

title: H.E. W. Tells BirthCurb Clinics To Stop Using the Dalkon Shield
description: WASHINGTON, July 3The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has sent word to more than 3,000 federally funded familyplanning clinics to ston using an intrauterine birthcontrol device called the Dalkon Shield.

title: Beirut Newspaper Writer Reported Kidnapped by 4
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 last night kidnapped Michel Abu Jawdeh of Beirut's influential newspaper An Nahar, police sources said.

title: N.F.L. Owners Ask End Of Strike on Old Terms
description: National Football League club owners countered the Players Association's recent legal move yesterday, filing unfair labor practice charges against the union. They also went one move up by proposing that the union end its strike and proceed under the old agreement.

title: France Divides State TV Network Into Rival Units
description: PARIS, July 3  The French Government announced today that it would divide the nation's threechannel television network into independent, competing units  still controlled by the state.

title: Mrs. Mitchell Institutes Action for a Separation
description: Martha Mitchell started separation suit in State. Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday against her husband, former United States Attorney General John N. Mitchell. Mrs. Mitchell is represented by law firm headed by Melvin Belli.

title: TWO LISBON PAPERS FINED IN CRACKDOWN
description: LISBON, July 3Two leading afternoon newspapers disclosed today that they had been fined in the first official crackdown on the press since severe regulations went into effect a few days ago.

title: Illness Delays Brasco Trial
description: The trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco was recessed yesterday until tomorrow because Judge John M. Cannella was ill. Mr. Brasco, a Brooklyn Democrat, is on trial in Federal District Court here on a charge that he conspired to receive bribes to help a truck company that was controlled by John A. Masiello, who was identified by Federal authorities as a Mafia member. The Congressman's first trial on the charge ended with a hung jury last March.

title: Rise Is $1.6Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) The Federal Reserve Board said today that consumer credf it rose by more than $1.6billion in May, powered by big jumps in lending for automobiles and home improvements.

title: Deaths
description: BERTONMax. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted lather of Naomi Stelnfeld & Cara Berton. Dear brother of Hannah Slander Phillip Mishkin. Services Friday, July 5, 10 A.M., at Garlick's, 1439 Unionport Rd., Parkchester, Bronx.

title: Key Loan Rate Up
description: The prime interest rate to large corporate borrowers was increased by a quarter of a point to a record 12 per cent yesterday by a number of banks across the nation. The move reflects a tightening of available credit in the banking system. Page 25.

title: Hints of Conspiracy in Slaying Of Mrs. King Reported Fading
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 3Suggestions of a possible conspiracy in connection with the slaying of Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. began to break down today.

title: Greentree's Colt Victor In Juvenile
description: Knightly Sport of the Greentree Stable broke from the No. 1 post in the $29,650 Juvenile Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. John Gayer, who trains the son of Sir Gaylord, had misgivings @At the about the inside position, but the @Race colt went on to @I'racks score a convincing victory in the 5furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies. With Jacinto Vasquez riding him, Knightly Sport moved easily through the going, holding down second place to the stretch. There, he sped into the lead and remained in ffont to the wire, beating the runnerup, Ramahorn, by 1 lengths. Next, a head pack, came Bold Gun, who had been made the favorite by the crowd of 18,413.

title: World's TopFlight Modelists Vie at Lakehurst
description: LAKEHURST, N.J., July 3 Lighter than a copper penny and almost invisible, the broadwinged model airplane climbed silently and lazily toward the ceiling of the cavernous dirigible hangar, its rubber banddriven propeller scarcely ticking over.

title: People in Sports
description: The Case of the Yellow Envelope continued to produce charges and countercharges yesterday as Clemson's basketball coach, Tates Locke, denied his school broke any rules trying to recruit Moses Malone.

title: Labor Problems Hurt Chrysler in Europe
description: PARIS, July 3The Chrysler Corporation, the world's third largest auto company, has run into difficult labor problems in Europe that have stirred ??? mors that it wants to discontinue operations in both Britain and France.

title: New Influx of Drugs Seen As Turkey Drops its Ban
description: Federal and local officials said yesterday that they expected the Turkish Government's decision to lift its threeyear ban on the growing of opium to create a significant influx of heroin into New York City.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Is there a better way to measure the length of a warranty than by how long a consumer owns an appliance? Automobiles, for example, have the mileageortime warranty, but appliances carry only time warranties. Should a warranty, for example, be based on how much an appliance is actually used?

title: Hearing Ordered in Dispute On Middlesex Shopping Site
description: TRENTON, July 3 (AP)A state appeals court today ordered a lowercourt hearing to clear up procedural problems in the proposed development of shopping center in the Borough of Middlesex.

title: Free Banking in Britain
description: LONDON, July 3 (Reuters)The Midland Bank, Ltd., announced today free banking for all personal customers who stay in credit or maintain an average credit balance of 50 or more over a sixmonth charging period. The hew policy lakes effect from Julie 1.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GOSHEN, N.Y., July 3 (AP)  Henri Filion, substituting for his older brother, Herve, who broke his ankle in spill in the Debutante Stakes yesterday, won today's Grand Circuit harness racing feature at Historic Track with Devona Hanover.

title: STATE TIGHTENS WASTE DISPOSAL
description: TRENTON, July 3The State Department of Environmental Protection announced new regulations today for disposing solid wastes, to curb water pollution, poisonous gases, toxic deposits and other health hazards.

title: Dow Shows a Gain Despite Increases in Prime Rate
description: The stock market showed signs of recovering yesterday but the announcement of an increase in the prime rate by the Bankers Trust Company smothered the advance.

title: British Bank Branch
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (Reuters)The Bank of America said today it had opened a new retail bank in Reading, England. Bank of America said it plans to open more branches, which will operate under a new company, Bankamerica Finance, Ltd. The subsidiary will be wholly owned by Bank of America through its investment subsidiary the Bamerical International Fancial Corporation.

title: People and Business
description: Terming the Federal budget deficit her pet peeve, the nation's newly installed United States Treasurer, Francine I. Neff, has come up with the notion that the Government print its greenbacks in red. As she watched the first batch of bills bearing her signature come off the presses at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing yesterday, Mrs. Neff said that she had broached the idea at a Treasury Department staff meeting last Friday, and that Mr. Simon thought it was a pretty good idea.

title: ExOfficial Out of Prison
description: MIAMI, July 3 (UPI)John J. Priestes, the first of the men sent to prison in a Federal Housing Administration scandal that led to an investigation of a political fund for Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, returned home yesterday after six months behind bars,

title: SHEET METAL UNION MUST TAKE 40 BLACKS
description: Sheet Metal Workers Union Local 28 has been ordered by Federal District Court judge to accept 40 blacx and Puerto Rican apprentices Ly Sept. 30.

title: SOVIET AGAIN CUTS TV NEWS FOR U. S.
description: MOSCOW, Thursday, July 4 For the second day in a row, the Soviet television station here last night blocked an outgoing American newscast about Soviet dissent.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: Adolf Hitler and the German Trauma: 1913.1945: An Interpretation of the Nazi phenomenon, by Robert Edwin Herzstein (Capricorn Books: Putnam, $7.95).

title: Paul E. Strand, 81, Helped Pitch Braves to 14 Series
description: SALT LAKE CITY, July 3 (UPI)Paul E. Strand, who helped the Boston Braves rise from last place in the National League to the World Series title in 1914, died last night. He was 81 years old.

title: Upsets at Wimbledon
description: John Newcombe and Billie Jean King, favorites in the Wimbledon tennis championships, were upset in the quarterfinals. Newcombe lost to Ken Rosewall and Mrs. King to Olga Morozova. Page 11.

title: Selassie Grants 5 Concessions To Army, Including an Amnesty
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 3 (Reuters)Emperor Haile Selassie today granted five requests put forth by the armed forces, including amnesty for political prisoners, the Ethiopian radio reported here.

title: NIXON, BREZHNEY DECIDE TO SEEK A NEW AM PACT
description: MOSCOW, July 3President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, unable to devise a permanent agreement on limiting offensive nuclear arms, signed a communiqu today committing their countries to negotiate a new interim accord extending to 1985.

description: Horses & Equipment

title: Witness Tells Rodino Unit Of Hunt's Money Demand
description: WASHINGTON, July 3A former lawyer for President on's reelection campaign comJudiciary Committee today the rnittee described for the House early stages of a scheme that led to a $75,000 cash payment last year to one of the original Watergate defendants.

title: U.S. STEEL RAISES ITS PRICES ON TIN
description: The United States Steel Corporation, in its third major pricing move within the last four weeks, announced yesterday that it would raise prices of tin mill products, beginning Aug. 5. United States Steel did not provide a percentage increase, but said that the price advances would add about 1 per cent to annual revenues, which were a little over $7billion last year.

title: Chess: U.S. Team Noses Out Bulgaria For ThirdPlace Medal at Nice
description: The United States won the bronze medal for third place in the International Team Tournament in Nice, France.

title: C.I.A. Agent Said to Give Secrets to Russian in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, July 3A tale of a drunken and despondent C.I.A. agent who apparently sat down with a Soviet K.G.B. operative somewhere in Latin America and told him what he knew has emerged as a result of a Senate Watergate committee inquiry into the activities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: EVE CLENDENIN
description: Miss Eve Clendenln, an artist with works in the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum here and in the Chrysler Museum in Norfolk, Va., died here yesterday. Miss Clendenin, who lived at 150 Central Park South, was 78 years old.

title: Ross to Quit Town Hall
description: Jerrold Ross has resigned as director of Town Hall, effective Sept. 1, to head the arts division of the New York University School of Education. N.Y.U. has owned the midtown concert facility since 1958. Mr. Ms had been fulltime head of the division of music education as well as halftime director of Town Hall; his new position will place him in overall charge of the divisions of dance and art education as well as music education at N.Y.U. Dr. Ross said that a new, fulltime director of Town Hall would be announced this month.

title: Illness Delays Brasco Trial
description: The trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco was recessed yesterday until tomorrow because Judge John M. Cannella Was ill. Mr. Brasco, a Brooklyn Democrat, is on trial in Federal District Court here on a charge that he conspired to receive bribes to help a truck company that was controlled by John A. Masiello, who was identified by Federal authorities as a Mafia member. The Congressman's first trial on the charge ended with a, hung jury last March.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI)The Agriculture Department today purchased 154,000 pounds of frozen ground beef and 417,000 pounds of canned pork for use in school lunch programs, begining a $100million Governmentpurchase program.

title: Upsets at Wimbledon
description: John Newcombe and Billie Jean King, favorites in the Wimbledon tennis championships, were upset in the guarterfinals, Newcombe lost to Ken Rosewall and Mrs. King to Olga Morozova. Page 11.

title: FORNICATION LAW ARGUED IN COURT,
description: NEWARK, July 3  Arguments on whether a rarely enforced New Jersey law against fornication is constitutional were heard in Essex County Superior Court today before Judge Stanley G. Bedford.

title: Poodles in the Midwest: Tale of Pioneer Breeder
description: America's No. 1 breed for the last 14 years has been the poodle. Yet, only three decades ago, that ubiquitous canine was almost unknown in the Midwest. The pioneer who did so much for the bred in the cornandwheat belt is 3. Lynn Welsh. In the forties, frequently I had the only poodles at a show, he recalled. It there were four or five other; it would be a tremendous entry.

title: Jacob's Pillow: New and Ancient Dances
description: LEE, Mass., July 3In this third summer since the death of its founder, Ted Shawn, the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival appears determined to carry on the tradition of its originator.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Claudius James. Giesick Jr., charged with seconddegree murder in the death of his bride, remained in jail in New Orleans on a reduced bond of $50,000, which his attorney said was too high. The attorney, David Evans, succeeded Tuesday in getting the bond lowered from $250,000, but said that Mr. Giesick could not meet anything higher than $20,000.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Colson Says Ehrlichman Sought Aid for Plumbers
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 Charles W. Colson, the former White House special counsel who will go to prison Monday for obstruction of justice, testified today that John D. Ehrlichman asked him to raise $5,000 for the White House plumbers unit a few days before the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: Back in U.S., Nixon Extols Peace Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 3President Nixon returned to the United States tonight after his summit meetings in the Soviet Union and said that the chances for peace were now the brightest in a generation.

title: Jazz Events
description: Today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Anthony Lewis recent column on The Meaning of Torture was both moving and accurate. Not only has the United States remained silent for the most part while governments which we support silence their real and imagined political opposition by the use of imprisonment and torture, but also in most cases we provide money through our AID proem to assist these regimes to do their inhuman work.

title: Rise Predicted in Meat Prices; Cattle Futures Show Sharp Gain
description: Retail meat prices for beef and pork probably will rise noticeably by the middle of next week, according to analysts who follow the trend of futures prices.

title: LOTTERY NUMBERS July 3, 1974
description: Tickets matching only the last number become eligible for the millionaire semifinal drawing to be held later.

title: LEFKOWITZ PLANS MORTGAGE SESSION
description: Scores of complaints from wouldbe purchasers of homes who say they are unable to obtain mortgages from banks have prompted State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowiti to schedule a public hearing in his office at 2 World Trade Center on July 12.

title: The Issues in Canada
description: Canada's politicaj leaders are again giving the world a demonstration of hbw to conduct a civilized, responsible election campaign. The big question is whether this model effort will pay off at the polls Monday by providing Canada with an effective Government after twenty months of Prime Minister Trudeau's minority Liberal administration.

title: Glamour Analysts at High Multiple in Bear Job Market
description: Wall Street's bear market during the last year has had a devastating effect on employment among securities analysts, causing layoffs estimated as high as 20 per cent or more. However, the best analysts have never had it so good.

title: Weekend Fishing Report for Local Waters
description: Along most of the shore from Southern New Jersey to Cape Cod, angling is good for both of the East Coast's most important light tackle marine game fish, the striped bass and the bluefish.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF AS PRIME HITS 12%
description: Prices hit a new fouryear low again yesterday on the Amex as Bankers Trust, followed by other banks, announced the raising of its prime rate from 11 to 12 per cent. Similiar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: PRICE RULES SET 011 UNLEADED. GAS
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 In a move that may mean price reductions for unleaded gasoline, the Federal Energy Administration said today that refiners prices for that fuels should be no more than 1 cent a gallon above the price of regular gasoline.

title: MSGR. JOHN J. DWYER
description: Msgr. John J. Dwyer, pastor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Heart, 30 Clermont Avenue, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn, died Tuesday. His age was 85. Monsignor Dwyer studied at St. John's College and seminary and was ordained in 1914. He served as a priest at Sacred Heart and then as its pastor from 1935 until his retirement in 1966.

title: Peron Rites in Washington Attended by Vice President
description: WASHINGTON, luly 3 (AP)  Vice President Ford joined LatinAmerican diplomats today at memorial services for President Juan Domingo Perdn of Argentina.

description: Horses & Equipment

title: WaitandSee Summit
description: MOSCOW, July 3The SovietAmerican summit meeting of 1974, begun in a spirit of expectant reunion six days ago, passed into history today on in more subdued and sober notewithout the triumph and sense of accomplishment of 1972 or the buoyant, easy good fellowship of 1973.

title: Unions Say Some Stores Here Use TwoWay Mirrors in Dressing Rooms to Curb Rise in Shoplifting
description: At least two department stores in the New York area have twoway mirrors or observation vents situated in the women's and men's dressing roams.

title: HARPER EMPLOYES END 17DAY STRIKE
description: The 17dayold strike at Harper & Row, the largest labor disruption in recent book publishing history, ended yesterday as management and labor agreed on a new threeyear contract that provides 320 of the firm's 600 New Yorkbased employes with raises totaling $46 a week.

description: Knightly Sport of the Greentree Stable broke from the No. 1 post in the $29,650 Juvenile Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. John Gayer, who trains the son of Sir Gaylord, had misgivings the about the inside position, but the colt went on to score a convincing victory in the 5furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies. With Jacinto Vasquez riding him, Knightly Sport moved easily through the going, holding down second place to the stretch. There, he sped into the lead and remained in front to the wire, beating the runnerup, Ramahorn, by 1 lengths. Next, a head hack, came Bold Gun, who had been made the favorite by the crowd of 18,413.

title: Typical Family's $12,051 In 73 Gained on Inflation
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 Ile typical American family lad an income of $12,051 last year and managed to keep somewhat ahead of inflation, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: NIXON GAIN SLIGHT IN A GALLUP SURVEY
description: President Nixon did not register an appreciable gain in popularity after his recent fivenation tour of the Middle East, according to the findings of a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: VETERANS CLUBBED IN CAPITAL PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) At least a dozen Vietnam veterans protesting for greater benefits were clubbed to the ground by policemen today when they tried to cross police line in a march to the Capitol.

title: Parker Hurls Victory
description: When Harry Parker started to tire in the ninth inning against Philadelphia at Shea Stadium yesterday, the New York Mets righthander wasn't worried about losing his shutout. He wasn't even worried about failing to complete his first game in four years in the majors.

title: SALE OF UNIT SET BY SPENCER FOODS
description: Spencer Foods, Inc., of Spencer, Iowa, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its beef division to Armour & Co., a division of the Greyhound Corporation, for Greyhound stock valued at about $11.5million. The terms call for the exchange of about 0.85 share of Greyhound common for each share of Spencer common, of which there are 992,100 shares outstanding.

title: Sikkim's King, Bowing to Foes, Says He'll Accept New Charter
description: GANGTOK, Sikkim, July 3 (AP)The king of Sikkim an nounced today that he Ilk agreed to sign a democratic oriented constitution thal would reduce him to figure head status.

title: Local Pianist Wins a Tchaikovsky 2d
description: MOSCOW, July 3MyungWhun Chung, a 21yearold  New York pianist, today was announced as the secondplace winner in the piano section of the quadrennial Tchaikovsky Competition at the Moscow Conservatory. The first prize went to 18yearold Andrei Gavrilov of the Soviet Union.

title: Vote on IncomeTax Bill Is Now Due Next Week
description: TRENTON, July 3 (AP)Assembly Speaker S. Howard Woodson said today that vote on the Byrne administration's incometax bill could come on July 11. The vote had been expected July 15 or 18.

title: Charger Rookies Report Despite Pickets
description: SAN DIEGO, July 3Under a hot sun in the mountains behind San Diego, football's first picket line went into action today in an atmosphere of all  out good humor.

title: Realty Trust Seeks Shift
description: Fidelity Mortgage Investors, a real estate investment trust, announced yesterday that its trustees would call a special meeting of shareholders to consider removing the trust from taxexempt status under the Internal Revenue Code, a move apparently directed at freeing the trust's management to attempt to improve the status of its portfolio. Fidelity is one of several trusts to report portfolio problems recently.

description: CINCINNATI, July 3A man who calls himself Hananiah E. Israel, and says he is a spiritual teacher, said here today that Marcus Wayne Chenault had been one of his pupils to whom he had revealed his beliefs that black ministers are among the main oppressors of black people.

title: Public Campaign Funds
description: After unconscionable delayand with the obvious reluctance of leading membersthe House Administration Committee appears to have made a major breakthrough. It has conceded the necessity for the use public funds in the election process.

description: On this Fourth of July, Americans have to find solid middle ground between complacency and disgust, between a vengeful moralism and the politics of cynicism.

description: Despite attractive profits in the last two quarters, oil industry gains may be turned into losses by a number of factors, economists at the First National City Bank said in report prepared for release today.

description: James Claude, Thomson, missionary and educator F who had long been active in the Far East, died yesterday in Broomall, Pa. at the age of 85.

description: Communities in Westchester, County and Fairfield County, Conn., yesterday began buryH ing the 24 young people who were killed three days ago in the fire and panic in a busy Port Chester singles bar straddling the state line.

title: U.S. Dollar Drops; Gold Also Slides In Trading Abroad
description: BRUSSELS, July 3 (UPI)The United States dollar today dropped to its lowest rates in weeks but recovered some of its lost ground by closing time.; Gold rallied from its fivemonth; low overnight, but fell even; lower by the close.

title: Northrup Homers Decide
description: DETROIT, July 3.The Yankees almost celebrated the eve of the Fourth of July in fitting fashion tonight. They exploded for 13 hits, including a home run, a triple and two doubles. But when the fireworks were over, there were the Yankees, the victims of their seventh straight defeat.

title: I.B.M. and Comsat Plan Joint Venture
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) announced plans yesterday for a joint domestic satellite venture. Subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission, they plan to acquire the onethird interests held by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation in the CML Satellite Corporation. The Comsat General Corporation, a subsidiary of Comsat, owns the remaining onethird interest ini the satellite.

title: 2 GOVERNORS SAID TO RECEIVE THREATS
description: At least two Middle Western Governors have been threatened with cremation, officials disclosed yesterday, and similar postcard threats are believed to have been mailed to a dozen other governors.

description: PHILADELPHIA, July 3 Some years ago, a group of prominent Democrats went down to Washington seeking White House permission this old city to become the cial focal point of the country's bicentennial celebration.

description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY It was a dream for years and then last spring, 26,000 acres of beaches, parks and wetlands in New York and New Jersey were turned over to the Federal Government as part of the Gateway National Recreation Area, the first such urban preserve in the country. What better way to celebrate Independence Day than to visit Gateway?

description: WASHINGTON, July 3 (Reuters)A spokesman for the International Westminster Bank said today the bank had received payment of $4million in respect to a letter of credit deemed by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to represent a possible claim by the bank against the United States National Bank of San Diego, which failed.

title: Police Arrest Numbers Suspect Linked to a $14Million Bank
