title: New Head of N.E.A.
description: CHICAGO, July 3As firstyear teacher in Kansas City in 1948, Jim Harris was upset to find that at its annual meeting the state teachers association designated its social events as either For Whites or For Colored. He wrote a letter complaining about the policy and was so surprised when the group readily agreed to integrate its activities that he showed his satisfaction by spending $150 of his modest $2,279 annual salary to become a life member of the National Education Association.

title: MRS. WALTER G. BARLOW
description: Mrs. Hanna Dorothea Hansen Barlow, wife of Walter G. Barlow, president of Research Strategies Corporation here, died Tuesday at her home in Pennington, N. J. She was 541 years old. Besides her husband, she is survived by a son, Eric Paul; three daughters, Mrs. D. Reid Bryant 3d, Deborah A. and Alison Joan Sarah, and a sister, Mrs. Einar Torgersen.

title: KUWAIT OIL BIDS BELOW POSTINGS
description: KUWAIT, July 3All of the more than 40 bids received by Kuwait's Finance and Oil Ministry so far for the Government's oilparticipation prices were less than Kuwait's current posted price of $11.54 a barrel, according to ministry sources.

title: Garrow's Lawyers Facing a New Inquiry
description: SYRACUSE, July 3The Onondaga County District Attor ney, Jon K. Holcombe, anflounced today that a grand jury would look into possible health and penal law violations by two attorneys for Robert F. Garrow, the convicted murderer.

title: HERSTATT FORCES EASING OF CREDIT

Some of us will be content if we can simply watch the parades go by while munching hot dogs that cost under a dollar, but none of these simple pleasures will satisfy the doers of good. The reformers sniff their opportunity and one of them, according to a news clipping before us, detects in patriotic music.

title: Democrat Wins on Coast
description: VENTURA, Calif., July 3 (UPI)Omer Rains, a Liberal Democrat, swept to an upset victory in a special state Senate election last night. Mr. Rains, a lawyer, took 58 per cent of the vote in defeating State Assemblyman Don MacGillivray in the election to fill the unexpired term of Robert J. Lagamarsino, a Republican, who was elected to Congress in March.

description: Goaded by a second day of 90degree heat and lured by such prospects as one to four days off, generally favorable weather and adequate supplies of gasoline, New Yorkers by the tens of thousands began abandoning the city yesterday for the Independence Day holiday; weekend.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Nearly 200 years after the American revolutionaries declared their independence, American football players have discovered the ring of the word freedom, as if it were an audible that took two centuries to penetrate. No freedom, no football is today's battle cry in the National Football League Players Association strike. But their sense freedom is occasionally confused, if not illogical. In hoping to persuade rookies to honor the picket lines, the N.F.L.P.A. is really telling them. By not reporting to training camp, you are lessening your chances to join our union. The only way a rookie can join the N.F.L.P.A. is by making a team, not by spurning an opportunity to make a team. their demands of the owners, the N.F.L.P.A. also appears somewhat confused. In a recent memo from Edward Garvey, the Thomas Jefferson of pro football, the N.F.L.P.A, elaborated on four of its freedom issuesthe common draft, trades and waivers, discipline and dispute settlement.

title: Wallpaper Explodes With Firecrackers
description: Mix a little nostalgia with some thoughts of the nation's 200th anniversary, just two years away, and what happens? Wallpaper. At least that's how it worked with Hubbell Pierce, the designer. Mr. Pierce recalled how, during his childhood in Atlanta, firecrackers would light up both the Fourth of July and Christmas Day. Those memories, plus getting caught up in the Bicentennial spirit, inspired him to design a red, white and blue wallpaper plastered with firecrackers. Besides, he noted this week, it's a safe way not to forget firecrackers now that the Federal Consumer Products Safety Commission has banned them from sale. The patent vinyl wallcovering, called 1776, is available through architects and decorators at Philip Graf, 979 Third Avenue (at 58th Street) $27 a roll.

McCartney's Things We Said Today hints at the possibility of loss, with a weeping chromatic descent in triplet rhythm, and with rapid but dreamy tonal movement flowing from B flat by way of a rich dominant ninth to E flat: the subdominant triad of which then serves as a kind of Neapolitan cadence drooping back (without the linking dominant) to the grave pentatonic G minor.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 3 (AP)Financial troubles of the Franklin National Bank in New York have caused repercussions for a Minneapolis bank.

title: Ralph Waldo Emerson
description: Give me truths, For I am weary of the surfaces, And die of inanition. If I knew Only the herbs and simples of the wood, Rue, cinquefoil, gill, vervain and agrimony, Bluevetch and trillium, hawkweed, sassafras, Milkweeds and murky brakes, quaint pipes and sundew, And rare and virtuous roots, which in these woods Draw untold juices from the common earth, Untold, unknown, and I could surely spell Their fragrance, and their chemistry apply By sweet affinities to human flesh, Driving the foe and stablishing the friend,0, that were much, and I could be a part Of the round day, related to the sun And planted world, and full executor Of their imperfect functions. But these young scholars, who invade our hills, Bold as the engineer who fells the wood, And travelling often in the cut he makes, Love not the flower they pluck, and know it not, And all their botany is Latin names. The old men studied magic in the flowers, And human fortunis in astronomy, And an omnipotence in chemistry, Preferring things to names, for these were men, Were unitarians of the united world, And, wheresoever their clear eyebeams fell, They caught the footsteps of the SAME. Our eyes Are armed, but we are strangers to the stars, And strangers to the mystic beast and bird, And strangers to the plant and to the mine. The injured elements say, Not in us; And night and day, ocean and continent, Fire, plant and mineral say, Not in us, And haughtily return us stare for stare. For we invade, them impiously for gain; We devastate them unreligiously, And coldly ask their pottage, not their love. Therefore they shove us from them, yield to us Only what to our griping toil is due; But the sweet affluence of love and song, The rich results of the divine consents Of man and earth, of world beloved and lover, The nectar and ambrosia, are withheld; And in the midst of spoils and slaves, we thieves And pirates of the universe, shut out Daily to a more thin and outward rind, Turn pale and starve. Therefore, to our sick eyes, The stunted trees look sick, the summer short, Clouds shade the sun, which will not tan our hay, And nothing thrives to reach its natural term; And life, shorn of its venerable length, Even at its greatest space is a defeat, And dies in anger that it was a dupe; And, in its highest noon and wantonness, Is early frugal, like a beggar's child; Even in the hot pursuit of the best aims And prizes of ambition, checks its hand, Like Alpine cataracts frozen as they leaped, Chilled with a miserly comparison Of the toy's purchase with the length of life.

As a result, in her nightclub performances and even in concerts where she shares the stage with others, she is often just getting warmed up by the time she is finished.

Aspen is a very fragile place at this point.

title: FIRE STUDY HALTS IN PORT CHESTER

title: American Found in Kenya Dies of Effects of Ordeal

title: Chris Evert Eliminates Miss Melville, 62, 63
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 4It will be Chris Evert against Olga Morozova in the women's final of the Wimbledon tennis championships. The Russian, who dethroned Mrs. Billie Jean King yesterday, came out of the ruck and triumphed over Virginia Wade in a match that raged over 90 minutes on center court with the issue trembling in the balance until the final stages. The scores were 16, 75, 64.

title: Bitter Jones Delivers 5 Hits
description: Cleon Jones had a day any ballplayer would be proud of, getting five hits in eight at bats, and adding 10 points to his batting average (now at 284) during the Mets doubleheader split with Philadelphia at Shea Stadium yesterday. But he still thinks he has to fight against a reputation for being lazy.

title: Mrs. Griep Is Wed To W. E. Little Jr.

title: Food Supply Held Ample, Yet U.S. Could Run Short
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 There is no excuse for us ever getting into a position where we won't have enough food, Tony T. Dechant, president of the National Farmers Union, told a reporter.

title: MONROE GUTMAN, 88, LEHMAN EXECUTIVE
description: Monre C. Gutman, who retired in 1969 as chairman of the executive committee of Lehman Brothers, the banking house, died late Wednesday night at his home, 480 Park Avenue. He was 88 years old.

title: Troubles for Marcos
description: MANILAOne of the biggest problems facing President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martiallaw Government is that its publicity machine has consistently claimed too much for it. Almost every day Manila newspapers use banner headlines to announce sweeping decrees and promises that, it is evident, can never be fulfilled. Many of the proclamations have an apocalyptic ring, as if the mere words have transformed society at that very moment.

It proved to be one of the most rewarding concerts of the festival.

description: PARIS, July 4  To preserve employment for Frenchmen in the recession that many fear is coming, the Government announced today that no more foreign workers would be permitted into the country until October, when the situation will be reviewed.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, July 4 (AP)Bobby Unser bettered his own record today by nearly 27 seconds in winning the 12mile Pikes Peak Hill Climb, a stock car competition. Unser climbed to the 14,100foot summit in 13 minutes 13.16 seconds. The 1968 Indianapolis 500 winner, who also owns the sportscar record for the climb, was driving a 1974 Dodge Dart. Bob Silvers of Colorado Springs, finishing second in 13:32.64 in his 1973 Oldsmobile Omega, also broke Unser's previous record of 13:40 set in 1069. It was Unser's first race in five years over the twisting, turning clitt road. He said he decided to come back and compete because his records were in danger of falling, His racing family, including three brothers and an uncle, have combined for 28 victories here. Unser has won 12 times.

title: Cross of Gold
description: A longOverdue bill to fulfill a United States commitment to help the world's poorest nations finally sailed through the House this week, burdened with an intolerable cross of gold.

title: The Balmville Tree
description: Most of the legends about the Balmville Tree in Newburgh are untrue. But the tree itself, one of the biggest and oldest in the Northeast, is alive, though sick and desperately in need of protection. It didn't spring from a riding crop thrown away by George Washington, and there is little likelihood that Matthew Vassar slept under it and dreamed of becoming a rich man and founding Vassar College. It is simply a magnificent old tree that has been growing since 1699, well before Washington was born, at the junction of what once were two Indian paths.

I., getting ready to open the professional football season seven days hence. Next Thursday the New York Stars of the World Football League will launch a 20game schedule against the Jacksonville Sharks in the crisp Florida evening. Six nights later the survivors will display W.F.L. wares to a New York clientele for the first time, engaging Birmingham in Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

Mr. Warren, a former Governor of California, was Chief Justice of the United States for 16 years until he reired in 1969.

title: The Pop Life
description: The Grateful Dead have always enjoyed a mystique that comes closer to reality than the images of several other of the San Francisco flowerpower bands. The popular recollection of those longgone summers of love hack in the ninteeensixties is of innocent (if blissfully sexual) children wandering around with acidinduced smiles on their faces. Sure, they ran into walls a lot, but the walls were soft and inviting.

title: Sakharov, Detente and Liberty
description: ROXBURY, Conn.The Soviet nuclear physicist Andrei D. Sakharov was on a hunger strike this weekhe ended it yesterday for medical reasons in order to protest to his Government the persecution of individuals who hold dissident opinions. At the same time, President Nixon met with Leonid I. Brezhnev to work out new modes of economic and technical cooperation, Mr. Sakharov believes, and share his belief, that the human content of dtente is not only equal in importance to the weight of goods and services to be exchanged but that the enhancement of human libertyor its further destructionis truly its essence.

title: About New York
description: What with one thing or another, it was supposed to be the worst night of the year at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, but when Barry Mayer said the worst part was over, it was still short of midnight.

description: FERGUSON, Mo., July 4Although it wasn't one of the country's biggest celebrations, quite a few outoftowners came here for this little city's Fourth of July parade today.

title: The Screen:' Charge of Machete' Shows Cuban Strife
description: "First Charge of the Machete" is an overly fancy Cuban variation on American television's old "You Are There" series, those re-creations of great moments in history as they might have been recorded by reporters equipped with hand-held cameras and 20-20 foresight.The time is October, 1868, when Cuban nationalists in Oriente province rebelled against the Spanish colonial regime, captured the city of Bayamo and, later, decimated the Spanish troops sent in to put down the rebellion. The principal instrument of the Cubans was the machete, the lowly farm tool that was elevated to the status of lethal weapon in a time of crisis.The film, which was made in 1969, was shown at the First Avenue Screening Room Sunday and will be repeated there at noon and midnight today and tomorrow.No matter how cleverly planned and ingeniously executed, there is always something bogus about these attempts to pretend that history happened yesterday, when sound cameras were on hand to record the events. The more clever and ingenious, in fact, the more bogus.It is the conceit of Manuel Octavio Gomez, who directed this film, that motion-picture photography of 1868 would look like very crude Mathew Brady, even though the sound-recording equipment is on a par with today's. "First Charge of the Machete" is almost impossible to look atthe images being all black or white with no intermediate shades. It not only is a terrible strain on the eyes, but it also makes the white subtitles invisible at least half the time.Mr. Octavio Gomez's attempt to give contemporary purpose and passion to events first obscures and then ultimately overwhelms them: we're too busy noticing the elaborately designed cinema to give much heed to the vrit behind it.He also apparently thinks that 19th-century newsreel cameramen would have been absolutely committed to close-ups and to movement. If the subject of an interview is not moving around, then the camera moves around him. Nothing is allowed to be static. At one point this incessant movement gave me the impression that the director somehow resented buildings and trees for not being able to walk.

title: U.S. Shells All Gain At Henley

We may not put on our next show, scheduled for around July 15, but we'll certainly have something for September, he said.

title: Monmouth Oaks Won By Honky Star at 331
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 Honky Star, the filly who was disqualified from first in last year's Sorority Stakes here, made up for it today by winning the $59,450 Monmouth Oaks at Monmouth Park.

title: Bronx Man Is Slain While Helping Raise Money for Scouts
description: A gunman, apparently firing at random into a crowd attending a poolside party at middleincome housing project in Harlem Wednesday night, killed a 41yearold Rronx man who had gone there to help raise money for the Roy Scouts.

title: BORGWARNER SEES 10% RISE IN PROFITS
description: Secondquarter earnings of the BorgWarner Corporation increased by 10 to 15 per cent from $18.6million, or 96 cents a share, in the 1973 period, reversing the 7.5 per cent decline in this year's opening quarter, according to a company estimate.

title: LLOYD A. FALLERS
description: CHICAGO, July 4, (UPI)Lloyd A. Fallers, a professor of anthropology and sociology at the University of Chicago, died today at the university's Billings Hospital. He was 48 years old.

title: GRUMMAN HOPES FOR $200MILLION
description: The Grumman Aerospace Corporation expects to receive $200million in lowinterest loans or advance payments from the Federal Government for production of military jets for the Navy and for Iran over the next year.

title: No Nuclear Danger Is Found in L.I.Copter Incident
description: Local officials on Long Island say they are satisfied with Defense Department assurances that last week's forced landing of a helicopter believed to have been carrying nuclear arms presented no danger.

title: Hunt for Boy Unsuccessful As LILCO Cuts Its Service
description: The Long Island Lighting Company cut practically to zero the generation of electricity at its three units in Northport on Wednesday night as rescue workers and divers, searched unsuccessfully for the body of a 14yearold boy who had apparently fallen into a discharge basin.

title: Mother and Child Shot On Coney Island Stroll
description: A mother and her daughter were shot on a Coney Island street about 10:30 last night as they and the girl's stepfather walked near their home. The identity of the gunman was not known.

title: Nightclub Fire Alerts Patrons and Owners to Safety
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 4Some nightclub patrons here are more alert to the locations of the exits and some of the owners are obviously safetyconscious. But the fire that killed 24 young people in Port Chester Sunday morning apparently has had little effect on the dining, drinking and dancing habits of young people in Westchester County.

title: Tchaikovsky Winner Finds His Inspiration in Nature
description: MOSCOW, July 4Eugene Fodor is a handsome cleancut, squarejawed young man who looks more like an athlete or a virile outdoorsman than a talented violinist who has just shared top honors in the worldfamous Tchaikovsky competition.

title: Pearson Captures Firecracker 400
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4With half the crowd turning thumbs down, and the other half raising a finger heavenward, the world's fastest stockcar race ended spectacularly today with the two best drivers nearly crashing twice on the final lap in a catandmouse game.

title: Astronomers Report They Find A Second Black Hole in Space
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 4 (AP)  Astronomers who claimed a year ago to have discovered a mysterious black hole in space say they may have found a second one.

description: NEW DELHI, July 4 (AP)The King of Sikkim signed away his powers today and opened his Himalayan realm to more Indian domination.

description: Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mule Haas of Philadelphia A's, Star of 29 World Series, Dies
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 4 (UPI).George William (Mule) Haas, an 11year veteran of the major leagues and a hero of the Philadelphia Athletics's World Series success in 1929, died last Sunday night in New Orleans while visiting his son, George Jr. He was 70 years old and lived in Avon.

title: 5 Officers Hurt in Melee At Concert in Elizabeth
description: Five police officers were injured in Elizabeth, N. J., last night in a fight between policemen and a group at a neighborhood park that arose when the police tried to stop the setting off of fireworks, the police said.

title: Abstinence From Meat To Be Urged by Cooke
description: Cardinal Cooke will urge this Sunday that Roman Catholics in the Archdiocese of New York abstain from eating meat on Wednesdays out of loving concern for the starving and desperate poor in faminestricken nations of Central Africa and Southern Asia.

title: Dining OutIt's an Expensive and Noisy Restaurant
description: Musing upon the menu of Katja, a spanking new re taurant that opened last Saturlay night at 225 East 58th, I figured that if you ordered right, you could get one hors d'oeuvre, one entree, skip the salad and end with dessert and coffee for $50.02 after 7 per cent taxit hadn't gone up yetand minimum 15 per cent tipone person, no drinks, no wine, and no tip to the captain. That's New York, summer of 1974.

title: ASHBEL GULLIVER, 77,, EXYALE LAW DEAN
description: Ashbel G. Gulliver, a former dean of the Yale University Law School, died late Wednesday in Hanover, N. H. He was 77 years old and lived in Norwich, Vt.

title: Mingus, Roach, Blakey Resurrect 50's Hard Bop
description: Charles Mingus, Max Roach and Art Blakey all started their jazz careers in the nineteenforties, were among the most influential jazz figures of the nineteenfifties and have maintained that influential stature as they have grown into elder statesmen of the music. Hearing all three with their present groups at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening provided an interesting summation of the development of these three contemporaries in the last 20 years.

title: People in Sports
description: It's right there on the tapes, Joe Brinkman, umpire at Wednesday night's Chicago White Sox game, struck the team's manager, Chuck Tanner, in the face while signaling his ejection from the contest with the Texas Rangers.

title: The Right to Privacy
description: Your June 24 editorial Protecting Privacy couldn't be more timely. Legislative hearings are being eonducted by both the Senate and the House on the Comprehensive Right to Privacy Act, introduced by Congressman Barry Goldwater Jr. and myself in the House and most recently by Senators Ervin, Percy, Muskie, Bayh, Goldwater, Kennedy and Mathias in comparable bill in the Senate.

title: Syrian Charges That Israel tooted Golan's Ancient Sites
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, July (Reuters)A Syrian museums official accused Israel today of looting archaeological treasures and destroying ancient sites and historic buildings in villages on the Golan Heights.

title: Bulgaria Ignoring An Appeal to Save Former U.N. Aide
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3A monthlong campaign begun here to get clemency for a Bulgarian economist facing a death sentence has not evoked any encouraging response from the Bulgarian authorities.

title: Television
July 4 Tradition May Be Up to Dodgers
description: Once upon a time there were 16 major league baseball teams, three of them in New York City, where the Dodgers played in Ebbets Field, the Giants cavorted in the Polo Grounds and the Yankees won pennants and World Series galore in Yankee Stadium.

title: JAIIIES BARKER, LED ALLSTATE INSURANCE
description: CHICAGO, July 4 (AP)James M. Barker, former chairan of the board of the Allstate Insurance Company, died yesterday. He was 88 years old.

title: Questions That Won't Go Away
description: Now that Richard Nixon and Henry Kissinger have left Moscow after useful but not miraculous summit, questions will be asked again about how much the Secretary of State really knew about White House plumbing and tapping. Maybe a new feat to match his Middle East performance might have overwhelmed these questions for a while butdespite his defenders cries of outragethey ought to be asked.

title: Morgenthau Lists Priorities for D.A.
description: In his first policy paper of the campaign, Robert M. Morgenthau, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for District Attorney in Manhattan, yesterday outlined an overview of what he would do to change the procedures and priorities of the prosecutor's office.

title: Ed Sneed Leads Golf On 67133
description: MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP) Ed Sneed, scoring birdies on the first three holes, carded a fiveunderpar 67 and extended his lead to three strokes today In the second round of the $130,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.

title: Paula Pine Married to Kenneth Rones
description: Miss Paula Judith Fine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton S. Fine of West Hartford, was married there yesterday afternoon to Kenneth S. Rones, son of Mr. and Mrs. David D. Rones of New York. Rabbis Abraham J. Feldman and Harold S. Silver performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Israel, assisted by Cantor Mark Lipson, cousin of the bride.

title: Market Place REIT's Suffer As Rates Soar
description: When the realestate investment trusts were introduced a few years ago, they were widely hailedparticularly by their sponsors as providing a means by Which the small investor could participate in the realestate market.

title: Beach Throngs Seek Relief in 95 Heat
description: Bearing up under scorching heat which soared to a muggy 95 degrees, New Yorkers celebrated the birth of their nation by stomping and sweating to fiddles and banjos, crooning sea chanteys and learning the crafts of their revolutionary ancestors at the South Street Seaport yesterday.

title: MORE POSTERS GONE FROM PEKING SITE
description: PEKING, Friday, July 5 More posters disappeared from a prominent Peking street yesterday, but the move failed to deter two men from Flunan Province who pasted up a new protest alleging rightist persecution of a longtime revolutionary there.

title: LONDON CALLS ON ULSTER TO DEVISE OWN SETTLEMENT
description: LONDON, July 4After five years of trying and failing to find a political solution for troubled Northern Ireland, the British Government today announced new plans that call on the people in the province to devise a settlement themselves.

title: Roosevelt Raceway Results
description: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries

title: Food Supply Held Ample, Yet U.S Could Run Short
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 There is no excuse for us ever getting into a position where we won't have enough food, Tony T. Dechant, president of the National Farmers Union, told a reporter.

title: U.S. ENVOY MAKES SOVIET TV SPEECH
description: MOSCOW, July 4In an unusual Independence Day address on Soviet television, the United States Ambassador, Walter J. Stoessel Jr., told the Soviet people tonight that Americans would welcome even broader contacts on an individual level as a part of improving SovietAmerican relations.

title: Two Letters on a Dissident's Situation
description: Excerpt from an appeal by Andrei D. Sakharov to Leonid I. Brezhnev and Richard M. Nixon

title: Gold Falls to $131
description: The price of gold continued to slump in London yesterday, dropping $5 to $131 an ounce, a fivemonth low. Dealers said the sustained decline might indicate gold is losing its position as an investment haven. Page 31.

title: Lawyers and Ethics
description: In your June 11 editorial on Lawyers Watergate, you refer to the need for the development of postgraduate educational programs to help lawyers explore the multitude of complex and murky ethical questions that continually confront practitioners. The process has already begun.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Secretary of State Kissinger said in Brussels after a meeting with the Atlantic alliance council that the key obstacle to an agreement at the NixonBrezhnev talks on nuclear offensive arms was the difficulty of agreeing upon how to balance missile totals and warhead totals. With the Soviet Union holding a substantial advantage in the number of missiles and the United States a 3to1 advantage in warheads, Mr. Nixon and Mr. Brezhnev committed their countries to trying to negotiate a new interim accord that would extend until 1985. The aim is to complete it before the present interim accord expires in 1977. [1:8.]

title: Del Webb, Former Part Owner Of the Yankees, Is Dead at 75
description: Del E. Webb, the former semiprofessional baseball player who built an offseason carpentry business into a multimilliondollar construction and hotel empire and partownership of the New York Yankees, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital, in Rochester, Minn. from complications following surgery for lung cancer at the Mayo Clinic. He was 75 years old.

title: Mets Records
NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 23

title: U.S. Shells All Advance At Henley
description: HENLEY  ON  THAMES, England, July 4There were more champagne corks than, firecrackers popping for the opening day of the 1974 Henley Royal Regatta and American oarsmen celebrated the Fourth of July by winning all their heats in the 135th renewal of the oldest rowing event in the world.

title: Danbury Discovers Iveson Centennial
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 4He may not be quite as big yet as stockcar races, but Charles Ives has finally made it in his hometown. Ives, the rugged individual who is by general consent the most significant serious composer produced by this country, has been virtually unknown in this city of 55,000 until this year, the centennial anniversary of his birth. But now Danbury has discovered Ives, thanks to a few fanatical admirers and civicminded citizens.

title: A Painting for Nixon, A Car for Brezhnev
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., July 4 (UPI)  President Nixon received a painting of Moscow by night and Mrs. Nixon a set of amber jewelry in a gold setting from their Soviet hosts, a White House spokesman said today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CAN YOU TAP THIS There is something called the National Tap Dance Foundation, and it wants you to know more than you already do about tap dancing. So today at the Bowery Savings Bank's office at Bowery and Grand Streets, there will be an exhibition of all sorts of tap dancing, historic and otherwise, performed by some of the greats in the art.

title: Business Briefs
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 4 (AP)  The Venezuelan Government said today it is imposing strict new controls on foreign investment to help diversify the nation's oildependent economy and spur lagging industry.

description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 Honky Star, the filly who was disqualified from first in last year's Sorority Stakes here, made up for it today by winning the $59,450 Monmouth Oaks at Monmouth Park.

title: A Jerseyan, 60, Reflects On Effort to Quit Soviet
description: HARTFORD, July 4 (AP)She's a stranger in her own country. What should be her native language is foreign to her. Until last month, she was one of 12 Americans held in the Soviet Union, some for decades.

title: Sakharov Ends 6Day Fast
description: MOSCOW, July 4 (AP)Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and political dissident, said tonight that he was ending his hunger strike for medical reasons. He said that he had lost 17.6 pounds and had suffered from failing eyesight and dizziness after six days of taking only water to protest Soviet treatment of political prisoners.

description: N. Y. Daily220434

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 4 (UPI)  The Professional Putters Association's national championship begins here tomorrow with more than 250 pros and amateurs from 42 states competing for $10,000 in prize money. Among the participants in the twoday 144hole medal play event will be the defending chempion, Daryl Freman, Mike Baldoza, the world putting champion, and Vince Randall, putter of the decade.

title: Stars Depend on Old Pros to Stop Foes
description: At times Gerry Philbin, John Elliott and Lloyd Voss must feel as If they are camp counselors, watching over eight youngsters morning and afternoon in the New York Stars summer camp.

title: Shore Resorts Looking For Prosperous Season
description: The resort industry on the, New Jersey Shore still has hopes that fears of gasoline shortages and the rising cost of travel abroad will combine Ito give, it one of its best years lever. But at the moment the prognosis seems somewhat mixed.

title: The Dance
description: Of all the jewels in the diadem of Russian ballet, perhaps the last act of the Marius Petipa La Bayadere, to music by Ludwig Minkus, is the purest, most precious and absolutely pellucid. One watches this ballet, when it is well staged and danced, and receives a strangely comprehensive impression of what the Russian Imperial Ballet was like in its ascendance.

title: The Sailing Mystique Grips the Hinterland
description: STURGIS, Mich., July 3This stretch of prairie countryside on the Indiana border, halfway between Chicago and Detroit, proclaims its character in countless ways.

title: Hiller Yields 4 Hits During Late Rally
description: DETROIT, July 4  Just when it seemed that Jim Northrup had demolished the Yankees for the second game in a row with a late inning home run, along came New York tonight with a threerun rally in the ninth for a 6to4 victory.

title: Wushu Troupe Dazzles
description: Let's not go overboard about Wushu of China, the second troupe in the performing arts to visit this country from the People's Republic of China. They're merely astounding.

title: A BritishStyle Celebration on Long Island
description: OYSTER BAY COVE, LI., July 4One hundred and ninetyeight years after Independence, with the Union Jack flying alongside the American flag, there was a typical Fourth of July picnic todaydarts and hot tea and a bagpipe band and a soccer game on the cricket field.

title: Greek Orthodox Church Forms Social Action Unit
description: CHICAGO, July 4  The Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of North and South America has established its first Office of Social Concerns and has committed the new agency to organize, implement and develop a program of social action for the church's twomillion members in the United States and Canada,

title: Peddlers and Merchants Seek To Resolve Battle of Bronx Hub
description: Truce reigns in the War of the Peddlers, and across a kind of South Bronx demilitarized zone, a pair of longtime enemies are starting to begrudge each other a kind word.

description: TRENTON, (AP) July 4Republican Representatives from New Jersey generally say they are keeping an open mind on whether they will vote to impeach President Nixon.

title: On L.I., Jazz Takes a Back Seat to Soul
description: Wednesday night's concert at the Nassau Coliseum on Long Island, part of the Newport Jazz Festival, was billed as a Salute to Jazz and Soul, but in fact jazz took very much a back seat, if it was there at all. And the soul music went on and on: the billtopper, Gladys Knight and the Pips, finally took the stage at 12:14 A.M., to play for nearly an hour, after a concert scheduled for an 8 P.M. start.

title: F.T.C. PLANS STUDY ON CONDOMINIUMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 4The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it would undertake a nationwide investigation of the development and management of residential condominiums.

description: ST. LOUIS (NL)Placed Sonny Slebert, righthanded pitcher, on 21day disabled list with Inflamed tendon of the right elbow. Recalled Bob Forsch, righthanded pitcher, from Tulsa of the American Association. Signed Claude Crockett, Southern Illinois outfielder, fifthround choice free agent draft.

description: BILLY TAYLOR AND JAZZMOBILE ALLSTARS, Lincoln Center outdoor concert, 12:15.

description: Securities and commodities exchanges, banks and United States Government offices will be open today after being closed for Independence Day.

title: Grownups Regain The Ability to Play
description: The purpose of the workshop, said Leah Friedman, its director, is not therapeutic. No one is there to analyze problems, confess, encounter, play touchyfeely, work through mental blocks or uncover hidden traumas.

title: Bridge World Federation's Action Denies Winner High Ranking
description: Winning a world title might seem to disqualify anyone for the doubtful distinction of being the unluckiest player in the tournament. Yet Fritzi Gordon of Britain can be said to have achieved this improbable double at the world pair championships in Las Palmas in May.

title: Summitry And Hypocrisy
description: Nobody seems to be very happy about the NixonBrezhnev summit meeting, but actually it was more honest than most. It was a standoffa holding operation in a time of political uncertainty all over the world. In this sense, it was a realistic conference because it expressed the political realities, which are uncertain at best.

title: He Puts on Big Fireworks Shows, and Sometimes It Means Getting Burned
description: ATLANTA, July 4Jerry Howell is 40 years old, but you would hardly know it to talk to him. He jumps around like a kid, loves to tinker with cars and rides his 10speed bike 20 miles a day. He wears his light brown hair in a quarterinch crewcut.

title: Hong Kong Making Study Of BankLicensing Policy
description: HONG KONG, July 4 (Reulers)A review of the tiovernment's policy on issuing bank licenses has been finished and the GovernorinCouncil will soon he consulted on the findings, according to Financial Secretary Philip HaddonCave.

title: Wood, Field & Stream
description: YORK COUNTY, New Brunswick  My companion anglers at Rocky Brook camp on the South West Miramichi River clearly were more successful financially than I, but I was not overwhelmed, for all men are equal before the lordly Atlantic salmon.

title: Boating Outlook
description: The National Weather Service issued this forecast at 6:45 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island South Shore and nearby coastal area:

title: SOYIE IS DOCKED WITH SPACE LAB
description: MOSCOW, July 4 (AP)Two Soviet astronauts entered the Salyut 3 space laboratory after successfully linking their Soyuz 14 spacecraft with the orbiting station, the Government announced late Thursday.

title: Merckx Leads Tour
description: CHALONS  SUR 'MARNE, France, July 4 (UPI)Eddy Merckx of Belgium won today's 132mile seventh stage of the Tour de France bicycle race to recapture the overall lead. It was the fourth time Merckx has taken the overall lead since the tour started a week ago.

title: Bank Failure in Germany Jars Confidence Abroad
description: PARIS, July 4The mechanism in which international banks pay one another is threatened with a breakdown as a result of last week's bankruptcy of one of the big German private banks, Bankhaus I. D. Herstatt of Cologne. Such a breakdown would have dangerous implications for world business and finance.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS REMAINS STABLE FOR FIFTH MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.2 per cent in June, a level that has held essentially stable for five straight months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: MRS. EVA ONCKEN
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. July 5 (AP)Eva von Knorring Oncken, a concert pianist and teacher at Douglass College here, died today in Meredith, N.H. She was 94 years old.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (UPI)A Federal Court threw out today an antitrust suit filed against the National Hockey League in 1972 by two allied World Hockey Association groupsMetropolitan Hockey Club and its successor, Golden Blades Hockey Inc., both of New York.

title: Rare Turtle is Hatched In a Texas Experiment
description: SOUTH PADRE ISLAND, Tex., July 5 (AP)An eightyear experiment has paid off with the hatching of a tiny sea turtle, the first of its kind born in the United States in 25 years.

title: German Company Reports Plans for 40Million Plant
description: Stiddeutsche Kalksticks offWerke, A. G., of Trostberg, West Germany, announced plans yesterday for building $40million plant at Becancour, Quebec, for the production of silicon metal and ferrosilicon.

title: Sneed's 204 Gains Lead Of 4 Shots
description: MILWAUKEE, July 5 (UPI) Ed Sneed shot a oneunderpar 71 today and increased his lead to four strokes after three rounds in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tourney. His total was 204.

title: Yanks Get 20 Hits, Beat Rangers, 142
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., June 5 Any similiarity between the Yankees of a few nights ago, who were then finding it difficult to put few hits together, and the Yankees who took on the Rangers tonight must have proved a revelation for even their manager, Bill Virdon.

title: Major League Baseball Results and Standings
description: Major League Baseball Results and Standings

title: Newark's New Council Stresses Amity; Says Top Need is Better School System
description: NEWARKThe circus is gone, said Councilman Anthony Giuliano as the new ninemember City Council met briefly Wednesday to approve Federal aid programs.

title: Kroger Company Earnings Rose 46% for 12 Weeks
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's thirdlargest supermarket chain after Safeway and A. & P., achieved earnings increases of 46 per cent in the 12 weeks and 92.3 per cent in the 24 weeks ended June 15 on sales gains of 14.6 per cent in both periods, it was reported yesterday.

title: Rail Freight Traffic is Up 4.5% From the 1973 Week
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.9 billion ton miles, 4.5 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

title: Mets Koosman Beats Giants On Hitting of Schneck, 32
description: To get two hits, knock in two runs and be a hero in the New York Mets' 32 victory over San Francisco was all just a bonus for Dave Schneck last night, the icing on the cake.

title: Report Urges HospitalCommunity Ties
description: A special panel on the expansion of medical facilities here called yesterday for a close planning arrangement between voluntary hospitals and community boards to avoid the conflicts that have turned the two groups into implacable enemies in the past.

title: Chock Full o Nuts Shops Revert To Original NoTipping Policy
description: Chock Full o Nuts has restored the notipping policy that it started out with and maintained for 40 years.

title: Ives Concert a Success
description: DANBURY, Conn., July 5  Danbury made up for its neglect of Charles Ives, a native son and one of America's most important artists, by putting on a Fourth of July concert at the State Fair grounds that attracted 7,000 people, probably the largest audience ever to hear an Ives program anywhere.

title: A Brassy Old Town Brightens Australia's Hinterland
description: KALGOORLIE, Western Australia, July 5By day, Kalgoorlie is little different from dozens of other country towns in the vast hinterland Australia, with its main street of old pubs and new department stores and elderly residents chatting idly in the sun'Only the hoisting frames of the mines along the Golden Mile and the huge, gray plateaus of slag mark it as something more than a watering hole or rural trading post.

title: Dacca Summit
description: Although overshadowed by President Nixon's visit to the Soviet Union, the summit meeting in Dacca last week between Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan and Sheik Mujibur Rahman of Bangladesh was a dramatic event that could have important longrun consequences for the 150 million people of their two countries and for the entire Indian subcontinent. Initial results of the meeting were disappointing. It is unfortunate that no apparent progress was made toward solving problems left over from the Bengali war of independence two and onehalf years ago, such as the division of assets and liabilities, the fate of some 400,000 nonBengali Muslims left stranded in Bangladesh, the establishment of diplomatic relations and resumption of trade.

title: Comic Books About to Be Used As an Aid for Problem Readers
description: Comic books, once scorned by parents and teachers, are about to be tapped by educators as an intellectual resource in solving the reading problems of children.

title: U.S.U.S.S.R. Track Summaries
description: MEN'S TRACK EVENTS WOMEN'S FIELD EVENTS WOMEN'S PENTATHLON

title: 11 Guards and 5 Inmates Injured In a Clash at Prison's Hospital
description: TRENTON, July 5 (UPI)At least 11 guards and five inmates were Injured today, none seriously, in a clash between officers and inmates at the Vroorn Building, the maximumsecurity prison wing of Trenton Psychiatric Hospital.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS REMAINS STOLE FOR FIFTH MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.2 per cent in June, a level that has held essentially stable for five straight months, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Dr. Walter G. Lough Dies; Internist Taught at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Walter G. Lough, professor emeritus of medicine of New York University PostGraduate Medical School, died here Thursday at the age of 89. He lived at 176 East 77th Street.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A Vineland man who was stabbed following an argument at a Fourth of July barbecue was charged in connection with the fatal shooting of one man and the critical wounding of another during the altercation.

title: Mistrial Declared In Case Involving Dun & Bradstreet
description: A mistrial was declared yesterday in the case against Dun & Bradstreet and one of its former district managers, who had been charged with conspiring to defraud the Federal Housing Administration and making false statements that enabled the poor to buy houses with F.H.A.insured mortgages.

title: Dow Declines 1.10
description: I Many brokers and most investors appeared to have tried to stretch the July 4th holiday into a long weekend as volume on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday fell to its lowest level in more than two years.

title: Pro Tennis Groups Are Streamlining Their Formats
description: A tightened and enriched format for World Championship Tennis in 1975 and the secondhalf schedule of the World Team Tennis this month and next are indications of how professional play patterns may stabilize around two poles in the next few years.

title: Lottery Numbers
Chris Evert Captures The Wimbledon Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5This is the year of Chris, Evert. In just an hour today she defeated Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union, 60, 64, and added the Wimbledon tennis title to the Italian and French titles that she won a few weeks ago. She was the runnerup a year ago in all three of these tournaments.

title: Stan Getz, Recovered, Enlivens Fisher Program
description: The Newport Jazz Festival can be grateful for the resilience of Stan Getz's stomach. Mr. Getz had been scheduled to be at the festival's Jazz and the American Song program on Wednesday evening to provide jazz backing for Johnny Mathis and Mabel Mercer and to do a solo turn of his own with the songs of Jerome Kern. But an attack of food poisoning prevented his appearance and left a big hole in the jazz and song program.

title: COFFEE GROWERS PLAN PRICE PROPS
description: PARIS, July 5An organization representing areas producing 85 per oent of the coffee in the world has just announced after a meeting here plans to intervene in coffee markets in New York and London to stop prices from falling.

title: FED STAND ASKED ON NOTE ISSUES
description: Pressures began amassing both here and in Washington yesterday against the more than $1billion in novel, high interest notes that the First National City Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation intend to sell to consumers.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Favored Accipiter Takes Mile As Hatchet Man Finishes 4th
description: The anticipated approximation of a match race between Accipiter and Hatchet Man resulted in a decisive triumph for the former at Aqueduct yesterday. Running easily under Angel At the Santiago, Accipiter, who camRace paigns in the silks tracks of Sigmund Sommer, won the onemile feature by 2% lengths, covering the distance in 1:34 3/5.

title: PLUMBERS JUDGE REFUSES TO QUASH CALL TO KISSINGER
description: Kissinger Told to Be Ready to Testify he said, He's to hold himself in readiness, which is a polite way of saying he is under subpoena. The motion to quash was held in abeyance.

title: Deal Set on Sale Of Dunlop Canada For $10.25Million
description: Dunlop Holdings, Ltd., and Pirelli Group announced in London yesterday that they had signed an agreement to sell Dunlop Canada, Ltd., to the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company of Canada, for $10.25million (Canadian). Dunlop owns 60 per cent of the Canadian company and Pirelli the remander. Under terms of the agreement $8.6million will be paid in August, $1.3million in November and the balance in February, 1975.

title: Jazz Events
description: Today's events in the Newport Jazz Festival:

title: St. Louis Bridge in Use a Century
description: ST. LOUISThe most glorous Fourth ever celebrated in this Mississippi River city was 100 years ago this week when three days of bands, parades and speeches culminated in $10,000 worth of fireworks spangling the city over the river.

title: Notes on People
description: Earl Beacham of Chitenango, N. Y., received his commission as a second lieutenant in the United States Army Reserve this week. What makes this news is that Mr. Beacham is 78 years old and earned his gold bar more than 55 years ago.

title: N.A.A. CY. PARLEY BARS NIXON STAND
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 5 The leadership of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today, for the second year in a row, quashed a move from the convention floor calling for the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: FAMILIES WIN POINT ON NIGHTSPOT FIRE
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 5Jacob D. Fuchsberg, representing some families of the victims of the fire at Gulliver's night spot in Port Chester, obtained an order today from State Supreme Court Judge Morris Lifkin that would grant them the right to participate and observe in the investigation being conducted by District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County and by police and fire officials.

title: Side Issues Detour World Cup Buildup
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 5The announcement of the referee for the final World Cup soccer match Sunday and the denial of drugging reports stirred more excitement today than the PolandBrazil game for third place tomorrow.

title: Nearby Horse Shows AT LAKE PLACID, N.Y.
description: Preliminary JumpersSue Campbell's Mla. AmateurOwner JumpersFoxbrook Farm's Space Citation.

title: DR. JOHN J. SHAW
description: Dr. John J. Shaw, retired chief of dermatology at United Hospital in Newark; died yesterday at the Inglemoore Nursing Home in Livingston, N. J. He was 67 years old and lived at 749 Scotland Road, Orange.

title: Harvard Crews Lead U.S. Gains at Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 5 (AP)Rowing crews from Harvard University spearheaded the United States challenge through the second day at Henley Royal Regatta today.

title: VOLUME ON AMEX HITS 8YEAR LOW
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange were mixed yesterday as volume plummeted to its lowest point in eight years due to the Fourth of July holiday and an exodus of traders from the city. Prices fell in the overthecounter market.The Amex market value index advanced 0.96 to 77.96, but declines led advances, 315 to 256, while 267 issues were unchanged. Volume reached only 1.08 million shares, the lowest point since Oct. 14, 1966, when 1.04 million shares were sold. A total of 1.9 million shares changed hands on Stocks with the largest centage gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: CATTLE FUTURES RISE DAILY LIMIT
description: Live cattlefutures prices jumped the daily pennyapound limit once again, closing at 44,57 cents a pound in terms of the August delivery on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: NO CONTEST PLEADED IN PRICEFIXING CASE
description: Seven of nine manufacturers of paper labels and eight individuals indicted by a Federal grand jury in San Francisco in a criminal pricefixing case last March have pleaded no contest before United States District Judge Charles B. Renfrew.

title: HERMIT IN DEAL FOR PART OF CHAIN
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, July 5 (Reuters)The West German Bank fur Gerneinwirschaft, A.G., a trades union institution, said today it had bought five subsidiary branches of Bankhaus I. 1). Herstatt in and around Cologne for an undisclosed sum.

LEADERS CATCHERCarlton Flsk, Boston, 718,129; Thurman Munson, New York, 487,054; Bill Freeman, Detroit, 455,225; Ray Fosse, Oakland, 265,534; Ed Herman, Chicago, 192,540; Dave Duncan, Cleveland, 189,081.FIRST BASEDick Alin, Chicago, 697,851; Carl Yastrzmskl, Boston, 471,978; John Mayberry, Kansas City, 463,503; Mike Hargrove, Texas, 350,660; Harmon Killebrew, Minnesota, 250,490; Gene Tenace, Oakland, 213,459.

title: American Mior Inns Pact Reached With Holiday Inns
description: American Motor Inns announced yesterday that it had reached a settlement with Holiday Inns under which it would receive $4million in damages plus legal fees. The settlement was a result of September, 1973, ruling by Federal District Court in Newark, which found that certain franchising practices of Holiday Inns were illegal.

title: Rabbi Blau of Israel Dies at 81; Led Sect Opposing Statehood
description: TEL AVIV, July 5Rabbi Amram Blau, leader of a religious fanatical sect that refused to reeognize the state of Israel, died in Jetusalem today at the ageof 81.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: Most Active Stocks MUTUAL FUNDS BANKS AND S & L's INSURANCE OTHER BONDS Supplementary OTC

title: Envoy to Barbados Retiring
description: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, July 5 (AP)The United States ambassador to Barbados, Eileen R. Donovan, one of the highest ranking women in the Foreign Service, has announced that she is retiring and returning to the United States, Miss Donovan has served in Barbados since 1969.

title: What's Sweeter Than Picking Your Own HalfPrice Cherries?
description: LINLITHGO, N. Y., July 4 It's 30 cents a pound and all you can eat, a woman from Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn said as she and her husband left the cherry orchard at Klein's Kill Fruit Farm with 12 pounds of sweet cherries.

title: Georgette Heyer is Dead at 71; Wrote Regency England Novels
description: LONDON, July 5Georgette Heyer, the novelist, died in a hospital here last night after a twomonth illness. She was 71 years old.

title: Lee Konitz on Alto Sax: Cool Style, Warm Ideas
description: Lee Konitz, with his, clean, uncluttered alto saxophone style, teaches much about the basic mechanics of the jazz solo when he plays. Much of the time at Fordham University on Friday afternoonhis concert was part of a free series in conjunction with the Newport Jazz FestivalMr. Konitz appeared with only one other instrument in support, which further served to clarify hti work.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JULY 6, 1974
description: International The State Department said that William B. Macomber Jr., the United States Ambassador to Turkey, had been called back for consultation because of the strained TurkishAmerican relations resulting from Turkey's decision to resume the cultivation of opium poppies. Turkey was once the main source of illegal heroin in the United States. On Monday, Turkey lifted her banimposed in 1971 as part of an agreement with the United Stateson cultivation of the poppy. The 1971 arrangement included an American pledge to give Turkey $35.7million over a fouryear period as compensation. [1:67.1].

title: S. B. Baruch Weds Mrs. Pamela Solins
description: Mrs. Pamela Sue Solins and Stephen Benjamin Baruch, both of Edgewater, N.J., were married yesterday noon by Rabbi Arnold B. Marans at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L. I.

title: Antiques
description: Most of the bird decoys collected by the late William J. Mackey Jr. were stacked like cordwood in the basement of his Belford, N. J., home, recalled Quintina Colio this week. But some, she said, decorated the shelves of his 18thcentury American cupboards and were arranged on the top of his historic Philadelphia Chippendale lowboy that is believed to have once belonged to George Washington.

title: City's ShortWeighting Rule Is Upheld in Federal Court
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a suit that challenged the city's consumeraffairs regulations against shortweighted packages.

Running easily underangel At the Santiago, Accipiter, who camRace paigns in thesilits Tracks of Sigmund Sommer, won the onemile feature by 23 lengths, covering the distance in 1:34 3/5.

title: NEWS INDEX
CHARLES HIRSCHHORN
description: Charles H. Hirschhorn, a founder and the president of the National Tea Packing Company, Inc., of Long Island City, Queens, died Thursday in New York Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 211 Central Park West.

title: PLUMBERS JUDGE REFUSES TO QUASH CALL TO KISSINGER
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The prosecution rested its case today in the conspiracy trial of John D. Ehrlichman and three others, and the judge ordered Secretary of State Kissinger to hold himself in readiness for a possible appearance as a defense witness.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LODI. July 5With the addition of Jim Lago of Lyndhurst, Tony Lakawicz of Elmwood Park and John Nashmy of Bergenfield, the Bergen County Men's Bowling Association Hall of Fame numbers 22 members.

title: Poor Lands Face Barrier Of Food Cost, Expert Says
description: Soaring food costs are making it increasingly difficult for the poorer countriesand poorer people everywhereto get a share of limited food supplies and still find money for almost equally vital needs, such as fuel, according to a leading analyst of international food and population problems.

title: Dr. Edwin Stringham Dies; Taught Music at Columbia
description: Dr. Edwin John Stringham, a composer and musicologist who was the first instructor in music criticism at the Columbia University School of Journalism, died Monday at his home in Chapel Hill, N. C. He was 83 years old.

title: 13 Hurt at Fireworks Show
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 5 (AP) Thirteen persons were injured when a rocket fell into crowd and exploded during fireworks display here yesterday, the police said.

title: CONTRACTOR SLAIN IN PAYROLL ROBBERY
description: An elderly painting contractor was stabbed to death in the hallway of his Brooklyn home yesterday in a payroll robbery.

title: Chris Evert Captures The Wimbledon Title
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 5This is the year of Chris Evert. In just an hour today she defeated Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union, 60, 64, and added the Wimbledon tennis title to the Italian and French titles that she won a few weeks ago. She was the runnerup a year ago in all three of these tournaments.

title: Sikorsky Denies It Bid On Amtrak Contract
description: STRATFORD, Conn., July 5 (AP)A spokesman at the Sikorsky Aircraft division of United Aircraft said today that his company never submitted a bid on the contract for six turbotrains awarded last month by Amtrak to a French concern.

title: A VIOLENT FLARE RECORDED ON SUN
description: A violent solar flare broke out on the sun yesterday in a region where on June 28 scientists first detected unusual activity and have been photographing it daily ever since.

title: Canadian Election Points Up Divisions
description: MONTREAL, July 5For the last eight weeks, political candidates have been telling the Canadian people that the election for a new Parliament next Monday provides an occasion for pulling their huge, diverse land together.

title: Glassblower Murdered At His Shop in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 5Lester Finch, a glassblower who specialized in making delicate knickknacks, was clubbed to death with an iron bar as he worked last night.

title: NIXON FEARED RISK OF HEALTH REPORT
description: MIAMI, July 5President Nixon ordered that the seriousness of his leg ailment be kept secret during his recent trips abroad because he feared public disclosure would interfere with his negotiations with foreign leaders, Gerard L. Warren, the deputy White House press secretary, said today.

title: Radio Station Caller Confesses a Killing, Tells Police of Site
description: Saying he had killed a homosexual, a man using the name Scorpio telephoned a radio station yesterday and directed the police to a Brooklyn apartment where they found a body in a bathtub.

title: Slowdown to Fast Food
description: On Wednesday, the City Planning Commission will probably adopt a limited zoning change that would make it impossible to convert legal nonconforming commercial uses in residential neighborhoods to fastfood places. That technical mouthful means no takeout burgers pizzas on streets like Park Avenue, but not much more. It would simply tighten existing regulations.
