description: News Summary and Index, Page 19

title: Pro Transactions
description: Pro Transactions

title: LEBANON SAID TO BAR MISSILES FOR CAMPS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 5The Lebanese Government has reportedly refused to allow the Palestinian guerrillas to station groundtoair missiles and other heavy weapons at their refugee camps in Lebanon.

title: S.I. RIDERS FACING A STRIKE MONDAY
description: A Federal District Court judge refused yesterday to grant a temporary injunction sought by the Staten Island Rapid Transit system to head off a strike threatened by 36 railroad policemen and track maintenance workers. They plan to walk off their jobs at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Sports Today
description: The Schaefer 500 Indianapolis carrace, at Pocono International Raceway, Long Meadow Pond, Pa. The International cliffdiving champion ship, at Acapulco, Mexico, will also be shown.

title: Huge Arms Cache Is Stolen on Coast From an Armory
description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP)  Enough weapons and ammunition to outfit a full Army company have been stolen from a National Guard armory in suburban Compton, the authorities reported today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SMALL IS BETTER That might be the slogan of the more than 250 small book and magazine publishers from across the country who are coming together this weekend for the beginning of a threeday exhibition of their wares at the New York Cultural Center, Columbus Circle. New York is a town of bigtime publishers and bigname authors, of course, but the sponsors of the New York Book Fair, as they, are calling it, expect a heavy crowd during their exhibition.

title: U.S. Calls Back Its Envoy In Turkish Opium Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The State. Department said today that the Uriited States Ambassador to Turkey had been called back for consultation because of strained TurkishAmerican relations resulting from the Turkish decision to resume the cultivation and sale of opium poppies, once the main source of illegal heroin in this country.

title: Thailand Riot Toll is Put at 25; Violence Appears to Taper. Off
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, July 5 (UPI)Gunfire between policemen and rioters continued for the third night tonight while Premier Sanya Dharmasakti and his Cabinet met in urgent session to decide on measures to end the violence that has plagued Bangkok's Chinese district.

title: Deaths
description: In Memoriam

title: Nuptials Held for Eleanor Pratt West
description: Miss Eleanor Pratt West, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Margerum West of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday afternoon to Paul Charles L'Amoureaux Jr., son of Mrs. and Mrs. L'Amoreaux of Winnetka. III. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Hearing Opens on Cadet Who Married
description: A fivemember military tribunal begin hearings yesterday at the United States Military Academy in the case of a cadet who had been penalized as result of his marriage.

title: Accord on Claims Is Initialed by U.S. And Czechoslovakia
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The United States and Czechoslovakia reached preliminary agreement today on a settlement of financial claims against each other dating to the end of World War II.

title: Those Tax Returns
description: The tax fraud indictment of bandleader Skitch Henderson sharpens questions about the equity with which the nation's tax laws have been administered, with special reference to President Nixon's returns. Mr. Henderson was indicted for alleged acts which at least superficially bear a strong resemblance to those involved in Mr. Nixon's enormous claim for tax deductions based on his gift to the United States of prePresidential papers.

title: Campaign Started By Gulf to Head Off Reforms of Oil Tax
description: PITTSBURGH, July 5The Gulf Oil Corporation has begun a major lobbying effort to head off oil tax reform measures before Congress, it was learned today.

title: GEORGE GENT DIES; A TIMES REPORTER
description: George Gent, who reported on cultural news for The New York Times, died yesterday morning at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N. J. He had been suffering from cancer. He was 49 years old and lived in Wyckoff, N. J.

title: MORTGAGE RATES INCREASED TO 9%
description: Interest rates on Federally insured home mortgages were allowed yesterday to rise to 9 per cent in a move designed to encourage lenders to grant them.

title: PAUL J. KERN. DIES; AIDE OF LA GUARDIA
description: Paul J. Kern, president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission during the Administration of Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died Thursday in San Francisco. He was 66 years old and lived at 380 Cedar Lane, River Vale, N.J.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships Outgoing Passenger and Mail Ships

title: the equipment in Japan and North and South Korea.
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $087million, up 10 per cent from the yearearlier $900million. Total retail store sales were about $10.741billion, up 7 per cent from last year's $10.036billion.

title: Dance: La Bayadere
description: Natalia Makarova's sumptuously successful new staging of La Bayadere has proved a real shot in the arm for American Ballet Theater at the New York State Theater. The ensemble has never danced better in its almost 35 years of existence. The ballet's second performance on Thursday night was every bit as impressive as its first the night before. Indeed, it might have been a little more impressive, if only because it was removed from the firstnight hoopla. The company, slowly and gracefully, was able to demonstrate how fully it can command that imperial Russian ballet style that is the key to this enchanting ballet.

title: OECD. SEES RISE IN CONSUMER COST
description: PARIS. July 5For the sixth consecutive month consumer prices rose by more than 1 per cent in May in the major industrialized countries, the Organiation for Economic Cooperation and De;elopment has just announced.

title: Dave Anderson Kyle. Rote Jr. Views the World Cup
description: To most Americans, the World Cup is a trophy in another world, one where soccer is supreme. But as the United States best known soccer player, Kyle Rote Jr. understand, that world. He also foresees the time when the United States will be a contender. In that connection he talks admiringly of the Netherlands team that will oppose West Germany in Munich tomorrow for the World. Cup title.

title: Newport Jazz
description: Since McKinney's Cotton Pickers are going to play this afternoon at Carnegie Hall as part of the Newport Jazz Festival, it is not unreasonable to assume that many New Yorkers under the age of 50 may ask who and what McKinney's Cotton Pickers are.

title: English Bishops Selection
description: YORK, England, July 5 (AP) Leaders of the Church of England recommended overwhelmingly tonight that 450 years of state involvement in the selection of bishops be ended. By a vote of 271 to 70, leaders at the church's ecclesiastical council decided to start moves to end the selection of bishops by the British Prime Minister and their subsequent appointment by the Queen.

title: PENNY PLANNING RAILACT APPEAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (UPI)  Trustees of the bankrupt Penn Central Transportation] Company announced today that they had filed a notice of appeal to the United States Supreme Court from a lowercourt ruling that struck down as unconstitutional three sections of the new Regional Rail Reorganization Act.

title: StakeOut Officer Slays a Suspect, 16, in a Harlem Subway Mugging
description: A 16yearold youth was shot, and killed Thursday night by a transit policeman who was on a stakeout squad in a Harlem subway station after the youth and four others allegedly tried to mug a 70yearold man, the police reported yesterday.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Pro Tennis Groups Are Streamlining Their Formats
description: A tightened and enriched format for World Championship Tennis in 1975 and the secondhalf schedule of the World Team Tennis this month and next are indications of how professional play patterns may stabilize around two poles in the next few years.

title: ETHIOPIA REPORTS CHANGE IN SENATE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 5 (Reuters)Emperor Haile Selassie was reported today to have appointed an acting president of the Senate following the arrest of the president of the upper house of Parliament by the armed forces earlier this week.

title: Drug Seizures Set Record
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, July (UPI)Mexican Federal officials announced today a new national record in drug seizures25.6 pounds of heroin and cocaine, 73.5 tons of marijuana and 90,000 barbituate pills during a 115day period.

title: Profit Drop Led to Grant Chief's Quitting
description: Richard W. Mayer resigned June 25 as chairman and chief executive of the W. T. Grant Company because the board of the big retail chain was not pleased with last year's 78 per cent earnings decline and decided that Grant's needed a chief executive with a broader marketing background.

title: Sports Today
description: NEWARK, July 5Two 18thcentury farmhouses, the only ones still standing in this city, serve almost as textbook examples of what can happen when Americans take an intelligent interest in their heritage.

title: Finland Threatens Newsprint Cutoff To U.S. Next Year
description: HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 (AP)Finland will stop exporting newsprint to the United States at the beginning of next year if there is no significant increase in American newsprint prices, Finnish paper producers decided today.

title: Soviet Men, Women Lead U.S. in Track
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 5Tom Byers insisted he was fouled from behind, 100 yards from victory. Jimmy Carnes, the United States coach, agreed.never lost to the Russians outdoors in this country. The Soviet women led, 3626.

title: Jersey Tennis Champions
description: KEARNY, N.J, July 5 Jeff Miller of Scotch Plains and Steve Siegel of Teaneck defeated Tom Carey of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Peter Bromley of Mount Kisco, N.Y., 63, 67, 76, for the New Jersey State men's doubles tennis championship today at the Arlington Players Club.

title: Where War is Life: Tales of the Vietnam Delta
description: ONG CHUONG ISLAND, South VietnamIn the delta, it is the war that defines life. The war is ancient, ordinary.

title: Employe of C.I.A. Cover Quit 2 Years Ago
description: SINGAPORE, July 5A man who gave his name as Arthur H. Hochberg left Singapore hurriedly about two, years ago, and has not been heard from since. He left in such a rush that he did not even tell his office landlord that he was pulling out and closing down his small office.

title: MORTGAGE RATES INCREASED TO 9%
description: Interest rates on Federally insured home mortgages were allowed yesterday to rise to 9 per cent in a move designed to encourage lenders to grant them.

title: Japan Company Licensed By American Precision Unit
description: BUFFALO, July 5 (AP)American Precision Industries aid today its subsidiary the Dustex Corporation had licesed a Japanese concern to make Dustex airpollution control and product recovery equipment.

title: CLARK BEGINS TREK IN NOMINATION BID
description: Former United States Attorney General Ramsey Clark, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, yesterday began a trek across the state that is scheduled to take him from Montauk Point at the end of Long Island to Niagara Falls in 40 days.

title: Black Eagle of Harlem, 77, Looks Back On Days as Flier and Soldier of Fortune
description: Fifty years ago this week, Hubert FauntleroY Julian, the, Black Eagle of Harlem, took off, from the Harlem River to they cheers of thousands on what was billed as a flight to Ethiopia.

title: Tigers Defeat White Sox, 96 and 74
description: Pitchers are a singular lot they hate all batters with unbridled ferocity. Especially do they hate homerun hitters who go on streaks.

title: 42 on Amtrak Train Hurt as Cars Jump Track at 70 M.P.H.
description: MELVERN, Kan., July (UPI)Thirteen cars of an Amtrak passenger trainthe old Super Chief"jumped the trackat 70 miles an hour today, and four sleeper cars, a lounge car and a diner plunged down 50foot embankment. Fortytwo persons were injured, some seriously.

title: Summaries of the Races
description: Harvard University defeated Aberdeen Ur.I verslty, Scotland, 4 lengths, 7:23:

title: PANEL'S LAWYERS QUERY MITCHELL
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Former Attorney General John N. Mitchell has been questioned for nearly three hours by counsel for the House Judiciary Committee and has restated his position that he will not testify in the impeachment inquiry unless compelled by subpoena, his lawyer said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: PAINE. By David Freeman Hawite. 500 pages, Illustrated. Harper & Row, $15.

title: 3 High Greek Aides Reported to Resign; Cyprus Issue Cited
description: ATHENS, July 5 (AP)Authoritative sources said today that Greece's Foreign Minister and two highranking diplomatic officials had resigned as a result of the country's deteriorating relations with the Turkish and Cypriote Governments.

title: Events Today
description: LIGHT OPERA OF MANHATTAN, Jan Hus Playhouse, Gilbert and Sullivan's Fhe Pirates of Penzance, 4 and 8:30.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Boeing Company announced yesterday that KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ordered two Boeing 747B airliners, Including spare parts, the order is valued at about $80million. The planes are scheduled for delivery in late 1975.

title: Reliance Wins Settlement In Case Charging Fraud
description: Reliance Group, Inc., formerly the Leasco Corporation, has won a $6.2million outofcourt settlement from British Book publisher Robert Maxwell, in a case charging him and others with fraud and misrepresentation in connection with the Reliance purchase of an interest in Pergamon Press, Ltd., in 1969.

title: Drug Ring Broken
description: The Justice Department says a drug ring that smuggled $32.7million in cocaine into the United States by using Chilean diplomatic pouches and military flights has been disrupted with the arrests of 22 persons. Page 7.

title: Distribution Ready For Football Film
description: The Football Writers Association of America has announced that its annual film of the organization's allAmerica team is ready for distribution.

title: Sneed's 204 Gains Lead Of 4 Shots
description: MILWAUKEE, July 5 (UPI) Ed Sneed shot a oneunderpar 71 today and increased his lead to four strokes after three rounds in the $130,000 Greater Milwaukee open golf tourney. His total was 204.

title: City May End Its Contract On Concrete Litter Baskets
description: Unhappy with the condition of the 470pound streetcorner concrete baskets that were hailed as the ideal way to control litter and earn money for the city, the Beame administration says it may oust the company that owns and maintains the baskets.

title: Futile Cries Point Up an Urban Problem
description: An incident that happened during the sultry Fourth of July afternoon to one New York woman at a wellknown West Side store has pointed up an anguishing urban question: What are the responsibilities of a private citizen to come to the aid of a person who calls out for help against a possibly criminal act?

title: U.S. Judge Bars Back Payments Over Error by Social Security
description: A Federal judge in Connecticut has ruled that an elderly Germanborn immigrant who said he had been misinformed by Federal officials on his for Social Security could not collect six years of back payments.

title: Litton to Liquidate HewittRobins Unit
description: BUFFALO, July 5 (AP)Litton Industries said today it planned to liquidate its HewittRobins plant after unsuccessful attempts to sell it.

title: Regional Enforcement Sought By Outgoing State Police Head
description: TRENTONNew Jersey's several hundred local police departments should be consolidated into regional forces if they are to keep up with growing, changing state and the evasive tactics of organized crime, in the opinion of Col. David B. Kelly, who retired last weekend as superintendent of the New Jersey State Police.

title: Crucial Questions and Answers On U.S.Soviet Arms Test Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The United States and the Soviet Union signed a treaty this week to limit underground nuclear weapons tests, Following are some questions and answers about the agreement.

title: LIGHTNING KILLS GIRL, 15, IN PARK
description: Lightning struck and killed a 15yearold girl and injured two young sisters, one of them critically, near a small lake at the north enc of Central Park yesterday afternoon during a brief but severe thunderstorm that blackened the skies and drenched the metropolitan area.

title: Philadelphia Papers Publish
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (UPI) The city's three major daily newspapers resumed full publication schedules today after dissident delivery truck drivers decided to halt wildcat work stoppages in protest against an approved contract. The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Daily News and The Bulletin said they planned to resume full publication and deliveries to newsstands and homes after the drivers returned to work at The Inquirer yesterday.

title: OneDiamond Opener Poses Bridge: Problem for the Rebidding
description: A recurring headache for standard bidders is the rebid problem that arises when the opening bid is one diamond and the response is two clubs. If the opener has a minimum hand he has various optionsand on occasion all of them are unsatisfactory.

title: Peron Aide is Prominent in the Corridors of Power
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 5Only a few hours after Juan Domingo. Peron's death last Monday, a short, whitehaired and extremely pale man appeared on Argentine television to confirm the news and, according to his most strident critics, to lay claim to a sizable piece of the fallen leader's mantle.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal District Court judge refused yesterday to grant a temporary injunction sought by the Staten Island Rapid Transit system to head off a strike threatened by 36 railroad policemen and track maintenance workers. They plan to walk off their jobs at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: State to Restudy L.I. Expressway Plan
description: State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler yesterday ordered the suspension of further planning to double the number of lanes or otherwise expand the capacity of the Long Island Expressway in Queens.

title: Enclosed Sidewalk Cafes Facing Closer Re orr.
description: SIDEWALK CAFES ARE FLOURISHing in New York this summer, and while officials still welcome new openair cafes that add a flair to the city's streets, the flair officials are considering same official guidelines for enclosed cafes that take up sidewalk space.

title: The Nixon Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The cases corning up in the Supreme Court on Monday are of enormous interest. Some novel constitutional questions are to be explored, and the Court's decisions may indirectly affect President Nixon's continuance in office. Yet for all the historic ambience of these cases, there can hardly be much suspense about their probable outcome.

title: Aide of a Senate Panel, in Cuba, Is Expected to Talk With Castro
description: WASHINGTON, July 5Pat M. Holt, chief of staff of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is in Cuba and is preparing to confer with Premier Fidel Castro, according to sources in Havana.

title: State to Restudy L.I. Expressway Plan
description: State Transportation Commissioner Raymond T. Schuler yesterday ordered the suspension of further planning to double the number of lanes or otherwise expand the capacity of the Long Island Expressway in Queens.

title: Eurodollar Borrowings Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (Reuters)Liabilities of United States banks to their foreign branches rose $866million to $3.36billion in the week ended June 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. This was $1.84billion higher than the level of Eurodollar borrowings in the week ended June 27, 1973.

title: Top Rookie Of Chargers Joins Strike
description: SAN DIEGO, July 5 (AP) The striking National Football League Players Association won a victory of sorts today in its threedayold strike when Dan Goode, one of the San Diego Chargers firstround draft choices, left the training camp and joined the picket line.

title: High Price of Illness
description: The average cost of patient care in the city's voluntary hospitals already at a staggering $150aday levelwill go up by at least $15 immediately as a result of the substantial wage increases a state arbitration panel has ordered for 35,000 orderlies, kitchen aides and other nonprofessional employes.

title: People in Sports
description: Ben Jipcho of Kenya, who won gold medals at the Olympic Games in Munich in 1972, may have to return them if the Kenya Amateur Athletic Association can prove that he was paid while running as an amateur.

title: Elvin Jones Leads Mix In Jazz Bill
description: International aspects of jazz, East and West Coast variants of jazz and even the question of what constitutes jazzall these came together in a Newport Jazz Festival program at Avery Fisher Hall late Thursday evening.

title: An Argument for Eliminating Broadcasting's Fairness Doctrine
description: A free press must include all journalism if it is to serve its common purpose in a free society. Journalism transmitted over the air should no more be inhibited by government than the print media from informing the people, from stimulating discussion and from helping citizens thereby to take the action, essential to effective selfgovernment.

title: People in Sports
description: Ben Jipcho of Kenya, who won gold medals at the Olympic Games in Munich in 1972, may have to return them if the Kenya Amateur Athletic Association, can prove that he was paid while running as an amateur.

title: Business Loans by Banks Climbed to Peak in Week
description: Business loans rose by a record of almost $1.1billion in the week ended Wednesday at major New York City banks, iaccording to figures released yesterday by the New York Federal Reserve Bank.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Supreme Court Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg ordered that, pending a further hearing next Wednesday, landlords of 100,000 rentcontrolled apartments need not return money they owe their tenants under a recent law enacted by the city. The law repealed socalled laborcost rent increases of up to 4 per cent a year and it made the repeal retroactive.

title: Enclosed Sidewalk Cafes Facing Closer Regulation
description: Sidewalk cafes are flourishing in New York this summer, and while officials still welcome new openair cafes that add a flair to the city's streets, the same officials are considering tighter guidelines for enclosed cafes that take up sidewalk space.

title: Mistrial Declared In Case Involving Dun & Bradstreet
description: A mistrial was declared yesterday in the case against Dun & Bradstreet and one of its former district managers, who had been charged with conspiring to defraud the Federal Housing Administration and making false statements that enabled the poor to buy houses with F.H.A.insured mortgages.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX

title: Chou, 111, Under Treatment in Hospital
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, July 6Chou Enlai, China's 76yearold Premier, is being treated in a hospital in Peking, Hsinhua, the official press agency, reported early today.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Jockeys

title: In Space Station After Soft LinkUp
description: MOSCOW, July 5Two Soviet astronauts were orbiting the earth tonight in the Salyut 3 space station after their Soyuz 14 spacecraft, in which they rose from the earth on Wednesday, made a smooth linkup with the station before dawn this morning.

title: Gold Gains
description: BRUSSELS, July 5 (UPI) Gold recovered hesitantly today from its lowest price in more than five months, while the United States dollar moved erratically in European markets and advanced in Tokyo.

title: Kissinger Talks to Allies And Mends Some Fences
description: ROME, July 5Secretary of State Kissinger met with allied leaders, in Paris and Rome today, and the Italian Foreign Minister said: This is the way we think the alliance should work.

title: Elizabeth Will Study Clash Of Citizens and Policemen
description: ELIZABETH, July 5 (UPI)A full investigation into a clash yesterday between policemen and residents of the Peterstown section, in which 11 policemen were injured, was ordered today by Mayor Thomas G. Dunn in an attempt to prevent further violence over the weekend.

title: Sears, Roebuck Sales Advance; Other Chains Results Mixed
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., the nation's leading merchandise chain, reported yesterday a 3.8 per cent increase in sales for the month of June. It was the smallest gain for any month since June, 1972, when it was 3.4 per cent.

title: People and Business
description: The world's 10th largest hank, Credit Lyonnais in Paris, has appointed a new chairman. He is 59yearold Jacques Chaine, who previously was chairman of the Banque du Commerce Exterieur, France's equivalent of the ExportImport Bank.

title: Humphrey is Linked to Inquiry By Jaworski Into Dairy Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The special Watergate prosecutor's investigation of illegal political contributions by representatives of dairy farm cooperatives has embraced Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1972, according to reliable sources.

title: Soviet Men, Women Lead U.S. in Track
description: DURHAM, N. C., July 5Tom Byers insisted he was fouled from behind, 100 yards from victory. Jimmy Carnes, the United States coach, agreed.

title: Assemblyman Williams Guilty of Lying
description: Assemblyman Calvin Williams, Democrat of Brooklyn, was convicted of perjury yesterday by a State Supreme Court jury for having lied about an accident in which a car sideswiped two parked cars nearly four years ago on BedfordStuyvesant street.

title: Survivors of 1972 Dam Disaster Accept $13.5Million Settlement
description: The Pittston Company, the owner of a coal mine dam that breached in February, 1972, causing the deaths of 125 West Virginians in the valley below, announced here yesterday that it had settled a $65million damagesuit by the survivors out of court for $13.5million.

title: Wimbledon Summaries
description: WOMEN'S SINGLES

title: Festival in Corfu is Canceled; Many Face Losses This Month
description: Scores of American musicians engaged to participate in the 1974 Corfu Festival in Greece were notified Thursday and yesterday that the festival had been canceled because of overwhelming inflation and the failure of some financial sources.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: I.C.C. WILL STUDY RAIL GRAIN SHIPPING
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP)  The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it would investigate whether a railroad rule allowing grain shippers to retain freight cars indefinitely was being used to create a black market in freight cars.

title: Sports Today
description: The Schaefer 500 Indianapolis, carrace, at Pocono International Raceway, Long Meadow Pond, Pa. The International cliffdiving championship, at Acapulco, Mexico, will also be shown.

title: Business Records
description: Petition filed by; D. CRAIG VANCE, R.D. #3 Holiday Brook Road, Roscoe, N.Y. Liabilities, $9,082; assets, $2390.

title: Dr. Alfred H. Williams, 81, Of Reserve, Wharton Dean
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 5 (AP) Dr. Alfred H. Williams, former president of the Feddal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia and former dean of the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, died Wednesday at his home in Wailingford. He was 81 years old.

title: Tonight's Roosevelt Entries
description: Roosevelt Raceway Results

title: 22 Held in $32.7Million Cocaine Ring
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) A drugsmuggling ring that allegedly brought $32.7million worth of cocaine into this country by using Chilean diplomatic pouches and military flights has been disrupted with the arrest of 22 persons this week, according to the Justice Department.

title: Ohio Town Opposes A Plan for Dumping New York Garbage
description: CADIZ, Ohio, July 5A proposal to dump tons of garbage from New York City into the hills of this southern Ohio village has brought protests from residents.

title: Shark Repeller for Swimmer Devised
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 A Florida college instructor and a friend have invented an electrical method for repelling sharks. The equipment, which a swimmer can wear on his back, automatically goes into operation when immersed in water.

title: Accountability Plan Angers Teachers, With Many Foreseeing Threat to Job
description: Accountability Plan Angers Teachers,

description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was: 432031

title: Energy Chaos
description: Federal Energy Administrator John C. Sawhill is quoted as discouraged by the way energy demand has shot up since the end of the Arab oil embargo. Since Americans obviously are not conserving energy as they did only a few monthsor weeksago, the Administration, includ ing Mr. Sawhill himself, has the duty to speak out on the subject with force and conviction. Why doesn't the Administration tell the country the facts about the energy situation now instead of waiting for the next crisis, which officials privately foresee for the coming winter?

title: To the Tourists, New York is Still a Great Place to Visit
description: For Basil and Inge Tomberlin of Keene, N. H.; and their two children, Shanna, 4 years old, and Steven, 3 months, as well as for Mr. Tomberlin's parents, Roy and Viola Tomberlin of Seattle, yesterday's oneday excursion to the top of the Empire State Building was the quintessence of dedicated tourism.

description: Should a company offer I price considerably in excess of the current market for a major block of its own shares and not offer the rest of the company's shareholders a chance to participate?

title: Mrs. Breer Leads By Stroke on 70
description: GRAND ISLAND, N.Y., (AP) Mrs. Murle Breer carded a birdie, a holeinone and another eagle in succession today in the Niagara Frontier golf tournament. She posted a threeunderpar 7, and took a onestroke lead.

title: DIRECTOR SHARING IN NEW ENGLAND HIT
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) A New England lawmaker criticized today two Federal commissions for permitting electric utilities and banks to share common directors, which he said was in violation of the law.

title: LIGHTNING KILLS GIRL, 15, IN PARK
description: Lightning struck and killed a 15yearold girl and injured two young sisters, one of them critically, near a small lake at the north end of Central Park yesterday afternoon during a brief but severe thunderstorm that blackened the skies and drenched the metropolitan area.

title: Art: An Esthetic Smorgasbord in Chicago
description: CHICAGOThe task of selecting a persuasive and representative survey of contemporary American art has never been more difficult than at the present moment. No single style can be said to dominate either the consciousness of our artists or the sympathies of the art public. Call it pluralism or anarchy, creative freedom or sheer aimlessnessimmense divergencies of taste, loyalty and outlook now divide critics, museum curators and collectors quite as much as they haunt the disparate efforts of the artists themselves.

title: Farmington, N.M., is Beginning to Harvest Fruits Of 100 Years of Indian Bitterness and Frustration
description: FARMINGTON, N. M.The city of Farmington is beginning to reap a crop of bitterness.

title: What Nukes Are Good Nukes?
description: PARISThe United States Government quite obviously expects political relations with France to become more intimate under its newly installed Government and the prospect of a NixonGiscard d'Estaing summit, following one of Henry Kissinger's pathfinding missions, will certainly help warm friendship that has sometimes faltered.

title: WINE TALK
description: Last week in this space some lines were given over to a reader who noted that, regardless of the bottle size, most wine shippers did not hesitate to say that it contained a pint and 8 ounces. Then the reader gave what he considered to be the actual liquid measurement equivalents of bottles holding 70, 72, 74 and 75 centiliters.
