title: Christina H. Langmuir is a Bride
description: Miss Christina Hiscox Langmuir and Robert Jeffrey Riotte were married yesterday afternoon in Edgartown, Mass., (Martha's Vineyard). The Rev. Robert Hammett, an Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. Brian Roberge of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony in the Federated Church.

title: Nearby Horse Shows
description: Preliminary JumpersSue Campbell's Mia. AmateurOwner JumpersFobbrook Farm's Space Citation.

title: COOKE ASKS A FAST TO BACK AFRICANS
description: Cardinal Cooke has proposed that the Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York make a continuing personal sacrifice a to demonstrate again in a very personal, private way that we truly share a concern for the starving and undernourished people in Africa south of the Sahara, in Ethiopia and in other places.

title: Phillip Berrigan, in Cage At White House, is Held
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) Philip F. Berrigan, the antiwar activist, was arrested today on the street outside the White House as he sat shackled in a simulated tiger cage prison cell. The cage, a 3by8by4foot structure used in South Vietnam, was mounted on a flatbed truck and was on display.

title: Michael Gerald Ford Weds Miss Brumbaugh
description: Miss Gayle Ann Brumbaugh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Brumbaugh, was married in Catonsville, Md., yesterday to Michael Gerald Ford, eldest son of Vice President and Mrs. Ford.

title: U.S. Calls Back Its Envoy In Turkish Opium Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, July 5The State Department said today that the United States Ambassador to Turkey had been called back for consultation because of strained TurkishAmerican relations resulting from the Turkish decision to resume the cultivation and sale of opium poppies, once the main source of illegal heroin in this country.

title: OpenAir Cafes: A Drink Amid the Fumes
description: Yes, there are sidewalk cafes in New York. But if you're cherishing memories of the Boulevard St. Germain in Paris, or Rome's Via Veneto, forget it. The justbrewed espresso, the leisurely read of a newspaper, the whiling away of hours watching the street theater of the passing strollers, who in turn stare at youremember?

title: Policeman Balks Rape Attempt But Tenants Ignore Plea for Aid
description: Tenants in a Jamaica, Queens, apartment building turned deaf ears early yesterday to pleas for aid from an offduty policeman who had prevented a rape, the police reported.The officer, Myron Cherry of the West 123d Street station in Manhattan, said in an interview that he was in the stairwell of the apartment building for 40 minutes holding at bay three men he had arrested for allegedly trying to rape an unconscious woman. A fourth suspect escaped.body would make that lousy call to help me. I knocked on five doors, Officer Cherry said, and no

title: HUNGARY IS TOLD TO TAP HOT WELLS
description: BUDAPESTHungary, which has been soaking away her rheumatic aches in steaming subterranean mineral water since Roman times, is hoping to offset the soaring cost of fossil fuels with her own geothermal heat.

title: Fire Department Bans Long Hair and Beards
description: Contending that flare rather than flair is the proper concern of hirsute firemen, the Fire Department has banned long hair, beards, goatees, muttonchop sideburns and handlebar mustaches, effective tomorrow.

title: The Broader View
description: The end of the long Independence Day weekend is another turning point in the inquiry into the conduct of the Nixon Administrationand we may be approaching something conclusive somewhere around that corner. On Monday, for the first time, the Supreme Court becomes a participant, and the House Judiciary Committee returns for the crucial phase of its impeachment study.

title: Coppola Plans A Detroit Epic
description: Although he has pot been forced into an offer he couldn't refuse, Francis Ford Coppola, director of The Godfather and its sequel, Godfather II, admits that he is already involved in three future films. They are thematically unrelated to previous Coppola projects like The Conversation or The Great Gatsby, the producerdirectorwriter said. They will be made as entirely independent, privately financed productions, he added, and while I'll personally only make one, I'll supervise all three films.

title: The New york Times Book Rivew Editors'Choice
description: THE DEATH OF THE DETECTIVE, by Mark Smith. (Knopf, $8.95.) A madman who envisions himself as Death stalks his victims and is in turn hunted by a detective in this crowded, inventive novel set on Chicago's dark side.

title: Judge Backs 2 Newsmen On Their Refusal to Talk
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass, July (AP)A judge has ruled that two Lowell newsmen could not be compelled to disclose who had given them details of a grand jury investigation of alleged bribery involving Dracut town officials.

title: Pope and Kissinger Discuss the Mideast
description: ROME, July 6Secretary of State Kissinger briefed Pope Paul VI on the recent AmericanSoviet summit talks in Moscow and discussed Middle East problems with the Pope during 70minute audience in the Vatican today.

title: PORTUGAL HOLDS 3 IN A 1965 SLAYING
description: LISBON, July 6At least three persons are reported under arrest here on charges of having participated in Portugal's most notorious political crimethe slaying of Gen. Humberto Delgado, once the major leader of the opposition to the country's now fallen dictatorship.

title: Those Copycat Fragrances
description: For women who have always loved real perfume but had to settle for cologne, relief may well be at hand as several small companies arc now advertising what they assert to be copies of famous perfumes at savings of 60 to 80 per cent.

title: Chilly Flight for Mechanic
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July (UPI)An airline mechanic was locked in the livestock section of a cargo plane yesterday but survived a chilly flight to Seattle. The Pan American World Airways employe, Leo Boukanovsky, was doing maintenance work in the plane when the compartment doors slammed shut and the plane took off for London. He got out of the plane when it landed in Seattle to pick up more cargo.

title: Future Social Events
description: New Capability Browns?

title: Letter: Brookhaven Building Moratorium Scored
description: To the Editor: In a recent story concerning the building moratorium in Brookhaven, a point was missed which should have been brought out, and that was the impact on the economy of Suffolk.

title: Mrs. D'Atri Bride on L.I.
description: Mrs. Helena Sherwood D'Atri of Titusville, N. J., widow of Ralph W. D'Atri who was president of EquipcoTrenton, an engineering concern in Trenton, was married yesterday afternoon to Victor J. Georgetti of Garden City, L. I., who heads his own engineering construction firm there.

title: JAMAICA BATTLES MARIJUANA RINGS
description: KINGSTON, JamaicaIn determined campaign to combat drug trafficking from this Caribbean island, the Jamaican authorities have hunted out and destroyed at least 10 clandestine airstrips.

title: Supreme Co:tiffs Tapes Hearing Is a Sellout
description: WASHINGTON, July 6The hottest ticket in Washington this weekend will not get you into the local sports arena, the Kennedy Center Opera, House, the Wolf Trap Outdopr Performing Arts Center or the private White House tour.

title: News of Dogs
description: A Siberian husky creates a picture of the frozen North and a dog sled. Mrs. Linda Siegel never has driven a team over the tundra but she and her husky, EuMnr's Kelev, have prayen to be a winning team in the obedience ring. They are a prime example of what can he accomplished in a metropolis, for they are training in a public park and on the roof of a West Side a part men t house.

title: Summaries of Yesterday's Events in U.S.U.S.S.R. Track Meet
Inflation Goes Around the World
description: The 24nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported last week that, for the sixth consecutive month, consumer prices rose by more than 1 per cent in May in the major industrialized countries.

title: GRAIN FOOD STUDY ASKS ENRICHMENT
description: The Federal Government's chief independent scientific research arm has concluded that significant numbers of Americans suffer a variety of vitamin and mineral deficiencies and has recommended that all foods made of wheat, corn and rice be enriched with 10 essential nutrients.

title: Something for Viewers More Interested in the News Than in Personalities
description: WHAT do you do when your competition is the Today show, the earlymorning money machine entrenched on NBC? Next January ABC, which has resisted getting into that particular morning TV game, will offer its stations a new twohour lomat of news and entertainment, apparently designed for a headon confrontation with Today. CBS, on the other hand, tried doing exactly thatand failed. So now, the CBS Morning News, using only one morning hour (7 to 8 in New York) Monday through Friday, has returned to doing what it did best in the first place: hard news and news analysis.

title: Newport Jazz
description: If one were to judge by a Newport Jazz Festival program called Friends of Eddie Condon and Ben Webster on Friday evening at Carnegie Hall, Mr. Condon's friends are a lot more fun than Mr. Webster's. Both Mr, Condon, the saloonkeeper, guitarist and philosopher, and Mr. Webster, one of the greatest of tenor saxophonists, died within the last year, and this program was a tribute to both of them.

title: Pro Transactions
description: NEW YORK (NBA)Signed Harthorne Wingo, forward; Tom Riker, center; Dennis Bell. Ken ??? and Fred Hilton, guards.

title: Miss Hanifin Engaged To Thomas Reagan Jr.
description: Plans have been made by Miss Elizabeth Chauvenet ilanifin and Thomas Joseph Peagan Jr. for a late August wedding. Their engagement has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John William Hanifin of Hunting Valley, Ohio. Mr. Reagan is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reagan of Savannah, Ga.

title: Eileen Kelly Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Francis Kelly of Bay Shore, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Mary Kelly, to Richard George Henning, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Valentine Henning of Garden City, L.I. A September wedding is planned.

title: Game Shows Now Dominate Daytime TV
description: BEGINNING two weeks from tomorrow, television viewers who watch Channel 4 on weekdays between the hours of 9:30 A.M. and 2 P.M. will be able to watch no fewer than nine straight game shows. That's not a trend, that's a glut.

title: Handicapped. Are Given Site for Picnic
description: A group of handicapped people who had been denied the use of Forest Park in Queens for a weekend outing next month learned last week that the city had changed its mind. The group will have a picnic at the park after all.

title: Two Bands Bring Back Old Times
description: Time turned backward at Carnegie Hall on Saturday afternoon, when the Newport Jazz Festival presented the music of two longdeparted big bandsMcKinney's Cotton Pickers, which flourished from 1927 to 1931, when Don Redman was the group's musical director, and Tommy Dorsey's orchestra of the late nineteenthirties and early forties.

title: Emission Test Tying Up Auto Inspection Lanes
description: NORTH BRUNSWICKThe line at the Inspection Station here begins forming at 6 A.M., and the first motorist on it knows that, even if his vehicle does not pass,. at least he will not have spent more than an hour and a half to learn the bad news.

title: Some Feel That to Spare the Rod Will Spoil the School
description: The periodical disturbance about the beating of youth has just come around again  the question as to the propriety of using the rod is a very difficult one to decide. Whether corporal punishment is essential to education is a point continually debated, but the discussion commonly leaves off where it began.

title: New Jersey
description: ACTOR'S CAFETHEATER, 263 Ctntral Avenue, East Orange Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living in Paris. Sunday, 7;30 P.M.; Thursday through Saturday, 8;30 P.M. (through Aug. 3). $3.50$4.90; students and the elderly, $2.50$3.90; group rates. (201) 675.1881.

title: MiddleSchool Concept Is Growing in Popularity in Central and Eastern Suffolk
description: NORTHPORT  I don't feel the junior high school bas any validity any more, from the sole point of view that ninthgraders set an example that is too advanced in social behavior for seventh and eighthgraders to deal with, said Mario Di Sciullo, principal of the Middle Island Middle School the other day.

title: Visions of Suffolk Photographers Displayed
description: HUNTINGTON  They use the same tools, but the worlds they discover are worlds apart.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The Way They Stand Today

title: Passaic Students Doing Rural Jobs
description: WALLPACK CENTER For the second summer, 60 Passaic High School students are working hereabout in what has been described as an experimental conservation project. The program is believed to be the only one of its kind in the state.

title: Ideas & Trends
description: A hospital technician calls an epileptic at work 30 miles away. The patient is told to increase his anticonvulsant medication. Review of his electroencephalogram, transmitted from an inconspicuous recording monitor attached to his scalp, had warned of an impending seizure.

title: But Essentials Are the Same: Money, Patronage, Power
description: The postwar population shift from city to suburbs has been followed by the growth of the kind of monolithic political machine in parts of suburbia that was once strictly the fare of big cities. Political bossism is, in fact, flourishing in the suburbs while it is more or less holdng its own in New York City. The new suburban machine is epitomized by the Nassau County Republican organization run by Assemblyman Joseph M. Margiotta, just as Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, retains the title as the city's preeminent political leader.

title: The World /Continued In Summary
description: In an effort to force the Spanish Government to live up to an eightyearold proclamation to liberalize political life, 400 Spaniards have sued the nation's Ministry of Information to permit publication of a new daily newspaper in Madrid.

title: Even Brownstoning Was Better in 1934
description: Nostalgia and reminiscence being the order of the day, I must recall my brownstone experience in 1934. We were babes in the woods; my husband and I. We had been married four years and had lived in five apartments, all in brownstones, all equally unsatisfactory. The latest one, at 370 Bleecker, had a kitchenette with a dish cupboard near the ceiling. It could not be reached without a ladder. The bathroom looked out over a car repair garage. It had no shower, but nice tiles. The landlord who had renovated this brownstone hated showers. The closets were too small even for a Depression wardrobe.

title: Governor Hopefuls Slacken Campaigns For July 4 Holiday
description: Yesterday was a light day for campaigning, as the three gubernatorial candidates apparently joined many other residents of the state in seizing the holiday weekend as chance to relax.

title: MRS. EUGENE A. YATES
description: Mrs. Margaret Yates of 200 East 66th Street, the widow of Eugene Adams Yates, former chairman of the board of the Southern Company, a utility holding company, died yesterday at Cape Cod Hospital in Hyannis, Mass., Mrs. Yates, who had a summer home in Nantucket, was 86 years old.

title: Wimbledon Champions Are at Love at Ball
description: LONDON, July 6 (UPI) The most famous sweethearts in sports and the new Wimbledon champions, Chris Evert and Jimmy Connors, opened the traditional championship ball at the Grosvenor House Hotel tonight by dancing to the tune, The Girl That I Marry.

title: Los Angeles Transit Gains Amid Debate
description: LOS ANGELES, July 6For years, rapid transit in this city was a dinner table joke. Ange. lenos recounted stories of halfempty buses that rolled past waiting passengers, of schedules that went awry, of fares that jumped alarmingly at each new zone.

title: Helen Lazarus, Ronald Freeman Will Be Married
description: Miss Helen Lazarus, a magna cum laude graduate of Smith College, class of 70, plans to be married to Ronald Michael Freeman, an associate in the corporatefinance department of Salomon Brothers, the stockbrokers.

title: What's New at the Movies
description: What's New at the Movies

title: Ellen Polly Levine Bride of Surgeon
description: The marriage of Miss Ellen Polly Levine, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Levine of Elizabeth, N. J., to Dr. G. Gregory Gallico 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gallico Jr. of Ridgewood, N. J., took place yesterday afternoon in New Haven.

title: Deborah Lyons Bride Of John S. Liggett Jr.
description: Miss Deborah Ann Lyons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lyons of Blackwood, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to John S. Liggett Jr., who is in his third year at the Jefferson Medical. School in Philadelphia. Hes the son of Dr. and Mrs. Liggett of Sewickley, Pa.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: A routine monitoring operation at the Space Environment Laboratory at Boulder, Colo., combined with clear weather over the Rockies last week to produce a dramatic picture of the most energetic sun flare to be precisely recorded.

title: Picture Postcards Since the 1880's: Rich and Potent Folk Art
description: THE exhibition of picture postcards currently at the Emily Lowe Gallery of Hofstra University, in Hempstead, Long Island, is such a good idea It makes one marvel that nobody ever thought of it before. Called Wish You Were Here and organized by the gallery's director, Robert R. Littman, the show contains about 2,000 postcards ranging in provenance from Victorian England to presentday Ogden, Utah. It will remain where it is until Aug. 25, then come to the New York Cultural Center on Sept. 12 for a monthlong stay.

title: Reggie Workman, on Bass, Backs Tyner and Hubbard
description: Reggie Workman, the bassist, lived up to his name at a Newport Jazz Festival concert late Friday evening at Carnegie Hall. Aside from a brief appearance by the Wild Magnolias, a group of colorfully costumed Mardi Gras singers and dancers from New Orleans, the program was shared by two groupsthe McCoy Tyner Quintet and the Freddie Hubbard Quintet. Mr. Workman served as bassist for both groups, each of which concentrated on fast, driving performances that challenge the endurance of a bassist. Mr. Workman endured, and quite successfully.

title: Footnotes Before the Footlights
description: ITHACA, N.Y.,When he became associated with the Southeast Asia Program at Cornell University last year, Raul Manglapus, the former Foreign Secretary of the Philippines, decided that he wasn't going to waste his time writing a treatise on political science that would end up unread on dusty library shelves.

title: Nixon Picks Partner (Age 10) for a Dance
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., July 6 (UPI)  President Nixon, ebullient and impulsive, danced tonight with,10yearold Lisa Berry of Fort Lauderdale, Fla as the band at the Key Biscayne Hotel played Thank Heaven for little Girls.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY, JULY 7, 1974
description: The Major Events of the DaySection

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Weekly tickets, dated rest Thursday, With the ticket number or the accounting number matching the winning number, or with either set of six numbers in reverse, win $500.

title: There Is Quebec, Then All the Rest of Canada
description: MONTREALOn the surface there Is much talk about national unity, but at election time in Canada there is always an elementquite beyond the issues of the daythat tends to divide the country. It is the watch over the vote in Frenchspeaking Quebec province, and what it means for Englishspeaking Canada.

title: David Renton to Wed Miss Flood
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Francis Flood of Larchmont, N. Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Marie Flood, to Ddvid Malcolm Renton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Joseph Renton of Avalon, Calif.

title: Deaths
description: ACHESONEdward Joseph, 79 years. Retired teacher N. Y. C Board of Education, beloved husband of Rose, devoted father of Eileen Bohn. Reposing at Piro Funeral Home, corner of DeKalb and Vanderbilt Ayes. unlit Monday, 9 A.M. Mass at Queen of All Saints R. C. Church, 9:45 A.M. Visiting hours, 2 to 5 and 7 to 10 P.M. ALTSCHULMilton. Adored son of Ida. Beloved nusband of Shirley. Devoted father of Judy and George Altman and Marsha and Arnold Gilbert. Loving grandfather Scott, Todd and Ian. Dear brother of Gloria Leeds, David and the late Nathaniel. Services Sunday, July 7, 12:30 P.M. at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdarn Avenue.

title: Water Troubles Maple Shade
description: MAPLE SHADEWater, and water alone, was the principal topic at a recent Township Committee meeting that drew about 70 angry residents. And it was not the wet June that was the subject of discussion.

title: Suffolk Loses Suit on Police MinorityHiring Plan
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ruled that it would be discriminatory for Suffolk County police officials to hire three Puerto Ricans who scored lower than others on a Civil Service examination.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The best day the stock market had last week was Thursdaythe Fourth of July holiday, when it was closed.

title: Rita Sue Weitzen Sets August Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Weitzen of Cedarhurst, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rita Sue Weitzen, to Mitchell Clark Benson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley. R. Benson of Hewlett, L. I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Street Fete in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITYThe annual Mount Carmel Family Festival, presented by the parishioners of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, will be held from next Friday through July 15 on streets adjoining the church, which is at 99 Broadway. Last year this street festival attracted nearly 25,000 people.

title: Study Is Ordered on Far Rockaway
description: At the request of community groups, the city has authorized a $30,000 study to recommend ways to revitalize the Far Rockaway shopping area in Queens.

title: Le Corbusier and The Tragic View Of Architecture
description: Like most masters of modern architecture, Le Corbusier has generally been written about by his apologistsand, on occasion, by his extreme detractors. Now Charles Jencks, the British architectural scholar who has been nothing if not prolific lately, has produced what his publisher claims is a dispassionate biography, making no concessions to idolators.

title: The Main Problem in Horse Racing Today: No One Is Looking Out for the Poor Bettor
description: Horse racing is an unusual sport Unlike most other popular pastimes, it is not for children. Aside from the fan who simply enjoys fresh air and the beauty of the beast, racing is principally a mature person's vehicle to test, his wits against the crowd. Through the artscience of handicapping, and, the wagering instrument, he is as much a participant as the horse itself. That is the fundamental reason for the sport's success, and perhaps that is its curse as well.

title: John Ragsdale Is Fiance Of Ann Lucinda Schulte
description: Mrs. John Stephen Schulte of New York, Bedford, N.Y., and. Sarasota, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann Lucinda Schulte, to John Milton Ragsdale, son of Mrs. L. V. Ragsdale of Fall River, Mass., and the late Dr. Ragsdale, Miss Schulte is a daughter also of the late Mr. Schulte, who was a vice president and a director of Park & Tilford, Inc.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Elizabeth Woodward to Wed Aug. 3
description: Miss Elizabeth Noell Woodward, a certified public accountant with Arthur Young & Co., and Robert Knud Christensen, an assistant treasurer in the European investment and management group of the Bankers Trust Company's international banking department, plan to be married. The ceremony will take place Aug. 3 in Richmond, where Mr. and Mrs. John E. Woodward Jr., parents of the bridetobe, have announced the engagement.

title: How to Get the Most Out of Boat in Tricky Light Air
description: A nice, steady breeze of to 12 knots, when the water is pleasantly ruffled but does not have whitecaps, makes for the easiest sailing conditions. The boat has a feel and does what you want her to do when you make a controlling motion, but she is not in danger of being overpowered, of capsizing, or suffering equipment damage. Would that all sailing days were like this.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: David Dempsey's article on The Living Will and euthanasia (The Living Willand the will to live, June 23) deals evenhandedly with the idea of a person having the right to decide to give to other persons the right to allow him or her to die rather than to prolong medical treatment expected to prove useless. I suggest that an even more fundamental right, and one less open to criticism, is the right to commit suicide. I understand this right is affirmed in the revised humanist statement of principles.

title: Bridge
description: An unhappy orphan, largely neglected by teachers and textbooks alike, is the game contract in a minorsuit. The beginner planning to play in a game contract is advised to select a major suit or notrump. When should I play in five clubs or five diamonds? he asks, and gets the answer never. One should never use the word never in bridge generalizations, which is itself a statement for logicians to ponder over.

title: Key Vote in Japan Today Ends a Militant Campaign
description: TOKYO, Sunday, July 7After one of the most aggressively fought campaigns in Japan's postwar history, the nation votes today to elect half of the upper house of Parliament.

title: This Week in Sports
description: Richard Hunter and Lura Wilson will defend their titles in the threeday New York State championships, which begin Friday at 6:30 P.M. at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L. I. Star status has been awarded to Saturday's international round, which begins at 12:30 P.M. Any records made or broken in that round will be recognized by the International Archery Federation.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The DeVry Technical Institute has leased 60,000 square feet of space in the 95,000squarefoot Campus Office Park in Woodbridge, N. J.

title: ZAIRE TAKEOVER: PLUSSES, MINUSES
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, July 3President Mobutu Sese Seko announced list November that all foreignowned agricultural and commercial activities would have to be sold to citizens within three months' time.

title: New Try in Ulster
description: The deteriorating situation in Northern Ireland clearly demanded a fresh initiative from the British Government. While it is difficult to muster much optimism about Britain's new proposals for Ulster, they offer at least as much hope for advancing a solution to the problem as any of the alternatives suggested so far from any other quarter.

title: LunchHour Gardens Relieve Office Tensions
description: EMPLOYE gardens are sprouting all over the country as a growing number of corporations make land available for staff use. Many lunch hour gardeners wield the hoe to counteract staggering increases in the cost of food. Others see it as a new challenge, a form of exercise, or a chance to relax away from office tensions.

title: Mobile Version Of Jazz In Suffolk
description: With the introduction today of its jazzonwheels mobile festival, International Art of Jazz, based at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, will initiate several summertime firsts in honor of its 10th anniversary.

title: 2 Homers Yield 5 Runs As Yanks Win Again, 93
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 6  The Yankees continued to show signs tonight that the batting slump that had plagued them during the early phases of their current 13game trip is over.

title: Nightclub Safety Studied On Island
description: MINEOLA  The Town of Hempstead and the City of Long Beach announced plans last week to reinspect rock clubs and other nightspots in their areas in the wake of the fire in a Westchester County nightspot in which 24 young people lost their lives.

title: Shipping/Mails
Home Repair Clinic
description: Questions from readers about home repair problems should be addressed to: Home Improvement Department, The New York Times, Times. Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered in this column:

title: Nancy Scott Hovey Betrothed to Charles T. Cooper
description: Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Hovey Jr. of Locust Valley, L. L, have announced the engagement of Mr. Hovey's daughter, Miss Nancy Scott Hovey, to Charles Terrell Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Cooper 3d of Waltham and Rockport, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: A Musical Season
description: Andrew Porter is a man of many words. These he phrases elegantly and floods with a scholar's love of detail. When Winthrop Sargent retired from frontline dutyhe still covers recordingsThe New Yorker lured Porter over from England to be their music critic for the 197273 season, and were pleased enough to invite him back this coming year, It was, taste aside, a change from musician who wrote journalism to musicologist who wrote essays.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: HOLLYWOOD  Motown Industries, the nation's largest black enterprise, increasingly presents an image of black and white management whose favorite color is green.

title: Margaret M. Kinnaird Fiancee Of Howard McDonald Tuttle Jr.
description: Mrs. Eleanor Foster Kinnaird of St. Petersburg Beach, Fla. and Robert Frederick Kinnaird of Englewood, N. J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Martin Kinnaird, to Howard McDonald Tuttle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Tuttle of Cleveland Heights, Ohio.

title: Guam Winner Declared
description: AGANA, Guam, July 6 (UPI) The Guam Election Commission today declared Gov. Carlos G. Camacho the tentative winner of the June 29 Republican gubernatorial primary by 242 votes over Senator Paul Calvo.

title: Fashion
description: Fashion street, (also known as Bleecker, also known as offBleecher") is unusually full of unusual shops, where clothes may be ordered in the customer's choice of size and fabric. One example shown belowa soft, Dacron crepe dress in maroon and gray, worn here by Pat Walker, the designer and owner of the shop. Dress, $90; big straw hat, $27. The shop: We Two & Friends, 215 W. 10th St. We Two & Friends is open Monday through Saturday from 12:30 to 8 P.M.

title: Clare P. Robb Wed to Bruce Wright
description: Miss Clare. Patricia Robb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Robh of Plandome, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Bruce Jeffrey Wright, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Franklin Wright of East Quogue, L. I. The Rev. Robert L. Brown performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church, Manhasset, L. I.

title: Art: A TwoPronged Show
description: MORRISTOWNAs summer fare, the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences is presenting one show for naturelovers and another for fanciers of the ancient oriental craft of rubbing.

title: Photography
description: IDON'T say a history of the picture postcard is not needed. On the contrary, a really good history of the picture postcard would be a great deal more welcome just now than yet another history of Impressionist painting. I only say that the summer exhibition at the Emily Lowe Gallery of Hofstra University in Hempstead, L. I., Wish You Were Here: A History of the Picture Postcard, is not, despite its subtitle, such a history.they will be soon, for they sum up and express, better than any form of abstract painting, the postwar Age of Affluence in which they were made, an era to which rising prices and the threat of shortages has already given a nostalgic period charm.

title: Yankee Records
description: BATTING

title: The Ballet: Exceptional Swan Lake
description: David Blair's staging of Swan Lake for the American Ballet Theater returned for the first two times this season at the New York State Theater Friday night and yesterday afternoon. On Friday the OdetteOdile was Cynthia Gregory, partnered by Bruce Marks, and at the matinee it was Martine van Hamel, partnered by Jonas Kage.

title: Bask, don't burn
description: Tan is beautiful, red is painful and too much ultraviolet is dumb and dangerous

title: News of the Stage
description: Cinemascope Products, Inc., a subsidiary of 20th CenturyFox, is financing the forthcoming Broadway musical The Wiz, a black version of L. Frank Baum's The Wonderful Wizard of Oz. Kenneth Harper is producing.

title: Is Redford just another pretty face?
description: On Fifth Avenue a girl approaches him as though he were an altar.

title: Can a Symbol of Graft Be an Architectural Landmark?
description: THE first impression one gets of the Beanie administration on a visit to City Hall is of cordial chaos in a scene straight out of a Marx Brothers movie. Something like the stateroom sequence in A Night at the Opera, with everyone coming and going in every direction at once, appearing and disappearing out of portholes and steamer trunks. Only here they, come from under stairs and out of the basement and through false doors in a steady stream to the Deputy Mayors's offices, and one expects to see Groucho chasing Margaret Dumont around the rotunda any moment.

title: Dutch and West Germans to Settle World Cup Soccer Supremacy Today
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 6The Netherlands and West Germany, two offenseminded teams with different styles on and off the field, meet in the championship game of the World Cup soccer tournament at Olympic Stadium tomorrow.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A rather weird and unclassifiable book is Christopher Leach's THE SENDOFF (Scribner's, $4.95). Its basic ingredients put it into the mystery category; its treatment and interpretation give it literary quality. Anyway, here is this very normal, middleclass British couple who, with daughter and soninlaw, are just about to go on vacation. The day before they are to leave for Spain, the lady of the house discovers a corpse in the kitchen. So they get rid of the body.

title: ideas &Trends
description: The American Psychological Association has begun a fiveyear curriculumdevelopment project that is designed to drastically alter instruction shout human behavior in high schools.

title: Lots of Tinkering And Little Energizing
description: WHEREFORE art thou Romeo, Juliet, Tybalt, Mercutio, Friar Laurence, Lady Capulet? Or to jump to the Twelfth Night that is now in repertory with Romeo and Juliet at the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., what sort of identity crisis has overtaken Sir Toby Belch, Viola, Feste, and the stiff, overweening Malvolio?

title: The Homestretch
description: As the Watergate scandals have engulfed the Presidency, it is inevitable that they have somewhat impeded the work of Congress. Most of the time, Mr. Nixon has been too preoccupied with Watergate and with his foreign journeys to pay much personal attention to the flow of legislation. The normal dialogue on legislation between Capitol Hill and the White House has been for the most part disrupteda notable exception being the Administration's successful fight last week for funds for the International Development Association (I.D.A).

title: Superior, Private Dump?
description: Federal District Court Judge Miles W. Lord continues to set an example of social conscience in the case of the Reserve Mining Companywhile the company, in contrast, continues to put profits above the public health and the environment of three states.

title: He Moves With Elan From Candy to the Cello
description: SOUTH RIVERFive days a week, Edward Birnn spends his working hours as the owner and chief executive of four candy stores and of a company that produces sweets for these outlets and some 200 other wholesale and retail customers from coast to coast.

title: Scholarships for Women Have Come a Long Way
description: Don't discourage your tomboy daughter, mother. Consider giving her a lacrosse stick or hockey skates for her next birthday instead of cosmetics or a doll. In time, she may reward you with an athle tic Scholarship to the college of her choice just as athletically gifted sons have been doing for decades.

title: Unanimous Coart Raling A gainst Nixon Predided
description: LOS ANGELES, July 7 (Reuters)A political scientist at Michigan State University who uses a computer to predict Supreme Court decisions said today he expected the Court to rule unanimously against President Nixon on the White House tapes issue.

title: Police Doubt a Shot at Ford Motorcade
description: DALLAS, July 6The shat tering of a window in a police car that was escorting Vice President Ford today set off reports that it had been fired upon by a sniper, but the reports were later discounted by officials.

title: Miss Francis Has Nuptials
description: Miss Dorothy Bleecker Francis, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Elmer deWitt Fatiquier Francis of Summit and Normandy Beach, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Craig Arthur Atwater, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur B, Atwater of Clarence, N. Y.

title: CRIME RATE IN RIO IS RISING SHARPLY
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 Brazilians are beginning to call this handsome port city the Chicago of Latin America.

title: Broader Horizons for Executives
description: Just as parents send their children to summer camp to expand their horizons in agreeable surroundings, so corporations send their executives to similar places.

title: New Doctrine for NATO
description: PARISThe purpose of the new strategic doctrine developed by U.S. Defense Secretary Schlesinger during the past year is to tie the United States more closely to its NATO partners in Western Europe's defense. This was acknowledged in the twentyfifth birthday communiqu issued at Brussels June 26 when the alliance pledged itself to resist any attack with all forces at its disposal. The word ail refers to nuclear weapons.

title: A NEW G.O.P. VIEW OF IMPEACHMENT
description: WASHINGTON, July 6  A new theory of how best to deal with the political conundrum presented by impeachment has begun to take hold among the Republican leadership in the House of Representatives.

title: Said the Penthouse Buyer: Son, Fix It
description: When Luben Vichey, an impresario and for many years a leading basso at the Metropolitan Opera, first saw the cooperative penthouse apartment at 570 Park Avenue, it was an absolute mishmash of cubicles and closets in terrible condition, a very gloomy place.

title: Italy Enacts Stiff Taxes; Gasoline and Beef Go Up
description: ROME, July 6The Gov: ernment presented the nation tonight with a package of austerity decrees that will cost every Italian an average of $100 in new taxes during the next 12 months, and is certain to result in a sharp increase in the cost of living.

title: Few & Novel
description: The keys to this novel of possession belong to an ancient typewriter whose deceased owner taps out thrillers through a surrogate. Before Henry Potts borrows the old machine from his London landlady, he is an unpublished author of mysteries. But the minute his fingers touch the keys, the writer finds that the typewriter begins to rattle off the campiest derringdo imaginable, evidently inspired by the late proprietor, who had tried his hand at thrillers in the 1930's. Potts identifies very closely with the title role in his story, introduced as the international sportsman, famous polo player, ski champion, boxer, daredevil flier, racing driver, holder of the Legion d'Honneur, the famous playboy bullfighter, gamblerthe most eligible bachelor in the world, etc., etc. And he transmogrifies his boarding housemates into characters in his fantasy.

title: Ingrid Nelson Engaged to John Broad
description: Mr. and Mrs. George J. Nelson of New York and Briarcliff Manor, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ingrid Maria Nelson, to John Broad, son of Lieut. Gen. Sir Charles Broad and Lady Broad of Beaminster, Dorset, England.

title: Calendar of Nearby Motor Sports Events
description: July 10Westchester Sports Car Club meeting at Colonial Tavern, Hawthorne, N. Y., 8:30 P.M. Information: Ed Luiso, phone (914)6646788.

title: Miss Zinner Wed to Dale Lindsay
description: In the Stowe (Vt.) Community Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Barbi Milner, daughter of Dr. Kurt Zinner and Mrs. Nora Zinner, both of Wellsville, N. Y., was married to Dale Alton Lindsay Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lindsay of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Philip H. Chase performed the ceremony.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: AT the midpoint of every year, the spirits of businessmen are normally uplifted in anticipation of a fasterpaced second half and the American public's sentiments are usually buoyed by the advent of holiday and vacation pleasures.

title: The death of ethical and political argument was only temporary
description: While watching Tom Stoppard's play Jumpersrecently performed on BroadwayI wondered what the audience, consisting predominantly of people outside professional philosophy, were making of it. They were surely missing a few philosophical in jokes, but that did not matter. might be more perplexing, I thought, to be unable to judge how close to reality Stoppard's portrayal of philosophers in a modern university had come. The play's central character, George Moore, is professor of moral philosophy who spends most of the play trying to write a lecture he must deliver on the topic: Mangood, bad or indifferent? the lecture, which we hear him dictate to his patient secretary, as wild a parody of academic philosophy as the vice chancellor's team of gymnasts from which the play takes its name?

title: Grumman Sees Clear Skies
description: The Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest private employer and taxpayer, says it has recovered its financial health  and its top officials are trying to persuade its bankers that the recovery is permanent.

title: Radio
description: Today: Leading Events

title: Letters to the Editor
description: We have been treated in recent weeks to several articles about the failure of a builder to complete homes he had sold [Buyers Hurt as Builder in Rockland County Falters, May 26; Point of View: State Must Act to Protect New  Home Buyers, June 16]

title: Two Are Shot, by Robbers In $20,000 Bronx Holdup
description: Two employes of a South Bronx beer distributor were shot late Friday night by one Ott three robbers armed with sawedoff shotgun who fled after forcing the owner to hand over holiday receipts totaling $20,000 in cash and $40,000 in checks.

title: Abby Plitt Plancee Of Paul A. Gellert
description: Miss Abby Leslie Plitt, a graduate of Syracuse University, and Paul Anthony Gellert, an independent consultant and vice president for the New York Society for Ethical Culture, plan to be married Sept 8 at the High.; land Mills, N. Y., summer home of the parents of the bridetobe, who have announced the engagement.

title: Acrostic puzzle
description: Acrostic puzzle

title: Soviet Crew Defeats U.S. At Henley
description: HENLEYONTHAMES, England, July 6  The cream of crew racing was served up with the strawberries today to crowds that lined the Henley Royal Regatta course.

title: Hollywood's New Sensationalism: The Power and the Gory
description: THE books on the history of film describe the stunning effect on audiences of the earliest tworeelers: At the sight of a moving train on screen, some people actually fled the theaters, screaming in horror. Others were struck with awe and delight. Movies were a form of circus spectacle before they began to tell storiesand long before they were considered an art. Since then, narrative and cinematic techniques have been refined, and the new medium has finally achieved intellectual respectability.

title: Freedom of the Press Requires Responsibility in the Press
description: Last week the U.S. Supreme Court struck down a Florida statute which required newspapers to provide equal space to political candidates to reply to editorial criticism, The court was unanimous in its decision.

title: Elmont Day Center Is Finally Closed
description: MINEOLA  The Elmont Day Care Center, which Mssau County officials had planned to close June 21, has been incorporated into the Lakeview Day Care Center one week later than initially planned.

title: People and Business
description: It's only the Fourth of July weekend, but Robert D. Hecklau, president of Shulton, U.S.A., is already concentrating on Christmas, The reason is that a large share of the $50million in annual sales chalked up by the Cliftonbased manufacturer of toiletries falls into the category of gift merchandise.

title: Epilogue
description: The announcement by the King of Sikkim that he would sign a new Constitution virtually ends the centuriesold divine monarchy of Tibetan origin. King Palden Thondup Namgyal, the hereditary ruler of the tiny Himalayan kingdom, in conceding to demands for more democratic rule, had been warned by the state's popularly elected assembly that if he did not give his approval there would be no more role for him to play in Sikkim. The new constitutional reforms will reduce the status of the King, or Chogyal, from absolute ruler to figurehead. The King is married to Hope Cooke, a former American debutante, who left Sikkim last year and moved back to New York.

title: ' Dear Mr. Verdi: Your Script Is Operative'
description: ' Dear Mr. Verdi: Your Script Is Operative'

title: Miss Lindemann Becomes Bride Of V. H. Muscat
description: St. Bede's Chapel in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Catherine Darmour Lindemann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Lindemann Jr. of Greenwich and Chebeague Island, Me., to Victor Hiller Muscat, son of Mr, and Mrs. Victor Muscat of Greenwich and La Jolla, Calif.

title: Letters: On Muggings In South America
description: To the Editor: I read with much interest the article, Encounter: A Healthy Democratic Mugging in Colombia by Marvine Howe (Travel Section, June 23). I found it particularly timely, because I have recently been apprehensive about the same kind of incident.

title: Pamela Knowles Wed To Richard Fleizach
description: In the Eastchester (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church yesterday afternoon, Miss Pamela Ann Knowles, daughter of Mrs. Phyllis B. Knowles of Tuckahoe, N. Y., and Harry Vincent Knowles of Eastchester, was married to Richard Andre Fleizach, son of Mrs. Frank F. Fleizach of White Plains and the late Mr. Fleizach. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Earl E. Eisenbach.

title: Sneed Wins By 4 Shots On 72276
description: MILWAUKEE, July 6 Ed Sneed, the leader all the way, shattered the hopes of any wouldbe challengers with an eagle 3 on the sixth hole and breezed to a fourstroke victory in the Milwaukee open golf tournament today.

title: Women Meet and Grow Together
description: RIVERHEAD  It is not that Doreen Kirby does not enjoy the role of housewife and mother. A supermarket bookkeeper until her daughter, Dawn, was born three and onehalf years ago, Mrs. Kirby, 28, likes staying home to care for her toddler.

title: Frontier Violence
description: Legendary Western heroes exemplify American innocence. John Wesley Harding, who travelled with a gun in every hand, brought Bob Dylan back from his season in hell to traditional American idioms. The Texas outlaw John Wesley Hardin killed his first man at age 11. By the time he was 18, reports Professor Holton, in his chronicle of Western violence, Hardin had killed 26 more. An admirer who watched him shoot down five armed opponents in less than a minute said later that with either hand or both hands at the same time, that boy can handle a pistol faster than a frog can lick flies.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The leading proponent of capital punishment in New Jersey is no longer in the Legislature, but the memory of his cause lingers on.

title: Prospect Park Boathouse Is Reopened
description: The fleet is back in home port at the newly refurbished 69yearold boathouse in Prospect Park.

title: Connors Crushes Rosewall, 61, 61, 64; U. S. Sweeps Wimbledon Singles Crowns
description: WIMBLEDON, England July 6With the world waiting in the wings, Jimmy Connors beat Ken Rosewall for the Wimbledon men's tennis title today. Rosewall, the sentimental favorite, had staged one of the great turnarounds by coming from two sets and match point down against Stan Smith to reach his fourth final here over 20 years. But today he was given no chance, demolished by weight of stroke and serve as Connors won, 61, 61, 64, over 93 minutes.

title: More Parking and Trains for Metropark
description: ISELIN  More trains, more parking and major improvements in connections to and from the Garden State Parkway are on tap for the bustling Metropark station of the Penn Central Railroad.

title: It May Be That Argentine Conflict Runs Too Deep for Consensus
description: BUENOS AIRESI returned to the country to unite, not to foment disunion among Argentines, the late President Juan Domingo Per6n said in his last public speech two weeks ago.

title: Election for Parliament Tomorrow Is Second in Two Years,
description: OTTAWA, July 6Canadian election forecasters see a strong possibility that another minority government will emerge from the national election for Parliament Monday, whether the vote favors Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of the, Liberal party or his principal rival, Robert L. Stabfield, leader of Progressive Conservative party.

title: Katherine Maggio Wed
description: Miss Katherine Grace Maggio, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Salvatore Maggio of Brooklyn and Hampton Bays, L. I., was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Allen Bowler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robett P. Bowler of East Meadow, L. I. The Rev. Justin Kerber performed the ceremony in Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Churdh in Brooklyn.

title: MRS. MARY HORTON NUTRITIONIST, 77, DIES
description: Mrs. Mary Burnett Horton, a specialist in nutrition and home economics, died Monday of a heart attack at New York Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived at 400 East 58th Street.

title: Tenor Accused of Plotting Murder of Fellow Singer
description: CHICAGO, July 6 (UPI) A tenor with the Lyric Opera of Chicago was arrested and charged early today with biting another man to kill a fellow singer because of professional jealousy, the authorities said.

title: Miss Leslie Daum Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren Daum of Lawrence, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Daum, to Gary Rheinwald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Rheinwald of Brockport, N. Y.

title: Indians Beat Angels, 10; Go Into First
description: ANAHEIM, July 6 (AP)Dick Bosnian, making only his third start of the season, got late help from Tom Buskey tonight and pitched the Cleveland Indians into first place in the American League East with a 1.0 victory over the California Angels.

title: RAIDS TO CONTINUE AT TOPLESS CLUBS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., July 5The Nassau County District Attorney said today that he would continue his crackdown on topless and bottomless dancers under provisions of a state law, despite decisions by Federal courts that town prohibitions against these types of dancing are unconstitutional.

title: Detroit Strike Settled
description: DETROIT, July 6 (UPI)Negotiators reached a contract agreement today covering near ly a third of the city's 24,000 employes and brought an end to a potentially crippling strike that lasted only four hours. The tentative settlement between the city and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes came before the strike had a chance to curtail such public services as the bus system and garbage collections.

title: What words on music are useful for
description: Henry Pleasants first started stirring up the world of music with a book called The Agony of Modern Music. He had been known before then, as daily music critic in Philadelphia and as a writer in national magazines. But it was in 1955 that he made his mark with the first publication of the thesis he has developed and expanded ever since.

title: AROUND THE By Joan Lee Faust
description: Tomato plants come in two forms, determinate and indeterminate. These 50 cent words describe whether or not the plants should be staked. Hopefully each home gardener knows the variety name of the tomato plants he is growing! Among the popular determinate tomatoes are: Supersonic, Jet Star, New Yorker, Fireball and Heinz 1350. They do not need staking.

This report showed minor fluctuations from an April 1 report, which had been criticized by Health Department officials, who said the initial report was not representative of the bathing season.

Chauncey Newlin of New York.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Fritz Kessel, physician for the undefeated Netherlands soccer team that plays West Germany today for the World. Cup title believes it's important that nothing upset an athlete's style of life. The official doctor for the Dutch Football Association for seven years, says: Upsets can he caused by the climate, it can he the foodbut it can also be matters, relating to an athlete's personal habits, his sex life, for instance. Our players are used to having sex between two times a day and once a week depending on individual temperament. A strenuous tournament like the World Cup might reduce their urge but it does not, wipe it out. Thus we have wives and girl, friends visit herethe last time for the full period between the two games, three days, and the next time for a similar length. Short visits would be like a command performance. Longer spells have the soothing effect, which we desire.

title: Mets Defeated by Giants, 52

Then they returned to their battle stations and to some new hardships while Westrum's San Francisco Giants were dusting off Berra's Mets, 52.

title: New Providence Strives to Maintain Intimacy
description: NEW PROVIDENCEResidents of this pleasant Union County borough readily admit that New Providence is not the most exciting place in the state, but many are afraid that change would rock the boat and create problems they would regret. When moved here from Newark 17 years ago, the whole area was rural, said Mrs. Martin H. Marshall. 'It took a lot of adjusting. Now that we're a fullgrown community, one that I love, I'd hate to see change. Change brings problems.

title: Psychiatrist and 2 Patients Robbed in 5th Avenue Office
description: A psychiatrist and two patients were robbed yesterday in his office at Fifth Avenue near 71st Street by two men, one carrying a small ax and the other with a hunting knife, who tied up their victims and then fled in the physician's car.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: SEVERAL BIG BANKS raised their prime rate to a record 12 per cent, up from 11.8 per cent.  The Census Bureau says the typical American family had an income of $12,051 last year, up 8.4 per cent from 1972.

title: What's Doing in MAINE
description: VACATIONLANDMaine is the largest of the six New England statesalmost as large as the five others put together. The state's prime assets, at least from the viewpoint of the millions of vacationers who converge upon Maine annually, are its lobsters, its 17 million acres of forest land, its 2,500 clear lakes and its scores of beaches. The Maine coastline, when measured as the gull flies from Kittery in the south to West Quoddy Head in the north, is 230 miles long, but if one follows the wild shoreline of bays, peninsulas, inlets and headlands, the distance is 3,500 miles. Maine has fewer than a million yearround residents, but last year its mountains, lakes and seaside resorts attracted more than 4 million visitors who spent more than $400million. The state produces 75 per cent of the nation's lobsters, a bumper crop that totaled 17 million pounds last year, and the haul this year is expected to be even greater.

title: INVESTING ABROAD.
description: LONDON  American investors suffering from malaise over the state of their portfolios might well look toward London to see what real devastation in the stock market is all about. They might even begin to feel that things aren't so bad.

title: Detroit's MiniStations Take the Police to the People
description: DETROTI, July 6  for a long time, the 7,500 people who lived in the BrewsterDouglass housing project on the northeast fringe of downtown Detroit were the special prey of one species of urban jackal. There, among the project's tall brick towers and neat onestory row houses, almost within the shadows of the central city's spires, the jackals attacked with impunity. They were young men who waited for old people to walk to nearby stores to cash their Social Security check, robbed them of their cash on the way back, and then vanished before the police could respond.

title: Edgar Degas, the Reluctant Modernist, at a New Exhibition in Boston
description: IN no other painter of the 19th centurynot even in Menet or Cezanne is the notion of tradition at once so boldly affirmed and yet so drastically revised as it is in the work of Edgar Degas. He belongs, without question, to the great line of avantgarde masters who made of French painting in the 19th century the principal fulcrum of modernism, He thus prepared the way for all those rejections and suspensions of convention that, in the 20th century, reduced the very concept of tradition to a term of opprobrium. Yet Valery was not exaggerating when he spoke of Degas as an artist nourished on Racine and the old music. No other artist of his time, either in the Academy or the avantgarde, was more conscious of the glories of the past, or more reverent of its standards and distinctions. Everything about the modern worldits politics, its morals and its irestelseems to have offended him deeply, yet he never allowed his piety for the past to modify or falsify his vision. There was something unmistakeably heroic in his fidelity to the truth of his own emotions, and it was upon this truth that the great achievements of his art were based.

title: Headliners
description: His Excellency President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire will from now on be addressed simply as Citizen Mobutu. The change is intended to help unify the more than 200 ethnic groups in the former Belgian colony. Other changes include the creation of committees to revise the country's constitution and instruct party members on ideology, and a bit of revision in the Zaire calendar: Christmas will now be celebrated on June 24, the day the country's constitution was proclaimed.

title: Dave Anderson
description: The tennis mods keep trying to eliminate the word love from the game's vocabulary. Some umpires shout the words nothing or zero to make the score sound more competitive than social. But the mods will have to wait now. By winning the Wimbledon men's and women's singles championships four months before they are to be married, Jimmy Connors and Chris Evert have restored the word love to tennis in all its cliche splendor. Love match. Love story. Love conquers all. Surely they will emerge from St. Anthony's Church in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., in November under a canopy of crossed tennis racquets. America demands it. Even the antilove mods expect it. After all, this romance was made in heaven, meaning two years ago over a Coke at Wjmbledon, which is more important than heaven to most tennis players. The wedding had been discussed for last May but Jimmy's mother shook her head. Nobody wins Wimbledon on their honeymoon, she declared. And now, as the singles champions, Americe's sweethearts opened the Wimbledon Ball last night with the first dance. It's a storybook script for a movie in the 1940's with Van Johnson and June Allyson, except that nobody would have believed it then either.

title: Food: Only 24 pounds of seaweed By Craig Claiborne with Pierre Franey
description: Blessed are those who live by the sea for theirs is the kingdom of shellfish and seaweed, the principal ingredients of an oldfashioned clambake. Clambakes out here in East Hampton come in two sizes: the large traditional backbreaking affair with pits to dig and rocks to fire and sand to sweep, and the more recently evolved washboiler clambake for smaller gatherings, The latter, of course, may lack the color of the original, but we can state emphatically that the results are more or less equal. And there is one vast and important difference. The marvelous, oldfashioned clambake demands 600 pounds of seaweed. With the washboiler type you can settle for a child's portion24 pounds. Bonackersthe natives who were born on the Eastern tip of Long Island (and specifically in the vicinity of Acabonack)have their own method testing the doneness of a washboiler clambake. They put a raw potato in the center of the top layer of seaweed. When the potato is tender without being mushy, it is time to feast. The clambake described here is one recently staged by Ed Gorman, a Boston born parttime Bonacker.

title: Banks and Builders Shun Mortgage Aid

title: Battle on Dystrophy
description: More than one million Americans suffer from muscledestroying dystrophic diseases and related neuromuscular disorders. There is no effective treatment yet, but the Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America is waging a battle against the diseases.

title: Inflation as the ripoff of the middle classes
description: While Watergate and related scandals continue to dominate the front pages, today's inflation the preoccupying issue for most Americans. The two subjects are not unrelated, of course. While Watergate is sapping public confidence in political institutions, inflationrapid and persistentis altering economic foundations long taken for granted. Americans are disoriented, bewildered and increasingly resentful of this twopronged assault on their security.

title: W.F.L. (That's Football) Opens 20Carne Season at Five Sites Wednesday Night
description: Unlike the established N.F.L., which is threatened with the cancellation of its preseason schedule, the W.F.L. has eschewed exhibition games in favor of a 20game regularseason schedule. In other words, the lellgue hasn't given prospective fans a chance to see how bad its teams really might be before they begin playing for keeps.

title: Miss Knowlton Officer's Bride At West Point
description: Miss Hollister Knowlton, daughter of Lieut, Gen, William A. Knowlton, superintendent of the United States Military Academy at West Point, N. Y., and Mrs. Knowlton, was married there yesterday afternoon to Lieut. David Howell Petraeus, U.S.A., who graduated last month from the academy as a Distinguished Cadet. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sixtus Petraeus of CornwallonHudson, N. Y.

title: Calendar of Horse Shows
description: Today Northern Westchester Professional Horsemen's Association, Primose Farms, Somers, N. Y. Regular, green and junior working hunters; ponies, pleasure, short stirrup, equitation. 9 A.M.

title: PANAMA CANAL HAD RECORD LOSS IN YEAR
description: PANAMA, July 6 (UPI)The company that operates the Panama Canal closed its books for the fiscal year 1974 on June 30 with a record deficit, estimated at $12million, according to a Panama Canal spokesman.

title: Arabs Gain U.S. Respect, Writer Finds
description: CAIRO, July 6An envoy of the Arab League who has been exploring American attitudes toward the Arab world returned from New York to Cairo this week with word that the natives over there are friendlyup to a point.

title: A Cruise a la Russe Two Cheers for the Maxin Gorki!
description: YES, Maxim, it Is, but the great white cruise ship bearing your name is cutting through a sea the color of lead, beneath a sky the color of pewter, and It is raining on Communist crew and capitalist passengers alike. At least on those passengers who are not indoors, perhaps watching the movie Papillon in the Maxim Theater, or drinking prime Russian vodka at loW prices in the Volga Bar or the Lido Bar, or taking afternoon tea, or sitting in the Rossia Lounge with its deep chairs and large windows looking out on the depressing ocean. The outdoor swimming pool on the illnamed Sun Deck lies deserted in the gray drizzle, but eight decks down, in the lower depths of the Maxim Gorki, in the sauna adjoining the Indoor pool, a few bloated bourgeois imperialists sizzle and roast, basting themselves with warm water from a wooden dipper into a wooden bucket.

title: The OTB Game: Now You See It, Now You Don't
description: Picture a group of con men setting up a game of chance in which the house takes out a fourth to a third of the pot on every turn of the wheel.

title: 6th Vietnam Devaluation
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 6 (Reuters)South Vietnam devalued the piaster to 630 to the U. S. dollar from 620 Friday, a Government spokesman announced. It was the sixth devaluation this year.

title: On Safari in Kenya, A Curious Regression
description: When we left Nairobi in the VW microbus with popup top, laden with cameras and tropical gear, we were khakicovered strangers, apprehensive about one another and the upcoming adventure, Assigned five, plus driver, to a busso each traveler would have a window fore air, elbows and picturetaking we sized each other up. All the other women were career types: a judge, a reporter, a physical therapist, an economic consultant; and I, failed wife. We each felt oddly displaced on that hot eally morning last Mardi as Andrew, our expert Kikuyu driver, wound his way through the already teeming Nairobi traffic on the road out to the Kenyan bush where the gazelles and elephants were.

title: Y.R.A. Regatta Canceled
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 6Lack of wind on Long Island Sound today forced cancellation of the season's 17th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta scheduled by Hugenot Yacht Club.

title: Connors Wins for U.S. Wimbledon Sweep
description: Jimmy Connors completed a United States sweep of the singles tennis titles at Wimbledon with an easy victory yesterday over Ken Rosewall of Australia.

title: Lillian Reis Wins Drug Plea
description: MIAMI, July 6 (AP)A charge of possession of marijuana has been dismissed against Lillian Reis, 42 years old, the former showgirl, because her apartment was searched without a warrant. United States District Judge William O. Merhtens, however, upheld a conviction and twoyear prison term for using a false name and address to obtain prescription for a narcotic drug.

title: The Nation
description: The Pentagon has provided Its critics with a striking example of how research and development projects funded by Congress on a relatively minor scale acquire a bureaucratic life of their own and grow into huge weapons programs without Congressional awareness of what's going on.

title: Parkway Planning Anniversary Show
description: WOODBRIDGEIn commemoration of the Garden State Parkway's 20th anniversary, the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the 173milelong superhighway, is planning to present a show, Tomorrow's Transportation.

title: Team Lacks 3 Fencing Champions
description: Money and points, not performance at the national fencing championships two weeks ago, spelled the difference in the selection of this year's United States fencing team that leaves late this week for the 1974 world championships in Grenoble, France.

title: Tilda Schwartz Will Be Bride
description: The engagement of Miss Tilda Robin Schwartz of Menlo Park, Calif., to Hugh kennedy Tirrell of Atherton, Calif., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Lee Schwartz of La Jolla, Calif., and this city. Mr. Tirrell is the son Of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Alden Tirrell of Buffalo and East Aurora, N.Y.

title: Prejudices In Disguise
description: The earlier, superficial image of Robert Craft the appendage of Stravinsky  a muscular acolyte, half cheerleader, half eminence grise, who placed us all in his debt as the onlie begetter of those fascinating Dialogues, but cancelled part of it by so often stepping forward to conduct in place of the man we had come to hearhas long been replaced by that of a powerful personality in its own right. This stimulating collection of pieces published over the last few years confirms the impression of mind of uncommon clarity and intelligence.

description: There are hundreds of books on extinct animals for children, so any new one is published at some peril.

description: The juke box blasted out rhapsody of rock as Geraldo Ramos Valdes entered the Mardi Gras, a midtown bar featuring topless dancers, where he is employed m a bouncer.

description: It would take, T. David Bullard said, an act of God to get him off the ballot. After meeting with Governor Wilson, T. David Bullard said, Our reward is in Paradise, not in Albany, and he dropped out.

title: Inflation Is Ravaging the Bond Market
description: The bond market, keystone of the nation's system of financing public and private needs, is being dangerously eroded by inflation. Owners of fixedincome securities are watching their holdings crumble in value these days, making them increasingly reluctant to consider new commitments.

title: SUMMER IS FOR KIDS. HELP THE FRESH AIR FUND.

The victims were identified as Jeffrey Curtis, 19 years old, of Maysville, Ky., John E. Walter, 17, of Shelbyville, Ky., and Jordan W. Howard, 31, of Frankfort, Ky.

title: Lake Placid Man Wins Ski Jumping
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 6 (AP)Joe Lamb, 20 years old, of Lake Placid, cleared distances of 120 and 112 feet today to win the 27th annual summer ski jump competition here. Lamb's runs down the ski jump, covered with crushed ice, earned him 180.9 points.

title: Nark!
description: John R. Bartels Jr., head of the Department of Justice's Drug Enforcement Administration, recently complained that nobody knows what Federal narcotics agent does and that there are a great number of people who regard narcotics agents as corrupt Nazis who don't know how to open the door except with the heel of their right foot?

title: Diane Regan and Peter Doniger, Students at Rochester, to Marry
description: Miss Diane Gordon Regan and Peter Scott Doniger, students at the University of Rochester, will be married in Morristown, N. J., on Aug. 18 at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Donald Thomas Regan. Mr. Doniger is the son of Mrs. William Doniger of Rye, N. Y. and the late Mr. Doniger.ester. Her fiance, an alumnus of the Loomis School in Windsor, Conn., is a student at the Graduate School of Management at the university.

title: A Greek poet's notes
description: The fascination of this sort of poetic journal is in its density and depth of feeling. It is not a record of events (though it covers a specific period) but a series of notes, apparently desultory, about the impact of man, nature and historic time upon a profoundly sensitive and educated writer, the greatest modern Greek poet. It would not be unfair to compare this work in its delicacy, passion and astuteness with that of the Valery we meet with in the Notebooks. Both the Frenchman and the Greek were determined to write poetry of deep but controlled feeling and metaphysical subtlety.

title: Death Fund for Hijacking
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 6 (UPI)The Maryland Board of Public Works has approved $8,200 in death benefits for the family of an airport security guard killed in an attempted hijacking at BaltimoreWashington airport last February. Neil Ramsburg of Simpsonville, Md., was killed after 11 months service, one month short of the minimum necessary for receiving death benefits.

title: New Subway Train Being Tested on E Line
description: A futuristic subway train that has been tested in the pity for the last three weeks will be placed into service between Queens and Manhattan on the E line of the old IND division, for one week beginning tomorrow.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is difficult to see Donald Jackson's Judges, an eloquent, thoughtful book, libeled as a sloppily written tract (June 16) without raising a cry. So forgive me if I ask a moment of your time.

description: FARMINGTON, Conn., July 6Ch. Galaxy's Corry Carina, a Doberman Pinscher, was named best in show today at the Farmington Valley Kennel Club show. The award was the 17th best for the 4yearold bitch.

Paul Boochever of Westwood, Mass., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Howard G. Sawyer of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Sawyer.

title: TYPHOON KILLS 27 IN WESTERN JAPAN
description: TOKYO, Sunday, July 7 (AP)  Twentyseven persons were listed as dead and 23 missing early today after a typhoon struck western Japan with winds of 65 miles an hour, the national police reported.

title: Jews in Soviet Hold 14% Of All Doctoral Degrees
description: Manpower statistics recently published in Moscow show that Jews play an even more significant role among senior Soviet science personnel than had been recognized. While making up 1 per cent of the population, Jews account for 14 per cent of scholars with doctoral degrees.

description: The 60yearold owner of two butcher shops that have (served the Harlem neighborhood around the old Polo Grounds for decades was slain last evening outside one of his stores.

description: The president of the National Football League Players Association told the Associated Press yesterday that the N.F.L.P.A. would do everything legally within its power including soliciting help from other unionsto prevent N.F.L. exhibition games if a strike against the owners is not settled.

title: International Event Is Slated for Juniors at L.I. Show
description: A junior international team jumping competition will be held for the first time in the United States in conjunction with the North Shore show in Stony Brook, L.I., Sept. 2 through 8. Albert E. Hart, president of the American Horse Shows Association, made the announcement yesterday.

title: Edwab Gains Net Final.
description: KEARNY, N. J., July 6 Topseeded Neal Edwab of Roslyn, L. I., won by default from injured Gary Adelman of Roslyn and secondseeded Ed Faulkner of North Plainfield, N. J., defeated Randall King of Staten Island, 16, 62, 75, to gain the final of the New Jersey men's tennis championship at the Arlington Players Club. Adelman defaulted because of a badly sprained index finger.

title: RENOVATIONS DUE FOR CITY SCHOOLS
description: The City Planning Commission, implementing a basic budgetary decision to stress the modernizing of older public schools instead of building new ones in an era of declining birth rates, made public yesterday the details of four prototype alteration and expansion projects that it considers both imaginative and economical.

title: Bayside Recalls Its Past Theatrical Residents
description: W.C. Fields may be hoping into eternity that he would rather be in Philadelphia, but, according to historical records, the famed comedian was one of numerous theater and screen stars who once helped make Bayside, Queens, the Beverly Hills of the East.

title: Old Factories Becoming Apartments
description: First the candy company moved out. Then the lighting manufacturer moved out. So the factory building at 321 East 22d Street stood vacant for months.

title: The Axiom About the Weaker Sex: A Myth Cooked Up in the Kitchen
description: It used to be popular, among those who believed the male to be the superior a the species, to point out that thrpughout history most of the great scientists, statesmen, and philosophers have been men. To which the feminists have replied, You can't compete in the niarketplace if you're kept in the kitcheft And the women's rights movements, demanding an equal share in political, academic and economic affairs, have begun to give the lie to the argument from history.

title: More Young People Are Staying Down on the Farm
description: RIVERHEADA tight job market coupled with a more optimistic fbrecast for the farmer are drawing a number of young people back to Long Island farms, reversing a trend that developed more than 20 years ago.

title: The Idea Is to Protect Nonsmokers
description: At. Brownies, a natural food restaurant on East 16th Street in New York City, recently, one woman objected to another's lighting up a cigarette. A sign in the restaurant says, Thank you for not smoking, and the smoker insisted this was not outright prohibition. The two women (both appeared to be in their sixties) began hitting each other, and before the police arrived in force the nonsmoker got her nose broken.

title: Help for Long Island Consumer Is as Near as the Telephone
description: MINEOLA  Long Island consumers who have complaints can turn to their telephones for help, but many people do not know where to call. The following is a guide to help consumers reach the right agency with a minimum of trouble.

title: Dead Heat Cuts Payoffs at OTB
description: A dead heat involving the oddson favorite, combined with the new 5 per cent surtax on winning offtrack wager, created minuscule payoffs for customers at OTB shops yesterday.

title: A Polish exile's poems
description: Czeslaw Milosz has been exiled from his native Poland for almost 25 years, the last 12 of them in the United States. Although he is considered by many to be the greatest living Polish poet, his writing is scarcely known here, aside from one prose work, The Captive Mind, which appeared at the height of the McCarthy era, when it was received as simply another antiCommunist testimonial. But The Captive Mind is far more than a work of political invective; it is an elegy for destroyed values and, indirectly, an autobiography. In it, Milosz argues that Marxism had not been a belief for Polish intellectuals so much as a form of escape from the anguish of personal identity. Twenty years later, the book remains one of the finest ever written about the lure and the inner cost of totalitarian ideology. It is also a key to Milosz's conviction that poetry must be a moral as well as an esthetic discipline, that poetry must translate the anguish of personal experience into a framework of values which defend against skepticism and sterile anger and thereby defend against the lure of ideology.

title: Key to the Gun Scores Over Monmouth Favorite
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July Don't Be Late Jim and Key to the Gun, chestnut colts, captured the two divisions of the $25,000 added Lamplighter Handicap for 3 year olds today at Monmouth Park.

How a Home Builder Weathers the Storm
description: HAUPPAUGE, L.I.No one has to tell John Anderson that the home construction business is experiencing one of its worst periods in recent years. As a home builder himself, Mr. Anderson knows from experience.

title: Wood, Field and Stream Death of an Atlantic Salmon
description: YORK COUNTY, New BrunswickBright as an angler's dream of a far away pool, the Atlantic salmon wisted out of the dark water and into the morning air when it felt the pressure of my line.

And in the last three, the anchovy, critical to world food supply, disappeared, and then reappeared, off the Peruvian coast.
