title: Votes in Congress
description: 1. Vote on motion to authorIze the Judiciary Committee to disregard a rule allowing all of its members to question witnesses in Its impeachment inquirt, which required a twothirds vote of those present for passage. Motion rejected, 207 yeas to 140 nays, July 1.

title: Burke, New Education Head, Envisions Quality Schooling
description: TRENTON  While New Jersey educators and legislators grapple with the task of defining a constitutionallyguaranteed thorough and efficient education, the man who could make it all happen took over last week as the state's new Commissioner of Education.

title: 53% in a Gallup Poll Consider Watergate Coverage Excessive
description: A majority of Americans believe that newspapers, radio and television are devoting too much space and time to covering the Watergate scandals, according to a Gallup Poll released yesterday.

title: Camera World
description: ATWOWEEK summer workshop in photography will be conducted on Martha's Vineyard from Aug. 1629 by a group of professional photographers. To include a series of seminars on a wide range of subjects from landscapes and seascapes to portraiture and darkroom techniques, the course will include field trips and assignments, and there will be informal critique and discussion sessions at which the work of those participating will be shown. The fee for the workshop will be $100 for one week or $175 for the two weeks. For more information write Carol Lazar, 75 Central Park West, New York, N.Y. 10023, or phone (212) 3626739.

title: If Watergate Offers Any Lesson to Contributors, It's Caution
description: WASHINGTONIn the getting and spending of giant specialinterest political treasuries, life goes on, much as before.

title: New Catamaran Tunes Up for Trials
description: Patient Lady III, one of the most sophisticated sailing machines in the world, is currently zipping through her tuning trials on Long Island Sound near Rowayton, Conn. The new Lady is the latest of an exotic breed of Cclass twinhulled sailwing catamarans that clip along the water's surface as if they were about to take off. She costs about $30,000 plus immeasurable amounts of dedicated volunteer effort. This is a fraction of the $]million figure for a 12Meter America's Cup monohUll, but the cat can maintain sustained speeds of over 20 knots, almost twice as fast the big keel racers can go.

title: Mrs. Nixon Plans Cruises
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) Mrs. Richard Nixon will again sponsor cruises aboard the Presidential yacht Sequoia this summer for groups that have made notable contributions to their communities, the White House has announced. It said that the cruises would take place once a week along the Potomac River.

description: ROCK SPRINGS, Wyo., July 3Shelby Houston is an electrician. He makes $9 an hour working for the world's largest construction company. And he lives in a tent. There's just no housing, said his wife, Sylvia. We'll probably buy a trailer when it turns cold, if we can find one and if we can find a place to put it.

These talks represent a degree of consultation on EastWest relations that goes far beyond this Administration's past practice in dealing with friends abroad.

title: Is A Free Woman The Woman We've Been Waiting For?
description: A ii FREE WOMAN, by the German  director Volker Schlondorff, is not only the first film from any country dealing intelligently and sensitively with a modern woman influenced by the feminist movement, but it is also such a tender and a personal movie that musing in public as to why it doesn't totally work makes me feel something like Benedict Arnold. After all, having been denied for so long a screen portrayal of a real woman, a heroic and sympathetic woman, why complain on finally getting one? And, indeed, Elisabeth, the heroine of A Free Woman, is such a figure.

title: Junc H. Braverznan Physician's Fiancee

title: In St. Louis, At Least, They Plan Together
description: PLANS for celebrating our Bicentennial in 1976 in all their chaotic complexity are going to be with us from now till then. Some of them will be worth mentioning. Take St. Louis, for example. It has managed to get its many diverse cultural institutions to cooperate in a twoandahalfweek program ending on July 4. According to Mrs. Homer E. Sayad, chairman of the project, it is the first time in the cultural history of St. Louisexcept for the 1904 World's Fairthat all our leading cultural agencies have creatively joined forces for a single common purpose.

Sexual offenses rose 9.2 per cent.

title: Funds for Clearing Port Of Debris Nearing Reality
description: A Long delayed public works project vital to the Port of New Yorkeffective removal of harbor debrishas moved closer to reality with the approval by the House of Representatives of the public worksAtomic Energy Commission appropriations measure for the coming fiscal year.

title: Unsolved Kidnapping Sharpens, Political Divisions in Mexico.
description: MEXICO CITY, July 6The kidnapping of a prominent Mexican senator by leftwing guerrillas a month ago is causing serious political problems for the Government and sharpening the conflict between conservatives and reformists throughout the country.

title: Book Ends
description: Book Fair. Check one: small magazines and presses are (a) in trouble or (b) burgeoning. Actually both choices contain semblances of the truth. But if you are interested in inspecting for yourself the little magazine/press scene in all its inchoate fervor, you can do so during the week of July 7 in New York. First, there is the New York Book Fair, which will feature exhibits by around 200 small book and magazine publishers. This will be held July 7, and 9 at the New York Cultural Center. The fair is being sponsored jointly by Friends of Books and Comics/East, an organization of small presses, the Committee of Small Magazine Editors and Publishers (C.O.S.M.E.P.) and the American Library Association Social Responsibilities Roundtable. As at any;book fair, booths wig be set up displaying the publishers products, and there will also be combined exhibits of feminist, third world and general publications. In addition to the visual stimuli, there will be pleasures for the earcontinuous poetry readings from 2 to 10 P.M., July 8 and 9. Parallel with the Book Fair, C.O.S.M.E.P. is holding a conference for littlemagazine people at Columbia University. This runs from July 8 through July 12 and will be held at Ferris Hall. Panels on such breadandbutter matters as funding, production, promotion and reviewing are scheduled. And there will be special panel on thirdworld publishing and one on The Challenge of Small Press Publishing. C.O.S.M.E.P. was founded in 1968 and claims some 500 member publications.

title: Bottle Deposit Law, In Force a Year, Hailed in Vermont

Below the knee and beyond is the working rule for skirt lengths. Capes are the fillip to provide a hit of swashbuckling charm in a wardrobe that is built around practical notions such as sweaters and skirts.

title: Mary Perna Married
description: Miss Maty Patricia Perna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Perna of Bedminster; N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Roderick Marshall McNealy, son of Mrs. Robert A. Conger of Chicago and the late Dr. Raymofid W. McNealy. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed in the Princeton University Chapel by the Rev. Charles B. Weiser.

title: 17YearOld Youth Is Slain in a Usually Quiet Park in Bay Ridge
description: A 17yearold youth scheduled to start work tomorrow for the city's Youth Services Administration was shot in the head and killed late Friday night in quiet Owls Head Park in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn.

title: Bergen Increasing Battle Against VD
description: HACKENSACK The Bergen County Health Department has distributed new posters listing the telephone numbers of the county's venereal disease hot line band its various clinics. The clinics offer confidential and free treatment.

title: M.O. PARLEY REAFFIRMS GOALS
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 6 When the convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People ended yesterday after five quiet days of meetings, greetings and Creole gumbo, Dr. Aaron Henry, a member of the national board and a veteran civil rights activist, summed it up this way:

title: Encounter: You Like? Well. Yes
description: ABRUPTLY, I found that I wanted to swim in the Ionian Sea by myself. My head was full of the sights and sounds of Delphi, and I didn't want them diffused by the learned chatter of my bus companions, enthusiastic and charming though they were. And if I was to swim in the Ionian Sea somewhere between two towns named Lapa and Lechaina, I wanted to do it consciously, deliberately, to experience it, to find how it was different from every other sea. 1 wanted no statistics. My husband had declined to swim, preferring to stay on the shady porch of the little inn at which we had lunched and read.

title: Milhaud: He Churned Out Music but Fulfilled the Composer's Role
description: WHEN Darius Milhaud died the other day, the obituaries made a point of his having written more than 400 works. As well they might. Prodigality of that sort is anything but typical of 20thcentury composers, and the Frenchman's output made him something of an anachronism. In a rocketship age he was tireless maker of beautifully crafted butter churns and weathervanes. It is, in fact, hard to think of many other composers of our time who worked so productively and with such apparent ease. Hindemith,.and Villa Lobos come to mind, but the list of the prolific is significantly short.

title: Connors a Confident Champion
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 (AP)He is a killer, said Jimmy Connors's longtime coach, Pancho Segura, today after his protege's victory. The tougher the situation, the meaner he gets.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An order to vacate the Knickerbocker Hotel 120 West 45th Street has been lifted by the city's Office of Code Enforcement after tenants helped to transform the hotel into a decent place to live.

title: Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THE article on What Really Ails the Fabulous Invalid? by William J. and Hilda Baumol (June 2), is another example of what really ails the fabulous invalid. To talk of cost disease and increased productivity of the actor is to apply the criteria of the businessman to the world of art.

title: Margaret Carrere To Marry July 27
description: Mrs. John Francis Carrre of New Orleans has announced the engagement and approaching marriage of her daughter, Miss Margaret Lykes Carrere, to Kevin McCarthy Johnson, son of Walter H. Johnson Jr., vice chairman of Saturday Review/World, and Mrs. Johnson of Katonah, N.Y. The couple plan to be wed in New Orleans on July 27.

title: FOR BERGTRAUM
description: A new high school under construction in downtown Manhattan, which will prepare its graduates for jobs in business and finance, has been officially designated the Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers in memory of the former member and president of the City Board of Education.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Summary

title: David Spiro, Pathology Head At New York Medical, 52, Dies
description: Dr. David Spiro, an experimental pathologist who was professor and chairman of the department of pathology at New York Medical College, died Friday at his summer home in Wellfleet, Mass. He was 52 years old and lived at 6 Paula Place, Chappaqua, N. Y.

title: Elizabeth Crocker Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. William J. Crocker of New York and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Ann Crocker, to Q. Basil Meade Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Meade of Richmond and Islamorada, fila. A September wedding in Bermuda is planned.

title: Labor Seeks to Ease Ecology Rules in a Bid to Increase Jobs
description: TRENTON  The unemployment problem in New Jersey may vmfront the Byrne administration with some difficult environmental decisions.

title: Japan Fears Spread Of Mercury Disease
description: TOKYO, July 6Two decades ago, fishermen in the town of Minamata on Japan's southern island of Kyushu were surprised to see their cats suddenly begin to twitch, jump crazily and finally dive into the ocean to die. They called it the dancing cat disease.

title: WIDE DRIVE URGED ON SUBWAY SAFETY
description: Federal investigators, reporting on a fatal accident in Colorado last year involvng an experimental subway car, has called for greatly expanded Federal efforts to improve the safety of rail and subway cars.

title: Polo Is Making Comeback
description: PLUCKEMINOnce a way of life only among the wealthy, polo is enjoying a rebirth in New Jersey. The game, sometimes called hockey on horseback, is now attracting spectators from all walks of life.

title: Miss Stellar Betrothed
description: Dr. Eliot Stellar, provost the University of Pennsyl vania, and Mrs. Stellar of Ardmore, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Anne Stellar, to Charles E. Fallon Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fallon of Chatham Township, N. J.

title: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records
description: Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records

title: Colson Says He Thought He and Colleagues Were Above the Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 6 diaries W. Colson, in a reflective interview about his days as a White House tough guy, has declared that he and other highlevel aides were convinced that they were above the law while working for President Nixon.

title: Shopper's Guide to Ships
description: The following chart shows the price a couple would pay for (1) the best suite, (2) a representative outside double with two lower berths and (3) a minimumpriced accommodation on the Maxim Gorki for a typical Wall Street cruise and on some other luxury cruise liners operating out of New York. The Gorki's figures are even better than they would appear because hers are for an eightday cruise and the others are all for sevenday cruises. All prices reflect fuel surcharges and have been rounded off to the nearest dollar.

title: The Final Report Is Likely to Outdo Its Own Leaks
description: WASHINGTONThe Senate Watergate Committee is slipping into history. The staff is dispersing, the Senators have gone on to other tasks, the blinding lights of the committee hearing room have long since been switched off and taken down. Yet there is one last salvo to come from the committeeits final report.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: FollowUp
description: In the late nineteensixties, when freedom in education was the rage, Fordham University created a utopian threeyear college without classrooms, credits, term papers, requirements or grades.

title: The Region
description: In the aftermath of a fire at a Port Chester, N. Y., singles bar, which killed 24 young people, questions are being asked about the cause of the blaze and about fire safety codes for public buildings in that community and others.

title: Mrs. Ruth Knight, 79, Dies; Novelist and Script Writer
description: Mrs. Ruth Adams Knight, novelist and radio script writer, died Thursday in South Pasadena, Calif., where she lived. Her age was 79.

title: REV. JOHN P. CASEY
description: The Rev. John P. Casey, pastor of Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church in Hicksville, L.I., since 1968, died Thursday of a heart attack in Syosset (L.I.) Hospital. His age was 51.

title: Martha McGarry to Wed Aug. 24
description: The engagement of Miss Martha Ellen McGarry, to Garfield Lankard Miller 3d, son of Mrs. Miller Jr., of Buffalo and the late Mr. Miller, has been announced by her father, Prof. Frederick J. McGarry of Weston, Mass. The wedding is planned for Aug. 24.

title: Mary Peatman To Be a Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. John G. Peatman of Silvermine, Norwalk, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Madeline Peatman, to John Francis Fitzpatrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Fitzpatrick of New York.

title: Suffolk Buying 1st Farm Tract
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON  Employing a complex but commonly used realty ploy, John V. N. Klein, the Suffolk County Executive, has acted to purchase 68 acres of choice property here under his farmland preservation program.

title: Vatican and Poland Move Closer to Diplomatic Tie
description: ROME, July 6The Vatican and Poland have agreed to establish permanent working contacts, a papal spokesman has announced. The move appears to be a step toward formal diplomatic ties.

title: Nassau Is Backed By Court On Housing
description: MINEOLANassau County received the goahead last week from the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Second District to proceed with construction of a $44million sports and recreation complex, a central. reference library and an industrial park, office buildings and possibly a luxury hotel, at Mitchell Field in Hempstead.

title: The Oil IndustryCaught in a TugofWar
description: Caught in a crossfire between producingcountry demands and consumingcountry outrage over prices, the oil industry is changing. This mutation appears almost certain to continue and possibly accelerate in the future.

title: Red Smith
description: Through the courtesy and scholarship of Stanley I. Cohen, a client in Ridgewood, N. J., it Is possible to brighten this morning with the advice that there was a Nixon, a Mitchell and a Dean on the Philadelphia Phillies of 1926, and a Cox on the Brooklyn Dodgers that same year. I haven't done the research into individual games, Cohen writes, but it is possible that these four names appeared in the same box score 48 years ago.. It is possible in spite of the fact that, both Mitchell and Dean were starting pitchers. Mitchell appeared three times in re lief that season and Dean seven times so one may have replaced the other against Brooklyn. Cox was the Dodgers regular right fielderZach. Wheat was in left and Gus Felix in centerso almost certainly he batted against both Mitchell and Dean.

title: Correction
description: In a story on Manhattan's horizontal growth in the June 30 Week in Review, a sentence regarding Manhattan Landing incorrectly stated that one bridge would lead to the project. The sentence should have read,  pedestrians will have to get to the area via special bridges over the highway and through underpasses.

title: Seaver's Bad Hip Flares Up As Mets. Trounce Giants, 60
description: Apart from the fact that they defeated the San Francisco Giants, 6.0, the New York Mets ended the first half of the baseball season yesterday in almost exactly the same straits as a year ago11 games under the .500 level, hurting and last in the National League's East Division.

title: Inmates of V room Building Lose Privileges as a Result of Clash
description: TRENTON, July 7Recreation periods and other privileges for 47 inmates of the Vroom Building, the maximumsecurity prison wing of Trenton Psychiatric Hospital, have been suspended for two weeks as a result of a clash Friday between five inmates and 11 guards there.

title: Cruise Steers Jazz Fete to Happy End
description: Jazz came up the river frotn New Orleans again yesterday. The Hudson, not the Mississippi. And for a few sparkling hours, the waters became a meeting place for friends and strangers from all over the world.

title: State to Review All Correction Centers In Wake of Matteawan Fraud Reports
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday said he was ordering a staff conference in Albany further inquiries into correctional facilities in the state following findings that mentally ill and handicapped inmates were cheated in commissary transactions at Matteawan State Hospital in Beacon, N.Y.

title: Wealthy Ethiopians Warned to Yield Arsenals
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, 7 (AP)  The Ethiopian told the country's aristocrats, today to give up private senals and give hack merit property they have taken The order, in an official broadcast, set a Friday deadline.

title: CONSUMERS SHOW LESS PESSIMISN
description: White consumers remain pessimistic about personal finances and the business outlook, their pessimism was much less pronounced in May than it was three months earlier, according to the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research.

title: City Hospital Built to Be Altered
description: With construction only 60 per cent completed and occupancy not scheduled before early 1976, the Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center, the first municipal hospital designed to provide private rooms for its patients, is already being hailed as the first hospital in the city built so it can easily be altered.

title: Lisbon Government Getting Down to Basics
description: LISBON, July 7Portuguese officials are declaring themselves more optimistic these days as the first great wave of social unrest that swept the country after the military coup April 25 appears to have lost most of Its force.

title: Sets Lose, 2521 To Lobster Team
description: BOSTON, July 7  A decisive mixeddoubles victory by Raz Reid and Janet Newberry over Nikki Pilic and Sharon Walsh paced the Boston Lobsters to a 2521 decision over the New, York Sets in World Team Tennis tonight. The matches were played before 2,412 fans at the Walter Brown Arena on the campus of Boston University.

title: Chile Destroys Vote Rolls
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 7 (Reuters)Chilean records that contained the names of four million eligible voters were destroyed last night by the Government, a Government spokesman reported. He said that the Government of the late president Salvedor Allende Gossens had put false names on the rolls before elections in March of last year.

title: Texas Police Assess Some Theories About Cause of Ford Motorcade Incident
description: DALLAS, July 7  Texas Police investigators continued today to investigate the mystery of a shattered car window in Vice President Ford's motorcade, which generated fears yesterday that the motorcade had been fired upon.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TRENTON, July 7The Legislature has provided the impetus for the revitalization of New Jersey's thoroughbred and standardhred breeding industries.

title: Kenton and Ferguson Share Stage
description: Followers of loudness, highness and ridiculousness in big bands had a field day at the Newport Jazz Festival early Saturday evening when the bands of Stan Kenton and Maynard Ferguson shared a program at Carnegie Hall.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: Suez Canal Port to Reopen
description: CAIRO, July 7 (Reuters) The harbor of Poet Said, at the northern tip of the Suez Canal, will reopen for shipping in 10 days for the first time since the 1967 Middle East war, the Egyptian daily Al Ahram reported today. The newspaper said the Egyptian cargo ship Abu Simbel is due to dock at Port Said on July 17.

title: Colson Due to Surrender And Begin Sentence Today
description: BALTIMORE, July 7 (UPI)Charles W. Colson, described by President Nixon as a man who would do anything to achieve a goal, was expected to surrender to Federal marshals here tomorrow to begin serving a sentence of one to three years for obstruction of justice in the Ellsberg breakin case. He pleaded guilty to one count of attempting to smear Daniel Ellsberg while the latter was on trial for making the Pentagon papers available to the press.

title: Stock Exchanges Abroad Hard Hit in the First Hall
description: PARIS, July 7It's happening not just in Wall Street but in most of the world's financial centers. One stock market after the other is succumbing to tight money and the fears of a generalized world recession.

title: COMPANIES DELAY ABU DHABI OIL TALKS
description: ABU DHABI, July 7 (Reuters)  Negotiations between Abu Dhabi and foreign oil companies aimed at Abu Dhabi's taking over a majority holding in the industry here were unexpectedly susnended tonight.

title: 33 DEATHS IN JAPAN AS TYPHOON PASSES
description: TOKYO, July 7 (AP)  As much as 12 inches of rain from a typhoon lashed western, and southern Japan over the weekend. Thirtythree persons were killed and some 50 injured in the storm, while 15 persons were reported missing, the police reported today.

title: TV: Edwardians Depicts a Candid Lloyd George
description: In a modest gesture to relieve the summer rerun doldrums, public television's masterpiece Theater has imported half of a series from the British Broadcasting Corporation called The Edwerdians.

title: S.E.C. Is Investigating Companies Political Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun investigations which could lead to widespread court action against companies and executives who made illegal campaign contributions to President Nixon and other politicans.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Early unofficial returns from Japan's national election showed the ruling LiberalDemocratic party taking a commanding lead in its bid to hold the majority in the upper house of Parliament. In the heaviest voting on record for the upper house, the LiberalDemocrats had won 53 of the 78 contests already decided. [1:8.]

title: Police Chief Orders CoverUp
description: ATLANTA, July 7 (AP)From now on, says Police Chief John Inman, officers arresting nude persons must obtain clothing for them before hauling them to jail. If no clothing is available, Chief Inman wrote in the department's daily bulletin, the arresting officer will call the rescue unit to the scene for the purpose of obtaining a disposable blanket to cover the person with before transporting the arrested person to jail or to the hospital.

title: Tax Bill May Be Debated Thursday, Speaker Says
description: TRENTON, July 8 (UPI)The Rev. S. Howard Woodson Jr., Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, says that if Governor Byrne is anywhere near getting the 41 votes needed for passage of his incometax package in the Assembly, the measure will he up for floor debate Thursday.

title: City DepositBottle Plan Faces Lobby That Killed Similar Bills Elsewhere
description: In the New York City Councii, a proposed law to require returnable beverage containers has been sponsored by 28 Councilmen, well over a majority of the 44member body.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Police Commissioner Michael J. Codd ordered the dismissal of a detective convicted at a departmental trial of having accepted about $3,500 taken illegally from a narcotics dealer.

title: Millions Pour Back Into Sweltering City After4Day Holiday
description: The return from the country to the citya passage that is as much psychological as geographicbegan late yesterday for millions of New Yorkers who jammed trains and wedged onto highways in an oftenpainful retreat from pleasure.

title: Knifton Is Winner In Bridgeport Walk
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 7John Knifton, a 34yearold industrial chemist competing for the New York Athletic Club, won the Connecticut Amateur Athletic Union's 10,000meter racewalking championship today in a field of 71 contestants.

title: Sue Roberts Gains First Golf Victory
description: GRAND ISLAND, N. Y., July 7 (AP)Sue Roberts shot a threeunderpar 70 today for a twostroke victory in the Niagara Frontier golf, tournament. It was her first triumph on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour. Her 54hole total of 213 was six under par.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: GOING OUT Guide

title: Party Leaders in Canada Wind Up Election Race
description: TORONTO, July 7  Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and his principal rival, Robert L. Stanfield, wound up their campaigns this afternoon with appearances in southern Ontario, a crucial region in Canada's parliamentary election tomorrow.

title: Three in Brooklyn Family Murdered in Their Home
description: The bodies of a 55yearold building contractor, his wife: and a man described as a visiting relative were found yesterday afternoon in separate rooms of the couple's ransacked apartment in their twofamily home in Brooklyn.

title: Major Bills In Congress
description: VETOED FuelGives the President broad powers to curtail energy consumption and manage fuel supplies. Veto sustamed by Senate.

title: EDITH ROMAINE
description: Edith Romaine, a former concert singer, who was soloist at the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in the nineteentwenties, died here Saturday. She was 87 years old and lived in New York and Isle au Haut, Me.

title: TALK OF REIN HELD A BANKLOAN SPUR
description: The money market is awash with talk that some form of Federal control over bank lending may be imposed unless the unrelenting demand by big corporate borrowers for credit abates soon. Such talk may have moCredit tivated corporate Markets treasurers to borrow a record $1.1billion here in the week ended June 26, the end of the latest bankstatement period.

title: Rangers Win on Yank Error, 32
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 7 There is little as discouraging for a pitcher as losing a game on unearned runs, and Pat Dobson, the Yankee righthander, was the victim of that depressing development tonight as New York was beaten by the Rangers, 32.

title: PREMIER'S PARTY RUNNING IN FRONT IN JAPANESE VOTE
description: TOKYO, Monday, July 8Early unofficial returns from yesterday's election showed the governing LiberalDemacratic party taking a comfortable lead in its bid to hold its majority in the upper house of parliament.

title: 2 Women Hikers Missing
description: YELLOWSTONE NATIONAL PARK, Wyo., July 7 (AP)Park rangers searched today on Mount. Washburn here for two missing 21yearold women. A park spokesman said Christine Smith of Three Forks, La., and Rebecca Russell of Memphis were last seen about 2 P.M. Friday by a ranger at a lookout station. He said the two women had hiked to the top of the mountain and told him they were hiking back down.

title: Fire Drives 17 From Homes
description: Seventeen persons were left homeless in the Morrisiana section of the Bronx last night when a threealarm fire heavily damaged three threestory frame dwellings between 1157 and 1153 Forest Avenue, at Home Street. A simultaneous blaze a block to the east destroyed five vacant wooden buildings from 1143 to 1153 Tinton Avenue.

title: QUEENS MAN SEIZED AS ABDUCTORRAPIST
description: A 26yearold unemployed machinist was seized at home yesterday afternoon held on charges of kidnapping; and rape following a complaint by an 18yearold Queens girt who identified him as attacker.

title: Newport Jazz. Basie Men Come to Life For Enthusiastic Throng
description: Count Basie's band, which often performs like a welloiled but completely impersonal machine, came to life late Saturday evening before an enthusiastic audience that filled Carnegie Hall for a Newport Jazz Festival concert. The elements that brought the band to life were slow and subtle in taking effect, but by the second half of their concert the usually dour, boredlooking Basie men were full of smiles, relaxed and showing high spirits.

title: EUROPEAN LEFT HAS MEETING ON CHILE
description: PARIS, July 7 A European conference of Communists, Socialists and Social Democrats meeting to discuss Chile closed here this afternoon with a resolution calling for the, restoretion of civil and political rights in that country.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Jackson, Back, Sees Real Chinese Detente
description: EVERETT, Wash., July 7 (UPI)  Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, back from a sixday visit to China, said today that the United States was developing a real detente with the Chinese leaders.

title: Israeli Says Missile Sites in Lebanon Would Be Subject to Attack
description: TEL AVIV, July 7The commander of the Israeli Air Force, Maj. Gen. Binyamin Peled, said today that if missile launchers were set up in Palestinian camps in Lebanon they would be subject to attack by his bombers.

title: East German Girl Sets Swim Mark
description: ROSTOCK, East Germany, July 7 (Reuters)Ulrike Richter of East Germany set a women's world record the 200meter backstroke here today, Her time was 2 minutes 18.41 seconds.

title: NIXON'S POWERS FACE TEST TODAY IN SUPREME COURT
description: WASHINGTON, July 7The Supreme Court meets tomorrow in a highly charged political atmosphere to hear two cases with profound legal and personal implications for President Nixon and his former aides, six of whom'are accused of conspiring to cover up the Watergate burglary.

title: WINTER WHEAT CROP IS ESTIMATED LOWER
description: Conrad Leslie, a leading crop reporter, yesterday forecast the nation's winter wheat crop, now being harvested, at 1.42 billion bushelswell below his June 1 estimate of 1.57 billion and also below the Department of Agriculture's June 1 projection of 1.53 billion.

title: Guitars, From Soft to Boisterous
description: Last year the Newport Jazz Festival offered an outdoor concert called Guitar Explosion. This year, several of the same artists moved indoors to Avery Fisher Hall for a similar program, given twice Saturday night. Only this time it was called Guitar Impressions, and the title made a difference.

title: World Cup Gross
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 7 (AP)The 1974 World Cup tournament grossed from $29million to $31million and was the biggest football business of all time, Herman Neuberger, president of the World Cup Organizing Committee, said today. Ticket sales alone accounted for $12.9million, Neuberger said. Each team in the final received $784,300.

title: Nearby Yachting Results
description: Nearby Yachting Results

title: Israelis Bar Mufti Burial
description: AMMAN, Jordan, July 7 (Agence FrancePresse) Israeli authorities have refused to allow the body of the former Grand Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin elHusseini, to be buried in the city, his birthplace, Jordanian officials said today. A request for permission to bury the Mufti, who led the fight against a Jewish state in Palestine in the nineteenthirties, was made by the Islamic Council of Jerusalem to the Israelis, who rejected it, the officials said. The Mufti died Thursday in Beirut, Lebanon.

title: Prisoner Stabbed in Fight Inside. City Jail in Brooklyn
description: A prisoner at the Brooklyn House of Detention, Atlantic Avenue and Smith Street, in downtown Brooklyn, was stabbed yesterday morning by another prisoner during an argument in Cell Block No. 9.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: Chenault's Road to Atlanta and Tragedy Is Linked to a Bizarre Interpretation of Bible
description: DAYTON, Ohio, July 7 week after a young black man shattered the quiet of a church service in Atlanta by killing Mrs. Martin Luther King Sr. and a deacon, the nagging question of motive persists. his choice, but was preordained 2,000 years ago, as was everything that happens today.

title: World Team Tennis
Cruise Steers Jazz Fete to Happy End
description: Jazz came up the river from New Orleans again yesterday. The Hudson, not the Mississippi. And for a few sparkling hours, the waters became a meeting place for friends and strangers from all over the world.

title: HENRY L. FLATTAU
description: Henry L. Flattau, a founding partner in the law firm of Parker, Chapin & Flattau, died yesterday at his home, 205 East 69th Street. He was 69 years old.

title: GLADDEN W. BAKER
description: Gladden W. Baker, a retired director and chairman of the finance committee of Travelers Insurance Companies, died Thursday in Hartford. He was 76 years old.

title: Troy May Be the Loser in Aftermath of Beame's Successful, NoBudging Budget Battle
description: Everybody misread Mayor Beanie in the late great Battle of the Budget. But the noisiest of the blunderers was Matthew J. Troy Jr., the City Council Finance Committee chairman, and some politicians suggest that in his case the story may not be over yet. Give the devil his due, said one Councilman, shaking his head over the way Mayor Beame had insisted the maneuvering room in his $11.1billion municipal budg et was minuscule and then demonstrated, with a rare display of his political power, that he had meant exactly what he said.

title: 7th Avenue Fashion Flurry Belies Threadbare Results
description: On the surface, all seems well on Seventh Avenue, the huh of New York City's women's and children's garment industry. It is frantic, noisy and congested  normal in other words.

title: U.S. to Start Checks on Welfare And Health of Migrant Workers
description: Trenton, July 7 (UPI)Checks on the health and welfare of migrant workers will take place this month before the seasonal farmhands take up residence at the hundreds of farm camps dotting southern New Jersey.

title: Soviet Jewish Scientists Propose New Seminar
description: MOSCOW, July 7A group of Jewish scientists prevented by the Soviet secret police from holding an unauthorized international seminar during President Nixon's visit, said today that they would try again to hold the seminar in September or October.

title: Theater
description: MADISON, N. J., July 6There is no questioning the professional, picturesque facade applied to Measure for Measure, which is part of the 10th season of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival.

title: Catholic Wounded in Ulster
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 7 (UPI)A gunman firing through a glass door wounded a 20yearold Roman Catholic man early today at his home in North Belfast. The victim was hospitalized in serious condition.

title: IN JAIL 46 YEARS, MAN WINS PAROLE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 Wesley Robert Wells, who has spent nearly half a century behind bars, made his trip to freedom in a RollsRoyce.

title: Hearing Set for Wednesday in Abortion Clinics in City
description: The city Department of Consumer Affairs has scheduled a hearing for 10 A.M. Wednesday to listen to allegations of improper medical procedures and questionable financial arrangements at some abortion clinics here.

title: Tour for Mexican Chief
description: MEXICO CITY, July 7 (AP)President. Luis Echeverria Alvarez of Mexico says that he will seek and end to the unfair blockade of Cuba when he makes a LatinAmerican tour this month. He is to leave, Wednesday on a 19day tour of Ecuador, Peru, Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela.

title: Bronx Girl Killed by a Train
description: An 18yearold Bronx girl was killed yesterday by a southbound Penn Central passenger train that apparently sideswiped her after she had taken a short cut across the tracks near the East 241st Street branch and the Bronx River Parkway in the Wakefield section. She was identified as Alicia De Marco of 3230 Steuben Avenue.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: That Bengali Necessity, An Umbrella, Is in Peril
description: TUNGI, BangladeshA Bengali and his umbrella cannot be separated, so the saying goes, but moreand more poor Bengalis in Bangladesh are parting with theirs these days.

title: Warm Springs Center Taken Over by Georgia
description: WARM SPRINGS, Ga., July 7 (AP)A legacy from President Franklin D. Roosevelt, a treatment center for polio victims, was taken over by the state of Georgia today.

title: 19,600 See TV Soccer At Garden
description: A cheering, but orderly crowd of 19,600 at Madison Square Gardenpart of a worldwide television audience estimated at 800 million saw West Germany defeat the Netherlands and in the World Cup yesterday:

title: Theater: The Seagull
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 7Many of the finest actors and actresses on the American stage have appeared in many of the world's finest plays at the Williamstown Theater Festival, under the artistic direction of Nikos Psacharopoulos. This is a place where serious artists can nurture and test their talents by playing roles that might not otherwise be available to them in the commercial theater.

title: West Germans Win Soccer Cup
description: MUNICH, West Germany, July 7West Germany repulsed a fierce attack to defeat the Netherlands today in the World Cup soccer final, 21, and become the champion in the world's most popular sport.

title: 150 Rabbinic Students Here Begin JewishIdentity Tour
description: Some 75 twomember teams of youthful Orthodox rabbinic students of the Lubavitcher Movement's seminaries in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section left yesterday to visit Jewish communities throughout the country to stress the role of traditional Judaism as a major factor in strengthening Jewish identity.

title: Elderly Man and Wife Kill TeenAge Robber
description: MIAMI, July 7 (AP)A 79yearold man and his wife fought off and killed a teenage robber who broke into their cottage at a senior citizens project last night, the police said.

title: Drilling Shows Volcanic Origin of 2 Atlantic Islands
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, July 5 Drilling deep into the roots of geologically ancient Bermuda and of relatively young Sao Miguel in the Azores indicates that both islands are volcanic by products of a process that is believed to be continuously widening the Atlantic Ocean.

title: IHunger in America
description: Late in the nineteensixties millions of Americans were shocked to learn that widespread hunger existed in this country. Over the last five years, the Government has intensified its efforts to feed the hungry poor more adequately. Now, the Senate Select Committee on Nutrition and Human Needs is asking how, this effort is going. A 26member panel of experts worked for several months to produce the answer. It is: terrible.

title: Waterfront Master Plan Focuses on Many Uses

title: Bridge: New Book Called Best on Game Since Culbertson's Gold Book
description: One has to go back almost 30 years to find a parallel to The Complete Book of Bridge by two British experts, Terence Reese and Albert Dormer, published here by Saturday Review Press/ E.P. Dutton & Co. Inc, at $9.95. Its predecessor is the Culbertson Gold Book, a remarkable work in its day that attempted to give the bridge enthusiast all significant information about the game.

H.T. ROWE, 68 DIES; WAS I.B.M. OFFICIAL
description: H. T. Rowe, former Suriday editor of The New York Herald Tribune and retired advertising aria information director of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Saturday of a stroke in Valley Hospital, Ridgewood, N.J. He was 68 years old and lived at 302 Glenwood Road, Ridgewood.

description: Alexander Angus LeRoux, a former operatic tenor, who more recently operat'd a bar bershop in Lake Placid, N.Y., died yesterday in Lake Placid Memorial Hospital at the age of 97.

title: Norfolk Plans Amusement Park and Shopping Center in Dome

title: Peterson Triumphs In France
description: DIJON, France, July 7 (AP) Ronnie Peterson of Sweden risked one desperately late braking point today to outfox Niki Lauda of Austria and win the French Grand Prix auto race.

title: Marshall Gets 2 Saves as Dodgers Sweep Expos
description: Mike Marshall, the Los Angeles reliever, who loves hard work, helped his teammate, Tommy John, gain his 13th victory and become the National League's winningest pitcher yesterday in the Dodgers 4.1 triumph over the Expos at Montreal, Marshall also saved the second game, won by Los Angeles, 53.

title: Sadat's Daughter Married
description: CAIRO, July 7 (UPI)Scores of veterans of the October Middle East war were guests at the wedding tonight of President Anwar elSadat's 17yearold daughter, Noha, and Hassan Sayed Marei, son of a presidential aide, in Alexandria, Government sources said. President Sadat's daughter is a student of literature at Cairo University. Her husband is a lecturer at the American University in Cairo.

title: Topless Club Reopens Pending Judge's Review
description: PENNSAUKEN, July 7 (UPI)  The Club Lido reopened its topless act here this weekend and waited for a Federal judge to review the proceedings to determine whether the performance was protected under the First Amendment. The club operator, John Schoch, 37 years old, said he did not know if United States District Court Judge Clarkson S. Fisher was in the opening night audience.

title: Hair Ban Strikes Firehouse Sparks
description: Fireman Joseph Callahan, who describes his reddishblond beard as both funky and the kind Ulysses S. Grant wore, angrily posted his combined protest and warning yesterday in Engine Company 13's firehouse at 251 Lafayette Street a 10yearold picture of himself, cleanshaven and crew cut, that was captioned, What will look like after Monday, July 8, 1974.

description: Einstein's theory of relativity, in the somewhat exaggerated view of Herbert S. Denenberg,. PennsyNania's former insurance commissioner, is a lot easier to understand than the wording in a typical insurance policy.

title: New Books
description: Hank Aaron 715, edited by Pat Reshen (Arco, $4.95). A behindthescenes look at the homerun leader.

title: Brooklyn Man Shot Nearing His Home; Mob Aspects Seen
description: A 31yearold Brooklyn man was shot in the chest early yesterday morning moments after he left the parked car of two friends and began walking, toward his residence near Prospect Park, the police said.

title: If White House Has an AntiImpeachment Lobby, Its Work Isn't Apparent to Many in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 7  If the White House is conducting an antiimpeachment lobby on Capitol Hill, as some critics have asserted, it is doing so with a gossamer touch that seems to be unfelt by many members of Congress.

title: 2 Escapees Found Killed
description: BOSTON, July 7 (AP)Two men who escaped last night from the Deer Island House of Correction were found shot to death in East Boston today, the police said. The bodies of Richard Giandello, IS years old, and Philip Giantasio, 21, were found a few blocks apart.

title: Rome No. 4 in Tax Disputes
description: ROME (AP)Rome is Italy's largest city in terms of population, but it only ranks No, 4 on the scale of tax disputes. Tax authorities say Turin has the most disputed income tax returns, followed by Milan, Naples and then Rome.

title: Turley Asks U.S. Ideas on Opium Curbs
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 7 (AP)The Turkish Government said today that it would welcome any help the United States might offer in controlling the flow of illegal opium from Turkish poppy fields.

title: Miss Kathryn Kempner Is Bride
description: Miss Kathryn Margaret Kempner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Loeb Kempner of White Plains, was married there last evening to Dr. George Howard Poteat, who received a doctorate in political science in December from Washington University in St. Louis. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Harold Poteat of Whittier, Calif.

title: A.T.&T. Chairman Honored
description: John D. deButts, chairman of the board of American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has been selected to receive the 1974 award for excellence in business and industry, from the Society for the Family of Man in recognition of his distinguished business achievements and for his community activities. The presentation will be made here Oct. 31.

title: Poll Finds Service Stations Thwarted on Unleaded Gas
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) Many highvolume service stations did not meet the July deadline to start selling unleaded gasoline, the American Automobile Association ported today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The United States Civil Service Commission has rejected the final appeal of William F. Higgins Jr., a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who was dismissed last October for insubordination. The commission's Board of Appeals and Review notified Mr. Higgins, who lives Hillsdale, that it was upholding the Feb. 27 decision of the Civil Service regional director in New York that the F.B.I. agent assigned to the Newark office was guilty of insubordination for refusing to halt his inquiry of a Cleveland bankruptcy case.

title: Dr. Jno L. Hunt Weds Teresa Gioia
description: Miss Teresa Ann Gioia, a candidate for a doctorate in Italian at the University of Michigan, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Jno Leland Hunt, a clarinetist with a doctorate in musicology from Michigan.

title: Dance: The Creative Gift
description: George Balanchine and Antony Tudor are the two creative immigrants who have done almost everything to formulate American classic ballet. They have both given so much. When we look at America's indigenous choreographers, from Jerome Robbins onward, the influence of both the Georgian and the Englishman are apparent.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: FLOWERY BRANCH, Ga., July 7 (UPI)Jackie Oliver of England, leading from start to finish, beat his UOP Shadow teammate, George Follmer, by half a minute today in winning the second leg of the CanadianAmerican Challenge Cup auto race.

title: Paris: The Coming of Age of Impressionism
description: PARIS  In 1874 Monet, Renoir, Degas, Pissarro and their friends rented a place on the Boulevard des Italiens belonging to the photographer Nadar to exhibit their work. Looking at a Monet oil representing Le Havre harbor at sunrise, titled Impression, a critic derisively spoke of impressionism. Thus 1974 is as good a time as any to celebrate the coming of age of the most popular movement in art history.

title: Cemetery Fund Is Ended
description: UNITED NATIONS N.Y., July 7 (AP)  The United Nations budgetary committee teas stricken from the 197475 budget a $160,000 expenditure for upkeep of a cemetery in South Korea for those killed in the Korean War. The appropria tion had been the budget each year since 1960.

title: Nixon Inspects Palm Beach Estate Willed to U.S.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., July 7 (AP)  President Nixon made an unannounced trip by helicopter this morning to Palm Beach to look over the MarALago Estate, willed to the Government for possible use by Presidents or visiting foreign dignitaries.

title: Maryland Incumbents Favored To Keep Their Jobs This Fall
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 7 With the deadline past for candidates to file for the Sept. 10 Maryland primary, relatively minor opposition has developed against most incumbents holding major office, despite widely publicized investigations into corruption in the last year.

description: MIAMI, July 7 (AP)Chris Evert, the queen of Wimbledon, arrives, from England today to hear a proclamation in her honor from Florida Gov. Reuben Askew. She was cheered for her tennis triumph.

description: A 23yearold man was stabbed to death yesterday afternoon in a city pool in Brooklyn that was crowded with nearly 3,000 bathers. The police said the slaying apparently was a revenge killing.

description: MIAMI BEACH, July 7 (AP)Cornelius Vanderbilt Jr., author and former newspaperman, died here today at his home. He was 76 years old.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, July 7 (AP)The Cambodian command said today that Government troops pushing north from Phnom Penh retook a key pagoda yesterday.

title: ExBronx School Board Accused of Fund Misuse
description: A state audit charged recently that the former board of Community School District 8 in the Bronx had misused or failed to account for thousands of dollars of petty cash and other funds.

description: CONCORD, N. H., July 7 (AP) Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson is scheduled to speak tomorrow night at a Republican fundraising reception at the Concord Armory.

description: The bloodspattered bodies of a 55yearold building contractor, his wife and a man described as a visiting relative were found yesterday afternoon in separate rooms of the couple's ransacked apartment in their twofamily home in Brooklyn.

title: The Science Gap
description: From the energy crisis to Soviet MIRV multiple warhead missiles, the United States today is confronted by a plethora of dangers that with foresight might well have been headed off. Failure to perceive the true dimensions of these threats and to act upon them in time reflects, in part, the absence of an effective system for funneling topgrade scientific advice directly and quickly to the White House.

title: Saving All Structures of Landmark Quality
description: So now they want to tear down the 102yearold Tweed Courthouse. Mayor Beame's special task force to improve the Civic Center area doesn't think much of the grand and outrageous monument on Chambers Street, reeking as it does of the city's history and character. A nice clean new building, they feel, would enhance City Hall. (But with landmarks, as with rickrack, one man's enhancement may be another man's shlock.)

title: MRS. HENRY P. LEVERICH
description: Mrs. Katharine Bingham Levericli of Washington, widow of Henry P. Leverich, a Foreign Service officer and State Department official, died yesterday in Georgetown Hospital in Washington. She was 69 years old.

title: A SovietU.S. Park?
description: The communique that followed the recent NixonBrezhnev summit talks included a section on environmental protection which has received too little notice. The pronouncement was important not for its concrete proposals but because its inclusion showed renewed recognition that it will take more than arms control and diplomacy to assure man's future on this planet.

title: MOSCOW PRAISES RESULTS OF TALKS

description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 7 (AP) Mrs. Ellnora Krannert, an Indianapolis philanthropist, died yesterday at Indiana University Hospital. She was 84 years old.

He would nullify the constitutional provision for Presidential accountability that was designed to prevent dictatorial usurpations.

description: Mrs. Lily Kanter Kaufman, wife of I. Kaufman, a retired member of the staff of the Newspaper Guild of New York and a former reporter and war correspondent for The Brooklyn Eagle, died yesterday in Long Island College Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived at 84 Remsen Street in Brooklyn Heights.

description: BALTIMORE July 7 (AP) Striking city workers said today they would continue their walkout, despite a backtowork order and the threat of heavy fines.
