title: Beech Aircraft Dividend Up
description: The Beech Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday its quarterly dividend was being raised from 12 cents to 15 cents per share. The Wichita, Kan.based airplane manufacturer said the revised dividend would be paid Aug. 2 to shareholders of record July 19.

title: MERGER CANCELED BY PAPER COMPANY
description: The International Paper Company announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to merge the General Crude Oil Company into a subsidiary of International through a $437million purchase of General Crude's common and preferred shares.

title: Drama Season Review: It's Better Looking Back
description: It was the best of seasons, it was the worst of seasons. Theater seasons are like the weather, They always seem more dramatic after a few decades of contemplative retrospection. When we were young, the summers were hotter and the winters were colder. Theater seasons were better, too, It is, as everyone knows, the atom bomb that has done it.

title: Mrs. Dempsey Duo Leads in L.I. Golf
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 9Carol Beinbrink and Mrs. Phebe Dempsey of St. George's Golf and Country Club scored a twooverpar 74 over the 5,515yard Maidstone Club course today and lead the annual women's Long Island Golf Association betterball championship by six strokes.

title: ONE COUNT DROPPED IN REINECKE'S CASE
description: WASHINGTON, July 9  At the goverment's request, Judge Barrington Parker of the united States District Court dismissed today one of three perjury counts against Lieut. Gov. Ed reinecke of California.

title: Airline Is Ordered to Hire Men for Stewardess Jobs
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) A Federal judge ordered a Philadelphiabased airline today to hire male applicants for stewardess positions and, to seek out previously rejected males who had sought such jobs but were turned down because of their sex.

title: Decision in Canada
description: At a time when democratic institutions are in retreat or under heavy pressures almost everywhere and when weak, minority governments are the rule rather than the exception throughout the Western world, the signifiance of the decisive outcome in Canada's general election can hardly be exaggerated.

title: OTB Return On Decline With Surtax
description: OTB revenue to the city, state and racetracks declined by $473,000 during the first week of the new 5 per cent surtax on winning payoffs, the president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation said yesterday.

title: Giants Post Signs; Scene Is Low Key
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 9 Charlie Evans hoisted the white picket signEnd Commissioner Dictatorship in front of the brown station wagon as it maneuvered through the Barlow Road entrance gate to Fairfield University today.

title: Levitt Links Recidivism to Poor PrisonAid Programs
description: A State Controller's study has found serious deficiencies in the state's prisonerrehabilitation programs and has identified the failures as a factor in growing criminal recidivism.

title: Market Closes Steady; Dow Industrials Up 1.72
description: The stock market engaged in aholding action yesterday, going nowhere on a volume of 15580,000 shares, compared with 15,510,000 shares on Monday.

title: White House Aide Criticizes A.T.&T.
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The Nixon Administration criticized the American Telephone and Telegraph Company today, for using its power to persuade the Government to extend its monopoly in communications.

title: Conference Over Busing
description: The one question now holdi\ng up conference agreement on this year's extension of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act is, substantively, the least important question of allbut, emotionally, the most acute: the question of busing.

title: City Zoning. Plan Aims to Keep Rural Spots
description: In an attempt to preserve what is left of country greenery in New York City, the Planning Commission yesterday proposed a new zoning concept, the Special Natural Area District, and moved to designate the Staten Island greenbelt as the first such protected area.

title: U.M.W. Backs Strict Strip Mining Curb
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The new, reformoriented leadership of the United Mine Workers union resolved a prolonged internal struggle today by announcing its support of the stronger of two Federal bills to control strip mining scheduled for a vote next week in the House.

title: Inquiry Blames Yachtsman In Drowning of 2 in Crew,
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) The Coast Guard commandant today recommended the prosecution of a Connecticut yachtsman who allowed two crewmen to jump into frigid waters off the coast of New Jersey while keeping his dog on a small skiff after their schooner had capsized. The two crewmen drowned.

title: Highs and Lows
description: New York Stock Exchange

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN LEGEND (U.S. Lines), Havre July 22, Rotterdam 23 and Felixstowe 25; sails from Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Red Smith A Filly Who Can Teach Arithmetic
description: It started with a Labrador retriever named Champ. He belonged to Dr. and Mrs. Kenneth M. Mazik; and he had a way with the deeply disturbed children in Au Clair School, which the Maziks operate at St. Georges, Del. The response Champ could bring from these withdrawn, sometimes hostile kids led Dr. Mazik to put the children to work with animals in the hope of finding an area of vocation for the older boys. Poultry are big in the country around St. Georges, near the top of the Delmarva Peninsula that is the Eastern Shore of Delaware, Maryland and Virginia, so Au Clair School went into raising turkeys. The turks turned out to cost us $3.95 a pound, Dr. Mazik said the other day. There was no way a private school could afford that. We're in the heart of horse country here. At our farm near Middletown we have horses like Kelso and Northern Dancer as neighbors. We needed something more tractable than thoroughbreds, though, so we claimed a 9yearold pacer named Tugfire.

title: LAOS PREMIER SAYS HANOI UNITS MUST GO
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 9 (UPI)The Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, said today that he had told North Vietnam that North Vietnamese troops still in Laos must leave under the peace agreement that ended the Laotian war.

title: Percentage Gains
description: Stocks with the largest percentage gains on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Na 3 Post for Rich Trot Helps Make Delmonica Hanover Pick
description: Asparagus tips were on the menu, but the most Inescapable tip at the UnitedNations yesterday was a horse named Delmonica Hanover.

title: MIMING POOLS UNDERSTUDY HERE
description: Potential swimmingpool buyers are faced with a massive illicit market peddling junk merchandise at grossly exaggerated prices, according to a spokesman for the National Swimming Pool Institute.

title: French Report Two Bombs, Not One, in Weekend Tests
description: PAPEETE, Tahiti, July 9 (UPI)France exploded two nuclear weapons at her South Pacific testing ground over the weekend, not one as reported by Australia and New Zealand, French military sources said today.

title: Ethiopian Cabinet Gets Army Guidelines
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 9 (UPI)The army issued a set of guidelines tonight for the future government, retaining Haile Selassie as Emperor, but with reduced powers, and giving the military a major role in important Cabinet decisions.

title: CABINET IN LISBON FALLS AS 5 RESIGN
description: LISBON, July 9  Portugal's first effort at civilian government since the revolution in April collapsed tonight with the resignation of Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos and four of his middleoftheroad nnnisters.

title: Earl Warren Is Dead in Capital at 83
description: Former Chief Justice Warren Dead in Capital at 83 General, Governor and Chief Justice spans one of the most dynamic eras in our history and his contribution was large indeed.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: For Belfast Children, a Summer of Tranquillity in Minnesota
description: BREWSTER, Minn.The guns won't boom for 11yearold Lawrence McGlade in the next five weeks. He won't have to be rousted out of bed at midnight because of a bomb in his apartment building, and he needn't worry about getting caught in a crossfire of bullets whenever he steps outofdoors.

title: Peacemaker Shot In Attempt to Halt Clash in Brooklyn
description: Next time I'll probably stop and think twice, Raul Cubero told a visitor yesterday as he sat in a wheelchair in the intensivecare unit of Brooklyn Hospital, where he is recuperating from a gunshot wound in the stomach. I guess you learn from experience.

title: PRICES ON AMEX CONTINUE TO DROP
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to decline yesterday but the gap between the number of those declining and those advancing narrowed somewhat compared with the day before as volume dipped slightly. The closing price, however, was the lowest since July 7, 1970 when it was 74.60 Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Israel's Raid Is Regarded as a Restrained Retaliation
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 9Israel's latest raid on fishing ports in southern Lebanon was regarded here as restrained in comparison with the threats of violent reprisal issued by Israeli officials after a Palestinian guerrilla raid from the sea on the beach resort of Nahariya two weeks ago.

title: Haldeman Asks Million for Book About His Years in White House
description: H. R. Haldeman, President Nixon's former chief of staff, is seeking $1million through an agent for rights to a book he is writing about his years in the White House.

title: U.S. Attorney Staff Invited to Challenge A Residency Rule
description: David G. Trager, the New United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, has given the assistants in his office who live outside the district an Oct. 1 deadline to move into it, but at the same time has urged them to question the constitutionality of the district's residency requirement.

title: LIBRARIANS FOCUS ON ETHNIC STUDIES
description: Jambo, jambo, jambo, intoned Evelyn Jones Rich, a courteous Afrinanist, bidding her listeners good day in Swahili.

title: Woman Dies in Fall Here
description: A young woman plunged to her death yesterday from atop the CBS Building in midtown Manhattan, the police said. Detectives were looking for anyone who saw the 20yearold woman fall from the building, at 53d Street and the Avenue of Americas, about 6 P.M:

title: Bridge: LI
description: The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League beginning here Friday at the New York Hilton and Americana Hotels are virtually sure to be the biggest tournament ever played anywhere. The record of 16,043 tables set last year in Washington is expected to be broken by at least 1,000 tables.

title: DIFFERENCES CITED IN PANEL VERSION OF 8 NIXON TAPES
description: WASHINGTON, July 9The House Judiciary Committee released today eight transcripts its staff had prepared of President Nixon's Watergate conversations, and committee members of both parties said that the marked differences from: the edited transcripts made public by the White House could damage President Nixon's case in the impeachment inquiry.

title: St. Clair Denies Knowing If Nixon Would Defy Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 President Nixon's chief defense lawyer, James D. St. Clair, said today that he did not know whether the President would obey a Supreme Court order to turn over subpoenaed White House tapes.

title: Byrne, Visiting Shore, Studies Erosion
description: OCEAN CITY, July 9Governor Byrne, in a pink summer suit and tieless in the broiling afternoon sun, took a boat tour of Cape May County inlets and beaches today.

title: CIVILIAN MINISTERS DISMISSED IN BOLIVIA
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 9 (Reuters)President Hugo Banzer Suarez has swept civilian policians out of his Cabinet and promised a return to constitutional rule next year.

title: Cancer and Diabetes Bills Pass House, Go to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Compromise bills authorizing threeyear programs of almost $2.8billion to fight cancer and $41million to help battle diabetes were passed by the House today and sent to the Senate.

title: COWLING ON DC10 DISABLES ENGINE
description: The National Transportation Safety Board disclosed yesterday that a National Airlines DCI0 suffered dangerous damage Monday when cowling tore from the left engine, smashed into the wing and knocked out the rear engine.

title: Alfred B. Leech, 56, Dies; Executive of AllisChalmers
description: MILWAUKEE, July 9 (UPI)Alfred B. Leech, public relations manager for AlliiChalmers and a former editor of Newsweek magazine and former reporter for United Press International, died Sunday. He was 56 years old.

title: NANCY NEWHALL, PHOTO CRITIC, 66
description: Nancy Newhall, a noted photography critic, conservationist and editor of many works by America's bestknown photographers, died Sunday at St. John's Hospitat in Jackson, Wyo., the result of injuries she received in a boating acciant on June 9. She was 86 years old.

title: Police Officer's Conviction On Drug Charge Reversed
description: The Appellate Division, citing trial errors by Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh, yesterday ordered a new trial for a former city police officer convicted on an indictment brought by Maurice H. Nadjari, the special state prosecutor.

title: Samuels Gains the Endorsement of Albany Sheriff
description: ALBANY, July 9Howard J. Samuels, the designated DemoTrade candidate for Governor, was endorsed today by the Albany County sheriff, John J. McNulty Jr., one of the few Democrats with a political power base in this area who is not loyal to the Albany County Democratic machine led by Daniel T. O'Connell.

title: Comparisons Between Passages in the White House and Committee Transcripts
description: FOREWORD Comparisons: White House Aides Discuss What Dean Calls 'The Self Protection' Comparisons: Nixon Tells Mitchell Everyone Should 'Stonewall It' to 'Save the Plan' Comparison: No Decision

title: Ehrlichman and 3 Others Conclude Their Defense
description: WASHINGTON, July 9John D. Ehrlichman completed today more than seven hours on the witness stand, repeating his denials that he knew in advance of the breakin at the office of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: EURODOLLAR PLAN 1S STUDIED BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (Reuters)The Administration is studying a proposal that would help to broaden the equitycapital base of banks participating in the Eurodollar market, aid in recycling Arab oil revenues and give United States banks a more competitive footing in the Euromarkets.

title: U.S. Phone Line Is Due For Runaway Children
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI)The Government said today that it would establish a nationwide tollfree telephone line on which the estimated one million American children who run away from home each year will be able to pass messages onto their parents without disclosing where they have gone.

title: G.E. eports Highs for Sales and Net
description: The General Electric Company improved on its recordbreaking firstquarter pace through the first six months. The giant electrical manufacturer reported yesterday new highs in sales and earnings for both the second quarter and finst half.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP)Lancy Smith, medalist in the qualifying round, advanced to the second round of match play in the Women's Western Golf Association amateur championship today by defeating Pain Palmieri of Santa Rosa, Calif., 5 and 3.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: Money

title: Dockers Here Win Guaranteed Salary Of $16,640 a Year
description: Labor and management in the port's longshore industry reached agreement yesterday on a new threeyear contract, which includes a guaranteed annual income of $16,640 in the pact's final year.

title: For 16 Years, Warren Saw the Constitution as Protector of Rights and Equality
description: Presiding over the Supreme Court for 16 yearsfrom 1953 to 1969Earl Warren championed the Constitution as the vigorous protector of the individual rights and the equality of all Americans.

title: Classes on Sex Education Won't Be Coed, H.E.W. Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary ofHealth, Education and Welfare, says he is amending proposed Federal regulations against sex discrimination to allow separation of boys and girls in sex education classes.

title: Nader Suit Asks Cut In Ceiling Price for Oil
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 Ralph Nader and an associate, Carl E. Nash, asked the Federal District Court here today to roll back the average ceiling price on controlled crude oil from the present $5.25 a barrel to $4.25, its level last Dec. 19 when the Administration authorized a $1 increase.

title: State Acts Against 2 Services Making Abortion Referrals
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday that the state had acted against two abortion referral agericies that had been accused of using bait advertising and of charging fees for abortion referrals, which is specifically forbidden by state law.

title: TeenAger Takes Syce Cup Sailing
description: NORTHPORT, L.I., July 9 Jody Taffet, a 19yearold sophomore at Potsdam State Teachers College, today won the Syce Cup, emblematic of the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association women's sailing championship.

title: Bennett Calls Price Impact Damaging
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 The new Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs warned the oilproducing countries today that any cutback in production levels in an effort to hold up prices would be counterproductive.

title: Rookie Who Beat Perry Touted
description: OAKLAND, July 9Gaylord Perry's winning streak is over, and in the long run the player who ended it may become the better remembered of the two.

title: Ground Is Broken For the Mee s Wing Of American Art
description: A silver spade full of earth was languidly turned over by Mayor Beame in an open courtyard of the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday and construction of the new American Bicentennial Wing was under way.

title: Henley Sits Unmoved as Texas Outlines Its Case
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 9 Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. sat unmoved in a crowded room today as the state built up its case of homosexual lure and multiple murder against him.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RIDGEWOOD, July 9That old saw, Those who can, do; those who can't, teach, doesn't apply to Tony Fusco, the personable professional at the Upper Ridgewood Tennis Club.

title: Films
description: SUMMER FILM FESTIVAL FOR CHILDREN at 2 P.M. every Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday through Aug. 29 at Gimbels East, 86th Street and Lexington Avenue, Community Room, 11th floor. Program includes famous clasics and musicals. For information, call 348.2300, extension 277 or 276.

title: JOHN BROGAN, 81, OF KING FEATURES
description: John A. Brogan, who played a major role in building King Features Syndicate into the world's largest featuredistributing organization, died Monday evening in Nassau, the Bahamas.

title: SWIMMING POOLS UNDER STUDY HERE
description: Potential swimmingpool buyers are faced with a massive illicit market peddling junk merchandise at grossly exaggerated prices, according to a spokesman for the National Swimming Pool Institute.

title: Events Today
description: THE TEMPEST, a Play by William Shakespeare, directed by Garland Wright, at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street, 8.

title: Imperiled O.E.O. Rescued Till October
description: Like the Imperiled Pauline of the silent screen serials, they; beleaguered Federal Office of Economic Opportunity once, again has been snatched just in time from disaster.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York City Council yesterday approved a bill banning smoking in passenger elevators, but voted to raise the permissible sound level for automobile horns.

title: Carter Asked to Run
description: ATLANTA, July (AP)Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia has been asked to consider entering the New Hampshire Democratic primary in the 1976 Presidential elections, an aide said today. He has been asked to consider the race by persons in the South as well as other parts of the country, said Jody Powell, the Governor's press secretary.

title: Alcoa Plans to Raise Primary Ingot Prices
description: The Aluminum Company of America announced yesterday that it would increase the price of unalloyed 99.5 per cent primary aluminum ingot 2.5 cents a pound to 36 cents, beginning with shipments Aug. 2.

title: A 2d Group Wants Liner United States For a Floating Fair
description: A second group unveiled its bid yesterday for the laidup liner United States to use her as a floating bicentennial exposition and trade fair.

title: Smoking Ban Voted Here For Passenger Elevators
description: The City Council yesterday approved a bill banning smoking in passenger elevators, but another enbnmental mattersound pollutionwas set back when the Council voted to raise the level of automobile horns.

title: LAID TO AGNEW UNIT
description: The Justice Department studying a series of apparent violations of campaign laws in 1972 and 1973 by the Americans for Agnew Committee.

title: Burns, on a 214, Takes Ike Golf; Bostwick Is 2d
description: EAST WILLISTON, Li., July 9  George Burns of Port Washington, L.I., has done lust about everything an amateur golfer can do in the New York metropolitan area. When he took the 22d annual Ike tournament by a twostroke margin at Wheatley Hills Golf Club today, he won his fifth major amateur tournament in the area.

title: Nuclear Fallout in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., July (UPI)The Alabama Department of Public Health said that radiation fallout from Chinese and French nuclear weapon testing has been detected in the state. The department said the fallouts did not pose a significant threat to the public health.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A mailorder concern specializing in postersize enlargements of photographs has been ordered to speed its service and to make restitution to customers who demanded refunds after delays in service. Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said that the concern BY'U Inc., also known as Congers Color Labs and Blow Yourself Up, Co., of Congers, N.Y., had failed to aeliver their products in reasonable time even when the consumer paid an extra charge for superspeed service. The concern and its president, Raymond M. Mohr, consented to a judgment State Supreme Court here, signed by Justice Sidney H. Asch. It was ordered to deposit $3,500 in security with the Attorney General for two years while full restitution is made.

title: World Football League Kicks Off Season Tonight
description: The dye on the footballs may still be wet and the players may not he able to keep dry in the stifling heat, but the World Football League brings midweek, midsummer football to the nation's sports life tonight.

title: Pesticides Blamed For Death of Geese In Long Island Pond
description: A dozen Canada geese from a flock of 35 to 40 that had made their home in a pond on the grounds of the Sperry Gyroscope Company in Lake Success, L. I., suddenly became ill and died yesterday morning after the area was sprayed with insecticides.

title: Trial of 5 Refugees Accused In Kidnapping of Boy Begins
description: NEWARK, July 9  Twelve jurors and six alternates were selected today as five Cuban refugees went on trial in the kidnapping of 8yearold John Calzadilla from a street near his home in Dix Hills, Li., last March 6.

title: U.S. Tries to Avoid Showdown With Turks on Poppies
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Nixon Administration officials said today that they were seeking a formula to avoid a serious confrontation with Turkey over the Turks decision to resume cultivation of opium poppies, the source of most of the illegal heroin sold in the United States until production was forbidden in 1971.

title: Sirica Refuses to Dismiss Watergate CoverUp Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 9Judge John J. Sirica denied today wide series of defense motions for dismissal, for separate trials, for moving the proceedings out of Washington and for delaying the start of the Watergate coverup conspiracy case.

title: 2 Killed as Balloon Falls
description: TAVARES, Fla., July 9 (UN) Two men were killed this afternoon when the hot air balloon they were test flying lost its air and plunged 500 feet into an orange grove about eight miles southeast of here. The victims were identified as Fred Edward, 29 years old, owner of the balloon, and Jimmy Wayne Hall, 33, both of Casselberry.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was: 473993

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
description: (Prices in 32d of a point, composite bill yields In basis points.)

title: Westchester Panel Approves WasteDisposal Plan for County
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 9A proposal to handle Westchester County's worsening garbagedisposal on a countywide basis was approved unanimously tonight by a committee of the Board of Legislators, indicating quick approval by the full body and early implementation.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The State Energy Office aske the Fedeml Government to increase gasoline allocations for the four shore counties of Atlantic, Cape May, Monmouth and Ocean during the peak tourist months of July and August. G. Gordon M. Large, acting administrator of the office, said: After viewing data on traffic patterns, growth in the area, the high incidence of gasstation closings and several other factors, our office has concluded that the Shore area may experience greatly increased demand for gasoline in the coming weeks.

title: Kissinger, in Spain, Initials Statement of Cooperation
description: MADRID, July 9On the last stop of his European tour, Secretary of State Kissinger today initialed a new declaration of military cooperation between Spain and the United States.

title: ITALIANS STRIKING TO PROTEST TAXES
description: ROME, July 9Italy's powerful labor front started a series of strikes today to protest against the new taxes that the Government decreed Saturday in an austerity effort aimed at staving off national bankruptcy.

title: Ripples in Court
description: The tempting fallacy is to anticipate that the Supreme Court will now finally decide Watergate, once and for all. Increasingly skittish Congressmen look across the Capitol lawn to the Court for rescue from politically perilous decisions. An exasperated electorate longs for it all to end, sensitivity to public right and wrong dulled by the charges, countercharges, the ambiguities real and contrived. However deeply desired, Watergate cannot simply be made to go away.

title: Climbing Interest Rates
description: How to cure Wall Street's acute case of the jitters? There is no shortage of remedies being offered by both private and public confidence healers. The need was particularly great early this week when the Central National Bank of Cleveland raised its prime interest charge to its most creditworthy corporate borrowers to 12 per cent, and most major banks moved up to 12 per cent. The stock market, reciprocally, plunged.

title: Symbols and Courts
description: WASHINGTON, July 9On the way to Watergate trials on Pennsylvania Avenue and to the House and Senate on Capitol Hill these steaming July days, it is hard to avoid the contrast between the enduring symbols and ideals of the Republic and the petty maneuverings of the contemporary politicians.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: VOICES FROM ABROAD Well, not exactly too far abroad. But the Newark Boys Chorus has been gathering esteem for each of its eight years of existence, with enormously wellreceived world tours, including a special concert last year before Pope Paul VI at the Vatican. Today it's crossing the Hudson River for a free concert downtown.

title: Nettles Grand Slam Paces Yank Victory
description: KANSAS CITY, July 9Having just completed an explosive fourgame stand in Texas where they staged a 59hit, 37ran bombardment, the Yankees opened their threegame visit with the Royals tonight by detonating a sixrun, firstinning rally.

title: Javits Feels Nixon Issue Affects World's Economy
description: Senator Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that there would be a very positive effect on the world's economy if President Nixon stepped down. But he added that the same effect might be obtained if Congress acted quickly on the question of impeachment.

title: Spoleto Fete Ends With Future in Doubt
description: cannot envisage the festival's continuance. Mr. Valli also has announced in conjunction with Mr. Menotti, that even if the continuance of the festival is assured, its entire structure must be restudied.

title: Leon Shamroy Dies at 72; Cameraman Won 4 Oscars
description: Leon Shamroy, who won the Academy, Award for cinematography four times, died Saturday in the Motion Picture and Television Country Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: Dr. A. L. Loomis Bell
description: Dr. A. L. Loomis Bell, a radiologist who had practiced in Brooklyn until two months ago, died Monday at Bridsboro, Pa., at the age of 84.

title: Advertising: New Wyse Impetus
description: Wyse Advertising of Cleveland opened an outpost here about seven years ago in hopes of siphoning off some of the millions and millions of dollars from the national advertising budgets that are controlled from New York.

title: Company Agrees to Pay In Good Samaritan Death
description: The Liberty Mutual Insurance Company announced yesterday that it would pay death benefits to the family of a man who was shot to death last October as he pursued a berserk gunman.

title: U.S. Nuclear Test Today
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 10 (UPI)  The Atomic Energy Commission announced yesterday that an underground nuclear test, with a yield of 20 to 200 kilotonsan explosive force equal to 20,000 to 200,000 tons of TNT  has been scheduled for 9 A.M., Pacific daylight time, tomorrow at the Nevada test site.

title: CITY ACTS TO BAR TUINEL STOPPAGE
description: Over the objection of Paul O'Dwyer, President of the City Council, the Board of Estimate yesterday approved a $5million payment to prevent a halt in work on the 14milelong water tunnel being built from the Hillview Reservoir in Westchester County to Astoria, Queens.

title: Schmidt and Giscard Will Seek Closer Common Market by 80
description: BONN, July 9Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France ended two days of talks today, and the West German leader said they had achieved farreaching agreements on the major problems facing Western Europe's Common Market.

title: Title Shoot Opens Today
description: CHARDON, Ohio, July 9 (UPI)  The 14th annual United States international shooting championship opens here tomorrow with more than 400 competitors from across the nation expected at the ClevelandWinchester Gun Club. Tryouts will also be held for 14 spots on the 50member United States team that will compete this September in the 41st world shooting championships in Switzerland.

title: 300,000 in US. Have Phlebitis, Affliction of Nixon and Franco
description: WASHINGTON, July 9By, the latest government estimate more than 290,000 Americans have something painful in common with President Nixon and Generalissimo Francisco Franco phlebitis.

title: 8 of 13 Escaped Convicts Rounded Up in Tennessee
description: NASHVILLE, July 9 (UPI)The police today rounded up all but five of 13 Tennessee State Penitentiary convicts who stole a prison bus and sped to freedom while guards fired at them with shotguns and pistols.

title: Naval Academy Expels 7 for Cheating
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 9Seven United States Naval Academy midshipmen have been expelled for cheating, and 13 have been placed on probation as the result of a scandal that began seven weeks ago with the leaking of questions on a final examination.

title: 74 LOSS POSSIBLE AS VW SALES DROP
description: WOLFSBURG, West Germany, July 9 (AP)  Worldwide sales of the Volkswagen group in the first half of 1974 declined 17.5 per cent from the 1973 period, Rudolf Leiding, chairman, said today, to 1.02 million vehicles.

title: U.S.toEurope Air Fares To Rise 5th Time This Year
description: International airlines tentatively approved yesterday the fifth increase in United StatesEurope air fares of the year, but cushioned effects on some travelers by voting a new early bird discount plan for those who buy tickets at least 60 days before a trip at a time when airlines are experiencing the worst slump in transAtlantic travel since the jet age began more than 15 years ago. Summer peakseason travel is running 10 to 15 per cent below last year Higher fares, coupled with in

title: Capra Tops Poll
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP)Buzz Capra, the Atlanta Braves righthander whose 60 wonlost record last month included four complete games, three shutouts and an earnedrun average of 1.04, was voted yesterday the National League's player of the month for June.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and lode; Page 39

title: Nixon Says Eisenhower Should Have Kept Adams
description: WASHINGTON, July 9President Nixon was critical of President Eisenhower's handling of a scandal during his Administration that led to the dismissal of his chief of staff.

title: Patriarca Bail Opposed
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July (AP)  The state Attorney General's office urged the Rhode Island Supreme Court today to reject a request from Raymond L. S. Patriarca for release on bail. Mr. Patriarca, once identified as head of organized crime in New England, has asked to be released pending an October hearing.

title: Volcker's Successor Takes TOugh Job
description: WASHINGTON, July 9One of the toughest jobs in the United States Government was taken on today by a quiet, unassuming man who has not been much in the public eye.

title: Olivares Stops Utagawa For Featherweight Title
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 9 (UPI)Hardhitting Ruben Olivares of Mexico City became the first former bantamweight champion in 34 years to win the featherweight title tonight by stopping Zensuke Utagawa of Japan in the seventh round of their scheduled 15round World Boxing Association championship bout.

title: Listing of Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Open Interest Cash Prices

title: Bridge
description: The world's biggest team championship reaches its climax at the New York Hilton Hotel during the next three days, and serves as a curtain raiser to the world's biggest tournament. Some 5,000 teams entered in the Grand National team tournament during the last nine months, and they are now reduced to eight by qualifying contests at local and zonal level.

title: Fuji and Rockwell in Deal
description: TOKYO, July 10 (AP)Fuji Heavy Industries, Ltd., said today it and the Rockwell International Corporation had signed an agreement under which the two companies would jointly develop a twin engine business plane.

title: JUNE RETAlLSALES FELL 1% FROM MAY
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Retail sales declined about per cent in June from a May level that had been revised upward, preliminary Commerce Department figures disclosed today.

title: Home of Brooklyn Woman Looted of $43,300 and Dog
description: Burglars broke into the Brooklyn home of Maria Chaviano during the afternoon yesterday and escaped with $43,300 in jewelry, cash and clothing in addition to her pet Yorkshire terrier, the police reported.

title: Market Place Few Are Calling For Avon Stock
description: Avon Products once among the most glamorous stocks, reeled yesterday in the midst of rumors about its earnings results for the quarter just ended, and a Chicagobased banking firm reportedly rated, the stock a sell. Avon dropped 5 points to 36, its lowest level since 1966. The turnover of 123,500 shares put Avon in sixth, place on the active list.

title: REPORT QiiESTIONS BOZO'S ACCOUNT ON HUGHES FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The staff of the Senate Watergate committee disclosed today what it described as additional information to support the charge that Charles G. Rebozo gave or lent part of a $100,000 campaign contribution to President Nixon's personal secretary and his two younger brothers.

title: Nixon Briefs Congress Leaders on Soviet Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)  President Nixon apparently convinced Congressional leaders today that his recent visit to the Soviet Union was successful even though he acknowledged that the arms control agreements reached with the Russians were rather minuscule.

title: Earl Warren
description: As Chief Justice of the United States, Earl Warren emerged as a compelling embodiment of cherished American virtues. The combination of the Chief Justice's character and the decisions of the Court over which he presideddespite deep and bitter criticism of some of those decisionsmade him, both at home and around the globe, the symbol of basic decency and unyielding integrity.

title: Cape Verde Isn't Sure It Wants Independence
description: PRAIA, Cape Verde Islands, July 5A stirring, for independence has been shaking Portuguese Africa since the coup in Lisbon last April 18.

title: Planning Body Rejects Bid To Convert Kimberly Hotel
description: The City Planning Commission refused yesterday to approve the conversion into a home for the elderly of the Kimberly Hotel, a former singleroomoccupancy hotel that the police said was a gathering place for criminals.

title: MOVIE AD CALLED SLUR ON HARLEM
description: Hi, this is Bill Cosby. Remember the good old days when you used to go uptown to Harlem and have a good time  before it became very, very dangerous. Well, you can still go uptown without gettin your head beat in, by going downtown to see Uptown Saturday Night. This way the people are all on the screen and won't jump off and clean your head out.

title: House Votes to Publish impeaehlhent Hearings
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)The House voted authority today for publication of 20,000 sets of its Judiciary Committee, impeachment inquiry hearings and proceedings and 50,000 copies of the final report.

title: Bergey Sent By Bengals To Eagles
description: CINCINNATI, July 10 (AP)  Bill Bergey, free of a World Football League commitment, was traded within the National Football League today, going from the Cincinnati Bengals to the Philadelphia Eagles for three future draft choices.

title: 230Year Border. Fight Settled By Maine and New Hampshire
description: CONCORD, N. H., July 10The governments of Maine and New Hampshire placed their stamp of approval today on a negotiated settlement of a maritime border dispute dating to 1740.

title: Woman Dies in Fall Here
description: A young woman pluneed to her death Tuesday froM atop the CBS Building in midtown Manhattan, the police said. Detectives were looking for any; one Who saw the 20yearold Woman fall from the building, at 53d Street and the Avenue of Americas about 6 P.M.

title: Songs and a New Comedian Make Lively Cabaret
description: Have you been thinking more and enjoying less lately? Tired of cerebration and eager for celebration? If sanssouci is your goal, the place for you is the Little Hippodrome, the theater restaurant at 227 East 56th Street.

title: After Delay, Prisoner Gets Furlough to Be Wed
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 10 (AP)A convicted murderer and his fiancee picked up a marriage license at City Hall here today, a few hours after the man had been furloughed from a state prison for 12 hours.

title: PLOT TO KILL POLICE BRINGS LONG TERM
description: Robert Hayes, a reputed member of the socalled Black Liberation Army, has received five prison sentences of 35 years to life for the attempted murder of five police officers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: An Israeli commission of inquiry op the Maalot incident in which 20 Israeli students were killed has found that copies of letters in Hebrew from Arab gunmen were not relayed by Israeli officials to the Cabinet in Jerusalem. The commission said the precise terms would have aided the Government in deciding earlier on its options. [1:12.]

title: Phils Cash Pays Dividends As Marshall Fails to Save
description: Mike Marshall, the Dodgers ace relief pitcher, is working toward his doctorate at Michigan State University during the off season. His specialty is kinesiology.

title: Warren Rites Slated Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The body of Earl Warren, the former Chief Justice of the United States, who died last night at the age of 83, will lie in state tomorrow and Friday outside the courtroom in the Supreme Court building in which he presided for 16 years.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday told rate bureaus representing the nation's big overtheroad truckers that they are free to increase their rates on days notice by 8 to 11 per cent.

title: Mrs. Mary Liebhaf sky Wed to Paul Rooney
description: Mrs. Mary LaRosa Liebhafsky and Paul Kevin Rooney were married here last evening at the St. RegisSheraton by State Supreme Court Justice Ernst Rosenberger.

title: Giants Will Use Rookies, If Necessary, Mara Says
description: The New York Giants will operate this season even if they have to use rookies or hold a tryout camp to recruit players, Wellington Mara, the club president, said today.

title: FRED A. DOWD
description: CINCINNATI, July 10Fred A. Dowd, president of the First National Bank from 1955 until 1971, died last night. He was 69 years old and lived here.

title: Democratic Lawyer Seeks To GOvern Virgin Islands
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, St. Thomas, V. I., July 10 (UPI) Alexander Farrelly, a lawyer, won the Democratic nomination for Governor of the Virgin Islands yesterday.

title: Miss Krupsak Tours Brooklyn; Samuels Is Due to Back Cuomo
description: State Senator Mary Anne Krupsak proved during a strenuous tour of Brooklyn yesterday that her name was not household word in the state's most populous county but that she probably would get many votes for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor because she is a woman.

title: Cabin Cruiser Agrounci,
description: A 25foot cabin cruiser ran aground on Liberty Island yeSterday afternoon, and all persons on board were evacuated after the boat began taking on water, the Coast Guard reported, No injuries were reported.

title: FUEL OIL CONCERN BACKS SALES PLAN; STATE DROPS SUIT
description: The Asiatic Petroleum Corpo ration, accused by the state of having withheld homeheating oil from the market last summer and selling it at exorbitant prices in the winter, agreed in court yesterday to sell specified amounts here this summer and next, when such fuel is cheaper.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Padres Defeat Mets; Winfield Clouts Two
description: Ordinarily, two pitches don't decide an SI game. However, the first two pitches Jerry N.00smari threw to Dave Winfield were very decisive in San Diego's victory over the Mets yesterday before a paying crowd of 16,962 and 10,090 Midget Mets at Shea Stadium.

title: Thyssen Will Pay $27 a Share For Indian Head Common Stock
description: The Thyssen Bornemisza Group of the Netherlands will pay $27 a share fdr the out standing common stock of Indian Head, Inc., it was announced yesterday. ThyssenBornemisza already owns a total of 1.95 million shares of Indian Head, or 34 per cent of the total of 5.8 million shares outstanding.

title: FRANKLIN PRESIDENT MEETS WITH PATHAN
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (Reuters)The new president of the Franklin National Bank met today with the chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, Representative Wright Patman, of Texas, who hinted that the troubled New York bank might be merged with an outofstate institution.

title: SIMON AND BURNS IN WRISTON TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Walter B. Wriston, the chairman of the First National City Bank and its parent holding company, Citicorp, conferred today with Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon and with Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Corcoran BellRinger in W.F.L. Opener
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 10On an evening that was more conducive to a plunge into a swimming pool or a seat in front of an air conditioner, an enthusiastic crowd of 55,534 watched the Philadelphia Bell score four 7point touchdowns and crush the Portland Storm. 335, tonight in one of five opening World Football League games.

title: TV: The Sinners, 13 Irish Vignettes
description: As public television fusses with market projects, subscriber campaigns and foundation / corporate  support game plans, some stations are going about the more immediate  problem of finding some fresh programing for the present. The.Eastern Educational Network has gone to England's Granada Television and cleverly acquired a series of 13 hour  long plays adapted from Irish short stories. Collectively titled The Sinners, the plays begin their weekly run on Chan nel 13 tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: Businessmen Assert Watergate Hinders Nixon's Economic Role
description: By an overwhelming margin, leaders of American business say that the Watergate affair has seriously affected President Nixon's ability to manage the nation's business and economic affairs, according to a survey by The New York Times.

title: Annapolis Boatyard Slides Into History
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., July 10Trumpy's, the boat yard where 400 luxuriously handmade versions of the RollsRoyce of American motor yachts were built earlier in this century for millionaire owners named Armour, Baruch, du Pont, Firestone and Whitney, slid down history's ways into oblivion Monday, the victim of plastic technology, the cost of craftsmanship and the highrise condominium building boom.

title: Seoul Asks Death For Poet, 6 Others On Plotting Charge
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 10 (AP)The prosecution has demanded death penalties for the Korean poet Kim Chi Ha and six other persons on trial on charges of attempting to overthrow the Government of President Chung Hee Park.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The office that overseas the administration o the New York State courts modified its procedures to make judges responsible for filing reports of fees paid to lawyers and other guardians appointed by the court.

title: Sentencing of Legal Aid Lawyer Delays Cases in 12 Courtrooms
description: Proceedings were interrupted yesterday in 12 Manhattan Criminal Courtrooms when Legal Aid Society lawyers attented the sentencing of a colleague for criminal contempt and were not on hand when their clients were called for arraignment and hearings.

title: GRAND JURY BEGINS HOMESTAKE INQUIRY
description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 (UPI) A Federal grand jury began an investigation of possible criminal fraud in the operations of the HomeStake Production Company, whose investors included well  known entertainment and business figures.

title: Music: By Way of France
description: Since the time of Franck, if not before, France has always had a goodly supply of distinguished organistcomposers working in the great old churches of Paris. Franck, Widor, Vierne, Dupre, Langlais, Messaien  the quality and strength of the music they and their colleagues produced has varied greatly, but every time a new link has been required to keep the chain that has been supplied from breaking.

title: Girl Tells Jury She Got $2,000 Offer To Help in Kidnapping Long Island Boy
description: NEWARK, July 10  A 17yearold girl, the key witness for the prosecution, testified in Federal District Court today that she had been offered $2,000 for her part in the kidnapping of 8yearold John Calzadilla, who was seized March 6 for a $50,000 ransom.

title: Open jump Is Captured By Balbuco
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 10  Mr. and Mrs. Patrick Butler's Balbuco, a mount that has won major events all over North America, captured the featured open jumper class today at the Lake Placid Horse Show.

title: AllStar Football Off
description: The College AllStar game, traditional opener of the National Football League exhi bition season, was canceled yesterday for the first time in its 41year history. Sponsors of the charity game attributed the decision in large part to the N.F.L. players strike. Page 21.

title: Theft and Drug Counts Charged to 3 Firemen
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 10 (UPI)  Three Atlantic City firemen, including a fire captain, were suspended today following their indictments on charges ranging from possession of drugs to theft of money from the scenes of fires.

title: `The Cure in Italy: Strict Diet, Plus That Funny Tasting Water
description: MONTECATINI TERME, ItalyWhen we were very young (and very, very poor), we used to read the novels of authors such as Henry James and Edith Wharton and it seemed to us that their characters were forever rushing off to Europe to drink the waters and take the cure and it sounded rousingly sophisticated, worldly and romantic. We decided that spas were places for important people who were eternally engaged either in hopeless love affairs, international it trigue or contemplating suicide.

title: Woman Dies in Bus Mishap
description: MOUNT McKINLEY, Alaska, July 10 (UPI)A Pennsylvania woman was killed and 26 others injured yesterday when a sightseeing bus in Mount McKinley National Park overturned. The dead woman was identified as Katherine McFadde, 69 years old, of McKeesport, Pa.

title: Artificial Reef for Beach Sought by Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 10Officials of this South Jersey resort believe they have found an inexpensive solution to beach erosion: an offshore artificial reef of sandfilled nylon bags designed to keep sand from washing out to sea.

title: Exchange Firms Losses in May Cut to Half of the April Deficit
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that its 434 member firms lost $21.6million in May, less than half their April losses of $47.8milnon and below the loss of $37.8million in May, 1973.

title: U. S. PROSECUTORS UNDER AN INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department, acting upon the suggestion of Federal Judge Orrin Judd, is considering the possibility of disciplinary action against Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn for conduct allegedly suggesting that they could control sentencing.

title: The CoConspirator
description: The House Judiciary Committee's versions of the White House tapes add up to a devastating indictment of President Nixon. They make it unmistakably clear why the Watergate grand jury initially wanted to indict him along with his close associates for conspiracy to obstruct justice and finally insisted at least on naming him as a coconspirator.

title: Ronson Rebuffs Liquifin and Votes to Keep Own Management
description: Shareholders of the Ronson Corporation, the nation's largest manufacturer of tobacco lighters, voted to retain their present management under the leadership of Louis V. Aronson 2d, it was announced yesterday in Newark.

title: Dario Shindell, Clarinetist, Actor and Opera Director
description: Dario Shindell, musician, actor and opera director, was found dead in his apartment at 45 East 66th Street on Tuesday. An autopsy is being conducted to determine the cause of death.

title: Flaws Mar Test of Radio Alert For Use in National Emergency
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Technical and procedural failures marred a test last week of the radio system President Nixon would use to address the public in the event of a catastrophic emergency.

title: Senate Votes for Right To Veto U.S. Atom Aid
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)The Senate today voted unanimously to give Congress veto power over President Nixon's plan to provide Egypt and Israel with nuclear reactors.

title: Fulbright Asks Haig to Explain Kissinger Role in Taps
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 Senator J. W. Fulbright said today that he had asked President Nixon and the White House chief of staff, Gen. Alexander M. Haig, to provide information to back up Secre1 tary of State Kissinger's contention that he did not mislead the Foreign Relations. Committee last fail about nis role in the wiretapping of 17 officials and newsmen between 1969 and 1971.

title: LARGE ISRAELI BANK ALLOWED TO REOPEN
description: JERUSALEM, July 10 (AP)The IsraelBritish Bank reopened today after the government suspended all its businesi because of the bank's unstable finanical condition, a Bank of Israel spokesman said.

description: WHITE PLAINS, July 10Westchester's County Executive, Alfred B. Del Bello, accused private industry today of trying to pick off our cities in seeking CO sell prototype incineration units before a proposed countywide garbage disposal system was proved.

description: TOKYO July 10The dollar rose against the yen on Tokyo's foreignexchange market again today, reaching 289.50, its highest rate since early last March.

Y., on Aug. 3. The 24yearold musician from Colorado became the first American to win a top prize in the Soviet violin contest.

title: INTEGRATION PLAN FOR TWAIN SCORED
description: An education consultant for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday called a proposal to correct racial imbalance in Coney Island high school blatantly racist because it left enrollment by whites on voluntary basis while calling for involuntary assignment of blacks.

Ed, which has deprived its stockholders of earning maximum dividends on investments.

title: Lisbon Seeks to Save Coalition Cabinet
description: LISBON,. July 10Premier Adelino da Palma Carlos, who resigned suddenlY last night with four of his ministers, was called in by President Antonio de Spinola today in an effort to put the civilian coalition Cabinet together again.

title: MITCHELL CALLED VAGUE AT HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 John N. Mitchell, one of the few officials who had regular access to President Nixon, reportedly said he had a loss of memory today when asked about the Watergate case by House Judiciary Committee members and lawyers.

description: CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)The 1974 College AllStar game, plagued by the National Football League play ers strike, was canceled today, marking the first time in its 41year existence that the annual charity game will not be played.

description: State Attorney General Lou is J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that the widespread interest in buying silver coins and bars as a hedge against inflation had spawned serious frauds in which brokers and dealers who contracted to purchase bags of silver coins had taken the investors money but had failed to buy the coins.

title: NIXON TESTIMONY IS READ AT TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The defense in the trial of John D. Ehrlichman concluded its case today with testimony from President Nixon, whose sworn, written answers to six questions submitted by the defense were read aloud to the jury by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell.

title: Dave Anderson
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 10Ever since the World Football League was organized, cynics have wondered if it really would get off the ground. Let it be recorded that the New York Stars got off the ground today at 10:54 A.M. in their chartered Southern Airways DC9 that deposited them here for their opening game against the Jacksonville Sharks tomorrow night. The jetliner had rolled away from the gate at Kennedy International Airport at precisely 10:30, as scheduled. If the Stars ever sign Joe Namath, their charters won't always depart so promptly. On occasion the New York Jets have waited for their quarterback, the occasion being whenever he wasn't there on time. And the Stars would have been delighted to delay their departure for him, too. But at least they had O. J. aboarda quart container of orange juice, not the striking union member who might picket for 2,003 yards with the Buffalo Bills this year. In the midst of the Stars historical flight, their coach, Vito (Babe) Parilli, spoke for posterity.

title: Unsteady Portugal

Still, President Antonio de Spinola should be able to reconstruct the civilian coalition Government that collapsed Tuesday, now that all major componentsincluding the centrists whose resignations ignited the crisishave declared in favor of its continuation.

title: Two Soviet Astronauts Finish a Week in Space

Piper of New Milford, N.J., one niece, Mrs. Dorothy, Jane Toth, also of New Milford, N.J., one nephew, Robert H. Lauzon of Pittsford, N.Y. Friends may call from 1 to 2 P.M. The increase is in line with a dad. son last month by the Organization of. Petroleum Exporting Countries at a meeting in Quito, Ecuador.

description: LONDON, July 10Philip B. F. Agee, a former employe of the Central Intelligence Agency who has written hook about the agency's operation in Latin America, denied today that he had ever disclosed information about the agency to the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency.

title: New Books
description: A Pictorial History of the American Indian, by Oliver La Farge, revised by Alvin M. Josephy Jr. (Crown Publishers, $9.95).

title: PLAN UNIT VOTES FASTFOOD CURB
description: The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to prohibit the establishment of fastfood restaurants on residential blocks in the city, but cautioned that its action should not be construed as an attempt to limit the increasingly popular takeout operations on commercially zoned streets.

title: Horses & Equipment
description: RESPONSIBLE PEOPLE looking for a private stable or stalls to lease in Westchester or Rockland County. X6853 TIMES.

title: Cairo Air Crash Kills 6
description: CAIRO, July 10 (AP) Ar Egyptian passenger aircraft crashed near the internationa airport here today while on a routine training flight, killing two Egyptian pilots and foul Soviet advisers, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Credit Markets Awaiting Outcome of Cliffhangers
description: The credit markets were still waiting for the outcome of the Citicorp and New York City cliffhangers yesterday but managed to accord betterthanexpected receptions to the new offerings that did come to market. At the close of trading there was no word of the fate of Citicorp's controversial $850million floatingrate notes, which were to be sold yesterday. Officials of Citicorp, parent of the First National City Bank, and the Federal Reserve were still discussing the issue.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, July 10After months of searching and screening, St. Peter's College announced today the appointment of Dick McDonald as its new basketball coach, McDonald, who has resigned as basketball coach at William Paterson College, succeeds Bernie Ockene, who died of a heart attack last April 26.

title: Turks See No Major Rift With U.S. Over Poppies
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 10Turkish officials say that their decision last week to resume the cultivation of opium poppies should not cause a major rift in TurkishAmerican relations.

title: Gurney Is Indicted in Extortion Racket
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 10 A Federal grand jury accused Senator Edwards J. Gurney of Florida and six other men today of running an influencepeddling and extortion racket for the last three and a half years.

title: Screen:Auto Racers and a Girl Adrift in 'Dirty Mary'
description: "Dirty Mary Crazy Larry," which opened at the Forum and other theaters yesterday, is about a couple of young, down-on-their-luck racing car drivers named Larry (Peter Fonda) and Deke (Adam Roarke) who extort a lot of money from a supermarket at the beginning of the movie and spend the rest of the time, less than a day, attempting to outwit the county police. They are accompanied on the ride by Larry's girl, a parolee named Mary (Susan George), who has a good figure, a pretty face and even fewer brains than Larry or Deke.Although it's one long chase (from where to where is never known), "Dirty Mary Crazy Larry" is as aimless as its dimly seen characters, who talk a lot of dreadful, cute-tough dialogue but are never recognizable except as the actors who play them.Even that factor isn't much help in enjoying the film. At least half of it is devoted to semi-spectacular examples of trick driving and multi-vehicle smash-ups, at which point you are perfectly aware that the actors have been replaced by stuntmen. The film is so bereft of emotion and so full of physical movement that it's possible this is a point that John Hough, the director, and the screenwriters wanted to make. It's a very small point to be made by such a noisy picture.

title: A Reporter's Notebook: Students of Kissinger in High Places
description: PARIS, July 10Secretary of State Kissinger's Western European travels, unlike his trips to Communist capitals and the Middle East, had a special personal flavor. It was a kind of class reunion.

title: Section 1001
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The most tyrannous law on the statute books today is Section 1001 of Title 18 of the U.S. Code, which makes it a crime for a person to lie to any Federal official (It is not a crime, of course, for a Federal official to lie to any Person.)

title: Around the City on a Summer Night, Dramas of Life Are Played Alfresco
description: A summer, night in New York lacks a single focus. There is no quay or plaza where everyone promenades. Instead, there are pockets, clashing, dissonant. The season drives city folk outdoors, and dramas of life and death, love and hatred are lived in open settings.

title: Beatrice Sandler, 67, Dietitian, Food Editor and Writer, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Beatrice Pollock Sandler, a wellknown dietitian, food consultant and cookbook author died Sunday at Miami Beach. She was 67 years old and was the widow of Jerome Sandler.

title: CARL F. KAUFFELD, EXPERT ON SNAKES
description: Carl E. Kauffeld, retired diector of the Staten Island Zoological Society and a widely known authority on snakes, died yesterday of emphysema at Richmond Memorial Hospital on Staten Island. He was 63 years old and lived at 298 Giffords Lane, Great Kills, S.I.

title: GUYANA MAY RAISE BAUXITE ROYALTIES
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, July 10 (UPI)  Guyana today became the third Caribbean Bauxite producing nation to move toward getting a larger return from the export of the aluminum ore by foreign companies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his June 29 letter, Alan K. Scouten, regional architect of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, presents an argument that implicates the affluent as culprits responsible for exclusionary onefive and twentyacre zoning that is keeping people out of the municipalities he would like to see developed to provide an uncrowded, substantial environment for all.

title: Supreme Law of the Land
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Everyone Will have his own memory, his own feelings about Earl Warren, What came to my mind at the news of his death was a scene in the Supreme Court on Aug, 28, 1958.

title: FUEL OIL CONCERN BACKS SALES PLAN; STATE DROPS SUIT
description: The Asiatic Petroleum Corporation, accused by the state of having withheld homeheating oil from the market last summer and selling it at exorbitant prices in the winter, agreed in court yesterday to sell specified amounts here this summer and I next, when such fuel is cheaper.

title: The Ballet: D'Anttiono Glows in Corsair Pas de Deux
description: A showpiece is a showpiece is a showpieceit all depends what you are showing. Le Corsaid pas de deux is one of the most celebrated showpieces of classic dance it is a home run with the entrechat setand there is only one way to do it. Magnificently. It is the kind of pas de deux in which you do not just failif you do not triumph, metaphorically at least, you are pulled down a trapdoor, or sucked up by a stage vacuum cleaner. And sometimes that metaphor is not all that metaphorical.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Halting the steady downward trend, that to many investors has been too long, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday:, Prices in the overthecounter market also were mixed.

title: Maalot Inquiry Criticizes Action by Dayan and Cur
description: JERUSALEM, July 10An Israeli commission that investigated the killing of students at Maalot on May 15 said today that the Cabinet had not been able to debate the Arab guerillas precise demands because it did not get them.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A threejudge panel of the Appellate Division of Superior Court in Morristown overturned a ruling on a disputed race for the Sparta Township Council by awarding 294 challenged writein votes to Harry Wright. Mr. Wright ran on a Write In Wright platform. The panel overruled a decision by Superior Court Judge John R. Ard in ruling that the ballots, all cast simply for Mr. Wright Wright, were legitimately cast for Mr. Wright.

title: Player Ties Briton With 69, Shares Lead in British Open
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 10With three deuces going to the turn, Gary Player scored a 69 today to share the firstround lead with a British exschoolmaster, whose only previous distinction, in an Open came at Carnoustie in 1968 when he was bitten by a rat.

title: SHOP TALK
description: It's heaven for some, and hell for others, and it's called summer. For anyone with a lawn or terrace, it's time to move outdoors.

title: Streets and Courts
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N, Y.The black struggle for justice has a long, laudable and reasonably successful court history. For decades, blacks have, of necessity, taken their grievances to the Federal courts when virtually all other channels of redress have been inattentive and unavailable.

title: Ruffian Sets Astoria Record at Aqueduct
description: Ruffian lived up to the expectations of most of the 14,420 fans at Aqueduct yesterday. The homebred daughter of Reviewer carried the silks of the Locust Hill Farm to a ninelength triumph in the 68th running of the Astoria Stakes, and in so doing came within a fitth of a second of tying the track record for the 5furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies.

description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest producer of paper, reported yesterday the highest sales and earnings for any quarter or halfyear in its 76year history and the biggest percentage gains for any period.

description: Walter B. Wriston, the chairman of Citicorp, conferred yesterday in Washington with Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon and Arthur F. Burns, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. Yesterday's scheduled sale by Citicorp of notes with floating interest rates was delayed. Details on Page 47.

title: IRAN SHOWS INTEREST IN NEW U.S. FIGHTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Iran has expressed an interest in purchasing 250 of the F17 lightweight fighter planes being developed by Northrop Corporation for the Air Force, Pentagon sources said today.

title: Alcoholism Cost to Nation Put at $25Billion a Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Alcoholism and related problems are costing the nation more than $25billion a year, and most American youth are drinking at least occasionally, according to a major report on alcohol and health that was made public today.

description: WASHINGTON, July 10The defense in the trial of John D. Ehrlichman concluded its case today with testimony from President Nixon, whose sworn, written answers to six questions submitted by the defense were read aloud to the jury by Judge Gerhard A. Gesell.

description: OCEANPORT, July 10 Horses that will break from starting gates in another year met today in their first competition, without saddles and riders and showing onlookers nothing more than a slow walk interrupted by an occasional skittish trot.

title: Arms After Moscow
description: McLEAN, Va.  Although no proof wag probably needed, the agreements negotiated at the Moscow summit conference have demonstrated beyond a shadow of doubt that United States arms control goals have become hostage to impeachment politics.

description: Money

title: A General Retires
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) Army Lieut. Gen. Leo E. Benade, who reportedly is under consideration to become Veterans Administrator, will retire on Sept. 1; the Pentagon announced today.

description: BONN, July 10 Official West German sources said today that Israel would be kept informed of the dialogue the Common Market was undertaking with Arab states to deal with the financial and supply problems of oil.

description: In their fight to keep pace with inflation, many investors have increasingly turned to bonds paying high yields.

title: ILLICIT ROADWAYS ARE CUT IN ULSTER
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 10 (UPI)  British troops blew up illicit roads and erected concrete harriers today in major drive to close roads used by the Irish Republican Army for hitandrun raids from the Irish Republic.

title: SILBERT HEARINGS BELIEVED STALLED
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The confirmation hearings for a former Watergate prosecutor who was nominated by President Nixon to become United States Attorney for the District of Columbia appeared stalled today in the Senate Judiciary Committee.

description: CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)A spokesman for. Sears, Roebuck & Co. said today that prices in the newly published fallwinter caatalogue had been increased 6 per cent over last year.

title: AllStar Football Off
description: The College AllStar game, traditional opener of the National Football League exhibition season, was canceled yesterday for the first time in its 41year history. Sponsors of the charity game attributed the decision in large part to the N.F.L. players strike. Page 21.

description: Richard D. Heffner, professor of communications and public policy at Rutgers University, has been appointed chairman of the Rating Board of the Motion Picture Association of America.

description: WASHINGTON, July 10President Nixon's friend Charles G. Rebozo paid $45,621.15 for improvements at Mr. Nixon's private estate in Florida, and at least some of that money may have come from political contributions, according to staff report issued today by the Senate Watergate committee.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: HEALTH PLAN'S COST PUT AT $6.5BILLION
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)  Presenting Congress with the latest cost figures for various health insurance bills, the Nixon Administration said today that its version would cost $6.5billion above the estimated $103billion the nation will spend on health care during the next 12 months if no legislation is enacted.

title: BRASCO ACAIN DENIES A BRIBE CONSPIRACY
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco testified at his bribery) conspiracy trial yesterday that he had never accepted or requested any payoffs to assist a truck company owned by a reputed Mafia member.

description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. July 10 (AP)The defender, Dianne Wilde of Amsterdam, N.Y., defeated Paula Kern of Windsor today and advanced to the second round of the 45th annual New York State women's amateur championship.

description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) The House Rules Committee delayed final action today on a strip mining law amid extensive debate by committee members. The chairman, Ray J. Madden; Democrat of Indiana, scheduled a continuation of the proceedings for tomorrow.

The company also that it had increased prices on all Americanand Frenchprocess zinc oxides by the same amount.

But a pair of recent shocks to the industry has made this the most uncertain of times for noncommercial television, in the of many officials of public broadcasting who are gravely concerned about future sources of funding.

description: A 2yearold girl who the police said was trying to reach a toy on a sixthfloor fire escape yesterday fell to her death in the rear yard of the Lower East Side apartment house where she lived, at 361 East 10th Street The child was identified as Tynaisha Gonzalez.

description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 10 (AP) Gertrude Pike Duesenberg, widow of August S. Duesenberg, the pioneer automobile manufacturer, died yesterday. She was 95 years old.

description: Good news is often hard to come by these days, but the energy crisis has produced at least one large silver lining. Principally as a result of the lower fuelsaving speed limits adopted by the states early this year, highway deaths have fallen off sharply.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Can you tell a candy bar by its wrapper? Not necessarily, unless you look closely, in the case of Baby Ruth.

title: Chess: What Makes Boris Run, or In and Out of the Doldrums
description: Boris Spassky complained to me in Nice that he was in the wrong frame of mind during his disastrous semifinal candidates match with Anatoly Karpov in Leningrad this spring. I felt depleted, devoid of creativity, the former world champion said. I needed more time between my match with you and the Karpov match to recover the spirit to play well.

description: The Penn Central Railroad's working cash position is much better right now than its management had been expecting it to be, according to Jervis Langdon Jr., president and chief executive officer.

title: OffDuty Officer Is Shot While Stopping Holdup
description: An offduty police officer who had stopped in at a Harlem bar last night to show off a fishing catch foiled a holdup by two men whom he engaged in a gun battle. The officer and one of the holdup men was wounded. The second escaped.

title: BRITAIN WILL USE OWN TECHNOLOGY
description: LONDON, July 10The Government here announced today that it would use British technology in the development of the nation's nuclear power program and suggested that the public lacked confidence in American nuclear reactors.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 1 (AP)The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has ratified ??? threeyear contract with Local Technical Engineers, providing wage increases and other fits for operating and office employes, it was announced today.

title: CORRECTION IN TEXT OF U.S.SOVIET PACT
description: MOSCOW, July 10 (AP)Because of a transmission error, a phrase and a sentence were omitted by The Associated Press from its transmission of the text of the treaty signed by President Nixon and the Communist leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, on July 3 limiting underground nuclear tests.

title: ALLIED CHEMICAL LIFTS PROFIT 80%
description: The Allied Chemical Corporation posted an 80 per cent increase in secondquarter earnings on a sales gain of 31 per cent, making the halfyear profit 67 per cent higher and sales 27 per cent ahead of last year, the midyear report disclosed yesterday.

title: 20,000 at Unveiling of Statue To Mary Bethune in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, July 10Under a bright morning sun, more than 20,000 people from all over the country witnessed today the unveiling of the Mary McLeod Bethune Memorial, the first monument to a black person or a woman on public land in the nation's capital.

The homebred daughter of Reviewer carried the silks of the Locust Hill Farm to a ninelength triumph in the 68th running of the Astoria Stakes, and in so doing came within a fitth of a second of tying the track record for the 5furlong sprint for 2yearold fillies.

title: Superheated Danger
description: To take your dogor catalong for a pleasure drive on one of these hot, summer days may be considered kindness to the animal; but to leave it unattended in closed caror one with windows only slightly opened  for even a short period of time can turn your pet's pleasure trip into a nightmare of torture, and very possibly death.

title: People and Business KerrMcGee's Head Leaves Outside Board
description: Dean A. McGee, the 70yearold chairman and chief executive officer of the KerrMcGee Corporation, announced yesterday his resignation as a member of the board of directors of the Oklahoma Natural Gas Companybowing to a move by the Federal Trade Commission against alleged interlocking directorates.

title: Release of Transcripts: The Pattern for an Argument
description: WASHINGTON, July 10The publication of House Judiciary committee transcripts of Watergate tape recordings was the start of an evident effort by committee officials to give both the Congress and the public an education on evidence that could support the impeachment of President Nixon. In 218 printed pages, the coinmittee presented yesterday White House dialogue that was markedly different from the written version contained in transcripts issued earlier by the President.

title: John B. Williamson, Communist Convicted Here in 1949, Is Dead
description: John B. Williamson, one of the 11 members of the Communist party's national board who were convicted in 1949 of charges of advocating the overthrow of the Government by violence, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, on a London street. He was 70 years old.

title: Simon Foresees Drop For World Oil Prices
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP)Treasury Secretary William E. Simon, who leaves tomorrow on an official tour of the Middle East, said today he believed world oil prices would decline in the near future.

title: Many Take a Turn as Leader in Collective Black Artists Band
description: While the Thad JonesMell Lewis band, which has been playing Monday nights at the Village Vanguard for more than eight years, is taking one of its occasional trips out of town, the Collective Black Artists Ensemble has moved into the Vanguard to hold the fort on Monday. The C.B.A. Ensemble is a 17piece band that has been in the process of development for five years and that has really taken shape in the last year.

title: Judges to File Reports of Fees Paid to Lawyers and Guardians
description: The office that oversees the administration of the state court system modified its rules yesterday to make judges responsible for filing reports of fees that are paid to lawyers and other guardians appointed by the court.

He strained ligaments in his right hand yesterday while working out for the fight.

description: LIMERICK, Ireland, July 10 (AP)  Kara Kennedy, 14yearold daughter of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, was hospitalized today with a minor leg injury.
