title: Flight Abroad Reported
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 11, (UPI)  Patricia Hearst may have fled to Guatemala with two members of the Syntbionese Liberation Army, a television station reported tonight.

title: TRAFFIC FLOW INTO THE CITY FROM NEW JERSEY
description: A year ago at this time, the 96 employes in Jerry Neustadt's two plants were busy assembling Christmas lights, rushing to fill orders from 2,400 customers who included some of the largest retail chains in the country.

title: U.S. Is Ready to Accept New Sea Limits
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, July 11 (Reuters)The United States announced today that it was prepared to accept a 200mile economic zone for coastal states as well as a 12mile territorial limit as part of a package for an international law of the sea.

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
description: United States Government and Agency Bonds

title: SPINOLA DISSOLVES CABINET IN LISBON
description: LISBON, July 11  President Antnio de Spinola today dismissed the rest of the twomonthold civilian provisional Cabinet as a prelude to the formation of a new Cabinet that wellinformed sources said would be dominated by military officers.

title: NIXON EVALUATES STATE OF ECONOMY WITH EXECUTIVES
description: WASHINGTON, July 11President Nixon, in a private meeting today with a group of leading business executives and economists, repeatedly expressed the fear that Congress would pass silly and dangerous legislation if the Administration overdid its antiinflation program and tipped the economy into a recession.

title: Civilian, 21, Injured At Ft. Dix, Is Dead
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 11William Wheeler, the 21yearold civilian injured in a confrontation involving himself, a second civilian and a company of Army trainees in a remote section of Fort Dix, died today in Burlington Memorial Hospital, apparently of a cerebral concussion.

title: Eastwood's 66 Leads at Quad Cities
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, July 11 (AP)Littleknown Bob Eastwood shot a fiveunderpar 66 today to take a onestroke lead after the first round of the $100,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament.

title: Revolution Brings Art To Lisbon
description: LISBONOne of this city's biggest art shows in years has opened as one of the most striking examples of how the revolution in April has brought cultural opportunities to Portugal that she has not had for almost 50 years.

title: Ballet: Tudor's Jardin
description: It is curious, this special Proustian pungency of Antony Tudors ballet Jardin aux Lilas. The ballet is now nearly 40 years oldit was created in London in 1936yet it still retains its sad and fragrant lilacblossom freshness. On Wednesday night, American Ballet Theater, the American curator of this peculiarly English ballet, gave it its first performance of the season at the New York State Theater.

title: Boating Outlook
description: The National Weather Service issued this forecast at 6:45 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long island south shore and nearby coastal area:

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Settlement of the Nassau County police salary dispute with the Federal Cost of Living Council was announced a joint statement by the County Executive, Ralph G. Caso, and Cliff W. Schmitt, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association. The Cost of Living Council had held that the 7.5 per cent increase in pay for the police, plus benefits, in the period of its jurisdiction between Jan. 1 and April 30, 1974, exceeded the Federal guidelines. A deduction $55 a man from gross earnings will be accepted in full settlement of the differences between the guidelines and what the policemen received.

title: New Books
description: Another Spring by Henry S. Maxfield (Little, Brown, $6.95). A man seeking isolation is forced into the life of a New Hampshire village.

title: Some Police Strike As Baltimore Aides Stay Out 11th Day
description: BALTIMCV, July 11 (UPI)Patrolmen in the southwestern district of Baltimore walked off their jobs tonight to join more than 3,000 striking blue collar municipal workers in an 11day strike

title: Stars Bow, 147, In Debut
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 11  Under inspection from the World Football League's first national television audience and an assembly of 59,112 spectators that lifted the announced attendance for six opening games to 258,624, the New York Stars lost to the Jacksonville Sharks, 147, Ionight on two puntunit mislakes.

title: InflationWeary Men Turn to Discount Stores
description: When Jacob K. Javits and John A. Roosevelt and Lewis W. Foy, president of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, bought suits at a discount from Harry Rothman, Inc., they were happy to sign the register of 1,000 distinguished customers.

title: Traffic Returning To Normal Here
description: Traffic volume in the city has nearly returned to preenergy crisis levels, and there has been a resurgence of business in the city's parking industry after what spokesman called the disaster of January and February, when operators found themselves at the bottom of an 18month slide.

title: CBS Chief Defends Ban on Mobil's Ads on Energy
description: Arthur R. Taylor, president of CBS Inc., in a statement distributed to newspaper editors, defended the advertising policies of his company in reply to complaints of the Mobil Oil Corporation concerning the networks refusal to accept idea advertising.

title: 5,000 Flee Safely From Office Fire
description: Five thousand people fled safely down the stairwells of two adjoining downtown office buildings yesterday in an orderly escape from a smoky fire 21 floors high following drill and warden systems started after the fatal 1970 fire at 1 New York Plaza.

title: Israel's Problems, As Seen by 5 Students
description: JERUSALEM, July 11 Of the 25,100 Israelis who graduated from high school fast month, the vast majority young men and women alike  will go directly into the army. They will be inducted for periods of compulsory national service ranging from 20 months to three yers.

title: HIGH CREDIT COST HITS BOND MARKET
description: More prospective borrowers walked away from the bond market yesterday, rejecting the high cost of credit. In the secondary bond markets, however, there were some signs of stability.

title: Market Place
description: Some investors who feel assetrich companies seldom go wrong view the present market as one offering remarkable opportunities, for the patient.

title: Commodity, Price Index. Off 0.5 in Latest Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 228.8 from 229.3 last week.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: FAIR HAVEN, July 11Who is Monmouth County's hest allround amateur athlete? A woman? A 57yearold man? Someone confined to a wheelchair? An obscure weekend softball player?

title: Civil Court Judge Is Seated
description: Mayor Beanie swore in Pasquale E, Divernieri yesterday as a judge of the Civil Court. Judge Divernieri, a 51yearold lawyer, will serve tlyi interim term until the end of tnis year. He will be paid at the rate of $42.451 a year.

title: Pescarolo's Medicine Is Driving
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 11 The scars on his face are only partly covered by his beard. The hurt inside Henri Pescarolo goes deeper.

title: The Pop Life
description: Patti Smith isn't likely to appeal to the same pop audience that craves, say, Three Dog Night. Miss Smith, who is at Max's Kansas City through Monday, has her devoted admirers, to be sure. But her performance and her personality are such that no record company has dared to take a risk with her, and she hasn't really performed outside New York at all.

title: Data From House Panel Tell of Political Moves
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 H. R. Haldeman, while chief of the White House staff, exercised authority over a broad range of matters related to President Nixon's 1972 campaign, according to two documents released today by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: Senate Votes to Repeal, NoKnock Drug Law Rule
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The Senate voted 64 to 31 today to repeal the controversial no knock provision in the Federal drug laws.

Next to that was something from Goethe, written with a ballpoint pen. Begin, it said, and then the work will be completed.

title: A Ruling in Mozambique Orders Gold Sentto Lisbon
description: LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 11 (Agency FrancePresse)A consignment of gold ingots, blocked here on its way from South Africa to Portugal at the demand of local demonstrators, was ruled today to be the property of the bank of Portugal and as such to be sent to Lisbon. The ruling was made by Governor General Henrique Soares de Melo, who had ordered the shipment held up yesterday.

title: White House Phone List Cut Hunt After BreakIn
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The White House recalled an intern al telephone directory shortly after the June, 1972, Watergate breakin and reissued it without listing E. Howard Hunt Jr. as a consultant, a document released by the House Judiciary Committee showed today.

description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 The revenge motive is certainly expected to inspire the faction behind Axius in the $200,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway on Saturday night.

title: W.F.L. Openers Create Set of Paradoxes
description: After an 11month gestation, during which no one, not even those who conceived it, really knew what the child would look like, the founders of the World Football League have given birth to a bundle of paradoxes.

title: Materials Costs Cited
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday a larger decline in earnings in the second quarter than in the first quarter this year. This resulted in a drop of 33.9 per cent in profits for the initial half this year despite record sales.

description: John A. Kervick, whose powerful role in New Jersey Democratic politics was halted abruptly last year when he pleaded guilty to charges of political corruption, died yesterday of cancer at Overlook Hospital, Summit, N. J. He was 68 years old and lived in Summit.

description: Stock prices edged dowh yesterday. All popular indicators hit 1974 lows.

description: Prices declined as volume rose slightly on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. In the overthecounter market prices closed mixed.

description: Robert M. Kluger, vice president for engineering of Wolff & Munier, Inc., contractors and engineers, died Monday in Montefiore Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 750 Kat,pock Street in Riverdale, the Bronx.

description: As a result of the worst inflation this country has ever experienced in peace time and of the almost exclusive reliance on restrictive monetary policy to check that inflation  interest rates have gone through the roof and the financial solvency of many institutions, both private and public, is now threatened.

title: Nixon Names Judge Here
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) President Nixon today nominated United States District Court Judge Murray I. Gurfein to be a judge of the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. Judge Gurfein, 66 years old, had been serving as Federal judge in the Southern District of New York since 1971. He was a former partner irr the New York law firm of Gold stein, Gurfein, Shames and Hyde. The second circuit covers New York, Vermont and Connecticut.

title: Laotian Government Decides To Dissolve National Assembly
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 11 (UPI)The Laotian coalition, Government decided last night to dissolve the country's National Assembly, a Government spokesman announced today.

title: A Matter Of Two Principles
description: To indulge in judicial rationalization in order to sanction the exercise of a power where no power in fact exists is to strike the deadliest of blows to our Constitution.

title: Give Me Your Tired, Your Old, Your Money
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio was prepared, when I first began investigating nursing homes ten years ago, for the dreary quality of life would find in those places where we hide those who are old and sick. What I did not expect to find out was that nursing homes are an extremely profitable industry, for, like so many other people, I then believed the industry's statements that attributed poor patient care to the lack of money.

description: RESPONSIBLE PEOPLE looking for a arlSlate stable or stalls to lease In Westchester or Rockland County. X6853 TIMES.

title: Hospital Union Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) The Senate has passed a compromise bill allowing employes of nonprofit hospitals to join unions. The 63to29 vote sent the bill to the House for final action. Under the compromise agreed to by SenateHouse conferees, any workers who object to joining a union could pay the equivalent of dues to charity.

title: Bergen Police to Fight Crime With Beanbags
description: HACKENSACK, July 11 (UPI)The Bergen County Police Department has found a new weapon in its fight against crimebeanbags.

title: 13% PRICE RISE DUE FOR MARKET BLOC
description: BRUSSELS, July 11Consumer prices in the ninenation European Economic Community will rise 13 per cent in 1974 and the gross national product of the Nine will go up 2.5 per cent for the same period, according to estimates released today by the Common Market's Executive Commission.

title: House Panel's Lawyer.
description: WASHINGTON, July 11I'm a lawyer. I like to take on difficult cases. I like to prepare cases. To me, success is seeing that justice is done, that the Constitution is preserved and fairness occurs. That was John Michael Doer's description of himself last December when he was selected to head the impeachment inquiry staff of the House Judiciary Committee: And the way Mr. Doar methodically prepares cases was demonstrated today when the committee made public the first massive installment of 4,133 pages of evidentiary information that Mr. Doar and his staff of more than 100 have prepared for the members of the committee who are considering the possible impeachment of President Nixon.

title: U.S. Team Wins in Lacrosse
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, July 11 (peuters)The United States lacrosse team kept its unbeaten record intact tonight with a 216 victory over South Australia. The touring American team reeled off 11 goals before the home team scored late in the second period. The leading scorers for the Americans were Pat O'Meally of the University Maryland, 4 goals; Jack Thomis of Johns Hopkins, 3 and 3 assists, and Jimmy Trenz of Cornell, 2 and 2 assists.

title: JOHN TAYLOR TERRY
description: John Taylor Terry, retired senior partner of Wood, Walker & Co., stockbrokers, and a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, died here Wednesday. He was 85 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Rail Freight Tonnage Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The Association of American Railroads reported today that United States railroad freight traffic last week totaled an estimated 13.5 billion tonmiles, 4.7 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period, which included the July 4 holiday and the second week of the annual coal miner's holiday, totaled 425,684 cars, 0.7 per cent above last year. The American Trucking Associations, Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage last week was 10.5 per cent below a year ago.

title: Red Smith
description: Baseball's first scheduled Scramble for. Scratch comes off tonight in San Diego. The men who own baseball and the men who play it have been openly lusting after loot since the Cincinnati Red Stockings converted a game, for boys into a vehicle for profit more than a century ago, but never until now have fans been invited to shard in the swag.

title: Even in the Heat, Suits and Ties Still Feel Right To Businessmen
description: What will most businessmen wear to work this summer when the temperature ions toward infinity and the air  conditioner sputters around the fuelsaving 78degree level recommended by the Federal Energy Office?

title: HighLevel U.S.Palestinian Contacts May Develop
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 Highlevel contacts between the United States and Palestinian organizations may develop in coming months as part of an evolving American effort to bring about a Middle East settlement, a senior State Department official said today.

title: 2 Sanitation Aides Sworn
description: Sanitation Commissioner Robert T. Groh yesterday swore in two deputy commissioners, Walter J. Hinckley and Ralph F. Demarco. Mr. Hinckley has been deputy health Commissioner since 1973. From 1968 to 1970 he was inspector general of the Sanitation Department. Mr. Demarco has been serving as acting deputy borough president of Queens, replacing Mr. Groh, who left Borough Hall to take the commissionership, Mr. Demarco will be paid $29,429 a year and Mr. Hinckley, $30,648.

title: What to Do About It
description: What the nation requires is a national policy to attack inflation, unemployment and crucial social seeds in way that will command the support and respect people generally because it is fair. Such a policy will protect the living standards and jobs of those who are most susceptible to the capricious erosion of rising prices or of rising unemployment.

title: Fiat and Kloeckner Plan CommercialVehicle Tie
description: Fiat, S.p.A., of Turin, Italy, and KloecknerHumboldtDeutz of Cologne, West Germany, announced yesterday that they had agreed to merger their commercialvehicle capabilities into a separate company that would have sales of almost $2billion. Fiat is Italy's largest manufacturer of motor vehicles and Producers more than 80,000 trucks and buses a year. K.H.D.

title: The Disillusion of a C.I.A. Man: 12 Years From Agent to Radical
description: LONDON, July 11I did not write this book for the K.G.B. I wrote it for revolutionary organizations in the United States, in Latin America and everywhere else. I wrote it as a contribution to the socialist revolution.

title: CITY TOLD TO SHUT TOMBS IN 30 DAYS
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered the city to close the Manhattan House of Detention for Men within 30 days.

title: CONTROL RID SET FOR OMEGAALPHA
description: The financially troubled OmegaAlpha, Inc., which through subsidiaries makes wire and cable products, has given A. R. Gale, a Greenwich, Conn consultant, the right to acquire control of the company under a contract which expires July 24. According to an Omega Alpha spokesman, Mr. Gale is not now a holder of OmegaAlpha stock.

title: U.S. Officers to Visit Cairo
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (Reuters)A fiveman United States military team is scheduled to arrive in Cairo on Sunday to study the Egyptian armed forces role in the October war with Israel, the Defense Department announced today. The Pentagon has denied reports that the team will survey Egyptian arms needs, but has acknowledged that Egyptian officers may take the opportunity to tell the Americans what United States weapons they may want.

title: Dubious Judgment
description: In these transcripts, portions not relevant  with regard to Watergate are not included, but everything that is relevant is included  I have spent many hours of my own time personally reviewing these materials and personally deciding questions of relevancy. President Nixon, April 29, 1974

title: Nixon Assistants Decline To Deny 2 New Charges
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 White House spokesmen declined today to deny specifically charges that campaign runds had been put to President Nixon's personal use and that another gap had been discovered in the Watergate tapes.

title: President Signs Bill Extending Benefits Of Veterans to 76
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI)  President Nixon has signed legislation extending education benefits for veterans of the Vietnam period from 8 to 10 years, the White House said today.

title: Byrne Acts to Save Plan for Income Tax
description: TRENTON, July 11Governor Byrne has told Democratic legislative leaders that he is prepared to accept a referenduni in 1976 on his proopsed incometax program as a condition to a, vote of approval ini the Assembly on Monday, a high Byrne aide disclosed tonight.

title: Orsolya M. Nadasdy Married To Fernando GalloZelaya
description: Miss Orsolya Marie Nadasdy and Fernando GalloZelaya, both of New York, were married yesterday morning by the Most Rev. Edwin B. Broderick, Roman Catholic Bishop of Albany, in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church here. A reception was given at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: European Security Conference Decides to Adjourn for Summer
description: GENEVA, July 1The Soviet Union bowed today to the West's insistence on a summer break at the slowmoving European conference on security and cooperation, but only after exacting a token concession on the length of the adjournment.

title: Screen: 'The Tamarind Seed' Arrives:The Cast
description: Blake Edwards, a very talented director of comedy ("The Pink Panther." "What Did You Do in the War, Daddy?" and others), has disappeared. Absorbed, perhaps, into the first image we see in his new film, "The Tamarind Seed," which opened yesterday at the Radio City Music Hall.That image is an eyeball but it's no ordinary eyeball. It's an eyeball so huge, so clear, so pure, so all-seeing and so fiercely knowing that it could be the mind of God. When the camera pulls back we see the eyeball to be one of a pair belonging to Julie Andrews (Mrs. Edwards), who has been the star and, I assume, the inspiration of two of Mr. Edwards's more recent films. The first was "Darling Lili," a charming comedy with music in which Miss Andrews played a World War I spy working stanchly if wrong-headedly for the Kaiser's victory. The second is "The Tamarind Seed," a film of the sort of staggering sober-sided romantic foolishness one seldom encounters outside the pages of first-person-narrated gothic fiction written by Victoria Holt and her sisters of the virgin quill."The Tamarind Seed" is not gothic fiction, technically speaking. It has the form of a contemporary love story set against a background of cold war intrigue stretching from London and Paris to Barbados and Canada. But don't be fooled by the time and places. The game is given away by the film's total absorption in the chastity of its heroine, a woman who considers a goodnight kiss as the first, irrevocable step toward total degradation.Mr. Edwards's screenplay, though it changes some geographical details, is an unfortunately faithful adaptation of the book by Evelyn Anthony, a novelist who attempts to avoid bad writing by more or less standing on its back: "Looking up, Judith found every clich speeding through her mind. The moon was like a pearl, the stars were like diamonds, the palm trees waved and the crickets sang. It was all so corny and impossible until one saw the reality.""The Tamarind Seed" is about Judith Farrow (Miss Andrews), a plucky widow and the veteran of a recently ended six-month affair with a married man, a fellow who is shown by the film to be of such clottishness that it does permanent damage to any sympathy we might have for poor Judith. On a holiday in Barbados, where she has gone to find herself, Judith meets Feodor Sverdlov (Omar Sharif), a tall, dark, handsome man to whom Judith feelshow should I say it?strangely drawn.There is, however, a problem. Judith is the assistant to a Very Important Person in the British Home Office in London and Feodor is the Soviet air attach in Paris. Did they meet just by chance? Is he trying to recruit her for spy work by seducing her? The British Intelligence officer (Anthony Quayle) attached to the Paris embassy thinks so. And this is what Feodor tells his boss, craggy old General Golitsyn (Oscar Homolka).What in heaven's name is a plucky girl to think? Or, as Judith says: "This whole thing has gotten out of proportion."The movie hops back and forth between embassies in London and Paris. Thoroughly mixed into the love story are subsidiary plots about a Russian spy highly placed in Allied diplomatic circles and the attempts to defect of a Soviet agent.The supporting performances are not at all bad, especially those of Mr. Homolka, Mr. Quayle, Dan O'Herlihy (as the British minister in Paris) and Sylvia Sims (as his unhappy wife). Mr. Sharif is animated and gallant as he gives Miss Andrews her line cues, which is his principal function.Miss Andrews, who can be a marvelous comedienne, is allowed to be funny here. However, instead of appearing vulnerable, she seems totally removed and above everything, as if she were a ballroom chandelier. There's no time for a performance when the camera insists on examining her with such love and admiration.

title: Inmates in the Capital Seize Hostages
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 An undetermined number of Federal prisoners seized United States marshals and lawyers today at the United States Courthouse here and reportedly threatened to kill the hostages unless they were granted safe conduct out of the country.

title: Father Held for Shooting Son
description: BERNARDSVILLE, July 11 (UPI) Robert Fahey was held ion assault charges today after he allegedly shot his son when he found the youth smoking marijuana, the police said. The Father Held for Shootingson son, Daniel, 18 years old, was also arrested for possession of 25 grams of marijuana. He was released from Morristown Memorial Hospital after treatment; for superficial buckshot wounds.

title: St. Clair Tries to Discredit Dean Before House Pane
description: WASHINGTON, July 11President Nixon's chief defense lawyer tried today to discredit John W. Dean 3d before the House Judiciary Committee in what one committee member called a real bloodletting.

title: Senate Votes to Repeal NoKnock Drug Law Rule
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 The Senate voted 64 to 31 today to repeal the controversial no knock provision in the Federal drug laws.

title: Yankees Beat Royals Behind Medich, 21
description: KANSAS CITY, July 11Manager Bill. Virdon spent almost the entire game tonight hoping for an insurance run that wasn't necessary as the Yankees clung to a slim lead and won, 21, for a threegame sweep of their series with the Kansas City Royals.

title: Nixon Backer Sees Bid To Overturn Landslide
description: BOSTON, July 11 (AP)The head of the National Citizens Committee for Fairness to the Presidency said today that some politicians were trying to overturn President Nixon's landslide victory of 1972.

title: TRAFFIC FLOW INTO THE CITY FROM NEW JERSEY
description: The energy crisisa fading memory to most Americans produced a special group of winners and losers, people whose livelihood depends in different ways on energy. Through events that none of them could have predicted controlled, some of these people were able to turn last winter's shortages to their profit, while others were plunged into a personal nightmare from which they have yet awaken.

title: Fishing Outlook for the Weekend in Nearby Waters
description: From Surf City, N. J., to Cape Cod, the usual pattern of summer fishing has begun to emerge in many areas, with large bluefish appearing in greater numbers and large striped bass becoming more difficult to find and catch.

title: Excerpts From 8 Volumes of Evidence Issued by Judiciary Pane
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The House judiciary Committee released today eight volumes of evidence accumulated in its impeachment inquiry into the Watergate breaki and coverup: Following are a background memoandum on the White House staff and President Nixon's campaign organizations; a foreword to the first volume by Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, committee chairman; the texts of statements of information presented by the staff to the committee members; and a statement of information presented on behalf of President Nixon. Printed separately are excerpts from a massive amount of documentary evidence provided to support the statements of information.belt recording by the President of his recollections of a telephone converselion with John Mitchell on June 20, 1972:

title: ABRAMS PROPOSES A MORTGAGE POOL
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx proposed yesterday that the city do what he said banks here were increasingly failing to do: use capital collected from small investors to provide badly needed mortgages on, apartment houses.

title: Samuels Backs Cuomo and Is Assailed
description: Howard J. Samuels, the Democratic State Committee designee for Governor, yesterday; endorsed Mario M. Cuomo for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor and was severely criticized for doing so by supporters of Mr. Cuomo's two opponents.

title: Nancy Wickwire, 48, Actress On Broadway and TV Is Dead
description: Nancy Wickwire, an actress who had appeared in featured roles on Broadway but was probably better known for her leading performances with important repeitory companies, died of cancer Wednesday in Mount Zion Hospital in San Francisco. She was 48 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: Civilian, 21, Injured At Ft. Dix, Is Dead
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., July 11William Wheeler, the 21yearold civilian injured in confrontation involving himself, a second civilian and a company of Army trainees in a remote section of Fort Dix, died today in Burlington Memorial Hospital, apparently of a cerebral concussion.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: ROME, July 11Hundreds of tourists were disappointed this evening when a performance of Puccini's Turandot at the Baths of Caracalla was canceled because the city has no money to pay singers, musicians and stagehands.

description: BONN, July 11The failure of one of West Germany's bestknown private banks and the question of who should pay off its debts have become political issues in this country, where criticism of the capitalist system has been mounting.

title: JOHN E. LEACH
description: BUFFALO, July 11 (AP)John E. Leach, who recently was elected chairman of the New York State Bar Association, died yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: Screen: Sontag's 'Promised Lands':Treatment of Israel Is at Screening Room
description: Susan Sontag's film about Israel, "Promised Lands," which was made in October and November of 1973, isn't intended to be a documentary. However, that country's situation is just too factually complex to be treated as a tone poem. In an effort to eschew talking heads, there's a lot of voice-over narration, as people walk through the streets, but sometimes we don't know who's talking. There's some handsome photography  especially of figures in landscapes  although what's seen and what is said often don't go together, and many shots seem irrelevant. The movie opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room.One's ready to be moved by the subject. But the viewer almost has to function as an editor, since the selection of the footage is so haphazard. Hence the emotions of or about Israel don't come through, even though glimpses of graveyards and corpses and the consciousness of Auschwitz, the lingering shock of the October attack and the awareness that the struggle between Arabs and Jews may be insoluble  as one man says, "There's no solution to a tragedy"  run through the marrow of the picture. Throughout, the ideas and the people and the machines of war are examined from a distance, as though everything had been observed through some kind of mental gauze.The Israelis  particularly those in robes  are filmed as if they were extremely foreign or exotic. Also, Israel seems like a nearly all-male country, since few women appear and none have been interviewed. There are a few sympathetic words for the Arabs, but their existence seems shadowy and abstract  almost as bloodless as the statues in a wax museum devoted to Israeli history.Two scenes are particularly disturbing. At a mass burial, the camera rushes in on a weeping profile in a way that's intrusive  because we've been given so little sense of the dead or even of the war. Later, in a hospital, a shell-shocked soldier relives his battlefield experiences under drugs, while a psychiatrist and the hospital staff recreate the noises of shooting and bombing. (This is said to be therapeutic for the patient. The staff looks as though it rather enjoys the task.) It should be devastating to watch this man burrow into the pillow, shudder, dive beneath the bed. But these moments have been filmed with such confusion that we can't respond to his suffering  indeed, suffering's hardly conveyed in "Promised Lands." Because the movie is dull and badly organized, the war is made to seem unreal.Unlike Claude Lanzmann's very fine documentary, "Israel Why," which was shown at the 1973 New York Film Festival, the Sontag film won't increase your understanding of Israel. Perhaps the latter should have been a book instead of a film.

title: Screen: 'Norma Jean'
description: You know that you're in for a festival of innocencewhich will almost certainly be betrayedin almost any movie that opens with a shot of sunlight dropping through leafy trees while music soars and a young couple scampers through the woods. (Well before "Jules and Jim," people running outdoors meant happiness on the screen, as long as the weather was good.) It helps if the couple is blond, if they have an affinity for a pure white rabbit and if the landscape contains crickets to provide some blameless sounds. Then all that's needed are some forces of corruption  which will be sure to stone the rabbit.Juleen Compton's "The Plastic Dome of Norma Jean," which is playing at the First Avenue Screening Room today and tomorrow, is an infantile ripoff of the Marilyn Monroe legend. In case the title fails to zap your reflexes, there are some early shots inside a truck that refer directly to Clark Gable and Monroe in "The Misfits."This Norma Jean is a clairvoyant whose talents are exploited by cruel materialists until she nearly goes bats and is finally wiped out. Sharon Henesy has been directed to speak in a quavery little voice laced with aspirates, to heave with distress and clutch her stomach while others grin or chortle wickedly, and to use regression to suggest suffering. She seems about 16 when the movie begins, but soon appears to be 12 and then rapidly retreats to 6.The film was made in 1967, but it seems more antique than that, because of the elderly rock music as well as the insistence on the purity of youth. (Several New York actors  Robert Gentry, Marco St. John, and Skip Hinnantare on hand, along with Sam Waterston, who seems to be avoiding the camera.) Throughout, the strained and artificial vision of doomed innocence serves as a reminder that it's fatal to fool with a myth if you can't deliver the comedy that enhanced it. For all the whimsy, "Norma Jean" is a harmless picture. And yet it's discomforting to be embarrassed in the name of a dead person  whose death has been worked over so often.

title: Hearing for Gurney's Plea Expected Soon in Florida
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 11  A prosecution spokesman said today that a hearing would be held in about a couple of weeks to allow Senator Edward J. Gurney of Florida and six other men to plead to a charge that they ran an extortion racket to sell the Senator's influence with the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Money
description: Money

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Shipping/Mails

title: News Summary and Index
description: President Antnio de Spinola of Portugal dismissed the rest of the twomonthold civilian provisional Cabinet as a prelude to the formation of a new Cabinet that wellinformed sources said would be dominated by military officers. The sources said an army officer would be named premier and other officers would get key cabinet posts. [1:4.]

title: NEW GAP IS FOUND ON NIXON'S TAPE
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) An assistant special Watergate prosecutor, Richard Benveniste, said today that another gap had been discovered in White House recordings of Presidential conversations.

title: Americans Defeat Italy
description: MESSINA, Sicily. July 11 (AP) The touring United States junior basketball team defeated an Italian squad, 9380, in an exhibition match tonight. The Americans led 4838 at the half.

title: Rutherford Injured in Glen Spill
description: WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. July 11  Johnny Rutherford, who said after winning the Indianapolis 500 last May that he wanted to do more road racing, broke his left ankle today while practicing for his first race on a road course this season.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE ISSUES THE VOLUMINOUS EVIDENCE FROM WATERGATE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 11The House Judiciary Committee made public today the voluminous evidence that it has received in its impeachment inquiry into President Nixon's role in the Watergate affair.

title: W.F.L. Openers Create Set of Paradoxes
description: After an 11month gestadon, during which no one, not even those who conceived it, really knew what the child would look like, the founders of the World Football League have given birth to a bundle of paradoxes.

title: Wednesday's Fight
description: New OrleansTony Licata, ??? pounds, New Orleans, outpointed Gary Broughton, 160, Brantford, Ontario, 10 rounds.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Texaco, Overseas Petroleum Company filed a counterclaim yesterday in the United States Court for the Southern District of New York against the Consolidated Edison Company for damages in excess of $55million.

title: Boating Outlook
description: The National Weather Service issued this forecast at 6:45 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island south shore and nearby coastal area:

title: Books of The Times
description: Intelligence, patience and thoroughness made a fine police officer of Albert A. Seedman, who retired in 1972 from the New York Police Department as Chief of Detectives after many years as a detective commander. But he had other assetscuriosity, occasional intuition, the respect of his men and a desire to be involved personally in investigations.

title: Theater: Word Is Law
description: LANGUAGE, A MAY written and directed by David Starkwealher; setting by Ron Radice; lighting by John Dodd; Peter Grossman, stage manager. Presented by the New York Theater Strategy. At the truck and Warehouse Theater, 19 East 4th Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Dutchess County, N.Y., grand jury has recommended the removal of two deputy sheriffs who first shot at a man they mistook for an escaped prisoner and then instead of apologizingarrested for reckless endangerment.

title: Loan to Sindona by Rome Bank Is Not Expected to Aid Franklin
description: WASHINGTON, July 11Not a single cent of the $100million loan from the Banco di Roma to companies controlled by Midhele Sindona will be used in aiding the Franklin National Bank, according to senior Government regulatory officials as well as sources close to Mr. Sindona and to the Banco di Roma.

title: Woodrow Wilson and Mr. Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 11In his first inaugural address, Woodrow Wilson said that the firm basis of government is justice, not pity, and he appealed to every man's conscience and vision of the right. This did not prove to be a very contagious suggestion, but Wilson said some things that day that are relevant to our present political and public confusions.

title: Settlement Is Reported With Kopechne Parents
description: MANCHESTER, N. H., July 11 (AP)The parents of Mary Jo Kopechne and Senator Edward M. Kennedy have reached a financial settlement in the death of the secretary, who was killed when a car driven by Mr. Kennedy ran off a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island in Martha's Vineyard, Mass., in 1969, The Manchester Union Leader reported today.

title: Developer Offers to Build Huge Hotel in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 11 A major developer offered to day to build a 1,100room hote on Atlantic City's boardwalli and follow it with commercial buildings and new housing.

title: ARABS TO SET UP ENERGY INSTITUTE
description: CAIRO, July 11Arab oil ministers decided at the end of a twoday meeting here today to set up an Arab Energy Institute through which Arab countries would join the worldwide search for new energy sources.

title: Two Iowa Farmers: Prosperity and Loss
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y.Two farmers rent part of the Iowa homestead where I lived as a child. One is prospering, the other is on the verge of bankruptcy. It isn't the weather, nor the character nor work habits of these healthy, diligent men that make the difference. What then?

title: Senate Votes to End Aid to Nations Selling Illicit Opium
description: WASHINGTON. July 11(AP) The Senate voted today to cut off militar yand economic aid to Turkey or any other opiumgrowing country that does not prevent diversion of the drug to illicit markets. Any cutoff however, would not take effect until Jan. 1 1975, under a drugbill amendment offered by Senator Walter F. Mondale, Democrat of Minnesota, adopted by a vote of 81 to 8. The amendment was added to a bill, which now goes to House, authorizing appropriations for the next five years for the Drug Enforcement Administration.

title: United Airlines Net Set Record in Half
description: With a 61.8 per cent passenger load factor, improved yieldsreflecting a phasing out of discount faresand tight control over costs, United Airlines, No. 1 in the industry, reported yesterday a record net of $42.6million for the first half of this year.

title: DUTCH ARMS DEMAND TO NATO IS REPORTED
description: BONN, July 11 (Reuters)A Dutch defense official was quoted today as having said that; the Netherlands would withdraw militarily from the: North Atlantic Treaty alliance by 1979 unless it standardized its weapons systems.

title: Parking Here an Issue Between U.S. and Soviet
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11  The United States and the Soviet Union are wrangling again about the parking of diplomatic vehicles on the city's streets outside of reserved spaces.

title: Seaver Will Face Dodgers Tonight
description: The New York Mets will lead with their ace, Tom Seaver, tonight against the Los Angeles Dodgers as they start an eightgame West Coast trip. Two obstacles face Seayer: Tommy John, the Nationai League's leading pitcher, who own a 132 wonlost mark, and Seaver's own sore hip.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Advice on the Judiciary Committee's Report
description: WASHINGTONWhatever may be said about the procedures being followed by the House Judiciary Committee in its impeachment inquiry, it cannot be denied that there is increasing public criticism of those procedures and, more important, that there is growing cynicism and apathy about the efficacy of the impeachment process itself.

title: BURMAH CANCELS GEON MERGER BID
description: Burmah Oil, Inc., which has been negotiating for the purchase of Geon Industries, Inc., for more than six months, said yesterday it considered the agreement terminated. In a letter to Goon, a company whose principal business is the distribution of foreign automobile, aviation and marine parts, Burmah said that a law suit filed on June 27 would adversely affect the properties or business of Geon and made it inadvisable for Burmah to consummate the agreement.

title: CHILEAN ADMITS USE OF POUCH FOR DRUG
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 12 (Reuters) A Chilean spokesman admitted today that diplomatic pouches had been used to smuggle cocaine from this capital to Washington.

title: TROOPERS PATROL BALTIMORE TO BAR RENEWED UNREST
description: BALTIMORE, July 12Gov. Marvin Mandel ordered 115 Maryland state troopers and the state's armored car into Baltimore tonight in an attempt to quell the street violence that has erupted here during a spreading citywide strike of municipal employes.

title: DR. F. C. GRANT, 83, THEOLOGIAN, DIES
description: The Rev. Dr. Frederick Clifton Grant, Edward Robinson Professor Emeritus of Biblical Theology at Union Theological Seminary and an author and leading Biblical scholar, died Thursday in Gwynedd, Pa., where he lived. He was 83 years, old.

title: Common Market Halting Cheese Export Subsidy
description: BRUSSELS, July 12 (AP) The European Common Market announced today that it had suspended its subsidy on cheese exported to the United States. The action, taken in response to pressure from United States producers, will tend to raise the price of imported cheese for Americans.

title: Fining of Bird Scholar Stirs Colleagues
description: Imposition by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service of a $3,000 fine against Dr. Charles G. Sibley, director of Yale's Peabody Museum, for illegally importing birds eggs from Britain has raised a controversy among ornithologists and conservationists here.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES
description: FOREIGN SECURITIES

title: India Charges Troop Activity By Pakistanis in Border Area
description: NEW DELHI, July 12A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that India had observed largescale Pakistani troop movements and maneuvers near the Indian border since the first week of June.

title: Greenspan Nixon's Choice To Head Economic Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 12President Nixon will shortly nominate Alan Greenspan, consulting economist in New York City, to be chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: U.S. Awaits Answers to Plea for Franklin Suitors
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reuters)The Government expects responses within the next 10 days from a number of banks that are considering the possibility of taking over all or part of the financially troubled Franklin National Bank, wellinformed sources said today. agencies to look at the prospect of merging with Franklin, an approach Franklin's chairman, Joseph W. Barr, reportedly favors.

title: Business Briefs
description: CLEVELAND, July 12 (UPI)Charles E. Spahr, chairman of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), announced today that the initial operating rate of the transAlaska pipeline would be doubled from 600,000 barrels daily of crude oil to 1.2 million barrels with completion in mid1977.

title: Matras Set Trial Pace At The Glen
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 12  Mario Andretti's whisper somehow managed to break the sound barrier created by the unmuffled roar of enough race cars to make an aspirin manufacturer delirious.

title: BILL WARD, COACHED TRACK AT ST. JOHN'S
description: Bill Ward, who was coach of track and field and since 1962 director of intramural activities at St. John's University, died yesterday at hisl summer home in Quogue, L. I. He was 64 years old.

title: Lots of Chairs Fold This One Does More
description: Like a snail that can pack its body away in the shell it carries around, a chair imported from Italy can collapse and be neatly packed into its canvas back.

title: CLARK SUIT IS SET BEFORE U.S. PANEL
description: A Federal District Court judge here yesterday ordered the convening of a threejudge court to hear a challenge brought by Ramsey Clark, a contender for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate, against the Liberal party's endorsement of Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: Japanese Premier's Future Is Clouded
description: TOKYO, July 12The resignation of Deputy Premier Takeo Miki today, in the wake of the governing LiberalDemocratic party's setback in the upperhouse election last Sunday, has touched off intense speculation about the political future of Premier Kakuei Tanaka.

title: MALCOLM LA'PRADE, MAN FROM COOK'S
description: Malcolm La Prade, who retired in 1957 as vice president for public relations of Thomas Cook & Son, travel agency, died Thursday at his home, 31 West 12th Street, He was 81 years old.

title: Survivor Says Fire Put Life in Focus
description: Paul Quinlan Jr. lies on his back on the second floor of Greenwich Hospital with sixpound weights attached to each of his hips. He wears jogging shorts and a Tshirt that says Neptune in bright red letters. When his phone rings, he uses one of several greetings: Greenwich Police, Gas company, Geriatrics.

title: Citibank Holds Prime At 12% in Reappraisal
description: The First National City Bank held its prime corporate lending rate to 12 per cent yesterday to allow for a period of reappraisal. The nation's second biggest commercial bank's action is always watched closely in the money market.

title: 10,000 Commuters Are Delayed by Derailment of 12 Freight Cars at Cliffwood
description: CLIFFWOOD, July 12 (UPI) Twelve cars of a 46car freight train of the New York and Long Branch Railroad derailed here early today.

title: Field of 9 Readyfor $200,000 Trot
description: WESTBURY, LI., July 12All nine horses, and eight of the nine drivers, were in per fect shape today awaiting the $200,000 International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night, A crowd of 35,000 is expected to attend the 16th running of the event, the richest trotting race in the world.

title: DEATH AT DIX LAID TO AN AUTO CRASH
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 12  The State Medical Examiner said today that the death of William Wheeler, the 21yearold civilian who was severely injured earlier this week in a remote section of Fort Dix, was unequivocally the result of a motorvehicle accident.

title: Bridge: Detroit Leading New York In National Team Semifinals Events Today Drama of Slam Hands 2 Favored Teams Keep Lead In Bridge Tourney Semifinals
description: The grand national team semifinals continued here last night with Detroit taking an impressive lead of 81 international match points over New York at the threequarter mark.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 12 (UPI)Bjorn Borg of Sweden, seeded No. 1, had to fight all the way today to beat Corrado Barazutti of Italy and qualify as the only Swede to gain the semifinals of the $50,000 Baastad grand prix tennis tournament.

title: M'CLORY SAYS NIXON IS HURT BY VERDICT
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 Representative Robert McClory, the second ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee, said tonight that the conviction of the President's former chief domestic adviser, John D. Ehrlichman, would seriously damage the President's case in the impeachment proceedings.

title: Wilmington Integration Order Poses the Possibility of Busing
description: WILMINGTON, Del., July 12  A threejudge Federal court panel today gave the Delaware Board of Education until Sept. 15 to propose means of desegregating the Wilmington schools.

title: City Playing Host to the Biggest Deal in Bridge
description: A bridge tournament of incomparable size, awesome in its complexity and precision, opened here yesterday.

title: ATLANTIC COLLEGE ASKS FAST INQUIRY
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 12The board of trustees of Atlantic Community College has asked the State Attorney General's office to expedite its inquiry into allegations of misuse of funds and employes by college officials.

title: City Playing Host to the Biggest Deal in Bridge
description: A bridge tournament of incomparable size, awesome in its complexity and precision, opened here yesterday.

title: Tonight's Entries at Roosevelt
description: Tonight's Entries at Roosevelt

title: CONGRESS GAINS WIDE BUDGET ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) President Nixon signed a bill today bringing Congress into the Federal budgetmaking process for the first time and curbing the President's authority to impound authorized funds without Congressional consent.

title: DiLorenzoTrial Jury Chosen; Testimony Is to Start Monday
description: A jury of nine men and three women was completed yesterday in the perjury trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo of Brooklyn and presentation of evidence is expected to begin Monday, following selection of two alternate jurors.

title: Fining of Bird Scholar Stirs Colleagues
description: Imposition by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service of a $3,000 fine against Dr. Charles G. Sibley, director of Yale's Peabody Museum, for illegally importing birds eggs from Britain has raised a controversy among ornithologists and conservationists here.

title: More Pickets Go Up; So Do Fans Tetnpers
description: 0. J. Simpson, whO ran far ahead of everyone in the National Football League last seasont walked at the head of a picket line yesterday as the Buffalo Bills opened their training camp at Niagara University.

title: Arson Suspect Called A Problem by Friends
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 He made attempts to be one of the guys, but he was always in trouble, Ernest Pugliese said today of Peter Leonard, childhood friend. Nobodys going to kave anything good to say about him. I think they found themselves a good patsy.

title: Shorts, Once Called Hot Pants, Survive Because They're Cool
description: When do hot pants become short shorts? Easy. When it's hot. Hot pants were what girls wore in the winter of 1971, with boots and tights to ward off goosebumps. The fad, the pundits tell us, is very dead.

title: New York Stock Exchange Transactions
description: New York Stock Exchange Transactions

title: EHRLICHMAN IS CONVICTED OF PLOT AND PERJURY IN ELLSBERG BREAK IN; LIDDY AND 2 OTHERS ALSO GUILTY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 John D. Ehrlichman, former chief domestic adviser to President Nixon, and three others were found guilty by a jury today of conspiring to violate the civil rights of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's former psychiatrist.

title: 40 POLICE ADDED AT 2 PARKS HERE
description: The police have added 20 men each to their patrols in Central and Prospect Parks following two recent murders of bicyclists and a general rise in crime.

title: Nixon Landing Delayed By Helicopter Trouble
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 12 (AP)President Nixon flew to California today for a twoweek stay, but his helicopter landing at San Clemente was delayed for a few minutes when a red warning light indicated possible difficulty with the landing gear. The helicopter hovered three feet off the ground, while a safety device was attached, and then made a safe landing.

title: DOLLAR SHOWS DIP; GOLD STAYS AT $138
description: BRUSSELS, July 12 (UPI)The dollar declined slightly on money markets today, while gold held steady at $138 an ounce.

title: A Variable Security Yielding 9% Is Offered by West Coast Group
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12While the flap was going on over Citicorp's plans for a floating interestrate note, investors here have been purchasing a similar security of the Transamerica Financial Corporation.

title: Production of Cars Fell 20% for Week From Period in 73
description: DETROIT, July 12 (AP)The first 1975model car rolls off a Ford assembly line next Monday, after a week of production scheduled at 137,229 cars for the industry.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Three Stratford Borough policemen were indicted on charges of conspiring to cover up an auto accident involving a police officer, the Camden County Prosecutor's office said. A spokesman for the Prosecutor said a grand jury handed up an indictment Thursday against Sgt. James Fuller. Lieut. William Gahgan and Capt. Raymond Dean.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, July 12 After two years of planning, Rutgers University will launch its first women's varsity sports program at the university level next fall with seven teams and a 14woman coaching staff. And before the year is out, Rutgers may also make available its first athletic scholarship for a woman.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: ClosedEnd Funds Cash Prices LONDON METAL MARKET

title: Market Place.:
description: An investor who says he owns $200,000 of New York City's taxexempt bonds and has confidence in them for the future is nevertheless distressed by some current advertising, stressing the fact that under the Constitution of New York State bondholders may be paid even before the Mayor, firemen and policemen.

title: Humphrey Backer Is Found Innocent In Loan of $100,000
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 12 (AP) A Federal judge today found a Minneapolis financier, Dwayne Andreas, innocent of making an illegal loan to the 1968 Presidential campaign of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey. Judge Edward J. McMannus ruled that Mr. Andreas was not; guilty of violating a Federal statute prohibiting corporate contributions.

title: Wilson's Election Edge as Incumbent Kept Whetted by Chief Labor Aide
description: Lou Levine is part of the incumbent's edge for Governor Wilson in this election year.

title: LatinAmerican Quake
description: BOULDER, Colo., July 12 (AP)A major earthquake was recorded last night on the border between Panama and Colombia about 185 miles south of Panama City, the National Earthquake Center reported. The quake measured 7.3 on the Richter scale and was potentially damaging, officials here said. However, no reports of damage had been received.

title: Blumenthal Backs Samuels and Cuomo To Lead Democrats
description: Albert H. Blumenthal, deputy minority leader of the Assembly and the Liberal party's candidate for Mayor last year, endorsed Howard J. Samuels and Mario M. Cuomo yesterday for the Democratic nominations for Governor and Lieutenant Governor.

title: GAIN SEEN IN FIGHT ON SECRECY BY U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The Nixon Administration says it has declassified more than 50 million pages of government documents since 1972 and has cut by 71 per cent the number of employes authorized to classify information as secret.

title: Dobson Hurls 2Hitter
description: The best lastplace team in baseball, the New York Yankees beat the best firstplace team, the world champion Oakland A's, 30, last night at Shea Stadium. Pat Dobson hurled a brilliant twohitter for his third straight victory over the A's this season as the Yankees won their fifth game in a row and the eighth of their last nine games.

title: MOSCOW CRITICAL OF U.S. LIBERALS
description: MOSCOW, July 12A prominent Soviet analyst of American affairs warned tonight that detente was still threatened, not only by outright opponents of good SovietAmerican relations, but by wellmeaning liberals distracted from the main goal by side issues.

title: Argentine Labor Picks Leaders to Set Course for the New Era
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 12 For two days, about $00 Argentine labor delegates milled about the plushly carpeted lobbies and auditorium of Teatro San Martin, a multistoried cultural center in the heart of this bustling capital.

title: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings
description: Major League Baseball Box Scores and Standings

title: Seoul Military Court Dooms Dissident Poet
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, July 13 (Reuters)  A court  martial today condemned a major South Korean dissident poet,. Kim ChiHa, five students and a leftist after convicting them of having participated in a studentled plot to overthrow the Government and install Communist regime.

title: Stocks Make Best Gain Since May of 1973 On Decline in Demand for Business Loans
description: The stock marget got the medicine it needed yesterdaya dose of good newsand leaped to its best gain in more than a year.

title: Hazardous Diplomacy
description: From a foreign policy standpoint, defenders of Amercan arms sales argue that if this country does not supply the arms, other countriesthe Soviet Union and France, for examplewill do so. There surely is some truth to this argument; but it also may be dangerously selfdelusive, depending on the specific circumstances particular arms sales. Selling huge quantities of sophisticated military equipment to another countrywhich may decide to exercise its sovereign right to use that equipment  represents an important foreignpolicy decision for the United States. If a nation receiving American weapons uses them in warfare with its neighbors, the issue of resupplying that nation quickly arises. The United States may in effect be committed to one side in the war if it does resupply or to the other side if it does not.

title: Israel, for the First Time, Gives Basis of Talks With Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, July 12Information Minister Aharon Yariv said tonight that negotiations between Israel and the Palestinian guerrilla organizations could be held if the Palestinians would acknowledge the existence of Israel as a Jewish state and terminate hostile actions against her.

title: OffDuty Bridge Patrolman Shot Near Home in Jamaica
description: Two teenagers and a man in his late twenties jumped an offduty Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority patrolman last night near his home in Jamaica, Queens, shot him once, in the right side and escaped, with his service revolver, the police reported.

title: View on Jaworski Dismissal
description: HOUSTON, July 12 (UPI)The president of the American Bar Association said yesterday there was a strong possibility that the special Watergate prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, would be dismissed, especially if he wins his Supreme Court case on White House tapes President Nixon seeks to withhold. I think there is some possibility Mr. Jaworski may be terminated or fire, said Chesterfield Smith of Lakeland, ???

title: Radio
description: 6.9 AM., WQXR. Excerpts from Water Music, Handel; Le Ballet des Ages, Campra; Overture to Acis and Galatea, Haydn; Violin Concerto No. 3, SaintSaens; Tabor from My Country, Smetana; Overture to La Forza del Destino, Verdi; Prelude for Orchestra, Scriabin; Symphony No, 1, Hanson.

title: Iran Asks U.N Action to Keep Region Free of Nuclear Arms
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12  Iran asked today for United Nations action to keep nuclear weapons out of the Middle East.

title: MORTGAGE NEEDS AIRED AT HEARING
description: A wide array of solutions to the problem of the critical scarcity of residentialmortgages funds  including more more government subsidies for interest paycents and changes in banking laws and lending policies were propsed here yesterday.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the capitalist who is promoting big deals with Moscow, predicts that one result of President Nixon's recent visit there will be Soviet recognition of Israel.

title: Booming Arms Trade
description: The world economy may be heading for a slump, but the international arms trade is booming. The world market leader in this unsavory competition is the United States which, in the fiscal year that ended last month, sold some $8.5 billion in arms, almost doubling its sales in a single year. About $7 billion of the American weapons were sold in the Middle East and Persian Gulf area.

title: Sneed Leads. Quad Cities By a Stroke
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, July 12 (AP)Ed Sneed, a struggling tour alsoran until a week ago, carded a sixunderpar 65 today for a onestroke lead at the midway point of the $100,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament.

description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: Show Tunes Sung By Barbara. Cook In Full, True Voice
description: The Broadway musical theater of the nineteenfifties and sixties owed a great deal to the scrubbed, schoolgirl charm and glowing voice of Barbara Cook. Slim and applecheeked, with long blond hair and a surprisingly big voice, Miss Cook sang Cunegonde in the original production of Candide. She was Marian the Librarian in The Music Man. She also appeared in She Loves Me, The Gay Life and revivals of The King and I, Carousel and Show Boat.

description: World Football League

title: Nixon Portrait Missing
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., July 12 (AP)A fullcolor portrait of President Nixon was discovered missing from the lobby of the Federal Building here yesterday.

title: Greenspan Nixon's Choice To Head Economic Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 12President Nixon will shortly nominate Alan Greenspan, a consulting economist in New York City, to be chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

title: IMPEACHMENT PANEL BARS TV AT DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that the committee's debate on proposed artticles of impeachment would not be televised. However, he said that the debate would be open to the public.

title: COMPANIES ISSUE EARNINGS FIGURES
description: ?? higher prices for aluminum, it was reported yesterday.

title: National Steel Plans Plant
description: PITTSBURGH, July 12 (AP)The National Steel Corporation announced plans yesterday to construct a new plant at LaGrange, Ga., for its subsidiary, the StranSteel Corporation. The new plant will manufacture metal building systems for the Southeast market and will provide about 200 new jobs, the company said.

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
description: United States Government and Agency Bonds

title: Apodaca Victor, 52
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12The New York Mets called upon their reserves tonight and the reserves produced a 5.2 victory over the Los Angeles Dqdgers before crowd of 50,12D in Dodger Stadium.

title: Dave Anderson
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 12In a moment of modesty about six years ago, Al Davis, the overseer of the Oakland Raiders, was discussing the potential for forming new pro football league.

title: New Device to Produce Synthetic Furs Patented
description: WASHINGTON, July 12A Massachusetts textile specialist and art collector received this week the third of a trio of patents that cover the production of manmade furs. The machine patented this week by Daniel Frishman of Andover, Mass., adds luster and a furlike appearance to the basic pile fabric knitted by such machines as the one he patented last month. The electric apparatus disclosed this week, as Dr. Frishman explains, combines mechanical action and heat to convert a woolly surface into a furlike array of fibers.

title: MURDER CONVICTION BRINGS DAMAGE SUIT
description: A $2million damage suit was filed against the state by Robert Grimaldi, whose conviction for the 1972 Queens murder of Conrad Greaves, a witness in a racket inquiry, was reversed by the Appellate Division in April.

title: CLARK SUIT IS SET BEFORE U.S. PANEL
description: A Federal District Court judge here yesterday ordered the convening of a threejudge court to hear a challenge brought by Ramsey Clark, contender for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate, against the Liberal party's endorsement of Senator Jacob K. Javits.

title: Wheat, Corn and Soybeans Rise; Silver Off as London Prices Fall
description: Wheat, corn and soybean futures prices jumped the daily limits at the opening of trading yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices were responding to the Government's crop report issued after the close on Thursday. Its estimates were significantly lower than earlier forecasts released by the Government.

title: 2 Favored Teams Retain Bridge in Semifinals
description: The grand national team semifinals continued here last night, with the two 1 favored teams holding modest leads. Playing at the Americana Hotel, New York led at the halfway mark by the tiny margin of three international match points against Detroit, while Los Angeles was 22 points ahead of St. Louis.

title: 50,000 Join Ulster Protestants Parade
description: BELFAST; Northern Ireland, July 12Fifty thousand Protestant marchers, elated by their recent overthrow of the power sharing Northern Ireland government, paraded here today in Northern Ireland's biggest Orange Day celebrations.

title: The Way They Stand Today
description: The Way They Stand Today

title: 640 Houses Planned in the Jersey Meadows
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., July. 11Plans for the first major housing development in the Hackensack Meadowlands Development District640 town houses that could expand to 5,00Q units in the futurehave been submitted by Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc., for approval lby the state and Federal Governments.

title: Detente Around The Edges?
description: PARISI cannot understand why the United States, so earnestly seeking detente with all the important power blocs, pays so little apparent attention to small sores festering along the edges.

title: AirConditioner Sales Slackening
description: High prices, the drop in homebuilding and the unwillingness of many landlords to add necessary wiringcombined with unseasonably cool weatherhave curtailed the sale of airconditioners thus far this year.

title: 42 Missing as the Midway Leaves Her Base in Japan
description: TOKYO, July 12 (Reuters)Fortytwo crewmen missed the sailing of the United States aircraft carrier Midway when she pulled out of Yokosuka naval base Tuesday, a Navy spokesman disclosed today.

title: Citicorp Revises Securities Offering
description: An offering by Citicorp of $850million in a controversial and novel type of security cleared two major hurdles yesterday after the bankholding company agreed to alter the terms of the proposed offering. It still was uncertain when the issue would be offered to the public.

title: Three Bills on Strip Mining Sent To House Floor by Rules Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The House Rules Committee has voted to sand three stripmining bills to the House floor for debate, including a proposal to ban the practice entirely The action yesterday by the committee should guarantee a lengthy, wideopen debate on the topic. The legislation is scheduled for action next Friday, and it could be several days before a final vote is taken.

description: A 17yearold Harlem youth, one of three young men arrested in the slaying 22 months ago of Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann, a noted law professor, was sentenced to up to 18 years in prison yesterday on his plea of guilty to having robbed the Columbia University scholar.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Nixon Administration has lost control of the United States policy of maintaining a political and economic quarantine against Cuba, in the opinion of Government officials specializing in Latin American affairs. Pat M. Holt, staff director of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who met with Premier Fidel Castro in Havana Saturday, is also understood to believe that Mr. Castro and others in Latin America have begun to determine the pace and direction of Cuba's breakout from hemisphere isolation. This view reportedly is shared by a growing number of Latin American governments. [1:78.]

title: HERMAN GLICK
description: Herman Glick, vice president of Glick Brothers, a chain of meat markets in Brooklyn and Long Island, died of a heart attack Wednesday in the Coney Island Hospital. He was 46 years old and lived in Sands Point, L. I., and Hollywood, Fla.

title: SelfRule Likely for Portuguese Guinea
description: LISBON, July 12The new military  dominated cabinet that is expected to be announced here shortly reportedly will grant independence in the next few weeks to Portuguese Guinea, one of three African territories where Portuguese troops have been battling liberation movements for 12 years.

title: YachtWatching Weekend
description: Yachtwatchers have a choice this weekend. They can see hundreds of yachts in Long Island Sound competing Larchmont Yacht Club's 76th annual race week or watch two or three 12Meter craft in the America's Cup observation trials off Newport, R. I.

title: PRICES ON AMEX MOVE FORWARD
description: Reversing the trend thus far this year, prices on the American Stock and the overthecounter market bounded upward yesterday, Exchange trades dipped slightly on the Amex but showed a slight increase in the counter market.

description: Mayor Beame yesterday unexpectedly ordered that round theclock talks begin with the unions representing firemen and sanitationmen.

title: Girl Who Failed Badminton Test Scores a Point at Bias Hearing
description: TRENTON, July 12 (AP)A State Department of Education hearing examiner tentatively ruled today that a high school girl who had been denied a diploma because she had failed written badminton and tennis tests had provided a primafacie case of discrimination.

description: A series of five opera specials, originally to be presented on a limited number of public television stations next season, has been canceled for lack of sufficient production funds.

title: EDWARD HOLLOWAY, A TAXLAW EXPERT
description: Edward Holloway, a specialist in corporate, tax., estate and trust law here for 59 years, died Thursday in White Plains Hospital of a stroke. He was 83 years old and lived at 1 Edgemont Road, Scardsdale, N.Y.

title: Wide Meat Mislabeling Found In State FoodStores Inspection
description: A recent statewide inspection of 71 food stores for suspected mislabeling of meat disclosed 4,000 labeling violations, according to Thomas W. Kelly, an agent for the state's Office of Weights and Measures.

description: NEW DELHI, July 12 The bold antiinflation measures Prime Minister Indira Gandhi announced last weekend have run into serious opposition.

description: Lawrence S. Freundlich stole a glance at his watch as he sipped his plastic cup of ChateauLascomhes 1967 and he said with a smile, I just need it to calm my nerves.

description: TEL AVIV, July 12The Israeli Cabinet, seeking ways to fight inflation, proposed today that employers and employes be required to make loans to the state.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A surge of ticket buying was touched off yesterday at the American Ballet Theater following the announcement of three forthcoming appearances by Mikhail Baryshnikov, the ballet star who defected last month in Toronto from a Soviet company. A line for tickets began forming before the box office opened at 10 A.M. At one point during the day, ticket seekers waited as long as two and a half hours to obtain seats for one of the three scheduled appearancesJuly 27, Aug. 5 and Aug. 9. Long before closing of the box office, which is open from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M., Monday through Saturday, the last of the tickets in the 2,779seat house for the first appearance had been sold. Only few seats still remained for the other two performances, a spokesman said.

title: BYRNE CAMPAIGNS FOR HIS TAX PLAN
description: TOMS RIVER, July 12Governor Byrne retraced the steps of his triumphal electioncampaign trail in Ocean County today, not looking for votes this time, but in his words, to talk about the problems of government.
