description: Mrs. Elizabeth Ames Cleveland, wife of J. Luther Cleveland, retired chairman of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Thursday in Winter Haven, Fla., at the age of 76. She lived in Lake Wales, Fla., and formerly in Pelham, N. Y.

title: Fodor, Home From Moscow Triumph, Trades Violin for Cow Boots Briefly
description: MORRISON, Colo., July 12 The aspen leaves were silver in the wind. The meadows where elk graze were still, and the sun was hot.

title: 2d Ave. Subway Plan Includes A Provision for Widening Street
description: The Second Avenue subway is being designed and built so that the street above can be widened later to handle more traffic by cutting back the sidewalks five feet on each side.

title: More Nonwhites in Ouard
description: BOSTON, July 12 (AP)Increasedminority enlistments in the. Massechusetts National Guard. In the last year have brought the total nonwhite complement in the guard to 4 per cent, Maj. Gen. Vahan Vartanian, the guard's adjutant general, said today.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, JULY 13, 1974
description: The Nixon Administration has lost control of the United States policy of maintaining a political and economic quarantine against Cuba, in the opinion of Government officials specializing in Latin American affairs. Pat M. Holt, staff director of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, who met with Premier Fidel Castro in Havana Saturday, is also understood to believe that Mr. Castro and others in Latin America have, begun to determine the pace and direction of Cuba's breakout from hemisphere isolation. This view reportedly is shared by a growing number of Latin American governments. [1:78.]

title: Justin E. Morrill Dead; Retired Director of U.S.G.
description: Justin E. Morrill, retired national director of the United Service Organizations, died yesterday in Palo Alto, Calif., while on a visit. He Was 69 years old and lived at 310 East 55th Street.

title: Antiques: Delight in Toys
description: To assemble the 200 playthings for the Toys From the Attic exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, John Noble investigated on his hands and knees all the storage areas under the museum's eaves.

title: Issue and Debate
description: While professional football's newest league began with a flourish this week, its oldest languished under the burden of a player strike. Established players picketed training camps, whose occupants were rookies and free agents; the College AllStar game was canceled and both sides took turns lashing out at each other.

title: TROOPERS PATROL BALTIMORE TO BAR RENEWED UNREST
description: BALTIMORE, July 12Gov. Marvin Mandel ordered 115 Maryland state troopers and the state's armored car into Baltimore tonight in an attempt to quell the street violence that has erupted here during a spreading citywide strike of municipal employes.

title: 640House Development Planned for Meadowlands
description: SECAUCUS, N.J., July 11Plans for the first major housing development in the Hackensack Meadowlands Development District640 town houses that could expand to 5,000 units in the futurehave been submitted by Hartz Mountain Industries, Inc., for approval by the state and Federal Governments.

title: Stocks Rise Sharply
description: The stock market yesterday scored its biggest gain in more than a year, pushing the DowJones industrial average up 27.61 points. The market was primed for the advance by a report that businessloan demand at major banks here had slowed. Details on Page 31.

title: Charlie Caldwell, Dead Before His Time
description: Charlie Caldwella black man, age 32, resident of Mount Vernon, N. Y.died in his apartment on the morning of Oct. 19. For the last five years he had been in and out of jail for a variety of drug bustswe first became friends when I taught an English college course in the Westchester County Pen and was a political radical. The last year of his life he had become much loved and respected as the leader of youth program in the community. The police claim that he died from an overdose; his friends insist he was not junkie and believe he was murdered, mysteriously and for an unknown motive. In either account, his death appears irrational and inexplicable, the kind of sudden, violent end we have become accustomed to hearing about in the last few years.

title: William Rosenthal, Dean Of Social Work at Yeshiva
description: Dr. William A. Rosenthal, dean of the Wurzweiler School of Social Work at Yeshiva University, died yesterday at home after a long illness. He was 54 years old and lived at 239 Hart Avenue, S. I.

title: French See Disconnection In Narcotics Link to U.S.
description: PARIS, July 12The role of Marseilles as a crucial link in heroin traffic to the United States may have ended, some French antidrug experts believe.

title: MAN FIRES AT POLICE AND IS SLAIN BY THEM
description: A 25yearold Brooklyn man being frisked with two companions by two police officers last night fired a shot at the officers and was killed with several shots in the return fire, the police reported.

title: FORD SAYS NIXON HAS BEEN CLEARED
description: SANTA FE, N. M., July 12Vice President Ford said today that new evidence as well as the old evidence exonerated President Nixon of any impeachable offense.

title: Mayor Takes WalkTalk Show to S.I.
description: The Mayor's walk and talk road show moved onto Staten Island last night, with Mr. Beame leading a jaunt through two older business districts in an effort to lend a hand to the neighborhood shopping strips.

title: Fire in Bar That Killed 24 Is Laid to Greenwich Man
description: A 22yearold unemployed Greenwich, Conn., man was charged by Connecticut authorities yesterday with setting the fire that killed 24 young people and injured 32 othcrs two weeks ago in a singles bar astride the New YorkConnecticut border.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BUT STUFF Film books, film magazines and film memorabilia have grown from a diversion to an obsession to an industry. There's a store in Greenwich Village catering especially to cultists with thousands of books, hundreds of thousands of magazines on file and all kinds of items to do with the movies.

title: Detroit's Long School Year Finally Ends
description: DETROIT, July 12At 11:40 this morning, the dismissal bell finally rang for the last time at John E. Clark elementary; school on Detroit's northeast; side. The longest school yearor so it has seemed to many Detroiterswas over at last.

title: Tigers Horton Disabled
description: DETROIT, July 12 (UPI)The Detroit Tigers announced today that Willie Horton would be hospitalized tomorrow and may have to undergo knee surgery. The slugging left fielder, who injured his right knee when he ran into the grandstand wall in Tiger Stadium in May, was placed on the 15day disabled list. Detroit purchased Jim Nettles from its Evansville farm club in the American Association to replace him.

title: INSURER IS BLOCKED ON CNA PURCHASES
description: Judge Prentice H. Marshall, of the Federal District Court in Chicago, issued a preliminary injunction yesterday to prevent the Accident and Casualty Insurance Company of Winterthur, Switzerland, froth soliciting purchases of large blocks of stock of the CNA Financial Corporation.

title: 2 Share Lead In Borden Golf
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 12 (UPI)Sharon Miller andMardell Wilkins shot threaUnderpar 69s today to share the firstround lead in the $40,000 Borden women's golf tournament. A field of 81 teed off.

title: Grain Crop Points to Meat Price Rise
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 The more moderate prospect for grain harvests is likely to have little effect on retail prices this year, but may cause a reduction in the production of livestock and thus put upward pressure on meat prices in 1975, the Agriculture Department's chief economist said today.

title: A Man Of Property
description: WASHINGTON, July 12  For most Americans, it is bewildering and too painful to contemplate the possibility that Richard Nixon entered the White House in 1969 fully intending to use the Presidency to make himself a rich man. Since the Presidency is sanctified in our national imagination, it boggles the mind to think that any man who has won this great honor might see it as a wonderful opportunity to line his pockets.

title: N.F.L. Impasse Holds
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP)Negotiators for striking National Football League players and the league's 26 teams met for seven hours today and made no progress toward resolving the 12dayold walkout, the Federal mediator reported.

title: ROBERT N. KAY
description: Robert N. Kay, vice president and chief administrative officer of the trust department of the Bank of New York, died Wednesday at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 57 years old and made his home here.

title: DEATH AT DIX LAID TO AN AUTO CRASH
description: MOUNT HOLY, July 12The State Medical Examiner said today that the death of William Wheeler, the 21yearold civilian who was severely injured earlier this week in a remote section of Fort Dix, was unequivocally the result of a motorvehicle accident.

title: Back to the Bike
description: The Federal Government's decision to mandate safety standards for bicycles reflects the phenomenal reemergence of the bike as a popular mode of transportation in the United States. Bicycle sales doubled from less than seven million in 1970 to more than fifteen million last year, outstripping the sale of automobiles for the first time since World War 1.

title: Blind Man in Missouri Gets Darkroom Technician's Job
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo. (AP)After a long wait, 50yearold Joe Elliot has finally landed an ideal job. Mr. Elliot, blind since birth, is now working as a darkroom technician at the Kansas City College of Osteopathic Medicine.

title: Earl Warren Is Buried in Army Rites at Arlington
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 Earl Warren, the former Chief Justice whose decisions helped change the social and legal fabric of the nation, was buried on a grassy slope at Arlington National Cemetery today.

title: Crop Forecasts Analyzed to Give Range in Outlook
description: In a followup to the corn and soybean acreage report issued Thursday, the Department of Agriculture issued an economic analysis of the crop production outlook, using a new minimum and maximum range of estimates.

title: U.S. Is Set to Begin Talks on Relations With East Germany
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (Reuters)The United States will open negotiations Monday on establishing diplomatic relations with East Germany, a State Department spokesman said today.

title: ARMY SAYS IT SEIZED A TOP SELASSIE AIDE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 12 (UPI)  The army said today that it had arrested close adviser to Emperor Haile Selassie. The adviser, Ras Mesfin Silleshi, one of the most powerful men in Ethiopia, was the top man on the army's most wanted list.

title: Notes on People
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the capitalist who is promoting big deals with Moscow, predicts that one result of President Nixon's recent visit there will be Soviet recognition of Israel.

description: Paperback publishers plan to rush out editions of the texts of the Senate Watergate committee report, which was handed over to the Government Printing Office yesterday, and of the final report on impeachment of the House Judiciary Committee; which is expected to be made public around the end of this month.

title: HAROLD HENDERSON, JAPANESE SCHOLAR
description: Harold Gould Henderson, who retired in 1956 as profeisor of Japanese language and arts history at Columbia University, died Thursday at his summer home in Hunter, N. Y. He was 84 years old and lived at 179 East 70th Street.

title: Intrepid and Courageous Race in Cup Trial Today
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 12 The second set of trials to select the yacht to defend the America's Cup in September will begin here tomorrow. There are three candidates present, Courageous, Intrepid and Valiant, and one absentee, Mariner. The latter is being rebuilt in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and will miss this series, called the observation trials, but will be present for the final trials beginning Aug. 15.

title: FATHER OF 3 HELD AS SLAYER OF WIFE
description: HACKENSACK, July 12 (AP) George North of Englewood Cliffs, a father of three children whose wife was found decapitated on Wednesday in upstate New York, was charged today with her murder.

title: And This Is About Conceptual Art
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.When I was lonely I used to look at the moon and tell myself that the same moon could be seen at the same moment across the sea by the persons I loved. In that comforting thought there was a germ of poetry, good enough perhaps for the notebook of a writer; but it was no poem.

title: Cotton Markets
description: Cotton Markets

title: The Chronicle and Nixon's Role
description: WASHINGTON, July 12The House Judiciary Committee's long chronicle of President Nixon's role in the aftermath of the Watergate burglary is meticulously detailed, but the impact of the eight thick volumes of impeachmerit evidence is deliberately indirect. Nowhere in the 3,891 pages of the impeachment inquiry staff's presentation is there a flat declaration that Mr. Nixon engaged in a Watergate coverup. But the burden of the material, implicit on page after page in the view of those familiar with the evidence, is that Mr. Nixon at best did not halt and at worst directed the obstruction of the Watergate investigation.

title: F.D.I.C. INTERVENTION IN BANK SUIT IS SET
description: SAN DIEGO, July 12 (AP)A Federal Judge said he plans to allow the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation to intervene in a lawsuit filed by minority shareholders of the insolvent United States National Bank.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 12 (UPI)Bjorn Borg Sweden, seeded No. 1, had to fight all the way today rto beat Corrado Barazutti of Italy and qualify as the only Swede to gain the semifinals of the $50,000 Baastad grand prix tennis tournament.

title: Cards Gibson Gets 2,999th StrikeOut But Loses His 9th Game, 73, to Braves
description: Winning pitchers are consistent, and that word could be Bob Gibson's middle name. Through 1972 the St. Louis righthander had recorded nine seasons in which he struck out 200 or more batters.

description: KALAMAZOO, Mich.  Residents of New Horizon Village are beginning to feel as if they have been orphaned at an early age.

description: ATLANTA (NL)Activated Norm Miller, outfielder. Optioned Sonny Jackson, outfielder, to Richmond of the International League.

title: Ervin Panel Urges A Public Attorney In Its Final Report
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) The Senate Watergate committee formally went out of business today, and its chairman said the committee recommended creation of a new office of public attorney to handle cases in which public officials are charged with wrongdoing.

title: PETERSEN BACKS NIXON IN INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, July 12Henry E. Petersen, who was in charge of the original Watergate investigation, defended today President Nixon's conduct in the days after the prosecutors began to break the case.

title: Nicklaus Moves Within 4 Strokes of Lead In British Open as Player Slips to 75212
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 12In a brilliantly erratic round of golf that included a stretch of birdie, birdie, eagle, Jack Nicklaus came from nine strokes back to within four today of Gary Player, still the British Open leader with a oneunderpar total of 212 after three rounds.

title: She Tired of Just Making Candles
description: On most days, the otherwise attractive living room in the East Fifties apartment of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Delehanty has in it a pile of empty milk and orange juice cartons, discarded tissue boxes, cans that once contained tuna fish and soda pop, matchbook covers, small cardboard trays that have held tomatoes or green peppers, openwork cardboard boxes once filled with strawberries or blueberries, and other debris usually thrown away as quickly as possible.

title: Horseplayers Find Way to Beat 5% Surtax
description: Horseplayers with telephone accounts at the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation have found a way to beat the new 5 per cent surtax. They are switching their action upstate to the PhoneaBet Department in Schenectady, whose Off track Betting Commission is preparing a court challenge to the surtax. Under a new state law, all OTB operations outside New York City must begin levying the tax on offtrack payoffs by the end of next month.

title: Both Sides in Henley Trial Rest
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 12  After a week of grisly testimony by the prosecution, both sides rested today in the mass murder trial of Elmer Wayne Henley Jr.

title: A PERRY OSBORN JR:
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 12A. Perry Osborn Jr., vice president of the board of directors in charge of public affairs at the Burke Rehabilitation Center here, died yesterday in Garrison. He was 57 years old.

title: MORTGAGE PAYMENT IS DELAYED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) President Nixon has arranged a sixmonth postponement of his final mortgage payment on his San Clemente estate, officials said today.

title: Sneed Leads Quad Cities By a Stroke
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, July 12 (AP)Ed Sneed, a struggling tour alsoran until week ago, carded a sixunderpar 65 today for a onestroke lead at the midway point of the $100,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament.

title: Tremors in Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, July 19 (UPI) Three earth tremors jolted this mountain capital within a 13minute period this morning but there were no reports of damage.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Alyeska Pipeline Service Company announced yesterday that it had awarded contracts totaling $85million to two companies and another $13million contract to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in connection with the construction of the 798mile transAlaska pipeline. Alyeska, a consortium of oil companies, said that the award was given to Sumitomo Shoji American Inc., of Japan, and International Portable Pipe Mills, Ltd., of Calgary, Alberta.

title: Toll in Watergate: Total of 36 Verdicts Or Pleas of Guilty
description: With the conviction in Washington yesterday of John D. Ehrlichman and three codefendants, the Watergate scandal has now produced 36 verdicts or pleas of guilty. In addition, five persons have been cleared of charges arising from the scandal and at least seven others await trials.

title: Raskind in Net Final
description: GREAT NECK, LI., July 12 Rey Garrido of Huntington and Dr. Richard Raskind of New York gained the final of the New York State 35yearsandover tennis championship today at the Great Neck Tennis Center. Garrido defeated Otto Merunko of Great Neck, 64, 61, and Raskind eliminated Bob Barker of Sands Point, 62, 26, 63.

title: 30 in Drug Ring Sentenced in France
description: MARSEILLES, Franch, July 12 (UPI)A judge here sentenced 30 convicted heroin traffickers today to prison sentences ranging from six month to 18 years.

title: SENATE UNIT VOTES F.T.C. DATA REQUEST
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today Federal Trade Commission request to collect certain business data on 500 companies.

title: BONN IS PLANNING BIG TAX CUT IN 75
description: BONN, July 13  West German authorities are planning a significant tax reduction next year to increase the purchasing power of consumers and to check the recessionary forces gathering in Europe's biggest economy.

title: Man Jailed for Car Deaths
description: SYRACUSE, July 12 (AP)Carlton H. Shover Jr., 22 years old, of Elbridge, was sentenced today to four years in prison for the deaths of two Syracuse men in a road accident. Onondaga County Court Judge Albert Orenstein sentenced the defendant for criminally negligent homicide in an accident on June 10, 1973, in which the car he as driving struck the rear of a motorcycle carrying Calvin J. Fisher and Gary W. Ward. Both were killed. Mr; Shover also received a oneyear sentence for driving while intoxicated. The terms are to be served concurrently.

title: Del Webb Left $1.5Millibn, Tax Paid, to Second Wife
description: LOS ANGELES, July 12 (AP) Del E. Webb willed a taxpaid $1.5million to his second wife and $75,000 a year for life to his first wife, court records show.

description: WASHINGTON, July 12One of two armed convicts holding seven hostages in the Federal Courthouse here vowed tonight to take a lot of people with him if the pair were not guaranteed their freedom.

title: Congress Is Urged to Standardize the Effects of Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 Two different brands of the same drug do not always behave identically in the patient who swallows them, a report to Congress said today.

title: Maalot, Badly Scarred, Is Still in Limelight
description: MAALOT, Israel, July 11The bullet holes in the classroom walls have been plastered over and the bloodstains scrubbed from the tile floors. The shattered windows have been replaced, and someone has written on the blackboard in colored chalk: Happy summer vacation.

title: Art: Nine Shows in One at the Guggenheim
description: The big summer show that now fills the entire exhibition space of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is an event of exceptional interest. Indeed, it is really nine events of exceptional interest. For the museum has selected from its sizable permanent collection the works of nine modern masters  Picasso, Leger, Brancusi, Chagall, Mondrian, Klee, Kandinsky, Delaunay and Franz Marcand the result is a succession of oneman shows that dramatically illuminates some of the most crucial developments in the history of modern art.

In the still coolness of her private palazzo on the Grand Canal, her homecummuseum for a quarter century, the words seem to sidle from her mouth and hover in the air, as though eaclosed within cartoon balloons.

title: The Holy Foolery Of Charles Ludlam
description: The Holy Foolery Of Charles LudlamCAMILLE is dying. The glittering courtesan of belle epoque iscoughing her life away under a crystal chandelier, while icy snow descends softly outside her window. Her feverwracked, emaciated body, sinuous under a shroudlike negligee, tosses fitfully, and her luxuriant, blackasnight hair snakes to the floor. The earthy snoring of her faithful maid Naninc, head buried on the dressing table near a statuette of the Madonna, evokes the commonplace world in which Camille is the eternal doomed deviant.

title: Dave Anderson
description: At the British Open each year, the American golfers usually resemble men turned hack in time to the hickory shaft. Instead of the sunny clothes they always seem to be wearing on the tour here, they are bundled in turtlenecks and sweaters. Their eyes squint in the grayness of wind and rain. Lurking everywhere is the swaying tall grass on the dunes that distinguish the seven seaside links where the Open is played, Over there the Open means only the British Open, as if the United States Open never was played once, much less 74 times. But the British Open has been played 103 times. Even the new United States Open champion, Hale Irwin, has needed the appellation of Irwin, the American in order that he might he properly identified to the British there this week. But some Americans don't need an introduction any more. Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, lee Trevino each has won the British Open twice and Tom Weiskopf won it last year. Over there they remember other American golfers of the past, such as Ben Hogan and Sam Snead, Bobby Jones and Walter Hagen. And they remember Tony Lema.

title: Now Lisbon Is Talking On Their Terms

The main reason is that Portugal, having delayed adopting this new policy for too long, must now negotiate froma position of weakness after the decade of attrition inflicted by the African colonial wars in GuineaBissau; Angola and Mozambique. Lisbon cannot by itself lay down the conditions for transferring power. But another important difficulty stems from the differences among the black leaders in the Portuguese territories which make it harder to conduct talks.

title: New British Graphics in Brooklyn
description: THE British are not coming; they are, in fact, already hereby way of an absorbing exhibition of graphic works, New British Printmakers, on view at the Brooklyn Museum, 188 Eastern Parkway, through August 25. The exhibition is comprised of 76 prints by 18 young artists  they range in age from their midtwenties to their midthirtiesfew of whom have been exhibited here before. What makes the Brooklyn show particularly interesting is that it confirms the great revival of interest in graphics both here and in England that has been one of the signal developments in contemporary art.

title: What's Doing in the BERKSHIRES
description: THE MUSESHawthorne, summering in the Berkshires near Lenox to 'recuperate from The Scarlet Letter, was inspired to start The House of Seven Gables, while few miles to the north, in Pittsfield, Melville was writing Moby Dick. At his Stockbridge estate, Chesterwood, Daniel Chester French created his sculpture of the seated Lincoln for the new Memorial rising in Washington, and the youthful Isadore Duncan danced across the lawn to display the Grecian garb French had designed for her. At his Jacob's Pillow retreat in West Becket, Ted Shawn founded a summer festival of the modern dance  (now four decades old). And Serge Koussevitzky transformed Tanglewood from the scene of community tent concerts in the nineteenthirties to an international music center built around the Boston Symphony Orchestra. In New Marlboro there stands a stone memorial to Elihu Burritt, the learned blacksmith who 140 years, ago practiced his trade with a Greek grammar in the crown of his hat for ready reference. He studied 40 languages, including Sanskrit, into which he translated poems by Longfellow, another Berkshires frequenter. In short, while thunderstorms are far from rare in these western Massachusetts mountains, it is the spiritual lightning striking visitors that accounts for the region's cultural glory.

title: AROUND THE
description: This is a fantastic year for roseseveryone has noticed. June especially was crowned with masses of these magnificent blooms. The plants refuse to give up and are continuing with a full summer parade, perhaps not quite as splashy as the June one, but a steady display of color any

title: Player's 282 Takes British Open By 4 Shots for His 3d Victory
description: LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 13  Gary Player won the British Open golf championship today for the third time. He led from start to finish, stifled every challenge and came coasting home with a oneunder par 70 for a total of 282 and a fourstroke marginthe biggest since Tony Lema took the 1964 Open at St. Andrews by five shots over Jack Nicklaus.

title: Colombey, Where Frenchmen Bask in Radiations of Grandeur
description: Do what you like and say what you like, there will be fewer and fewer people who have known Napoleon, a wit remarked 150 years ago. Since his death on Nov. 9, 1970, that sad truth has applied as well to the lordly Charles de Gaulle. But on weekends now, when the weather is fair, as many as 30,000 Frenchmen, along with a few foreign de Gaulle worshippers and the merely curious, throng into de Gaulle's village of ColombeylesDeuxEglises, about 135 miles east of Paris, to bask in whatever radiations of grandeur may still be emanating from his modest tomb in the parish churchyard, and to stand awestruck before a monolithic monster of a cross of Lorraine that looms over the village from atop a hill behind it.

title: Stamps
description: DESPITE the grandiloquentlysounding American World Series or Super Bowl, the most truly global sports event is the World Cup soccer competition that has just ended with the victory of West Germany.

title: Gas Supply Cut Sharply For Users In South
description: FOLSOM  Two naturalgas Companies that serve South Jersey and the Jersey Shore are facing an acute shortage of their product.

title: Learning Language In a Hurry
description: IN the days of Daisy Miller, anybody rich enough to travel could spend three years getting tutored in foreign languages for a Grand Tour, or stalk monolingually through world capitals, dependent on concierges and hired guides with pencil moustaches. Such practices now seem as cumbersome as a Vuitton trunk on a walking trip through the Pyrenees. The modern idea, the 28dayexcursion idea, is to get a quick, practical smattering of the language from conversation lessons, longplaying records or a paperback book. But at Manhattan's New School, jetage innovation marches on, and has given rise to a unique series of OneDay Language Courses for Travelers. (Previous experiments elsewhere with fast languagelearning have spanned several days of intensive sessions.)

title: Rumanians, With Independent Foreign Policy, Are Rigidly Curbed at Home
description: BUCHAREST, July 8 Rumanians seem to be paying ford the relative independence (I) their foreign policy in rigid curbs on free expression. By comparison Poland and Hungary seem like open societies.

title: Philadelphia Club Victor In Relays

The Pioneers took the 440yard, 880yard and onemile relays, setting meet records in the 880yard run and onemile relay with times of 1 minute 23.3 seconds and 3:09.6, respectively.

title: Gary Player Victor In British Open Golf
description: Gary Player of South Africa won the British Open golf championship at Lytham St. Annes, England, by shooting a finalround 70 yesterday. He finished with a 72hole total of 282, four strokes better than Peter Oosterhuis of Britain, the runnerup, and five better than Jack Nicklaus of the United States.

title: Air Pollution Is Affecting Vegetables Grown in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, July 13 (Reuters)Even vegetables grown in Tokyo are decaying from air pollution, Japanese scientists said this week.

title: Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: LET me begin by taking exception to a statement in Vincent Canby's June 234 review of my movie Memories Within Miss Aggie. What has the physical condition of the World Theater to do with the film Mr. Canby is supposed to be reviewing? He says he sat in the balcony of the theater (the theater by the way is undergoing construction) and was met by the unpleasant smell of disinfectant. Unless his olfactory sense is the basis for understanding a film, I cannot understand why this point was included in his review at all.

title: News of the Realty Trade Third Ave. Tower Leases 4 Floors
description: Scala, McCabe, Sloves, Inc., the advertising agency, has leased four floors in the 41story tower at 800 Third Avenue. The 450,000squarefoot building is now twothirds rented.

title: Lynn Peters Has Nuptials
description: Miss Ann Lynn Peters and Dr. John Richard Morris were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Paul Coleman.

title: GOV. WILSON CALLED ANTILIBERTARIAN
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday labeled Governor Wilson as one of the most antilibertarian governors in this state's history and gave him a 27 per cent civil liberties rating for his action on 18 bills passed by the Legislature and sent to him for action.

title: Television This Week
description: 2:30 P.M. (4) FILM: The Grapes of Wrath (1940). Henry Fonda, Jane Darwell, John Carradine. The American screen at its peak.

title: Prepared Childbirth Method Growing in Acceptance on L.I.
description: It's really the ultimate experience, said Mark Rosenthal of Nesconset, a husband who had been allowed to be present in the delivery room when his wife, Carol, gave birth, without drugs or anesthesia, to their second child. The Rosenthals were among thousands of Long Island couples who have been trained in the Lamaze technique of prepared, childbirth, which has been gaining acceptance by obstetricians and hospital administrations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: GAMBLER IS SHOT WALKING TO CAR
description: A 62yearold convicted gambler with a record of 38 arrests was shot and seriously wounded late Friday night after leaving a social club in the Borough Hall section of Brooklyn.

title: Deborah Baldwin Fiancee of Irwin Arieff
description: Miss Deborah Baldwin, a greatgranddaughter of Ruth Bowles Baldwin, cofounder of the National Urban League, and Irwin B. Arieff plan to marry July 27in New Canaan, Conn., at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Baldwin Jr., who have announced the engagement of the couple.

title: Struggling to create a humane society
description: For a portion of its length James Comer's book is an autobiography  a rise story about a frail East Chicago black lad who makes it to med school and miles beyond. His account of his schoolboy's working summer in a black job (the grease pits at Youngstown Sheet and Tool) records, shatteringly, the choked accents and gestures of black workers in a locker room on the day word passed of the murder of Emmett Till. (Till was the 14yearold youngster who was murdered in Mississippi two decades ago for allegedly whistling at a white woman.) Comer as a college senior remembers an admissions interview by med school faculty seemingly bent on disqualifying him for forgetting a U. S. Attorney General's name. Comer, the young interne on clinical assignment in pediatrics loses a 7yearold black girl injured in a car accident. The child, internally bleeding, was set down outdoors uncared for, because the Negro ward  was crowded.

title: GOV. WILSON CALLED ANTILIBERTARIAN
description: The New York Civil Liberties Union yesterday labeled Governor Wilson as one of the most antilibertarian governors in this state's history and gave him a 27 per cent civil liberties rating for his action on 18 bills passed by the Legislature and sent to him for action.

title: Americans abroad and corruption in the air
description: Although it was hideously overpraised for the doubtful virtue of being full of restrainta rare virtue in an age when novels have their pretensions sticking out a mile, but hardly something to make a reader keel over with admirationJohn Knowles's A Separate Peace remains a novel in miniature, very clear but not very ambitious. It was the work of a literary apprentice who showed himself to have greater range in subsequent novels, Morning in Antibes and Indian Summer. My own favorite is Morning in Antibes (a choice the present novel, with the same setting, does nothing to alter). It is a strange mixture of a foundering marriage and the central character's friendship with an Algerian refugee, saying little about the marriage but telling volumes about the way sympathy of a political and personal kind is generated. In that book, the Riviera was a hothouse of steamy air and unexpected blossoms. In Spreading Fires Mr. Knowles's Riviera is again exotic, but here it's hard to keep from thinking that it's really only expensive, and that if you had enough money you could go to pieces there, too.

title: Tour Earnings
description: P.B.A. BOWLING

title: Architecture
description: WELL, as we said last week, back to square one. No one tears out the historic hearts of cities anymore for parking lots. Everyone understands that the present is a dimensionless bore without the past. We all know that the ricnness, the interest, the art and character of cities depends on the contrasts and continuity of new and old. We understand now about townscape and environment. We are steeped in the lessons of landmark loss and bulldozer renewal, of dull unistyle development. We accept that the spirit and the senses must be satisfied by human scale and historic anchors.

title: 7 More Doomed by South Korean Court
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 13 (AP)Seven more persons, including the wellknown poet Kim Chi Ha, were sentenced to death today by a military court on charges of plotting to overthrow the Government, and former President Yun Po Sun was added to the list of 55 civilian defendants in the trials.

title: He's Still the Same Henry Aaron, but No One Will Let Him Alone
description: Back In July of 1968, Henry Aaron hit the 500th home run of his illustrious career, off Mike McCormick of the San Francisco Giants, and people began to take notice. They began to think in terms of a record that would never be surpassedBabe Ruth's record of 714.

title: 35 Proposals: A Call for Establishing New Institutions
description: WASHINGTON, July 13In its report today the Senate Watergate committee made a total of 35 recommendations for legislative change, including creation of an independent public attorney to investigate and prosecute wrongdoing in the executive branch.

title: City and 2 Unions Agree
description: City labor negotiators have reached tentative understandings with representatives of the fire and sanitation unions on basic wage increases in a twoyear contract. Page 36.

title: Drag Racers Anger 4 Towns
description: NUTLEYFour North Jersey communities are being plagued with drag racing, especially on Route 21, which runs through the affected townsNutley, Belleville, Clifton and Passaic. Not one has a specific law on the books banning drag racing and all are relying on antinoise ordinances to halt the disturbance.

title: Notes: On Cape Cod, Look for Peter Rabbit
description: THIS summer Sandwich, Mass., honoring a hometown boyThornton W. Burgess, the creator of more than 15,000 stories about puch creatures as Danny Meadowmouse, Jimmy Skunk, Jerry Muskrat, Reddy Fox and Sammy Jay, And of course and above all, Peter Rabbit. Burgess, who died in 1965 at the age of 91, would have been 100 years old this year, and the town of Sandwich, on Cape Cod, is holding a centennial celebration Aug. 8, 9 and 10. There will be a pet show, the dedication of nature rails, walking tours of Sandwich, dlsPlays and exhibits, a puppet show, a story hour, a play and a musical baaed on Burgess stories, a Burgessinspired parade parade and a tribute to the author by the naturalist and conservationist Richard H. Pough. The events will begin at 10 each morning and go on into the evening in Sandwich proper and at the nearby Briar Patch, setting pf many Burgess stories.

title: U.S. Denies Any Knowledge Of Earlier Indian Atom Test
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (Reuters)The State Department said today that it had no confirmation that India tried to explode a nuclear device three months before her successful underground test in May.

title: Presbytery Accused Of Whitewashing Minister in Inquiry
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith has taken issue with the Presbytery of New York City for the Presbytery's clearing one of its ministers of charges of antiSemitism.

title: Reported Crime Is Declining in Queens
description: Queens is safer from crime than it was a year ago, according to preliminary statistics for the first six months of this year, compared to the corresponding period last year.

title: Courageous Triumphs, Then Loses
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 14Courageous and Intrepid, the two leading candidates to defend the America's Cup in September, were like unsuccessful ondida tes at a beauty contest today as they divided two races. They were more than adequate but each displayed a flaw, long in the tooth here, flaccid there.

title: TREMOR IN STATE CLASSED AS QUAKE June 7 Occurrence Startled Wappinger Falls Area
description: A tremor last June 7 that startled residents of Wappingers Falls, N. Y., and that was assumed by many to have been a quarry blast, has been diagnosed as a small earthquake.

title: Borg Downs Parun, Gains Final of Swedish Tennis
description: BAASTAD, Sweden, July 13 (AP)  Topseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden and thirdseeded Adriano Panatta of Italy advanced to the men's final of the $50,000 Swedish open tennis championships today.

title: Lowenstein May Run on L.I.
description: MINEOLA  Persistent reports last week indicated that Allard K. Lowenstein of Long Beach will seek to run against Representative John W. Wydler, the Republican incumbent in the Fifth Congressional District.

title: Dance: Cynthia Gregory Shines as Giselle With Ballet Theater
description: Whatever the reason, the American Ballet Theater certainly pulled its socks up Friday night at the New York State Theater with an outstanding performance of Giselle, led intelligently and impressively by Cynthia Gregory, Ivan Nagy and Martine van Hamel,

title: Battle Stations
description: President Nixon's efforts to surmount the charges brought against him have been dogged by a recurrent phenomenon: Each time the outlook for him brightens, a spate of new developments sties up the storm with renewed force.

title: Kathy Gilbert Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Stewart E. Gilbert of Jamaica Estates, Queens, N. Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathy Gilbert, to David Levine, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Levine of Fairlawn, N. 3. Dr. Gilbert is a founder and a trustee of Deepdale Hospital in Queers.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Taking Fluke
description: GAY HEAD, Mass.A hot and unrelenting west wind of nearly gale force moaned along Lobsterville Beach, piling up 3foot waves that surged and receded with a hollow, grinding sound over the smooth stones; and occasional tern beat past, barely making headway, then wheeled about and hurtled downwind.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Photography
description: PERHAPS coincidentally, two Canadian magazines have issued, almost simultaneously, anthologies of vernacular imagery.

title: New Novel
description: I have read novels of Catholic boyhoods and novels of Wasp boyhoods, but I don't recall one in which the protagonist experienced both. John Morressy's funny and engaging book must represent a first. It charts the early course of Philip Archer, born of an IrishItalian mother and an AngloSaxon father on Dec. 7, 1941. Orphaned at birth, Archer has an opportunity to taste the worst of both worlds. At first he is farmed out to a maternal aunt and uncle in Brooklyn and enrolled in a parochial school staffed by an order of nuns nicknamed The Little Sisters of the Inquisition (Their triple vow was poverty, chastity, and brutality.). At age 11, the boy is shipped to a rich aunt on his father's side, who introduces him to snobbery. At a succession of prep schools, Archer learns that brutality is ecumenical. Through pluck and luck, he battles through a loveless childhood to find in maturity the warmth he had earlier missed. Morressy is a nimble stylist, who writes with charm.

title: Historical Facade To Be a Sculpture
description: The historically significant facade of an 1838 building facing Independence Square in Philadelphia will be preserved as a freestanding sculpture when work is completed on a 21story addition to the headquarters of the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Company. The original marble Egyptian revival building was designed by John Haviland. In 1902, its width was doubled in an expansion project., The architects for the new $22million Penn Mutual tower, MitchellGiurgola Associates, recessed the gray glass facade of the addition at its base, creating a sunken courtyard next tq the entrance. The Haviland facade will stand in front of the courtyard, facing Independence Hall across the square. The cost of taking the old facade apart, then reassembling it was estimated at $130,000. The project is to be completed in the fall.

title: The Split Personality of Richard Rodgers
description: THERE cannot he much doubt that Richard Rodgers is one of the great melodists of our time. The perpetual freshness of so many of his tunes is demonstrated over and over every dayon the radio, in elevators, in airplanes. And now that the recording industry has joined in by reissuing great quantity of the composer's songs and complete shows, it seems good time to take a laok at his long and successful careeras well as the new recordings. T

title: World Team Tennis
description: World Team Tennis

title: Dining Out in New Jersey
description: The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based, on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of Comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

title: Sunday Observer
description: There is a secret drawer at our house which has not been opened for years. Some years ago, all of us tacitly agreed that we would simply not open the drawer anymore. Its contents were quietly, without a word being said, sealed out of our lives like friends of long ago who have drifted away on the eddies of life and become strangers. They were of a time that had passed.

title: Miss Peterson Plans Nuptials
description: Joseph S. Peterson of Gullderland, N.Y., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Karen Jo Peterson, to Alan Pinto Joseph, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Joseph of Scarsdale, N.Y. An Aug. 11 wedding is planned.

title: Hospital Seeking Lawrence Location
description: The South Shore division of Long Island JewlshHillside Medical Center is awaiting the decision of the Nassau County iivard of Supervisor: concerning a conditional contract to buy countyowned land in Lawrence for its new 250bed hospital.

title: EHRLICHMAN FACING COAST DISBARMENT
description: SEATTLE, July 13 (AP) John D. Ehrlichman's conviction on perjury and conspiracy charges will result in at least his temporary suspension from the practice of law in Washington state, the president of the state bar association says.

title: News Summary and Index SUNDAY JULY 14, 1974
description: The Major Events of the DaySection 1

title: Francis Breckinridge Montague Is Fiance of Anna van Lynden
description: Rijnhard B. van Lynden, the Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, and Baroness van Lynden have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anna Maria Dorothea van Lynden, to Francis Breckinridge Montague.

title: 3 U.S. Drivers Escaped Sahara, but Lost to Sheepherder's Dog
description: Three Californians who raced in the World Cup rally from London to Munich in May have vivid memories of the 10,000mile automobile a race. But for them, the course was only 8,000 miles.,

title: Man Charged in Slaying of Mt. Vernon Detective
description: A 31  year old Manhattan man arrested in connection with another murder was charged yesterday with the shotgun slaying of Bernard Christopher, a Mount Vernon detective gunned down last month during a holdup in a Westchester bar.

title: Roadside Farmstands Still Thriving
description: WOODCLIFF LAKE  The roadside farm market, long a familiar oasis for Jersey motorists, continues to flourish throughout the state. At last count, there were 623 such outlets, including 37 in urbanzied Bergen County; in fact, they en be found in every county except Hudson.

title: Thomas L. Stix, Agent, Is Dead; Set Up RadioTV Appearances
description: Thomas L. Stix, who had represented a number of wellknown literary and news personalities for radio and television appearances, died yesterday in Martha's Vineyard (Mass.) Hospital. He was 78 years old and made his home on the island.

title: A Preview of the New Hirshhorn Museum
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. COMPARED to the kind of Rockefeller who brought home whole churches and gave them away, Joseph H. Hirshhorn may be but a robber baronetcollector. Still, none of Hirshhorn's predecessors managed just what he has done as his lifework. It is an accomplishment well suited to the Guinness Book of World Records: the world's largest free museum built and maintained in a capital city by government, housing 19th and 20th century art as seen by one man and named after him.

title: The Region In Summary
description: The proposals that have been offered to integrate a Coney Island junior high school go considerably beyond the school itselfthey include ideas for reversing neighborhood housing patterns.

title: Ajello in Democratic Race For Connecticut State Post
description: HARTFORD, July 13 (UPI)State Representative Carl R. Ajello Jr. of Ansonia will seek the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General, it was announced yesterday.

description: DOWN

title: Television
description: A PHYSICIAN who was once scheduled to appear as a guest on Dr. Joyce Brothers talk show called her the day before the telecast to say that he wouldn't be there because he had oome down with the flu. Dr. Brothers found a second doctor, connected with another hospital but with the same specialty and with equally impressive credentials.

title: Miss Hill Winsjunior Golf
description: MONTEREY, Calif, July 13 (UPI)Carolyn Hill, 15 years old, of Placentia won the 1974 California junior girls' golf championship today, defeating Paula Gregory, 15, of Alamo, 6 and 5, at the Monterey Peninsula Country Club. Miss Hill also is Los Angeles city women's champion.

description: General

description: Miss Ellen Hillard Eddy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Eddy Jr. of Short Hills, N. J., was married yesterday afternoon to Alan Thorndike under an oak tree at Bogside, the home of the bridegroom, in Scarborough, Me., by the Rev. Kenneth Almeida of the First Congregational Church. After the ceremony, a wedding reception and clambake was given for the guests and families.

title: Ehrlichman and Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The cone viction of John Ehrlichman for conspiracy and perjury in the case of Daniel Ellsberg's psychiatristthough it will be appealedis regarded here as highly significant for two main reasons,

description: LONDON, July 13  Lord Blackett, one of Britain's leading and most versatile scientists, died today. He was 76 years old.

description: National League American League Major League Averages Major League TeamAgainstTeam Records

title: Strike Up the String Quartet
description: STYLISTIC diversity and even lapses of actual ensemble can produce artistic results in some types of chamber music. Takethe piano trio for instance: The recordings of the great ThibaudCasalsCortot triumverate  with each of the Illustrious musicians going his own stylistic way and yet fusing memorably  are a lasting tribute to my assertion.

title: Japan's Businessmen Are in a State of Shock
description: TOKY5OThese are the statistics: The highest rate of inflation in the industrialized world, with consumer prices 23 percent; a tripling in oil costs, leading to a billiondollar deficit in Japan's balance of payments last month; and a staggering 30 percent wage hike won by workers this spring.

title: Marjorie McWeeney to Wed Sept. 14
description: Miss Marjorie L. McWeeney, daughter of Mr. andivirs. John Xavier McWeeney of Rye, plans to be married Sept. 14 to Peter Maximus Kennedy 3d, an assistant vice president of the Bank of America here. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy Jr. of Rye and Pomfret, Conn.

title: Alion to See Kissinger
description: TEL AVIV, July 13 (Reuters) Foreign Minister Yigal Allon will visit the United States on July 28 and meet Secretary of State Kissinger the following day; officials said tonight.

title: Haskell to True Knight
description: OCEANPORT, N.J., July 13 When you're hot you're hot, and the Darby Dan Farm combination of John Galbreath (owner), Lou Rondinell (trainer) and Miguel Rivera (jockey) had the hot hand again today in the $111,100 Amory L. Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: Thomas Powers's Guest Word, Bound to Die, (June 2) struck a nostalgic chord in many of us. I miss not only the 16page signatures but also the generous margins of the past. These books opened out much better than most present books and were much easier to read.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: William Gaddis's The Recognitions received little attention when it first appeared in 1955, perhaps because it seemed so inaccessible. It is certainly a complex structure, rather like the monastery that figures near the beginning and the end of the book, with turreted walls, parapets, crenelations, machicolations, bartizans, a harrowing variety of domes and spires in staggering Romanesque, Byzantine effulgence, and Gothic run riot in mullioned windows, window tracings, and an immense rose window whose foliations were so elaborate that it was never furnished with glass. as in some other aspects, it has certain similarities with Malcolm Lowry's Under the Volcano, which Lowry himself described as like some Mexican Churrigueresque cathedral. The Recognitions

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Oakland A's, doubleheader, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 1 P.M.

title: News of the Stage
description: A new theater package titled I've Got a Song, with a book by E.Y. (Yip) Harburg and Fred Saidy and lyrics by Mr. Harburg to music by Harold Arlen, Burton Lane, Vernon Duke, Earl Robinson, Jay Gorney, Sammy Fain, and Ira Gershwin, will arrive here in early November, after a fourweek run starting Sept. 27 at the Studio Arena Theater in Buffalo. Joel W. Schenker and Claire Nichtern are the producers, and Harold Stone will direct, with Jo Mielziner design. ing the scenery. Negotiations for a Broadway theater are un

title: TRIAL OF BRASCO, NEARING THEEND
description: Representative Frank J. BrasCp will return to the witness stand for crossexamination tomorrow morning as his second trial nears an end in Federal Court here.

title: Realty Splash
description: There is something to be said about people who try to swim where others are drowning. Either they have skills the others lack or they have misjudged their own abilities.

title: Jones, Brannan Advance
description: TULSA, Okla., July 13 (UPI)Tom Jones of Tulsa University and Mike Brannan of Brigham Young won their matches, 2 up and 4 and 3, today to advance to the 36hole final in the 71st TransMississippi golf tournament. Jones defeated Mark Pfeil of Southern California and Brannan ousted Lindy Miller of Fort Worth, Tex.

title: STATELINE STUDY ON AT GULLIVER'S
description: New York and Connecticut surveying teams with plat maps, tapes and transits sought yesterday to fix the exact position of the state line that runs through the bar where 24 young people were killed and 32 were injured in a fire two weeks ago.

title: For Wives of Heart Attack Victims, Help in Learning How to Cope
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn. The problems are many and they are posed by women brooding about the adjustments they must make both as wife and mother in living with a man recovering from a heart attack.

title: ALEXANDER GEISS
description: Alexander Geiss, artist and former animator and writer for Walt Disney Studios in Hollywood, died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 305 West 28th Street.

title: Panel Rationalizes 2 Towns Meetings
description: MAPLEWOOD  A Joint Planning Council set up by concerned citizens here and in neighboring South Orange has virtually eliminated conflicts in dates and duplication of subjects for community meetings: The result is a marked increase in attendance and time saved:

title: Family Court Judge Named
description: Mrs, Yorka Condeles Linakis has been appointed a judge of the Family Court in Queens. Mayor Beame, in announcing the appointment to the $42,451ayear position, noted that Mrs. Linakis, a Jamaica, Queens, iresident, was a past president of the Queens County Bar Association.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The New York Yankees take over Shea Stadium this week while the Mets are on the road. The Yanks play the Texas Rangers Tuesday night at 8 o'clock and Wednesday at 2 P.M. A fourgame home series with the Kansas City Royals begins with night games Thursday and Friday and afternoon games Saturday and next Sunday at 2 o'clock.

title: Katharine Auchincloss Engaged
description: Dr. J. Howland Auchincloss Jr., professor of medicine at the Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, and Mrs, Auchincloss have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Hazard Auchincloss, to Richard Michael Lorr, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lorr of North Massapequa, L.I. The Auchinclosses are of Syracuse and also have a home in Cazenovia, N.Y., where the wedding is planned for Aug. 17.

title: J & J's New Brunswick Tract
description: NEW BRUNSWICKSince last December, four Philadeiphiabased concerns, whose executives and source of funds were a closely guarded corporate secret, have invested more than $1.5million to option or purchase property in a decaying sixbhck downtown section here.

title: How to Help Your Putting, OftenOverlooked Stroke
description: Putting is about 50 per cent of golfand it is about 100 per cent unexamined.

title: Good Life Is Goal For South Orange
description: SOUTH ORANGE  Officials here say that the average family income is about $28,000 a year, one of the highest in the state, but they prefer not to call South Orange an affluent community they say that it has a great mixture of people and that being known as a rich place sometimes gives a bad impression affluent community, said to the rest of Essex County.

title: Mets Beaten By Dodgers; Millan Hurt
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13The apparently endless series of miseries afflicting the New York Mets took a new direction tonight as it was discovered that Felix Millan had fractured a bone in his wrist the night before and would be out of the lineup for at least 10 days chipped bone. He won't need a cast and can continue to work outhe got into the game in the eighth as a pinchrunnerbut his regular skills, including double play pivots, will be sorely missed. Bud Harrelson, the injured shortstop, is almost ready to go hack to work, in which case Teddy Martinez might shift to second, Tonight Ken Boswell took Millan's place.

title: Shifting Winds Mar Start Of Larchmont's Regatta
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 13The 76th Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week opened on Long Island Sound today under less than favorable circumstances.

title: Yanks Trounce A's, 126, for Sixth in Row
description: A banner held aloft by fan in Shea Stadium before yesterday's game read: The Bronx Bombers Are Exploding. After scoring five runs in the fifth inning and six more in the seventh to trounce the embarrassed Oakland A's, 126, the Yankees are making it a sign of the times.

title: The World
description: Difficult times are still ahead for the world's economies, the experts agree, but there are some signs of relief, particularly concerning oil. Until now, oil has been the chief villain in accelerating inflation and deepening many national balanceofpayments deficits.

title: Radio
description: 88:30, WNBCFM: Consumer Challenge.

title: Atlantic Ave. Wins Special Districting
description: The City Planning Commission gave its approval last week to establishment of a special zoning district to preserve the character of sevenblock stretch of Atlantic Avenue east of Court Street in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Invention as the mother of necessity
description: In the Capitol's Statuary Hall, Dr. John Gorrie, one of the hall's leastsung heroes, resides in marble immortality next to Robert Livingston. They are fitting neighbors. As one the drafters of the Declaration of Independence, Livingston was concerned with the pursuit of happiness; Gorrie's claim to fame lies in pioneering what may be a major stride toward that goal, at least by the 20thcentury standards and yearnings of a society that is not given to ascetic pleasures. Dr. Gorrie is credited with having invented airconditioning.

title: Curiouser and curiouser
description: At 7:17 A.M. local time on June 30, 1908, something frightful occurred in the Tunguska area of central Siberia. As though a catastrophic midair explosion had taken place, virtually all trees within a radius of 20 miles were blown down. As recently as the nineteensixties, the charred tree trunks, many of them with the bark torn off, could still be seen from the air, forming a striking pattern of lines radiating from the explosion site.

title: Margaret Tutt Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell Thayer Tutt of Colorado Springs have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Honnen Tutt, to Frank John Steinegger 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frank Steinegger of Darien, Conn. The couple are graduates of the University of Denver, They plan to marry Sept. 7.

title: Peronist Labor Chief Dies 2 Days After Election
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 13Adelino Romero, the newly elected leader of the federation that controls Argentine labor died today of a heart attack. His death left the Peronist tradeunion movement in further disarray.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Just a short time ago, the real estate investment trust shares were the darlings of Wall Street. The industry grew at a fantastic rate. Now, on a daily basis, we see news articles telling of the problems that face this industry.

title: A New Scheme for Real Writers
description: When I taught at Harvard a couple of years ago, many students were importuning the college to design what they had somehow agreed to call a creative track in the English department. This system of switches and semaphores was intended, as nearly as I could tell, to eliminate from the itineraries of talented persons all the whistle stops which were visited by the milk trains of scholarship. The Twentieth Century Limiteds on this new track would rocket nonstop to Chicago, which was variously a precocious novel or short story collection or play or scenario.

title: Chess: Add Another Item to That Old Saw About Love and War
description: The system used in the international Team Tournament for awarding medals for individual results is not entirely fair, since two players competing for the same medal may not face the same level of opposition.

title: Frances M. Griffith Will Be Bride
description: Miss Frances Martha Griffith, who is in marketing planning with Chemco International Leasing, a subsidiary of the Chemial Bank, and Stephen Alexander Laserson, an assistant vice president in Chemical's Wall Street division, plan to marry Sept. 21.

title: ERVIN PANEL ASKS SWEEPING REFORM OF ELECTION LAWS
description: WASHINGTON, July 13The Senate Watergate committee, in its last official action, released today a final report that included proposals for a sweeping overhaul of campaign and other statutes that, it predicted, would go far toward precluding another Watergate.

title: The Full Employment Budget? Forget
description: WASHINGTON  After a brief ascendancy, the full employment budget concept has gone into decline both inside and outside the Government. It is no longer the predominant measure of the impact of the Federal budget on the economy or a test of what governmental fiscal polky should be.

title: Darwin on Man
description: A man who returned man to nature

title: The theater and the media To the Editor:
description: It must take some very fancy mind juggling to write a 5,500word essay assaulting a number of notables for giving themselves to the news media as willing or unwilling victims, and then to submit this essay to The New York Times Magazine with an estimated readership of some four million people (not to mention getting paid for the job).

title: Aid to Overseas Jews Detailed By Joint Distribution Committee
description: The Joint Distribution Committee, the major American agency aiding needy Jews overseas, reported last week that it had spent $29,624,000 last year to aid 396,000 Jews,

title: PROGRAM OF ROCK BY JOHN C. ATTLE Songs at Reno Sweeney's Delivered Too Seriously
description: Of, the numerous performers who passed through Jacques Brel Is Alive And Well And Living In Paris during its original) fiveyear run in New York, one, of the most appealing was John C. Attie, a young man with a fascinatingly mobile and expressive face.

title: A New Taste and Tell Library for Herbs
description: HERBS have been used for culinary and medicinal uses for as long as 5,000 years. And for anyone who wants to delve into their fascinating history, Cornell University has a new herb garden, designed as a student's living reference library.

title: Johns Hopkins Receives $3.9Million for Study
description: The United States Agency for International Development has awarded a $3.9million grant to Johns Hopkins University to support a new program to Wye health problems related to human reproduction in underdeveloped countries.

title: The String

title: Abortion Ruling Appealed
description: ST. PAUL, July 13 (AP) Attorney General Warren Spannaus of Minnesota filed an appeal yesterday seeking reinstatement of Minnesota's 1974 law restricting abortions after the first 20 weeks of pregnancy. He said that he had filed the appeal with the United States Supreme Court and the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit. A threejudge panel of United States District Court overturned the Minnesota law June 28.

title: What's New in the Camera World
description: STUDENTS of architecture, as well as photographers, should find Architectural Photography, by John Veltri (Amphoto, $17.50) a worthwhile addition to their libraries. Printed on high quality glossy paper, the book is profusely illustrated with many striking architectural photographs, some in color but most in blackandwhite. Unlike most books on this subject, many of the, photographs in this volume include people, and many show how to take pictures from unusual angles that lend interest. The text describes the equipment required for architectural photography, describes in detail the use of the view camera for creating effects and solving problems, and also discusses printing and enlarging in a rather general way. Obviously not written for beginning photographers, this volume is a good illustrated reference guide for those who are interested in the title's subject, and it is handsomely put to

description: The big question asked over the last few weeks in and around the House Judiciary Committee's hearing room by committee members who were uncertain about how they felt about impeachment was, Where's the smoking gun? In large measure, that question was a tribute to the defense strategy of James D. St. Clair, President Nixon's lawyer. He has argued that the President can be impeached only if is found that he committed a serious crime.

Crime in the streets, the drug problem, urban rioting, increasing violenceall gave Americans good reason to be disturbed and to make their feelings known. But as happens all too often, their political leaders flocked to exploit the political issue without doing anything useful about the basic problem.

title: How much of a citizen can a soldier in trouble be?
description: The late unpleasantness of 19651972 provoked much reportage about military justice. In tone, this writing was hysterical when it was not merely strident; in substance, it was too often uninformed when not downright opaque. Mainly, it dealt with anecdote or incident  the oases of Seaman Priest, Captain Levy, Lieutenant Howe, The Presidio 27, the massacre at My Lai and its grim aftermatha familiar litany. The atmosphere of the day did not allow anything like disinterested evaluation of military justice and the qualifications of those who wrote about it were often dubious. The Harper Colophon edition of Military Justice Is to Justice as Military Music Is to Music by Robert Sherrill features a uniformed pig on its cover, which pretty well says it all.

title: Foe of Men's Myth Braces for Battle
description: Margaret Dunkle makes her living gathering data to combat the inequality of women. In her Washington office she writes newsletters, studies laws, hears what opponents say and do and seeks out injustice. She is project associate for the Project on the Status and Education of Women, Association of American Colleges, a clearinghouse of information concerning women in higher education. The projest is funded by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, the Danforth Foundation and the Exxon Education Foundation. Miss Dunkle's attention is focused largely on collegiate and high school athletics for women and she is trying to show the world, with facts and figures, that women deserve more, deserve to be equal.

title: For Fall's NewCar Owner, Nonleaded Gasoline Shouldn't Be Hard to Find

title: Home Improvement
description: THE old saying which states that an ounce of prevention is worth more than a pound of cure is particularly appropriate when applied to the maintenance and installation of fences around the homeespecially the fence posts which, of course, support the entire structure. If the posts have been properly installed and firmly anchored in the ground a reasonably well designed fence should last for many years without need for repairs, but even an old fence with some loose or wobbly posts can usually be given a new lease on life with a few simple repairs, or by replacing a few posts.

title: Rand's Diminishing Role Re Thinking New York's ThinkTank Philosophy
description: Rand. It stood originally for Research and Development. Before everything else, perhaps, it exemplified a mentality that reached its peak in the 1960's, a heady period of think tanki, scientific management and systems analysis. In Santa Monica, Calif., the Rand CorPoration was helping the young men in Robert S. McNamara's Defense Department analyze missile systems, deployment of troops and the potential need for new overseas bomber bases. In the East, the New York CityRand Institute, semiindependent offshoot born almost two decades after its California progenitor, was helping the young men in Mayor John V. Lindsay's Budget Bureau analyze welfare systems, deployment of policemen and firemen and the potential need for new neighborhood hospitals.

title: Controls Are Off, and So Are the Wraps on Wage Demands
description: After two years of short rations, trade unions are demanding and winning larger slices of the pie the bargaining table. With consumer prices climbing at more than 10 per cent per year, organized labor is hurrying to catch up and to build some protection against future inflation. At the same time, the dismantling of wageprice controls has removed any legal restraints on union demands. Under these circumstances, it is not surprising that labor has rediscovered Samuel Gompers's admonition to seek more, more, here and now.

title: A cooks cook invents a new way with chicken
description: My American students at L'Ecole des Trois Gourmandes in Paris always ask for chicken recipes, because chicken is relatively inexpensive in the United States. Unfortunately, those massproduced American chickens, while fleshy, lack flavor (and I must confess that in France, too, these washedout chickens are appearing in our markets). I am always searching for a way to restore the succulence rind flavor to such poultry. This poulet en roulade is my greatest success.

The city's Board of Estimate ratified a unanimous decision of the City Planning Commission to reserve the tract, situated bptween and running from the canal Fourth and Seventh Streets to Smith Street, for public purposes.

title: Regulating Television Programs For Mice
description: THE screen is dark, the hovel silent. The childrenor mice, as network people refer to them have been shipped off by diplomatic pouch to their grandparents in California, where they will pump on bicycles, splash in pools, consume tacos, burn skin, be pampered and not watch television. They will not even think about television in the pitiless glare of the sun. Nor will the psychiatrists be thinking about television, having all gone off to Cape Cod or Martha's Vineyard. Nor will their patients, having all gone off to the Hampton or Fire Island. It's too hot for sex, and no serious person is interested in anything but gin. I am muselebound in my, desuetude.

title: Fashion
description: For wise shoppers there's more to do on a rainy summer day than play Scrabble with the children. Maria Elena de la Iglesia, who may be the world's top expert on catalogues (she compiled The Catalogue of Catalogues and The Catalogue of American Catalogues (Random House) estimates that in this country alone, there are about 1,500 catalogues devoted to clothing and accessories and a good 3,000 other types. This may be only the tip of the iceberg, she says, pointing out that some New York stores do as little as two per cent of their business over the counter; the rest comes from catalogue shoppers.

title: By the Sweat of Their Feet
description: A few years ago, when the controversy flared over who, precisely, the national parks were forpeople? cars? trees? beasts? posterity?The Times took the editorial stand that they belonged to people in trusteeship, not to convert at their whim into forest counterparts of Coney Island. At the same time a Republican House Interior Committee member, Representative John P. Saylor vowed to fight the preservation lobby. Parks are for people, he maintained, and members of Congress will not allow that basic assumption to be submerged. He alluded to convincing evidence that some of the ad hoc interest groups  vocalizing about our parks are more interested in area than in people. People and cars being synonymous, Coney Island continues its ruinous advance on these muchviolate preserves  last year 215.6 million visits were paid the national parks, more than double the 102.7 million often 1963.

title: Dance
description: ARICAN BALLET THEAMERTER is undoubtedly he classic establishvent company of American dance. Indeed it is practically a freak of nature that New York City Ballet is in fact, the company that New York enjoys most often. Let me be clear. I am not making any value judgment about either of these two great American companies. I am merely pointing out the place they both clearly play in American dance. In a World of safe guys and wise guys, Ballet Theater would always try to be the safe guys. And yet, contrast of contrasts, it is City Ballet that happens to command the big theater, it is City Ballet that calls the tune, it is, City Ballet that gets the establishment money.

title: A Key Addition to the Walters
description: but his 19thcentury French academic paintings, which he bought along with those of currently brighter stars such as Ingres, Delacroix, Corot and Downier, are of such quality that they have been a rebuke, largely unheeded, to the wholesale rejection of the French academicians by other museums and history of art professors. Now that some of pariahs, painters like Grme and Couture, are coming back into favor, and now that we are beginning to recognize that to discard the defeated Academy is to ignore a vital part of 19thcentury cultural history, the Walters Gallery will bring out additional examples from William Walters's academic collection to hang in context with paintings of the men who, from our 20thcentury perspective, discredited everything they stood for.

title: Against despair, impotence and selfloathing
description: The playwright William Gibson and his wife have two sonsthe believer and the doubter, to whom this valuable book is dedicated. One is Dan, a cool lad of sixteen, bearded and longhaired, soon to enter college as a mathandscience major. The other son, named by me after the apostle who wouldn't believe except he put his finger in the print of the nails, is moodier, the doubter, of course, now a shorn nineteen in suit and necktie Who has declined college, and since fall taken up residence as a student here instead. It's his first long absence from home, it will last seven months, and the rest of us have dropped in to say hello at Christmas, casuallike.
