Dyer, who is black, was asked if he felt out of place among the Scottish caddies: I suppose I'm different. I guess I look like a fly in a glass of buttermilk.

title: Cluster Developments Evoke Praise and Scorn
description: Only eight feet separate David Miller's house in Fair, Lawn, N.J., from those of his neighbors on both sides. But Mr. Miller, a junior high school principal who has two ttenage children, couldn't care less about the proximity.

title: Social Announcements
description: Engagements

title: Cool Shoes Captures Hunter Title
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 13Bernie Traurig of Bloodstock Enterprises in Mechanicsville, Pa., had been watching Cool Shoes perform in horse shows for several months. He was impressed and wondered whether the mount was for sale.

title: Daughter to the Lipmans
description: A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Lipman of New York on July 6 in the LyingIn Hospital, Mrs. Lipman is the former Miss Myra Ann Rosenthal of New York.

title: Food for Thought
description: It's not a fourstar restaurant, but it has a printed menu, a chef, waiter and busboy. Don't expect any fancy napery or china. Your table is your lap and you lunch as you wait for your hair to dry or the blond streaking to process. The new eatery is the Pierre Michel salon at 6 West 57th Street.

title: Britain's Offshore Oil
description: Any groundbreaking, longrange program advanced the moment by Britain's minority Government is enveloped in unreality. Everyone knows it will be subject revision after the next election, now expected in September or October. So it is with the plan under which the British Government would seek at least a 51 per cent share in all existing and future North Sea oil fields.

title: Singles Becoming More Stable Tenants
description: Singles. The very word is anathema to landlords of some family buildings. They have visions of stewardesses piled into onebedroom apartments, landing and taking off with disconcerting regularity. Or, worse yet, partying noisily, damaging property and defaulting on leases.

title: Deaths of L.I. Sisters, 4 and 7, Attributed to Mysterious Illness
description: The deaths of two young sisters, one on July 5 and one yesterday, are under investigation by the Suffolk County Medical Examiner's office, which termed the illness to which they suecumbed unknown pending further tests.

title: Haven Pell Weds Mina Stockman
description: Miss Mina Monroe Stockman and Haven Nelson Borland Pell were married yesterday afternoon in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Roslyn, L. I. The Rev. Bradford Colton performed the ceremony.

title: Strike Goes To 3d Week; End Unseen
description: The National Football League players strike, which has already claimed the annual College AllStar game as one of its victims, heads into its third week with no signs of a quick settlement.

title: Capital Spendingthe Silver Lining
description: There is a silver lining  albeit a very thin one to the cloud that darkens the economy today. National output may be stagnant, consumers gloomy and housing in a deep slump. But in the heartland of American industry a capital spending boom (or boomlet, as some prefer to call it) is under way.

title: Chronicles of Wasted Time
description: Autobiography is the most abysmal of literary forms for reasons that are reasonably evident. Anyone who writes a book should be able to write. He should also have something interesting or useful to write about. He should also be able to see his subject with some clarity and deal with it with reasonable honesty and detachment. The rarest accidents apart, the autobiographer is, in the nature of things, deprived of all these prerequisites.

title: JAPAN'S ELECTIONS HEAVILY FINANCED
description: TOKYO, July 13They call it the zaru ho, or bamboobasket law, because it Is so full of holes that water leaks out everywhere.

title: 2d Straight Triumph
description: WESTBURY, L. I., July 13 The richest race in trotting, the $200,000 Roosevelt International, was won by the United Stales tonight for the third straight year and by Delmonica Hanover for the second straight in a flurry of mishaps for the Europeans.

title: Ford Doubts House Will Impeach Nixon
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 13Vice President Ford, emerging from a meeting with President Nixon at the President's estate here, indicated today that he expected the House Judiciary Committee to recommend impeachment proceedings against Mr. Nixon.

title: 5 Die as Migrants Car Hits Auto
description: Metropolitan Briefs Five persons died when a car carrying a group migrant workers on a fishing trip crossed the center line and collided head on with another auto in Egypt, N.Y., 15 miles southeast of Rochester, the state police said. Jose Falcon, 22 years old, the lone survivor, was reported in fair condition at Genesee Hospital in Rochester with facial and head cuts and fractures. The dead were identified as Kevin George, 21, of Newark, N.Y., driver of the other car; Miguel Colon, 33, of Fairport, N.Y., driver the migrants car, and Ramon Luis ReyesAmador, Israel Torres Sostre and Jose Juan Sostre, who the police said had been in the area for only a month.

title: M. J. Metzger to Wed Randy Nussbaum
description: Stanley Nussbaum of Lawrence, L. I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Randy Deborah Nussbaum, to Matthew Jay Metzger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias A. Metzger of East Rockaway, L. I. The wedding will take place Aug. 11.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  The New Jersey Legislature is expected to vote later this month on a proposed $200million Green Acres bond issue for the acquisition and development of parks and open spaces.

title: Palestinians Skeptical of Israeli Talks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 Israel's conditional offer to negotiate with the Palestinians got big headlines in Arab newspapers today. But Palestinian leaders withheld official comment and were privately skeptical.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Dr. Ira S. Cohen Is the Fiance Of Miss Karen Ruth Sampson
description: Miss Karen Ruth Sampson and Dr. Ira S. Cohen, both of Brookline, Mass., plan to be married Sept. 22 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Sampson of Woodbridge, Conn., who have announced the engagement of the couple.

title: Operetta: At Caramoor Kalman's Countess Maritza, Product of Viennese Twilight, Is SemiStaged
description: KATONAH, N. Y., July 13 Apart from Die Fledermaus and a few other exceptions, Viennese operetta has lapsed into neglect, at least outside the Vienna Volksoper, Munich's Cartnerplatztheater and the Central European opera circuit. And everything considered, it's unlikely that efforts like the Caramoor Festival's concert version of Emmerich Kalman's Countess Maritza, seen here last night and to be repeated next Saturday, will spark an operetta revival here.

title: Along the Strawhat Trail
description: Raul Julia plays Macheath in The Threepenny Opera PC the Williamstown Theater in Williamstown, Mass.

title: SIMON IS IN CAIRO FOR 3DAY TALKS
description: CAIRO, July 13William E. Simon, the United States Secretary of the Treasury, arrived here tonight for three days of talks on how the United States may be able to help Egypt strengthen her financial position,

title: The Return of The Small Label
description: WITH remarkably little fanfare and for no easily explicable reason, America finds itself In the midst of a resurgence of small classical record companies. All seven of the companies surveyed in this article report an upsurge of sales over the past couple of years. Many of them had struggled along for years, losing money or just breaking even, and now suddenly find themselves healthily in the black. And new, small labels seem to be popping up with increasing frequency all over the country.

title: What's New In Art
description: New Hampshire

title: Wheelchair Games Open Next Sunday
description: The United States won 38 gold medals, more than any other country, at last year's Stoke Mandeville Gamesthe annual world tournament of wheelchair athletes.

title: Rape and Research
description: If a huge area of the West, fom North Dakota to New Mexico, is not to be turned into another Appalachiapoisoned streams in a desolate landscapethe House Representatives will have to pass the stripmining bill scheduled for a vote this week. Sponsored by Representatives Udall of Arizona and Mink of Hawaii, the measure is far from the punitive restraint described by the shrill lobbies of the coal and power companies. On the contrary, it represents the minimum protection that the land requires; such improvements as the bill needs are in the direction of more stringent controls.

title: Aleksandr Y. Bereznyak, 61, Pioneer in Soviet Jet Design
description: Aleksandr Y. Bereznyak, Soviet pioneer in jet aircraft development, died in Moscow last Sunday at the age of 61.

title: Book Ends
description: Hearstlings. A small freshet of books on the Patricia Hearst kidnapping are scheduled, if not already out. Viking has Newsweek columnist Shane Alexander under contract for a book on the case but that is a goad ways from completion. Nearer to hand is Tanya. by Marilyn Baker (with Sally Brampton), which Macmillan will publish in late September. Mrs. Baker is a 44yearold mother and newswoman on KQED, the San Francisco public television station, whose extensive contacts among the San Francisco street people enabled her to score several important beats on the story as it evolved. It was she, for example, who established that Field Marshal General Cinque was Donald DeFreeze, an escaped convict. Mrs. Baker's reporting bit so close to home that she was subjected to several death threats. In the realm of fantasy, Grove Press, in conjunction with Dell, has a novel out that was actually written several years before the kidnapping but foretold many of its aspects. The novel was called Black Abductor, was written by James Rusk Jr. under the pseudonym Harrison James and published by an obscure porno publisher in 1972. The GroveDell version, however, is called Abduction: Fiction Before Fact and includes a preface by New York Post editor Al Ellenberg detailing the parallels between the novel and the reallife story.

title: Bridge
description: A curious resemblance can be found between the scientists who specialize in electronics and the bridge scientists who specialize in squeezes. Both groups deal in miracles that the general public admires without comprehension, and both groups try to perform their miracles in smaller and smaller spaces. Most textbooks imply that the esoteric squeezes need at least a fourcard endingbut they are wrong. Here, for example, is a threecard triple squeeze:

title: Picnic, Anyone?
description: What ever happened to the picnic? Don't look now, but when you get a chance, saunter out onto the flagstoned patio, sit in one of those folding chairs and watch what is going on at the charcoal grill. That is what happened.

title: An Indicted ExJudge to Get U.S. Hearing
description: ATLANTIC CITYA Federal appeals court has for the second time ordered a full hearing into charges that a former Atlantic City municipal judge was coerced by members of the New Jersey Supreme Court into testifying before a state grand jury that eventually indicted him.

title: Design
description: It is one of the most unlikely sites for an expensive home that one could imaginea fiveacre island, just an outcropping of black granite with frosting of pines in Canada's Georgian Bay, an arm of Lake Huron. But there's something about an island. The owners of this one had enough romance in their souls (and money in the bank) to consider it worthwhile to snake a power cable 20 miles across the bottom of the bay from the mainland, to set off 2,000 miniblasts of dynamite in order to lay the foundation properly, to ship all the raw materials in on barges and to maintain a 30man building crew who camped out on the island during the construction. A modular system devised by the architect, C. Blakeway Millar, allowed whole sections of the house to be assembled in a Toronto workshop, then shipped to the island. This permitted some saving in onsite labor costs. But such Herculean efforts come high and the owners, members of a prominent Toronto family, did not worry about cutting corners. The price of their island privacy is their secret, but the result is obvious

title: HIPPIE HITCHHIKER HAUNTS THRUWAY
description: BUFFALO, July 10(AP)The vanishing hitchhiker, long a familiar figure in American folklore, is back on the scene, and the whiteclad figure's favorite haunt seems to be the New York State Thruway.

title: Parade in Paris Moved To Mark Bastille Day
description: PARIS, July 13 (AP)A parade, expected to include more than 13,000 men and women, will march past President Valery Giscard d'Estaing tomorrow in eastern Paris to mark the 185th anniversary of the storming of the Bastille, at the start of the French Revolution.

title: Merchandising That Coping Quality
description: In an age of oil spills, price increases, worker unrest and consumer activism, businessmen are facing more flak than ever, And more than ever, businessmen have to learn to be cool, calm and collected under fire.

title: Headliner
description: Earl Warren had been the thoroughgoing politician, supported by all factions and both parties in his climb to the governorship of California, He was the Republican Vice Presidential nominee on the losing ticket in 1948. He wanted to be President, and was quite open about it, but gave his full support to Dwight D. Eisenhower in 1952. The next year, President Eisenhower nominated Mr. Warren as Chief Justice of the United States Supreme Court. Most thought it political appointment; many, a mediocre choice.

title: 74 Powerboat Showdown At Steel Pier Wednesday
description: Atlantic City isn't big enough for the both of them, and it's a tossup to say who will emerge from Wednesday's showdownthe Hennessey Grand Prix with its $12,000 first prize. The combatants are Art (Snapper) Norris, the leading American Power Boat Association (A.P.B.A.) contender, and Dr. Carlo Bonomi, the Italian offshore powerboat racer, who was last year's world champion and is a shooin for the 1974 international title.

title: Impeachable Offenses
description: With the final witnesses to be heard in the next two or three days, the members of the House Judiciary Committee are entering the climactic stage of their long impeachment deliberations. Chairman Rodino, his colleagues and the committee's legal staff have thus far conducted this extraordinarily difficult assignment, one which had few modern precedents or guidelines, with fairness, diligence and good judgment. The country can rightly feel that a thorough, conscientious and nonpartisan job has been done.

title: Unearthing Paterson's Industrial Past
description: PATERSONA strange kind of dig is under way here within the longneglected confines of the 87acre historic district near the Great Falls of the Passaic.

title: Domino Theory Applied in Auto Racing
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 13Elliott ForbesRobinson Jr., the finest hyphenated racing driver outside France, has this domino theory. If it's true, the 30yearold Californian will be a Grand Prix star in the near future. Here is how it happened: A few months ago, he and his wife were taught dominoes at Glendale and, in a practice round for beginners before a tournament, were soundly defeated. But when the tournament started, something happened to ForbesRobinson, the same thing that happened when he was a 218pound, 5foot9inch teenage football player, the same thing that happened when he learned to waterski and the same thing that happened when he learned to motorcycle.

title: Criminals At Large
description: Some of the best vintages of 72 and 73 have come to market in paperback this month. One of the best to sample is Gerald A. Browne's 11 HARROWHOUSE (Dell, $1.50). This is the one about the diamond caper to end all diamond capers; it involves not merely a diamond or two, or threebut tons of diamonds. All that, and doubledealing, taut dialogue, breathless action.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: The stock market opened the week in the dumps and closed soaring. The nation's credit and money situation was the key to both good and bad performances.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was: 920099

title: 7 Hostages Still Held
description: WASHINGTON, July 13Two armed convicts holding seven hostages in the cell block of a, Federal Court building permitted the release today of 14 other prisoners as they continued negotiations with Justice Department officials.

title: Miss Nancy Roloff Fiancee of Banker
description: Miss Nancy Roloff, an assistant supervisor in the grantsprocessing department of the Ford Foundation here, and Charles Cozad Bradford 3d, who is with the Irving Trust Company, plan to be married in October.

title: Something Old For A Change Of Tree Scene
description: GARDENERS are always trying to find something new to grow. For a switch, why not try something old, really old, even several million years?

title: U.S. Foxhound Kennel Carries an Arabic Name
description: The American foxhound traces back to the 17th Cetitury. George Washington is said to have owned some. So it is rather incongruous that the leading foxhound kennel in the United States bears an Arabic name. It's Hazira and is owned by Dr. Robert Smitn, an Economic Development Administrator for Mississippi. Asked why he choose the name, Smith responded, I studied Arabic when I was at the Army language school. Hazira literally means House of Dogs, so what better name for a kennel.

title: Federal Aides Discount Sludge Threat
description: Two Federal agencies said yesterday that the sludge reported to be creeping toward the beaches of Long Island was no threat to swimmers and might even be of natural origins.

title: Major League Baseball
description: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS

title: Miss Smith Victor In Western Golf
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 13 (UPI)Lancy Smith, a former Curtis Cup player from Williamsville, N. Y., became today the first medalist in four years to win the prestigious Women's Western golf tournament. She defeated Beth Barry, 6 and 5, in the final.

title: Young Explorers New York
description: The Plaza Hotel is the Plaza. But to children it's also Eloise's home, which was never quite the same place when she had finished exploring it. New York City has other such hidden gems. They are those real scenes found in children's books. None of them will be pointed out this summer by the guide on your bus tour. The subway tokenseller won't know what you're talking about when you ask him directions. And so, to help a parent find them easily, the Book Review has provided the map to the right. All the children's books mentioned come in paperback, and are portable, if not pocketable.

title: Excerpts From Recommendations in Report of the Senate Watergate Committee
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP)Following are excerpts from that part of the Senate Watergate committee's report, issued today, that presents its legislative recommendations:

title: Jeanne B. Brennan Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Miss Jeanne Beatrice Brennan, until last month a teacher at the American Community School in Milan, Italy, to Arthur J. Kenney, a European basketball player on the Sporting Club Modernes team of Le Mans, France, has been announced by Col. Martin J. Brennan, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Brennan of New York, parents of the prospective bride.

title: Paperbacks of the Month
description: During the sixties, when Paris's Olympia Press was making pornographic/literary history, Iris Owens contributed to its reputation with four novels under the the pseudonym of Harriet Daimler. Now she's celebrating her return to her native land with this first book under her own name. The heroine, Harriet, is just back from a fiveyear French whirl, just parted from her boyfriend named Claude, living from day to day with sensual abandon in Greenwich Village, trying to discover love and a place to spread herself. Harriet spins her yarn in a fashion that isin the words of Leonard Michaels, who reviewed it in these pages  a democratic and indefatigable style of bigotry which resembles the satire of Lenny Bruce, but Is authentically her own. Michaels added that he hadn't read a more wittily offensive serious novel lately.

title: Radio Hams Turn to Video
description: PRINCETONCQ. Slowscan TV from K2BH. Slowscan TV from K2BH.

title: Expo 74: Merging Marx and Macy's
description: GRANTED; the ideal world's fair in honor of the environment would be no world's fair at all. But somewhere along the line to outandout, manasvarmint misanthropy, most of us must climb off the noninternalcombustion ecological bandwagon. Your oil company board chairman gets off at an early stop; your rural communard who holds out for a flush toilet over a compost heap disembarks somewhat later. We weigh gains against costs to ourselves and others. We hedge, trim, balance, compromise. To swipe a phrase from the ecological militants, we adapt to our environment.

title: Miss Feloney Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Feloney of San Juan, P.R., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christine Feloney, to Donald Ross Miller Jr. of Orlando, Fla., son of Mrs. Constance H. Miller of Orlando and of Donald R. Miller of Forest Hills, Queens. Miss Feloney is a graduate of Wellesley College and her fianc of Dartmouth College.

title: Impeachment
description: One of the more rewarding side effects of mission impeachment has been the thumping reentry of several orbiting legal eminences onto the good earth of the political process. Emboldened (or perhaps enraged) by the sight of Raoul Berger triumphant, and virtually alone, on the constitutional field of battle, a number of his peers have rushed forth to tilt lances with him, or at least to stake out a territory of their own.

title: Yank Games This Week
description: TodayOakland at Shea Stadium, 2, 1 P.M.

title: In Italy, the Energy Crisis Was Just Too Much to Take.
description: ROME  With a collective groan, Italians are now paying 20 per cent more for beef and veal, up to 80 per cent more for electricity, 15 per cent moreor about $1.70 a gallonfor gasoline, and stiff new taxes on the autos, motorcycles, pleasure craft and apartments they own.

title: BALI Bulletin Board
description: Brooklyn  Brooklyn in the Early Twentieth Century, by Henry Sanford Northrup, through Sept. 28, Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., Long Island Historical Society, 128 Pierrepont Street.

title: TREMOR IN STATE CLASSED AS QUAKE
description: A tremor last June 7 that startled residents of Wappingers Falls, N. Y., and that was assumed by many to have been a quarry blast, has been diagnosed as a small earthquake.

title: The New Bork Times Book Beuiew Editors Choice
description: THE DEATH OF THE DETECTIVE, by Mark Smith. (Knopf, $8.95.) A detective hunts down a madman who has incarnated himself as Death In this teeming novel set on Chicago's dark side.

title: Israel Builds New Border Fence
description: MALKIYA, Israel, July 13 The dense coils of concertina wire are studded with tiny razor blades and rooted to the ground by iron stakes. The 12 foot  high hurricane fence is alive with electric warning devices and topped with strands of barbed wire.

title: J. V. Hazlett 3d Plans to Marry Sarah J. Hutton
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. Hutton 3d of Rye, N.Y., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sarah Johnson Hutton, to James V. Hazlett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hazlett Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia.

title: APPLICANTS SEEK VETERINARY JOBS
description: An unprecedented interest in veterinary medicine is causing such a surge in applications that officials at some of the nation's 19 veterinary colleges say it is now more difficult to get into veterinary school than into medical school.

title: Richard Raible Weds Sarah Provenzano
description: Miss Sarah Andrews Provenzano was married yesterday morning to Richard Anton Raible, The Rev. Hugh Eller performed the ceremony in St, Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Huntington, L. I. He was assisted by the Rev. John J. Skelly.

title: Met Games This Week
description: TodayAt Los Angeles. TomorrowOpen date. TuesdayAt San Francisco, night.

title: Panama Reports a Quake
description: PANAMA CITY, July 13 (Reuters)About 200 persons were left homeless in Darien province by an earthquake that shook this capital yesterday. The earthquake, centered on the Colombian border in the area of Turbo, destroyed 28 houses in the towns of El Real and La Palma.

title: On Listening to Mahler, Ravel and Ives Play Their Own Music
description: SOME years ago, when ff was younger and still knew virtually everything, I believed what I heard on historical records. I believed, for instance, that Debussy played his Preludes flabbily and without dynamic contrastlike a cocktail pianist, was how I think I phrased it. That opinion, as connoisseurs of historical recordings may already have suspected, was based wholly on a MignonWelte piano roll performance that appeared about a decade ago transferred onto a longplay disk. Fortunately, I gave my opinion of Debussy's pianism in the presence of a pianist who did not need records, historical or otherwise, to know how the French composer played. The pianist, Rudolph Ganz, was born 15 years after Debussy and died in Chicago only two years ago at age 95. He explained to me with the greatest possible tact not only how excellent a pianist Debussy had been, but how little the presentday listener can rely on historical records, especially certain piano rolls, as a basis for artistic opinions.

title: Nancy Hardy Bride of Lawrence Getto
description: Miss Nancy Jean Hardy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hugill Hardy Jr. of Pelham Manor and Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., was married to Lawrence Phillip Getto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Getto of Rockaway, N.J., yesterday afternoon. The Rev. John Fitch performed the nondenominational ceremony on the lawn of the Hardy home on Boulder. Island at Saranac Lake. A reception was given at the Wawbeek Inn.

title: Cardigan Bay: Nondescript, Battered and a Winner
description: Ten years ago next Tuesday, probably the most spectacular of all harnesshorse races took place at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Red Smith
description: Jay Hanna Dean, who is also known as Jerome Herman Dean but answers more readily when addressed as Dizzy, was born in Lucas, Ark., or maybe Bond, Miss., or perhaps Holdenville, Okla., sometime in 1911 or thereabouts, and approximately 19 years later pitched his first game in the major leagues. He knocked off the Pittsburgh Pirates on three hits. The following winter Ile showed up unannounced in the Cardinals offices in Sportsman's Park in St. Louis and went into executive session with Branch Rickey, the vice president and general manager. Two or three hours later, aware that newspapermen were on the premises, he departed by a rear door and Rickey trudged wearily into the outer office.

title: A master animal trainer responds
description: Ever since the publication of Science and Human Behavior in 1953, B. F. Skinner has been identified as the spokesman for behaviorism, that school of psychology whose program is to consider only those facts which can be objectively observed in the behavior of one person in its relation to his prior environmental history. Its charge against other schools of psychology is that in their search for explanations, they turn from observed behavior to a fanciful inner world. They appeal, in other words, to such fanciful concepts as mind, feeling, consciousness, and so on. By a long and sometimes torturous path, spelied out in detail in his Beyond Freedom and Dignity, Skinner finally concludes that freedom and dignity are illusions toomoreover, illusions fully as dangerous to mankind as the concept of mind is to a scientific psychology.

title: William Mackey Weds Miss Greenwood
description: Miss Cynthia Louise Greenwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Greenwood of Holyoke, Mass., was married there last evening to William Charles Mackey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Williard C. Mackey Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Matra First
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., July 13After a fine morning and a promising early afternoon, Mario Andretti's luck changed back to bad this evening.

title: LETTERS
description: John R. Bunting expresses some of the most transparently ridiculous opinions I have ever read by a business leader. I em not questioning that his methods might not right a listing ship (Tight Money Is Not Enough, June 23)merely question whether or not it wouldn't be better to bail out that ship rather than rearrange the ballast.

title: Temple Provides Bus Service for Newark Elderly
description: NEWARK  For half of the 958 older citizens of the 1,367resident Seth Boyden Houses, a lowincome project in a depressed area of Newark, the day begins at 10 A.M., when a rented bus lakes them food shopping or to a barbecue or a ride the ferry.

title: A Conference Asks: Can Television Be Trusted?
description: Do the words truth and authenticity set you to instant nodding? How about appearance and reality? Or art and fact? Consider the plight of the group that met recently in Virginia for several days to discuss precisely these terms and their relationship to television, notorious propagator of the passive audience. More surprisingly, consider that the sessions, a mixture of programing screenings and group reaction; produced some lively debates on questions essential to the very existence of television.

title: MARION A. YAGUDA
description: Marion Archbold Yaguda, a past president of the women's auxiliary of the American Medical Association and National Council of Homemaker Services, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical: Center. She was 73 years old and lived in Montague, N.J.

title: How to Fight Inflation: A Survey
description: Last Thursday President Nixon opened a national dialogue on how to cope with inflation, He invited 31 businessmen and economists to discuss with him the worldwide disease that has been plaguing ordinary citizens and national economies, threatening political leaders and shredding the reputations of pundits whose remedies don't seem to work.

title: Miss Edwards To Be a Bride
description: Miss Donna Claire Edwards, daughter of Mrs. Sara B. Edwards of Atlanta and Douglas Edwards, a radio and television correspondent for CBS News in New York, who lives in New Canaan, Conn., and William Jantzen Opper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Lincoln Opper of Rockport, Me., plan to marry Sept. 7 at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn. A wedding reception is planned at the Black Swan Restaurant in Old Saybrook.

title: An Original AllIsland Musical Opens in Hauppauge
description: HAUPPAUGE  When it comes to Broadway, this mid  Suffolk community is certainly off geographically. The Long Island Expressway is not exactly 42d Street.

title: At 81, She Finds She Can't Hold to 5Day Week
description: PRINCETONFor 81yearold Dorothea Greenbaum, a sculptor and printmaker, there is no such thing as the fiveday week.

title: Films That Refuse To Fade Away
description: LIKE unused skis, a second tennis racquet or an outofdate bankhook, movies occasionally get lost. They disappear physically. The negative is thrown out. The cans of film are misplaced. No one remembers where they were stored. However, movies also are sometimes found. Movies like Walking Tall and Billy Jack belong to one type of found movie: the movie that more or less ignores New York with the same kind of persistence as a bad but popular Broadway show that stays on the tryout road making nothing but money. Walking Tall and Billy Jack were found in the provinces. People out there loved them and, in the case of Walking Tall, they made it a giant hit long before it was seen in Manhattan. The New York critics had nothing to do with it. They had been ignored.

title: A tragedy, an enigma, a political Achilles heel.
description: Five years ago, around midnight of July 18, 1969, a black fourdoor Oldsmobile 88 owned by Senator Edward Kennedy was driven off a bridge on Chappaquiddick Island, Mass., and it landed upside down in eight feet of water. About 9 o'clock the next morning a scuba diver entered the car and recovered the body of Mary Jo Kopechne, 28, one of the dozens of young women who in those days looked upon themselves as followers of the Kennedy clan.

title: Group Seeking to Sort Out Historical Documents
description: STONY BROOKFor years years, professional and amateur historians have missed opportunities to study materials they could not find, or did not even know existed. But now, a new organization has been formed to sort out the problem.

title: Hatchet Man Sets Mark By JOE NICHOLS
description: The next time out Hatchet Man finished fourth in a race that was run on the slop.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Richard Lyons news article The Challenges to the Doctors [Week in Review, June 30] was a rather brief recounting of the most newsworthy problems facing American health. It failed, however, to even approach the crux of the various problems.

title: Miss Morse Wins State Golf Title
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 13 (AP)Cathy Morse of Pittsford won the New York State women's amateur golf championship today. She defeated Diane Wilde of Amsterdam, 4 and 3, in the final match.

title: Late TV Listings
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2.

title: Richmond Discards Pupil Reassignment Following Protests
description: RICHMOND, July 13 (AP)The Richmond School Board decided today that the city's residents were weary of continual changes in school attendance patterns and killed a proposed pupil assignment plan that would have reduced crosstown busing.

title: The New School Arrangement Can Be Integrated and Unequal
description: The United States Supreme Court has put off ruling on the Detroit case, in which a lower court has ordered that white children from 53 suburban towns that surround the city be integrated with pupils in Detroit's overwhelmingly black schools. Decision is expected soon. Whether or not the court holds that metropolitan integration is required under the law, its decision will exacerbate An increasingly acrimonious debate within the black community over whether school integration should Continue to be a major social priority for black Americans.

title: Bottles Are Hurled at Rodino in Newark
description: NEWARK, July 13 (AP) Representative Peter W. Rodino, Jr. was met with a barrage of water, eggs and bottles as he toured the Columbus Homes development today.

title: Camille Marie Kiely Wed to Rory Kelleher
description: Miss Camille Marie Kiely, daughter of Prof. James J. Kiely of the English faculty at Bentley College in Waltham, Mass., and Mrs. Kiely of South Hingham, Mass., was married yesterday afternoon to Rory Kelleher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Kelleher of Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Weekly List of Mutual Funds
description: The following Is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

title: EDNA A. MTERSON DIES; HEADED RIGHTS UNIT
description: Edna Astruck Merson, a founder and chairman for 12 years of the Committee on Civil Rights in Manhattan, died Saturday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 78 years old and lived at 410 East 57th Street.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: More than 1,000 people representing 13 regions under Communist rule marched up New York City's Fifth Avenue to begin the 16th annual observance of Captive Mains Week.

title: Two Defeats For Valiant In Cup Trial
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 14The America's Cup trial races took on the character of interminability today as Valiant bombed out.

title: Letters to the Editor Of Press Freedom, the Right to Reply
description: The Supreme Court decision striking doWn Florida's right to reply law is, not surprisingly, being hailed by the press as another victory for liberty.

title: Advertising: The Male Attitude
description: Does where an ad appear affect its chances of being noticed? Media advertising salesmen frequently hawk the importanceof their editorial environment but there has been little if any research to back up claims.

title: A's Win by 74, 61 Bando Hits Pair
description: The Yankees trying to come up in the standings, got their comeuppance instead yesterday at Shea Stadium. The Oakland A's, who, its seems, play only as hard as necessary to win the pennant, finally rose up and smote their Neiv York tormentors twice, 73 and 61, before 42,915 sundrenched fans.

title: Red Sox Kings for a Day in American League East
description: The game of musical chairs continued in the American League Eastern Division yesterday as the Boston Red Sox became the third Team in three days to occupy first place. The Cleveland Indians were on top Saturday and the Baltimore Orioles were there before the start of yesterday's schedule.

title: Agitate Wins By 2 Lengths In Rich Race
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 14 (AP)The favored Agitate, with Bill Shoemaker riding, outdueled Stardust Mel to win the $150,000 Hollywood Derby at Hollywood Park today by two lengths.

title: Silicone Infections Traced to Tijuana
description: SAN DIEGOA 40yearold divorcee yearning for a more alluring figure answered an advertisement promising Silicone for a Beautiful Bust in the personals column of a San Diego suburban newspaper.

title: A Listing of Recently Published Books
description: Return Journey by R. F. Delderfield (Simon & Schuster, $8.95). Small English seaside resort in the ninefeentwenties.

title: Bastille Parade in Paris Returns to Bastille Site
description: PARIS, July 14It was parade of men, not machines, on this Bastille Day of 1974.

title: PROFESSOR TO HEAD CITY RENT BOARD
description: The City Council is expected to approve at its next regular meeting Mayor Beame's nomination of Jerome Prince, professor of law and dean emeritus of the Brooklyn Law School, as chairman of the Conciliation and Appeals Board.

title: Rise in Eskimo Mental Illness Linked To the Intrusion of Western Society
description: YELLOWKNIFE, North West Territories, July 12Social dislocations caused by the intrusion of Western ways upon the simpler hunting and fishing society of the Far North have been followed by a severe outbreak of mental illness, suicides and murders among Eskimos, according to mental health exports.

title: Bash Pleased Report Cleared G.O.P. Panel
description: WASHINGTON; July 14 (AP)George Bush, chairman of the Republican National Committee, said today that he was pleased that the Senate Watergate com mittee has confirmed in its final report that the G.O.P. committee had not been involved with Watergate.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: Matlack Takes 8th on 6.Hitter, 41
description: LOS ANGELES, July 14With Bud Harrelson back at shortstop, Teddy Martinez plaYing second in place of the injured Felix Milian, and Jon Matlack pitching the kind of game that has made him so respected a lefthander in less than three major league seasons, the New York Mets defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4.1, today.

title: SIMON ASKS EGYPI TO WIDEN APPEAI FOR INVESTMENT
description: CAIRO, July 14Treasurl Secretary William E. Simon started three days of talks with Egyptian officials here to day on the question of hour to make Egypt safe and at tractive for American anc other foreign capital.

title: Jackson Crosses Fairfield Picket Line
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 14 Four days ago, Honor Jackson told player representatives of the New York Giants that he was coming to camp, even if it meant crossing a union picket line.

title: MORRIS HARTIG
description: Morris Hartig, a founding partner of Gruntal & Co., stockbrokers, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 90 Riverside Drive.

title: New Corporate Bonds
description: New Corporate Bonds

title: U.S. URGED TO CUT SOUTH KOREAN AID
description: The United States Government was urged yesterday to protest the injustice and the inhumanity of President Park Chung Hee's acts in South Korea and to limit further aid to that country.

title: Police Divided Over Assignment Of Women to Street Patrol Here
description: The assignment of policewomen in the last year to street patrol has turned into such an emotional issue that it is dividing the rank and file of the Police Department.

title: Caramoor
description: KATONAH, N. Y., July. 14  The Caramoor Festival took a lighthearted turn last night with the presentation of a pair of trifles that Mozart and Antonio Salteri created for a party at the Schtinbrunn Castle Orangenie in 1786.

title: Winner Planning to Use Squad on Hand
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 14 Wave after wave of experienced players stayed away from the Jets training camp on their scheduled reporting day today, but Coach Charley Winner forged ahead with plans to prepare his rookies for a full complement of exhibition and regularseason games.

title: 3,000 Attend Black Heritage Festival at Arts Center
description: HOLMDEL, July 14The hills of northern Monmouth County reverberated this evening to the driving drums of the African Dance Society of NewArk and the spirituals of the Missionary Jubilaires.

title: 11Yearolds From 12 Countries Are Spending Harmonious Sufnmer in Tarrytown Camp
description: When Judy Hilsinger leaves her desk at Bantam Books and rushes up to Tarrytown, N.Y., it is, she says, to reenter the experience that changed her life over 20 years ago. It is also to make sure that4the 60 foreigners she imported to New York this summer are enjoying an experience that will change their lives as well. Fortyeight 11yearold children from 12 different countries, each national group accompanied by one adult, are participating in the first Children's Internatiopal Summer Village ever to be based in the New York area, Miss Hilsinger is its mother.

title: JACKSON LINKS AID FOR SOVIET TO ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (Reuters) Senator Henry M. Jackson said today that trade concessions to the Soviet Union should be tied to an agreement by Moscow to cut military spending.

title: Yugoslav Freighter Sinks
description: BARI, Italy, July 14 (AP)The 2,092ton Yugoslav freighter Cavtat sank today after a collision with an 11,000ton freighter of Panamanian registry four miles off Cape Otranto in eastern Italy. Maritime authorities said all 30 of the Cavtat's crewmen had been rescued by the other ship, the Lady Rita.

title: HARLEM JOB UNIT SCORED IN AUDIT
description: A state audit of a Harlem educational and job training facility administered by the City University said yesterday that while the center's yearly budget had nearly tripled to more than $1.3million in the last six years, the number of people placed in jobs fell from 166 in 1968 to 32 in 1973.

title: PATRONS OF A BAR KILL ROBBER HERE
description: A gunman who had shot bartender during a holdup in bar near the northern tip of Manhattan early yesterday was then set upon by several patrons, who wrested his gun away and shot him to death, the police said.

title: Immigration Service Data Said to Curb Two Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, July 14Congress and the Justice Department are reluctant to pursue allegations of corruption in the Immigration and Naturalization Service because of adverse information about Congressmen, members of Congressional staffs, a Federal judge and some officials of the executive branch, according to wellplaced Government sources.

title: Red Sox Kings for a Day in American League has
description: his ninth victory and first since June 17. His main support came from Davey Johnson, who hammered a threerun homer. Hank, Aaron, making his final appearance in St. Louis as an active player, received an ovation his first time at bat. He has hit 90 of his 725 home runs off St. Louis pitching.

title: On Spending and Taxes
description: Mr. Nixon has made clear that he does not intend to do anything bigto cut taxes or to increase them, to experiment again with wageprice guidelines or to restructure his budget. The huge and rising defense budget is apparently sacrosanct. The President continues to talk in terms of minor trims in his $305 billion budget, but it appears that Federal spending is more likely to go up than down this year, with outlays for hausing, veterans education and welfare payments to the aged and disabled rising more than expected.

title: PATRONS OF A BAR KILL ROBBER HERE
description: A gunman who had shot a bartender during a holdup in a bar near the northern tip of Manhattan early yesterday was then set upon by several patrons, who wrested his gun away and shot him to death, the police said.

title: If You Were Worried
description: WASHINGTONIf you were worried about the outcome of the Supreme Court's deliberations about your case; if survival in office were your goal; and if you had a good instinct for the manipulation of the mediawhat would you do to get ready to turn lemon into lemonade?

title: Buckskins Edge Sets Team, 2625
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 14 (UP1)The Minnesota kluckskins edged the New York Sets, 2625, last night and clung to first place in the Gulf Plains section of World Team Tennis.

title: Common Cause Advances in Suit To Curb the Franking Privilege
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Common Cause, the selfdescribed citizens lobbying organization, has advanced its suit against the Government that, if successful, would reduce substantially the Congressional franking, or free m%iling, privileges.

title: 7 DROUGHT LANDS GET FOOD SUPPLY
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, July 14 United Nations appeals for food for seven droughtstricken nations at the southern edge of the Sahara are being met, relief officials here report.

title: Winner Planning to Use Squad on Hand
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 14 Wave after wave of experienced players stayed away from the Jets training camp on their scheduled reporting day today, but Coach Charley Winner forged ahead with plans to prepare his rookies for a full complement of exhibition and regularseason games.

title: CLAYTON FARRIS
description: DELRAY BEACH, Fla., July 14 (AP) Clayton Farris, president of the Trucktor Corporation, a New Jerseybased concern, died yesterday of cancer. He was 79 years old.

title: MURIEL SONNENFELD
description: Muriel Block Sonnenfeld, a social worker and manager of the mental health clinic at the Queens House of Detention for Men, Kew Gardens, died Saturday of complications from a hernia in Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens. She was 46 years old and lived at 7622 Grand Central Parkway, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Pastry crusts with soggy bottoms and anemiclooking sides can be avoided with a new black tin quiche pan. The black metal ??? heat quickly rather than reflecting it.

title: Attack on Rodino Laid to Racial Tension
description: NEWARK, July 14Smoldering antagonisms between white residents of a Roman Catholic parish here and the nearly, tallblack population of a  housing development that many in Newark consider the city's worst, apparently fueled the attack late yesterday on Representative Peter W. Rodin Jr. of Newark, who was making an inspection visit.

title: SEPARATISM GAINS IN WEST AUSTRALIA
description: PERTH, Australia On the transportation page of The West Australian, Perth's morning newspaper, shipping and aircraft movements are divided into two sections, overseas and E.S., or the eastern states pf Australia.

title: Henley Trial a San Antonio Attraction
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 14 One of the major points of interest in this sunbaked tourist city these days is the mass murder trial of Elmer Wayne Henley Jr.

title: Whale Quotas
description: The claims contained in a letter from the Japan Whaling Information Center, appearing elsewhere on this page, will astonish anyone familiar with the facts. At.the 1973 meeting of the International Whaling Commission, both Japan and Russia voted against quotas for fin, sperm and minke whales, refusing to accept them even after they were approved by a majority of the member nations.

title: Sindona's $1Million Offer To Nixon Group Examined
description: The Internal Revenue Service is investigating an offer made in 1972 by Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who is the largest single shareholder in the troubled Franklin National Bank, to contribute $1million to the Committee to Reelect the President, according to ininformation obtained from Govarnment sources.

title: Race Week For Yachts
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 14Because of poor wind, the only sailors who were able to compete on the second day of the 76th Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week today were those manning 71 yachts in the three cruising classes.

title: Chou Suffered Heart Attack, Chinese Disclose
description: PEKING, July 14 Chinese officials, explaining Premier Chou ??? stay in the hospital, have told a visiting Canadian delegation that the 76yearold head of government has suffered a heart attack. The officials did not disclose when the attack occurred or how serious it was. Premier Chou said two months ago that he was not feeling well, but it was only last week that the Chinese press announced that he was in the hospital.

title: INCOME TAX FACES FIRST TEST TODAY
description: TRENTON, July 14 (AP)Officials of Governor Byrne's administration maintained over the weekend that they could round up enough votes to pass Mr. Byrne's incometax plan, but conceded that the Governor could be dealt an embarrassing defeat.

title: Afghanistan Is Reported Denying Troop Movement
description: NEW DELHI, July 14 (Reuters)Afghanistan has denied moving troops to her frontier with Pakistan and has charged that Pakistan has bombed border districts, it was reported here today.

title: Off Off Broadway Emerging From Wings
description: Drawing thousands of playgoers to more than 700 productions on the Bowery the East Side, the Upper West Side, Greenwich Village and on the fringes of Chinatown, Off Off Broadway has sharply increased its audience this season, possibly even doubling it.

title: War Hero in a Losing Battle
description: Edward N. Evans operated a firefighter crash truck with the Army Air Forces in combat zones during World War II. His squadron medical officer said he was admired by all for his fearlessness and valor amid exploding bombs and ammunition.

title: Pincay Loses a Fight And 6 Hollywood Rides
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 14 (AP) His left eye swollen shut after a postrace fight with a fellow jockey, Wayne Harris, Laffit Pincay was forced to cancel all of his six mounts today at Hollywood Park because of his injuries.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: DOWN

title: TEARS OVER FOOD GROWING IN INDIA
description: NEW DELHI, July 14Farmers in the Punjab pleaded with a Government minister yesterday for more fertilizer, and in the state of Uttar Pradesh, officials expressed fear that dwindling wheat supplies would not reach Government shops in cities. In New Delhi, Government reserves of food have ebbed to the lowest point in years.

title: Court And Congress
description: WASHINGTONAfter a slack month, the tide of impeachment is rising again. The Supreme Court argument in the case of the President's tapes, the House Judiciary Committee's voltunes of evidence, the conviction of John Ehrlichman, the Senate Watergate report: These dramas in quick succession have had their Impact.

title: Reserve Is Gratified By Franklin Result
description: WASHINGTON, July 14The Federal Reserve Board has been able to undertake a massive rescue operation for the Franklin National Bank without compromising its overall monetary policy objectives.

title: 'Duel of Pitchers Erupts Into a RedsPirates Brawl
description: PITTSBURGH, July 14 (AP) Daryl Patterson, a Pittsburgh Pirate relief pitcher, never threw a pitch in today's double header split with Cincinnati, but he finished the day with a black eye, some missing hair and a bite that was treated with a tetanus Shot.

title: WEICKER CHARGES COVERUP GOES ON
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. a member of the nowdefunct Senate Watergate committee, charged today that a highlevel coverup of White House involvement in the Watergate affair was still continuing.

title: Cosmos Streak Ends on 31 Loss To Italian Team
description: The New York Cosmos lid one good thing left going for them, but now that is gone, too.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LEONIA, July 14In the last 11 years, basketball has blossomed as a summer tradition in this southern Bergen County town.

title: Striking Baltimore Police Told to Work or Lose Jobs
description: BALTIMORE, July 14Police Commissioner Donald D. Pomerleau announced tonight that striking policemen would be dismissed unless they returned to work immediately.

title: BUSINESS IS SLOW TO ENTER EGYPT
description: CAIRO, July 14Six months after it was proclaimed by President Anwar elSadat, Egypt's open door policy aimed at attracting foreign capital and Western technology is still in Tits preliminary stage.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, JULY 16, 1974
description: Treasury Secretary William S. Simon began three days of talks with Egyptian officials on the question of how to make Egypt safe and attractive for American and other foreign capital. He conferred for more thin two hours with Deputy Premier Abdel Aziz Hegazi, who explained the structure of the Egyptian economy. Mr. Hegazi assured him that the foreigninvestment liberalization measures recently adopted in Egypt are farreaching, members of Mr. Simon's delegation said. [1:]

title: James Magill, Banker, Dies; Gave Haverford $3Million
description: James P. Magill, a retired Philadelphia investment banker, civic leader and philanthropist, died Saturday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 88 years old.

title: Immigration Service Data Said to Curb Two Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 Congress and the Justice Department are reluctant to pursue allegations of corruption in the Immigration and Naturalization Service because of adverse information about Congressmen, members of Congressional staffs, a Federal judge and some officials of the executive branch, according to wellplaced Government sources.

title: Barry Curtis, a Rock Musician, Marries Pamela Artura Katims
description: Pamela Artura Katims, daughter of Milton Katims, music director and conductor of the Seattle Symphony Orchestra, and of Mrs. Katims of New York and Seattle, was married yesterday afternoon to Barry Richardson Curtis, a rock musician who is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Curtis of Mount Vernon, Wash.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: There appears to be no danger or an epidemic of some strange disease, following the unsolved deaths of two young sisters from a Lake Grove, L, I., family, according to Dr. Sidney B. Weinberg, the Suffolk County Medical Examiner.

title: Today's Entries at Monmouth
description: Today's Entries at Monmouth

title: 7 Hostages Flee Cell With a Smuggled Key
description: WASHINGTON, July 14All seven hostages who had been held for nearly three days in the basement cell block of court building by two armed convicts escaped today by using an elevator key smuggled in to them.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 27

title: Radio
description: 610 A.M., WNCN. Trauermusik, Hindemith; Pas de deux from Paquita, Minkus; Overture to Semiramide, Rossini; Dense; Debussy; Concerto No. 1 in F minor, Vivaldi; Overture to L'Olimpiade, Pergolesi; Concerto for Guitar, Violin, Viola and Cello, Vivaldi; Overture in G minor, Bruckner; Jeux d'Enfants, Bizet.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A report on New Jersey's economy indicates that businesses are still in a sales slump and that the number of people out of work remains disturbingly high, the Commissioner of Labor and Industry, Joseph A. Hoffman, said. A report by his department's planning and research division shows business is still in the doldrums.

title: Marion Cooper Wed To David Alan Pollock
description: Marion Cooper, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Cooper of West Newton, Mass., was married there yesterday afternoon to David Alan Pollock, a member of the technical staff at Bell Telephone Laboratories in Holmdel, N. S. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Pollock of Malverne, L. I. Rabbi Terry Bard performed the ceremony at Temple Shalom.

title: Shipping/Mails All Hours Given In Daylight Savings Time
description: Tomorrow, July 16

title: About New York War Between Sexes Just Not the Same
description: There is a stillness now, and the rhetoric is not so noisy. Some of the heroines have fallen and been replaced, and others carry on as before. The Great Republic has tottered, but it has not yet collapsed, and What isegan in anger has almost a placidity about it now. What will happen to the women's movement nobody knows, but the old war between men and women is just not the same.

description: Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, first Chief of Staff of the Air Force and commander of United States strategic bombing forces in Europe and the Pacific in World War IL died yesterday at Walter Reed Medical Center in Washington lie was 83 years old.

title: Guyana Set to Nationalize Reynolds Bauxite Venture
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, July, 14  Prime Minister Forbes Burnham said today that his Government would nationalize; Reynolds Guyana Mines, Ltd a subsidiary of the Reynolds Metals Company, by the end of this year.

title: BLACKS PROTEST PITTSBURGH HUNT
description: PITTSBURGH, July 14 Black residents of this city have strongly condemned tactics used by the police in their search for three black suspects in the July 3 killing of Patrick Wallace Jr., 32 years old, a white patrolman.

title: Consumer Notes
description: Trustees of New Jersey's Blue Cross and Blue Shield are scheduled to vote July 25 on a proposal that would open the hospitalizationand medicalinsurance plans on a oneshot, 30day basis to people now ineligible for enrollmentthose who suffer from such chronic illnesses as heart disease and diabetes.

title: Rising Costs Peril Kawaida Towers; Builder Is Balking
description: NEWARK, July 14Kawaida Towers, the controversial black sponsored housing project that has been fighting and winninglegal tests, for two years, may nave to be abandoned because of inflationary construction costs.

title: Contract Talks Go On With Firemen's Union
description: Intensified negotiations ordered by Mayor Beame were under way agate last night between the city and the 11,000member Uniformed Firefighters Association in an effort to complete agreement on a new twoyear contract.

title: Books of The Times
description: FLYING. By Kate Millett. 545 pages, Knopf. $8,95.

title: Soviet Space Maneuver
description: MOSCOW, July 14 (AP)Soviet astronauts Pavel Popovich and Yuri Artyukhin moved from their Salyut 3 space station into the docked Soyuz 14 transport craft during their ninth working day in space to work on the Soyuz's manual controls, Tass reported today. In its brief progress report, said government press agency said the men were feeling well, but id did not include the customary statement that the space laboratory's systems were functioning normally.

title: Striking Baltimore Police Told to Work or Lose Jobs
description: BALTIMORE, July 14Police Commissioner Donald Pomerleau announced tonight that striking policemen would be dismissed unless they returned to work immediately.

title: Rising Costs May Scuttle Kawaida Towers Project
description: NEWARK, July 14KawaiIda Towers, the controversial blacksponsored housing project that has been fightingland tvinninglegal tests for two years, may have to be abandoned because of inflationary construction costs.

title: ALBERT KINOY
description: Albert Kinoy, a former health education teacher at Boys High School Brooklyn and past chairman of the high school games council of the Public School Athletic League, died yesterday in Peekskill (N. Y.) Community Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N. Y.

title: Clapton, Rock Virtuoso, Plugs in at the Garden
description: Ever since Eric Clapton stepped into the spotlight with the Yardbirds in 1964, he has been dogged with a tagEric Clapton is Goda tribute to his guitarplaying by his more fanatical fans, and one that may not have been meant entirely facetiously.

title: Farm Union Continues Its Picketing of Shoprite
description: ORANGE, July 14 (UP)The United Farm Workers yesterday, continued their picketing of Shoprite Foodarama owned by a man the union says broke an agreement not to stock nonunion table grapes.

title: Strike in Ohio Spreads to a 7th Prison
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 14 (AP)A strike for higher pay by more than 2,000 prison guards and other state workers spread to a seventh prison and a fifth mental health center tonight.

title: Major League Baseball Results and Standings
description: The Way They Stand Today

title: JACK SOLOW
description: Jack Solow, president of J. Solow & Son, Ltd., diamond cutters; 48 West 48th Street, died Thursday. He was 78 years old and lived in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: AUDIT DISCOVERS $5.4MILLION GONE FROM CITY VAULT
description: An outside audit of trust funds held by the City Controller has discovered that $5.4million in easily negotiable securities are not in the city vault where the Controller's records say they should be.

title: Lowenstein Enters Race for Congress In District on L.I.
description: MINEOLA, L.I., July 14Allard K. Lowenstein, the antiwas activist and former Long Island Congressman, tonight announced his candidacy for Congress from Long Island's Fifth Congressional district.

title: How the Electric Guitar Became a Way of Music
description: The enormous adulationeven adoration  accorded such a diffident instrumentalist as Eric Clanton on his current American tour is but the most recent proof of the place the electric guitar has gained in our musical life.

title: FUCHSBERG SEEKS HIGH COURT BENCH
description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, who lost an expensive and highpressure campaign for Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals last year, yesterday announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for associate judge of the state's highest court.

title: Portugal's New Premier Works To Form Cabinet to End Crisis
description: LISBON, July 14Col, Vasco dos Santos Goncalves, an army engineer who was unexpectedly chosen last night as the next Premier of Portugal, began today to try to form a Governrnent of military men and civilian leaders to tackle a mounting series of problems here and in Africa.

title: President May End G.I. Bill of Rights For Future Service
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The Nixon Administration is considering killing the G.I. Bill of Rights for future veterans, Congressional and Administration sources said today.

title: Giscardian France, Without the Past Grandeur, Is Put on Parade
description: PARIS, July 14 France celebrated Bastille Day under her new President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, today. He used the occasion to advance the aim of giving his administration a new image of vigor, popular concern, and a modern and simple style in contrast with the grandeur of past years.

title: British Report Navy Ship Sails Through Suez Canal
description: LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) A British Navy minesweeper, the Maxton, today became the first vessel since 1967 to travel the whole length of the Suez Canal, the British Ministry of Defense said in London.

description: MOVIES IN THE PARKS, Presented by The Film society of Lincoln Center, Sunset Park, Brooklyn, enter et 44th Street and Fltth Avenue, 9 P.M.

title: 14 Killed in Communist Shelling During Voting in SOuth Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 14 (Reuters)  Fourteen persons were killed, 67 were wounded and three are missing after Communist shellings around polling stations today during South Vietnam's local council elections, Interior Ministry officials said.

title: Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, 83, Dead; First Air Force Chief of Staff
description: Gen. Carl A. Spaatz, first Chief of Staff of the Air Force and commander of United States strategic bombing forces in Europe and the Pacific in World War It, died yesterday at Walter Reed Medical Center in Washington. He was 83 years old. The Air Force said death was the result of congestive heart failure.

title: Ecological Treasure Dedicated
description: BERNARDSVILLE, July 14The New Jersey Conservation Foundation today dedicated an ecological treasure, the 165acre estate of W. Redmond Cross, a businessman who died in 1940. The 70yearold estate was purchased by the foundation from the Bank of New York for $750,000. The bank had acted as trustee of the late millionaire's properties.

description: More than 1,000 people representing 31 regions under: Communist rule Marched up' Fifth Avenue yeterday morning to begin the 16th annual servance of Captive Nations Week.

description: WASHINGTON, July 14All seven hostages who had been held for nearly three days in the basement cell block of court building by two armed convicts escaped today by using an elevator key smuggled in to them.

title: HOle Shuts Some Lanes Of West Side Highway
description: Another gaping hole confronted motorists on the West Side Highway yesterday afternoona twofootbythreefoot abyss at 55th Street that forced the closing of the southbound lanes from 72d to 46th Streets for several hours.

title: An End to No knock?
description: In voting to end authority for District of Columbia policemen and Federal narcotics agents around the country to obtain warrants to enter dwellings without knocking and identifying themselves, the Senate has taken a wise step which the House should quickly follow. The noknock authority was first granted to District of Columbia policemen in the District of Columbia Crime bill paised in 1970. The last Senate vote on the issue came in October 1970 On ari effurt by Senator Ervin to delete it from the Drug Abuse Prevention Act. Senator Ervin's amendment failed then by a vote of 4220.

title: Jackson Crosses Fairfield Picket Line
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 14 Four days ago, Honor Jackson told player representatives of the New York Giants that he was coming to camp, even if it meant crossing a union picket line.

title: 3 Guards Hurt as Inmates Take Over Queens Jail Floor

title: Andretti, Oliver Win

title: A's Win by 74, 61 Bando Hits Pair
description: The Yankees trying to come up in the standings, got their comeuppance instead yesterday at Shea Stadium. The Oakland A's, who, its seems, play only as hard as necessary to win the pennant, finally rose up and smote their New York tormentors twice, 73 and 61, before 42,915 sundrenched fans.

title: War Hero in a Losing Battle
description: Edward N. Evans operated a firefighter crash truck with the Army Air Forces in combat zones during World War II. His squadron medical officer said he was admired by all for his fearlessness and valor amid exploding bombs and ammunition.

title: Back to Square One
description: In his private meeting with a group of businessmen and economists last week, President Nixon did more listening than talking, according to his chief economic spokesman, Kenneth Rush. But what Mr. Nixon did say, as reported by others present at the meeting, suggests that, after five and a half years of oscillating economic policy, culminating in the worst inflation this country has sustained in its peacetime history the President back where he beganwith a policy of gradualism that depends solely on slow monetary growth to bring down the rate of inflation.

title: Personal Finance: Small Investors Highest Yields
description: Until the stock market shows signs of turning around, millions of small investors are eagerly looking for a safe place in which to pace, their money and still get a fairly substantial return.

title: Guide
description: IRISH UP With all the outdoor summer music proarams going on these days, you have to give special credit to a group that has mething unusual to offer today at 12:15 P.M. a popular quintet from Ireland tailed Casterbridge Union will be presenting, at Bryant park, a repertory of a relatively new form of rock muic called Celtic rock.

title: A Fresh Air Visit for Senior Citizens
description: CROTON  ON HUDSON, N.Y.From the picnic table, 63yearold Vivian LoPinto of the Croton Senior Citizens winked at 65yearold Cone WayLee of the Chinatown Open Door.

Rodino Jr. of Newark, who was making an inspection visit.

title: Sinatra, in Encore, Culls Unions Ban Ridiculous
description: SYDNEY, Australia, July 14 (UPI)Frank Sinatra told a concert audience today that last week's union threat to stop his $675,000, fiveconcert tour of Australia was ridiculous.

title: Borg Conquers Panatta In Swedish Tennis Final
description: BAASTAD, Sweden. July 14 (UPI)  Bjorn Borg of Sweden defeated Adriano Panatta of Italy, 63, 60, 67, 63, today in the final of the Swedish open tennis tournament.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 14With Bud Harrelson back at shortstop, Teddy Martinez playing second in place of the injured Felix Milian, and Jon Matlack pitching the kind of game that has made him so respected a lefthander in less than three major league seasons, the New York Mets defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 41, today.

title: Bridge. New York's Triumph Scored Away From the Tables Here
description: The national championships of the American Contract Bridge League usually provide not more than one major winner each day, but there were three triumphs Saturday night at the Americana Hotel, registered by Los Angeles, Miami and New York.

description: After 75 years of viewing the city through tall fences and with scholarly detachment, the Bronx Zoo and the New York Botanical Garden have begun letting their gates swing open for a wide range of community contacts.

title: Catering Place Destroyed
description: A Brooklyn catering establishment was destroyed early yesterday by a fouralarm blare that started in the basement and swept through three floors, the Fire Department reported. Fire officials said the Colonial Mansion in the Bensonhursf (section was unoccupied when the fire erupted shortly before A.M, A wedding reception had ended at the threestory brick building two hours earlier.

title: Madrid Hospital Reports Franco Continues to Gain
description: MADRID, July 14 (Reuters) Doctors attending Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who is hospitalized with phlebitis in his right leg, have begun to reduce the dosage of medicines he is receiving, a medical bulletin said today.

title: Stockton Captures Quad Cities Open by Stroke With a 64 for 271
description: BETTENDORF, Iowa, July 14 (UPI) Dave Stockton shot a blazing sevenunderpar 64 today and captured the $100,000 Quad Cities open golf tournament. He started the round four strokes behind the leaders and finished with a 13underpar 271.

title: Jersey Income Tax
description: A crucial vote is scheduled for today in the New Jersey Assembly on Gov. Brendan T. Byrne's proposal for a state income tax: True to Jersey tradition, the outlook is bleak for finding a sufficient number of legislators willing to stick their necks out in tupport of this longoverdue reform.

title: Screen: Dreams Rampant in 'Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz':The Cast
description: Duddy Kravitz (Richard Dreyfuss) is an 18-year-old Canadian Jewish boy with the face of an angelic WASP. Bute he has his problems. He's not only Jewish, he's very poor. Also, the time is the mid-nineteen-forties, when the other comers who came before Duddy had already invented the light bulb, the radio, the Toni Home Permanent and Kleenex."The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Forum Theaters, is the funny, fantastic and often moving story of Duddy's adventures as he desperately tries to establish himself as a comer. By hook and by crook and by studying books like Willard Funk's "It Pays to Increase Your Word Power."Duddy waits on tables, drives a taxi, smuggles dope, becomes a film producer (for his own Dudley Kane Enterprises), rents out pinball machines and dabbles in odds and ends of other occupations, including forgery."The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz" is a Canadian production that was filmed mostly in and around Montreal. It was written by Mordecai Richler, the Canadian author who wrote the original novel, and directed by Ted Kotcheff, the Canadian film director, none of whose earlier films ("Outback," "Life at the Top") are anywhere near as good as this.Perhaps because of the close collaboration between Mr. Richler and Mr. Kotcheff, and because of the obviously high regard the director has for the author and his work, the film looks very much like a novelist's movie. Such an abundance of visual and narrative detail is essentially literary.This could mean disaster for a movie but not this time. It's true that the frantic pace and the cramming of so many incidents into the film results in certain problems; the continuity is often sketchy and some characters seem less like people than vivid apparitions.Yet the manic, fragmented structure of the film is an almost perfect reflection of Duddy's state of mind as he goes barging from one get-rich-quick scheme to the next, never quite sure where he's headed nor how he's gotten as far as he has without being arrested.When Duddy latches on to Mr. Friar (Denholm Elliott), a perpetually sloshed, blacklisted film director of dubious achievements, and sets up a company to film weddings and bar-mitzvahs, the movie takes on the air of a slightly lunatic fairy tale. Their first production, "Happy Bar-Mitzvah, Bernie!", which we are allowed to see, is a riotously abrasive home-movie that cross-cuts between shots of Bernie's nice, middle-class bar-mitzvah and shots of Zulu rites, Hitler, a circumcision ceremony, storm troops marching, the bar-mitzvah feast and a man eating razor blades.It is superbly loony, a bit frightening and riveting, which is, I suspect, how we're supposed to feel about Duddy who, as played by Mr. Dreyfuss (the intellectual schoolboy in "American Graffiti"), is part cblean-cut conman, part corrupted prophet."It's little money-grubbers like Kravitz that cause anti-Semitism," says a Jewish friend. His rich Uncle Benjy (Joseph Wiseman), who has a portrait of Trotsky on the wall, describes himself as a socialist and owns a blouse factory, calls Duddy "a pushy Jew boy" and says, "People like you make me sick." But then a wealthy Jewish scrap-metal dealer who has befriended Duddy reminds him: "It's war. It's war and the white man has all the guns."The film's attempt to cover so much ground reinforces the feeling that we're watching a kind of urban fable. I have no idea how much time passes in the course of the picture. Duddy's successes and disasters follow upon each other as quickly as those of Dick Whittington. They seem almost magical.This is responsible, I think, for the special appeal of "The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz" and differentiates it from the usual literature about unscrupulous ambition, most of which is pious and dull and goes without saying.There's not a bad performance in the film. In addition to the actors already mentioned, one should also cite Jack Warden who, as Duddy's father, has an especially funny Richlerian monologue at the beginning of the film, Micheline Lanctt, as the French-Canadian girl whom Duddy uses so meanly, and Randy Quaid (the prisoner in "The last Detail") as Virgil, an American gentile and epileptic who becomes one of Duddy's most willing victims.It's Virgil's fondest dream to unite the world's epileptics into an organization that would be rather like the B'nai Brith, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and the Mattachine Society."The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz" is an alternately sad and hilarious movie of dreams rampant.

title: AUDIT DISCOVERS $5.4MILLION GONE
description: An outside audit of trust funds held by the City Controller has discovered that $5.4million in easily negotiable securities are not in the city vault where the Controller's records say they should be.

title: MOOD IS CHEERIER FOR BOND MARKET
description: Credit market optimists, sighting some welcome straws late last week, helped slow the long erosion in values of fixedincome securities. Buyers even looked at the utility bonds for the first time in weeks on Friday. Bond market sentiment was improved by the strong drop in business loans here in the holidayshortened week ended last Wednesday, as reported by the Federal Reserve the following day.

description: John A. Kley, chairman of the County Trust Company, White Plains, has been elected vice chairman of the Bank of New York Company, Inc., it was announced over the weekend.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 14 (UPI)Cathy Douglas, wife of Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, will rejoin a nun she once worked with in a program for severly mentally and physically handicapped children in Oregon, she told a news conference yesterday.

Not satisfied with homegrown talent like Bobby Murcer, Roy White and Thurman Munson that enabled the club to finish second once and fourth no fewer than three times in the last nine years, New York's arrogant ownership raids other rosters for Sandy Alomar, Chris Chambliss, Lou Piniella, Walt Williams, Bill Sitdakis, Jim Mason, Dick Tidrow, Sparky Lyle, Pat Dollson, Sam McDowell, Gene Michael, Graig Nettles, Cecil Upshaw, Elliott Maddox and Rick Dempsey, to name just a few.

title: To Be Hypocritical or Not to Be
description: HANOVER, N. H.There are many kinds of hypocrisy, but the kind I am concerned about involves performing immoral actions while at the same time publicly condemning similar immoral actions by others. Immoral action does not mean swearing in privete, but rather serious violations of the moral rules: killing, deceiving, failing to perform one's duty or violating the law. No rational person can favor such hypocrisy.

title: TV. A Moving How Could I Not Be Among You?
description: The most profoundly moving moments on television, tonight are provided at 9:30 on public TV, in a 30minute film about death. Photographed and produced by Thomas Reichman, How Could I Not Be Among You? is about Ted Rosenthal, the poet, recorded in the months after he leartied he was going to die of leukemia. As a portrait of one man's courageous confrontation with death, the film is quite beauiful and tremendously affecting. As a film project, however, it has become ??? in a web of questions.

description: Jacob D. Fuchsberg, who lost an expensive and highpressure campaign for Chief Judge of the States Court of Appeals last year, yesterday announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for associate judge of the state's highest court.

description: MOSCOW, July 14 The Soviet Army newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda chided Japan today for continuing to permit the operation of American bases and aerial reconnaissance units on Okinawa.
