description: Antony Tudor's Undertow, which the American Ballet Theater gave for the first time this season Saturday night at the New York State Theater, is commonly called a psychological ballet and casebook view of the making of a murderer.

title: Two Drown as Rescue Fails
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 14 (AP)A 47yearold man accidentally, drove his car into the San Antonio River here early today while rushing to save a girl who had sone under water, Both drowned. The victims were Susie Adams, 16, and George Wallace.

description: William H. Giles, who retired recently as president of Van Buren Industries of Westbury, L. I., packaging machinery, now a part of the Emhart Corporation, died yesterday of a heart ailment in Central General Hospital, Plainview, L. I. He was 56 years old and lived in Westbury.

title: Yarborough First
description: BRISTOL: Tenn., July 14 (AP) Cale Yarborough passed Buddy Baker on the fourth turn of the final lap today and finished first in the Volunteer ma stock car race at Bristol International Speedday.

description: PARIS, July 14It was parade of men, not machines, on this Bastille Day of 1974.

description: Dr. Robert Sosler, a genera practitioner in Brooklyn for 50 years, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn He was 74 years old. His home and office were at 1610 Avenue J, Brooklyn.

description: LONDON, July 14 Sibyl Hathaway, Dame of Sark, a tiny island near the French side of the English Channel, died at her home there today. Her age was 90.

description: There is growing evidence that whatever biological and cultural evolutionary reasons there may have been requiring role differentiation in the past, they are now gone or at least not pertinent to today's world, and thus it is no longer legally possible nor morally tolerable to justify differential opportunity for men and women on those grounds.

Members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters Local 169 voted yesterday on the package that includes increased salary, a costofliving escalator clause and other benefits.

description: Events Today

title: Books of The Times
description: This is a book about the emergence of a compromise that settledperhaps only temporarilyone of the most heated controversies New York City has endured in the last decade: the fight over the plan to erect three 24story apartment towers for the poor in one of the most secure middleclass enclaves in Queens. As the dispute boiled over in 1972, spilling into the Presidential campaign of Mayor John V. Lindsay, the name Forest Hills lost its traditional association with bucolic tennis matches and became, for the nation, a symbol for race and class hostilities run rampant. In May, 1972, Mr. Lindsay asked Mario Cuomo, a Queens lawyer, to enter the dispute between himself and the opponents of the giant housing project to see it tnere was a possibility of finding some room for agreement. Mr. Cuomo agreed to try, and in October, the Board of Estimate formally adopted the compromise he proposed. It was hardly a surprising compromisethe size of the project was simply halvedbut it wasn't achieved until Mr. Cuomo could come up with the details from an exhaustive study of court decisions, government regulations and the complex welter of economic and legal factors in housing construction in the city.

title: Treasury Bills Fell At the Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The rates of Treasury bills fell today as the Government borrowed a total of $4.5billion at its weekly auction of shortterm securities. The average rate op the threemonth bills was the lowest since late June.

title: U.N. Tones Down Report on Indian Ocean Bases
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15A corrected United Nations report showed today that the Soviet Union and the United States had stepped up their military rivalry in the Indian Ocean, that Britain's presence there had declined, and that no evidence had been found of Chinese bases or of the deployment of Chinese naval units there.

description: NEW ORLEANS, July 15 (AP) A Federal appeals court today reversed a judge who held, that the sales scheme operated by Koscot Interplanetary, Inc., did not violate federal securities laws.

title: Joseph E. Fontana Dead; Hearst Magazine Official
description: Joseph E. Fontana, vice president and director of manufacturing for Hearst magazines since 1969, died Saturday night at his summer home in Southold, L. I. He was 66 years old and lived at 1232 80th Street in Brooklyn.

description: Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. was convicted yesterday in San Antonio, Tex., of six murders in the largest multiple slaying case of the century. Details on Page 9.

title: Two Convicts Surrender As Attempt to Escape Fails
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Two armed convicts surrendered quietly to the police and United States marshals tonight after barricading themselves in the United States District Courthouse for more than 100 hours.

title: Texas Gas Is Expanding
description: OWENSBORO, Ky., July 15 (UPI)The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation has agreed in principle with the state of Kentucky to develop a large coal gasification pilot plant. The project is intended to pave the way for building a $200million plant with a capacity of 80 million cubic feet of high BTU gas daily from Kentucky coal. The pilot plant will be in western Kentucky near the Ohio River but the site has not been chosen.

title: A Lawyer Is Sentenced For Robbing His Clients
description: A lawyer who used his license the way a bank robber uses a submachinegun was sentenced yesterday to two threeyear terms in state prisons for robbing elderly clients of almost $85,000.

title: Auto Sales Down 28.4% In First 10 Days of July
description: DETROIT, July 15 (AP)A severe 49 per cent sales drop at the Ford Motor Company during the first 10 days of July sent United States auto sales sliding 28.4 per cent below the 1973 pace.

title: FRANCIS J. SHANLEY
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 15 (AP)  Francis J. Shanley former acting police superintendent who became a public housing official, died today at his office here. He was 52 years old.

title: Church World Service Repudiates Promotion of Revolutionary Change
description: Church World Service, the $25  millionayear Protestant and Eastern Orthodox agency for overseas aid, declared yesterday that it is not in the business of promoting violent revolutionary change, and that its continuing aim would be to respond to human needs quickly:

description: BALTIMORE, July 15A 15day strike by sanitationmen, jail guards and most other municipal service workers ended today, but hundreds of policemen refused to return to duty without an unqualified amnesty for their illegal fourday strike.

If those injustices and hardships were sufficient to stir the ghettos to revolt then, there cause for disquiet now.

description: The Getty Oil Company eastern operations announced yesterday that ef??? today it would raise the wholesale price of gasoline and several other petrolaum products by 1 cent a gallon. The company said the increases were the result of higher crude oil costs.

title: DEALER SAYS MILK IS FULL OF POLITICS
description: ALBANY, July 15An independent milk dealer in Westchester County charged today that he was being forced out of business through collusion and power politics in the milk industry.

title: The Courthouse Story
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The drama in the basement cellblock of the United States Courthouse here has been remarkable in many respectsbut in none so much as the restraint and good sense shown on all sides. In the kind of confrontation which all too often results in a bloody shootout, everyone concerned seemed to be doing his best to avoid unnecessary viofence.

title: Africa's Fading Treasure
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The great game preserves of Africa, among the glories of this planet, are under such pressure that some ecologists here give them no more than another ten years of effective life, while more hopeful observers talk of twenty. Early in the year, Nairobi National Parkso close to town that suburbanites take in their dogs at night to protect them from marauding leopardswas strewn with some 3,000 carcasses of wildebeests and zebras, the victims of drought and the rapid closing in of adjacent lands. Instead of acting as buffers and essential expansion belts for periodic migrations, these border lands have become tightening cordons, slowly constricting the life of the parks.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New York City Board of Education, acting under a Federal court order to Improve integration at Brooklyn's Franklin K. Lane High School, submitted a plan to draw 570 white students from neighboring Queens into the school while simultaneously sending 600 minority students within the current feeder pattern to other high schools.

title: French Cut Film on Uganda Leader After Protest
description: PARIS, July 14Several cuts have been made in a film about Maj. Gen. Idi Amin, President of Uganda, after a formal protest from his Government and threats of reprisals against 150 French nationals living in Uganda.

title: Migrant Labor Housing
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  The Nixon Administration was accused today of trying to kill a Federal program that would provide better housing for migrant farm labor. Senator John V. Tunney, Democrat of California, said that for the second year the Administration had proposed no funds for the program, and urged the Senate Appropriations subcommittee to help save the program.

title: Foreign Exchange
description: Foreign Exchange

title: Talk Show Hostess Dies After Shooting Self on TV
description: SARASOTA, Fla., July 15 (AP)In keeping with Channel 40's policy of bringing you the latest in blood and guts and in living color you are going to see another firstattempted suicide.

title: Medical Official Sent to Lab on Coast With Girls Tissues
description: The Suffolk County Medical Examiner's office, unable to de(ermine what killed two Lake, Grove, L.I., girls, last night dispatched its chief toxicologist and samples of the dead girls' tissues to the Finnegan Corporation, a San Francisco laboratory, on the chance that its more advanced equipment could find traces of a deadly chemical.

title: Stage: Prodigal Sister
description: Plays at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater are exercises in audience identification: Cheer the hero, hiss the villain, recognize the stereotype. This theater fulfills the function of a neighborhood playhouse as a meeting place for: a shared theatrical (based on life) experience.

title: Rail Group Head Approved
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Arthur D Lewis to be chairman of the board of the United States Railway Association. The group Was set up last year to oversee the reorganization of railroad freight service in the Northeast and Middle West.

title: Henley Found Guilty
description: Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. was convicted yesterday in San Antonio, Tex., of six murders in the largest mass slaying case of the century. Details on Page 9.

title: Radio
description: 1.10 A.M., WNCN. Troisieme Concert de Clavecin, Rameau; Fatal Divinite from Alceste, Gluck; Zambra from Danzas Espanolas, Granados; Quartet for Oboe and Strings (K. 370), Mozart; Novelette No. 1, Schumann; Ah! Fors e lui from La Traviata, Verdi; The Enchanted Lake, Liadov; Polonaise in A flat, Chopin; La Favorite, Donizetti; Adagio for Organ and Strings, Albinoni; Recorder Sonata, Handel.

title: Byrne's Tax Victory
description: TRENTON, July 15While Governor Byrne's tax program and the state income tax it embraces still face an uncertain future in the State Senate later this month, its narrow victory this evening on the Assembly floor nevertheless holds out the promise of restructuring what state officials here regard as one of the most lopsided and regressive tax systems in the country.

title: HENRY SIVIADJA, 77; FRENCH PUBLISHER
description: PARIS, July 15  Henry Smadja, owner and publisher of the Paris newspaper Combat, died today, the day after his 77th birthday.

title: U.N. Reports TruceForce Aide Met Makarios
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 15  A United Nations spokesman said tonight that Archbishop Makarios, the deposed president of Cyprus, had a meeting today with the British officer who is the Paphos district commander for the United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus.

title: 3 Dodgers, 3 Reds Pace AllStar Poll
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers and their closest western division pursuers, the Cincinnati Reds, were the heavy winners yesterday in the final National League allstar baseball voting, each placing three players on the squad.

title: Robbery Suspect Jumps From a Police Window
description: A 21yearold pursesnatching suspect suffered undetermined injuries when he broke away from detectives and leaped from a thirdstory window of the Ericsson Place Police Station yesterday, the police reported.

title: Smallpox Grows in India; Worst Over, Officials Say
description: NEW DELHI, July 15India's smallpox epidemic has spread from Bihar and the number of cases has reached more than 130,000.

title: Nudists in Riis Park Warned Of Closing by U.S. Magistrate
description: A Federal magistrate yesterday suggested that Jacob Riis Park in the Rockaway section of Queens be closed if it is going to be a gathering place of nudists.

title: World Team Tennis
description: (Lest night's matches not included.)

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: In a ruling that should spare municipalities the loss of property tax revenues, the appellate division of superior court rejected the argument that the amount of taxes actually collected in one year should be used to set the tax rate for future years. The court turned down the challenge to the 1965 tax rate in the Bergen County community of Bogota by the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc. Federal Paper argued the 1965 tax on business property should have been levied at the rate of $5.95 instead of $13.64, which would reduce its tax bill from $71,789 to $31,315. The company said the rate should have been based on the amount of taxes collected in 1963, which was far less than the original tax levy because the tax burden was reduced by 45 per cent after a review of assessments.

title: MRS. CHARLES WHITTIER
description: Sydney Sewall Whittier, widow of Charles L. Whittier, who was vice chairman and president of the plans board of Young & Rubicam, Inc., the New York advertising agency, when he retired to Maine in 1954, died yesterday in Boothbay Harbor, Me. She was 77 years old and lived in South Portland, Me.

title: Athens Junta Was Open In Dislike of Archbishop
description: ATHENS, July 15The immediate chain of events that led to the coup in Cyprus today probably goes back to last November, when President George Papadopoulos of Greete was ousted by a group of military officers.

title: NBC'S RADIO UNIT NAMES NEW CHIEF
description: Jack G. Thayer has been appointed president of the NBC Radio division, which consists of the NBC radio network and the company's AM and FM stations in New York, Chicago, Washington and San Francisco. He will report to Herbert S. Schlosser, president of the National Broadcasting Company, who made the appointment.

title: BELL UNIT TO PAY RECORD INTEREST
description: The Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania, which has one of the highest corporate credit ratings in the nation, paid record 9.737 per cent to borrow $175million on 40year debentures yesterday. It was also the most money that any unit of the Bell system had ever paid for capital.

title: Barry Leithead Is Dead at 67; Sportsman Led Cluett, Peabody
description: Barry T. Leithead, retired chairman of Cluett, Peabody & Co., Inc., shirtmakers, died yesterday in ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 67 years old and had made his home in Aiken, S.C., since his retirement.

title: A Time to Fast
description: Conscience as well as cost is a consideration that may soon impel Americans to, reduce their consumption of meat. It takes 1,600 pounds of grain per person every year to provide the highprotein diet that has become common in the United States. That is four times the amount of grain that has been available per person for all food purposes in developing countries such as India. As the world's food supply starts to run perilously short in the face of burgeoning populations, especially in the poorer lands, religious leaders and others are beginning to point to the moral implications of this country's extravagant conversion of grain into animal products.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ANGOLA PROTESTS SAID TO KILL 20
description: LUANDA. Angola, July 15 (Reuters)Shooting broke out in the center of Luanda today and unofficial reports said that, nearly 20 people had been killed and 15 wounded as troops broke up the two demonstrations.

title: Man and Daughter, 2, Hurt In Collapse of Sidewalk
description: A man carrying his 2yearold daughter on his way to the corner grocery yesterday evening fell 15 feet with her when a section of sidewalk collapsed under him in front of 71 East 197th Street, near Madison Avenue, the police reported.

title: Reported Crime Over U.S. Rose 15% in First Quarter of Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Reported crime in the United States increased 15 per cent during the first three months of this year, the Fedetal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Rabin Bars Any Talks With Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, July 15 Premier Yitzhak Rabin today ruled out any possibility of contact or negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Police Seize Hijacker in Japan After 75 Flee Airliner
description: NAGOYA, Japan, Tuesday, July 16 (UPI)A youth armed with a knife and saying he had a bomb hijacked a Japanese airliner last night in an attempt to free a leftwing terrorist.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LEONIA, July 15Jen Bednarek plays basketball so well it is hard to believe she is just 16 years old. And thanks to the Leonia summer basketball league, she has a chance to improve and exhibit her skills.

title: Mrs. Aydelotte Wins Golf Medal
description: DARIEN, Conn., July 15Mrs. G. Thomas Aydelotte of Stanwich won the medal in the Women's TriCounty Golf Association championship tournament by three strokes.by scoring 38, 3876 at Woodway Country Club today.

title: Shapp Seeks Funds to Press Philadelphia Police Inquiry
description: HARRISBURG, July 15 (AP) Gov. Milton J. Shapp is still looking for state funds to help finance an investigation into alalleged police and administrative corruption in Philadelphia.

title: S.E.C. Suspension Lifted
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday lifted its suspension on trading of securities of the Commonwealth Na tional Realty Trust of Rockville, Md., a mortgage lender that fell into, shaky status when its adviser, the Commonwealth Corporation filed Chapter X proceedings under the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is appalling that, in the agreements recently made with Egypt and Israel, our country has become an active partner in nuclear diplomacy in the unstable Middle East. To offer existing safeguards as reassurances, as some official spokesmen have done, would be ludicrous if the potential consequences were not so horrible.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Cypriote troops led by Greek officers overthrew the Government of Cyprus. There were conflicting reports on the fate of Archbishop Makarios, the country's 60yearold President who, according to early dispatches, was killed. But later reports indicated he might have been given refuge. The rebels named Nikos Giorgiades Sampson as the new President. He is a 38yearold GreekCypriote newspaper publisher who had been an assassin. [1:8.]

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: After nearly five months of price declines, the composite price index for fresh food the city buys for its institutions has started an upward trend that consumers may also expect, Purchase Commissioner Robert I. Cohen reported yesterday. For deliveries for the two weeks starting next Monday, the city's costs under new bids opened last Friday have gone up 8.6 per cent from the current twoweek period. The current prices in turn, on bids received June 28, were 3.4 per cent above June 14 bids.

title: MORE COLLATERAL PUT UP BY SINDONA
description: ROME, July 15  Michele Sindona, the owner of 21.6 per cent of the Franklin New York Corporation, has reportedly yielded a controlling interest in Societa Generale Immobiliare as collateral for a loan of more than $100million.

title: Revenues Also at Peak
description: Philip Morris, Inc., the first of the tobacco Companies to issue financial results for this year's second quarter, reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for the second quarter and first half.

title: HENLEY CONVICTED IN MURDERS OF SIX
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 15 Elmer Wayne Henley Jr. was found guilty tonight on all charges for his part in the nation's largest mass murder case of the century.

title: People in Sports
description: Greg Cook, outstanding rookie quarterback with the Cincinnati Bengals in 1989, has hardly played since then because of three major operations for shoulder injuries, This year he reported to training camp convinced he had regained, his passing touch, But he had trouble throwing in a workout on Sunday and left cam p that night. He left a note foe Bill Walsh, assistant, to Coach Paul Brown, which said:

title: Eli Lilly Raises Dividend
description: INDIANAPOLIS, July 15 (UPI)1 Eliy Lilly A. Co., the pharmaceutical house, announced today that it had raised its quarterly dividend on common stock, to 25 cents a share from 23.5 cents, payable Sept.10 to holders of record Aug. 16.

title: Jury Picked in Reinecke's Perjury Trial
description: WASHINGTON, July 15A jury was selected today in the perjury trial in Federal District Court here of Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California.

title: No. 1 Rookie Is Big Camp Topic
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, July 15Even if they don't agree on the issues in the National Football League players' strike, Steve Tannen, the Jets labor leader, and Charley Winner, the Jets coach, agree on one thingthe image conjured up by Carl Barzilauskas.

title: dame Management Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The Senate passed 870, a bill today authorizing the Government to manage game, fish and wildlife on land controlled by the Atomic Energy Commission, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the National Forest system and the Bureau of Land Management.

title: Treaty With West Germany Ratified by Czech Assembly
description: PRAGUE, July 15 (Reuters) The Czechoslovak Federal Assembly today Unanimously ratified a treaty normalizing relations with West Germany.

title: Highs and Lows
description: Highs and Lows

title: MRS. ALLEN WARDWELL
description: Helen Rogers Wardwell, widow of Allen Wardwell, a senior partner in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died Sunday at her home, 355 Ocean Avenue in Lawrence, L. I. She was 92 years old.

title: Prosecutor Says He Will Show DiLorenzo Interfered in Inquiry
description: The prosecution in the perjury trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo told the jury yesterday that it would prove that the judge had tried to get a Waterfront Commission lawyer to go easy on the investigation of Thomas, Masotto, described by the prosecutor as the judge's longtime friend, client, tenant and butcher.

title: Despite Leuci's Admissions of Crime, Most Cases Are Expected to Hold Up
description: Most of the corruption or drug cases in which Detective Robert S. Leuci is a Government witness will  still be good despite Mr. Leuci's recent admissions of crime, according to lawenforcement officials who are reviewing the cases.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: NEWS INDEX

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee on Relations With the Host Country3 P.M.

title: Major Copper Concerns Struck, 30,000 workers Idle
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., July 15. (AP) Four of the nation's five major copper companies were struck today by a 26union coalition, idling about 30,000 workers. One of the companies, the Kennecott Copper Company, reached a tentative agreement with its employes later in the day.

title: Hair Spray Confiscated To Curb Air Hijacking
description: LONDON, July 15 (Reuters) Women passengers at London's Heathrow Airport saw their aerosol cans of hair spray confiscated by security policemen today because it was believed the cans could be used as flame throwers to hijack airplanes.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: Roosevelt Results

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was: 324889

title: Poll Favors Owners Over Players
description: MILWAUKEE, July 15 (UPI)  Readers responding to a Milwaukee Journal straw vote on the National.Football League players strike were overwhelmingly in favor of the owners.

title: 3 Escape in Plane Crash
description: LACONIA, N.H., July 15 (AP) Asea plane was demolished Saturday night when the pilot attempted to land here at private landing field, but the three occupants escaped serious injury. Two passengers, Thomas C. Reed, 45 years old of Belmont, Mass., and his son, Thomas S. Reed, 10, were treated at a local hospital for minor injuries and ret eased. The pilot, William Harmon, 50, it Exeter, was uninjured.

title: House Gets Bills to Extend Congress'Control of C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Representative Michael J. Harrington introduced two bills today to extend Congressional control over the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Reporter in Connecticut Upheld on Council Parley
description: ENFIELD, Conn., July 15 (UPI)  A state referee ruled today that a newsman had a right to remain at a supposedly closed session of the Enfield Town Council, but upheld the Council's right to shut its doors when considering administrative matters.

title: 2 Convicts Surrender
description: Two convicts who had barricaded themselves in Washington courthouse surrendered and were put on a plane for the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta. Page 20.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: HAPPY MEDIUMS Under the moon, the psychics sail tonight, and you're not very likely to find a more unusual happening all summer. Dezia, who we're told is a noted English clairvoyant and numerologist, has put together something called a Psychic Sail, in which you'll be able to spend a fourhour cruise aboard a rented Staten Island ferry in the company of some 50 clairvoyants, astrologers, palmists and other psychics, most of them from London, who will be happy to answer your questions and demonstrate their talents.

title: Seventh Army Morale Rising in Europe
description: Seventh Army Morale Rising in Europe

title: Table of Taxes
description: TRENTON, July 15 (UPI)  Following is a table showing what an average family of four would pay in state income taxes after normal deductions:

title: U.S. GIVES WARNING ON CYPRUS STATUS
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The United States today obliquely warned Greece, Turkey and the leaders of the coup against Archbishop Makarios, President of Cyprus, to avoid any steps that could compromise the independence of Cyprus.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Texas Rangers, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: Judgment Day
description: WASHINGTON, Silly 15It is like watching a slow avalanche.

title: STEEL OUTPUT OFF FROM A WEEKAGO
description: Production of steel, which has been declining steadily since the week of June 22; dropped to a new low for the week ending Saturday, the American Iron and Steel InstiMute reported yesterday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The whining New York daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Four Alleged Robbers Caaght in Traffic lain
description: PENNSAUKEN, N. J., July 15 (UPI)  Four men reportedly armed with machine guns were arrested today after they allegedly held up a Bank of New Jersey, armored car and stole more than $100,000.

title: 3 Airlines Pay $60,000 In Ticket Violation Fines
description: WASHINCITON, July 15 (UPI) Three of the nation's major airlinesUnited, Trans World and Americanpaid fines totaling $60,000 today for violating airline ticket regulations.

title: U.S.Japanese Energy Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Secretary of State Kissinger and the Japanese Ambassador, Takeshi Yesukawa, signed an agreement today providing for five years of United StatesJapanese cooperation in research and development in nonnuclear energy. The two countries have a separate agreement covering nuclear cooperation for peaceful purposes.

title: Fulbright Sees Kissinger As Detente Foes Target
description: WASHINGTON, July 15senator J. W. Fulbright suggested today that opponents of dtente with the Soviet Union were hoping to unseat Secretary of State Kissinger as the result of the Foreign Relations Committee's investigation into his role in the wiretapping of 17 Government officials and newsmen from 1969 to 1971.

title: Award for Tiant
description: NEW YORK, (UPI)Luis. Tiant, the Boston Red Sox righthander, with two completegame performances in which he did not allow a run, was named yesterpay the American League's player of the week. The 33yearold Tiacrt has pitched 17 consective scoreless innings.

title: Echo of Morse Opens Domestic Satellite Net
description: The tapping out of What hath God wrought, the historic first telegraphic message, on the original telegraph key of Samuel F. B. Morsefollowed by a brief telephone conversation between Mayor Beame and Mayor Thomas Bradley, of Loa Angeles  started Westerri:Union's commercial satellite service yesterday via Westar I. It is this country's first domestic satellite coinmithications system.

title: U.S. LAG WORRIES COMMON MARKET
description: BRUSSELS, July 15Finance ministers in the European Economic Community expressed concern today that lagging expansion in the United States could help lead the world into an economic slump.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
White House Denies Accord With Soviet. On Arms Is Secret
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15The White House denied today charges by Senator Henry M. Jackson that President Nixon had made a secret agreement with Moscow to restrict the number of United States nuclear submarines.

title: JERSEY ASSEMBLY BACKS INCOME TAX BY VOTE OF 413
description: TRENTON, July 15  Governor Byrne's income tax bile won its first legislative test by the narrowest possible margin tonight when the State Assembly approved the proposal by a vote of 41 to 38.

title: Chemical Maker Up 1%
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co., the world's largest chemical producer, had record sales and earnings for the second quarter and first half of this year, but the profit gains were modest, according to the midyear report issued yesterday.

title: HEAD OF COMMISSION ASSAILS WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP)  The Consumer Product Safety, Commission has been doublecrossed by the White House in the agency's sevenmonth battle for political independence, Chairman Richard O. Simpson said today.

title: PAUL J. WHITE JR., 49, PAPER FIRM OFFICER
description: Paul Joseph White Jr., vice president of Great Eastern Packing and Paper Stock Corporation, died after a long illness Sunday in United Hospital, Port Chester, N. Y. He was 49 years old and lived in Rye, N. Y.

title: Texas Fights Parrot Fever
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 15 (AP)  State and Federal health officials took steps today to combat the spread of parrot fever in Texas, where they say 25 persons have been sickened by the disease, spread in this case by turkeys. The Texas Animal Health Commission and the Agriculture Department's Plant and Health Inspection Service set up a project office at College Station to work with turkey producers and processors in combating the disease.

title: Lindsay to Play Senator In a Preminger Thriller
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay is to play a United States Senator in a motion picture now being filmed in France.

title: Brooklyn Trainer's Dream Coming True at Big A
description: Vinnie Cincotta has been doing well this year as a trainer, starting with winter racing in Florida. However, while he appreciates all his achievements in the Sunshine State, he has always wanted to score impressively in New. York. The reason is obvious: Vinnie was born in Brooklyn, on March 12, 1938.

title: Dave Anderson
description: MIAMI, July 15In the hot sun at the gate to Biscayne College where the Miami Dolphins hold their training camp, Doug Swift, the linebacker and player repreientative, wore a floppy red hat, a white Tshirt advertising Adidas across the chest, blue jeans, thong sandals and a National Football League Players Association picket sign. Nearby, red, white and blue bunting hung from the roof of a rented beige camper that was air conditioned. That way the Dolphin laborers could keep their cool along with the Dolphin management residing air conditioned offices during the labor dispute that has delayed their quest of an of unprecedented third consecutive Super Bowl triumph. The team's experienced players were scheduled to report yesterday but when their July 26 genie with the College AllStars was canceled, Don Shula decided that Wednesday was time enough. Only a handful of Dolphins with diamondstudded Super Bowl rings will cross the picket line.

title: Writing a Book Can Possibly Be Easier Than Getting It Into Hands of Reader
description: An admirer of Aleksand Solzhenitsyn telephoned the hook department of Alexander's department store recently and asked whether The Gulag Archipelago was in stock.

title: New Bond Issues
description: New Bond Issues

title: Morgan Mansion Loses Status as City Landmark
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday invalidated the landmark status of the J. P. Morgan mansion on Madison Avenue in a decision that could represent a major setback, to landmark preservation efforts in New York.

title: Talking of Oil
description: With quiet deliberation, the world's major oilconsuming countries are discovering an impressiveif belated readiness to cooperate in devising contingency plans for dealing with any future oil shortages. Against the gloomy forebodings of last winter, the progress made in the 12member energy coordination group, meeting in Brussels, is unexpectedly encouraging.

title: Vegetable Oil Spilled Here
description: Thousands of dollars worth of vegetable oil poured out of a railroad tank car and onto the grounds of a Brooklyn processing plant when a valve lock was broken, the police reported yesterday. The police said vandals apparently had broken the lock over the weekend. The car, holding 135,000 pounds of oil valued at $60,000 to $70,000, was standing beside the NutOla Food Products, Inc., processing plant at 770 Chauncey Street, in the Bushwick section.

title: Strike Unit On 24Hour Call to Talk
description: HOUSTON, July 15 (AP)Bill Curry, president of the striking National Football League Players Association, said today he had put his negotiating team on 24hour call to start talking.

title: Television
Bidge:
description: Qualifying for the final two rounds of the life master pair championship at the Hotel Americana here today was much harder than usual. The American Contract Bridge League introduced an extra cut into the semifinal stage yesterday, thereby reducing the field from an original 516 pairs, to 180 pairs, to 90 pairs, and finally to 32 pairs. This savage cutting procedure makes It possible for each pair in the final to play against each other pair.

title: DR. DANIEL H. BARISH
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Dr. Daniel H. Barish, health scientist administrator, Bureau of Health Services Research, Department of Health, Education and Welfare, died yesterday of cancer at his home in Rockville Md. He was 57 years old.

title: Gun Lobbyist Shot Fatally By Persons Seeking Rapist
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Louis Sisler, a lobbyist for the National Rifle Association and a former Indiana state judge, was fatally shot last weekend br a woman and several youths looking for a rapist, the District of Columbia police said.

title: Butter or Margarine? Now It s More a Question of Health
description: That longrunning debate, Margarine vs. Butter, has been channeled into another direction lately. The emphasis is now on the health factors, not the price gap.

title: John G. McConnell Dies; Published Montreal Star
description: MONTREAL, July 15 (AP)John G. McConnell, former pub Usher of The Montreal Star died Friday. He was 62 years old.

title: Ah, the Fifties: Like It or Not, A Staid Decade Is Being Copied
description: We've had fashion revivals of the 1920's (flapper dresses), the 1930's (slinky, bias cuts) and the 1940's (twin sweaters and platform shoes). Evenfor those who want to go back that farthe 1900's embroidered muslins, currently designed by Giorgio di Sant Angelo and tagged at $1,500.

title: NIXON VALUATION OF PAPERS HALVED
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Internal Revenue Service, as part of its audit of President Nixon's tax returns, employed independent appraisers who valued Mr. Nixon's prePresidential papers at less than half the $576,000 claimed by the President's own appraiser.

title: High Court Asked to Review Its Decision on Kerner Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Lawyers for Otto Kerner Jr., former Governor of Illinois, asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider its decision not to review his conviction on bribery and related charges.

title: Business Briefs
description: Several copper mining companies invoked the force majeure clauses in their sales contracts yesterday in the wake of labor strikes. Force majeure is a standard clause In business contracts. It refers to forces outside the control of the company.

title: ARMY TAKES OVER CYPRUS IN A COUP LED BY GREEKS; MAKARIOS'S FATE IN DOUBT
description: Cypriote troops led by Greek Army officers overthrew the Government of Cyprus yesterday.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Centex Corporation of Dallas announced yesterday that a subsidiary, the Centex Construction Company, was awarded a $49.2million contract to build a waterpollutioncontrol plant along the Potomac River. The contract was awarded by the District of Columbia Government's Department of Environmental Services. The facility, a sedimentation plant, Is scheduled for completion in mid1977.

title: Lufkin Back at D.L.J.; Firm Had 3Month Loss
description: Dan W. Lufkin, one of the trio of 30yearolds who created the maverick Wall Street firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette 15 years ago, returned to it yesterday.

title: New Chief on Cyprus
description: Last Jan. 30, when Gen. George Grivas was buried at a mountain hideout from which he commanded Cyprus's struggle for independence from Britain, the major eulogy was delivered by Nikos Giorgiades Sampson. The 38yearold Mr. Sampson, who had joined General Grivas's guerrillas as a highschool student and quickly rose to command a terrorist assassination squad, vowed beside the general's bier to fight for the union of the island with Greece.

title: From Victorian Bibelots to Campaign Dresses
description: WASHINGTON  People bring in the most exquisite things, said Anne Bradshaw, whose small, imaginative Georgetown shop is full of those exquisite things.

title: Elcock Inherits Hatful of Woe
description: Walter Elcock has just returned home to Boston from Europe wearing his second hat as newly elected president of the International Lawn Tennis Federation. But the hat perches precariously because he has inherited a flock of problems to go with those already burdening him as head of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

title: NEW ORLEANS PAPERS APPEALTOHIGHCOURT
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 15 (AP) Lawyers for two New Orleans newspapers took their plea for an end to a gag rule at a murder trial to the United States Supreme Court today.

title: A Secondary Defense of Nixon
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15  The White House appears to be steadily seeking to construct a secondary line of defense to protect President Nixon against impeachment. The primary defense argument of News the President's Analysis lawyers and loyalists is that there is no evidence linking Mr. Nixon with any Watergate crime. Now, in countless public and private statements, White House aides are contending that the President has been denied due process throughout the impeachment proceedings and will not be fairly treated by his judges no matter what the evidence shows.

title: Bank's Net Rises 17 %
description: The Bank America Corporation, parent of the nation's largest bank, reported yesterday a 17 per cent rise in secondquarter earnings, while the Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent of the thirdlargest American Bank, showed a 16.5 per cent gain.

title: Treasury Opposes Barring Citicorp Issue
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Treasury and other Federal financial agencies today came out in opposition to emergency legislation aimed at blocking issuance of securities by bank holding companies such as the floating interest rate notes due to be sold by Citicarp, parent of the First National City Bank.

title: Texas Bars Savings Gifts
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 15 Statechartered savings and loan institutions in Texas will be barred, under a ruling adopted today, from offering premiums to depositors in efforts to attract savings. The ruling, by the State Building and Loan Section, is to take effect Sept. 15.

title: Income Tax Vote
description: TRENTON, July 15 (AP)Here is the way the member of the Assembly cast their votes today in passing a state income tax bill, 4138:

title: South's Poultry Workers Lot: Minimal Pay for Messy Work
description: FOREST, Miss. The sun was low over the corn patch when Mrs. Annie McLaurin rode up the dirt lane and pulled into her driveway. A rooster crowed under a fig tree and a young hound moved slowly across the dirt yard and disappeared behind the unpainted house.

title: Fernandez Defeats Goss on a Decision
description: Jose Fernandez, a junior lightweight from the Dominican Republic who now fights out of New York, scored a majority decision over Sammy Goss of Trenton in the 10round feature last night at the Felt Forum in Madison Square Garden.

title: 2 STORE GROUPS WILL STUDY AINS
description: Two of the country's larges retail trade associations, the American Retail Federation a Washington and the Nationa Retail Merchants Associatio of New York, announced joint ly yesterday that a 12mat task force representing botl groups had been appointed to study common objectives and functions.

title: PosterCare Laxity Said to Cost City Millions
description: The State's Welfare Inspector General, George F. Berlinger, Said yesterday that the city was failing to assess adequately the ability of parents to pay for their children in foster care.

title: Pro Transactions
description: OAKLAND (AL)Reactivated Dick Green, second baseman, from Injured list and optioned Rich McKinney to Tucson affiliate.

title: Mostly Mozart Strategist Hears 75
description: The eighth annual Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center will open next Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall. Five Mondays later, when it's over, William Lockwood, the director, will be in his office working on next summer's programs. Even now he can say that he pretty well knows who the conductors will be in 1975.

title: Lindsay to Play Senator In a Preminger Thriller
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay is to play a United States Senator in a motion picture now being filmed in France.

title: HUTTON GROUP LISTS PROFIT IN QUARTER
description: The E. F. Hutton Group, Inc., parent of the Wall Street brokerage house of E. F. Hutton & Co., Inc., reported yesterday that it earned $11,000, or 2 cents a share, in the second quarter ended June 30, compared with a loss in the 1973 quarter of $922,000.

title: 2 Union Aides Urge House To Reject Strip Mine Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Two leaders of the United Mine Workers criticized today their union's executive board endorsement of a strip mining regulatory bill and called for the House to reject the legislation.

title: Consumers Voice
description: For the third time In four years the Congress is attempting to create an institutional voice for consumer interests in Washington, to balance the wellorganized activities of business lobbies and trade associations. Only the prospect of a filibuster, perhaps starting today, seems to stand between this muchneeded legislation and Senate passage, following last April's overwhelming approval by the House of Representatives.

title: Rabin Bars Any Talks With Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM, July 15 Premier Yitzhak Rabin today ruled tout any possibility of contact or negotiations between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Canadian Denies He Was Told Chou Had Heart Attack
description: HONG KONG, July 15  A Cattadian jurist who was the apparent source for reports yesterday that Premier ChouEtvlai had suffered a heart attack denied on his arrival here today that he had received any information from Chinese offidais about the state of the 76yearold leader's health.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended July 9.

title: Brasco Says Mairiello's Record Was Unknown to Him Before'68
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco testified in Federal District Cant here yesterday that he would not be on trial now if he had known before 1968 that John A. Masiello was a reputed racketeer.

title: Brasco Says Masiello's Record Was Unknown to Him Before'68
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco testified in Federal District Court here yesterday that he would not be on trial now if he had known before 1968 that John A. Masiello was a reputed racketeer.

title: Chase Asks Ruling On Herstatt Funds
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank asked a Federal court here yesterday how it should dispose of $156million it holds in the account of Bankhaus I.D. Herstatt, the West German bank that was ordered into liquidation last month.

title: Nine Concerns Set South African Deal
description: The Union Corporation and Barlow Rand, Ltd., both of South Africa, announced yesterday an agreement in principle to merge into a new group to be known as Unicorp Barlow, Ltd. Under the agreement, every 100 shares of Barlow Rand would be exchanged for 100 shares of Unicorp Barlow, and every 140 shares of Union Corporation for 100 Unicorp Barlow.

title: Advertising: Facts at Playgirl
description: William J. (but everybody calls me Bill) Miles Jr., executive vice president of Playgirl, has discovered what the publishers of Penthouse and Playboy already know  a good number of advertisers still consider it bad for their corporate image to be in one of the socalled skin books.

title: City's Health Code Reported Violated By 11 Food Places
description: Eleven restaurants and food distributors have been cited by the Health Department, after two inspections, for violating the city's health code. If these food places fail to correct their violations before their next inspection, they will be subjected to closing. A list of the establishments and the actions are as follows:

title: Virdon: Yankees Still in It
description: The Yankees woke up yes terday in last place. They found the heat wave they hac generated by winning nine of 10 games had been dissipated by a frontal system called the Oakland A's.

title: High Tides Around New York
description: High Tides Around New York

title: White House Says Revenue Rise Will Cut Expected Budget Deficit of $12Billion
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 15The White House said today that Federal revenues in the 1975 fiscal year ending next June 30 would be higher than expected and that the budget deficit for the year would probably be narrowed even beyond current estimates.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices closed moderately higher yesterday on the American Stock Exchange after having risen sharply in the first hour but then leveling off. Similar conditions prevailed in the overthecounter market.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given In Daylight Savings Time

title: Baseball Box. Scores and Standings
description: Baseball Box. Scores and Standings

title: P.B.A. Actsto Breiik Parity With 2 Other City Unions
description: The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association took three steps yesterday in an effort to break the wage parity that exists between policemen, firemen and sanitationmen.

title: Brooklyn Trainer's Dream Coming. True at Big A
description: Vinnie Cincotta has been doing well this year as a trainer, starting with winter racing in Florida. However, while he appreciates all his achievements in the Sunshine State, he has always wanted to score impressively in New York. The reason is obvious: Vinnie was born in Brooklyn, on March 12, 1938.

title: Prices of Commodity Futures
description: Prices of Commodity Futures

title: Human Births Reported From Eggs Fertilized in Lab
description: LONDON, July 15A British gynecologist gyneologist reported today that three, babies born in Europe during the last 18 months Iliad been conceived in test tubes from ova removed from the wouldbe mother and then placed in her womb.

title: Saigon Says the Vietcong Tried to Sabotage Election
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 15 (AP)  South Vietnam said today that the Vietcong tried to sabotage the municipal and providencial elections yestrday by sharply increasing ceasefire violations and terroists attacks. More than 600 Vietnamese were reported killed or wounded in the fighting.

title: Cotton Markets
description: Friday's salos 116,300 bales; open Interest 7,401,200 bales, Increased 11,500 bales,

title: Greek Gift to Cyprus
description: In a letter to the President of Greece dated July 6, Archbishop Makarios accused the military rulers in Athens of planning to murder him and furnished what he called irrefutable evidence that Greek officers commanding the Cyprus National Guard were plotting with EOKAB underground forces to overthrow his Government. He demanded that Greece recall the 650 officers.

title: Unconstitutional Prison
description: The responses of Corrections Commissioner Benjamin J. Malcolm and the Corporation Counsel's office to Federal District Court Judge Morris E. Lasker's denunciation of conditions in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men are disappointing. That facilitymore commonly and appropriately called the Tombswas ripped by riots in the fall of 1970.

title: COLSON REPORTED TO TELL INQUIRY OF CALL BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Charles W. Colson reportedly told the House Judiciary Committee today that President Nixon called him as late as last March 4 in search of information about the payment of $75,000 to one of the Watergate burglars.

title: Punch or Shove, Watts Stops Hart
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (UPI)  Bobby (Boogaloo) Watts knocked Eugene (Cyclone) Hart through the ropes at 2 minutes 40 seconds of the first round tonight to score a quick victory in a middleweight fight at the Spectrum.

title: NIXON VALUATION OF PAPERS HALVED
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Internal Revenne Service as part of its audit of President Nixon's tax returns, employed independent appraisers who valued Mr. Nixon's Presidential papers at less than half the $576,000 claimed by the President's own appraiser.

title: UNION SETS GOAL: SHUT DOWN OHIO
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 15 (UPI)  The 7,000member American Federation of State, County and Municipal Workers Union voted today to shut down the state of Ohio in a midnight strike in an attempt to gain a .40centanhour wage rise for states workers.

title: Deaths
description: Deaths

title: Gulliver Fire and Deaths Are Ruled To Have Occurred on New York Side
description: The prosecution of a 22yearOld Connecticut man charged with setting the fire that killed 24 young persons in a stateline singles bar at Port Chester, N.Y., two weeks ago is expected to be passed from Connecticut to New York authorities today.

title: Noah's Ark Bonanza
description: The emergency livestock loan guarantee bill which is scheduled to come to a vote in the House today, after receiving hasty endorsement in the Senate and only cursory examination by the House Agriculture Committee, offers but a superficial solution to the complex problems facing livestock producersand at a price which neither the producers nor the nation can afford.

title: Bruce Springsteen Evolves Into Figure Of Rock Expression
description: A year and a half ago, when Bruce Springsteen emerged as the latest in the line of new Bob Dylans, he impressed mostly for the manic energy of his speedy strings of words and metaphors. But times have changed, and Mr. Springsteen has evolved into one of the most exciting young figures in rock music. Anybody interested in where pop is going and who missed him at the Bottom Line this past weekend or who fails to hear him at the Schaefer Festival in Central Park on Aug. 3 is making a big mistake.

title: Open Interest
Massachusetts Blood Plea Stirs Hundreds of Donors
description: BOSTON, July 15 (AP) Blood supplies in the state greatly improved over the weekend, according to the American Red Cross, as hundreds of donors responded to an urgent plea for blood.

title: Byrne's Tax Victory
description: TRENTON, July 15While Governor Byrne's tax program's and the state income tax it embraces still faces an uncertain future in the State Senate later this month, its narrow victory this evening on the AsNews sembly floor nevAnalysis ertheless holds out the promise of restructuring what state officials here regard as one of the more lopsided and regressive tax systems in the country.

title: FED CITES CURBS ON MONEY SUPPLY
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee raised its target for the key Federal funds interest rate twice between midApril and midMay rather than permit rapid epansion of the nation's money supply to accelerate, it was disclosed today.

title: Nader Group Says Labor Department Lagged on Health Rules to Spur Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 15A Ralph Nader group charged, today that the Labor Department had failed to establish new standards to reduce the danger from such diseases as cancer and brain damage for 5 million workers in order to encourage campaign contributions to President Nixon from businessmen.

title: Seoul Conviction of 2 Japanese Expected to Aggravate Strains
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 15 Two Japanese accused of having been important gobetweens linking North Korean and Japanese Communists with the antiGovernment student movement here were sentenced to 20 years in prison today.

title: SOYBEAR FUTURES ADVANCE BY LIMIT
description: All soybean futures contracts and the nearby corn futures contracts jumped the daily permissible limits yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Elcock Inherits Hatful of Woe
description: Walter Elcock has just returned home to Boston from Europe wearing his second hat as newly elected president of the International Lawn Tennis Federation. But the hat perches precariously because he has inherited a flock of problems to go with those already burdening him as head of the United States Lawn Tennis Aisociation.

title: Tonight's Entries at Roosevelt
description: Tonight's Entries at Roosevelt

title: U.S. Steel's Chief Expects No Key 1974 Price Rises
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, said yesterday that his company did not intend to raise steel prices significantly on any major steel products for the rest of the year.

title: June's Factory Output Steady
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Industrial production was unchanged in June from the May level but rose in the second quarter from the depressed first quarter, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Aqueduct Race Charts
description: Aqueduct Race Charts

title: N.C.A.A. Named in Suit
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, July 15 (AP)The National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Big Eight Conference were accused of antitrust violations today in a Federal court suit seeking to overturn a ban on University of Oklahoma football telecasts. The suit was filed by attorneys for the newly organized Oklahoma Television Spoils Inc.

title: CURB ON NITRATES IN FOODS IS URGED
description: An expert panel on nitrites and nitrates advised the Department of Agriculture yesterday to restrict and in some cases ban these additives.

title: Notes on People
description: Michael Beaumont, the new Seigneur of Sark, the tiny Island in the English Channek promised yesterday that he would follow the example of his grandmother during his rule and said that the last thingsl want to, do is drag the island into the 20th century

title: Aqueduct Race Charts  1974, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)
description: Aqueduct Race Charts  1974, by Triangle Publications, Inc. (The Daily Racing Form)

title: Orantes Toppled By Vilas in Final
description: GSTAAD, Switzerland July 15 (UPI)Guillermo Vilas of Argentina needed only 50 minutes today to upset topseeded Manuel Orantes of Spain, 61, 6.2, in the men's singles final of an international tennis tournament. The victory earned the South American champion $8,000, while Orantes got $4,700.

title: Official's Son Killed
description: MIAMI, July 15 (AP)  The son of an official of the Dominican Republic has been killed. The police ruled it a suicide today, but family mem bers said it was an accident. Ney Garrido, 22 years old, was killed yesterday by a shot from a revolver in the presence of his wife and five children in the family home. The authorities identified him as the son of the secretary to the Dominican, president.

title: Seaver Is Entering Difficult Transition
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 Torn Seaver, whose fundamental importance to the New York Mets is so taken for granted that it often is not fully realized, is at the most difficult stage of his remarkable career.

title: United States Government and Agency Bonds
description: Monday, July 15, 1994 Prices In 32d of a point composite bill yields In booms points.

title: Court Rules Wayward Children May Be Held With Delinquents
description: The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that it was permissible to place children adsjudged to be persons in need of supervision in training schools that also contained youngsters convicted of relatively serious offenses  provided the supervision and treatment were adequate.

title: BALTIMORE ENDS ITS 15DAY STRIKE
description: BALTIMORE, July 15A 15. day strike by sanitationmen, jail guards and most other municipal service workers ended today, but hundreds of policemen refused to return to duty ywithout an unqualified amnesty for their illegal fourday strike.

title: People and Business
description: Harold E. Berg, president of the Skelly Oil Company, will be named executive vice president and chief operating officer of Getty Oil Company, succeeding Ernest B. Miller, according to plans announced by Getty Oil yesterday.

title: Roosevelt Results
description: Roosevelt Results

title: Two Ousted Teachers Say Air Force Stifles Academic Freedom
description: WASHINGTON, July 15In a dispute over academic freedom, two Air Force captains have complained that they were dismissed last year from their teaching positions at the Air Force Academy after publishing a paper that disagreed with official policy.

title: City Finds Inflation Squeezing Landlords
description: Warning that rental housing here was being ravaged by flation, Housing and Development Administrator Roger Starr made public a study yesterday showing that prices involved in operating a major group of apartments here had increased by nearly 20 per cent in the last year.

title: Prices of Stocks Steady As Volume Loses Ground
description: The stock market caught its breath yesterday with prices steadying and volume dropping off after Friday's hectic 27.61 advance.

title: FRANC SHOR, 60, DIES; GEOGRAPHIC EDITOR
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Franc Shor, an associate editor of National Geographic, died here today of a brain lesion at the Washington Hospital Center. He was 60 years old.

title: U. S. Steel's Chief Expects No Key 1974 Price Rises
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, said yesterday that his company did not intend to raise steel prices significantly on any major steel products for the rest of the year.

title: COUP STIRS FEARS OF TURKISH MOVE
description: ATHENS, July 15Western diplomats here expressed fears tonight that the coup on Cyprus might bring Greece and Turkey to the point of war, the kind of war that the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization barely averted 10 years ago.

title: Prof. Paul E. Miller Dead; ExDean of Howard Law, 38
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Paul E. Miller, professor of law and former dean of the Howard University School of Law here, died Friday of pancreatitis at his home here. He was 38 years old.

title: BEANIE KNEW IN 72 OF LOST MILLIONS
description: A 1972 audit showing that $3.95million in securities could not be accounted for when Abraham D. Beame was Controller was made public yesterday by Mr. Beanie's successor, Controller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Central Railroad to Get Almost $10Million Aid
description: NEWARK, July 15 (UPI) A Federal judge here today authorized almost $10million in state and Federal aid to keep passenger service on the bankrupt Central Railroad of New Jersey running through Nov. 30.

title: Chess:
description: After the United States took third place in the International Team Tournament, one point behind Yugoslavia, Svetozar Gligoric asked me whether I felt that we deserved the secondplace aver medal, since we won our match with Yugoslavia. As a strong believer in Savielly Tartakover's, moral victories do not count, I had to say no.

title: Policeman to Fight Penalty on Girl Friend Curb
description: CORAL GABLES, FLA., July 15A policeman who was suspended last week for living with a woman to whom he is not married intends to fight in courts the action by the chief of police.

title: REPUBLIC NATIONAL GETS TIGHT CONTROL
description: AUSTIN, Tex., July 15Texas insurance commissioner Don R. Odum has tightened his supervision of the Republic National, Insurance Company of Dallas, now that the Federal district court In the southern district of New York has affirmed his control of the company.

title: Woodlief Thomas, 76, Dies; Economist for Senate Unit
description: Woodlief Thomas, chief economist for the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency from 1965 to 1967, died Friday in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived in Palm Beach.

title: LongEroded Iceland Plans Forests Again
description: REYKJAVIK, IcelandAfter centuries of denudation and catastrophic erosion, Ireland is beginning to grow forests again.

title: Bodies of Two Are Found In Maine Canoe Accident
description: ELLSWORTH FALLS, Me. July 15 (AP)The bodies of two teenagers have been recovered in Maine's Union River near where their canoe capsized in rough water.

title: New Lane High Integration Plan Submitted by Board of Education
description: The Board of Education, acting under Federal court orders to improve integration at Brooklyn's Franklin K. Lane High Scholl, submitted a plan yesterday to draw 570 white students from predominantly white schools in Queens into the school, while simultaneously shifting 600 minority students in Lane's current feeder pattern to other high schools.

title: Briefs on the Arts.
description: Bill Cosby, who Stars with Sidney Poitier and Harry Belafonte in Uptown Saturday Night, has retracted and apologized for statements he wrote and delivered in a radio commercial for the film. It was aired on several local stations from July 3 to July 6. A protest was lodged last week by Walter Brecher, operator of the Apollo Theater in Harlem, where the movie was shown, who termed the commercial a dreadful slander and a vile characterization of a community.

title: ALFRED J. ZMUDA, GEOPHYSICIST, 53
description: WASHINGTON, July 15Dr. Alfred J. Zmuda, senior geophysicist of the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory, whose studies with research satellites, specialists said, led to a better understanding of the earth's magnetic field and the causes of the Northern Lights of the Aurora Borealis, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md. He was, 53 years old.

title: Simon Quoted as Calling The Shah of Iran a Nut
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI)The American Banker, a publication forthe banking induary, quoted Secretary of the Treasury William E. Simon today as saying he would bypass Iran on his Mideast trip because, among other things, The Shah is a nut.

title: Morgan Mansion Loses Status as City Landmark
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday invalidated the landmark status of the J. P. Morgan mansion on Madison Avenue in a decision that could represent a major setback to landmark preservation efforts in New York.

title: ARAFAT MAY MEET WITH KING HUSSEIN
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt, July 15 President Anwar elSadat said today he was confident that he would be able to bring about a meeting within the next few weeks between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, the head of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The meeting is to be attended by Syrian President Hafez alAssad and Mr. Sadat.

title: COLSON REPORTED TO TELL INQUIRY OF CALL BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 Charles W. Colson reportedly told the House Judiciary Committee today that President Nixon called him as late as last March 4 in search of information about the payment of $75,000 to one of the Watergate burglars.

title: Kuh in Letter Apologizes to 2 Justices Whose Conduct He Criticized in April
description: District Attorney Richard H. Kuh has made a private apology to two Supreme Court justices whose conduct he publicly criticized three months ago.

title: FLARES IMPERILED SALYUT 3 MISSION
description: MOSCOW, July 15Soviet space authorities disclosed to day that they had considered, but apparently rejected, a proposal to curtail the mission of the space laboratory Salyut 3, which is orbiting the earth with two astronauts aboard, because of intense solar flares.

title: Swimmer's Body Recovered
description: LAWRENCE, Mass., July 15 (AP)The body of Paul Berube, 22 years old, of Lawrence, was recovered from the Merrimack River yesterday after he drown while trying to swim across.

title: Murders Through May Off 5% From 73, Beame Says
description: Mayor Beame said yesterday that murders in New York had decreased by nearly 5 per cent in the first five months of this year, compared with the same period last year. In May alone, he said, murders showed a decrease of 39 per cent compared with May, 1973, according to figures of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Vincent Scamporino, Dies; Connecticut State's Attorney
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 15Vincent J. Scamporino, former State's Attorney for Middlesex County, died Saturday while attending a concert at the Oakdale Musical Theater in Wallingford. He was 65 years old.

title: LAURENS R. BOWDEN
description: Laurens Reeve Bowden, who had been active in yachting, died Sunday in Portland, Me. He lived in Newcastle, Me., and formerly in Bellport, L.I.

title: Regina Auspitzer, 86, Dies; Led Catholic Alumnae Unit
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., July 15  Regina Dougherty Auspitzer, a former president of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae, died yesterday at the Smithtown Lodge of heart failure. She was 86 years old.

title: MAYTAG INCREASING ITS PRICE LEVEL 5%
description: The Maytag Company, a large manufacturer of homelaundry equipment, announced yesterday that it was raising its wholesale prices 5 per cent this month, its second price increase this year.

title: House Bars Large Printings of Reports by Impeachment Panel
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The House of Representatives, registering pique at the Senate and the nearly $1million cost for the printing of additional copies of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment inquiry proceedings, rejected today resolution authorizing the cost.

title: BOY GONE 6 WEEKS; 2 ARE HELD ON COAST
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 (UPI) Two men were arraigned today on Federal extortion charges in connection with the apparent kidnapping of a wealthy industrialist's son.

title: Market Place: Vulnerabilty Up On Margin Debt
description: The unrelenting bear market increased the vulnerability of margin, accounts in June and apparently set up brokerage house customers for the worst siege of margin calls in many years.

title: Sherwin's Appeal Denied By State Supreme Court
description: TRENTON, July 15 (AP) New Jersey Supreme Court refused today to review an appeal by former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin and two others convicted of briberyconspiracy.

title: &EC. AIMS ACTION AT TELEPROMPTER
description: WASHINGTON, July 15The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Teleprompter Corporation, the nation's largest cable television franchise operation, had defrauded its stockholders and the public by providing misleading information nformation in 1973.

title: Packers and Eaters Busy As Blueberry Fete Begins
description: PARAMUS, July 15The Jersey blueberry took stage center in the Bergen Mall here this morning as nimblefingered berrypackers awed the public with their packing precision and small boys in a blueberrymuffineating contest turned into purplefaced stuffers.

title: Garland of Orioles Stars Against A's Until Ninth
description: Wayne Garland of the Baltimore Orioles pitched a dream game for eight innings against the Oakland A's but wound up in a nightmare last night.

title: Two Democratic Insurgents Pile Petitions for U.S. Senate Race
description: A threeway primary contest for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate was virtually assured yesterday when the two insurgent candidates, Abraham Hirschfeld and former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, filed nominating petitions containing more than twice the number of signatures required to get on the ballot.

title: THOMAS W. O'CONNOR
description: Thomas. W. O'Connor, a partner in the law firm of Logue & O'Connor, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 47 Crestwood Avenue, Crestwood, N. Y. He was 49 years old.

title: Doubt Lingers in Corona on Housing Compromise
description: Joy is grayed by fear and hope is streaked with suspicion in the city's sliver of private homes and backyard gardens of Corona, Queens, where, more than two years ago, some 60 homeowners thought their anguish had been ended by a compromise plan to save their homes from demolition for a proposed high school.

title: Turks Say They Won't Accept Any Fait Accompli on Cyprus
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 15Turkish Government officials warned today that they would not accept and fait accompli on Cyprus and expressed concern for the Turkish community there.

title: ARMY TAKES OVER CYPRUS IN A COUP LED BY GREEKS; MAKARIOS'S FATE IN DOUBT
description: Cypriote troops led by Greek Army officers overthrew the Government of Cyprus yesterday.

title: Walters Is Junior Sail Victor
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 15Fred Walters of Sagamore Y. C., who won last week when the New. York Y. C. ran the first junior open regatta of the season, triumphed again today off Larchmont Y. C.

title: Athens Junta Was Open In Dislike of Archbishop
description: ATHENS, July 15The immediate chain of events that led to the coup in Cyprus today probably goes back to last November, when President George Papadopoulos of Greece was ousted by a group of military officers.

title: Praise for Harlem People's Advocate Marks Opening of 2d Consumer Office
description: In a small, cramped storefront in Harlem, Federal, state and city officials and a few archenemy friends joined Florence Rice yesterday in opening her second consumereducation center uptown.

title: Meany Urges Nixon to Seek A Detente With Artericans
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) Charging that President Nixon's summit meeting in Moscow last month had faled to abate the arms race, George Meany suggested today that the Administration should try for dtente with the American people.

title: Income Tax Vote
description: TRENTON, July 15 (AP)Here is the way the members of the Assembly cast their votes today in passing a state income tax bill, 4138:

title: 2 CAN COMPANIES LIFT QUARTER NET
description: The two leading container companies  the Continental Can Company, Inc., and the American Can Companyhad record sales and earnings in the quarter ended June 30, they reported yesterday.

title: Jansen Noyes Sr., 89, a Partner In the Investment Firm, Is Dead
description: Jansen Noyes Sr., who retired in 1965 as the senior partner in the investment firm of Hornblower & WeeksHemphill Noyes Inc., died yesterday in his summer home on Fishers Island, N. Y. He was 89 years old and a former resident of Montclair, N. J.

title: American Enka Phasing Out Production of Rayon Yarn
description: The American Enka Company, a unit of Akzona, Inc., announced yesterday that it was phasing out the production of rayon filament yarn at its plant in Lowland, Tenn. Part of the plant will be converted to production of rayon staple fiber.

title: POVERTY OFFICIAL SAYS HE'LL RESIGN
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) The White House has demanded the resignation of Alvin J, Arnett as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, Mr. Arnett said today in an interview.

title: Former Argentine Official Slain As Acts of Terrorism Continue
description: SBUENOS AIRES, July 15A former Interior Minister who paved the way for elections last year that ultimately led to the return of Juan Domingo Peron was shot to death today by unidentified assassins.

title: A Judge Orders Haldeman To Give Pretrial Testimony
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C. July 16 (AP) A Federal judge ruled yesterday that a former White House aide, R. Haldeman, must testify in >a suit filed by 14 young people who charge that they were illegally prevented from attending a speech by President Nixon in 1971.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS DOWN ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: Haig Finds U. S. Global Role Enhanced in the Year
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Despite Watergate, events Of the past year have enhanced, America's leadership role 110 international affairs, according to Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr. the White House chief of staff, who accompanied President Nixon on his trips to the Middle East, Western Europe and the Soviet Union last month.

title: Market Averages
description: STANDARD & POOR INDEX

title: Women in Medicine Up Sharply
description: In a movement that could alter both the teaching and Practice of medicine, American women are entering the profession in dramatically increasing numbers.

title: Westmoreland Loses in South Carolina
description: COLUMBIA, S. C. July 16General William C. Westmoreland, the retired commander of United States troops in Vietnam, was decisively defeated today in the his first foray into politics.

title: Boy Dies in Russian Roulette,
description: PORTLAND, Ore., July 161 (AP)A 7yearold boy was shot to death while playing RusIsian roulette with his sister at their home here yesterday. Sheriff's deputies said the victim, Gary Allan Gott, died of a wound inflicted with a 38caliber revolver.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: July 17, 1974 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EGYPT TO ADMIT 4 BIG U.S. BANKS
description: CAIRO, July 16Four leading American banks today became the first foreign institutions in 17 years to be granted permission to operate banking offices in Egypt. They are the Chase Manhattan Bank, First National City Bank, American Express Company and Bank of America.

title: Excerpts From Rabbi Korff's Intetview on May 13 With President
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 16 (AP)Following are excerpts from a May 13 interview with President Nixon by Rabbi Baruch KorfI, chairman of the National Citizens Committee for Fairness to the Presidency:

title: SOVIET REPORTED, IN OFFER TO TURKS
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 16The Soviet Union was said to have informed Turkey today that it was ready to cooperate with her in defending the integrity and independence of Cyprus, whose Government was overthrown yesterday by the military.

title: Ohio's Public Employe Strike Spreads
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 16IR strike by public employes against Ohio's prisons and tal health facilities spread day to stateowned liquor stores and a university.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RENO, July 16 (AP)The condition of Dizzy Dean, the Hall of Fame pitcher, worsened this evening, a spokesman at St. Mary's Hospital said. The condition of Dizzy Dean, having deteriorated over the past two hours, has reached a critical stage, Ed Spoon said. He is experiencing heart failure.

title: Xerox Earnings Set Record
description: Others Report tion, the nation's fourth largest steel maker, reported yesterday gains in earnings for the quarter and halfyear. At the same time the company said yesterday it would spend about $160million on capital improvements at three of its steel plants.

title: CANDIDATE SEEKS VINDICATING VOTE
description: Assemblyman Calvin Williams, DemocratLiberal of Brooklyn, who faces up to seven years in prison on a perjury conviction, said yesterday that he would stay in the race for his legislative seat and that he would be vindicated in the polls.

title: Milk Official Says Nixon Aides Were Qbstacle to Election Gifts
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) Dairy farmer cooperatives would have given even more than. $2million to President Nixon's 1972 campaign if White House aides had not fumbled arrangements for, receiving the money, according to newly released Watergate testimony.

title: Zairian Says Fight Needs 2 Stadiums
description: If Zaire had a stadium with a seating capacity of 500,000 instead of 120,000, it would still be full for the Muhammad AliGeorge Foreman fight on Sept. 24, even at 3 o'clock in the morning.

title: Nixio Names New O.E.O. Chief After Arnett Is Ousted in a Rift
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 16 (UPI)President Nixon nominated Bert A. Gallegos today to; replace Alvin J. Arnett, vvlio was dismissed as director of the Office of Economic Opportunity because of his differences with White House policy.

title: THEODORE M. PERKINS
description: Theodore M. Perkins, vice president of the Bridgeport (Conn.) Engineering Institute; of which he was a 1933 graduate, died in St. Vincent's Hospital Bridgeport, on Monday. He was 68 years old and lived in Stratford, Conn.

title: A Policewoman Seizes Assailant 4 Years Later
description: Four years ago a tall, thin Man jumped Patricia Bell as she returned home from a movie in Washington Heights, struck her in the face and took her purse.

title: Scott Paper Dividend Up
description: The directors of the Scott Paper Company announced yesterday an increase in the quarterly dividend to 17 cents from 14 cents.
