description: Mollenhoff's Affidavit on Wallaces

title: Court Broadens Power of State When Guilty Verdict Is Nullified
description: TRENTON, July 16 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court today granted law enforcement officials broader authority in seeking to block new trials for criminal defendants in cases where a trial judge has thrown out a jury's guilty verdict.

title: ROUND 2 ON TAX: BYRNE OPTIMISTIC
description: TRENTON, July 16Saying he was encouraged by the Assembly's approval of his incometax program last night, Governor Byrne added today that he had high hopes that the State Senate would back the controversial proposal late next week.

title: BlackRobed Master of Ambiguity Makarios
description: ATHENS, July 16When false reports spread yesterday that Archibishop Makarios had been killed, many of those who have followed the career of the statesmanpriest reacted in disbelief. He had demonstrated his powers of survival against hostile forces so often that there seemed little reason to think that he could not do it again. The skepticism about the reports and the archbishop's own determination to thwart his enemies once again paid off. He broadcast today to Cypriotes saying: I am not dead. And then he flew from the Mediterranean island to safety from the leaders of yesterday's coup.

title: Advertising:Now Epstein, Raboy
description: When Mitch Epstein and Dick Raboy, a couple of wellknown guys in the business, decided to open a shop of their own and began looking for capital they learned just what tight money means, As far as they were concerned the money hole had dried up.

title: BUSINESS SHOWS RISE IN INVENTORY
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Total business inventories rose $3.7billion in May, equal to the largest monthly increase since the strong inventory buildup began late last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: His Art Wears Well
description: Ken Scott, the American painter who's been designing clothes in Milan for years, has a cheery way with prints, which he creates himself.

title: Kurds Report Iraqi Losses
description: VAN, Turkey, July 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  More than 4,500 Iraqi soldiers have been killed or wounded fighting against Kurdish forces in the last four months, the clandestine Voice of Kurdistan radio said in a broadcast monitored here. The broadcast said Kurdish losses had been small.

title: Environmental Aide Named
description: Steven C; Van Voorhis, a vice president of the General Electric Company, was appointed finance development chairman of the Council on the Environment of New York City at a meeting yesterday at Gracie Mansion. The post is unsalaried.

title: President Shifts on Public TV And Sanctions LongRange Aid
description: President Nixon, reversing position he took in June, yesterday approved a bill prepared by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy for the longrange financing of public broadcasting by the Federal Government.

title: New Discrepancies Found In Controller's Accounts
description: New Discrepancies Found In Controller's Accounts

title: Denver Backs Bond Issue
description: DENVER, July 16 (AP)The Denver City Council by a vote of 112 authorized $25million bond issue to finance massive improvements at Mile High Stadium. Voters will decide Sept. 10 if they want to pay for the improvements with an eighttenths of one mill property tax increase.

title: AntiDefamation Unit Charges Bias in Selection of Principals
description: Jewish applicants for jobs as principals or assistant principals in the city's elementary, intermediate and junior high schools have become victims of ethnic discrimination, the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith charged in a study made public yesterday.

title: Drought Aid From U.S.
description: GENEVA, July 16The United states today donated $100,000 to the special office established here by the United Nations to assist the droughtstricken ubSahara area of Africa,

title: Institution That Had Big Role Began in 1874
description: CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 16The presentation of the premiere of Seymour Barab's opera Philip Marshall here this week provided the mildest kind of reminder of what Chautauqua used to represent in the cultural life of vast portion of America,

title: Class of 78 Starts Training on LI. for Sea Careers
description: KINGS POINT, L.L, July 16 Dwight Olsson, a 20yarold paratrooper entering the United States Merchant Marine Academy today as women were admitted for the first time, said If they can hack it, I don't care. But one of the women, 20yearold Della M. Anholt, noted that there were only 15 females among the 985 men in the Academy. I think 5050 would be a lot better, she said.

title: Stars Home Debut Stirs Fan Interest
description: With most New York professional football teams only names and recollections in history, the city's 15th and newest team, the Stars, begins the home half of its World Football League schedule tonight against the Birmingham Americans at Downing Stadium.

title: Miss Wade. Stars As Sets Triumph
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., July 16  Manuel Santana returned to his playercoach role and Virginia Wade produced some of her best tennis as the New York Sets defeated the Boston Lobsters, 2218, in a World Team Tennis match at the Nassau Coliseum tonight before only 831 fans.

title: Why Join the Army?
description: WASHINGTONThere is a remarkable inconsistency between the common perception that Army service is an interruption in a young person's life and the fact that nearly 2,000 young men and women freely decided tojoin, the Army last year. These young people were not deceived. They were not lured by promises of ease or an easy way.

title: Britain in Pivotal Position In Diplomacy Over Cyprus
description: LONDON, July 16The British Government today found itself bearing a major share of the diplomatic effort to prevent the coup in Cyprus from flaring into conflict between Greece and Turkey.

Ehrlichman, was a blot on justice and that it would be extremely difficult for any Watergate figure to get a fair trial in Washington, according to a leader of the President's grassroot supporters, Rabbi Baruch M. Korff.

title: Hopi See Spiritual Side To Dispute With Navajo
description: ORAIBI, Ariz.  Legend has it that in the longago mists of forgotten time, when man emerged froin the third world into the fourth, the Hopi Indians received from a godlike white man a promise of deliverance.

title: WRITER CHARGES 12 WITH WIRETAPPING
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Tad Szulc, a former reporter for The New York Times, has sued 12 past and present members of the Nixon Administration for allegedly wiretapping his home and office telephones during the summer of 1971.

title: Flowers Left Bitter By Giants
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 16 Did the New York Giants trade Richmond Flowers to the Oakland Raiders in a final show of bitterness for his early allegiance to the World Football League?

title: REA Court Stay Granted
description: REA Express, Inc., was granted a stay yesterday by a threejudge court here of a Civil Aeronautics Board order terminating the company's air express monopoly rights which was to have become effective July 31. The court is expected to, undertake a review of the C.A.B.'s decision, which it reached originally last December.

description: High Tides Around New York

title: Premiere Held for FullLength Barab Opera
description: CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 16Philip Marshall, the first fulllength opera, by Seymour Barab to be produced; was given its premiere by the Chautauqua Opera Association here and proved to be an extraordinarily ambitious effort. Performed Friday and again last night, the opera contained not only the music of Mr. Barab but also his idea for the libretto.

title: Silent Loan Policy
description: A new silent policy is being adopted by many New York banks as part of their adjustment to tight money. For most small and some major businesses, the policy is no previous relationship equals no loans. Details on Page 58.

title: ATHENS PLEDGES NONINTERVENTION
description: ATHENS, July 16The Greek Government, in its first official statement on the coup in Cyprus, said today that the conflict was an internal affair of an independent state, and that Athens would respect the principle of noninterference.

title: Earnings Highest Ever
description: Led by the argricultural and special chemical segments, earnings and sales of the American Cyanamid Company in the second quarter and first half, exceeded any quarter and sixmonth period in its 67year history, the company reported yesterday.

title: COUNTIES CREATE AN URBAN PANEL
description: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., July 16 The National Association of Counties, usually identified with rural interests, has averted a serious split within its ranks by large, urban counties that had threatened to break away from the organization.

title: Bulls Enroll Wilson
description: CHICAGO, July 16 (UPI)The Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association signed today their No. 3 draft choice, Bob Wilson, a 6foot3inch guard from Wichita State.

description: To open its third summer of big hands, the St. Regisskierston Roof is counting less on bandthe Jimmy Dorsey orchestra conducted by Lee Castlethan it is on a singer, Bob Eberly.

description: There are plenty of New Yorkers who have never bothered taking a trip on the Staten Island ferry. Some have never dropped into the American Museum of Natural. History or visited the Statue of Liberty. And how many have bothered to take a look or even know aboutthe wonders that meet the eye from the 26th floor tower of the Riverside Church?

title: ANGOLAN CITY CALM AFTER FATAL CLASH
description: LUANDA, Angola, July 16 Calm returned to Luanda today after yesterday's confrontation between troops and demonstrators which left 12 dead and 30 wounded.

title: A BEACH SERVICE SET FOR TELEVISION HOST
description: SARASOTA, Fla., July 16 (AP)A memorial service for Chris Chubbuck, the talk show host who shot herself during television program, will be held on a beach near her home early Thursday so that fans can attend Timothy Chubbuck, the dead woman's brother said today.

title: $7.5Million Error
description: Someone gave the wrong instructions to a computer causing it to spew out about $7.5million in welfare checks to people whose cases were supposed to be closed, embarrassed city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: France Appoints a Minister for Women
description: PARIS, July 16President Valery Giscard d'Estaing appointed the writer Francoise Giroud, a leading feminist, today to the new post of Secretary of State for the Condition of Women.

title: TEXTILE PACT SET BY U.S. AND JAPANI
description: HONOLULU, July 16 (AP)United States and Japanese negotiators have signed a memorandum of understanding on a new textile agreement.

description: BALTIMORE, July 16All but about 100 of Baltimore's 2,800 policemen ended their fiveday strike and returned to normal duty assignments today.

title: Rivals for Consumers Affection Pledge Cooperation for Kuh's New Bureau
description: Even for an era In which politicians and government officials often step over one another in their eagerness to let the consumer know he is being cared for, yesterday was a rather special day for New York City. Practically everyone in the consumer business got into the act, putting aside for the moment the rivalries and jealousies that often split as they announced new help for the consumer.

title: Cyprus Resporisibility
description: The dramatic escape of President Makarios and the stubborn resistance by forces loyal to his elected Government against the wouldbe usurpers controlled from Greece provide an opportunity for constructive and decisive international action on Cyprus that must not be squandered. Secretary General Waldheim's appeal Greece and Turkey for maximum restraint on Cyprus, issued in advance of yesterday's United Nations Security Council meeting, was only the necessary, formal prelimimary.

title: Many Faults Discovered In Child Detention Places
description: NEWARK, July 16 Serious fire hazards, lack of medical services, isolation as a form of discipline, inadequate educational provisions and insufficient funds are among the findings of a yearlong survey of detention facilities, temporary shelters and residences caring for children in New Jersey.

title: 6 TeenAgers and 2 Guides Buried in Mont Blanc Slide
description: CHAMONIX, France, July 16 (UPI) An avalanche swept eight climbers, including six teenagers and two guides, down the kali face of Mont Blanc today and buried them under tons of snow and ice.

title: People and Business
description: Senator William Proxmire announced yesterday that Kenneth Rush, President Nixon's counselor for economic affairs, had changed his mind and would testify before the Congressional Joint Economic Committee.

title: The Panel's Evidence Relating to the White House and Internal Revenue Service
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The House Judiciary Committee released today a ninth volume in the impeachment inquiry., dealing with the relationship of President Nixon and his staff and the In ternal Revenue Service. The first eight volumes, excerpts from which were published in The New, Yorh Times on July 12, concerned the Watergate breakin and coverup. They included seven volumes of information gathered by the committee staff and one volume of information compiled by the President's lawyers. Today's volume, of committeegathered evidence, is thus entitled Book VIII. Following is the text of the statement of information from this volume.

title: People in Sports
description: The signing of Marvin Barnes and the probable resignation of Commissioner Mike Storm and his approval as a partowner of the Memphis franchise are some of the problems the board of trustees of the American Basketball Association will have to grapple with today when they meet in New York.

title: VIRGINIA STAFFORD
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 (AP) Virginia Stafford, a former travel and society columnist for The Minneapolis Star and Tribune, died on Sunday in Cuernavaca, Mexico, where she had lived for the last six years. She was 79 years old. She had retired in 1953 but continued to contribute travel and feature articles.

title: Earnings Up by 25%
description: Citicorp, the holding company that owns the First National City Bank, the nation's second largest commercial bank, said yesterday its net operating earnings for the second quarter rose 25 per cent from yearearlier levels, setting record.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: The hopeful prediction of Harper's Weekly in 1859 was that Washington Irving would be remembered as long as fine humor and good taste are appreciated among us. Fine humor and good taste, then, are alive and well at least at the New York Public Library, where 43 glass cases of books, manuscripts, notes, sketches and correspondence attest to the variety of Irving's interests and talents. Irving may be known to us by such standbys as The Legend of Sleepy Hollow and Knickerbocker's History of New York, but he was also a diplomat, popular historian and storyteller who loved to travel and write about what he saw. He wanted to become a famous American intellecttial, accepted on both sides of the Atlantic; and that desire seems to bring in all sorts of pretensions and diffidence that makes Irving's career American.

title: They Only Wait Who Also Serve
description: JIDDA, Saudi ArabiaIt Is startling to recall that fifty years ago the United States, which is now the world's most diplomatically involved nation, had no adequate Foreign Service. Only in July, 1924, when the act sponsored by Representative John Jacob Rogers of Massachusetts became law, did today's efficient system of representation develop.

title: $7.5Million Error
description: Someone gave the wrong instructions to a computer causing it to spew out about $7.5million in welfare checks to people whose cages were supposed to be closed, embarrassed city officials disclosed yesterday.

title: CONGRESS VOTES ON LEGAL SERVICES
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Legislation to provide Federal financing for legal assistance for the poor, stalled by Congress or the White House for the last five years, suddenly came to life today and moved to within two steps of enactment.

title: A. P. MONTGOMERY LOSES REGISTRATION
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 The Securities and Exchange Commission revoked today the brokerdealer registration of the defunct firm of A. P. Montgomery & Co and barred its president, Richard S. Friedman, from association with any brokerdealer or investment company for 180 days.

title: DEFENSE RESTS IN BRAE CASE
description: The defense rested its case yesterday in the trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco on a charge that the Brooklyn Democrat had conspired to obtain bribes to get a Post Office contract in 1968 for truck company owned by reputed member of the Mafia.

title: LEGTSLATOR HURT AT MIGRANT CAMP
description: Assemblyman Byron Baer's arm was broken yesterday when the Bergen County Democrat and others were attacked while inspecting migrant labor camps near Swedesboro, N.J., an aide said.

title: For the Birds
description: The case against Dr. Charles G. Sibley, distinguished director of Yale's Peabody Museum, rests on the simple proposition that scientists, like politicians, are not above the law. An outstanding ornithologist, Dr. Sibley has been fined $3,000 in a civil procedure for having systematically imported birds eggs and egg whites that he was not licensed to import.

title: L.I. Funeral Held For Second Girl, 4, In Mystery Death
description: Several dozen relatives and friends attended a funeral mass yesterday for Deborah Ann Logue, the younger of two Lake Grove, LI., sisters who were suddenly stricken and died of stillundetermined causes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It was 2:30 the Morning of July 4, and Fidel Castro was taking my daughter and me back to our hotel in Havana. We had already spent a couple of hours talking about the mechanization of the sugar industry and the need for building up scientific personnel, both toppriority items in today's Cuba.

title: NATO Meets on Cyprus Crisis; Backs an Appeal for Restraint
description: BRUSSELS, July 16The 15 members of the Atlantic, alliance consulted today over the crisis in Cyprus.

title: Trudeau to Call Parliament
description: OTTAWA, July 16 (AP)Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that he was convening Parliament for Sept. 26 and would reintroduce the budget proposals that defeated his previous minority government. He said he was removing a 12 per cent sales tax on shoes and clothing immediately.

title: Apolloll Astronauts Mark 5th Anniversary of Flight
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 16At 9:32 A.M. Eastern daylight time today, just five years to the minute after their Saturn rocket took, off from here for man's first landing on the moon, the three pilots of Apollo 11 unveiled a plaque designating the sandy oceanside launching site a national historic landmark.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey said in Trenton that he had high hopes of getting his incometax program, which was passed by the Assembly Monday, through the State Senate late next week. July 25, he said, would be a realistic date for the Senate vote.

title: Sugar n Spice n Male Chauvinism
description: STORRS, Cone.  If there's ever a time when girls are sugar n spice n everything nice it's in sdhooll. The pattern of American schools was borne in upon me a couple of weeks ago at a local high school's closing assembly. It is a pattern that may, quite unconsciously, give men an excuse for their chauvinistic behavior toward women in later life.

title: Fed Offers Utah Land
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) The Federal Government said today it was offering 23,391 acres of land in Utah for leases for geothermal energy. The Bureau of Land Management asked that bids be submitted by July 30, to the B.L.M. office in Salt Lake City.

title: The Baltimore Strike
description: Now that the strike of Baltimore's municipal workers has been settled, the government of that city has make the hard decision whether or not to penalize those who abandoned its vital services, particularly policemen. A display of the forgiveandforget attitude so common in the wake of strikes can only reinforce the intransigence of, public workers in Ohio, who a few days ago voted to shut don the'state if they don't get a wage botist of forty cents an hour.

title: Huisein Visits: Egypt for Talks on Palestinians
description: CAIRO, July 16 (Reuters)King Hussein of Jordan arrived in Alexandria today on threeday visit to explore with President Anwar elSadat means of reconciling Jordan and the Palestinian commandos.

description: New Bond Issues

Japanese Finance Chief Quits in Dispute

title: N.F.L. Firm on Preseason Play
description: The executive committee of the National Football League management council decided yesterday that all exhibition games would be played even if it meant lineups composed of rookies, free agents and the handful of seasoned players who had crossed picket lines, The Associated Press reported.

description: PEKING, July 16 (Reutprs) Hundreds of Chinese took to the water today in a swim to mark the eighth anniversary of Chairman Mao Tsetung's swim, in the Yangtse in 1966.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16John, M. Doar, the House JuL diciary Committee's special counsel, is planning to urge the committee late this week to conclude that it has no choice but to recommend, the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: EARNINGS LOWER AT MERRILL LYNCH
description: Wall Street firms continue to blame record high interest rates and doubledigit inflation for eating away their profits. Yesterday, Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc., parent of the biggest brokerage firm, became the latest to cite these factors as it reported a 34.5 per cent quarterly earnings decline from the same period last year and a 34.5 decline for the first half.

title: Two Seized With Firearms

Rivas, 30, were arrested yestetrday at Los Angeles International Airport.

title: Westchester to Charge Man With Murder in Bar Fire That Killed 24 on New YorkConnecticut Border.
description: The man accused of setting the fire that took 24 lives in a bar on the ConnecticutNew York border last month was charged with murder in New York yesterday, following surveys indicating that the fire began on the New York side of the building.

description: Two years ago, James Long, the 98pound black jockey from Coney Island, learned to ride aboard Harry T. Mangurian Jr.'s Statue of Liberty. He broke the filly in as a yearling. Yesterday at Aqueduct, he the 3yearTracks old in as a winner.

title: Brandt Aide Joins Cabinet In Move to Heal Bonn Rift
description: BONN, July 16Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has made an attempt to heal the political wounds opened by Willy Brandt's resignation by appointing a Brandt confidant, Egon Bahr, to his Cabinet.

title: About New York
description: The important thing to know about power in New York is that the appearance of having it is usually as important as having it itself. No one person really runs the city, although David Rockefeller is often thought of as its uncrowned king, and so there hangs about Mr, Rockefeller a kind of aura. Mr. Rockefeller has power, of course, but the aura is something else.

title: Barry Leithead's Rites
description: A funeral service for Barry T. Leithead, retired chairman of Cluett, Peabody & Co., Inc., manufacturers of shirts, will be held at Frank E. Campbell's, Madison Avenue at 81st Street, at 2:30 P.M, tomorrow. Mr. Leithead died on Monday.

title: Bridge: Final of Life Master Pairs Few New Yorkers Reach

title: Market Place
description: Usually, it is institutions that dispose of stock in massive blocks, but this does not appear to have been the case in Monday's 200,000share block of the Western Union Corporation. The Western Union block traded at 8, the low for the year, and the stock then closed at 8. The stock was unchanged yesterday.

title: OvertheCounter Quotations
description: OvertheCounter Quatati MUTUAL FUNDS INSURANCE Supplementary OTC

title: ST. JOE MINERALS LIFTS ZINC PRICES
description: The St. Joe Minerals Corporation yesterday put into of feet a 1cent price increase on all zinc products, including zinc oxide. The increase is only a fraction of the 5 cents a pound rise that the New Jersey Zinc Company announced a week ago. Until New Jersey Zinc raised its prices they were about in line with those of St. Joel Minerals. The new prices, now being quoted by St. Joe for prime Western zinc is 36 cents a pound, and all metal sales remain on a F. 0. B. smelter basis. New Jersey Zinc's price for prime Western zinc is 40 cents a pound and 41.5 cents a pound for special high grade.

title: Courageous Is Outsailed By Intrepid
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 16Intrepid beat Courageous at the America's Cup trials today by 1 minute 24 seconds in light and spotty winds. It was not the most conclusive race in the world, but the outcome gave the West Coast yacht a slight edge over her new rival backed by some of the most distinguished names from the New York Yacht Club's membership rolls.

title: N.F.L. Firm on Preseason Play
description: The executive committee of the National Football League management council decided yesterday that all exhibition games would be played even if it meant lineups composed of rookies, free agents and the handful of seasoned players who had crossed picket lines, The Associated Press reported.

title: Open Golf Captured By Moser
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 16Kelly Moser, an assistant pro at Winged Foot, scored his first major tournament victory today, when he won the 52d Westchester County Golf Association open championship.

title: U.S. Five Tops Japan
description: NIIGATA, Japan, July 16 (UPI)The University of Wisconsin basketball team tonight scored its second straight victory over the Japanese national team, 9657. The Badgers took the first game, 8364, in Tokyo Sunday in their sevengame series with the Japanese national team.

description: Major League Baseball Results and Standings

title: U.S. BEGINS INQUIRY IN COURT SEIZURE!
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). Federal law officers focused today on what Chief District Judge George L. Hart vowedi would be one hell of an investigation into how two convicts took over a basement cellblock of the United State courthouse for more than four days.

title: Giants Drop Mets Into Last Place, 94
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 A sixrun fifth inning, featuring tworun triples by Gary Matthews and Garry Maddox, carried the San Francisco Giants to a 94 victory over the New York Mets tonight before a crowd of only 3,976 at Candlestick Parkperhaps the smallest crowd over to attend a GiantMet game in the 13 years the rivalry has existed.

title: Time inc. Buys Own Stock
description: Time. Inc. announced yesterday that a program to repurchase 500,000 shares of Its own common stock begun last January had been completed. The stock will be available for use in connection with future contributions to employe benefit plans, the exercise of stock options and for possible acquisitions, the company said.

title: If Only the Stove Talked, They Could Be Friends
description: The icebox speaketh.

title: Theater
description: William Inge had four consecutive Broadway successes in the nineteenfifties, then a history of failure. When he died last year, apparently a suicide, the U.R.G.E.N.T. theater (an Off Off Broadway) company next to Broadway) had coincidentally, just revived one of Mr. Inge's final Broadway failures, Natural Affection, the beginning of what may become a reevaluation of the playwright.

title: Open Golf Captured By Moser
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 16Kelly Moser, an assistant pro at Winged Foot, scored his first major tournament victory today, when he won the 52d Westchester County Golf Association open championship.

title: Gurney Pleads Not Guilty And Is Released on Bond
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 16 (UPI) Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, was arraigned today pn charges of bribery, perjury and conspiracy in a surprise appearance before United States Magistrate Joseph Hatchett.

title: City and Firemen Agree On Pay of $18,000 by 75
description: The city and the Uniformed Firefighters Association reached agreement yesterday on the major elements of a twoyear contract that is expected to raise the basic pay of 11,000 firemen to more than $18,000 a year by the time the contract expires.

title: JEROME TRIPP, 68; SECURITIES EXPERT
description: Jerome C. L. Tripp, an expert on revenue bonds and the founder and president of Tripp & Co., Inc., dealer in taxexempt and revenue securities, died Monday at Del Mar Hospital, Tijuana, Mexico. He was 68 years old, lived in Westfield, N.J., and had his office at 40 Wall Street.

title: Auto Racing Teammates Still Feud
description: Mike Hillman, the big Englishman who runs the Shadow CanAm team, was trying to assure everyone, including himself, that the feud between his two drivers, Jackie Oliver and George Follmer, was over, forgotten and patched up. So you see, he said at Watkins Glen before Oliver and Follmer finished one, two for the third straight time this year, there is nothing more to say about it.

title: Underwriter Optimistic
description: Citicorp is planning to offer the $850million of its controversial and novel type of security to the public next Wednesday, according to one of the leaders of the issue's underwriting syndicate.

title: Turkish Cypriote Attacks TakeOver By the Greek Junta
description: The following is a pooled diipatch from news agency correspondents in Cyprus:

title: Westmoreland Loses
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland was decisively defeated by State Senator James B. Edwards in the South Carolina primary where he had sought the Republican nomination for Governor. Page 6.

title: NATO Southern Flank
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The immediate concern of the United States Government in the latest Cyprus crisis is to avoid open warfare between two of its NATO allies, Greece and Turkey. But beyond that it is faced with an extremely awkward set of political and strategic problems.

title: France Appoints a Minister for Women
description: PARIS, July 16President Valtry Giscard d'Estaing appointed the writer, Frangoise Giroud, a leading feminist, today to the new post of Secretary of State for the Condition of Women.

title: Ford Is Offering Debentures at 9%
description: The Ford Motor Company dove into a sinking bond market yesterday with an offering of $250million of 9 per cent, 20year debentures, which offer Call protection for half of that period. Goldman, Sachs & Co. is handling the sale, But in the taxexempt market, Ohio became the West borrower to reject a bid. A group led by Halsey, Stuart & Co., offered an interest cost of 7.298 per cent for the $45rndlion bond issue.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne said yesterday that, he still intended to nominate former State Senator Ralph De Rose to the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. However, the Governor said he was awaiting a report from the Attorney General on the outcome of a state police check into Mr. De Rose's background. A newspaper last week said the state police in running a character check on Mr. De Rose linked him with unsavory elements on the waterfront. The commission is charged with fighting organized crime and union racketeering on the docks.

title: 73% Plunge Reported
description: The Polaroid Corporation, which earned $8.4million in the second quarter of 1973, reported yesterday a sharp plunge to $2.2million in this lyear's second quarter.

title: NEPOTISM INQUIRY IS ON AT HOSPITAL
description: The Health and Hospitals Corporation has started an investigation of alleged nepotism, overstaffing and underutilization at Gouverneur Hospital.

title: MEDICAID HEARING IS TOLD OF ABUSES
description: Witnesses at a City Council hearing testified yesterday that Medicad group clinics continued to proliferate In the city  a growth accompanied by abuses, including questionable quality of medical care.

title: Stock Prices Slide
description: Stock prices moved lower yesterday in slow and generally aimless trading.

title: Arthur P. Coleman, 76, Is Dead; Specialist in Slavic Languages
description: Dr. Arthur Prudden Coleman, a specialist in Slavic languages, died Sunday at Meriden Hospital, Meriden, Conn. He was 76 years old and lived in Cheshire, Conn.

title: DR. JACOB B. GLENN
description: Dr. Jacob B. Glenn, a doctor and writer, died yesterday at Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn. He was 69 years old and lived at 140 Jaffrey Street, Brooklyn.

title: New Cubs Win a Battle In an Old, Losing War
description: The Chicago Cubs look different these days. They don't have Ron Santo and Ferguson Jenkins; they don't have Randy Hundley and Glenn Beckert, and they don't have a 10game lead in July in the National League East.

Haldeman told him in 1970 that President Nixon personally wanted a report on an I.R.S. investigation of Gov, George C. Wallace of Alabama's and his brother, Gerald.

title: Fund Totals Differ
description: A second audit of the City Controller's office by, an outside public accounting concern has uncovered a discrepancy of more than $30million between city funds deposited with major banks and the Controller's records of those funds.

description: Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by; PLAYGIRL INDUSTRIES CORPORATION, manufacturing dresses and a holding tomnavy, 250 W. 35th St., N.Y. Signed by David Elsensteln, secretary. Liabilities $577,637; assets 5379,124.

title: Requirements Waived by State Police To Let 2 Women Qualify as Troopers
description: TRENTON, July 16Under pressure from the State Civil Rights Division, the state police have agreed to temporarily waive height and weight requirements for admission to the force to permit two women to be eligible to qualify as state troopers.

title: Strauss Expects House To Vote Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Robert S. Strauss, the Democratic National Chairman, predicted today that the House of Representatives would vote to impeach President Nixon because of devastat, ing and overwhelming evidence against him.

title: U.N. Council Hears Plea on Cyprus and Adjourns
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 16The Cypriote delegate of President Makarios's Government called on the Security Council today to order a ceasefire and to prevent outside military forces from intervening in the country's affairs.

title: Lost and Found
description: The first two of three independent audits ordered by Controller Harrison J. Goldin have exposed incredible discrepancies in the city's accounts. In the first study, auditors discovered that $5.4 million in easily negotiable securities are not in the city vault where records of the. City Controller say they should be; in the second, the auditors found $30 million deposited in banks that the city apparently didn't know it had.

title: $158Million Claim Is Filed Against Westgate by F.D.I.C.
description: SAN DIEGO, July 16The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, acting as receiver for the defunct United States National Bank, has filed a claim for $158.8million in bankruptcy court here against the WestgateCalifornia Corporation.

description: Open Interest

title: 3 Counselors Are Guilty Of Bergen Child Abuse
description: HACKENSACK, July 16 (AP)  Three former Bergen County Children's Shelter counselors have been found guilty of conspiracy and child abuse in the Nov. 13 beating of 11 youths. After five hours of deliberation yesterday, the jury also found the three Leroy Blakely, 29 years old, his brother Herbert, 35, and Vincent Smith, 29 not guilty of misconduct in office.

description: American Stock Exchange Transactions: Complete Price Summary of Yesterday's Trading

title: Lindsay to Join ABCTV AM America Series as Commentator
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay's fledgling screen career took a new turn yesterday with the announcement that he is to become a commentator on a new ABCTV network series, AM America.

title: Utilities, in Change of Position, Favor U.S. UraniumEnriching
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Spokesmen for the privately owned electric utilities, in a change of position, told Congress today that the Government should assume the costly and urgent task of expanding the nation's capacity to enrich uranium.

title: BEEF LOANS WIN IN HOUSE, 210204
description: WASHINGTON; July 16The House of Representatives narrowly approved today a $2billion program of loan guarantees to livestock producers beset by depressed beef and poultry prices.

title: Small Businessmen Find Most Bank Loans Elusive
description: Robert Fireman has been operating a furniture and gifts store on Manhattan's Upper West Side for nearly three years. The store has a good credit rating and last year grossed more than $100,000.

title: Colson Testimony Seen As Having Little Impact
description: WASHINGTON, July 16Charles W. Colson completed today two days of testimony before the House Judiciary Committee without reportedly affecting the case for the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Bridge:
description: Very few of New York's mostfamous players survived into the final of the life master pair championship when the American contract Bridge League's summer nationals continued at the American Hotel here yesterday.

title: Apprentice Jockey Triumphs On Horse That Broke Him In
description: Two years ago, James Long, the 98pound black jockey from Coney Island, leaped to ride aboard Harry T. Mangurian Jr.'s Statue of Liberty. He broke the filly in as a yearling. Yesterday at Aqueduct, he broke the 3yearold in as a winner.

title: Con Ed's Average Bill For Homes Falls by 50c
description: Effective last Friday, the electric bill of the average householder in the Consolidated Edison Company's service area dropped by 50 cents as the fuel adjustment surcharge declined for the fourth straight month, the utility reported, yesterday.,

title: New Jersey Sports
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, July 16A forward finished his turn on the line, came back to the bench and said, These guys are good skaters. But they weren't skating up and down a rink on a hot summer day with hockey sticks in their hands. They were playing in the East Rutherford Recreation Department's street hockey league.

title: Ethiopia's Defense Chief Seized. In a Mounting Wave of Arrests
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jply 16 (AP)The Ethiopian Defense Minister, Lieut. Gen. Abebe Abye, was detained today by the armed forces following the arrest of 60 other leading officials in the last 18 days.

title: Common Market Plans BeefImport Ban
description: BRUSSELS, July 16The European Common Market decided here today to ban most imports of beef from nonmember countries until Oct. 31 in an effort to stem the growing meat surplus in Europe and raise the prices received by farmers.

title: St. Peter's to Be Repaired
description: ROME, July 16 (AP)  The iron fence that for more than three centuries has been surrounding the gallery of the dome of St. Peter's Basilica is being replaced, Vatican officials said today. The replacement is being made a few weeks after a 4yearold girl squeezed through the gaps in the fence and fell to her death.

title: Sotheby's Amid Criticism on Goods and Reserves, Shifts Rules
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet has disclosed several changes in its controversial auction practices. But the new rules may not have much effect either on its success in business or its failure to still criticism within the art and antiques trade.

title: Television
DOROTHY C. ALYEA
description: Dorothy Collins Alyea, poet and civic leader and the wife of Ethan D. Alyea, died Monday at New York Hospital. She was 75 years old and lived at 77 Highland Avenue, Montclair, N.J.

title: DECEPTION IS LAID TO 11 HEALTH SFIS
description: The Jack La Lanne health spas in the New York area were accused yesterday by the Federal Trade Commission of dozen deceptive or misleading practices.

title: Brooklyn and Manhattan To Be Democratic Arena
description: Manhattan and Brooklyn will be the major battlegrounds for Democratic nominations for Congress, the Legislature and the City Council in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: PORTUGUESE DELAY FORMING A CABINET
description: LISBON, July 16The formation of a new cabinet was delayed here today while discussions continued between the Premierdesignate, Col. Vasco dos Santos Gongalves, and representatives of political groups and the armed forces.

title: THOMAS.C. M'KINNEY
description: Thomas C. McKinney, head of Hudson Valley Newspapers, Inc., of Highland, N.Y., publisher of several weekly newspapers in Ulster County, died yesterday at Horton Memorial Hospital, Middletown, N.Y. He was 61 years old and lived at New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Criticizes Reaction In U.S. and Britain to Atom Test
description: NEW DELHI, July 16Prime Minister Indira Gandhi criticized the United States and Britain today for what she called the noise that they have been making, since Indias recent underground nuclear test.

title: Miss van Hamel Dances Nikiya With Classic Taste and Warmth
description: Consideration, clean technique and intelligent taste are the interpretive weapons that Martine van Hamel brings to choreographic treasure such as La Bayadere. She avoids flamboyance even in its legitimate employ, and shapes her role like a classically simple oriental vase. She danced Nikiya for the first time Mon day at the State Theater in American Ballet Theater's revival of the work.

title: Assemblyman Hurt in Attack at Migrant Camp
description: Assemblyman Byron Baer's arm was broken yesterday when the Bergen County Democrat and others were attacked while inspecting migrant labor camps near Swedesboro, N.J., an aide said.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: The winning New York daily lottery number yesterday was: 881505

title: The P. B. A. Threat
description: New York City has had a painful and expensive education in collective bargaining with its overstrong civil service unions; crippling strikes and excessive settlements in every vital municipal agency have helped push the city budget to astronomic heights.

title: SILVER FUTURES TURN DOWNWARD
description: For the first time in many weeks silver unleashed itself from London gold prices and moved in the opposite direction Silver prices dropped sharply here yesterday, while gold prices moved up.

title: PRICES ON AMEX AND 0TC DECLINE
description: Prices closed lower in light trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as volume fell slightly. In the counter market, prices also fell in decreased trading.

title: Yacoe Wins 2d Race at Larchmont
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16Joseph Yacoe of the Sea Cliff (L.I.) Yacht Club won his second straight Laser Class junior race of Larchmont Race Week on Long Island Sound today.

title: Red Smith
description: When Conn McCreary and Ted Atkinson were two of the best jockeys in the world, an extortionist went to work on them, demanding tips on winners in exchange for their lives. The anonymous letters outlined a signal codein the paddock they were to wear bandages on one or more fingers to indicate the saddlecloth number of the horse that would win. If they didn't cooperate, they were warned, they would be shot dead no matter where they tried to hide. Or, one letter suggested, somebody might chop McCreary's hands off instead. Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation advised going along with the scheme in the hope that the extortionist would betray himself. Trouble was, jockeys are lousy handicappers and they knew it, which didn't help their nerves.

title: Washington Acts to Prevent Very Dangerous Situation From Hiring Into War
description: WASHINGTON, July 16The United States, in intense diplomatic exchanges, is pressing Greece and Turkey to keep a very dangerous situation on the island of Cyprus from getting out of hand, an American official said today.

title: DISMISSAL IS SOUGHT FOR HOSPITAL GUARD
description: The State Department of Correctional Services is seeking the dismissal of a correction officer who formerly ran the commissary at Matteawan State Hospital in Beacon, a department spokesman, David L. Eno, said yesterday.

title: 72 SLAYING OF 6 GI'S IN VIETNAM CHARGED
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 16 (Reuters)A man who said he was a Nietnarti war veteran told a radio audience by; telephone here today that he and three other New Zealand soldiers shot and killed six American soldiers they had found torturing Vietnamese civilians more than two years ago.

title: SOME TAX RELIEF ON STOCKS IS SET
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP). The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively agreed today to key changes in the tax treatment of capital gains and losses.

title: Earthquake in Montana
description: HELENA, Mont., July 16 (AP) A moderate earthquake rattled windows in Helena, Butte and Bozeman today. There were no reports of property damage or injuries.

title: ELIZABETH WARRICK
description: RICHMOND, Ind., July 16 (AP)Elizabeth Warrick, a former stage and radio actress died Sunday at the age of 60.

title: As Strikes End: Calm and Garbage
description: BALTIMORE, July 16For a city that has gone through the trauma of simultaneous strikes by policemen, garbage collectors, park and zoo maintenance men, jail guards and highway repair crews, Baltimore appeared surprisingly clean and untroubled today.

title: President Shifts on Public TV And Sanctions LongRange Aid
description: President Nixon, reversing a position he took in June, yesterday approved a bill prepared by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy for the longrange financing of public broadcasting by the Federal Government.

title: Horse Brings $225,000
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 16 (AP)  Stardust Mel, runnerup in last Sunday's Hollywood Derby, was sold today for $225,000, which the California Thoroughbred Breeders Association said was the most ever paid at auction for a 3yearold gelded race horse. Larry Rose and his wife, who bought the horse two years ago for $6,000, sold him to Marjorie Everett, a director of Hollywood Park. In 17 starts, Stardust Mel won $179,800.

description: NEW ORLEANS, July 16 A male voice cried, Get these potatoes off the truck, ya heah?

description: WASHINGTON, July 16The Nixon Administration made a broad effort today to stop a move by Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Interior Committee, to extend the law that authorizes the Government to regulate petroleum prices and allocate fuels.

description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 16 A former President of South Korea went on trial before military court today on charges of subversion that carry a possible death sentence.

title: Study by the F.P.C. Sees Possibility, Though Unlikely, of Harbor Disaster With Liquefied Natural Gas
description: Warning that a major catastrophe was possible though unlikely, the Federal Power Commission has issued an environmentalimpact study of proDissed tank farms for liquefied natural gas on Staten Island that concludes that the risk to the public from such facilities is acceptable.

title: Rabbi Asserts Nixon Views Ehrlichman Case as Unjust
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 16  President Nixon believes that the conviction of his former aide, John D. Ehrlichman, was a blot on justice and that it would be extremely difficult for any Watergate figure to get a fair trial in Washington, according to a leader of thp President's grassroot supporters, Rabbi Baruch M. Korff.

description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 16 (UPI) Chico Hagey, the firstseeded player, moved into the quarterfinals of the national men's amateur grass tennis championship today with a 61, 60 rout of De Armond Briggs.

title: Liberty and Equality
description: Fame seems to favor those who court her most avidly. Calvin Bryce Hoover, a professor of economics at Duke University, did not court fame at all, and when he died in Durham, N. C., last month at the Economic age of 77, there Analysis was little public notice. But he was one of the most distinguished economists of his time and, in the interstices of a long academic career, one of this country's most useful and creative public servants.

title: NAYS BODY FOUND IN PROSPECT PARE
description: The body of a welldressed unidentified man, bound hand and foot and shot in the back of the head, was found on wooded slope of Prospect Park in Brooklyn yesterday, apparently the victim of a gangland killing,

title: 5,500 FURLOUGHED IN AIRLINE STRIKE
description: National Airlines sent furlough notices to 5,500 employes yesterday as a strike of 1,600 mechanics and other maintenance workers grounded the company's planes for the second day,

title: Dynamite Levets a Solid Building Built by Edison
description: WEST ORANGE, July 16With the crack of exploding dynamite and the roar of falling concrete and rocks, Building 24 succumbed to the wreckers assaults here this morning and broke another bond of memory between the town and the late Thomas Alva Edison, the inventor.

title: Augelli Leaves U.S. Bench For General Motors Post
description: NEWARK, July 16Judge Anthony T. Augelli of Federal District Court announced his resignation from the bench today, citing personal considerations coupled with the fact that Congress has failed to increase judicial salaries.

title: JURY BEGINS INQUIRY INTO FT. DIX DEATH
description: JACOBSTOWN, N.J., July 16 (AP)A Federal grand jury has joined the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Army in the inquiry into the death at Fort Dix of a young man in a confrontation with a company of basic trainees.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, July, 16 (Reuters)  Congress should give itself authority to set the guidelines for the Federal Reserve's monetary growth policy on an annual basis, a staff economist of the House Banking Committee recommended today.

title: Abel Talks of Depression
description: PITTSBURGH, July 16 (AP)I. W. Abel, president of the United Steelworkers of America said today that the nation faced a possible depression and he blamed Congress and the President for the inflated economy.

title: Italian Newspaper Sale Fought
description: ROME, July 16A Milan Court opened hearings today in a dispute over the sale of a majority interest in. Italy's most prestigious daily newspaper to a publishing company backed by industrial interests.

description: Tunney Disputes Reinecke Testimony favorable settlement on the antitrust cases.

title: WATER BIG ISSUE FOR MEXICO CITY
description: MEXICO CITY, July 16 The unusually heavy and prolonged rains of this wet season presented Mexico City and its environs with the most serious water crisis in the capital's history.

title: DILORENZO TRIAL TOLD OF A LUNCH
description: The former assistant counsel of the Waterfront Commission testified yesterday at the per jury ury trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo that he was shocked when the judge unexpectedly joined him and another judge for lunch.

description: Tuesday, July 16. 20th day. Weather clear, track fast.

title: CONTACTS CITED BY REP. COUGHLIN
description: WASHINGTON, July. 16 (UPI) Representative R. Lawrence Coughlin, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today that he had received four unusual contacts from the White House in the last week that could be interpreted as stroking in exchange for Ins support of President Nixon when the House votes on impeachment.

title: Courageous Is Outsailed By Intrepid

I., July 16Intrepid beat Courageous at the America's Cup trials today by 1 minute 24 seconds in light and spotty winds it was not the most conclusive race in the world, but the outcome gave the West Coast yacht a slight edge over her new rival backed by some of the most distinguished names from the New York Yacht Club's membership rolls.

title: Shopwell in Accord To Acquire Bohack
description: Shopwell, Inc., and the Bohack Corporation reached an agreement yesterday to merge Bohack into Shopwell through an exchange of stock valued at more than $6million. Under terms of the agreement, Shopwell contemplates the News issuance of 1 shares of its common stock for each share of Bohack common of which there are 1.3 million outstanding. The merger is subject to approval of the board and stockholders of both companies and the approval of the appropriate Government agencies.

title: Surprise for a Thief
description: MIAMI, Julyy 16 (AP)The person who stole a sack from the back seat of an old Chevrolet here yesterday got seven foot surprise, Inside the bag was a rattlesnake that had been caught a short time before by Police Lieut. Ross MacDonald. He was taking it to the Miami Serpentarium.

title: Army Secretary on Tour

title: Cyprus at a Glance
description: GeographyWith an area of 3,570 square miles, Cyprus is the third largest island in the Mediterranean sea (after Sicily and Sardinia). She lies in the eastern Mediterranean 40 miles south of Turkey, 60 miles west of Syria and 500 miles southeast of mainland Greece. The capital is Nicosia, with a population of over 100,000. Two mountain ranges traverse the island, rising to 6,400 feet at Mount Olympus. Between the ranges lies a wide plain, the chief agricultural region. The population of 650,000 is about 80 per cent ethnic Greek and 17 per cent ethnic Turkish; Armenians are prominent among the rest. The majority belong to the Orthodox Church, while the minority are Moslem.

title: Film: 'Adventures of "Rabbi" Jacob':Louis De Funes's Gifts Carry French Farce The Cast Gerard Oury Directs for Abundant Laughs
description: Louis De Funes, reportedly the biggest thing to hit French films since Brigitte Bardot, is a tiny middle-aged man, bald and usually frowning. He looks a little bit like Leon Errol, but he acts a lot more like a souped-up version of Edgar Kennedy.In the time the late Mr. Kennedy would have used to go through one slow burn, Mr. De Funes can experience three completely disconnected rages, register a couple of alarmed double takes and survive one or two near-fatal prat falls. He's a two-reel comedian for the jet age, when, of course, no one is making two-reel comedies any more.This means that a feature film like "The Mad Adventures of 'Rabbi' Jacob" uses up an awful lot of Mr. De Funes very quickly. It's a credit to Gerard Oury, the director and co-author of the screenplay, and to the rollicking bad temper and bigotry of the star that so much of "The Mad Adventures of 'Rabbi' Jacob" is so funny so much of the time.The movie, in French with English subtitles, opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and Beacon Theaters.In "The Mad Adventure of 'Rabbi' Jacob," Mr. De Funes plays a furiously prejudiced bourgeois businessman for whom life is almost insupportable because the world isn't inhabited exclusively by white French Catholics. As a result of a series of terrible coincidences he finds himself (1) sought by the police as a political assassin, (2) up to his chin in a vat of green bubble gum, (3) chased by a group of Arab terrorists, (4) the hostage of an Arab nationalist hero and (5) disguised as an American rabbi making his first visit in 50 years to his Parisian birthplace.Supporting the star who works tirelesslyand mostly with successfor laughs, are a number of fine sight gags and some very good supporting actors, including Suzy Delair, who plays Mr. De Funes's wife, a bossy woman with a passion for dentistry.

title: Against Homosexuality
description: SHIPPENSBURG, Pa.  The toleration of homosexuality among American college populations has been regarded as a successor to the antiwar radicalism of the nineteensixties and early nineteenseventies. Individual hostility and repugnance to homosexuality has bent before a tolerance among students, faculty and administrators, with results unimaginable even a decade ago. We seem to be experiencing a new humanitarianism, new and more personal revolutionism, not only on the campus but in American society at large.

title: Curb on Strip Mining

Such a course would leave great areas of the West in dismal ruins and the energy need as great as ever.

title: FOREIGN SECURITIES; (In U.S. Dollars)
' My Name Is Nobody,' Puts Fabled West on Film:The Cast
description: Sergio Leone's "My Name Is Nobody" is the kind of Western that only an immensely appreciative and witty Italian film maker could make. It stars Henry Fonda, one of Hollywood's most noble performers, as the greatest of the old West's gunslingers, and Terence Hill, one of Italy's newest young actors with an anglicized name, as the blond, intensely blue-eyed Nobody who goads, pushes and finally shepherds the older man safely into history.The film, an Italian-French-German co-production that was photographed in New Mexico, Colorado and Spain, opened yesterday at the Loew's State 2, Orpheum and Murray Hill Theaters.Mr. Leone did not actually direct the movie, a job that was handled by Tonino Valerii, a former assistant to Mr. Leone ("A Fistful of Dollars," "Once Upon a Time in the West," etc.), the man who gave the so-called spaghetti Westerns class.Yet it very much looks like a Leone film and, I suspect, it is. It's called "a Sergio Leone presentation," and it's based on his idea. In addition, it's filled with Leone observations about a West he originally encountered in old Hollywood movies.The time is 1899, midnight for the 19th century, when Jack Beauregard (Fonda), the fastest gun still alive, is making his way toward New Orleans and a one-way passage to Europe, where, he assumes, no one will try to pick a fight with him in bars along the Via Veneto. En route to New Orleans, he meets a mysterious young man who says he is Nobody (Hill) whose skills with a gun match his own and who doesn't want to see the great Jack Beauregard fade quietly into anonymity.At times Nobody seems to be a malignant clown who wants nothing more than to ridicule the older man. At still other times he talks half-seriously to Beauregard about ways in which the older man can realize his potential as a legend. Nobody thinks it would be nice if Beauregard single-handedly took on the 150 members of the fabled Wild Bunch (not yet gone to seed as shown in the Sam Peckinpah film), and so arranges this spectacular battle.The plot of "My Name Is Nobody" makes less sense as narrative than as a device on which to hang a series of incidents that are variations on the theme. In this fabled West, life is a continuing series of contests, in bar-rooms, on main streets and on vast plains where two opposing forces miles apart, come together so inevitably and so perfectly it seems they must be equipped with bat-radar.Though it may be too schematic for the taste of many Americans, "My Name Is Nobody" is filled with tumuluous beautifully choreographed action sequences that are so bloodless (a change from the early Leone films) they seem to be slapstick. The style of exaggeration is evident even in the extraordinary clarity of the images and of the sound, so that when we hear the rasping of a straight razor going over a week-old beard, it's as if we were being made aware of each whisker's fate.Mr. Hill is surprisingly effective and sometimes very funny, in a role that is an impossible mixture of Puck, the stage manager in "Our Town," Shane and conventional Ryan O'Neal. Mr. Fonda, as always, is firmly down-to-earth, creating a specific character of the sort that has little truck with the Leonelike introspection. He's a man of action at the end of his career."My Name Is Nobody" is terribly knowing. It has the manner of a buff who knows absolutely everything about a subject most other people haven't time for, but it's also very entertaining.

description: The National Football League has informed the New York Giants that a former member of their organization is being investigated by an 'official agency for gambling associations and other possible irregularities.

title: Honey Tree in Sky Felled by House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  The House Agriculture Committee goes along with the idea of sending Smokey Bear back to his New Mexico birthplace when he dies, but wants to eliminate references to a great honey tree in the sky.

title: IRAN TO ACQUIRE 25% INTEREST IN KRUPP STEEL
description: PARIS, July 17The Government of Iran is acquiring a 25 per cent interest in the steel works of the giant Krupp enterprise of West Germany, it was announced today, and establishing a presence in the parent company itself.

title: Honey Tree in Sky Felled by House Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP)  The House Agriculture Committee goes along with the idea of sending Smokey Bear back to his New Mexico birthplace when he dies, but wants to eliminate references to a great honey tree in the sky.

title: AHMAD JAMAL PLAYS AT RAINBOW GRILL
description: The mere fact that Ahmad Jamal, the jazz pianist, is at the Rainbows Grill is worthy of note because. Mr. Jamal does not have the kind of renown that one would expect the Rainbow Grill to look for in booking a jazz musician (Benny Goodman, Duke Ellington, Dave Brubeck, the Modern Jazz Quartet and Lionel Hampton represent the room's usual dips into jazz).

title: Advertising. A Different H. M. H.
description: There are other publishing moguls around who put out magazines. for largely male audiences and have the initials H. M. H., besides Hugh Hefner,

title: HUSSEIN TO ALIGN STAND WITH SADAT
description: CAIRO, July 17 (UPI)  King Hussein of Jordan and president Anwar elSadat of Egypt agreed today to set up a military cornmittee to work out joint Arab policies for the Middle East peace conference in Geneva.

title: Cost of Feeding Family of Four Passes $60 Weekly

title: Additional Excerpts From Interview With Nixon by Head of Panel on Presidency
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 17Following are additional excerpts from an interview with President Nixon in he White House last May 13 by Rabbi Baruch M. Korff, of the National Committee for Fairness to the Presidency. The interview is part of a book by Rabbi Korff, The Personal Nixon: Staying on the Summit, copyright 1974.

title: Military Arrests 7 Officiali In an Ethiopian Province
description: ASMARA, Ethiopia, JulY 17 (Reuters)  The Governor General of Eritrea, Lieut. Gen Debebe Haile Mariam, and. six other high officials of the province have been arrested by the Armed Forces Committee of the North, the Asmara radio said tonight.

title: Stockholdings Of Insiders
description: The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latest reports on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The reports include the following:

title: Caution Dominating Moves by Federal Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, JULY 17Over the last few weeks Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. and a number of other men have de clined to accept appointment as the Administrator of Veterans Affairs, an office that presides over a bureaucracy of 189,000 people and a budget of more than $13billion.

title: HAROLD G. FALLER
description: Harold G. Faller, president of Sunrise Home Juices, Inc., of Far Rockaway, Queens, died yeaterday in the South Shore Medical Center, Far Rockaway. He was 65 years old and lived at 571 Oak Drive, Far Etockaway.

title: Golden Needles, Search for a Statuette
description: If acupuncture hasn't been a major point in theatrical movies heretofore, its value is still debatable to judge by Golden Needles, which surfaced yesterday at the Cinerama, 59th and 86th Street Twin Theaters. The clutch of good and bad guys and dolls fighting over an alleged Sung Dynasty gold statutte bristling with those needles that promise either endless virility or death, is neither Sung, 20th century, medical nor movie art.

title: Police to Be Taught To Assist Victims Of Heart Attacks
description: Police Commissioner Michael, J. Codd announced yesterday that policemen on the streets Were being trained for the first time to aid heart attack victims.

title: A Texas Banker Buys Into Washington StarNews
description: WASHINGTON, July 17A millionaire banker from Texas has bought a controlling interest in The Washington StarNews, the capital's sole surviving afternoon newspaper, from members of the three families that have operated it for more than a century.

title: House Takes Up Bill to Set Strip Mine Standards
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 The House of Representatives opened today a threeday debate on a proposal for the first Federal regulation of strip mining for coal.

title: Events Today
description: MOVIES IN THE PARKS, presented by the Film Society of Lincoln Center, Inwood Park, Manhattan, entrance at Seaman Avenue and 215th Street, 9 P.M.

title: Former Navy Flier Covers Dog Circuit
description: A former Navy pilot, who flew missions over Iwo Jima and Truk in World War H, now is flying all over the country on a more pleasant assignment  judging dogs. He is Jim Frank of El Cajon, Calif., who is engaged in almost every phase of dog shows. As a breeder, he had success with Boston terriers. 4,s a clubman he has been president of the Silver Bay K.C. for 10 years and show chairman for four. He has been an ardent hunter since his youth. News of Dogs

title: Shrine Coaches Added
description: STANFORD, Calif., July 17 (AP)  Coaches Bob Blackman of Illinois and Vince Dooley of Georgia have been named to assist Head Coach Bo Schembechler of Michigan in preparing the East team for the 50th annual Shrine college allstar football game here Dec. 28.

title: 2 MAJOR AIRLINES POST JUNE GAINS
description: American Airlines, Inc., and Trans World Airlines reported yesterday sharply higher earnings for June compared with the 1973 month.

title: France Has Payments Loss
description: PARIS, July 17 (Reuters)France recorded an overall balanceofpayments deficit of 3.7 billion francs (about $737.4million) in 1973, compared with a surplus of 1.2 billion francs in 1972, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: U.S.EUROPE TIES REPORTED EASED
description: BONN, July 17 (AP)Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that tension between the United States and its European allies had largely disappeared and Atlantic relations could now be viewed in a rather relaxed way.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Councilman Robert F. Wagner Jr. urged Mayor Beame to reject a staff recommendation that the Tweed Courthouse, the 19thcentury monument to corruption, be demolished. Mr. Wagner, atlarge Democrat from Manhattan, said that instead the building should be renovated for executive headquarters.

title: InflationWeary Unions Pursue CostofLiving Clauses
description: WASHINGTON, July 17An editorial in today's issue of the machinist sheds light on why almost 600 labor strikes are under way in the United States, a large number, perhaps the largest number in 20 years. The Ma chinist, published News Analysis by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, said editonally:

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, P.M.

title: General Foods Expects Net To Be Up 7.5% in Quarter
description: Earnings of the General Foods Corporation for its first quarter ended June 29 are expected to show a 7.5 per cent increase to 57 cents a share from 53 cents a share a year earlier, James L. Ferguson, chairman, said at the annual meeting yesterday in White Plains.

title: EXCITY LABOR AIDE DENIES FUND MISUSE
description: James D. Norton, former acting direct& Of the city's Bureau of Labor Services, surrendered yesterday at the District Attorney's office on an indictment charging that he misused city funds for a vacation trip.

title: 42% of Deposits Lost By Franklin Since May
description: The beleagured Franklin National Bank has lost $1.26billion, or 42 per cent of its deposits, since its financial problems surfaced early in May, according to figures released yesterday by the New York Clearing House Association.

title: CONSENT JUDGMENT OFFERED 12 TRUCKERS
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) The Justice Department today announced that it had filed a proposed consent judgment under which a trucking association would be dissolved in 90 days and 12 trucking companies would be enjoined from fixing prices on handling im ported air freight at Kennedy International Airport.

title: The Pop Life
description: One might think that the most important thing about pop music was the music, out it isn't necessarily so. Rock has always been signi ficant as a battle cry for teenage protest or as background for amorous couplings. And for many people, especially those at the center or the periphery of the music business itself, the most important thing has been glamour.

title: Guns Enforce a Calm. On Streets of Nicosia
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 18The new Government on Cyprus says that life is back to normal here and indeed there is calm in this capital city ringed by 16thcentury Venetian walls.

title: Explosion in the Tower
description: The news story in yesterday's Times said: ... One died tonight in a hospital.... At least a dozen of the injured, about half of them children, were in serious condition. Two of the victims suffered severed legs, and rescuers found a child's foot beneath the displaced cannon.

title: Public Reaction in Cyprus to the Coup Remains Clouded Amid Outward Normality
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 18 Although outward normality was returning to this city today, public reaction to the military overthrow of the elected government of President Makarios remained clouded.

title: CLIFFORD M. BOWDEN
description: Clifford M. Bowden, a partner in the law firm of Shearman & Sterling, 53 Wall Street, died Saturday at his home in Glen Head, L.I. He was 71 years old., Bowden from

title: Bearne Tells of Vain Effort To Reconcile City's Books
description: Abraham D. Beame was aware last year, when he was Controller and running for Mayor, that a multimilliondollar discrepancy existed in the records of City Treasury funds, according to a statement issued by Mayor Beame yesterday. He ordered a crash program to try to reconcile the discrepancy, which was in the city's favor, sources Close to the Mayor said.

title: Dr. William H. Conley, 67, Of Sacred Heart University
description: Dr. William H. Conley, who retired July 1 as chancellor of Sacred Heart University in Bridgeport, Conn., died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital, Bridgeport. He was 67 years old.

title: Levine Gives Maine House As Free Wyeth Museum
description: CUSHING, Me July 18Joseph E. Levine, the film producer, announced today that he was donating the Olson farm to the state of Maine for use as a permanent museum for the works of the artist Andrew Wyeth. Mr. Levine made his announcement in the company of Gov. Kenneth M. Curtis and Mr. Wyeth.

title: VOLCANO IN SOVIET TO BE POWER SOURCE
description: MOSCOW, July 18 .The Soviet Union plans to tap the heat of an active volcano to run a 300,000kilowatt electricity station, the Mining Institute of Leningrad has ,Iannounced.

title: CHEMICAL MAKERS UNDERINDICTMENT
description: NEWARK, July 18E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co. and eight other chemical manufacturers that together control 60 per cent of the nation's dye sales were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges they fixed prices, pushing the cost of dyes to artificial and noncompetitive levels.

title: Hayes Tied With 4 at 66 In B.C. Golf
V.A. Starts Work to Replace the Kingsbridge Hospital
description: Just four years ago, Congressional investigators tore at the public conscience with tales of a scandal in the Bronx: ratridden wards at Kingsbridge Veterans Hospital and helpless patients unattended for hours. In a memorable photograph, a paraplegic exmarine slumped in a shower stall, waiting to be dried.

title: What Was It About?
description: Watergate, President Nixon stated in a recent interview, is the broadest but the thinnest scandal in American history, because what was it about?

title: Rail Traffic Increases
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 The Association of American! !Railroads reported today that; freight traffic on United StateS !railroads last week totaled an !estimated 15.7 billion tonmiles, 0.9 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same period totaled 503,982 cars, 3.4 per cent beloW last year.

title: ITALIAN UNIONS PLAN A NATIONAL PROTEST
description: ROME, July 18Italy's three major labor federations today announced a series of stoppages across the country next Wednesday to protest the austerity measures adopted by the Government this month to bolster a tottering national economy.

description: Two undercover investigators for the Waterfront Commission testified yesterday, at the perjury trial of Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo that they saw a reputed Mafia fig ure, Thomas Masotto, enter the chambers of the judge in the Civil Court building at Schermerhorn and Smith Streets in Brooklyn two times in January, 1967.

title: Darrell's Tales of Hoffmann Gives Few Rewards to Dancers
description: The most irritating aspect of Peter Darrell's realization of TheTales of Hoffmann is that the dancers work fiendishly hard for little artistic reward. Eventhe ballet's Hollywood orgy decor would be tolerable if there were some imaginative dancedesigns. In this American Ballet Theater's production, Cynthia Gregory and Jonas Kase were the leads Tuesday evening, while Eleanor D'Anturo and Ted Kivitt danced the fatally mismatched ,pair at the New York State Theater on Wednesday.

description: WASHINGTON, July 18 The Communications Workers of America rejected today late hour contract offer by the Bell Telephone System and directed its locals to take a strike vote.

Should Utility Lay Off Minorities Or Union Members, Court Asked
description: NEWARK, July 18 (AP)The Federal District Court here was asked today to decide whether a proposed 200man layoff by the Jersey Central Power and Light Company should be of newly hired black and Puerto Rican workers or longstanding union members protected by contract.

description: SYRACUSE, July 18 (AP)The president and chief executive officer of Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation said today inflation has forced the utility to cut back planned capital expenditures for 1975.

description: Delay Asked on Tripling of Oil Leases

title: LAWYER IN SEOUL HELD AFTER TRIAL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 18 A prominent South Korean lawyer who defended the nation's leading poet and 10 students in political trials last week has been arrested, associates disclosed today.

description: TOKYO, July 18 (UPI)Two leading Japanese auto makers said today they had accepted a steep price increase for steel sheet proposed by six major steel companies.

description: WASHINGTON, July 18Following the text of a White House memorandum from Egil Krogh Jr. and David R, Young to John D. Ehrlichman indicating the Department ofDefense's view of the Government's case against Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: Death of 2 Sisters on L.I. Continues to Baffle the Experts
description: When 7yearold Angelina Logue and her 4yearold sister Debora lay down for a nap last July Fourth after an afternoon's frolicking in their aunt's swimming pool in Dix Hills, L. I., no one noticed anything amiss. It was a hot day and the six other children who had been in the pool were exhausted too.
