title: Shootout Report Quotes Death Threat
description: LOS ANGELES, July 19, (AP) Before the May 17 shootout between the police and the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army, the leader of the terrorist group, Donald D. DeFreeze, said: I know I am going to die, and all of my people know that they will also, but we are going to take a lot of pigs with us,

title: Polaroid Will Focus on a New Inexpensive Camera
description: BOSTON, July 19The Polaroid Corporation, faced with sudden lag in profitability because of problems with its SX70 camera film, annouced here today that it would introduce a new inexpensive camera in September.

title: Bosnian Stops A's on NoHitter; His Error Spoils Perfect Game
Uganda Cites Border Threat But Tanzania Denies It
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, July 19 (Reuters)A military Fokesman said here today that Tanzanian troops and guerrillas had massed on the Uganda border, planning to invade, early today but later pulled back to positions three miles from the frontier.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
COST SOYBEANS SHOW ADVANCES
description: Reports of dry, hot weather In the Middle West continued to influence futures trading yesterday, although some of the buying that forced prices up sharply during the week had vanished.

title: Black Consortium Sets Building Loan For Atlanta Hotel
description: A group of black financial institutions has formed a consortium to make a $2.9million construction loan to a blackowned hotel in Atlanta,

title: E. David Ltikashok Dead; Film Producer Was 34
description: E. David Lukashok, a write! and producer of films, principally industrial and educational, died Wednedsay of a heart attack at his home, 27 East 11th Street. He was 34 years old.

title: PARENTS CONVICTED IN DEATH OF SON, 11
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., July 19 (AP)Lawrence and Alice Parker, who threw away their diabetic son's insulin in the belief that he had been cured by a faith healer, were convicted today of involuntary manslaughter and child abuse.

title: Books of The Times
description: A few years ago, women's tennisit was all amateur thenwas a divertissement one watched at Forest Hills while waiting for the real tennis to be played, the genuine article being, of course, the men's game. Well, no more. Women's tennis is now an occupation, the players are professional, the money is suitably green, and the game is fully as interesting, as exciting and as disciplined as men's tennis, now also largely professionalized.

title: WILLIAM H. MAXWELL
description: ORANGE, N. J., July 19 (AP)  William H. Maxwell, former features editor of The StarLedger of Newark, died Wednesday at his home here at the age of 93.

title: People in Sports
description: The Babe Ruth Birthplace Shrine and Museum in Baltimore was opened to the public; culminating a sevenyear drive to honor the memory of the former New York Yankee slugger.

title: Falcons Trade Reaves; N.F.L. Talks Continue
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP)Ken Reaves, an experienced cornerback and the Atlanta Falcons representative in the National Football League Players Association, helped set up a picket line outside the team's training camp in Greenville, S. C., today and then learned he had been traded.

title: Bandit Flees on Bicycle
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 19 (UPI)A young bandit held up the Cambrian branch of the Bank of America today and escaped with about $1,000 on 10speed bicycle.

title: Rehearing To Free Galley Refused by Appeals Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 19 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused today to reconsider releasing former 1st Lieut. William L. Caney Jr. on bail.

title: DeMarco Has Surgery
description: PITTSBURGH, July 19 (AP) Abe DeMarco, a defenseman for the Pittsburgh Penguins of, the National Hockey League, underwent an appendectomy today in North Bay, Ontario,.a club spokesman said. DeMarco, who joined the Penguins last season in a trade with St. Louis, was expected to be hospitalized about a week.

title: CITICORP REVISES OFFERING TERMS
description: Citicorp's controversial $850million offering of floatingrate securities, scheduled for sale to the public next Wednesday, have run into some investor resistance and may be scaled down slightly, according to Wall Street sources.

title: Royals Hold Off Yankees
Head of Piecinct and 10 Shifted After Inquiry
description: The commanding officer, three lieutenants and seven sergeants have been transferred out of the 10th Precinct in Manhattan, following a Police Department investigation that found laxness, several incidents of cooping [sleeping on the job] and poor supervision, the department's public information office said Thursday night.

title: ER, INC., OPPOSES PURCHASE OFFER
CARRIER IS READY TO AID AMERICAN
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 20 (AP)The Pentagon early today ordered the United States carrier Forrestal and other naval vessels toward Cyprus to he in position in case United States citizens have to be evacuted in the increasing tense crisis.

title: Soviet Plane Crash in Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 19 (AP)One person was killed and four were seriously injured today when a Russianbuilt Antonov 14 of the Egyptian Air Force trashed in suburban Cairo, reliable sources said. It was the second Sovietbuilt aircraft to :rash in Egypt in nine days.

title: DILORENZO GETS BACKING IN COURT
description: Former Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri, six judges, a former member of the House of Representatives, a Roman Catholic priest and the president of the Brooklyn Bar Association testified yesterday that Civil Court Judge Ross J. DiLorenzo, who is on trial on perhiry charges, had an excelIlent reputation for truth,

title: 9% Montreal Bank Yield
description: MONTREAL, July 19 (Reuters)The Bank of Montreal said otday it would increase the interest rate on savings accounts to 9% per cent from 83 per cent, effective Aug. 1.

title: Pennsylvania Governor Puts Signature on NoFault Bill
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) Goy. Milto J. Shapp signed a nofault automobile insurance bill into law today and put his signature on another bill that forces government agencies to ;make almost all policy decisons at public meetings.

title: Ella Grasso a Certain Winner in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, July 19Somi support her because she is ilwoman and this is supposed be women's year in politics Some support her despite he! sex. But to most of the Demo cratic delegates who gatherec here today to nominate Repre Isentative Ella T. Grasso fol Governorthe delegates vote tomorrowthe question seem irrelevant and a bit faded.

title: Diver Found Dead In Flooded Drydock At Navy Yard Here
description: A roundtheclock effort to rescue a. commercial diver lost in a threelevel drydock pump well in the old Brooklyn Navy Yard ended in failure yesterday when the diver's body was found on the second level of the well.

title: Narcotics Figure's $100,000 Murder Bail Here Called. Tainted
description: Leroy Barnes, a murder suspect listed by the policeas top narcotics dealer, has been freed on $100,000 bail posted by a former Las Vegas gambling figure.

title: Kuwait Threat Cited In Gulf and BP Deal
description: PARIS, July 19European oil analysts said today a threat by Kuwait to cut production was behind the decision by the Gulf Oil Corporation and British Petroleum Company to raise the price they will pay for Kuwait stateowned oil.

title: City to Appeal Court Order TO Shut Tombs by Aug. 10
description: The city Corporation Council's office said yesterday that it would appeal an order by a Federal judge that the city close the Manhattan Houst of DeVntion for Men known as the Urmbs.

title: Connecticut Democrats Convention Opens on Festive Note of Confidence
description: HARTFORD, July 19Connecticut Democrats opened thei 1974 state convention here to night in a festive atmosphere that was heady with confidence that in November the party wil be returned to power after foul years away from it.

title: U.S. Students on Shotat Jet
description: HONOLULU, July 19 (UPI)Teenagers aboard a South Korean airliner that was shot it near Seoul last night said Today there was praying but tic Panic on the plane. The jet, Carrying 165 students from the American Field Service's interrational scholarship program, arrived here early today and flew on to Los Angeles. A South Korean Defense Ministry spokesman said the plane was shot at by North Korean anti: aircraft but not hit.

title: Mets Beat Padres, 42, On 5Hitter by Matlack
Farmers Hail Right to Evict Migrants
description: TRENTON, July 19A Superior Court decision affirming the right of New Jersey farmers to summarily evict migrants who stop working was hailed here today by the New Jersey Farm Bureau.

title: Kissinger and Makarios To Meet in Washingtor
description: WASHINGTON, JULY 19Secretary of State Kissinger will meet here Monday wits Archbishop Makarios, the State Department announced today

title: Ballet: Balser de la Fee
Rumanians Tie French In Tennis
People and Business
description: C. Russell Luigs, 41, yesterday was named president and chief operating officer of U. S. Industries, Inc, I. John Billera, 62, who had held the title of president, continues as chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the $1.6billion conglomerate.

title: Ziegler Condemns A Kangaroo Court
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 19In its harshest attack yet on the House Judiciary Committee, the White House accused the committee's counsel today of conducting a kangaroo court and challenged the right of its chief counsel to present articles of impeachment against President Nixon.

title: Price Supports Studied
description: WASHINGTON, July 19President Nixon disclosed his decision to raise milkprice sup ports in 1971 after listening to an exposition by John B. Connally on political and economic considerations and on dairy cooperatives potential for campaign funding, a new transcript released by the House Judiciary Committee showed today.

title: Valerie Patrono Is Bride of Ned Kandel
description: Valerie Susan Patrono, a copywriter at the Young & eubicam advertising agency Hire, was married yesterday morning to Laing Phillip Kandel, a marketing analyst for the American Broadcasting Company. Justice of the Peace John Atkin performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Berthold Ewing Jr. of Darien, Conn., stepfather and mother of the bride.

title: The. Pool on East 23d Street Knows No Generation Gap
description: Where else can you have such a good time for 35 cents? remarked Rick Shuart, bouncing 3yearold Alise in the water of the East 23d Street public swimming pool the other day. Mr. Stuart was talking about the 25cent admission charge for himself and the dime for his daughter.

title: MONKEY POSTERS BACK IN PEKING
description: HONG KONG, July 19Golden Monkey, the pseudonymous author of Peking's most polemical wall posters, struck back today with a scathing attack on municipal leiders in the Chinese capital who appeared to have silenced him two weeks

title: DENNIS C. GOSS
description: Dennis C. Goss, a publicrelations executive, died yesterday in an Atlanta hospital. He was 38 years old and lived in Atlanta. Formerly he had lived in Bronxville, N. Y., and Groton, Mass:

title: Nader Urges Tougher Penalties In W hiteCollar Crime Cases
description: WASHINGTON, July 19Ralph Nader said today that whitecollar crime by businessmen and government officials cost the American people at least $4billion over the last 18 months, and he called for tougher penalties for those convicted of fraud and corruption.

title: Seoul Charges Catholic Bishop With Bid to Topple Government
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 19 A prominent Roman Catholic, bishop has been indicted for; allegedly attempting, to over! throw the Government by violent means and will be tried; before a secret military court! early next week, Catholic': sources said today.

title: Makers of Lysol to Take The Hyperbole Out of Ads
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) The makers of Lysol disinfectant have agreed to stop asserting that using the product around the house will kill germs that cause flu, colds or sore throat, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.

title: Kaiser Industries Shows Drop in Profit in Quarter
SAMUELS REBUTS CHARGE BY CAREY
description: Howard J. Samuels, who was accused by Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn of being in bed with the bosses Mr. Samuels attacked in the battle for the Democratic nomination for Governor in 1970, said yesterday that the circumstances were different then.

title: Cyprus TakeOver: A DaybyDay Account
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 19 The coup began around A.M. Monday. Units of the National Guard, led by their officers from the Greek Army, moved on police stations in Nicosia, the capital, and Famagusta, Kyrenia, Larnaca and Limassol, They were backed by 40 tanks, mortars and light artillery.

title: Art: The Taste of King George III
description: LONDON  In imperial terms, King George Ill of England is one of the alltime losers. He has never had a good press in the United States. In preRepublican days he was associated naturally enough with the policies of his Ministers; and since 1766 he has been thought of primarily as an oppressor, rightly and justly twerthrown, who was afflicted in later life by a peculiarly poignant and demeaning form of madness.

title: U.S. Says Soviet Alerted Seven Airborne Divisions
3 Tied in W omen's Open; Curtis Sifford Is Leader
SHORT INTEREST SHOWS DEWN]
Many Pasta Plants Found Unsanitary, F.D.A. Memo Sap.
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) An internal Food and Drug Administration memorandum says fewer than half the nation's pasta manufacturers meet Federal sanitation standards.

title: M.T.A. Shows the Way?
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has at last lifted some of the mystery from the world's most complex and perplexingtransportation network with the publication this month of two new Bus Guides for Manhattan and the Bronx.

title: Mel Allen's Father Dies
description: STAMFORD, Conn., July 19 Julius Allen Israel, father of the sportscaster Mel. Allen, died at Stamford Hospital last night. He was 85 years old and lived at 115 Dundee Road. Be:. sides his sons, Mel and Larry, a brother, two sisters, and four grandchildren survive.

title: Honeywell Laying Off 600 In Boston to Cut Costs
description: WALTHAM, Mass., July 19 (UPI)  Honeywell, Inc. announced today it would lay off about 600 employes in its Boston computer operations this month as part of its overall program of holding down expense... in a worldwide economy of inflation.

title: Ellsberg Lawyer Tells of Apology From Colson
description: Leonard B. Boudin, who served as Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's lawyer in the Pentagon papers trial, said yesterday that Charles W. Colson had apologized to him for attempting to interfere with Dr. Ellsberg's right to counsel.

title: Antitrust Suit Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The House Judiciary Committee published today voluminous docunientation on the tangled web known as the I.T.T. affair.

title: Antiques: Two Days and Three Historic HousesAnd Squash With Rum
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y.The first of the Sleepy Hollow Heritage weekends ended late Sunday afternoon after participants had made leisurely visits to three historic houses of the Hudson Valley, listened to informal lectures, watched films and dined on eolonialstyle cuisine that ranged from the simple (cornbread) to the sumptuous (roasted acorn squash laced with rum and served with mounds of butternut ice cream).

title: WHITE HOUSE ROLE ON SHOW DENIED
description: Top officials of CBS, who were involved in the purchase of the program series O'Hara, United States Treasury, in 1971, denied yesterday that the White House was in any way influential in placing the show with the network.

title: Crane Break on Courageous Halts Test
BETTY BRUCE, DANCER AND COMEDIENNE, 54
description: Betty Bruce, who went from ballet to tap dancing, added singing and then blossomed as a comedienne on stage, screen and television, died Thursday of cancer in Roosevelt Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 142 East 16th Street.

title: S.E.C. WILL SUSPEND UTILITY TOCK RULE
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (Reuters)The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it planned to suspend a rule requiring utilities to use competitive bidding when selling common stock.

title: U.S. Puts Pressure on Greeks and Turks
Young Americans for Freedom Pay Tribute to Senator Goldwater at Parley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 In their hearts, there is no doubt, Young Americans for Freedom still know he is right.

title: P.O.W. Gets New Post
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) Air Force Maj. Gen. John P. Flynn, the highest ranking P.O.W. held in North Vietnam, was appointed today to take charge of the basic training of all Air Force recruits. General Flynn, a native of Cleveland, has been commandant of the Air Command and Staff College at Maxwell Air Force base since returning from captivity last year. He will take command of the military training center at Lackland A.F.B., Tex., next month.

title: Justices'
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The Supreme Court may be unable or unwilling to hand down decision in the Nixon tapes case until after the House Judiciary Committee has voted late next week whether to recommend the impeachment of President Nixon.

title: Imperative for Cyprus
description: The Turkish military intervention on Cyprus sharply increases the chance for major bloodletting on the island and for war between Greece and Turkey. As Ankara will undoubtedly claim, this action may be legal under the 1959 treaties by which Cyprus achieved its independence; it is nonetheless a rash move likely to provoke a violent response from Greece.

title: Oil Import Estimates To U.S. at $25Billion
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 (Reuters)  The Commerce Department today raised its estimates of the cost of Unied States oil imports this year by more than $5billion to $25billion.

title: Guild Ends Convention
description: ST. LOUIS, July 19 (UPI)The Newspaper , Guild cone eluded its fiveday annual ebnvention today after voting to meet again next year instead of every two years. The convention also approved an allocation of $300,000 to hire six organizers for two years as part of an expansion drive for the union. Guild members will pay special assessments next March and April to pay for the allocation.

title: Reporter Held in Incident Involving Assemblyman
description: POINT PLEASANT, July 19 (AP)Charles Finley, a reporter for The Newark StarLedger, was arrested at his home here today on trespassing charges in connection with the incident at a Gloucester County farm in which Assemblyman Byron Baer suffered broken arm.

title: just a Quiet Ride in the Country
description: NANTES, France, July 19 (UPI)Militant farmers disrupted the Tour de France for the second consecutive day today, sending the 106 bicycle racers on the first detour in the 71year history of the race.

title: On Hyde Park Stage, Actors Get a Chance to Struggle
description: HYDE PARK, N.Y.  The Vanderbilts always knew how to face adversity, and thus it came to pass that shortly after the turn of the century, they built a huge stable next to their estate here so that, even if it rained, they and their guests could go horseback riding and not get their fillies wet.

title: TankCar Explosion Injures 129 Persons In Illinois Rail Yard
description: DECATUR, Ill., July 19 (UPI)  A tremendous tankcar explosion and a chemicalfed fire devastated a railroad yard today, demolishing a trainmen's dormitory and forcing the evacuation of up to 30,000 people from a threesquaremile area here.

title: OLITICIANS ON COAST GOT HUGHES MONEY
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif July 19 (UPI) Howard R. Hughes channeled more than $20,000 to Republican and Democratic candidates in California through lobbyist for the company identified as a C.I.A. cover, state records showed today.

title: Soyuz Returns Safely
description: Two Soviet astronauts returned to earth safely after rehearsing docking techniques for next year's SovietAmerican space mission. Page 62.

title: Earlier Testimony By Reinecke Read, Prosecution Rest
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The prosecution in the trial Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of Cal fornia concluded its case toda with a reading to the jury excerpts from Mr. Reinecke testimony before a grand jur; in February.

title: Rep. Brasco Guilty of Bribery Conspiracy
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco was convicted last night of conspiracy to take bribes to get a Post Office contract for Mafiacontrolled truck company.

title: The Officers'
description: AALFRED DELP, a Germa Jesuit priest, wrote his prison cell just be fore his execution the Nazis in the at tumn of 1944: One da there will be other who will be allowed to live better an Atappier than we who have had die. These 'others, who form Ge. many's postwar generation, are sti questioning how out of political indil Terence Hitler's regime could hay evolveda regime that afflicted th entire German people like a menu disease.

title: SOVIET PRODUCTION ROSE 8.3% IN HALF
description: MOSCOW, July 19 (UPI)Soviet industrial production increased 8.3 per cent in the first half of the year, well above the revised goal of 6.8 per cent, the Central Statistical Board said today.

title: Franklin National Seeks Trading Ban Extension
description: The Franklin New York Corporation and the Franklin National Bank said yesterday they had requested the Securities and Exchange Commission to continue the suspension of public trading in their stock, debentures and, notes for another 10 days, ending on Aug. 2. The current trading ban had been scheduled to expire July 23..

title: Ziegler Condemns A Kangaroo Court
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 19In its harshest attack yet on the House Judiciary Committee, the White House accused the committee's counsel today of conducting a kangaroo court and challenged the right of its chief counsel to present articles of impeachment against President Nixon.

title: Dave Anderson
description: ATLANTIC CITY, July 19The putdown on baseball now is that its romance exists mostly for the older generation, that the kids have so many other sports to follow. But in Puerto Rico, the romance remains for the kids. Jorge Lebron proves that. Jorge Lebron is only 14 years old, but last Monday the Philadelphia Phillies announced that he had signed a minor league contract for a reported $30,000 bonus. He might be the youngest professional baseball player ever; nobody knows for sure. At his introduction by the Phillies, the precocious shortstop from Patillas, P.R., was asked to identify his baseball idol.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: THE PLAYTHING'S THE THING The Museum of the City of New York's everpopular collection of toys is so huge that, at any given time, only a small portion of it can go on display. So there's a quality of eventfulness to the fact that, this summer, the museum has decided to go through its rich store of dolls, toys and children's games to produce an exhibition of some 200 items, many of them never displayed before because they were acquired recently.

title: Little Sark Faces Life Without the Dame
description: SARK, Channel Islands, July 19This tiny feudal British island off the coast of France has lost its ruler, and now the Sarkese fear the worstthat change will come.

title: 3d City Audit Is Believed To Be Most Devastating
description: Mayor Beame called back yesterday the top team that served him when he was City Controller to try to blunt the impact of still a third audit report from his successor. At City Hall the latest report was said to be even more devastating than the first two, which have caused the Mayor profound embarrassment.

title: Premier's Illness Stalls Laos Cabinet
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, July 18The coalition Government has responded to the crisis provoked by Premier Souvanna Phouma's heart attack last week in traditional Laotian fashionby doing nothing.

title: BREZHNEV GREETED BY POLISH CROWDS
description: WARSAW, July 19 (Reuters) Huge crowds and traffic jams greeted eonid J. Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist party, when he arrived here today to attend Icelebrations marking the 30th anniversary. of the Communist party takeover in Poland.

title: 5 MAJOR CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, July 19The House Judiciary Committee's senior counsels to both the Democrats and Republicans urged the committee today to recommend a Senate trial of President Nixon on one or more of five central impeachment charges.

title: Stefano Magaddino Dead; Reputed Crime Leader, 81
description: Stefano Magaddino, the reputed leader of an organized crime family whose domain once included western New York, died last night in upstate Lewiston, where he made his home. He was 81 years old.

title: U.N. Force on Cyprus Is $20Million in Debt
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 (Reuters)The 2,300man United Nations peacekeeping force in Cyprus is about $20million in debt, Secretary General Waldheim disclosed in a letter published today.

title: Coded System Is Devised For Sale of Merchandise
description: WASHINGTON, July 19A veteran inventor and businessman offers a coded system for the sale and delivery of merchandise that is designed to lessen the pilferage of goods by both customers and sales people. In the method patented this week by Luther G. Simjian of Greenwich, Conn., the customer makes the selection from a showcase, gets a coded card at a payment station, and turns it in at a dispensing station that may be near the door. The mechanism confirms the coding before releasing the article to the buyer.

title: 2 Men Plead Guilty in Theft Of Landmark's Iron Panels
description: Two men who were arrested last month in the theft of castiron panels of a dismantled landmark, the Borgardus Build ing, pleaded guilty yesterday in Criminal Court to a reduced misdemeanor charge.

title: Citibank Holds Prime As Formula Climbs
description: The First National City Bank held its prime corporate lending rate at 12 per cent yesterday, despite a formula that called for a 12 per cent charge to its most creditworthY customers.

title: WILLIAM R, HEROD, LED G. E. DIVISION
description: William Rogers Herod, who retired in 1960 as president of the International General Electric Company and vice president of the General Electric Company, died yesterday in Weekepaug, R.I., where he was on vacation. He was 76 years old and lived at 580 Park Avenue here.

title: Press Corps Is Evicted From San Clemente Inn
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 19 (UPI)  The White House press corps has been evicted from the San Clemente Inn and will use the Concordia Elementary School where Presiednt Nixon votes as its new press room.

title: CLASHES REPORTED:
Research Vehicle Launched
description: VANDERBERG, A.F.B., Calif., July 19 (UPI)A research and development reentry vehicle was launched at 5:58 P.M. yesterday by the Air Force Space and Missile Test Center here, it was announced. The reentry vehicle was propelled down the Western teste range by a modifood Minuteman.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR: The June 16 Sunday New Jersey section of The New York Times included an article entitled, Marijuana Penalties May Be Relaxed. It covered many of the views of New Jersey State Senator Alexander Menza, head of a special legislative committee to review the adequacy of New Jersey's drug laws.

title: True Knight Takes Suburban
description: The old inspirational insistence of try, try again finally bore fruit yesterday for the Darby Dan Farm's True Knight at Aqueduct. Competing in the $114,800 Suburban Handicap against nine rivals, including the formidable Forego, True Knight registered a 1length triumph over Richard Craigo's Plunk, the runnerup.

title: Anne Elaine Bolton Is Bride Of Steven M. Tower, a Teacher
description: Anne Elaine Bolton, daughter of Wallis Darte Bolton of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Elaine Heckmann Bolton, was married yesterday noon to Steven Matthew Tower, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wilson Tower of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Raymond Dana Scott performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Stamford.

title: The Cello Can't Play These Chords
description: SUZANNE CIANI, a slightly built, darkeyed 28yearold, does not wear steelrimmed glasses, talk in abstract gibberish, move like robot Or conform to other misconceptions one might have about a player and composer of electronic music. The daughter of a Boston physician, she began studying piano at the age of six, and had a traditional liberal arts education at Wellesley and Berkeley. She likes music by Mozart, Bach, and Carole King. Although she often sits down at a piano to play her own songs, her instrument is a 160pound mass of panels, wires, knobs, buttons and a pianolike keyboard called a Buchla. Miss Ciani describes it with almost evangelical enthusiasm.

title: Brian Healy to Wed Miss Owens
description: Constance Dale Owens, an assistant to the producer of the CBS Morning News, and Brian M. Healy, an associate producer with the CBS Evening News, plan to marry Sept. 28 at St. Dominies Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: FLORIDA BATTLES MOSQUITO CRISIS
description: MIAMI, July 20 (AP)Heavy spring rains perked up greenery and eased the threat of a water crisis in parched south and central Florida, but they also precipitated the worst mosquito infestation in years.

title: Matawan Is Reconsidering Acquisition of Industrial Complex
description: MATAWAN TOWNSHIP The fate of the 22acre Metal and Thermit Corporation complex still remains in doubt despite a unanimous decision by. the sevenmember Township Council 18 months ago to acquire the property.

title: Stefano Magaddino Dead at 82; Reputed Upstate Crime Leader
description: The body of Stefano Magaddino, the reputed upstate New York crime boss who was one of the last of the original national commission members who had ruled the American Mafia in the last 30 years, lay in his own Niagara Falls funeral chapel yesterday. He died Friday of a heart ailment at the age of 82. Floral wreaths kept arriving all day.

title: Slouching toward Israel
description: The Holocaust is still seeping into every crack of the consciousness of Jewstheologians, politicians, storekeepers, social workers, students. There is broad agreement that the murder of onethird of Jewry transforms the relations of Jews to God, to other peoples and to each other. But there is yet no agreed understanding of what these transformed relationships must be.

title: Brezhnev, at aPolish Fete Asks World Reds'
description: MOSCOW, July 20Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, called today for a meeting of world Communist parties, opposed by some parties on the ground that such a conference would probably be used to ostracize China from the world Communist community.

title: Richard G. Kessler To Wed Amy Stern
description: Amy Eloise Stern, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology here, plans to be married. Aug. 11 to Richard Gary Kessler of New York. The ceremony will be at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Fishman of South Orange, N.J., the bridetobe's stepfather and mother, who have announced the engagement.

title: Mental Health Institute Sets $5Million in Minority Grants
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The National Institute of Mental Health announced this week grants totaling nearly $5million to train 215 racial and ethnic minority students in mental health professions and nine minority reporters in health and science writing.

title: Anne Seagrave Becomes Bride
description: Anne Wood Seagrave, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman P. Seagrave of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Reese Peters Fullerton Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fullerton of Santa Fe, N.M.

title: GEORGE E. HITE
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 20 George E. Hite, senior partner of the New York investment banking and brokerage firm of Adams & Pack, died today at his home at Mead's Point here. He was 61 years old.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Bill North, Oakland A's center fielder, proved during recent visit to Shea Stadium that the club's reputation for being outspoken was justified. He announces: The manager [Alvin Dark] has no [expletive omitted] guts and the owner [Charles 0. Finley] doesn't know what he's doing.

title: Milwaukee Bus Company Fights Free Shuttle by DoubleDeckers
description: MILWAUKEE, July 20  A bank has brought a bit of Lon don here but Milwaukee's bus company was not happy about it.

title: Larchmont's Top Trophy To Brazill
Brasco Bans a Bid for Reelection After Conviction
description: Representative Frank J. Brasco, the Brooklyn Democrat who has served in Congress since 1966, abandoned his battle for reelection following his conviction Friday night for conspiracy to take bribes.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTONThe New Jersey Legislature has received the type of report card that most children would be afraid to show their parents.

title: JONATHAN BUTLER, ARCHITECT, 70, DIES
description: Jonathan Fairchild Butler, partner in Rogers, Butler & Burgun, architects specializing in medical institutions, died yeiteislay at his home in Rye, N.Y: He was 70 years old.

title: PENSION AID SCORED AT SENATE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The minimum income provided Social Security recipients is a form of guaranteed poverty, a Senate panel has been told.

title: Photography
description: NOT the least interesting thing about documentary photographs (and all other factual records) is the Way they reflect the viewpoint of their times. They aim for the truth, of course, and they tell it as well as they can. But they tell the truth as it appears to intelligent observers of the time and place. Which is not necessarily the way it will appear to intelligent observers of other times and places.

description: HARTFORD, July 20United States Representative Ella Tambussi Grasso was nominated by acclamation today at the Connecticut Democratic Convention as the party's candidate for Governor.

description: TRENTON  The Department of Environmental Protection has adopted a new set of solidwaste management rules to provide tighter controls over waterpollution dangers, gas control, use of landfill cover and the disposal of chemical and hazardous wastes, to impose usercharge fees and to obtain information.

title: Men at Rheingold Hopeful on Future
description: The temperature may be soaring into the 90's these steamy summer days, but at the Rheingold Brewery in Brooklyn, the employes whose jobs were saved when the plant was saved from extinction in March  are working with cool smiles and icy determination.

title: The Importance Of Understanding Heathcote Williams
description: LONDON SINCE the sixties, England has produced only one playwright whose inner resonance could compare with the front runners of the New Wave: Pinter, Osborne, Arden. That writer, on the strength of only one fulllength playAC/DCand a single oneacter"The Local Stigmatic"is Heathcote ,Williams. There is a need to proclaim this so portentously because England breeds writers faster than dogs breed fleas, and there is a strong tendency here, and in the United States, to be overcome by the sheer weight of numbers. There is an enormous amount of activity in England, but very few solid dramatic pieces: only a handful or plays are worth protecting or returning lo.

title: GASP Seeks Smoking Curbs
description: SUMM1TAn organization called J. J, Gasp (Group Against Smoking Pollution) has obtained more than 1,500 signatures on petitions asking state legislators to put all enclosed public places off limits to smoking.

title: QUESTIONS

title: Iraq to Improve Tigris and Euphrates

Holl of Rowayton, Conn., and the late Allen L. Mordecai of New York, in St. John Bosco Roman Catholic Church, Parma Heights, by the Rev. Joseph Tully.

description: The American economy has rounded out the first half of 1974 with inflation still coursing at record peacetime rates and with the gross national product decliningbut, on each count, with some iniprovement over figures for earlier in the year.

title: Stamps
description: KANSAS hard winter wheat, brought to the United States a century ago, is one more classic example of how immi. grants drawn by the freedoms of America have helped make this country great.

title: Houston Finds Murder Ring Random, Enigmatic Intrusion
description: HOUSTON, July 17  It was raining today in the Heights. The storm clouds swept in from a high Texas sky, drenching the peeling frame houses, the rutted roads and the Spanish moss on dying trees. The towers of the booming downtown district, rising out of the flat landscape to the south, were lost in mist.

title: Chris Evert Victor by 50 Lengths
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 20On an occasion where overtones overshadowed what actually occurred on the track, Chris Evert, the filly, won the largest single prize ever put up in any sport$350,000by beating Miss Musket by 50 lengths in a match race over a mile and a quarter at Hollywood Park today.

title: Ruling May Change PropertyTax Methods
description: A recent ruling by the State Court of Appeals may lead to changes in the propertytax structure in many communities, according to government and realestate officials on Long Island and In New York City.

title: ST. CLAIR ASSERTS PANEL LACKS DATA FOR CITING NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon's defense attorney, James D. St. Clair, told the House,Judfciary Committee in a formal brief made public today that there was no solid evidence that President Nixon had committed impeachable offenses.

title: Book Ends
description: August. As the annual August sirocco Wows in, we note a concomitant drought of titles upcoming for the month. The book drawing the most interest is the timely Kissinger, by Marvin and Bernard Kalb, a biography cum timeandmotion study of the Secretary in action. (And, by the bye, an expanded edition of Henry the K's American Foreign Policy is also due in August.). Paul Erdman, who served time in a Swiss jail for financial peculation then wrote a best seller called The Billion Dollar Sure Thing, has another financial mystery out called The Silver Bears. It involves silver manipulation and the Mafia. Evan Connell, who wrote Mrs. Bridge and Mr. Bridge, is represented by a new novel, The Connoisseur. And there looks to be substantial legacy of John O'Hara stories; collection of some of them, Good Samaritan and Other Stories, will appear. Only two have been previously published. William Hjortsberg offers a comic fantasy about bullfighting with one of the funnier titles of the year, Toro! Toro! Toro! Then there is a collection of short fables and an allegory by Brigid Brophy, The Adventures of God in His Search for the Black Girl.... In Ross and Tom, John Leggett studies the lives of Ross Lockridge and Thomas Heggen, two writers who lived (and died) the Fitzgeraldian adage nothing fails like success. Critic Richard Gilman represented by a collection of essays on the theater entitled The Making of Modern Drama.... The rest is a mixed bag, including: Love and Evil, by Alan Harrington, The American Way of Sex, by Peter Whittaker, The American Intellectual Elite, by Charles Kadushin, Innocents at Home, by Tad Szulc (foreign correspondent rediscovers his country), I Remember It Well, by Vincente Minnelli, The Mayflower, by Kate Caffrey and Chicano Power, by Tony Castro (MexicanAmericans in the United States).. Jim Bishop expands his time frame from his customary day to a year in F.D.R.'s Last Year. Richard Bach fans (of whom there are many, we are sure) will find him in a nonallegorical mood in A Gift of Wings. Dick Cavett tells his life story, sort of, between jokes, to his college roommate Christopher Porterfield in Cavett, while Brit Hume, former assistant remembers the big scoops in Inside Story. The Colette books continue to issue forth with The Evening Star, an autumnal memoir. And some consider Babe by Robert Creamer the best of the Babe Ruth biographies.

description: There's a great deal of satisfaction in making one's own surfcasting rod, and a small savings may also be realized.

Bay Staters may remernber Mike when he was a flanker on the Boston Sweepers in the Atlantic Coast League. Then came the Korean War and from 1950 until 1953, and Michelson was in a different game. Serving with the Airborne Rangers, he thrice was decorated, being awarded a Silver Star and two Bronze News of Dogs

title: Chess: O.K., You've Won a PawnNow Conies the Hard Part
The Riches of the Sea
description: In presenting its position to the Law of the Sea Conference in Caracas, the United States has moved accept the inevitable  creation of the new 12mile territorial sea and 200mile economic zone already favored by a majority of other nations. In doing so, however, the American representative, John R. Stevenson, properly insisted that the rights to extended jurisdiction at sea already claimed by many states must be accompanied by clearly recognized obligations to the international community.

description: BOSTON I AM determined to die with my name above the titles, Bette Davis likes to say in that imitably defiant way of hers, each syllable cropped so that it becomes an incident, each word stretched until it becomes an event. As usual, she means business. Recently, she took on tour around the country her program from the series, Legendary Ladies of the Screen, which was whit last year at Town Hall in New York, For a month she was the title: Bette. Davis In Person and On Film.

title: A Tribute to Dorothy Fields

She was born on July 15,1905. Although Miss Fields died last March, her friends will again celebrate her birthday. Tonight at Guild Hall's John Drew Theater they will offer A Tribute to Dorothy Fields as a benefit for the local cultural center.

title: Black U.S. Diplomat Pessimistic on South Africa

title: Anothr Man's Posion
description: SEATTLEI see. in the newspaper that Republican Representative John B. Collin of Arizona is up in arms over the wasting of money by Federal policymakers. As his special target, he has zeroed in on Government grants to support what he considers to be frivolous and unnecessary research projects. He waxes eloquent in his outrage against such outlandish pro, posals as those concerning the bisexual behavior of Polish frogs, the smell of perspiration in Australian aborigines and the blood groups of Polish Zlotnika pigs.

title: Lessons From A French Opera Company
description: WHY should a provincial French opera companythe Opera du Rhin in Strasbourgbe of interest to Americans? For one thing, in planning a period of remodeling and expansion it is calling on the services of people who have been.fixtures in the New York City scene for many years; for another, its incorporation into a regional cultural project the first of its kind in Francemight, have value as an example to us.

title: New &
description: Once upon a time there was a struggling advertising copywriter called Rosemary Reed. By dint of hard work and the intelligent manipulation of her action oriented personality, Rosemary was able to start her own agency and imake it thrive. Her private myth is that she is a female King Arthur, destined to preside over a Round Table of brave, reverent creative people. Lois Wyse translates Rosemary's Napoleonic (or Arthurian) lust for power into a fascinating occupational odyssey. It begins, necessarily, with the hijacking of a client, winds through the perils of incorporation, financing, partnership (and separation) and ends with the All About Eve syndrome.

title: The Opposing Forces
description: In terms of mainland strategic forces behind the armed forces already on Cyprus, Turkey outnumbers Greece by nearly 3 to 1, according to estimates by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and by the Institute for Strategic Studies, an independent agency in London.

title: Red Smith
description: Faced with the gravest and most acrimonious labor dispute their industry has ever encountered, owners in the National Football League have made package offer that would enable a fiveyear veteran earning $30,000 a year to increase his preseason pay from $2,900 to $3,000. Although the package included several other concessions, it brought a hoot of derision from Ed Garvey, the players union leader, who has insisted all along that the players were fighting for freedom, with financial considerations secondary. The freedom issues are money issues and a buck is a buck no matter how you spend it, was the mysterious response of the owners labor counsel, Theodore Kheel.

title: Death as a friendly onion
description: The subject of death leads in a flash to the subject of miracles. One of the most memorable patients described by Elisabeth KtiblerRoss in her first book, On Death and Dying (which was published by Macmillan in 1969, and of which some halfmillion copies are now in print), was a terminallyill person who, the author wrote, always believed in a miracle. This patient expected, against all the clinical evidence, to be healed. A clear enough instance of denial, no doubt, a classic mechanism of defense which, KiblerRoss would argue, can nevertheless serve a useful function. Terminal patients ought not to be deprived of hope if they seem to need it; besides, we are not infallible and can never be sure which is the last [hospital] admission. Human organisms can surprise us, and this particular one did indeed prove surprising. I think this is the miracle:, the patient confided to KiiblerRoss one day: I am ready now and not even afraid any more.

title: JEWISH SECT TO GO TO ORANGE COUNTY
description: More than 100 families of Hasidic Jews will soon be moving into a new housing development near Monroe, N. Y., in Orange County.

title: Dave Anderson
description: As the National Football League labor dispute continues, the owners and players act as if they are the only ones involved. But the public is more involved than either one. Already the owners are planning to foist rookies on the public as valid representatives of their franchises with no reduction in the price of tickets and no offer of refunds. That's no way to treat its permanence, as described by Wellington Mara, the chairman of the N.F.L. Management Committee and the president of the New York Giants, in contrasting the public not long ago with the transient role of owners and players.

title: Panel Questions Lawyers On Impeachment Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The House Judiciary Committee questioned its senior lawyers today op a massive analysis of impeachment evidence, an analysis that declares that President Nixon was directly responsible for the Watergate burglary and assumed active management of the ensuing coverup attempt.

title: Home improvement
description: ALTHOUGH everyone is conscious of the need for conserving energy in the home, few people are really willing to give up many of the conveniences offered by the wide assort ment of lighting equipment and electrical appliances which is an inherent part of almost every modern household. However, many people do not realize that they can use two simple and inexpensive electrical accessories to provide added convenience with their existing lights and appliances, while at the same time actually.cutting down on the amount of energy wasted in many cases. These two accessories are: automatic electric timers and the versatile new lightdimswitches.

title: The Mass of Evidence And What It Portends

The issues include White House relations with the Internal Revenue Service, a special nationalsecurity wiretap program, the activities the White House investigations unit known as the plumbers, the handling of the antitrust cases against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, and White House dealings with and Presidential decisions regarding the dairy industry.

Mr. Simon conferred with King Faisal at the summer palace in Taif, in the mountains 50 miles inland from this Red Sea port city, a United States said.

title: U.N. Council Calls for CeaseFire on Cyprus and End Foreign Intervention

The Cubiculo is now celebrating its sixth year with a threepart festival, which began last Friday and may be seen tomorrow and Tuesday and next Friday and Saturday at the Cubiculo Theater, 414 West 51st Street.

description: One effect of the new state rentstabilization law has been to spur the organization of tenants, according to Rose K. Gould, vice president of the Queens Presidents Council. The council says it represents 170 tenant and civic organizations in the borough.

title: Soviet Amateur Athlete: A Real Pro
description: The Soviet Union has no professional sports. It has no professional athletes. It fights international professionalism at every turn.

title: Chicory Blue
description: If they were white, or yellow, or phloxmagenta, we probably wouldn't look twice at chicory blossoms, which now brighten the rural roadsides every sunny morning. But chicory flowers are blue, one of the clearest blues that bloom in the fields, cerulean blue, the blue of clean, clear sky. The plants are tall, sometimes much as four feet, the leaves are relatively few, gray. green and coarsely toothed, and the flowers grow near the tip and hug the stems. They seem to thrive in dry weather and in poor soil.

title: Son for Mrs. Schwarz
description: A son was born July 2 to Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ira Schwarz of Cambridge, Mass., in the Mount Auburn Hospital there. The child has been named Dana Gilbert. His mother is the former Miss Lavinia Gilbert, daughter of John Baptiste Gilbert of Orinda, Calif., who recently retired as vice president of Crown Zellerbach in San Francisco. The child's father is a doctoral candidate in biochemistry at Harvard University and his grandfather is Daniel Schwarz, former Sunday Editor of The New York Times,

title: Common Market Deplores Cyprus Coup
description: PARIS, July 20 The nine Common Market nations agreed today to present a joint statement to Greece and Turkey demanding restoration of the constitutional status of Cyprus and accusing Greece of involvement in the coup that overthrew Archbishop Makarios on Monday, it was announced here.

title: Threat at Statue of Liberty
description: A telephoned bomb threat that proved false caused the evacuation by boat yesterday of 400 visitors to the Statue of Liberty. The threat was received at 10:40 A.M. Two hours later the statue was reopened to visitors after a thorough search of Liberty Island by the New York City Harbor Police.

Television
description: AS the dust settles under, or perhaps over, public television's struggles to put together a schedule for next season, reactions of the participants range from some bitterness (particularly in the areas of opera and public affairs) to cautious optimism. But out of the rubble are emerging glimmers of perspective, not only on the selections but also on the selection processes.

title: Agreed: Here comes national health insurance
description: In 1945, President Harry S. Truman proclaimed his belief that everyone should have ready access to all necessary medical, hospital and related services and proposed a national healthinsurance program to be tied to Social Security. But his plan was too radical to receive serious consideration by the Congress. It aroused hysterical opposition from the medical establishment and was widely regarded as socialistic, even though Truman insisted that what I am recommending is not socialized medicine.

description: To the Editor:

title: What has America been up to since World War II?; The Imperial Republic; The United States and the World 19451973. By Raymond Aron. Translated by Frank Jellinek. 339 pp. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice Hall. $10.
description: Raymond Aron is an institution in France. The holder of one of his country's most distinguished professorships and the author of notable books on philosophy, intellectual history, sociology, political science and the theory of international relations, he is also a formidable commentator on current events whose columns in the newspaper Le Figaro exercise considerable influence on educated opinion. A judicious and informed observer of the United States, Aron's appraisal of America's relation to the rest of the world over the last 25 years is bound to be read with high expectations. The Imperial Republic than fulfills them.

title: Louise Steiner Fiancee of James Greilsheimer
description: Louise B. Steiner, deputy director of the Office of Educational Development of the city's Human Resources Administration, plans to he married next month to James G. Greilsheimer, litigating assistant New York corporation counsel.

title: Virginia B. Carrick, an Editor, Is Wed to Willis Kingsley Wing
description: Virginia Brewster Carrick of New York and Willis Kingsley Wing of New York and Falls Village, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon in the presence of relatives and close friends at the home of the bride's son and daughterinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce R. Carrick in Mount Kisco, N. Y., by the Rev. Albert Ciarcia, a Unitarian minister from Stratford, Conn.

title: What's Doing in ALASKA
description: THE TALK OF THE 49th STATE It's all about oil, and the 79milelong TransAlaska , Pipeline that will carry the black gold from Prudhoe Bay on the Arctic Ocean to Valdez on the Gulf of Alaska, east of Anchorage. But even as conservation groups debate what effect the discovery of oil will have on the fragile environment of America's last frontier, Alaskans assert their own position by sporting bumper stickers with slogans such as We Don't Give A Damn How They Do It Outside and Sierra Club Go Home. A new batch of stickers currently gracing cars in Anchorage is addressed to critics of the pipeline. The slogan: Let The Bastards Freeze In The Dark. But aside from the stickers, there is real concern on all sides as to the impact the oil pipeline will have on Alaska. Construction is scheduled to get under way next year.

title: Eads Bridge Engineering Miracle and Work of Art
Hempstead Says Plan For Housing Is in Peril
description: Hempstead Town will not build the controversial 75 units of scattersite housing it promised to construct more than 18 months ago, unless Federal funds for the project are increased significantly.

title: Badger Five Wins
description: KYOTO. Japan, July 20 (AP)The University of Wisconsin basketball team, led by Dale Koehler's 22 points, coasted to a 7764 victory over a team of Japanese allstars tonight.

title: Peace on Cyprus Has Been a Sometime Thing
description: ATHENSFor an island about half kg big as the State of New Jersey and with a population of 840,000, Cyprus has given the world more than enough problems over the years.

title: U.S. and France Vie for Warplane Market
description: WASHINGTON, July 20A multibilliondollar competition is being waged between the United States and France over which country will produce new generation of fighter planes for the Western European allies,

Julie Sage Is Wed to Jerome Corbin Day
description: Julie Sage, a research assistant and doctoral candidate in biopsychology at Hunter College of the City University, was married yesterday to Jerome Corbin Day. The Rev. Burton Draesel performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Terraces in Llewellyn Park, West Orange, N. J.

title: In the Tristate Area, Officials Have Plowed Right In
description: Where once there were corn fields, orchards and grazing cattle, there now are housing developments, gas stations and shopping centers. The tranformation Is called suburbanization, which has grown rapidly in the nation in general and in the New York metropolitan.region in particular over the last two decades.

title: Miss Donovan Bride of Marvin Manheim
description: Margaret Mary Donovan, a teacher in the Somerville, Mass., school system, was married last evening in Cambridge, Mass., to Marvin Lee Manheim, professor of transportation systems at the Massachusetts institute of Technology. Rabbi Samuel Umen performed the ceremony in the M.I.T. Chapel.

title: Nonevent at the Museum of Modern Art: Graphics Show on A Specious Theme
description: AFINANCIAL crunch in recent years has been forcing museums throughout America to cut back on big loan exhibitions and to make more ingenious use of their permanent collections. The Museum of Modem Art, once the site of seemingly nonstop art extravaganzas, has been especially hampered by money problems. At the same time, with the richest collection of modern art in the world, the Modern has been well fixed to maintain a regular program of interesting shows while weathering the crisis.This situation has given prominence to a type of show that might be called the curatorial tour de force, meaning an exhibition based on some common characteristic of an otherwise heterogeneous group of works. A choice example of the type was the Modern's recent Printed in Germany, 1923, a selection of graphics defined by the title; more vividly than any arthistorical essay, it gave one a glimpse of an epoch. A more dubious example is Printed, Cut, Folded and Torn, a current show in the museum's thirdfloor Sachs Galleries.

title: Mrs. Kennedy's Views On Nixon Achievement
description: HYANNISPORT, Mass., July 20 (AP)  Rose Kennedy mother of the late President Kennedy, says President Nixon did well to reach the White House without advantages of a powerful family.

title: Two Formidable Female Stars
description: IN For Pete's Sake, Barbra Streisand plays a Brooklyn taxi driver's nutty wife who gets hopelessly involved, in succession, with the Mafia, with a call girl operation and with a gang of urban cattle rustlers as she desperately tries to raise enough money to send her husband (Michael Sarrazin) back to college. It's true that it's ultimately Sarrazin who has to bail Barbra out of Jail but until that moment, it's been her picture all the way.

title: Betsy Buchanan Is Bride
description: Betsy Kern Buchanan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cooper Buchanan of Valley Forge, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. William Davis Fishback Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fishback of Versailles, Ky, The Rev. Frederick P. Gehring performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Comforter in Charlottesville, Va., where there was a reception at 43oar's Head Inn.

description: Fiction

title: MRS. THROOP M. WILDER
description: Mrs. Throop M. Wilder, who in her youth appeared as a violinist with the Buffalo Symphony Orchestra, died Friday at her home, 129 East 69th Street. She was 86 years old. ,

title: What the Energy Crisis Taught Auto Makers
description: DETROITWith the energy crisis behind them, the auto makers are pondering the lessons of a turbulent year as they change over to the production of 1975 models, They feel somewhat like a sea captain who has guided his ship through a severe stormthey are less complacent and have learned a few things but are proud that they steered a steady course without panicking.

title: P.U.C. to Hear Plea By Bardin on Rates
description: TRENTON  Tile State Commissioner of Environmental Protection, David, J. Bardin, will urge the State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners tomorrow to shift the burden of gas and electric rates from small users to large consumers, a reversal of present policy.

title: Pop Music: Bowie Puts on Lavish Show at Garden
description: David Bowie (or just Bowie, as he prefers to be known now) has been attacked with an uncommon, even hysterical fervor in certain sections of the rock press for his latest album, Diamond Dogs. Because I hardly found the disk all that offensive, and because one purpose of rock n roll is to outrage, there was every reason to approach his live show Friday night at Madison Square Garden with whetted expectations.

title: Air Force SR71 to Seek TransAtlantic Speed Mark
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) The Air Force's 2,000mileanhour SR71 strategic reconnaissance plane will attempt new transAtlantic speed record between New York and London in September.

title: REINECKES MOTION FOR MISTRIAL FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, July 20. (UPI)  Judge Barrington Parker denied today mistrial motions sought by lawyers for 1 cut, Gov. Ed Reinecke of California and ruled out calling nine witnesses for Mr. Reinecke's defense against charges that he lied to a Senate committee.Judge Parker said he would decide a companion motion In dismiss the charges when the trial resumes Monday.Mr. Reinecke is charged with lying to the Senate Judiciary Committee about when he first told John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, of a $400,000 offer by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to finance the 1972 Republican National Convention,Mr. Reinecke's lawyer. James F.. Cox, argued for dismissal on the ground that Mr. Reinecke had not been adequately advised of his rights during an interview with Government lawyers. He also said the transcripts of his client's Senate testimony were faulty.

title: Tape Reveals New Kind of White House

DiPaola is expected to rule within the week on the Village of Hempstead School Board's request for a permanent injunction barring the village from taking further steps to construct a firehouse on Jerusalem Avenue, across from the Ludlum Elementary School.

description: VIENTIANEThe Chinese came last. By the time they got there, cardiologists from the United States, Thailand, France and the Soviet Union were already huddling around the bedside of Prince Souvanna Phouma, the 72yearold Premier of Laos, who had been stricken by a heart attack.

title: Future Events
description: July 26Since there's no rain date, it's bound to be fair weather at the 79th Ladies Village Improvement Society fair in East Hampton at the 17thcentury Mulford Farm, which overlooks the village green. Its a 12hour affair, starting at 10 A.M. There are 16 attractions for children. They may swing across an authentic jungle rope bridge or, if they can be still long enough, have their faces made up as cats, clowns or flowers. Adult browsers can meander through the textile, bargainbox flower, recycled toy on so on booths, and everyone can go for a hayride. The Fine Fair luncheon of offerings by local gourmets (salads, sandwiches, wickedly caloric desserts) will be served from 11:30 A.M. through teatime. The West SayvilleOakdale Spirit of 76 Ancient Fife and Drum Corps and the East Hampton Summer Band will take care of the music. There'll be a barbeque (adults, $5.50; children, $3) from six o'clock to eight and free square dancing from 7 P.M. to closing. Out of all that you ought to find something to improve your day. Mrs. William parr is chairman.

title: The Seventh Hero
description: This book is both more important and more rigorously difficult than any study of Thomas Carlyle would seem to have the right to be. But then Carlyle, the famously dour Victorian sage, is its occasion rather than its object. Its object is to get Carlyle to help us revolutionize our own society. As Carlyle struggled against the newly urbanized, commercialized, industrialized culture of England, so Philip Rosenberg, respectfully standing on Carlyle's shoulders (with all the awkwardness such a stance implies), struggles against that culture, fully developed in America.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Garth and Squier
description: It was David ,Garth's job to help find the real Hugh L. Carey, the tough Brooklyn, Congressman behind that jowly fellow with the Prince Valiant hair around his ear lobes who was talking in platitudes before the cameras on the WCBSTV Newsmakers show.

title: Green Line in Nicosia: Oil Drums, Guns and Hate
description: For 10 years, with the United Nations peacekeeping force separating them, the armed forces of the Turkish minority and the Greek majority on Cyprus have faced each other across an arbitraryand changingline d'alled the Green Line.

title: CrimeFighting as Part of Curricula
description: Last year, the New York City Police received close to 11,000 complaints of crimes on public school property. They ranged from murder, rape and robbery to false bomb reports. The New York City school system, which only recently began tabulating what it calls incidents, recorded almost 5,000 for the 197374 school year.

title: Recordings
description: BEETHOVEN could hardly have foreseen the consequences of his Ninth Symphony and its unprecedented choral finale. The work sent shock waves up and down the nineteenth century as other composers struggled to reinterpret the implications of Beethoven's synthesis of orchestra, voices and an ethical message. Conservative critics of the time viewed such a momentous expansion of musical esthetics and grammar with alarm. For Eduard Hanslick, the Missa Solemnis and the Ninth colossal Pillars of Hercules at the gates of modern music saying No farther!' To another anonymous writer, all of late Beethoven was simply that muddy well from whence, all our present troubles spring,

title: Frontier Justice: A RunIn With the Law
description: O AK CREEK CANYON is one of the natural wonders of the Southwest. Carved out of brilliant red rock, it runs 13 miles along a delightful clear stream meandering through treelined campgrounds along the canyon bottom. The canyon is in the Coconino National Forest, south of Flagstaff, Ariz., and is a popular spot for vacationers. The place is almost idyllic, except for two drawbacks: It is crowded; and it is inhabited by an extremely dangerous local speciesthe Arizona highway patrolman.

For the people who gave you the Renaissance, making pretty dresses in the face of galloping inflation and national bankruptcy is no impossible feat.

title: Cyprus: Test of Detente
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 In the Moscow summit meeting of May, 1972, the United States and the Soviet Union agreed to work together to reduce tension and prevent wars in critical areas of the world, and they perfected a system of instantaneous communications for this purpose. The socalled hotline to the Kremlin has been in constant use since the Turkish invasion of Cyprus, which is regarded here as a test of the policy of detente.

title: LOS ANGELES BANS NUDES AT BEACHES
description: LOS ANGELES, July 20The city of Los Angeles, responding to a wave of angry public sentiment, this week adopted a ban on public nudity in all area beaches, parks and playgrounds.

As a result, there will be little easing of the financial burdens on consumer countries.

Homer Duncan of Pryor, Okla., and the late Mr. Duncan. The Rev. Joseph E. MacGinnis performed the ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church, Huntington, L. I.

title: In Laos
description: YOU'VE heard about it. Now go see it! With that somewhat grotesque slogan, the South Vietnamese Government is seeking to woo tourists to its warravaged land, There is, however, a nation in Indochina that can offer the iracationer something Vietnam doesn't possess: peace. In this part of the world, peace is apt to be a tenuous state; as this was written, the ill health of the Laotian Premier was a crisis within the present coalition Government. But the tourists have again begun flocking to Laos; the traditional lures are substantial.

title: Mrs. Sheahan Has Child

Mrs. Sheahan, a former schoolteacher and a secretary at the White House during the Johnson Administration, is the former Anne F. Curran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Curran of Lake Oswego, Ore. The child, the couple's second, is named Sara Ames. Her father is director of management relations with U.S. Industries, Inc.

description: CRANFORD  Dr. Saul Orkin, who has been dean of Somerset County College since. 1967, was installed yesterday as president of Union College.

title: Criminals At Large
description: When the American writer, James Jones, turned to the detective story, it was only natural that he should adopt the conventions (and clichs) of that particularly American genre, the privateeye novel. And now when the British writer, Colin Wilson, turns to the mystery story, it is equally natural that he should adopt the conventions (and clichs) of that particularly British genre the procedural out of Scotland Yard. Wilson is planning a series of 12 books centered on the exploits of Chief Superintendent Saltfeet of Scotland Yard. The first is THE SCHOOLGIRL MURDER CASE (Crown, $5.95). Even the title

title: American League Flashes Urgent Sigh to AllStars
description: Baseball will stage its 45th AllStar Game on Tuesday in Pittsburgh with a new sense of urgency beneath the glitter: The American League', which has lost 10 of the last 11 games to the National League, has enlisted its 12 teams to an official policy of winning at almost any cost.

title: Text of U.N.'s Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. V., July 20Following is the text of a resolution on Cyprus passed unanimously today in the Security Council:

title: J. MURRAY DOWNEY
description: J. Murray Downey, who retired recently as executive vice president of C. & C. Trucking Company, which operates over a threestate area out of North Tarrytown, N. Y., died yesterday at his home, 21 Kingsland Road. He was 62 years old.

title: Can She Be a Ralph Nader on TV?
description: ER name became a household word as a result of countless television commercials between 1949 and 1960 in which she repeatedly opened refrigerator doors and assured the nation's TV viewers that they could be sure if it's Westinghouse. She made lot i of money at it and became thoroughly identified with the product she was selling, a veritable Miss Westinghouse. Then she left the business world for public affairs and a new career as a crusading consumer advocate, working first for a President (Johnson), and then a Governor (Rockefeller), and then a Mayor (Lindsay).

title: Camera World
description: ATOUR to a number of major photographic collections in Europe will be conducted by the International Museum of Photography at George Eastman House in Rochester, N.Y. from Sept. 15 to Sept. 30. Stops will be made in London, Paris, Munich, Salzburg and Cologne, and there will be visits to the Kodak Museum at Harrow, Lacock Ab. bey. Four days will be spent in London and en equal length of time in Paris.

title: The paintings are outliving their subjects

description: The director of the Office of Economic Opportunity, Alvin J. Arnett, has been discharged by President Nixon, apparently for resisting the President's plans for killing the anti; poverty agency.

title: Five Sets of Articles On Impeachment Listed
description: WASHINGTON, July 20The 306page Summary of Information presented to the House Judiciary Committee by its legal staff is intended to reinforce charges contained in five separate sets of proposed articles of impeachment before the panel.

title: Gurney Weighs Withdrawal
description: COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 20 (AP)Senator Edward Gurney, Republican of Florida, said today he would decide next week whether to withdraw from the Republican Senatorial primary in the wake of a Federal grand jury indictment. Earlier this month, a Federal grand jury in Jacksonville indicted Mr. Gurney, 60 years old, on conspiracy, bribery and perjury charges in connection with a $233,000 fund collected from builders reportedly seeking influence with the Federal Housing Administration.

title: B'nai B'rith Unit Finds U.S. at Fault On College Quotas
description: The AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith charged last week that the Federal Government had failed to take action against preferential treatment and quota systems in college admissions and hirings despite a prohibition against such treatment in the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Gonzales Retains Flyweight Crown
description: LIGNANO SABBIADORO, Italy, July 20 (UPI)Betulio Gonzales of Venezuela retained his World Boxing Council flyweight title today on a 10thround technical knockout over Franco UdeIla of Italy.

title: Youths Relive Life of indian
description: STONY BROOK  Evan Warner was having trouble starting a fire. The sparks that were supposed to fly when he briskly moved a twig up and down a branch refused to appear, let alone fly. Dried leaves lay around the branch waiting to be ignited.

title: DEMOCRATS DRIVE FOR OREGON POSTS

title: Art
description: LESS than two years hencein February, 1976we shall be observing the 100th anniversary of the birth of Constantin Brancusi. Anyone familiar with the old literature on this great sculptor would, until a few years ago, have had ample reason to dread the occasion. It is in the nature of anniversaries to inspire pious rhetoric, and Brancusi's life and work have long been the victims of some of the silliest I and most solemn pieties ever lavished on an artistic career. The man was iievated to the status of a legendary peasantsaintmysticmonk who had somehow managed to pass a lifetime In the French capitalwhen it was also the capital of the international avantgardewithout being in any way touched by its cosmopolitan culture or its sophisticated pleasures. His work was treated as if it were some barely material manifestation of a spiritual archetype. An aura of the ineffable enclosed every object and every event associated with his name. It was all fiction, of course, and no less of a fiction because Brancusi himself had been

title: Rags But No Tatters
description: July 28The sixth annual Newport Music Festival (July,,25 through Aug. 3) is coming up and, as has become the custom, its patrons gala will be held in the dazzling Great Hall of the Breakers, the notexactly humble cottage built in 1895 by Cornelius Vanderbilt, Commodore Vanderbilt's grandson. Patrons may be defined as those Who have ponied up a minimum of $100 to support the festival, which is sponsored by the Rhode Island Arts Foundation. Every gala must have a namethis one's is From Rags to Riches. Actually, the Horatio Alger story is that of ragtime, which has been admitted into the establishment of acknowledged art forms. What better proof is there than that the New England Conservatory Ragtime Ensemble, conducted by the conservatory's president, will provide the evening's entertainment? From its Southland origins ragtime surfaced in New York in 1897, when it became the darling of music publishers whose sales climbed sharply. But two other Newport cottagers, Mrs. Stuyvesant Fish and Mrs. Hermann Oelrichs, gave it cachet when they turned their formidable thumbs up on the dancing of Vernon and Irene Castle. Guests have been encouraged to wear ragtime attire, and after the concert Countess Anthony Szapary, whose grandfather was Cornelius Vanderbilt, along with other members of the foundation, will be hosts at a champagne reception and buffet.

title: Panel Offers New Harbor Safety Plan

The system would establish 34 potential harbor trouble zones and would ask vessels to make voluntary safety broad:casts by reporting their positions whenever they pass any of them.

In Rome, an outdoor performance of Turandot was canceled at the last minute, and disappointed tourists were turned away. The nearly bankrupt Eternal City couldn't afford to pay the cast.

Gardens

In fact, Miss Stout maintains that she hasn't eaten a vegetable she hasn't grown in at least 30 to 40 years, except when I go out to dinner, and then they just don't taste as good.

title: AGED LIVE BETTER INPOORER NATIONS

title: Ideas &
description: Leading molecular biologists have called upon their fellow scientists to defer a line of pure research because its potential hazards may outweigh its possible benefits.

title: Making Tracks
description: The French Line has made one of the more melancholy announcements of the summerthat its great passenger liner, the France, will be withdrawn from service after Oct. 25. A veteran of several transAtlantic crossings in the France can hardly help wondering why something couldn't be done to preserve this leisurely and civilized means of travel. Must everything be sacrificed to speed and efficiency?

title: Assessment Shift Barred
description: BOSTON, July 20 (AP)The Massachusetts Senate Thursday rejected legislation to force cities and towns to assess all property at 100 per cent of its fair market value. A similar measure was rejected by the House earlier.

title: ... In Egypt
description: IAM standing on a street corner in Cairo, watching traffic whiz by on the approach to El Tahrir Bridge, one of the main crossovers of the Nile. The carsboxy, locally assembled Fiatsmove at 60 miles an hour, and there are no stop lights. In the center of the broad avenue on this, particular evening stands a small band of paralyzed pedestrians, waiting for a gap in the traffic. I have just about convinced myself that the only way I'm going to make it across is in a taxi or a coffin whep a short, bearded man standing next to me turns and smiles. French? he asks. Italian? English? When tell him that I'm an American, he takes a step backward, throws his arms out in an expansive gesture and cries, Welcome, welcome! in a voice that causes heads to turn all along the sidewalk.

title: Dance
description: LONDONIT WAS in London that Ballet made its first excursion to the West. The date was September 14, 1956 and the place was the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. The ballet was the Leonid Lavrovsky/Serge Prokofiev Romeo and Juliet, and the dancers were the then still ageless Galina Ulanova and her partner, Yuri, Zhandhov. But it was a company of allstars, Sergei Koren was the Mercutio, Alexander.Lapa,uri the Paris, Konstantin Richter was ,the Tybalt, Alexander Radasky and Yelena Ilyushchenko were the CapWets, lraida Olenina was the Nurse, and Georgy Farman, yants the Jester. Even the second cast had Raissa Struchkova and Yuri Hoffman as the starcross'd lovers. It was quite a company. On April 16, 1959, with the same ballet and virtually the same cast, the Bolshoi made its North American debut at the old Metropolitan Opera

title: Laura/Flora of Lark Rise
description: Recently, my parents found a copy of the letter I sent my childhood heroine, Laura Ingalls Wilder, and her short, spidery acknowledgment. The year she died I told her how much my mother and I loved the stories of her childhood on the American frontier in the 1870's and 80's.

title: Fashion
description: The biggest news in fashion for fall is the very bigness of fashion.The skinny, tightshouldered clothes of seasons past are as pass as streaking. Big shirts are leading off the look right now. Cotton smocks are bikinitoppers for now; tweedy big shirts (with the lines of the French peasant smock) ward off ocean and mountain chills, and Russian cossack shirts provide nighttime elegance.

title: History with inventions; John Come Down the Backstay; By Caroline Tapley. Illustrated by Richard Cuffuri. 182 pp. New York: Atheneum. $6.25. (Ages 10 to 15)
description: In 1845 Sir John Franklin sailed for the Arctic with two small ships Erebus and Terror in search of the Northwest Passage. Its eastern approaches, or what were thought to be its approaches, had been discovered already and the continental shore charted westward to Bering Strait. Sir John's mission was to sail an unknown stretch of sea and ice for some three hundred miles, thus to prove that the longsought passage did really exist.
