description: WASHINGTON, July 25The Supreme Court raised major hurdles to merging city and suburban schools for racial integration today by all but banning the busing of children across school district lines for desegregation.

title: Court Directs Bergen to Stop Landfill Operations in Overpeck
description: HACKENSACK, July 25A judge in State Superior Court today issued a temporary order directing Bergen County to terminate all landfill operations in Overpeck Park in Ridgefield !Park Township by next Jan. 1.

title: MINORITY JOB PLAN FOR CITY PROJECTS UPHELD BY COURT
description: A controversial plan designed to provide black workers with thousands of jobs on city construction projects was approved here yesterday by Judge Morris E. Lasker in Federal District Court.

title: Business Briefs
description: House Rebuffs Patman on Bank Issues

title: CYPRUS CABLE LINKS ARE REPORTED OPEN
description: NICOSIA, July 25 (UPI)The new Government of Cyprus said it would restore cable communications today but not telephone and telex communications, the Cypriote radio said.

title: DR. MAX LEVIN DIES; NEUROPSYCHIATRIST
description: Dr. Max Levin, former neurologist at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals and clinical professor of neurology at New York Medical College, died here Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 73 years old and lived at 350 Central Park West.

title: New Jersey Tax Fiasco
No American Rush to Gold Seen
description: WASHINGTON, July 25In the first public analysis of its ;kind, a high Treasury official expressed strong doubt today that permission for Americans to own gold, which is likely before the end of this year, would significantly increase demand.

title: Beanie Signs Bill on Listing Of Civil Service Job News
description: Mayor Beanie yesterday signed a bill requiring that all Civil Service appointments, dismissals and salary changes be published in The ciest Record so that information about city jobs will be readily avail. able to the public.

title: DISMISSED TEACHER SUES COLLEGE ON JOB
description: TRENTON, July 25 (AP)Patricia Endress, who was dismissed as an assistant professor of journalism at Brookdale Community College in Lincroft after the student newspaper published conflictofinterest charges against the college's board chairman, ha filed suit to be reinstated.

title: It's True, a Genuinely Good Meal for About $10 a Person
description: Common sense and disastrous experience elsewhere tell me that you can't get a meal as good as the one had the other night at Purbani, a new Indian restaurant, for $10 a person, but arithmetic verifies the figure.

title: Burns Foresees Resignation
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July, 26 (AP)  James McGregor Burns, the political scientist, said today that he thought President Nixon might resign if the House voted heavily for impeachment.

title: Lottery Numbers
One Frank Hogan on Another
description: When you get to New York, m'boy get into politics! You'll make a fortune at it. They've got a district attorney down there with the same name as yours, Frank Hogan. Run against him And they'll pay you to get your name off the ballot. You've got a brilliant career ahead of you in politics, m'boy, as a nuisance candidate! That was my politicianfather's advice to me when I left home in Cambridge, Mass., some 25 years ago.

title: Suspect Shot, 3 Officers Killed in Oklahoma Battles
description: DEWAR, Okla., July (UPI).Pledging that he would shoot the first policeman who stopped him for speeding through a town, a man killed three officers last night and was wounded in an exchange of gunfire at his grandfather's house.

title: Jackson Registers a Panel To Handle 76 Campaign Aid
description: SEATTLE, July 26 (AP)Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, has taken the first formal step for a possible campaign for the 1976 Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: Soviet to Purchase Market Bloc's Beef
description: PARIS, July 26The Soviet Union is preparing to buy 50,000 tons of surplus Common Market beef at distresslevel prices in a deal that dramatizes the costs European taxpayers have to bear to support the farm population.

title: SPECIAL HANDLING OF NIXON PENALTY CONCEDED BY I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has conceded that he handlerl, fax penalties against Presltlent Nixon differently than the agency normally would for other taxpayers.

title: Beame Puts Off 2 Environmental Bills
description: Mayor Beame postponed action yesterday on one bill that would raise the permissible noise level of automobile horns in the city and on another bill that would ban smoking in passenger elevators. The Mayor has until! Aug. 10 to veto or sign them.

title: Fruit Supply and Prices Good in City
description: The season for fresh fruit in full swing, and quality merchandise at moderate to low prices is in good supply fruit stands throughout the city.

title: Kalmbach Told Panel of a Talk With Dr. Farkas
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI),  The woman who became United States Ambassador to Luxembourg was quoted as suggesting in evidence released to day by the House Judiciary Committee that a $250,000 campaign contribution was to much to pay for appointment as Ambassador to Costa Rica.

title: Many Blacks Voice Faith On Schools
description: DETROIT, July 26Busing is O.K., Mrs, Betty Green, four of whose children go to public schools in Detroit, said today, but if you're close to your school, and they're doing the job, there's no point in busing. And the schools here are trying to do the job.

title: The Malraux View of Europe: The Last of the Great Myths
description: The following remarks are excerpted from a radio interview with Andre Malraux, the French novelist, critic, historian and friend of Charles de Gaulle. The translation is by the Paris bureau of The New York Times.

title: Rodriguez Leads Golf With 63131
Contract Awards
description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology received an $85.8million addition to a previously awarded Air Force contract for research and development in fiscal 1975 and for operation of Lincoln Laboratory at the L. G. Hanscom Field, Lexington, Mass.

title: Royal Ascot N. Takes
description: YONKERS, July 26The nostalgia note at the Yonkers Raceway meeting continued tonight with the reproduction of the Whirlwind Trio. This race was the feature event on the program of Sept. 6, 1899, when horse racing was held for the first time at the present site.

title: Alexander Assails Javits as Ineffective
description: Mayor Lee Alexander of Syracuse, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, believes that he and the Republican incumbent Senator Jacob K. Javits, agree on most issues, but he questions Mr. Javits's effectiveness as a Senator.

title: Leftists Included As Greek Premier Completes Cabinet
description: ATHENS, July 26Premier Constantine Caramanlis completed his new civilian Cabinet today, including several men who had been imprisoned during the seven years of military rule.

title: WINE TALK
description: It has been said before and. it will be said again: the kindly old wine merchant with only your best interests at heart is a character out of Dickens. That is, fictional.

title: Morse Funeral Held in Oregon; McCarthy, Hatfield Praise Him
description: SALEM, Ore., July 26Political and labor leaders paid tribute today to former Senator Wayne Morse at a.funeral in the House of Representatives here.

title: Irate Deputies Question Saigon Premier
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 27  Premier Tran Thien Khiem and 12 of his Cabinet members appeared in the House of Representatives yesterday for an extraordinary marathon session of questioning on controversial national issues.

title: Seaver Shuts Out Cardinals
CLAIRE POTTER
description: Claire Potter of Claire & Walson, interior decorators at 37 West 57th Street, died here Wednesday. She was 82 years old and lived at 7 West 77th Street.

title: NIXON IS CONFIDENT, PRESS AIDE ASSERTS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 26 (UPI)President Nixon is confident that he will be vindicated when the full House of Representatives considers the articles of impeachment the Judiciary Committee has written against him, a White House spokesman said today.

title: AMEX PRICES SLIP IN LIGHT TRADING
St. Clair Agrees to Begin Yielding Tapeson Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, July 26Under pressure from Federal Judge John J. Sirica, President Nixon's chief defense lawyer tentatively agreed today to begin turning over the subpoenaed records of 64 White House conversations by next Tuesday afternoon.

title: Transit Awakening
description: In rapid succession this week, the House Rules Committee voted to send to the floor an $800million, oneyear emergency transit operating aid bill that it had kept bottled up since March; the House Public Works Committee, ending months of procrastination, reported $20billion, sixyear measure that would provide both operating and capital assistance for mass transportation.

title: BRITISH EFFORTS AVERT COLLAPSE OF CYPRUS TALKS
description: GENEVA, Saturday, July 27A breakdown in the threepow er conference on Cyprus was averted last night when, at the urging of the British, Turkey came up with a package proposal that Greece agreed to discuss with her this morning.

title: 1972 Nixon Threat To Dismiss Shultz Over I.R.S. Noted
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPDPresident Nixon threatened to dismiss George P. Shultz, former Treasury Secretary, if he tried to stop the White House from using the Internal Revenue Service for political purposes, according to the Washington bureau of the Cox newspapers.

title: MISS FORREST SINGS 30'S AND 40'S SONGS
description: When Helen Forrest was rid ing the crest of the swing era, singing with the bands of Artie Shaw, Benny Goodman and Harry James, she was superb craftsman working in a very limited area. Within single chorus of a pop song, played at a tempo that was chosen for its suitability for dancers or for the instrumentalists in the orchestra but very definitely not in the interests of the singer, she had a rare ability to project shading and meaning and to phrase so that the lyrics seemed to flow gracefull.

title: 6 Die as Military Copter Crashes, in Flames on Coast
description: VALLEJO, Calif., July 26 (AP)At least six persons died today in the fiery crash of military helicopter beside busy Interstate 80, the Alameda Na.Val Air Station reported.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Not one to let the outdoor cooking season go by unnoticed, the H. J. Heinz Com

title: SchoolIntegration Order Here Softened
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, in a final ruling yesterday on the Mark Twain Junior High School desegregation case, pulled back from his earlier order that the city alter Coney Island's housing and social patterns in order to integrate the school.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Called Psychotic by a Psychiatrist
description: NEWARK, July 26 (UPI)A psychiatrist testified today that Jorge Martinez had not realized he was committing a crime last March in the kidnapping of John Calzadilla because he was mentally ill at the time. Mr. Martinez was convicted yesterday with three others of the abduction.

title: A Major Breakthrough for Farm Output Appears Remote in China
description: HONG KONG, July 26China is maintaining a narrow margin of safety in her unending struggle to feed a fifth of the world's population on less than a tenth of the world's cultivated land.

title: Clinton to Be First State Prison Housing Both Men and Women
description: TRENTON, July 26 (UPI)Male and female inmates will be confined in the same New Jersey prison for the first time in the state's history starting next month, officials revealed today, but they declined to describe the arrangement as coed.

title: Court Puts a Limit on Picketing for Game Today
description: CANTON, Ohio, July 26 The Hall of Fame game between the Buffalo Bills and St. Louis Cardinals will be played here tomorrow afternoon under a court injunction, on a different television , network, with new rules changes and with four quarterbacks who have never thrown a pass in the National Football League.

title: PROFITS IN HALFOFF FOR BARCLAYS BANK
description: LONDON, July 27 ,(AP)Barclay's Bank, Ltd., one of Britain's major clearing banks, repotted a drop in profits for the first half of 1974, surprising some experts here.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, July 26"Girls are easier to teach than.boys. That's the opinion of Frank Martelli, the resident director of the Princeton Hills Golf Academy, which is located at the Lawrenceville School.

title: 5 TeenAgers Held For Robbing Youths On a Subway Train
description: Five teenagers were arrested yesterday afternoon when they beat and robbed several other teenagers in a Manhattan subway station and then continued their rampage aboard a train bound for Brboklyn, where a policeman seized them, the Transit Authority police reported.

title: 7 FARM WORKERS ARE QUESTIONED
description: NEWARK, July 26 (UPI) Seven migrant workers suspected of involvement in an attack on four persons, including State Assemblyman whose arm was broken, were called before the United States Attorney today for questioning prior to grandjury appearance.

title: NIXON IS CONFIDENT, PRESS AIDE ASSERTS
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif July 26 (UPI)President Nixon is confident that he will be vindicated when the.full House of Representatives considers the articles of impeachment the Judiciary Committee has written against him, a White House spokesman said today.

title: Nixon Signs a Bill For Cattle Credit
description: SAN CLEMENTE, July 26 (UPI)President Nixon signed today a bill to provide a $2billion temporary credit guarantee to prevent hardpressed cattle and hog producers from bankruptcy.

title: Philadelphia Fire Kills 4
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP), Three children and a teenager were killed and six persons injured today when a fire swept through a North Philadelphia row house. The police identified the four dead as Adrian Rew,i 10 years old; Otis Bradley Jr., 3; Omar Bradley, 18 months, and Clarissa Gardner, 15, a baby sitter.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Montreal Expos, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 9, 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 8 P.M.)

title: People in Sports
description: In a major shakeup, the Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association yesterdayannounced that Mel Daniels and Freddie Lewis had been traded to the Memphis Sounds for Charlie Edge and a substantial amount of cash.

title: Car Part Maker Stayed to Hold Skilled Force
description: Five years ago, John Wenzel, president of the Ideal Corporation, and Phillip Rauch, chairman and son of the company's founder, decided to build a new plant in Brooklyn to consolidate and make more efficient the manufacturing operations the concern then was carrying on in four different locations in the borough.

title: Schoolintegration Order Here Softened
description: Federal Judge Jack B. Weinstein, in a final ruling yesterday on the Mark Twain Junior High School desegregation case, pulled back from his earlier order that the city alter Coney Island's housing and social patterns in order to integrate the school.

title: BRITISH EFFORTS AVERT COLLAPSE OF CYPRUS TALKS
description: GENEVA, July 27A breakdown in the threepower con ference on Cyprus was averted last night when, at the urging of the British, Turkey came up with a package proposal that Greece agreed to discuss with her this morning.

title: Call for Mr. Rickey
description: The Atlanta Braves have a new manager. So do the Chicago Cubs. Earlier this season the San Francisco Giants changed managers and so did the California Angels. There is one thing that most newly hired managers of baseball teams have in common  they've managed somewhere else in the past and have been fired. And, there is something that all the freshly minted 1974 managers have with all the other men who have held such jobs over the whole history of the game: all of them are white.

title: Kalmbach Told Panel of a Talk With Dr. Farkas
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)1  The woman who became United States Ambassador to Luxembourg was quoted as suggesting in evidence released today by the House Judiciary Committee that a $250,000 campaign contribution was too much to pay for appointment as Ambassador to Costa Rica.

title: French Atom Test In Pacific Reported By New Zealand
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 26 (UPI)France apparently exploded another nuclear device at its testing grounds in the South Pacific today.

title: Excerpts From Panel's Evidence on Nixon's Income Tax Deductions and Audit
Bomb Blast Wrecks Car At London Airport Garage
description: LONDON, July 26 (UPI)A bomb exploded in a multilevel automobile parking garage at Heathrow Airport today damaging several cars and causing hundreds of travelers to miss their flights in the confusion that followed. Scotland Yard said there were no injuries.

title: People and Business
description: President Nixon's surpris ing espousal of jawboning in Thursday night's economic address might reflect the advice of his newest adviser. Alan Greenspan, whom the President nominated this week to be next chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, is a fierce opponent of, rigid wageprice controls.

title: Arthur Watson of IBM, ExEnvoy, Dies
description: Arthur K. Watson, who built the IBM World Trade Corporation from a new subsidiary of the giant International Business Machines Corporation in 1949 into a world enterprise with annual revenues of more than $2.5billion in 1970, died last evening in Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Elliman Said to Offer RCA $20Million for Cushman
description: The RCA Corporation has entered negotiations to divest itself of Cushman & Wakefield, lInc., one of the country's largest commercial real estate maniagement and leasing concerns.

title: Less Oil on the Waters
description: For several days recently beaches along a 24mile stretch of Long Island Sound were coated with fuel oil, accidentally discharged in a tankertobarge operation off Port Jefferson. A few days earlier a smaller spill the same area sent oil into beautiful wetlands of and seep Sinai to leave a black slick on the reed grasses and seep into the marshy soil.

title: Fire on the Enterprise
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., July 26 (UPI)A fire broke out in ant electronic maintenance space) area of the nuclearpowered aircraft carrier Enterprise but no one was hurt, it was reported yesterday.

title: Federal Jury Begins Deliberations on Reinecke Perjury Char
description: WASHINGTON, July 26  A United States District Court jury began its deliberations today in the perjury trial of Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke,of California.

title: Vernon B. Stouffer Dies at 72; President of Restaurant Chain
description: CLEVELAND, July 26 (UN) Vernon B. Stouffer, former owner of the Cleveland Indians and president of the Stouffer Corporation, died of a heart attack tonight at St. Vincent Charity Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in suburban Lakewood.

title: Recall of U.S. Envoy to Athens Is Urged
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Representative Wayne L. Hays said tonight he had urged the Nixon Administration to recall Ambassador Henry J. Tasca from Athens as soon as possible because he was tainted with the dictatorship in Greece even if he was innocent of mismanagement.

title: Citibank Prime Kept at 12 %
description: The First National City Bank, New York, kept its prime lending rate at 12 per cent yesterday, although its formula for calculating that level stood at 12.5 per cent. Last Wednesday, the bank's parent company, Citicorp, successfully raised $650million on floatingrate notes, it was noted, and much of the proceeds will be used to repay its shortterm debts.

title: Inco Defends Its Tender Offer for ESB
description: The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., denied yesterday that Reacquisition of ESB, Inc., common stock would have anticompetitive effects and said that it would vigorously defend the antitrust action Instituted by ESB in Philadelphia on Thursday. The suit filed in Federal District Court alleged that Inco, which has raised its bid for ESB from $28 a share to $41 a share during the week ended yesterday, would be violating Federal antitrust laws if it acquired ESB.

title: A. KING AITKIN
description: A. King Aitkin, an advertising man, died, in. Westport, Conn., on Monday. He was 87 years old.

title: Dr. John Ribble Marries Anne B. Strate
description: Anne Blythe Strate, widow of Gordon A. Strate, was married here yesterday to Dr. John Ribble, associate dean of the Cornell University Medical College. The ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity was performed by the Rev. Clarke K. Oler.

title: Russians Told for First Time That Nixon Faces Impeachment
description: MOSCOW, July 26In three paragraphs inconspicuously displayed on page five of the Communist party newspaper Pravda, the Soviet public was openly informed today for the first time that President Nixon could be removed from office.

title: Masiello Gets a Year for Silence, in 2d Brasco Trial
description: Jahn A. Masiello, a reputed Mafia member, was sentenced yesterday to one year in prison for his refusal to testify in the second trial of Representative Frank J. Brasco of Brooklyn.

title: GENE BYRNES, 84, CARTOONIST, DEAD
description: Gene Byrnes, cartoonist and writer, who created the comic strip Reg'lar Fellers, a saga of American boyhood, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 570 Park Avenue.

title: High Adviser Hopes Public Rejects Nixon Savings Idea
description: WASHINGTON, July 26A high Administration economist conceded today that he hoped consumers would not take President Nixon's request in last night's economic address, literally and save an additional 1.5 per cent of their income.

title: St. Clair Agrees to Begin Yielding Tapes on Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON. July 26Under pressure from Federal Judge John J. Sirica, President Nixon's chief defense lawyer tentatively agreed today to begin turning over the subpoenaed records of 64 White Hcuse conversations by next Tuesday afternoon.

title: 2 MtgrantLabor Camps Closed on Filth Charge
description: TRENTON, July 26 (UPI) Two migrantlabor camps in South Jersey were ordered closed by the state today after being charged with operating illegally and keeping laborers in filthy quarters.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Meets at 3 P.M. on the Cyprus issue.

title: Bohack TO SEEK REORGANIZATION
description: The Bohack Corporation, the large 71yearold New York area food chain, announced yesterday that it would file Monday for reorganization under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Law.

title: Construction Unions Call Strike to Press for Jobs
description: TRENTON, July 26Organized labor has scheduled virtual shutdown at construction sites throughout the state Monday as part of a demonstration that it describes as a march for jobs.

title: Security Council Puts Off Meeting Over Cyprus
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 26Cyprus asked today for an emergency meeting of the Security CoUncil on what she described as violations by Turkish forces of the ceasefire on the island, but the council put the session off.

title: Robber Is Shot in the Face By Brooklyn Club Owner
description: A Brooklyn man was shot in the face last night when he attempted to hold up a night club owner at gunpoint, the police said.

title: GOLDIN AND BEAK CLASH OVER AUDIT
description: Controller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday that mis.T eading information from the staff of his predecessor, Abraham D. Beame, had led him to believe that longstanding discrepancies in the city's bank balances had been resolved before he took office.

title: Berton Lewis Weds Miss Hooley
description: LONDON, July 26Wendy Ann Hooley and Berton Bramlette Lewis, both 21yearold actors, were married today at Edwalton Anglican Church in Nottingham, England, by the Rev. Paul Sher

title: Hess and Getty Oil Also Report That Earnings Climb
description: The Atlantic Richfield Corporation, the Amerada Hess Corporation and the Getty Oil Company added their names yesterday to the long list of oil companies reporting soaring profits for the second quarter of 1974.

title: Idealism and Legalism
description: Millions of Americans now have the opportunity watching the operations of the political process in an extraordinary undertaking, the likes of which have been seen only once before in the history of the Republicand then not over television. If the issue under considerationremoval from office of the President of the United Statesis momentous, the precise path to the resolution of that issue is tortuous and, as became clear yesterday, subjective at every point along the way. Human sensitivities, if not frailties, are the substance of politics.

title: Quebec Uranium Plant
description: MONTREAL, July 26 (AP)Canadian and French interests have agreed to begin a study on the feasibility of building a uranium enrichment plant in Quebec, preferably in the James Bay territory, the James Bay Development Corporation announced today.

title: City Record Has New Head.
description: William J. Garry, a 44yearold lawyer and Brooklyn Democrat was sworn in yesterday as director of the City Record, the city's official journal. Mr. Garry will be paid $29,777 year.

title: AbbyDubman Wed To Thomas Hansen
description: Abby Jane Dubman and Thomas S. Hansen, doctoral candidates at Harvard University, were married in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday morning. The Rev.; iierbert Vetter of the First Parish, Unitarian, in Cambridge performed the ceremony in the Appleton Chapel at Harvard.

title: U.S. AGENCY ISSUES WARNING ON LIGHTS
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) The Consumer Product Safety Commission today warned of possible electric shocks from a household light suspected of having cause one death.

title: Spain and U.S. Clash Over Shoe Exports
description: MADRID, July 26Shoes, and what Americans pay for them, have become a major source of contention between Spain and the United States.

title: Brasilia, a Capital City of Striking Architecture, Is Still Lacking Much Warmth
7,535 See Sets Bow to Freedoms
description: UNIONDALE, L,I,, July 26 There has never been any love lost between Virginia Wade and Billie Jean King. The mutual antagonism between these two powerful players has been adopted by their respective World Team Tennis teams the New York Sets and the Philadelphia Freedoms.

title: U.S. TIE SEEN NEAR WITH EAST GERMANY
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The United States is preparing to take up diplomatic relations with East Germany at the embassy level soon, probably next week, according to wellplaced Administration sources.

title: ChainStore Sales Rose 8.9% In June and 11.9% in 6 Months
Death Penalty Fast Goes On
description: SPRING LAKE, N. C., July 26 (UN)  A 21yearold Civil Service warehouseman at Fort Bragg is in the 14th day of a planned 45day fast as a protest over North Carolina's death penalty. John Butler, a vegetarian, says he has been living on a diet of distilled water, with the juice of four lemons per gallon, two tablespoons of honey and seaweed tablets.

title: Nader Sees No Difficulty In Cutting Energy Demand
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP)  Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, told Congress today that it would be simple for the nation to achieve a zero growth rate in energy demand.

title: The Needlepoint Boom: Any Pattern, Any Color And Plenty of Advice.
description: The insatiable demand for new needlepoint designs and new surfaces on which to apply them is steadily growing. Needlepoint may now well head the list of popular crafts.

title: Notes on People
description: The appointment of John Froines, a Chicago Seven trial defendant, as Director of Occupational Health for Vermont was confirmed yesterday, after it had been held up because of protests to the office of Gov. Thomas P. Salmon.

title: Prices of Gasoline And Residual Fuel Are Cut by Gulf Oil
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation announced yesterday a reduction in the price of all gasoline grades by 1.6 cents a gallon. The company also cut the wholesale price of residual fuel phur content by Changes $1 a barrel. The oil in excess of 1.5 per cent sul Bowaters Mersey 1 Paper Company, Ltd., of Liverpool, Nova Scotia, a member of the Bowater Group of Companies, said that it would increase the Canadian price of 30pound newsprint to $222aton from $204.50, effective Sept. 1. Most producers in eastern Canada raised their Canadian prices on July 1 to the level of $266 a ton.

title: HOUSE PANEL MOVES TOWARD VOTE ON FIRST ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT AFTER IT REJECTS A DELAY, 27 TO 11
Remain in City or Relocate: How 2 Companies Decided
description: Five years ago, David Perside moved his color printing plate business, G. S. Offset Services, from two small floors in an old loft building on West 22d Street to a modern, onestory brick factory in Carlstadt, N.J.

title: Times Gets,Stay on Order Barring South Africa Ads
description: The New York Times obtained an order in State Supreme Court yesterday requiring the city's Commission on Human. Rights to show cause why its order barring classified advertisements for employment in racially segregated South Africa should not be set aside.Mangan set Aug. 27 for a hearing, and the city agreed to stay the order until then.

title: Gain of J. &
For the G.O.P., a Punctual Convention
description: HARTFORD, July 26  Last weekend, at the start of their state convention, Connecticut Democrats drifted casually into. Bushnell Memorial Hall. When enough of them had taken seats, the convention was gaveled to order, and no one seemed particularly concerned that it was nearly an hour late.

title: Music: By Mozart, Age 12
description: What could seem more attractive in prospect than a program entitled The Young Mozart"? There never was an old Mozart, of course, and in a sense a young Mozart is all we have. In speaking of him, young means teenaged and even younger, and that was the fertile field plowed at the Mostly Mozart Festival on Thursday night by the New York Chamber Soloists.

title: State Finances $30,000 Study on WindmillGenerated Electricity
description: NEWARK, July 26 (AP)The state is studying the possibility of using windmills to generate electricity for New Jersey.

title: Shots Fired in Texas Prison
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., July 261 Gunshots erupted inside the Huntsville State Prison here tonight. A prison spokesman said! the leader of three armed inmates holding I I hostages had refused an offer of transportation out of the prison and refused to surrender.

title: Saigon Foresees a Drive By Enemy Near Da Nang
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, July 27South Vietnamese military sources said yesterday that the North Vietnamese had massed 10,000 to 12,000 troops in an apparent effort to take the district town of Duc Duc, which is within artillery range of Da Nang, the country's second largest city.Some of the heaviest fighting since the 1973 ceasefire has raged among the hills around Duc Duc in recent days, with the South Vietnamese claiming to have killed over 1,000 Communist soldiers in intensive air strikes and artillery barrages.

title: Congressmen and Lawyers Meet and Cast and Recast Article's of Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The House Judiciary Committee's impeachment debate began minutes late this morning, minutes late this afternoon and 48 minutes late tonight.

title: A Ma.yor on Labor Blacklist
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 26 (AP) The Greater New Orleans members of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations rebuffed its leadership yesterday and put Mayor Moon Landrieu on a labor blacklist for the dismissal of Sgt, Irvin L. Magri of the Police Department. Representatives of about 100 local unions with a membership of 68,000 reversed their executive committee's ruling. Mr. Magri, who headed the New Orleans Patrolman's Association, was ?? last week by the police superintendent for public criticism of him and department operations.

title: Isbrandtsen Files Suit Naming Former Head
description: Isbrandtsen Co., Inc., the shipping company, filed suit yesterday M the United States Court for the Southern District of New York charging its former president, Jacob lsbrandtsen, with siphoning off $20million in company assets for his own use, United Press International reported.

title: Huge Blaze Burning in Nicosia; Firemen Refusing to Fight It
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Saturday, July 27 (Reuters)A huge fire, possibly caused by arson, burned out of control early today inside the old and crowded walled city of Nicosia.

title: Israelis to Prevent Squatters Settling Unauthorized Areas
description: TEL AVIV, July 26  The Israeli Cabinet resolved here today to prevent Israeli Jews from setting up a settlement in Israelioccupied Jordanian territory in defiance of Government policy.

title: Nixon's Proposals for Social and Economic Change Still Pressed
Court's CitySuburb Busing Ban Seen Having Little Effect Here
description: The United States Supreme Court ruling barring merger of Detroit city schools with suburban school districts to achieve integration will probably have little effect on integration proposals in the metropolitan area, according to civilrights spokesmen.

title: Bomb Explodes Near the Home Of Gibson, but No Tie Is Seen
description: NEWARK, July 26A bomb exploded shortly after midnight in a car parked near the home of Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson here.

title: Devine Had No Idea of Court Order
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 26 (AP)Coach Dan Devine said today he had no idea officers of the Green Bay Packer Corporation had sought a court order that led to arrests of 14 of his players and six other striking National Football League players last night.

title: Armco Steel's Dividend Up
description: The directors of the Armco Steel Corporation announced yesterday an increase in the company's quarterly dividend to 40 cents a share from 30 cents. It is payable Sept. 9 to stockholders of record Aug, 9.

title: New York Y.C. Cruise Girds for Biggest Fleet
description: NEWPORT, R. I., July 26Three of the 12Meter candidates for the defense of the America's CupCourageous, Intrepid and Valiantwill be in the fleet tomorrow when the New York Yacht Club cruise commences with five cup races in Rhode Island Sound.

title: Appeal for Calley Parole
description: COLUMBUS, Ga., July 26 (AP)Kenneth Henson, Columbus attorney for former Army Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., said today he would go to Fort Leavenworth, Kan., to try to arrange an early release from prison of the soldier convicted for the killing of at least 22. civilians at My Lai Mr. Henson has asked the Army and Air Force Clemency and Parole Board to grant parole.

title: Market Declines Sharply; Investors Still on Sidelines
24 Are Killed and 71 Hurt In 2 Mexican Bus Crashes
description: MEXICO CITY, July 26 (AP)  Twentyfour persons were killed and 71 injured in two bus accidents near Mexico City yesterday, the Red Cross has reported.

title: Republicans in Connecticut Are Meeting To Pick Among HardFighting Hopefuls
description: HARTFORD, July 26  Connecticut Republicans opened twoday state convention here today to resolve one of the closest, hardestfought party political contests in recent memory in the state

title: High Adviser Hopes Public Rejects Nixon Savings Idea
description: WASHINGTON, July 26A high Administration economist conceded today that he hoped consumers would not take President Nixon's request in last night's economic address literally and save an additional 1.5 per cent of their income.

title: British Yacht Wins One Ton Series
description: TORQUAY, England, July 26 (AP)A British yacht, Gumboots, wag overall winner of the. One Ton Cup after finishing second 19day in the final race of tlio series. ?? boats made a clean sweep of the first thrVe places the final race, which was won by High Tension, with gumboots second and Solent Saracen third.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASWNGTON, July 26  A special United States court of appeals panel ruled today in fdvor of the Federal Energy Administration in a case brought by the states of California and Louisiana challenging the agency's action in subjecting the sale of crude oil from stateowned fields to price controls. The decision was announced here by the F.E.A.

title: Athens Expected to Move On Economic Problems
description: ATHENS, July 26The new civilian Government of Greece will need to move quickly to develop its economic policy to deal with such problems as high inflation, the heavy impact of military mobilization and a chronic trade deficit, expert economic sources believe.

title: 25 MILLION HEAR NIXON TV SPEECH
description: President Nixon, in his 35minute address on inflation Thursday night, probably reached as many television viewers as did the House Judiciary Committee's debate on the articles of impeachment,: although the telecast of the second night's session ran almost three hours in prime time.

title: Cyprus Fighting Revives; Turks Said to Widen Hold
description: NICOSIA; Cyprus, July 26 Scattered new fighting erupted between Greek Cypriotes and Turkish forces today shortly after President Glafkos Clerides charged that Turkey was using the ceasefire as a pretext to expand the territory under her control.

title: Turkey's Ceasefire
description: The complex Cyprus problems that lie before the Britishchaired tripartite peace conference in Geneva, which is already threatened by breakdown, will be impossible to resolve without greater GreekTurkish trust and confidence than now exists. The first step toward that mutual confidence, as British Foreign Secretary Callaghan has emphasized, is consolidation of the United Nationsordered ceasefire, now clearly being violated by Turkey.

title: Howard D. Harrington Dies; Managed Detroit Symphony
description: THOMASTON, Me., July 26Howard D. Harrington, general manager of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra for 20 years, died in his home here yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: Aaron's Smash Lands in Sports Writer's Face
description: ATLANTA, July 26 (AP)Henry Aaron, the Atlanta Braves slugger, ended a spirited discussion with an Atlanta sports writer tonight by smashing a carton of strawberries in the writer's face.

title: Boy Arraigned in Slaying Of Man at a Harlem Coop
description: A 15yearold boy has been arraigned in Family Court on juvenile delinquency charges stemming from the fatal snipershooting of a 41yearold Bronx man at a fundraising party at a middleincome cooperative development in Harlem on July 3.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Pentagon Changing Policy On Mental Health Program
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)  A Defense Department official said today that the Government had not reviewed mental health facilities used by military] dependents as thoroughly as it should have to uncover abuses and that changes in policy were being made.

title: WRITER IS KILLED BY TAXICAB HERE
description: Johanna Davis, the 36yearold author of the novel Life Signs, was struck and killed by a taxicab Thursday night while walking with her 11yearold son outside her apartment building in Greenwich Village, the police reported.

title: Rules Committee To Get a Resolution Before House Does
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)Any impeachment resolution voted by the House Judiciary Committee will be sent to still another committee before facing an estimated two weeks of House debate and voting, House sources said today.

title: 24Count Murder Indictment To Be Asked in Gulliver Fire
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 26 (AP) The Westchester County District Attorney, Carl A. Vergari, said today that he would ask a grand jury next week to indict Peter Leonard on 24 counts of murderone for each person who died in the Gulliver's singlesbar fire in Port Chester on June 30.

title: Panel of a Talk With Dr. Farkas Kalrnbah Told
Colson Says President Threw Ashtray in Anger
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI)President Nixon threw an ashtray across the room upon learning of the Watergate breakin, according to testimony by a former White House special counsel, Charles W. Colson, released today by the House Judiciary Committee.

title: A Bill on Racial Imbalance Is Signed by Gov. Sargent
description: BOSTON, July 26 (AP)A bill intended to encourage voluntary compliance with the state's Racial Imbalance Act was signed into law today by Gov. Francis W. Sargent.

title: Man in Radiation Mishap;, In June Is Going Home
description: LIVINGSTON, July 26 (AP) A man who barely survived,,, a radiation accident six weeks ago is ready to gb home from St. Barnabas Medical Center here, doctOr'S say.

title: New Arab Attack Predicted By Israeli Defense Minister
description: TEL AVIV, July 26 (AP)Defense Minister Shimon Peres of Israel said today that we have information that the Arabs are preparing to attack the state of Israel in a matter of months six, nine or 12 months.

title: Randy Johnson at Giant Base Also 2 Jets Report
description: ENGLEWWOOD, N. J., July 26  The New York Giants welcomed back three major defectors from the National Football League Players Association strike today. The leading quarterbacks, Norm Snead, and Randy Johnson, and Bob Tucker, the tight end, reported to the Giants. Meantime, two secondyear men showed up in the New York Jets camp at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.

title: Antiques: Shaker Events
description: The joy that Shakers documented in so many of their spirit drawings after their arrival on this continent 200 years ago will be shared vicariously here and abroad by thousands in the coming weeks.

title: ExMagistrate Gets Term
description: NEWARK, July 26 (AP)James J. Del Mauro, former chief magistrate of Newark, was sentenced today to four months in a Federal prison for incometax evasion: Mr. Del Mauro, 61 years old, who presided in Municipal Court from 1964 to 1970, was also fined $5,000 and put on three years probation by District Court Judge Daniel Snyder. Mr. Deli Mauro had pleaded guilty to charges that he understated his income in 1967 when he earned $20,000 as a judge. He also failed to report he had performed in his office.

description: Tennis Teacher Leads Women's Golf

title: First Known Sex Guide In Soviet Is Best Seller
description: MOSCOW, July 26 (AP) The Soviet Union's first known sex manual says the Soviet woman enjoys sex more than her French or English sisters. It maintains that premarital intercourse is harmful.

title: Five Draw Top Positions On Upstate Voting Machine
description: The State Board of Elections announced yesterday that Representative Hugh Carey, a Democratic candidate for Governor; State Senator Mary Ann Krupsak, a Lieutenant Governor hopeful; District Attorney Robert Meehan of Rockland County, a candidate for Attorney General; Abraham Hirschfeld, a United States Senate contender, and Jacob Fuchsberg, a Court of Appeals aspirant, had drawn top position on the Sept. 10 Democratic primary voting machines in their respective contests outside New York Citq.

title: Many Greek Cypriote Prisoners
description: ANKARA, Turkey, July 26 (UPI)Hundreds of Greek Cypriote prisoners were transferred to Turkey today while fresh Turkish troops landed on Cyprus.

description: WASHINGTON, July 26The House Judiciary Committee came down from Olympus today.

description: Bidding and making a grand slam is a rare and happy experience for the average. Player.

description: Assistant Chief William T. Bonacum, the controversial police officer who initiated the midtown towaway blitz last year and instituted parkingticket quotas before that, has resigned quietly from the Police Department after reportedly being told that he would be demoted.

title: Where to Find the Supplies
140 Civilians Are Being Hired To Replace Police Officers at 911
description: The Police Department announced yesterday that it was hiring 140 civilians on Monday to replace patrolmen who had been taken off the street in recent months to man the 911 emergency telephone system. had to use the resources available to us.

title: The Last Great Task a of Art
description: LONDON  That color should be set free to lead its own life has been the central Preoccupation of modern art for the best part of the last hundred years, Early or late, directly or obliquely, the big artists have come back and pack to it. It was the last great task of art. It was recognized as such in France, from the time when Gauguin was in PontAven to the timetoward the end of the nineteenforties  when Matfsse told death to go away and come back another day. And it was recognized as such in America, once again toward the end of the forties, when the decisive question was What is there still left do?

title: Black Lung Clinics Aided
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., July 26 (AP)Two black lung clinics in Pennsylvania's anthracite region will receive $257,400 from a $5million Federal grant made to help men affected with the miners disease, a United (Mine Workers of America official said Thursday. He said the clinic at the WilkesBarre General Hospital was to get $130,000 and the Vastine Foundation at Shamokin, $127,000,

title: Despite Flourishing Trade With Japan, Wartime Suspicions Linger in Oregon
description: PORTLAND,Ore.  In 1944 Oregonians painted out names of JapaneseAmerican soldiers on an American Legion post honor roll. Others warned. the soldiers parents that the would do well to sell their property.

title: Shoe Exports an Issue
description: The question of whether Spanishmade shoes exported to the United States are subsidized, and should therefore be subject to countervailing duties, is a matter of contention between the two countries, Page 39.

title: Program on cape Seeks to Protect Terns
description: EASTHAM, Mass., July 26 The beach buggy stopped two women in blue, both in their sixties, got out. A minute before they had seen a baby tern run across vehicle tracks in the sand. Now it had vanished. As they searched for the Chick, adult terns divebombed them and screamed outrage at this invasion near their nesting ground.

title: New Process Developed To Get Gold From Ore
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 Specialists in the Bureau of Mines have discovered an improved method of recovering gold from ore. The new process is not yet in use, but licenses are available from the Department of the Interior. Patent 3,825,651 was granted, this week to staff members of the Metallurgy Research Center in Reno. The inventors are Harold J. Heinen, a metallurgist, and Judith A. Eisele and Dennis D. Fisher, both chemists.

title: Father of Six Kills
description: An Albanian refugee shoe and killed a burglar in his Bronx apartment yesterday and was then held on a weapon's charge, according to District Attorney Mario Merola.

description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 26 (AP)President Nixon has accepted the resignations of the United States ambassadors to Ghana, Barbados and Mauritania.

title: Transport Bond Issue Bills Await Legislature Monday,
description: TRENTON, July 26The New Jersey Legislature will return on Monday for its final meeting of the special session, and will then urgently consider a number of pending major bills, including two new transportation bond issues totaling $300million.

title: Five States Challenge du Pont on Dumping Into Gulf
description: PENSACOLA, Fla. July 25The five states bordering the Gulf of Mexico challenged E.I. du.Pont de Nemours & Company this week to justify its dumping of chemical wastes into the gulf.

title: Baseball Fans Unhappy As TV Cavers Hearings
description: PITTSBURGH, July 26Television station KDKA received 502 phone calls last night protesting its broadcast of the House Judiciary Committee impeachment debate instead of the Pirates baseball game at Montreal.

title: ABC and PBS to Carry Today's House Sessions
description: ABCTV and the Public Broadcasting Service will televise today's session of the House Judiciary Committee's impeachment debate starting at noon. The networks are rotating the live coverage of the proceedings.

title: PEARL BUCK'S WILL IS UPSET BY JURY
description: RUTLAND, Vt., July 26The last will and testament of Pearl S: Buck was deemed invalid here today on the ground that she was the victim of undue influence and fraud by her business manager, Theodore F. Harris, when she signed the document in 1971.

title: U.S. CLIMBER DIES ON A SOVIET PEAK Moscow Gets Word That He Perished in Snowslide
description: MOSCOW, July 26  One of the 19 American Alpinists attempting to scale the third highest Soviet mountain was killed Wednesday by a snowslide, according to a message reaching Moscow today.

description: Larry Adams was denied a jockey's license by the New York State Racing and Wagerin Board yesterday, a decision that virtually could end his career. Adams is 38 years old. The denial was based on Adams's falsification of his license application, in which he failed to list two prior arrests. At the Race Tracks

title: Theater: Room Service
Martin Tops Gorman in Net Upset
description: WASHINGTON July 26 (UPI)  Seventeenyearold Billy Martin stormed over fifthseeded Tom Gorman for a 62, 61 upset today to advance to the quarterfinals of the $100,000 Washington StarNews tennis tournament. Martin, the United States and Wimbledon junior champion who has yet to lose a set against three older opponerlts in the event, startled onlookers with the ease of his victory.

title: People in Sports
description: In a major shakeup, the Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association yesterday announced that Mel Daniels and Freddie Lewis had been traded Co the Memphis Sounds for Charlie Edge and a substantial amount of cash.

title: Tigers Limited to 3 Hits, But Win in 11 Innings, 10
description: Ralph Houk, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, has been through his share of losing ball games during his career. One of those came Thursday night when the Red Sox rapped 17 hits and scored six times in the first two innings to send Detroit to its 14th defeat in the last 16 games, 124.

title: HOUSE PANEL MOVES TOWARD VOTE ON FIRST ARTICLE OF IMPEACHMENT; MOVE TO DELETE A CHARGE BEATEN
The Arithmetic of Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 26The open sessions of the House Judiciary Committee have served to contradict two of the White House's major propaganda themes. Instead of a kangaroo court or a lynching bee, the members of the committee have shown themselves to be conscientious and sensible.

title: BUS LANES URGED IN CLEANAIR PLAN
description: New York's major new strategy for meeting Federal cleanair standards is to create express bus lanes in some midtown streets from which all other vehicles would be banned during rush hours.

title: Leftists Included As Greek Premier Completes Cabinet

description: LONDON, July 26 (AP) Royal Air Force transport planes have evacuated 7,929 itourists of 48 nationalities from embattled Cyprus to bases in, Britain, an R.A.F. spokesman said today. The transport planes began arriving in England on Sunday.

title: A New Red Sea Miracle
description: ALHADA, Saudi Arabia  Since Moses persuaded the Lord to part the Red Sea waters and marched the Jews through it and away from a pursuing Egyptian army, this area has become Jess accustomed to miracles. But now another one is assuming shape.

description: MICK JAGGER: Everybody's Lucifer. By Tony Scaduto. 375 pages. Illustrated, David McKay Company, Inc. $8.95.

description: WASHINGTON, July 26The Commissioner of Internal Revenue has conceded that he handled tax penalties against President Nixon differently than the agency normally would for other taxpayers.

description: ROSEVILLE, Mich, July 26The gulf between the inner city of Detroit and this overwhelmingly white workingHeast, class suburb is wider than ever today. That's the way most ofi the people who live here it.

Weisl Jr., had adVocated some weeks agoNew York City going, to continue discussions" on the matter with the Nassau County government, Mayor Beame's office said.

description: NOSTALGIC VOICES

title: DOROTHY V. BORG
description: Dorothy Virginia Borg, sister of Donald G. Borg, chairman and editor of The Record in Hackensack, N. J., died yesterday at her home in Osterville, Mass. She was 65 years old.

description: NEW HYDE PARK: L. I., July 26Pausing regularly as airplanes roared overhead, Federal Aviation Administration officials conceded today that this longsuffering community was one of the few areas to receive approach traffic from both Kennedy International and LaGuardia Airportsalthough not at the same time.

title: Siderowf, Stein Reach Final in Golf
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., July 26 Doug Stein, whose favorite topic is his golf game, expounded on that subject well into this evening after he reached the final of the Metropolitan Golf Association's 72d amateur championship through a bit of sweet revenge.

title: ARTPARK'UPSTATEI OPENED TO PUBLIC! Dedication in Lewiston Has an Audience of 4,500
description: LEWISTON, N. Y., July 26Lewiston Artpark, New York State's new center here for the performing and visual arts, was dedicated last night in an eighthour program that ranged from a concert and ballet to public dancing under the starts and a spectacular display of fireworks.An openingnight audience of nearly 4,500 people overflowed the $7.2million theater and occupied most of the grassy seating space outside a movable partition at the rear of the hall.Dedication speeches were delivered by Katherine Wilson, wife of Governor Wilson; Earl W. Brydges of nearby Niagara Falls, the retired Republican majority leader of the State Senate, and Alexander Aldrich, Commissioner of the State Office of Parks and Recreation.For 90 minutes before the center was opened, theater and dance groups, gospel singers and a brass band performed on the stillunfinished 172acre grounds overlooking the Niagara River Gorge and the Candian boundary near this village of 3,300 people in the state's northwestern corner.The Artpark, which is to serve as a second home for the Buffalo Philharmonic, will have a yearround program, in which theater attractions will be presented and in which visitors will be permitted to watch artists in residence at work. State funds for the park came from a $2.5billion recreational bond issue approved, by the voters in November, 1972.

title: Dracula's Bones Mislaid in Rumania
description: SNAGOV ISLAND, Rumania  Hopes have been raised that the headless skeleton of Dracula, long missing from his tomb here, may turn up next year in a fresh excavation beneath the floor of Snagov Chapel.

title: THOMAS M. HENNESSEY
description: SOUTH YARMOUTH, Mass., July 26 (AP)  Thomas M. Hennessey, retired vice president and director of the New England Telephone Company, died yesterday at his home here. He was 72 years old.

title: G.M.'S PROFIT FELL 61.7% IN QUARTER
description: DETROIT, July 26  The General Motors Corporation, with sales still declining and costs rising, reported today net earnings of $305million in the second quarter of 1974, a drop of $491million or 61.7 per cent from the $797million profit made in the 1973 quarter. Sales were down 13.8 per cent.

title: Boulogne on a Budget
description: ONE summer afternoon, after splendid lunch, some Englishmen, in the Boulogne area for a business conference, stripped to the buff and streaked into the sea at Wimereux, a nearby resort. The English chairman of the conference was concerned that some female onlookers at the French port might be upset by this lapse of selfrestraint; Britain was about to enter the European Economic Community, and he feared an international incident. So he sent apologies to the Mayor. The official answer was most reassuring: Far from being in any way offended, the ladies of Wimereux have expressed.a wish that, when Britain is in the Common Market, perhaps they could see much more of Englishmen thus.

title: Less Dusting Urged In CornPest Fight
description: NEW BRUNSWICKOver the last three years, the peSt management specialist at Cook College here has been proving to the producers of the state's $11millionayear sweet corn crop that the cornear worm can be beaten only by spraying, but also by not spraying insecticides.

title: Pro Football Inducts 4 Into Canton Hall of Fame

title: Refugees Flood Cypriote Town
description: KYTHREA Cyprus July 27When a Turkish jet fighter roared over this mountain village yesterday morning, fouryearold Maria Christodoulou suddenly plugged both her ears with her fingers. The plane passed overhead in a moment, but the girl's fright remained.

description: WASHINGTON  The Fed eral Bureau of Prisons has apparently decided to go ahead with construction of prison for youthful offenders in Manchester Township, N.J., despite widespread local opposition.

title: Inside Washington
description: So many visitors to Washington walk past all the famous monuments in lockstep, eyes glazed over. They get no sense of the dynamic things going on around them, things that are going to shape their lives. We're trying to clue them in on the action.

title: Music: For Koussevitzky
description: LENOX, Mass., July 27 Among the, contributors to America's musical maturity, Serge Koussevitzky was one of the most dynamic and influential. When he became music director of the Boston Symphony. Orchestra in 1924, the United States had little to boast of musically. The country did not have a viable symphonic repertory of its own, was deficient in schools of highlevel professional training and, perhaps most serious of all, lacked confidence in its ability to deal effectively with, these shortcomings.

title: Art
description: ON Oct. 25, 1900, the young Andalusian artist who signed the drawings he was then contributing to the Catalan literary papers of Barcelona with the name P. Ruiz Picasso observed his 19th birthday. Either just before or just after that birthdaythe exact date has never been establishedhe left Barcelona for Paris. For the first time, Picasso's biographer Roland Penrose tells us, he made the acquaintance of the city in which he was to live the greater part of his life.

description: Hot July days are insect days, and there is little anyone can do about it. Man may boast that he rules the earth, but midsummer is loud with the rasping, buzzing, stridulating denial.

title: Virus Is Cause Peculiar Markings on Rose Foliage
description: SOME peculiar markings on rose leaves have been cause for comment among rose growers in recent weeks. There are jagged, yellow markings looking like streaks of lightning or yellowed areas feathering away from the midrib and veins. Some are ring patterns or watermarkings with fine, grayish lines.

title: Portugal Reports Cholera
description: LISBON, July 27 (Reuters)Health authorities reported today that 104 more cases of cholera, seven of them fatal, were confirmed in Portugal in !Trim July 19 to 25. This brings the total number since the outbreak began in April to 645 of which 18 have been fatal,

title: Why Such Concern Over Little Cyprus?
description: ATHENSRarely has a coup anywhere captured so Much world attention as that in Cyprus. Yet it one of those complex crises in world affairs that has also left many wondering why all the fuss?

title: Food: Three ways with veal scaloppine
description: Two's companyand never more so than when the cook plans to serve veal scaloppine. For unless this delectable cut of meat is to be braised as in veal birds, scaloppine is difficult to cook properly in large quantities (although expert chefs may disagree). The reason is that it should be cooked as quickly as possible on both sides. Otherwise, it will dry out and toughen. On this page we present three ways to prepare scaloppine for two. Veal piccata with lemon on a bed of spaghetti is shown in the photograph above. (It may be just as well that veal demands a certain intimacy, for the price of really good veal scaloppine ranges from about $4.50 to $7.50and sometimes even higher.)

title: Point of View
description: The author of the following article is an associate of the William Kaufman, Organization, which owns six highrise office buildings in New York. The Kaufman Organization did not file by July 18, as required by Local Law 5, action plans for combating fires in its buildings. The group is already involved in a legal battle over its refusal to post signs and unlock some doors leading to fire towers.

title: Numismatics
description: IN the eight years or so since the $2 bill went into limbo there have been sporadic spurts of interest in legislation to revive it. These attempts usually died aborning because they were sponsored by specialinterest groups whose principal purpose was to have the designs changed to commemorate some special person, place or thing. Now, however, there's a greater likenhood than ever that the $2 bill will again see the light of day. Legislation has been Introduced into Congress, but this time with a big difference: It is focused on an event of great national interestthe Bicentennial.Representative Jerry L. Pettis of California introduced the bill, known as 11.R. 15585, late last month. In its wording it directs, rather than merely authorizes, the Secretary of the Treasury to issue the $2 denomination with an appropriate design that will cornmemorate the American Revolution Bicentennial.

title: Lakewood Seeking New Schools Plan
description: LAKEWOOD  The Board of Education here may risk the loss of $800,000 in state aid by defying a desegregation order, The Board is demanding that New Jersey education officials permit it to modify its previously approved school integration plans.

title: I'm Ready for Anything, Texas Prison Inmate Says
description: HUNTSVILLE, Tex., July 27 "If they think I am kidding or bluffing, they are nowhere close to the truth. And if they want to storm the place, they can do so whenever they want. l've got plenty of ammunition and I'm ready to use it. Now lit's whoever wants to take the responsibility. I'm ready for anything. They are underestimating me. And by this they are putting so many lives in jeopardy.
