title: Sleep and Dreams; By Dr. Alvin Silverstein and Virginiu B. Silverstein. Illustrated,160 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott. $5.50. (Ages 12 to 16)
description: Sleep, that condition in which we spend approximately one third of our lives, is a no man's land which scientists have begun to penetrate only in recent decades. Today, new discoveries about sleep are being made constantly in laboratories around the world, and with each new finding, new questions arise. This lively book by Alvin and Virginia Silverstein covers the basic knowledge that has accumulated so far and describes some of the ingenious methods research scientists have used in their attempts to pin down the illusive facts about this universal but highly subjective experience. The help of the blind, for example, has been enlisted in studying the nature of dreams (test subjects who had been born blind dreamed only in sensations of touch and

title: College Enrollment Peek Due in 80s
description: TRENTON  The Department of Higher Education, in a special report issued last week, predicted that undergraduate college enrollment in the state would reach a peak of 272,000 by 1982, 15 per cent more than it is at this time.

title: HOUSECALL PLAN AIDS SEAMEN HERE
description: The port's modern waterfront is oldfashioned In one respectit is one of the few areas in the city where physicians regularly make house calls, day or night seven days a week.

title: New Hampshire Jobless Up
description: CONCORD, NIL, July 27 (AP)Unemployment in the state rose to 5 per cent last week from 4.6 per cent the week before, the Employment Security Department said Tuesday.

title: Priscilla Star Married on L.I.
description: The marriage of Priscilla Ann Star, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leon D. Star of Lawrence and Montauk, L. I., to Jon Randolf Waggoner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon C. Waggoner of Abilene, Tex., took place yesterday afternoon.

title: To Understand the Music Should We Meet the Composer?;
description: Do you like to know who a book's by? Just like that, with masterly disdain for the feelings of grammarians, E. M. Forster begins Anonymity, one of his essays In literary criticism. And, with only a slight shift in emphasis, we can ask the sn.me about any piece of music. Do you want to know who composed it, or do you want simply to listen to it? The confirmed believer in art for its own sake would have to reply, in all good logic, that he couldn't care less who composed the Eroica, which neither gains nor loses an inch of stature by being identified with one Ludwig van

title: The Nation In Summary
description: Despite the strong efforts of the energy industry, the House of Representatives has approved a relatively stringent regulatory bill to diminish the environmental destruction caused by the strip mining of coal.

title: State Incentive Plan Is Aiding Horse Farms
description: MONTAUKA new state law providing bonuses for winning New Yorkbred race horses may help revive an industry that flourished on Long Island before suburbanization galloped over the area's plush landsoape.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Time for Play
description: NEW LONDON, N.H.It was Sunday, and George Waring was doing all the chores a husband should do around the house and yard on a weekend.

title: Impeachment Bid Perils Major Bills in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The telephone in Mike Mansfield's Capitol office rings frequently now with callers, trying to find out when the Senate is likely to act on this bill or that bill.

title: Sense of Momentum Toward Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Only a month ago the storms destiny seemed at last to hi subsiding for President Nixon Among the knowledgeable Washington, the conviction wa growing that the impeachment cam paign against him had spent its mo mentum at till White House was hoped that the vote in till Rouse Judiciary Committee would be close, that the Presi dent might even eke out a one vote victory.

title: A WalkIn Center Helps the Divorced to Adjust
description: GARDEN CITYShe had the chagrined air of one who faces defeat with regularity. In a flat voice, the woman said her husband was an alcoholic. Occasionally he became violent, she said, adding, Me and the kids can't take it any more. A teenaged daughter had turned to drugs, a son was in therapy.

title: Muir's Closing Shop After 93 Years
description: EAST ORANGEMuir's, suburban department store founded 93 years ago, is going out of business.

title: Cramer of Germany Signs a 4Year Contract to Push Development of Soccer in This Country
description: Soccer in the United States took its longest kick forward yesterday when Dettmar Cramer of West Germany, perhaps the world's most re nowned developer of the game, signed a fouryear contract to work full time in this country.

title: 17 Hurt in Egyptian Club As a Grenade is Set Off
description: CAIRO, July 27 (Reuters)A hand grenade thrown onto the dance floor of an Alexandria night club wounded 17 persons today, the Middle East News Agency reported.

title: Sarah A. Erwin Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. James S. Erwin of Pittston, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Anne Erwin, to Paul Zeltan Bodnar, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Bodnar of New York. A January wedding is planned.

title: Bill on Martha's Vineyard
description: TISBURY, Mass July 27 (AP)Gov. Francis W. Sargent has signed a bill regulating land use on Martha's Vineyard. Favored by area residents by a 21 margin, the bill creates a 21member commission to protect areas threatened by development in Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket.

title: Suspicious Fire Destroys Part of Boardwalk Pavilion
description: A fire that the police said was started intentionally by four teenagers destroyed a wooden pavilion and 1,500 square feet of the boardwalk at Brighton Fourth Street in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Snow Leopard Dies in Zoo
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (UPI)Nikolai, a snow leopard under treatment for cancer, died Monday of a kidney ailment, Lincoln Park Zoo officials said this week.

title: Marcia J. Moody Bride of Brian Hirst
description: In the Long Grove (Ill.) United Church of Christ last evening Marcia Jane Moody, a senior at Northern Illinois University in DeKalb, was married to Brian Mark Hirst, who graduated from Northern Illinois in June and begins graduate work there next month.

title: Federal Official Named Berkeley Police Chief
description: BERKELEY, Calif., July 27 (AP)A Federal official who has handled security for the Woodstock rock festival and national political conventions is the new police chief here.

title: Monmouth Mark Set
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., July 27  Ruffian finally found a rival today who could stay with her  for five furlongs, anyway.

title: 6 Sentenced in Philadelphia In Urban Renewal Fraud
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) Six men convicted in a scheme to defraud the Phiiadelphia Redevelopment Authority of $1.5million in Federal urban renewal funds have been sentenced in Federal court.

title: The Other Branches
description: One of the marks of Richard M. Nixon's Presidency is that he has sought to expand his powers over Congress and to shape the ideology of the Supreme Court through appointments. Last week, those two branches of Government sat in judgment of Mr. Nixon and the result was severely damaging to his long and tenacious effort to avoid impeachment.

title: A Hodgepodge of 19thCentury Bad Paintings: Not So Bad As They Used to Be?
description: THE group of 19thcentury paintings from the Museo de Arte de Ponce, Puerto Rico, now on view (through Aug. 18) at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle, inchides so many examples of what we used to call bad painting that no young museum trying to build a reputation as a serious cultural institution would have thought of exhibiting them 20 years ago for fear of being hooted off the scene. And even now, an audience that has learned that you no longer play artists like Gerome and Bouguereau for laughs will find this a puzzling show. It is an odd mixture, including Delacroix (instant respect), Tissot (rising star), Sorolla y Bastida (heavens, when did he last turn up?), Moreau (Matisse's teacher couldn't have been all bad), Robert William Vonnoh (who?) and

title: New Jersey
description: THEATER

title: Carol Blake, Nurse, Wed to Peter Boyd
description: Carol Jean Blake, who received M.S. and R.N. degrees this year from the New York Medical CollegePace Univerf sity Graduate School of Nursing, was married in Syracuse yesterday afternoon to Peter Raymond Boyd, a fourthyear student at New York Medical College. The ceremony in the Hendricks chapel of Syracuse University was performed by the Rev. Charles Borgognoni, Roman Catholic chaplain there,

title: The Dance: Tetrushka
description: Petrushka is a ballet whose greatness is not always apparent in our time. The tendency is to regard it as a period piece and to hope. that its general atmosphere will waft out to the audience.

title: Rights Suit Against U.S. Is Dismissed in Alabama
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 27 (AP)A Federal appeals court has dismissed a suit charging 17 United.States Government agencies in Alabama with discriminating against blacks in employment practices. The court said the blacks filing the suit had not exhausted administrative channels to correct any discrimination.

title: in Teaneck, There Is Something for Everyone
description: TEANECKThis township, the most heavily populated community in Bergen County with 44,000 residents, seems to have a good mix of shopping, housing and transportation that marks it as a suburb in every sense of the word. And scattered about town are recreational facilities that are supported by municipal funds. Tennis courts, for example, are neatly manicured, well tended and used by diverse age groups.

title: Hilary Coulter Sets September Nuptials
description: Mrs. John Hamilton Coulter of Lloyd Neck, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Hilary Hamilton Coulter, to Eric Winslow Wodlinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Wodlinger of San Francisco, formerly of Larchinont, N.Y. Miss Coulter's late father was an architect and an officer of the French Legion of Honor.

title: Migrants Have ComeUp;There Was Nowhere Else to Go
description: Conditions have improved somewhat for migrant farm workers since the opressive years that produced Grapes of Wrath and Harvest of Shame. New Jersey and Connecticut have led the nation in advances in pay and some amenities. In certain areas, New York has not been far behind.

title: State Asks Opinions About Con Ed Fees For Overdue Bills
description: The Public Service Commission has asked consumer groups and other interested parties for comment on a request by the Consolidated Edison Company to levy extra charges against customers who fall so far behind in their payments that they warrant discontinuance of service.

title: The year
description: Berets won't just be for the kids this fall. This classic promises to be the hat of the year. Berets won almost unanimous approval with fashion designers for fall as toppings for big capes and coats. In ancient Greece, they were once reserved for the privileged classes. Later, Greek and Roman traders brought the beret into the Basque country where it found its spiritual home. Over the years, berets have passed through many countries and many changes. They have been jeweled, plumed and pomponned. In France in the early 16th century, the beret was considered the artist's hat.Today, it is the way to top off the 1974 look.

title: Rockefeller Praises Press For Exposing Watergate
description: TORONTO, July 27 (AP)Although noncommittal on the impeachment proceedings and his Presidential hopes, Nelson A. Rockefeller did say yesterday that the United States owed a great debt to the press for uncovering the Watergate scandals.

title: Future Social Events
description: How to Czech In

title: ARTICLE IN PRAVDA CRITICIZES NIXON
description: MOSCOW, July 27The Soviet press today published the sharpest rebuke of President Nixon to appear here in months. It seemed to analysts that Moscow may have begun the process of deflating Mr. Nixon's public image against the possibility that he may be removed from office.

title: V. SackvilleWest
description: No love affair ever did more to arouse interest in a writer than the recent discovery of Vita SackvilleWest's with Violet Trefusis. Providing the occasion for Nigel Nicolson's Portrait of a Marriage, published last year, Vita's tempestuous relationship with Violet, as well as the rather unusual marital arrangement she maintained with Harold Nicolson, seems to have certified her, in a way her work itself has not, as someone of authentic cultural importance to the present. With the inclusion of Vita's autobiographical narrative, written in 1920 at the end of her affair with Violet, Nicolson's book dramatically lifted her out of the relative obscurity in which she was resting as a poet, biographer and novelist. The distinction she never quite achieved in these capacities is certain now to be hers as the wife in a marriage that endured 49 professedly happy years despite the overt, sustained homosexuality of both partners. Exhibiting the extent to which a successful marriage need not be based on fidelity, sexual compatibility or physical proximity, the relationship of Vita and Harold has come to appear as the very embodiment of modern domestic bliss available to people of independent spirit. Here is

title: CostofLeaving Index
description: Escape from the humdrum problems of everyday remains a viable reason for foreign travel in 1974but there is one closetohome annoyance there's no escaping: inflation. Just what prices do tourists face this summer in the 10 nations most visited by Americans? The answer, as reported below in dispatches from New York Times bureaus: In virtually every case, the foreign inflation rate over the last year equals or surpasses our own 10.9 per cent. The writers do offer some consolation in the form of things that continue to be travel bargains. The countries are presented in the order of their popularity American travelers.

title: U.S. 3Day Squad Heads
description: The United States Equestrian Team's three day squad, the silver medal winner in the 1968 and 1972 Olympics, heads for England Tuesday, here it will compete in a halfdozen events capped by the world championships in Burghley, Sept. 12 through 15, Coach Jack LeGoff, along with five of the six riders and most of the horses, will fly to Europe on a chartered KLM Dutch airliner.

title: Growing Pains Pock Haywood's Road
description: ELKHART LAKE, Wis., July 27Hurley Haywood has been told he always wanted to be a racing driver. When I was in the crib, my mother said I'd throw away the soft cuddly toys and keep the hard steel ones with wheels, he said in the paddock of Road America after playing with the hard piece of steel he was to drive in a TransAm race here.

title: The best laid plans of the Devil and man; The Devil's; Storybook.; By Natalie Babbitt. illustrated by the author. 101 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $4.95. (Ages 9 to 13)
description: These ten original stories are cautionary tales in the best sense of the wordbrief, moral and sharpyet found myself disappointed in them. The reason, I suspect, is that Mrs. Babbitt has chosen a toofamiliar cast of characters for her parables and that her stage setting is Earth, Heaven and Hell. From the legend of Faust right through the movies of the thirties (where wellgroomed stars journeyed through Heavenly clouds to the accompaniment of Hollywood choirs) man's encounters with God and the Devil have been dramatized over and over again, the scenery familiar and the message always the same. The Devil plays his mischief and grapples for souls. Human beings are weak, and sometimes noble. And the very bestplansboth celestial and demonicoften

title: SPECIAL DISTRICTS IN STATE DECRIED
description: ALBANY, July 27There are thousands of public bodies and special districts in the state, and a study released this week concludes that many of them should be consolidated or abolished.

title: Robin Shelby Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Shelby of West Islip, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Ann Shelby, to John DeWitt Shuck, son of Mr. and Mrs. V. DeWitt Shuck of LaJolla, Calif.

title: It's Harder To Find Than Fund A Quartet
description: IT is hard enough for the individual artist to establish himself or herself in the world of music. It is doubly, if not necessarily quadruply, hard for a string quartet to reach a point where it can exist in financial and cultural security. Peter Marsh, first violinist of the 16yearold Lenox Quartet, has been concerned about this problem for a long time, and in 1970 he quietly instituted a program designed to improve the situation. This was at the State University of New York at Binghamton, where this quartet was (and still is) in residence and where he had the encouragement and help of the university's president, C. Peter McGrath, and the music department's head, Philip Nelson (now at Yale).

title: Barry Chaiken to Wed Jennifer Sue Franco
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Franco of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Sue Franco, to Barry Glenn Chaiken, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Chaiken of Short Hills, N. J. The wedding is planned for Sept. 12.

title: M'CLORY EXPECTED TO OFFER A DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 The secondranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee reportedly agreed today to sponsor a second proposed article of impeachment charging that President Nixon abused his constitutional authority.

title: SmallTown Rabbi Makes Big Time In Leading AntiImpeachment Drive
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 Wherever Rabbi Baruch M. Korff has gone; he has seldom gone unnoticed.

title: Commuters Offer Planning Aid
description: A total of 26,750 New Jersey rail commuters have signed transportation ques tionnaires with their names and addresses to express willingness to take part in planning improvements, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has reported.

title: What's Doing in NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: LIFESTYLEThe pace of living is attuned to the strongly pronounced seasons. Family farming is alive and well, although in some communities it faces attrition as encroaching land developers succeed in driving real estate prices (and taxes) beyond sane levels, Yearround tourism, however, is the leading industry of the state, whose attractions range from the majestic White Mountains to a 17milelong coastline. The people of New Hampshire have been described as laconic, suspicious and stubborn, and it is true that outofstaters are looked on as foreigners to be treated with a curl. ous mixture of cordiality and restraint. Nevertheless, if you stick around long enough, proverbial Yankee hospitality usually overcomes all. State government is conducted with fiercely conservative independence and traditional Yankee frugality. Any candidate for state office who dares to come out in favor of a state sales or income tax is a duck.

title: Bridge
description: Sooner or later every expert suffers misfortune when he tries for a slam but stops short in a contract of five hearts or five spades. If this fails by one trick he gnashes his teeth. He has risked something to gain nothing, and lost this unattractive gamble with the fates.

title: Calendar of Nearby Horse Shows
description: TodayStaten Island, Glove Lake Stables, Clove Road, Staten Island. Regular working hunters, open jumpers, western pleasure, gymkhana, adult horsemanship, equitation. 8 A.M.

title: Brennan is Reactivating Unit on Labor Training
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Labor Secretary Peter J. Brennan has reactivated a Federal apprenticeship committee to advise him on labor training issues.

title: Genie Wetstein Becomes Bride
description: Genie Wetstein and James R. Gerstenzang were married yesterday afternoon in Sherman, Conn. The Rev. L. Hamilton Gardner performed the nondenominational ceremony on the lawn at the shore of Candlewood Lake behind the. home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wetstein of Brooklyn and Sherman.

title: Books: The Energy Mess
description: As is so often the case with complex issues that suddenly erupt into public view, the great energy crisis of 197374 has been predominantly characterized as a battle between the good guys and the bad guys. Who is good and who is bad, of course, depends on one's vantage point.

title: For Halfpenny, Owners of Roberta Rights Prove to Be Real Shovv,stoppers
description: EAST ORANGEThe Halfpenny Playhouse was all set to open in its new home in Upsala College with a revival of the 1932 musical, Roberta, when it learned that the show could not go on.

title: Democrats Are Divided In Wake of Tax Defeat
description: TRENTON  Democratic leaders here say that the spirit of cooperation and partisan camaraderie between Democrats in the Senate and Assembly has been threatened sharply by the rejection of Governor Byrne's taxreform program in the State Senate.

title: Mansfield to Meet Scott To Arrange Nixon Trial
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP)  Democratic Majority Leader of the Senate, Mike Mansfield, said today he would meet on Monday with the minority leader, Hugh L. Scott, to begin formal Senate preparations for an impeachment trial of President Nixon.

title: Evesham: A Test of Politics
description: EVESHAM TOWNSHIP There is a battle of political philosophies being fought here.

title: What the Supreme Court Said
description: The President's counsel... reads the Constitution as providing an absolute privilege of confidentiality kir, all Presidential communications. Many decisions of this Court, however, have unequivocally reaffirmed the holding of Marbury v. Madison . that it is emphatically the province and duty of the Judicial department to say what the law is"....

title: Barbara B. Constantine Bride Of Robert Feldman in. Jersey
description: Barbara Byrd Constantine, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Hamilton Constantine of Englewood, N. J., and Grenada, W.I., was married yesterday evening to Robert Feldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard A. Feldman of New York.

title: Lynda Sharp Has Nuptials
description: The marriage of Lynda Suzanne Sharp, daughter of Peggy Teater Sharp of Bartow, Fla., and George Lindsey Sharp of Nicholasville, Ky., to Thomas Middleton Paine took place In Weston, Mass., yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Dana McLean Greeley of the Concord (Mass.) Unitarian Church performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr, and Mrs. John Bryant Paine Jr.

title: Case for Impeachment
description: The great constitutional drama of the impeachment of President Richard Nixon moves with gathering speed and intensity toward its fateful resolution. As the members of the House Judiciary Committee labored reach agreement on the final wording of articles of impeachment, there was no longer any doubt that a solid bipartisan majority of the committee would vote recommend such action to the House of Representatives. The first article was approved yesterday by a substantial majority.

title: Ocean County Unit Aiding Consumers
description: TOMS RIVERA handbook for the protection of consumers was issued last week by the Ocean County Department of Consumer Affairs at the 26th annual Ocean County Fair. It lists state statutes affecting the consumer.

title: Ballet: Dance Festival
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., July 27Ambition is a way of life for the American, Dance Festival, and has been since its brash beginnings over a quartercentury ago. The festival first dared to declare its existence. Then in succeeding seasons it presented the finest talents of modern dance in the warm surroundings of Connecticut College here, winning an established place for itself and its special crusade.

title: List of Incidents Compiled by Doar to Uphold the Committee Allegations in Proposed Impeachment Article
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Following is a list of 50 specific items, prepared by the House Judiciary Committee's special counsel, John M. Door, to defend the allegation in the committee's first impeachment article that President Nixon made a decision to participate in the Watergate coverup:

title: Restaurant Finds Nonsmoker Area Sparsely Used
description: EAST SETAUKET, L. I., July 27There is not much smoke in the nonsmoking corner of a pioneering restaurant here. But sometimes there are not many customers in that corner either.

description: ART

title: MEDICAID LOSSES LAID TO A DISPUTE
description: Controller Arthur Levitt has charged that the state is losing more than $6million a year in Medicaid remibursements for outpatient services because of a dispute between the Department of Mental Hygiene and the Department of Social Services over billing forms.

title: Dahlia Wins $194, 976 in Ascot Race
description: ASCOT, England, July 27 Nelson Bunker Hunt, a man of decisions, is confused. He doesn't know in what direction his champion filly, Dahlia, will be going in the future.

title: In Andover, the Martins Nest in Their Own Hotel
description: ANDOVER The Andover Hotel stands on Route 206 where it runs through this old Sussex County town. The Victorian structure is painted white with green trim. Next to it, on a tall pole near a parking lot, is a replica of the hotel a house for purple martins.

title: Census Errors Cost Cities Aid
description: NEWARK  Officials of several major New Jersey cities are gloomy over the prospects of receiving several hundreds of thousands of dollars in Federal revenue sharing that they say are denied them because of an admitted undercount by the United States Census Bureau.

title: SEYMOUR BASKIND
description: Seymour Baskind, a lawyer, who specialized in industrial relations and who for 35 years had been an arbitrator for the restaurant industry, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 35 Sheldrake Road in Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Floods Hit India
description: NEW DELHI, July 27 (UPI)Tenthousand people have been evacuated and more were reparted on the move in the three districts of southern Kerala State that have been hit by floods, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: Supreme Court Term: Something for Everybody
Sara N. Meeker Bride of Lawyer
description: In St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon, Sara Nelson Meeker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey H. Meeker Jr. of Honolulu, became the bride of James H. Carter Jr., son of Professor and Mrs. Carter of West Lafayette, Ind.

title: Melissa A. Beckwith Married To Samuel Wesley Poore 3d
description: Melissa Alean Beckwith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Beckwith Jr. of Eastchester, N.Y., and Samuel. Wesley Poore 3d, son of Mrs. Arthur Murphy Jr. of New York, formerly of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and of Samuel Wesley Poore, president of the Baldwin Building and Development Company in Fort Lauderdale, were married yesterday afternoon by the Rev. K. Gordon Drescher at Trinity Episcopal Church in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Nagaland Rebels Ambush Indian Patrol Van, Kill 11
description: NEW DELHI, July 27 (AP)Separatist Naga rebels ambushed a patrol van and killed 11 policement today, news reports said. United News of India, quoting official sources, said that the killings marked the worst rebel ambush this year.

title: Miss Boochever to Wed
description: Allison Jill Boochever and Brooks Hitchens Sawyer plan to. marry on Aug. 17 in the First Church in Dedham (Unitarian) in Massachusetts. Mr. and Mrs. S. Paul Boothever of Westwood, Mass., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Howard G. Sawyer of Stamford, Conn., and the late Mrs. Sawyer.

title: Gardens
description: ONE tree does not make a forest,. but it may create an ecological niche for shadeloving plants to thrive. An Oyster Bay, LI., terrace has such a tree. The paving made of bluestone squares separated by bands of brick, has a backdrop of existing evergreens. The old pear tree in center focus provides afternoon shade.

title: Intruder Is Stabbed to Death In Apartment in the Bronx
description: The intended victim of an alleged armed robbery fatally stabbed an intruder in his Bronx apartment yesterday, the police said. The gunman's weapon turned out to be a toy pistol.

title: Doctor Catches Yachting Fever
Saratoga: Euphoria, N. Y., or Nowheresville?
description: Its nightlife can be boring,

title: U.S. Delays Envoy Exchange With East Germany
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The United States has decided to delay exchanging ambassadors with East Germany even though the two governments have reached agreement on the essential points of diplomatic relations, an Administration official said today.

title: Debaters Ask: What Warrants Impeachment? What Is Proof?;
description: WASHINGTONA person who has lived through much American political life sat watching the House Judiciary Committee debate and murmured again and again, Amazing. Absolutely amazing.

title: Windsurfers and Hobies To Crowd Sailing Crowd
description: The fleets of competitive sailboats causing weekend traffic snarls on Long Island Sound and along the Eastern Seaboard will be joined in the next two weeks by com petitive sailboats from three of the more exotic classes. Today is the final day of the Northeast re gional windsurfing tournament off Newport, R.I. This type of sailing requires very athletic skipper who can hold a sail to the wind while balancing on a surfboard, virtually acting as a human mast. The windsurfers (the name is for both the boats and the sailors are aiming for the America's Tea Cup, to be awarded Aug. 12 after three days of open competition off Association Island on Lake Ontario.

title: Catholic Order Seeks $15Million to Cover BadInvestment Loss
description: BOSTON, July 27A Roman Catholic religious order and he Diocese of Reno have reportedly been forced to raise millions of dollars to meet finincial obligations stemming ram the near collapse of a fund in which they invested money raised by sales of bonds.

title: Town Is Devastated In Cambodian Victory
description: OUDONG, Cambodia, July 27The retaking of this town earlier this month has been called a major Government victory. But the victorious troops preside over a wasteland.

title: Camera World
description: FOR those interested in a career in professional photography, St. John's University is introducing an Associate in Science degree program which will be conducted at their Queens campus, and at the Germain School of Photography in Manhattan starting in September. Students entering this program will have to complete required courses plus independent studies, with the curriculum designed to provide a liberal arts background as well as the technical and commercial training needed to make a career in professional photography.

title: Rebozo Inquiry Pressed By Jaworski and I.R.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 27The special Watergate prosecutor and the Internal Revenue Service are jointly conducting what sources describe as an intensive, supersecret investigation into the handling of $100,000 cash payment from Howard Hughes that allegedly was used by members of President Nixon's family andWhite House staff.

title: How to Win Mixed Play
description: For pure fun, perhaps the most appealing form of tennis is mixed doubles. It's different from conventional men's or women's competitionbut that, of course, is part of its charm. That, and the fact it's usually approached in a more relaxed spirit.

title: Wrong Without Remedy
description: In its 1954 decision in Brown v. Board of Education; the Supreme Court ruled that separate but equal education was unconstitutional. It has reaffirmed that view in decision after decision during the ensuing twenty years; but last week, in Bradley v. Milliken, a Detroit case, despite reaffirming the essence of the Brown decision, the Court clamped tight limits on the remedies is disposed to grant in order to rectify unconstitutional deprivations suffered by minority school children.

title: Legislative Notes
description: TRENTON  In an unusual move, Senate President Frank J. Dodd ordered tight security measures to be put into effect for last week's decisive action on Governor Byrne's income tax proposal.

title: For Reed, a Summer At the Crossroads
description: Willis Reed has turned from the funloving, easygoing Knick center to depressed and moody man, harassed by pain and the uncertainties about his future.

title: Dining Out in New
description: ***Ye Olde Cedar Inn, 15 Cedar Inn Drive (off Route 37,  mile west of Garden State Parkway Exit 82A W), Toms River (201) 3491256.

title: Police Rape Units Required
description: BOSTON, July 27 (AP)Police departments in Massachusetts now must set up special units to investigate and prosecute rape cases. Gov Francis W. Sargent's office said this week that he had signed a bill. requiring such squads.

title: Card Game in Bronx Leads to Death of Two Men
description: A dispute during a card game in an East Bronx apartment erupted into a shooting Melee early yesterday leaving one man dead from gunshot wounds and his brother wounded. The alleged gunman jumped to Ms death off a bridge over the Bronx River.

title: Music
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival program at Fisher Hall on Friday night was, not even leastly Mozart; it was all Bach. There were four concertos, in all of which Anthony NeWinan doubled as conductor and harpsichordist. (He tripled as organist in a preconcert recital.) He had help as soloists from Paul Robison, flutist, and Ani Ka vafian, violinist, in the Triple Concerto in A minor and Brandenburg Concerto No. 5, and from Susanne Shapiro and Edward Brewer, harpsichordists in the ThreeClavier Concerto in C. Mr. Newman, a brilliant and populaf young Bach specialist, had the great D minor Clavier concerto to himself.

title: A Bankrupt Priest Seeks $19Million From His Brokers
description: CHICAGO, July 27 (UPI)A Roman Catholic priest who made $3million playing the stock market then went bankrupt yesterday filed three lawsuits totalling $19million against three large brokerage concerns.

title: LOSS OF A TOWN BY SAIGON FEARED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 (Reuters)Communist forces, pressing new attacks in the northcentral area of South Vietnam, were believed to have overrun an isolated district capital in the Central Highlands today.

title: Modelmakers Work Gaining New Recognition
description: The model is a necessity of architectural invention, the tool for testing and selling the designer's ideas.

title: Sports News Briefs.
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, July 27 (UPI)  Ford cars held the lead today in the 24hour touring car endurance race which started in brilliant sunshine on the 8.76mile Francorchamps track.

title: The Supreme Court's prescient mavericks
description: Like beer, Supreme Court majority opinions are an acquired taste. It takes some legal experience to savor the careful homogenization of five or more different temperaments, perspectives and philosophies, and the artful distillation of prickly legal precedent, that go into brewing judicial agreement on important constitutional questions. But dissents are often another case. Liberated from the constraints of consensus, inspired by transcendent vision of what Constitution and justice alike require, the great dissenters have on occasion displayed not only an eloquence accessible to most readers, but a gift for what might be called negative prophecy.

title: Neil St. John Raymond To Wed Miss Wheeler
description: Elizabeth Palmer Wheeler will be married to Neil St. John Raymond, managing director of the Raymond Cattle Company in Boston, on Sept. 28 in the Episcopal Church of the Ascension in Ipswich, Mass.

title: Rhodesia Is Moving 60,000 to Prevent Aid to Guerrillas
description: SALISBURY Rhodesia July 27An entire tribal community of 60,000 people is being Moved from its present trust land into 21 protected villages nearby, the Rhodesian security forces have announced Mere.

title: CAREY WILL WORK FOR FREE TUITION
description: Representative Hugh L. Carey, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, said yesterday that he would do all in his power, whether or not he was elected, to preserve free tuition at the City University.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Corning Shuts Pools to Fight Infection

title: The Articles Will Be Treated With All Deliberate Speed
description: WASHINGTON  The articles of impeachment that now seem certain to be sent by the House Judiciary Committee to the full House of Representatives will follow a routine path to the final vote, but that's all that will be routine about them.

title: The two John Stuart Mills
description: Ever since its publication in 1859, John Stuart Mill's On Liberty has

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes: Prospects Brighten for Concorde
description: IS the AngloFrench Concorde supersonic transport plane destined to revolutionize air travel by streaking from continent to continent at nearly 1,400 miles an hourmore than twice the speed of today's jets? A few months ago prospects looked altogether gloomy for the sleek deltawinged jetliner on which Britain and France have lavished billions of dollars. American carriersand they represent half of the world's commercial aircraft markethad turned down the Concorde's salesmen, and there was debilitating opposition to the project within both Britain and France because of the colossal expense. More recently, however. a number of factors have dispersed at least some of the gloom. In Britain and France there is a new ddtermination to push ahead. The view over there is that, having come this far, it would cost just as much to stop the project as it would to go on, says Leo Schefer, an official of the British Aircraft Corporation, which, with Aerospatialehas

title: Holly Ann Drew Is Bride of Scott Osier
description: Holly Ann Drew, daughter of George Raymond Drew of Cincinnati and the late Jean Kefauver Drew, was married there last evening to Scott C. Osier of Arlington, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. David K. Osier of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Stephen Hoard performed the ceremony in the Hyde Park United Community Methodist Church.

title: ExNazi Aide Quits A Parliament Post In a Furor in Bonn
description: BONN, July 27Bowing to public opinion a West German legislator who was an official of the Nazi Embassy in Paris during the occupation says he will give up a parliamentary post that put him in a position to delay ratification of a treaty with France on prosecution of war criminals.

title: POINT OF VIEW;Weak Performance, Weak Image;Business Seeks Best Way to Tell Its Story
description: Inflation and the energy crisis have added an ironic twist to the image problem of American business. If things are as bad as they seem, many people argue, then surely something or someone must be to blame.

title: A Summer GuideDillies and Duds
description: IT'S midsummer, that time of year when it's difficult to keep up with everything in what even taxicab drivers now refer to glibly as the media. Slick magazines become sticky in hot hands, the color comes off on the fingers. Newspapers blow inside out if you're on a beach and, if you're nifit, thgy pile up. at an alarming rate beside favorite chaiis or atop night tables unread: Even television, the instrument for people who take their information intravenously, can be too much at July's end. If you have an ancient set like mine, it gives off more heat than light.learn here. The films are listed alphabetically.

title: Quick Arrest Seen in Killing of 3d Ave. Store Owner
description: Homicide detectives expressed confidence yesterday that there would be a prompt arrest in the slaying last Wednesday of a 31yearold liquorstore proprietor in his establishment on Third Avenue near 72d Street.

title: 51% in Poll Favor Impeachment And 46% Back Removal of Nixon
description: Fiftyono per cent of the Americans surveyed believe that there is enough evidence to impeach President. Nixon land 46 per cent believe he should be removed from office, the latest Gallup Poll shows.

title: Officer Slays Youth, 15, In Thwarting Robbery
description: An offduty corrections officer shot and killed a 15yearold youth and critically wounded a 20yearold male companion after the two had seized him on a Brooklyn street in an attempted robbery, the police reported.

title: A Whole Lamb Done to a Turn in the Greek Tradition
description: WAINSCOTT  While not the typical backyard summer barbecue, for Nicocles Michas, his wife, Jill Barber, and their friends, a whole lamb turning slowly on a spit and glazing to a rich mahogany has become an inoreasingly frequent occurrence.

title: A Noble Goal
description: Mr. Justice Marshall was probably right to say in dissent that the Supreme Court decision in the Detroit school case was a reflection of a perceived public mood rather than the product of neutral principles of law." There is no doubt whatever that public opinion has turned massively against the kind of crossbusing that would have been required to unify Detroit schools with the 53 surroundiog suburban school systems; and the Court could not have been unaware of that.

title: Government Chemist Challenges Her Boss.
description: Modern science has made life infinitely easier for most housewives. It has also made it infinitely more dangerous for the population at large, according to Jacqueline Verrett, research chemist with the Food and Drug Administration in Washington.

title: Pointers on Building Wood Deeks;Home Improvement
description: WODD decks supported above ground on posts or piles are probably the simplest and most practical solution to the problem of building a patio or terrace on sloping ground, or over rocky terrain that would be difficult to cover with conventional outdoor paving or surfacing materials. A wood deck also has other advantagesit is relatively easy for a handy homeowner to construct by himself (so long as it is not a very high structure), it drains well after a rain, and it is cooler and generally more comfortable to walk on than concrete. In addition, openings can be created to permit trees or shrubs to grow up through the deck as a sort of decoration or shade

title: Of Time And a River Of Oil
description: TAIF, Saudi ArabiaThe particular kind of problem facing Saudi Arabia today hasn't been seen around the Middle East since King Midas ruled Phrygia in what is now Turkey. Everything Midas touched immediately became gold, but the unfortunate ruler soon discovered there were limits to its practical uses.

title: Ernest H. Kirschten Dies; Writer for PostDispatch
description: ST. LOUIS, July 27 (AP)Ernest H. Kirschten, veteran reporter and editorial writer for The St. Louis PostDispatch, died yesterday of cancer at his home. He was 72 years old.

title: Legislative Curb Proposed
description: BOSTON, July 27 (AP)The legislature will begin debate on. Monday on restricting the number of bills a member may file, the House Speaker, David M. Bartley, Democrat of Holyoke, told the membership Thursday. Members now may file as many bills as they like.

title: U.S. Sloop Is Sighted
description: CANBERRA, Australia, July 127 (Reuters)The American sloop Quest, reported missing earlier this week, was sighted !last night in the Tasman Sea, the marine operations center reported here this morning. All aboard are apparently well,

title: Mr. Nixon Constitution
description: WASHINGTONLike all strong Presidents, President Nixon has sought to have the nation follow his leadership and accept his decisions. But his conception of the Presidency is radically different from that of. his predecessors: It represents a sharp break with our history and constitutional tradition: The Nixon Administration has challenged our constitutional institutions. It has not merely committed acts in excess of constitutional right and authority. It has boldly confronted us with a new and revolutionary concept of the Presidency.

title: Blacks in Africa Dispute Backed By Lutheran World Federation
description: NORTFIELD, Minn., July 27 Leaders of the Lutheran World Federation voted here last night to support two black African Lutheran churchmen in their dispute with Prime Minister John Vorster of the Republic of South Africa.

title: William Roberts, Law Student, Weds Elizabeth Patricia Hamid
description: Elizabeth Patricia Hamid, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Hamid Jr. of Margate and Princeton, N. J., and William Bailey Roberts, son of Mrs, Raymond B. Roberts of Waban, Mass., and the late Mr. Roberts, were married yesterday afternoon by Msgr. Joseph Stoerline and the Rev, Edward Nelson in the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany in Longport, N. J.

title: Room Quiet, Faces Grim Upon Adoption at 7:05:21
description: WASHINGTON July 27  At 6:40 P.M., Representative Wil liam L. Hungate, the Missour Democrat who has enlivene the House Judiciary Commit tee's impeachment hearing: with his humor, concluded the debate on the last of the pre liminary questions.

title: Child for the Firmans
description: A daughter was born July to Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Firman of Hatonah, N. Y., in the New York Hospital. Mrs. Firman is the former Katherine Major, daughter of Mrs. Theresa Major of New York and Andrew Major of Rutherfordton, N. C. The child is named Linsay Talcott.

title: Hartford Limits Circuit Courts Power
description: HARTFORD, July 27  The Connecticut Supreme Court has ruled that circuit courts may not impose sentences of, morel than one year and that the General Assembly did not have the constitutional right to give the lower courts such power.

title: Mailbag
description: UNFAIR ATTRIBUTION

title: Life Is Elsewhere
description: When he wants to annoy the cultural commissars on his occasional visits to the Soviet Union, the superb Turkish novelist Yashar Kemalsouthern Anatolia's William Faulkner says, Well, Socialist Realism is basically antiMarxist:... It is also, in the right hands, a great recipe for comedy: The pofaced deflation in bureaucratic gibberish, the rigidity that seems designed to collapse amid howls of laughter from its own weight. Understandably, the Czechs are embarrassed by the attention shown to their deflations especially after the heroic fiasco of the Prague Spring. And Philip Roth points out in his introduction to Laughable Loves how skeptical Czech writers are when a foreigner expresses interest in them, as if the predicament is more important than the work and that any outside expression of praise can only be patronizing. Roth quotes the Czech novelist Ludvik Vaculik's lament about foreign critics judging Czech writing according to how it settles accounts with illusions

title: THE DOM CLOSES; TO BE COWPALACE
description: The Dom, the Lower East Side night spot that was popular in the midnineteensixties before going into a steep de cline, formally acknowledged its failing fortunes last night. It closed with the announcement that it would reopen in the fall as The Cowpalace, countryWestern discotheque.

title: Democrats in State Will Choose Convention Delegates in Primary
description: Democrats throughout the state may be unaware of it but they will be asked in the Sept. 10 primary to choose delegates to their party's miniconvention, which will meet in Kansas City Dec, 6 to 8 to draft the party's first national charter.

title: Family Favors One College
description: MIDDLETOWN, Pa., (AP)Virginia Hoelper is a self appointed recruiter for Bucks County Community College. The young woman, who was one of the college's original students in 1965, set the example for her rather large family and has since seen 30 members of her clan enroll at the school.

title: N. F. L. Alumni, Pickets Clash in Canton
The Ghosts of Byzantium Are Still Haunting Greece
description: LONDONOf all the many recurring themes of modern Greek history none has recurred so often or with such dire effect as that which, above all, raises the ghost of old Byzantium. It is what the new Greek Premier, Constantine Caramanlis, has characteristically called the National Question.

title: WORKERS GET LOAN TO BUY SCOTS DAILY
description: LONDON, July 27The British Government has offered to lend $4.2million to a group of newspaper workers to buy up the plant of a Glasgow daily that ceased publication and start their own cooperateive newspaper.

title: Turks, Confident of Strength in Cyprus, Take Strong Line on Talks
description: ANKARA Turkey, July 27Premier Bulent Ecevit, whose shaky minority coalition has been immeasurably strengthened since Turkey invaded Cyprus one week ago, said today: We will not consider any ceasefire proposals separately from effective security measures that will satisfy us.

title: GarbageFree Indiana Town Offers Flies. Slim Pickings
description: JASPER, Ind., July 24 Let's get it straight right now, the former Mayor said. there are flies in Jasper. There was, for instance, one reported fly The Talk sighting recently of near the teleInd, vision set in Jasper,Room 252 of the Holiday, Inn. And Melvin Bauer said he saw one by the courthouse the other day.

title: Ideas &
description: Economic gains made by blacks In the sixties have slowed in the seventies, and last year the income gap between blacks and whites widenedback to its 1966 levelthe Bureau of the Census has reported.

title: Jane Anderson Phillips Engaged
description: Jane Anderson Phillips, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Creighton W. Phillips Jr. of Garden City, L. I., plans to be married in October to Richard Charles Michael Dillon, vice president of the Goffstown (N.H.) News Corporation, publisher of four weekly newspapers in New Hampshire.

title: Vegetable Crop Called Bountiful.
description: TRENTONThe 10 major vegetables ready for harvest during July, August and September in New Jersey have a combined acreage of 36,490, compared with 35,520 acres in 1973, the New Jersey Crop Reporting Service estimates.

title: Son to Mrs. Lefkovits
description: A son was born July 2 to Dr. and Mrs. Albert M. Lelkovitz of New York at the Mount Sinai Hospital. The child has been named Ari Nathan. Dr. Lefkovitz is assistant attending dermatologist at the hospital as well as chief of the phototherapy section in the dermatology clinic.

title: Text of Bipartisan Substitute Article II
description: WASHINGTON, July 27Following is the text of a draft of a second article of impeachment, prepared today by a bipartisan group of House Judiciary Committee members and expected to be introduced on Monday by Robert McClory, Republican of Illinois, as a substitute for a second article pending before the panel:

title: Nation's Cities Fighting to Stem Growth
description: On March 21, the city of St. Petersburg, Fla., adopted an ordinance requiring the last 25,000 people who had settled there to move out.

title: Illinois Bell Is Accused of Harassment
description: WASHINGTON, July 27A woman lawyer has accused the Illinois Bell Telephone Company of dropping her name from both the Chicago telephone di. rectory and its information listing after she began representing a small communications concern in legal actions against the telephone company.

title: QUESTIONS...
description: BITTER TASTE

title: Huffing and Puffing Broadway, Through the Summer Doldrums
description: IN A BURST of oldtime pressagent stuntsmanship grown rare in recent years, Saul Richman, the jocund, middleaged publicist responsible for pro viding Moonchildren with full. audiences, announced in midJuly that astronaut John Glenn would plant his foot (in a moon boot, of , course) in wet cement outside the Theater de Lys last Saturday. Adjacent Bedford Street was to be renamed Moon Street for the occasionthe fifth anniversary of the Apollo 2. moon tripand the menu of. a nearby restaurant would feature fullmoon salad and spaghetti With moonballs. Despite the fact that Glenn personallynever set foot on the moon, his presence, was expected to garner newspaper and television coverage, reminding the public of the continued existence of Michael Weller's corhedy called Moonwhich is about 1960's

title: Chess: Browne Takes Clean Lead, But Don't Count Evans Out
Firemen's Wives Fight For Chauvinism on Job
description: SAN DIEGO, July 27The San Diego Civil Service Commission and the Fire Department have been kept busy this month trying to douse the anger of nearly 300 firemens wives who are determined to preserve the fire station as one of the last citadels of male chauvinism.

title: CAPT. FREDERICK SNYDER
description: Capt. Frederick W. Snyder, retired, senior docking captain for the Moran Transportation and Towing Company, died here July 19 of cancer. He was 58 years old and lived in New York.

title: Jan de Wilde Marries Cathryn Cockerill
description: Cathryn Grace Cockerill and Jan de Wilde, a Foreign Service officer in Washington, were married yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in Quogue, L. I. The Rev. Bernard Tierney performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the East Quogue summer home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick J. Cockerill of Manhsset and East Quogue. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles de Wilde of Alexandria, Va.

title: 2 City Children Die in Crash
description: FREDERICKSBURG, Va., July 27 (AP)Two New York City, children were killed today in a twocar collision on Interstate 95 in Spotsylvania County near here, the Virginia state police said. Ronald Everett, 9 year old and his sister Angela Everett, 13, of 530 Olmstead Avenue, the Bronx, were killed in the accident at 6:15 A.M. The police said their parents, Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Earl Everett, were injured slightly in the crash.

title: Welfare Tied to Living Cost
description: BOSTON July 27 (AP)Massachusetts residents receiving Aid to Families with Dependent Children general relief or state veterans benefits will find their checks increasing in step with the cost of living a year from now. Gov. Francis W. Sargent signed a bill yesterday tying those benefits to the Consumer Price Index.

title: Whistle in the Graveyard; Folktqles to Chill Your Bones. By Maria Leach. Illustrated by Ken Rinciari. 128 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $5.95. (Ages 9 to 13)
description: Some of these 39 brief tales seem more suitable as material for a study of strange human beliefs than as part of a collection for folktales to chill your bones. Though all the threetimesthirteen ghost stories are ghostly, not all are stories and not all are scary. They are retellings in Maria Leach's beautifully unencumbered style concerning personal encounters people from all over the world say they or their acquaintances have had with spooks. Some of these encounters are hairraising. A few are funny but a number are surprisingly inconclusive: The skull chased the man. He ran but it was still there. He got home and it was gone. The chill could be great from a panting, firstperson account but when we hear it thirdperson and unelaborated, it is curious but unsatisfying.

title: New Health Chief Is Acting on Abortions
description: TRENTONThe new State Commissioner of Health, Dr. Joanne E. Finley, says she is determined that her department, which has been criticized for footdragging abortion issues, will seek resolution of  the abortion problem during the next month.

title: Cautious Saigon Press Fails to Report Attacks on Thieu in Assembly Debate
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27Despite assurance from the Premier that the press would be free to report fully on yesterday's questioning of Cabinet members by the National Assembly, leading South Vietnamese newspapers carried accounts that softened much of the dialogue and excluded the numerous attacks on President Nguyen Van Thieu that had echoed through the Assembly chamber during the 15hour session.

title: Police in Seattle Shifting To Compact Patrol Cars
description: SEATTLE, July 27 (UPI)This city's police department has become the first of any major United States city to begin using compact sedans as police patrol cars, the police department says.

title: Dispute on Specificity Reflects Legal History
description: WASHINGTON, July 27For two days the 38 members of the House Judiciary Committee have argued and quibbled and sometimes shouted about the meaning of the word specificcity They have done so partly because of politics, but more so because of lawthe ancient legal requirement that a person is entitled to adequate notice of the claims or charges against him

title: The Nation /Continued
description: Faced with a rising proportion of black students, the nation's urban school systems had turned, in a last effort at racial balance, to mergers with suburban districts. But last week a United States Supreme Court decision made the city limits a virtually impenetrable barrier to busing for school integration.

title: Miss Van Vechten Engaged to Student
description: Stevens (Stevie) Van Vechten, a junior at the University of New Hampshire, and Todd Ernest Thompson, senior there, plan to be married.

title: Hilary Miles Hafela Is Married
description: St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N. J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Hilary Miles Hafela, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Courtney Hafela of Mendham, N. J., to Craig Malcolm Davis.

title: Brooklyn Women's Political Caucus Is Back on Electoral Scene
description: The Brooklyn Women's Political Caucus has reemerged this summerafter a year in disarray following election victories by its leading members in 19.72to support women candidates in three of the borough's more strongly contested primary races.

title: AROUND THE
description: IN THE SUN

title: How many brave but irrelevant books must women writers write to prove they can write like men?; Who's afraid of Erica Jong?
description: An invention: Let us suppose a woman who wants to enter the new territory of feminist thinking through books. She is 30ish, a homemaker and mother of small children. Let's call her Fredericka, because it is a derivative of a man's name; and let's say that before now she received her image of herself from men. In college, male teachers teaching ideas held by men about man"; in novels, male authors writing about men as heroes and women as consortsthat sort of thing.

title: Water Firm Seeks To Expand Supply
description: WEEHAWKENThe The Hackensack Water Company has announced plans to divert water from the Passaic River Basin to meet the needs of 800,000 customers in Hudson and Bergen Counties.

title: Grant for Vitamin Study
description: ST. LOUIS, (AP)A $99,000 federal grant to study brain damage resulting from vitamin E deficiency has been awarded to Dr. James Nelson, associate professor of pathology and pediatrics at the Washington University school of medicine.

title: Red Sox Conquer Yankees
description: BOSTON, July 27Maintaining their almost twoyear jinx over the New York Yankees at Fenway Park, the Boston Red Sox continued their lessthanfirm hold on first place in the American League Eastern Division tonight. They did with a 54 triumph before the largest crowd in Fenway in more than three years.

title: Sam Goldwyn's Oldie Wasn't So Goldie
Kimball Overholt Wed To Marshall Goodwin
description: Kimball Marshall Overholt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George T. Overholt Jr. of New Canaan, Conn was married there yesterday afternoon to Marsall Dana Goodwin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Marshall Lee, Goodwin of Scarborough, Me. The Rev. Grant Morrill performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: News of the Stage
U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Mobile home manufacturers, who have taken a beating this year to the tune of a..30 per cent sales decline from 1973 levels, may soon face more unpleasant news.

title: Reinecke Convicted of Lie On I.T.T. Offer to G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 Lieut. Gov. Ed Reinecke of California was found guilty by a Federal jury today of lying at a hearing in which the Senate Judiciary Committee delved into a corporation's pledge to help finance the Republican National Convention of 1972.

title: Ideas &
description: Professional men and women have always liked to think of themselves as unique, and as having a unique relation to their work. Their specialized training and talent, they have felt, has demanded that they be treated as individuals.

title: Leaders Seek a Coherent Role, Up From Colonialism
description: MEXICO CITYA mood of change pervades the Caribbean, particularly the former British possessions, as the jigsaw of tiny countries and territories struggle to break with their colonial pasts and shape a coherent role for themselves in the world.

title: Keith Carabine Fiance Of Virginia Stone Taft
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd B. Taft of, New York, Lakeville, Conn., and Murray Bay, Quebec, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Stone Taft, to Keith Carabine of Canterbury, England. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Carabine of Manchester, England.

title: Chile's Political Prisoners Are Put at 6,000 Nearly Year After Coup
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 26 Almost as soon as it took power last September in a violent coup that overthrew the late Salvador Allende Gossens, the military government in Chile vowed to provide speedy trials for thousands of its political prisoners and to release those found innocent or without charges against them.

title: O'NEILL SEES MARGIN OF 70 TO IMPEACH
description: HARWICH Mass., July 27 (UPI)Thomas P. O'Neill, the Democratic leader of the House said tonight that President Nixon would be impeached by a margin of about 70 votes in the House

title: Recordings,
description: IN the early sixties Detroit emerged as a music capital when the Motown Sound caught on across the country. Artists like Martha Reeves and the Vandellas, the Temptations, Smokey Robinson and the Miracles, and the Supremes won white rock, as well as black soul, audiences with music that had a smoother, sweeter sound than traditional rhythm and blues records. A distinctive quality of the strong Motown rhythm was the surging bass line as played by James Jamerson, one of the key Motown house musiciansnone of whom were ever really credited on album liner notes for their contributions to the sound. Motown always promoted the image that they were one big happy family all pulling for each other. But as the sixties progressed and the Motown Sound became more of a formula than an innovation, some of the artists began opting for more freedom

title: Aaron Clouts No. 726 In 100 Rout of Dodgers
Providence Best Goes to A Doberman
description: BARRINGTON, R. I., July 27A black and tan Doberman pinscher, Ch. Galaxy's Corry Carina, continued her winning ways today at the 67th annual dog show and obedience trial of the Providence County Kennel Club. The 4yearold bitch, who is owned by Mrs. Cheever Porter of New York and Mr. and Mrs. Frank D'Amico of Glen Cove, LI., registered her 18th best in show.

title: Dr. DeDomenico to Wed Vicki Lindauer
description: Vicki Marie Lindauer, a student at the University of Louisville School of Dentistry, and Dr. Ralph Joseph DeDomenico, who received a dental degree there last month, plan to marry Aug. 24 in Louisville, Ky., where Mr. and Mrs. Victor G. Lindauer of Louisville, parents Of the future bride, have announced the engagement.

title: State to Make Plea. For Energy Center
description: TRENTON  The Federai Energy Office will hear an appeal soon for support of Governor Byrne's efforts to establish a national research and development center on energy in New Jersey.

title: Soviet Vodka Diplomacy Works in a Maryland Town
description: CENTREVILLE, Md.  The people here on Maryland's rural Eastern Shore have detente of their own, complete with diplomatic protocol, state dinners, vodka and caviar.

title: Home Sellers Find the Going Rough
description: Allen Albala of Darien, Conn., spends at least three hours a day driving to and from his job in Cranford, N. J. He has had to do so since January, when the toiletries company for which he works moved its offices out of New York City.

title: The War Between the Tates By Alison Lurie.372 pp. New York: Random House. $6.95.
description: For 10 years, Alison Lurie has regularly produced insightful and witty novels about The Way We Live Now, drawing on a large talent for social verisimilitude. In her fifth book, with the effortless grace of a real ironic gift, she has raised The Way We Live Now into the Human Comedy. The War Between the Tates is a novel not only to read, but to reread for its cool and revealing mastery of a social epoch; something light and bright and sparkling, in Reuben Brower's phrase for Pride and Prejudice"; a nearperfect comedy of manners and morals to put on the shelf next to Vanity Fair or The Egoist.

title: Races On for Primaries
Letters to the Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: SPECIAL DISTRICTS IN STATE DECRIED
description: ALBANY, July 27There are thousands of public bodies and special districts in the state, and a study released this week concludes that many of them should be consolidated or abolished.

title: Cyprus Fighting Abates as Turks Hold Their Ground
description: MYRTOU, Cyprus, July 27The Turkish forces that advanced yesterday to within four miles of this strategically situated village held their ground today as Greek Cypriote National Guard reinforcements moved up from the west.

title: Hot Line Is Working in Morris County
description: MORRISTOWNQuestions are being answered and problems solved throughout Morris County at the rate of 20 a day since the start of the County Hot Line two weeks ago by the Board of Freeholders.

title: Grasshopper Restored To Faneuil Hall Tower
description: BOSTON, July 27 (UPI)The copper grasshopper is back atop Faneuil Hall.

title: Stamps
description: THIS is the peak time of travel, and a good time for a vicarious trip in the world of stamps, a trip that is edifying and scenic, yet without the hassle of rising costs for fares, food and lodgings.

title: Tour Set Thursday of Montauk Houses
description: MONTAUKFour houses with views will be featured on this year's Montauk Historical Society hope tour on Thursday.

title: India Evacuates 10,000
description: NEW DELHI, July 27 (Reuters)Some 10,000 people have been evacuated from Kerala in southern India and more were on the move because of heavy floods, according to reports reaching here.

title: Noted Ware Of Meissen Rare There
description: MEISSEN, East GermanyIn 1709 an alchemist who was trying to create gold from base materials stumbled on a formula for a white European porcelain that has made this ancient medieval town a famous name.

title: KISSINGER ASSURES GREEKS ON TRUCE
description: ATHENS, July 27In several dramatic early morning communications today, Secretary of State Kissinger gave the new Greek Government strong assurances that Washington would back up the fragile ceasefire in Cyprus.

title: Dave Anderson
description: Once a quarterback, always a quarterback. John Unitas retired last week as if he were calling a play in the huddle. Quickly and decisively. I worked out for four or five days, he explained before leaving the San Diego Chargers training camp. But my legs swelled and my knees popped and I decided that to stay would be foolish. End of valedictory. John Unitas was never much on orations. Orders, yes. Orations, no. Quarterbacks aren't speechmakers, they're leaders. When he was with the Baltimore Colts, he once threw a short pass that Tom Matte dropped. They were longtime teammates, but John Unitas snarled at him. Sports of The Times

title: NIXON CONFIDENT
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 27Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said today after the House Judiciary Committee voted in favor of the first article of impeachment that President Nixon still believed the full House of Representatives would reject any article of impeachment.

title: Marginal American Pro Athletes Beckoned to ShangriLa in European Arenas
description: PARIS, July 27  Just as foreign medical schools have found room for students not accepted by United States colleges, Europe is becoming the land of opportunity for American athletes unable to land jobs in major sports leagues.

title: Why Greenspan Said Yes
description: As the elevator hurtled down from 1 New York Plaza, a private club perched high above Manhattan's financial district, Alan Greenspan pondered his future and said wistfully: I wish they would just leave me alone in a room with my census of manufacturers. I'd be happy.

title: THE ECONOMIC SCENE
description: SOME highly interesting, worrisome and potentially significant recent developments on the American economic scene have aroused new debate over the health of the nation's economy and the Government policies that ought to be adopted to deal with its problems.

title: How the world economy got into this mess
description: The world has been slow to realize that we are living this year in the shadow of one of the greatest economic catastrophes of modern history. But now that the man in the street has become aware of what is happening, he, not knowing the why and wherefore, is as full today of what may prove excessive fears as, previously, when the trouble was first coming on, he was lacking in what would have been a reasonable anxiety. He begins to doubt the future. Is he now awakening from a pleasant dream to face the darkness of facts? Or dropping off into a nightmare which will pass away?

title: The Historic Pattern
description: Viewed from the perspective of American constitutional history, United States v. Nixon was an entirely predictable, almost preordained decision. What Chief Justice Warren Burger and his colleagues did was simply to apply a set of unwritten critical principles for reviewing Presidential authority laid down over 170 years ago by the Marshall Court and followed by the mainstream judicial decisions ever since. These provide that:

title: Criminals

title: Texas Highway Deaths Off
description: AUSTIN, Tex. (UPI)  The reduced speed limit on Texas highways has been a major factor in the 27 per cent reduction in highway deaths through the first six months of 1974, says the Texas Department of Public Safety. There were 1,030 deaths through June 1 this year compared to 1,413 for the same period in 1973.

title: The may It Was in Hopewell: Scorching Labor in a Peaceful Glen
description: RAGING inferno in the heart of an idyllic wooded glen was the scene a century and a half ago at the iron plantation of Hopewell Village, near Reading, Pa., where a feudalistic population worked exclusively at a single task, the smelting of iron in a great stone charcoalfired furnace. With that furnace and its surrounding buildings and equipment rescued from decay by the National Park Service, the restored hamlet now looks quite precisely the way it did in the eighteentwenties and thirties, at the height of its glory.

title: The Whitney Trots Out SureSell Itemsand Even Some Overstock
description: OLD loyalties never die at the Whitney Museum of American Art. They simply bore deeper into the woodworkand come out whenever the Whitney mountsas it has now doneanother of its surveys of modern American art. The current exhibition occupies four floors of the museum and includes some 235 works by 35 American painters and sculptors, all drawn from the museum's permanent collection. It ranges from a pleasant 19061907 painting, Picnic Grounds, by the Ashcan School painter, John Sloan, to a group of zanily doctoredup chairssome lethal, others prettily benigncalled Chair Transformations, by contemporary artist Lucas Samaras. The exhibition, therefore, presents a considerable slice of American art history.

title: Lenny's Many Voices
description: UNTIL now, Lenny Williams has been best known as the lead singer with the Tower of Power, one of the hottest bands around since Chicago. Pray for the Lion (Warner Bros. BS 2797) is Williams's debut as a solo artist, and it's a pleasure to see that his career has developed with such good sense.

title: Design
description: A fivestory brownstone should be big enough for any family of four. But not for the Robert Friedmans. Mr. Friedman, a writer with five novels and a biography of Jackson Pollock to his credit, needed room for his 6,000volume reference library and a home office where his secretary could work without interruptions. Abby Friedman, an accomplished cook who enjoys preparing the island specialties of the Caribbean on days when she's not working as a volunteer teacher in Spanish Harlem, wanted a large kitchen where the family could eat and their two teenagers could prepare snacks with their friends. They did not want to give up the privacy of a house, but when they found a gardenlevel duplex with a view of the East River in a nineteenthirties building, they changed their minds about that. Although the apartment had no more space than their house, when the"lost living space of stairs and landings was subtracted and the convenience of large, graciously proportioned rooms on only two levels taken into consideration, the apartment turned out to have much more useful space than the house. Not only that, it met all their demands. There were two maid's rooms that could be turned into an office, and the 30footlong gallery that formed the spine of the living level was a logical library. The oldfashioned pantry and kitchen were combined to make a big 20by15foot eatin kitchen.

title: Button, Milton
description: AT 10:30 A.M., on the 52d day of the WABC Musicradio Button Promotion campaign, WABC but ton spotter Andy Abbate joined, WABC engineer Gil Saffian in the $25,000 Button Promotion War Room at ABC corporate headquarters in midtown Manhattan, preparatory to conducting a field operation. Both Abbate and Saffian were ou.tfjtte4 for incognito work. Abbate, who is abou. 20, wore plaid polyester pants, a shortsleeved blue shirt, white shiny shoes and carried a clipboard. Saffian, who is about 30, was dressed in green shirt, tan polyester pants, white belt, and sneakers. On their left, as they entered the Button Promotion War. Room, was a giant map of the WABC listening area, covered with little red markers that indicated with martial precision the location of previous field operationsoperations undertaken on days 1 through 51 of the Button Promotion. Next to the giant maP were two gold drumsthe Location.. Drum containing sealed envelopes listening area stated inside, and the Prize Drum with prize certificates in it. Directly in front of Abbate and Saffian was a little plastic bucket full of buttons calling attention to the Button Promotion.

J. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jessica Ada Rinaldi, to Julio Enrique DeArcos, son of Cristina DeArcosLopez Ofia of Miami and the late Julio (Monchy) DeArcos, who was a lawyer in Havana and a scout for the Cleveland Indians baseball team.

description: HACKENSACK, N.J. July 27 (AP) A preliminary hearing for George North of Englewood Cliffs, N.J, charged with the decapitation slaying of his wife, has produced testimony indicating his wife planned to marry another man.

Powell Alexander Fraser Jr., U.S.N., son of Dr. and Mrs. Fraser Sr. of Bristol, Tenn., were married yesterday by the Rev. William R. Senge in the 200yearold Presbyterian Meeting House in Alexandria.

description: TAKE it out, says George C. Scott. Too much suffering, for God's sake.

description: In granting an extension of tax exemption to Stuyvesant Town, a redevelopmentcompany project, the State Legislature failed to provide that overincome tenants would have to pay rental surcharges, as such tenants do in MitchellLama developments.

title: A Vivid But Not So Hot Cat
description: TENNPMILT WILLIAMS is famous for his long gallery of doomed romantics, dreamers whose aspirations toward ideal purity make it impossible, for them to live in the real world. Amanda Wingfield, Blanche DuBois, Alma ill we know them all so well. But they do tend to blend into one another; as Mr. Williams continues to create them it becomes clear that they are metaphorical selfportraits, and that his indulgence toward them is a fOrin of selfindulgence.

title: Congress on Trial
description: After the Judiciary Committee's vote, the question is now up to the House, but one thing is clear. Somebody is obviously going to be impeached: the President, the Congress or the American ideal. The President, the courts and the press have had their turn. Now: the Congress.

Country rock did not actually take over the rock business, but it did maintain a foothold, and Poco, which was the headline at Friday's Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park, is still around and playing.

title: Chazalon: French Poet of Basketball:
description: In France, they chant her name, Chazalon, Chazalon, as she takes the court, and thousands of schoolgirls and schoolboys imitate her flashy style. She wears a spangled headband, dribbles between her legs, behind her back, shoots hook shots with both hands, double pumps on jump shots and, best of all, she sometimes employs an aroundtheback layup that always draws a roar from the crowd.

title: Singapore's Bank Boom
description: SINGAPORE  Beneath potted palms and gently creaking ceiling fans, bankers and businessmen gathered around the Hotel Raffles last week to sip rum coolers and converse. Their talk, though, mirrored none of the old Maughamian image of indolence and intrigue that characterized this seaport town for half a century. That image has long since given way here to a new moneytheism.

title: Real Facts About Food Published by Federal Unit
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The Agriculture Department has produced a booklet that officials said contained the real facts about what was happening to food prices.

title: EXCURSION VESSEL IMPOUNDED HERE

description: MONTVILLE, N. J., July 28More than 1,500 Croatians celebrated their new campground here today with a barbecue of 120 lambs, 14 pigs and mounds of beef patties called cevapcici.

title: BENJAMIN GERDY
description: Benjamin Gerdy, who taught history for 30 years in Abraham Lincoln and Erasmus Hall Hall High Schools in Brooklyn, died Saturday in Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn. He was 80 years old and lived at 110 Shore Boulevard in Brooklyn.

title: Fire Posts 5329 Rout; Kellar Star
Jackson 5 (Now 6) Taps Fans Energy For Extra Voltage
description: The audience as star: Reaction and energy flow from stage to seating and back again at a Jackson Five concert. Madison Square Garden was jammed Saturday for the Jackson Five, and it was a surging audience, full of protein and vigor. Aisles were cleared and promptly clogged again. Seats were used for standing, and the result was a view of the six soulsinging brothers  the youngest now works with the others  through a forest of undulating trouser legs.

title: Blueberries in Excess
description: PORTLAND, Maine, July 28 (AP)Forecasts of a plentiful Maine blueberry crop are expected to cut into demands by producers for a record price of at least 30 cents a pound, according to a survey of independent growers. It's a simple case of supply and demaniwe're oversupplied." said (issie Merrill, owner of Merrill Blueberry Farms in Ellsworth.

title: Manuel Elkins Dead at 68; Picture Editor of The Mirror

No matter What the urging on previous occasions, Presidents steadfastly had maintained that the Federal Government was apart from such eruptions; they had always been left to blow themselves out.
