description: The Central Park Zoo's two adult hippopotamuses, Falstaff and Rosey, and their yearold offspring, Daisy, are scheduled to be taken within a week to a new zoo in Toronto. They will be replaced by two pygmy hippos.

title: Cranach Display in Basel Recalls a European Era
description: BASEL, SwitzerlandDuring the years immediately after World War II, a certain general disfavor hung over all things German. Germany itself was in no shape to plead its case and where the great pantings of the past was concerned, Italy, France and the Netherlands had for 10 years and more a monopoly of International attention. The European exhibitions that everyone went to were in Venice, in Paris, in London, and (for the tercentenary of Rembrandt) in Amsterdam and The Hague.

title: 2 Republican Challengers Kept From Ballot Upstate
description: ALBANY, July 29 (AP)The State Board of Elections today ruled two Republicans off the ballot in their efforts to challenge Hamilton Fish Jr. and Richard E. Schermerhorn, Republican incumbents.

description: PAPILLION, Neb. (AP)A framed coin in the living room of the Dale Jarvis hone is quite a neighborhood conversation piece.

Arlen Realty and Development, through a subsidiary, already owns twothirds of the 1.5 million Atlantic shares outstanding, and the Arlen shares will be voted for the merger plan.

Before the day was done, Mr. Kerner became Federal prisoner No. 00037123.

ALBERT C. MOSER
description: Albert C. Moser, who retired recently as an art dealer and picture framer at 53d Street and Lexington Avenue, died lyesterday. He was 84 years old and lived at 319 East 50th Street.

title: Impeachment Vote Scored
description: TORONTO, July 29 (AP)The Rev. John McLaughlin, the Jesuit priest who is an aide to President Nixon, today assailed the voting of an impeachment article by the House Judiciary Committee as unjust and unconstitutional. Father McLaughlin, here to address the joint convention of the United States National Newspaper Association and the Canadian Community Newspapers Association, made the remark in an interview.

title: CHRYSLER NET OFF
description: DETROIT, July 29  The Chrysler Corporation reported today earnings of $27.8million in the second quarter, down 74 per cent from a year ago but a marked improvement from the 98 per cent drop registered in the first quarter.

description: Outstanding checks issued by the city as long ago as 1960 were discovered last year still carried on the city's books, according to officials in Controller Harrison J. Goldin's office.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Politeness and Violence Mix in Cyprus
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, July. 28 The clay before the Cypriote war broke out; Harry Haynes, a communications specialist at the United States radio transmitter just outside the capital, and his wife were resting in their room at the Nicosia Hilton. Suddenly a burst of :50caliber machinegun fire smashed through one wall of the room, stitching a row of twoinch lead slugs ihto the wall above his head.

title: COMPANY OFFICIAL IS SLAIN IN QUEENS
description: The 40yearold vice president and office manager of a Queens laboratory was found murdered in the company's warehouse late yesterday afternoon, apparently the victim of a robbery.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: Christi Pastore wanted to join the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour six years ago, but she was pregnant. She was pregnant again the next year, too. Then there were the diaper years that followed when she could manage only to play a few weekday rounds at her home club, Beaver Brook, in Clinton, N. J.

title: Beef Joins Oil as Source Of World's Latest Woe
description: MOSCOW, July 29Cowboys of the world  beef seems to be taking a modest place next to oil as one of the latest sources of international trouble, and like oil, it. cuts across all other divisions.The latest crisis was precipitated on July 16 by a decision of the European Economic Community to ban beef imports by member countries until next November. In addition, it was reported from Paris yesterday that the Common Market has begun dumping its beef surplus on the Soviet Union.Some meat producers in Communist countries might have expected the Russians to have helped support the beef market. Instead, it seems that the Soviet Union has been buying up Western Europe's beef surplus at $830 a ton  a bargain in vew of the world price of $1,000 a ton,Makes the Mouth Water1 can't wait for some of that good meat to reach the Moscow stores, if it ever does, one Russian said. The thought makes the mouth water.Hungary, one of Europe's most important suppliers of beef, takes a different view. Charging that Western Europe had banged the door on Hungarian meat, the newspaper Magyar Hirlap of Budapest commented:The Common Market authorities and the governments behind them want the Hungarian national economy, among others, to finance their own economic and political blunders.The Hungarians have not commented on Moscow's eager readihess to buy up the beef surplus at cutrate prices, but Hungary's profitminded collective farm managers are not likely to be pleased.Italy a Big CustomerYugoslavia, one of Europe's biggest beef exporters, is furious at the turn of events, Yugoslavia sells beef to the United States Seventh Army in West Germany, which presumably will go on eating steak, come what may. But a vastly more important customer is neighboring Italy.Not only have Italians come to insist on beef in creasingly with the passing years, but Italian hotels and restaurants have an insatiable need for beef to feed tourists  especially Germans. Traditionally, Yugoslav beef is excellent and cheap.But the Italian national economy has suffered more than most others in Western Europe recently, and the hard fact everywhere these days is that beef is just too expensive for most people most of the time.Consequently, Italy decided last spring to halt imports of Yugoslav beef for a while, and, from that moment, Ital. ianYugoslav relations have gone from bad to worse, At one point a few months ago, the two countries were talking as if they were on the verge of war over the longcontested Trieste border area.The Soviet army weighed in on Yugoslavia's side in an article in the Red Army newspaper, Krasnaya Zvezda, declaring with President Tito that the borders of European countries are inviolable,Warm Reception ReceivedBut now, as Moscow buys up cheap surplus beef in West Europe (mostly from France and Ireland thus far), relations between Moscow and Rome have never seemed so warm. Foreign Minister Aldo Moro of Italy is enjoying an extremely warm reception in the Soviet Union at the moment and has just signed a farreaching 10year economic cooperation pact with the Russians.

title: Debate on U. S. Nuclear Policy: Just What ls Strategic Superiority?
description: WASHINGTON, July 29In Moscow a feW weeks !!al Secretary of State Kissing answered a question on United States nuclear power With question of his own. What in God's name, he asked at a news @News@ conference, is @Analysis@ strategic superiority? Whatever the answer, he said later, Americans should have a chance to debate this an other questions about detente and national security after he returned home.

description: In some sections of Idaho, bumper potato crops have sent farmers and their wives on a jewelrybuying binge. They have been buying 1carat and 1 carat diamond ring's at $3,000 to $8,000.

description: SPRINGFIELD, ILL., July 28 (UPI)A seventh employe ofl the Norfolk F. Western Railway Company, Inc., died Sunday of injuries he suffered July 19 in a Lankcar explosion the rail yards at Decatur, Ill.

description: WASHINGTON, July 29 The House Judiciary Committee voted overwhelmingly tonight to adopt a second article of impeachment charging that President Nixon failed repeatedly to carry out his constitutional oath and duty to uphold the nation's laws.

title: FIRE ON EAST SIDE IS FATAL TO PRIEST
description: A priest died and more than a dozen others were rescued by firemen using aerial ladders and the platforms of tower ladders, last night, when a threealarm fire of suspicious origin erupted in the priory of St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church, at Lexington Avenue and 65th Street.

title: 3 Plead Not Guilty in Case Involving Senator Gurney
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 29 (AP)Earl M. Crittenden, former state Republican chairman from Orlando, and two Federal housing officials pleaded not guilty today to conspiracy charges in connection with an influencepeddling case involving Senator Edward Gurney, Republican of Florida.

title: Industry Disagrees on the Future of Fish Prices Here
description: The wholesalers, retailers and restaurateurs who deal with fish on Fulton Street do not agree on whether the price is going up or down. And those who monitor the industry seem to be equally divided.

title: Staff Memo Hints Impoundment May Not Be Impeachable Offense
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)  President Nixon may not have committed an impeachable offense by impounding funds appropriated by Congress, even though the courts have deemed some impoundments illegal, the impeachment inquiry staff has suggested.

description: Silver futures on the Commodity Exchange jumped the daily limit of 20 cents an ounce yesterday, a rise attributed mostly to lack of confidence and the House Judiciary Committee's vote Saturday on an article of impeachnient of President Nixon.

description: LONDON, July 29 (AP)A worker at a cigarette factory in. Bristol was slightly injured today when she opened a package containing an incendiary device, the police said.

description: WASHINGTONIt is, of course, postulate of democracy that majorities are usually right. But a constitutional democracy, recognizing that majorities may sometimes be wrong circumscribes their power by stipulating certain unalienable individual rights and by affording protection for the expression of minority or dissenting views.

The aircraft, which are among those being leased to Delta Air Lines, Inc., are to be delivered to Ozark during the firsthalf of next year.

Such payments are illegal.

description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., July 29  Federal Energy Admin istrator John C. Sawhill urge( the governors of the energy rich Western states today overcome their fears of rigic Federal regulation and to sup port the Administration': package of energy bills.

The Senate clearei. the bill for White House action last week by agreeing to accept the House provisions on gold ownership as part of a bill authorizing $1.5billion for the International Development Association. an agency of the World Bank.

title: ARAFAT OFF TODAY FOR TALKS IN SOVIET

Multitudes of Campers Parents
description: LIBERTY, N.Y., July 28In defiance of biological law, there seemed to be about six parents for each child. On Parents Day at Camp Shornria, the soccer field became a picnic area, with appetite rampant unto the farthest horizon. Then it became a parade ground, with multitudes marching to the call of the child. There is only one Parents Day each summer, so there was no time to waste.

The deficit totaled $916million, compared with $1.3billion in April, $1.2billion in March and $1.04billion in February. The loss for the first five months of the year totals $5.349billion, which exceeds the deficit for the whole of 1973.

description: TRENTON, July 30 (AP)Gerardo Catena, a reputed Mafia boss, got a step closer to freedom today when a judge ruled that he had demonstrated that he would never testify about organized crime before a state commission.

title: Chilean Court Condemns Four And Imprisons 56 in Mass Trial
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, July 30 (AP)(AP)An air force courtmartial today condemned four persons to death by firing squad and sentenced 56 to prison in the mass trial of persons seized after last year's coup against the Marxist coalition Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens. SANTIAGO, Chile, July 30

description: WASHINGTON, July 30Robert McClory had no ambition to practice law, and once he became a lawyer he did not want to be a politician. Twelve years after he was elected to the House of Representatives from Illinois, he was deadset against voting to impeach President Nixon. Last night, Mr. McClory did just that, and today he introduced an impeachment article of his Mon in the News

title: Stein Sees Little Easing of Inflation; Burns Reaffirms TightMoney Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters)  Two Government economic leaders today offered gloomy forecasts for the United States economy for the rest of 1974. They predicted rising unemployment, higher than expected inflation, continuing high interest rates and a drop in the ,gross national product.

title: Redman Agrees to Give Penske's Porsche a Spin
description: His face is twotoned, the result of bad burns suffered in a 1969 crash. He has retired once and moved to South Africa once. This year he quit Formula One racing because he doesn't like the hustle and bustle, the press sure of the grand prix scene. But Brian Redman, a 37yearold Englishman who is one of the most underrated drivers in the world, wasn't fast enough to run from Roger Penske's offer for a CanAm ride. Penske is brushing off the dust on the 12cylinder turbocharged Porsche 917/10 that Mark Donohue drove to the CanAm championship last year, and will try the car in the MidOhio race Aug. 11.

title: Bank Consolidation Set
description: LONDON, July 30 (AP)The Bark of America said today that its three European merchant bank in London, Paris and Luxembourg had been consolidated into one entity based in Luxembourg. The new entity called Bank of America International, S.A., will be owned 55 per cent by the parent Calfornia S 7/8by the parent California bank, 22.5 per cent by Banque de Paris et des Pays Bas and 22.5 per cent by Kleinwort Benson with a paidin capital of $30million.

title: The Turks on Cyprus
description: The Cyprus ceasefire accords reached yesterday amount to an interim settlement opening the door to confederation or even the eventual partition of Cyprusunless agreement can be found on new arrangements, acceptable to Turkey, giving nearautonomy to the Turkish Cypriotes in a unified island.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ZOO STORY It's hot or it's muggy, and you sometimes forget about the things around town that are always there for visits that can be enjoyed by an entire family. So why not stop by the king of the city's zoos, the Bronx Zoo, which has a lot of things going for it, geared specially for children in the summer?

description: SHIP BOTTOM, July 30The state police announced today that they had arrested four men and seized 32 pounds of highI quality cocaine in a motel room) here on Sunday when they attempted to help one of the men whom they believed to be seriously ill.

description: When business is kicked in the shins, every stockholder and every employe is entitled to shout ouch,  J. Paul Lyet, chairman and chief executive officer of the Sperry Rand Corporation, said at the company's annual meeting yesterday.

title: Two Aides of Gold Called To Testify in Rinaldi Case
description: Two assistant district attornets on the staff of District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklym will be called to testify tOday in the trial of Supreme Court Justice Dominic S. Rinaidi, who is charged with perjury and obstructing governmental administration.

title: Sears Expects Lower Net in the Quarter
description: Sears, Roebuck & Co., Inc., the nation's largest retailer, expects that its net income in the second quarter ending today will be lower than last year. The company forecast yesterday that its earnings would equal 95 cents a share, against a restated $1.02 a share in the like 1973 quarter.

title: MRS. HUGH CHISHOLM, SOCIETY FIGURE, 53
description: Mrs. Hugh Chisholm, a wellknown society figure who was active in charity work, died Saturday at the American Hospital, NeuillysurSeine, near Paris, She was 53 years old. She had homes here and in France.

title: Indian Museum Weighs Move to the Southwest
description: Beset by problems of funding, inaccessibility to the public and an investigation by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz's offite into its deaccessioning policies, , the Museum of the American Indian, home ,of the world's greatest collection of Indian material of the Americas, is actively considering a move out of New York City.

title: District One Board Limits Food Plan After Bitter Debate
description: The majority bloc of the Dis trict 1 school board last nigh renewed a contract for the dis trict's school feeding progran on a limited twomonth basis amid charges by minoritygrout members of the board that the limitation was a stalling tactic designed to force the program back into the control of the central Board of Education.

title: Donald V. Seibert Is Set to Head Chain
description: Donald V. Seibert, vice president and director of corporate planning and development of the J. C. Penney Company, was selected yesterday to become chairman and chief executive officer of the country's secondlargest retail chain. The 51yearold Mr. Seibert will succeed William M. Batten, who retires Oct. 1 but will remain as a director.

title: Saigon Forces List Retaking of Outpost And Loss of a Town
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, July 30 (AP)North VietnaMese forces seized a district capital in the Central Highlands today, while farther north hundreds of tankled Government reinforcements recaptured one of seven outposts lOst the day before, according to reports from the field.

description: A 56yearold former mental patient, allegedly found crouching in an areaway beside West Side church, was seized yesterday in the culmination of a nightlong police effort to halt a sudden wave of church arson that claimed a priest's life.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 The Senate refused today to cut off debate on legislation that would establish an agency intended to represent consumer interests within the Federal Government.

description: NEW DELHI, July 30 (Reuters)Earkh tremors were reported over a large area of Asia today, stretching from Soviet Central Asia across the Himalayas to Pakistan and India.

description: GENEVA, July 30  Greece, Turkey and Britain signed a declaration here tonight imposing a new ceasefire on Cyprus and providing for further negotiation, starting Aug. 8, on its political problems.

description: A holdup suspect was slain in an exchange of gunfire with the police in Queens last night minutes after he reportedly escaped from a Jackson Heights pharmacy with an undetermined amount of money.

Black Quarterback Will Start for Jets in Opener
description: John Jones, who patterned his passing style after Joe Namath's, was selected yesterday to become the first black quarterback to start a game for the Jets.

description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP)Average gasoline prices dropped in 10 states last week but the average nationwide price of gasoline remained unchanged, the American Automobile Association said today.

Howes, executive vice president of the New York City Association. Mr. Lenoir, who has been executive director of the Harlem Y.M.C.A since 1970, will continue in that post until a suc, cessor has been chosen.

title: Goldin Sells Chase $325Million Bonds At a Record 7.69%
description: Controller Harrison Goldin interrupted his vacation abroad yesterday long enough to award $324.9million in longterm city bonds at an average rate of 7.69 per cent, the highest longterm interest rate in the city's history.

description: MADRID, July 30Generalissimo Francisco Franco, who entered the hopital three weeks ago with an attack of phlebitis complicated by bloodclots, walked out today.

The only question, when the committee met today to News debate the proAnalysis posed Article III, was whether that defiance added up to an impeachable offense. To some observers, it should have been easy. It wasn't, as the debate  and the vote

title: Democratic Coalition to Meet To Choose 2 New Candidates
description: The New Democratic Coalition announced yesterday that its delegate assembly would hold a special meeting Saturday to replace two candidates who dropped out of contention since the liberal group gave them its endorsements last May 11.

title: GOVERNORS TOLD OF A FOOD CRISIS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 30 Governors of the nation's richest farm states were warned today that, in the near future, politicians would have to detide either to let people in Africa and Asia starve or persuade Americans to reduce their consumption of energy and give up meat at least once a week.

title: CHARLES WOODWARD
description: FAIRMONT, Minn., July 30 (UPI)  Charles Woodward, owner of Radio Station KSUM, died Sunday night. He was 56 years old. Mr. Woodward bought KSUM in 1962 after 22 years as an accountant with the Westinghouse Broadcasting Company.

title: About New York
description: There were something like 6 million visitors in New York last year, about 1.6 million of them from overseas, and the question naturally arises as to why they bothered* to come. The answer, of course, is that they came to see Manhattan, which is the capital of New York, and, some think, of the world, too.

title: Court Rules Relief Boards Can Collect Overpayments
description: TRENTON, July 30  The New Jersey Supreme Court overturned two lower court nilings today and held in a 5to0 landthark decision that a county welfare board was empowered to sue to recover excess dependentchild payments made to welfare recipients.

title: President Surrenders 11 Tapes to Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, July 30President Nixon, after a final review of their contents, surrendered today the first group of subpoenaed Watergate tapes that the Supreme Court had ordered him to turn over to Federal District Judge John J. Sirica.

title: GRAND JURY INDICTS 3 IN STOCK FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) A federal grand jury indicted three businessmen today on charges of obtaining more than $1million in a stock fraud scheme.

description: DETROIT, July 30The Ford Motor Company will cut its, capital spending in the United, States by more than $220million next year, its chairman, Henry Ford 2d, said today.

title: PowerSharing on Cyprus Is Still the Major Problem
description: ATHENS, July 30The firstround Cyprus talks in Geneva have dealt this week with comparatively simple matters: the conditions for a ceasefire, the size of the buffer zones, the shortrange status of Turkish troops. The difficulties encountered during these negotiations already give some sense of the size of the task still ahead  finding a longrange formula for the political future of the island. Much has changed in Cyprus in the last two weeks, since Archbishop Makarios was overthrown the Greekled National Guard and Turkey invaded the island. But the core of the problem remains essentially the same.

title: MRS. JAMES G. HALL
description: Mrs. Tamara Orousof Hall, widow of Col, James Goodwin Hall, vice president of the GrahamPaige Corporation and a photoreconnaissance group commander in World War 11, died Monday at her home, 320 East 57th Street. She was 72 years old.

title: Market Place:
British Scan Insiders
description: Interest in establishing rules to govern insider stock trading in Britain has been spurred by an official report on doubtful stock dealings involving a former Lord Mayor of London and his associates. Details on Page 46.

title: Thunderstorm
description: In the city, the thunderstorm is a break in the weather, the climax of a heat wave and the forerunner of a cooler interval. In the suburbs the thunderstorm cools things off, is good for the lawn and the fairways and saves the flowers from midsummer scorching. the country it is a godsend, after blistering heat that has curled the corn and parched the pastureland. It a benison, unless the farmer has twenty acres of hay down and in windrows, ready to bale tomorrow.

title: Arson Suspect a Loner Drivento Bizarre Deeds
description: A portrait of Gordon Earl Marais as a quiet, nomadic loner with a history of psychiatric problems and a recent tendency to bluster emerged yesterday in interviews with his relatives and acquaintances.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 30The National Urban League reported today that the spending income of black families declined last year by 2 per cent.

title: Mackinac Race Won By Dora IV
2 ARTICLES FAIL, TO WIN IN PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The House Judiciary Committee rejected tonight an article, of impeachment that proposed to remove President Nixon from office for tax fraud and for accepting improvements to his private property at Government expense.

title: Accountable Presidency
description: By a margin of 21 to 17substantially narrower than its divisions on the first two articles of impeachmentthe Judiciary Committee yesterday voted a charge against the President which is at least as close to the heart the case against him as the charge that he abused the powers of his office.

title: LOIS LONG IS DEAD; FASHION EDITOR
description: Lois Long, the former fashion editor of The New Yorker magazine, died Monday at Saratoga, N.Y. She was 73 years old and a fashion consultant for the magazine at her death.

title: Bohack Seeks Reorganization; Shifts Top Executives of Chain
New Jersey Sports
description: ORADELL, July 30Barbara Burek may be the first woman athlete to have turned down an athletic scholarship in an era when not too many are being offered to women. The 5foot3inch Garfield resident, who graduated from Bergen Community College in Paramus in June, was captain of the basketball team in her last year.

This year he quit Formula One racing because he doesn't like About the hustle and bustle, the presMotor sure of the grand Sports prix scene. But Brian Redman, a 37yearold Englishman who is one of the most underrated drivers in the world, wasn't fast enough to run from Roger Penske's offer for a CanAm ride. Penske is brushing off the dust on the 12cylinder turbocharged Porsche 917!10 that Mark Donohue drove to the CanAm championship last year, and will try the car Penske quit the CanAm series when the Sports Car Club of America legislated against the dominant Porsches by restricting fuel consumption so that the turbocharged cars Would have to make a pit stop.

title: Construction Contracts Value For June Is Reported Down 14%
description: A decline In the nonbuilding category of construction and continued weakness in housing resulted in a 14 per cent drop In constructioncontract value in June, compared with June, 1973, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Hong Kong Getting Chinese Who Flee Rural Duty
description: HONG KONG, July 30 It's an old story, with an ebb and flow that is almost as regular as the tides, and no one seems to notice when the tide is a little swollen. But the fact is that the number of illegal immigrants fleeing to this overcrowded British colony from the adjacent Chinese province of Kwangtung Is higher now than it has been in a decade.

title: WarnerLambert Net Up By 14.9%
GUILTY PLEAS LAID TO JAIL ANXIETIES
description: A former director of mental health services at the Tombs, who also visited inmates at the. Brooklyn House of Detention for Men, testified yesterday that the anxiety and stresses of prolonged pretrial detention often impelled defendants to plead guilty to lesser charges.

title: Contract Awards
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation received $25.2million in Navy contracts, including a $22.9million addition to an award with the Lockheed California Company for SBA antisubmarine aircraft.

title: NEW INDICTMENT OF HUGHES ISSUED
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 30Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire recluse, was indicted on stock manipulation charges tonight by a Federal grand jury that overrode the wishes of Department of Justice officials in Washington.

title: Judge Retains Tombs Closure Order; City Must Submit Improvement Plan
description: Judge Morris E. Lasker refused yesterday to stay his order to close the Manhattan House of Detention for Men by Aug. 10 unless the city submitted a plan to improve conditions for inmates.

title: AMEX PRICES OFF AS VOLUME RISES
O'Neill Center Thrivinging in 10th Season
description: WATERFORD, Conn. Midway through the 10th season at the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center, writers, directors and actors were guiding 12 new American plays through rehearsal and on to the stage. Young critics were sharpening their craft at the National Critics Institute. There was a continuing conference on children's theater.

title: DOCTORS JOIN CALI FOR HOSPITAL All
description: Physicians, nurses and ther staff members at Coney Island Hospital joined community groups yesterday in a demonstration that tied up traffic along a twoblock stretch of Ocean Parkway, between Avenue Z and Shore Parkway, for 15 minutes, starting at 2:30 P.M.

title: Body Found on Cape
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 30 (AP)The police are investigating a couple of footprints near a dismembered body found in the sand dunes a mile east of Race Point on Cape Cod. Officials say the unidentified woman, who the police estimate to have been between 30 and 40 years old, was found by a woman walking her dog in the area.

title: PRICES SLASHED BY BOND DEALERS
Black Rider Achieves a First at Spa
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30Jaines Long, the Harlemborn jockey who rode to his first victory July 4 at Aqueduct, made history of a sort today.

title: In Europe. It's Skirts, Skirts Everywhere
description: PARISIt's not that pants are obsolete. Hardly, It's just that skirts are coming out of the closet. In Paris and Rome, the streets are dotted with women of all ages and from all countries who are rediscovering the pleasures wearing skirts. Some have become as dedicated to skirts now as a year ago they were to pants, We've been masculine for so long, said Paula Marie Goodwin,

title: Montclair Hospital Is Picketed In Impasse Over Pension Issue
description: MONTCLAIR, July 30 Nonprofessional employes of Mountainside Hospital here demonstrated in front of the institution during their lunch hour today to demand changes in their pension plan for their new contract.

title: DR. ALEKSANDR TUR
description: MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI)Dr. Aleksandr F. Tur, head of the Leningrad Pediatric Institute, died Wednesday, Leningradskaya Pravda reported. He was 79 years old.

title: 3 St. Louis Landmarks Saved by New Owners
description: ST. LOUIS, July 30 Weeds stand several feel high in the walled courtyard! of the Spanish Pavillion, the jewel of the New Yorlt World's Fair, that was brought here after the fair closed in 1965. Deep cracks rend its white stucco facade. Its backers went bankrupt in 1970.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: State Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel has denied a request by landlords to order the city to authorize immediate rent increases of up to 7.5 per cent in hundreds of thousands of rentcontrolled apartments. Such increases may be permitted annually under the rentcontrol program's maximumbaserent formula, provided current rents are below maximum levels calculated under the formula and landlords have met certain requirements involving expenditures and removal of violations.

title: 2 G.O.P. Conservatives Appeal for Impeachment
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 Two stanch Republican conservatives  one a former Administration official and the other a member of the House called today for President Nixon's impeachment.

title: 15 N.F.L. Players Report to Camp
description: Four starters were among 15 established National Football League players who arrived at their training camps yesterday, the N.F.L. Management Council reported. The four were Royce Smith, Atlanta guard; Clarence Duren, St. Louis defensive back; George Buehler, Oakland guard, and Ernie Holmes, Pittsburgh defensive tackle.

title: House May Reconsider Impeachment Schedule
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The timetable for action by the House of Representatives on the articles of impeachment against President Nixon appeared to slip a bit today.

title: INDIANS ASSAIL U.S. ON MALARIA STUDY
description: NEW DELHI, July 30AntiAmerican feelings over what was characterized as secret United States sponsored malaria research flared up in Parliament today, with one member of the Communist party charging that Americans are planning to unleash germ warfare on India.

title: Bridge:
description: Exactly why men dominate tournament bridge is a question that has been often argued, but never answered satisfactorilyat any rate the satisfaction of feminist advocates. But there is no argument about the f4ts.

title: Phelps Dodge Unit Raises Prices on Copper Products
description: The Phelps Dodge Copper Products Company, a unit of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, announced yesterday increases in its fabricating charges (selling price less metal value) for all bare and tinned round wires and cables, copper in rolls (strip), drawn copper (bar) and square and rectangular wire. The advances of about 2 to 5 cents a pound, effective on Aug. 1, were made to partially offset higher operating costs, the company said.

title: Bishops Suspend 2 of 11 Women Ordained as Episcopal Priests
description: Two of the 11 women who were ordained as Episcopal priests in Philadelphia on Monday in defiance of church laws were suspended yesterday by the Bishops of the dioceses in which the women had been serving as deacons.

title: House Committee Approves Bill to Lift Tobacco Price
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The House Agriculture Committee approved a measure today that would increase by 10 per cent the Government's support price for fluecured and burley tobacco.

title: TRANSIT MD BILL BEATEN IN HOUSE; 350 FARE PERILED
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The House of Representatives today resoundingly defeated a move to give $800million in Federal subsidies to urban masstransit systems, including the New York City subways.

title: A Burning Question on Menus What's Frozen?
description: The only food frozen at 21 is the ice cream and the ice cubes, said Jerry Berns, vice president and host of the plush Manhattan restaurant.

title: Smith's Party Wins Landslide Victory in Rhodesia
description: SALISBUR Y, Rhodesia, Wednesday, July 31 (Reuters) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and his Rhodesian Front swept hack to power today with a landslide general election victory, crushing opposition challengers and seeming certain to win all 50 white seats at stake.

title: U. S. Steel Profit Sets Record
description: The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday that the secondquarter earnings were the highest for any quarter in the company's history. As a result, the board voted to increase the quarterly dividend by 10 cents, to 60 cents a share.

title: Kapp's Suit May Change N.F.L. Rules
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 The antitrust suit that may wipe out the Rozelle rule and other contract restrictions, regardless of any settlement of the National Football League players strike, is quietly moving through Federal court here. The next set of key arguments is scheduled for Aug. 19.

title: Seoul Detains 2 Irish Priests as Church Conflict With Park s Regime Deepens
description: SEOUL, South Korea, July 30 Two Irish Catholic priests have been detained for interrogation by the Korean Central Intelligence Agency, it was reported today, in a move that was expected to sharpen further the already serious con flict between'the Roman Catholic Church and President Park Chung Hee's Government.

title: PAN AM AIRWAYS HAS LARGER LOSS
description: Pan American World Airways, Inc., continued to be plagued with larger deficits as rising operating costs exceeded increases in revenues, the airline's semiannual unaudited statement disclosed yesterday. The impact of rising fuel prices on operating expenses continued.

title: Cypriote Village a Battle Scene
description: AYLOS EPIKTETOS, Cyprus, July 30Turkish tanks and guns fire from the olive groves while infantrymen dart from foxholes and advance through the dappled shadows cast by the dusty blue leaves.

title: SILVER FUTURES DECLINE BY LIMIT
description: Speculators took quick profits yesterday In silver futures following the sharp runup on Monday, Yesterday, under the impact of the profit taking, silver futures on the Commodity Exchange here dropped the daily 20centanounce limit.

title: Strachan Memos Indicate White House Knew of Spying Months Before Watergate
description: WASHINGTON, July 30The House Judiciary Committee obtained evidence that, months, before the Watergate breakin, White House officials, including H. R. Haldeman, were informed of Republican efforts to spy on Democratic Presidential candidates.

title: Screen: Flesh Gordon
Red Smith
description: The faith that moves mountains abides under the fashionably tailored breastbone of Wallace Gilroy, the oil and gas executive and amateur of the running horse. Neither he nor Mrs. Gilroy found it convenient to attend the Keeneland yearling sales in Lexington, Ky., last week, so they asked the sales manager, Bill Evans, to bid for them on a son of Raise a Native and Gold, Digger, a full brother of the swift Mr. Prospector. Evans got the colt for them, for $625,000, the highest price ever paid anywhere in the world for a yearold animal, Sports vegetable or mineral.

title: President Surrenders 11 Tapes to Sirica
description: WASHINGTON, July 30President Nixon, after a final review of their contents, surrendered today the first group of subpoenaed Watergate tapes that the Supreme Court had ordered him to turn over to Federal District Judge John J. Sirica.

title: British Scan Need for Rules on Insider Dealings
description: LONDON, July 30  An official report on doubtful stock dealings involving a former Lord Mayor of London and his associates, who have been accused of reaping $12million in profits by secret trading in shares of a company they ran, has lent impetus to interest in establishing rules to gosiern insider trading in Britain.

title: IRAN OIL COMPANY SIGNS 2 CONTRACTS
description: TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 The National Iranian Oil Company signed two separate service contracts today with West Germany's Deminex group of companies for the exploration and exploitation of two reputedly oilrich areas near Shiraz and Abadan. The agreement was signed by Manouchehr Eghbal, chairman of the Iranian company, and Guido Schurmeyer for the West German concern.

title: Newcomer Captures Carolina Runoff
description: CHARLESTON, S.C., July 30 Charles D. Ravenel, a political newcomer, tonight defeated Representative William Jennings Bryan Dorn for the Democratic nomination for Governor of South Carolina.

description: TRENTON, July 30 (UPI)The Legislature has completed work on a new system of immunizing schoolchildren that does away with compulsory smallpox vaccinations.

description: OSLO, Norway luly, 30 (AP)Rick Wohlhuter of the United States set a world record in the 1,000meter run today with a clocking of 2 minutes 13.9 seconds in the Martin Luther King Games.The time was 2,1 seconds faster than that set last year in Munich, West Germany, by Danie Malan of South Africa.

description: BALTIMORE, July 30 (UPI)Former Senator George L. Radcliffe, a Maryland Democrat and a strong supporter of President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 96 years old.

description: Oscar R. Gottfried, executive secretary of the Association of Private Hospitals for 40 years until his retirement in 1971 died, Sunday in Doctors Hospital. H6. was 79 years old and lived, at 290 West End Avenue.

title: Books of The Times
description: It's simple to follow the main action of Mark Smith's The Death of the Detective, the third novel by a young writer who teaches English at the University of New Hampshire. A dying Chicago business tycoon named Frazer Farquarson is murdered in the bedroom of his huge Lake Forest mansion. But shortly before his death, he has alerted a network of his associates of the impending foul play, and hardly has his heart stopped beating when one of them  a wealthy, retired detective named Arnold Magnuson  picks up the scent of the killer. During the next 36 hours or so, Magnuson tracks down clues all over the city and its outskirts. But instead of catching up with the killer. he stumbles along a horrifying trail of fresh murders. So predictable are the killer's movements and yet so elusive is his person that soon Magnuson begins to wonder if he himself isn't somehow responsible for the slaughter. Eventually, his very sanity is cast into the balance, and, as you can guess from the novel's title, his life as well.

title: Hunts Point Market, Called Grocer's Dream, Proving Nightmare to Many
description: It's tomato season. A decade ago, farm trucks would be rolling into the Washington Street Market every evening, laden with crimson, tart, sunsweetened tomatoes picked only hours earlier. By morning, they would be on sale in produce stores and on pushcarts.

title: Under Public Scrutiny
description: The experience of the past week should surely have laid to rest the reservations expressed earlier by some members of Congress and the public that live radio and television coverage of the impeachment process would be a dangerous infringement both of Congressional dignity and the rights of the President.

title: $30MILLION EXTRA IS ASKED FOR CON ED
description: ALBANY, July 30 (UPI)A Public Service Commission examiner raised his recommended rate increase for the Consolidated Edison Company by $30million, up to a total of $334,835,000.

title: Nader Group Challenges C.A.B.Head
description: A consumer group affiliated with Ralph Nader asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to disqualify its chairman, Robert D. Timm, from a transAtlantic airlinesubsidy case because of his acceptance of a free weekend trip to Bermuda early last month.

title: Bubble Gum Snapping To the Rescue in Strike
description: Football bubble gum cards will be issued earlier this year as a direct result of the National Football League players strike.

title: Music: Mozartean Styles
description: The pendulum swings as widely in musical performance practice as in hair length, heel height or any other serious aspect of human behavior. Just now, so far as Mozart performance is concerned, pianists are leaning sharply toward light, aristocratically reserved style that stresses clean articulation and a detached touch. The aim is singing line, but one not achieved by means of the blurred legato style that became fashionable in the 19th century.

title: London Stocks Hit Low
description: LONDON, July 30 (Reuters) The London stock market hit a 15year low today, reflecting lack of buyer confidence and lingering doubts about British politics. The Financial Times industrial 30, share index closed 5.8 points down at 242.5, the lowest level the index has reached since August, 1959.

title: Inquiry Into Alleged Kickbacks Spreads to Beame's Campaign
description: The finances of the Beame campaign for Mayor are being examined by Federal investigators in BrooklYn as part of continuing investigation of an alleged political kickback scheme at the Security National Bank, the office of the United States Attorney for the Eastern District confirmed yesterday.

title: Sponsors Suffer Setback on Bill for Farm Hands
description: TRENTON, July 30Sponsors of legislation to aid farm workers in New Jersey said today that they had won a partial victory but lost a big. ger battle in the special session that ended yesterday.
